reviews.review: A bit disappointing. After visiting other Gaudi places in Barcelona, this house was a bit disappointing: much less decorated, less stylish than expected.

Beautiful, fascinating and visionary. A magnificent example of modernist architecture that transcends era and remains as vital now as it did when it was first constructed. Gaudi's mastery is on show from basement to rooftop with wonderful craftsmanship and sheer majesty around every corner.

a must visit to understand Gaudi. you have to see this building from the inside to understand the genius and absolute functionality of Gaudi's designs. So elegant and graceful and innovative and light and practical..pure perfection.

Great on the outside. We amazed by Gaudis building of the Pedrera, the outside was beautiful and so clean. The inside was interesting and the roof was of course the highlight. I would have been fine seeing only the outside, as it is the most amazing part.

Beautiful!. The rooftop is spectacular and quite different from everything I've seen before. There is also a nice museum part and you can visit one of the apartments.
The audioguide is interesting and easy to follow.
I recommend booking online so you won't have to stand in line long! :)
Origins. Loved the tour and Origins show. A must to see when in Barcelona. Light and sound show on the roof was amazing.
Stunning Casa Mila. It was great to tour this building and look at Gaudi's work close up. The unique architecture and use of organic forms was amazing to experience.
Go in the late afternoon!. Beautiful house, great views from Barcelona, if you go in the late afternoon there might not be any lines.
So beautiful. What a masterpiece. It is such a special building, you will never forget it. Can't put it into words - you'll just have to see it.

Star Wars Before It's Time. Very unique venue by Gaudi. Rooftop seems like a inspiration for Star wars characters. Open apartment shows detail of Gaudi's design. Layout and trimmings are incredible. Audio box tour (included) very helpful. Go early to avoid crowds. Allow about 90 minutes for your visit. Buy your ticket well in advance.
Paulina. An amazing architecture, especially the top of the house. You have a beautiful view on Barcelona from it.
Great night tour. No crowd. The lights display at the roof top is worth to see and the cava at the end was a nice touch.Book ahead at their website and choose the night tour, it's way better.
Gaudi was Talented. Gaudi was certainly a talented man. Very interesting building. So ahead of his time. Not good for a hot day.
Very intresting. Not sure what we were expecting, but it was very intresting and a very worthwhile visit. Its like no other building so difficlut to describe; hence you must visit if in Barcelona

Impressive and beautiful. Fully recommended!. You can hear/read comments about "La pedrera" but you need to see it to really appreciate it! All of it was art. Goudi Style is incredible and I remember one of the things that I heard from the audio: "Nothing on Gaudi Style is done because of nothing" " All his works are meaningful". One of the most interesting things is that you can have an audio guide to follow all the visit/tour in every language.The Price varied depending of the age of the visitor. For students it is a good option as it is not expensive and this visit is a must to see.

Great views. Was well worth the visit just to see the views from the roof top. Great architecture from gaudi. Roof top was my favourite and the apartment was quite interesting. Bit expensive but still glad i visited.

Go to meet Gaudi!. I have visited the Pedrera on the 27th october, at the first time of the day, with just a few people. The elevator gave us the color of the visit...weird noise, are we arrived? Smiling around and the door was finally opening on a surprising roof with so strange figures cut in the cloudy sky, with sometimes a ray of sunshine...It's amazing to deambulate in the attic and the Mila's appartement is intersting. Don't miss this visit! Don't miss Gaudi's crazy imagination!I went to the Palau de la musica catalana in the same day to listen to a concert. What a magic place also!I hope the one who has shared these emotions will read these lines.

Don't spend your money here. Where there at night at the "show": All you get to do is to get up on the attic and they explain how it would have looked like. Then you get outside and get to see a "movie" about nature on the sculptures.The exterior of the building is the coolest but that you can see from the street. Inside - there is nothing spectacular.

Amazing design, like nothing I have ever seen.. Wonderful "take your time" tour with audio, no rush. Start at the roof and be amazed at the detail!! Everything has a story, including the chimney and roof vent covers!! Absolutely amazing what Gaudi thought of 100 years ago!! Be amazed by his design ideas and what is so appropriate and desired in homes today! Stunning!
Must see. The roof is just amazing. The way Gaudi designed everything with nature and functionality in mind is simply breathtaking.

Witness Gaudi's masterpiece up close here. Definitely worth a visit and is a must see when visiting Barcelona as it is one of the sights to see. We made the mistake of not booking tickets online so we arrived around 4pm on a Saturday and there was a bit of a queue which we had to stand in for around 30 mins. So book your tickets online! Upon entry, you get the audioguide you are taken up in a lift to the very top where you get to see Gaudi's work up close. Simply fascinating and will always be a masterpiece. As it was early October and late in the afternoon, the sun wasn't very hot and it was just perfect for taking pictures.You then have to go down the stairs visiting each floor to see the inside of the structure, where there are exhibits of models of his other works, the history of Barcelona and La Pedrera and also what items and animals in nature inspired Gaudi's work. For 20.50 euros for individual entry it is not cheap but is worth a visit.

Not to be missed, well worth the ticket!. The exterior of this Gaudi designed building is spectacular but get a ticket and roam the interior & incredible roof top full of extraordinary sculpture and fabulous views , it's an absolute wonderment!

Whoa, beyond your wildest imagination.... Yes, Gaudi was a genius, we know that intellectually. But until you see his works uncles and in person, its hard to feel this on an emotional level. La Pedrera is stunning. Fluid and supine, unlike any building you have ever been in. It is a work of stunning genius and should not be missed when in Barcelona.

A gaudi masterpiece. A must see while visiting Barcelona and another example of his brilliance in everything that he did. The visit will take about an hour or so to see everything, things are explained in your language as you walk around. There is also a period apartment that you can walk thru to see the luxury of the time and how every little detail was thought about. About 2 blocks away is another one of his buildings as well.

You must visit here!. A stand out visit while in Barcelona. Go early as it gets busier as the day goes on. We didn't pre book, good idea and possibly cheaper? Audio guide very helpful for background, visual experience stunning!

Best architecture in town. Best experience for Gaudi's art. The terrace is fantastic as well as the interiors. Unlike Casa Batllo' this place is not too crowded thus largely more enjoyable. The furniture is particularly interesting too.

Night Tour - A Must!. for the last night of our trip, we decided to the do the night tour. This cost €34 each but worth the money. You can only enter a night tour at certain times depending on the language you speak. You start off in the main entrance with an introduction to Gaudi and the building. There is then the option to take the stairs or lift (the stairs are very tiring!) to the attic. In the attic there are models of Gaudi's work, allowing you to see his concepts and designs. Our tour guide was great and very informative. Then you are up on the roof for the spectacular light show, there are only about 30 on each tour so you get a good view of the lights. We were then told that the tour would finish up in the basement for drinks and snacks. We were allowed to walk round half of the roof on our way down which was great, and we were pretty much just left to it! In the end we were the last people left on the roof. The views of Barcelona are great!Once downstairs, there is choice of champagne, juice or water and some snacks. The tour lasted approximately 90 minutes. This was great to do for our last night in Barcelona and we were pleased to have chosen the night tour instead of the day tour.
Gaudi experience. Another Gaudi masterpiece which shouldn't be missed. Different from Casa Batllo and just as good in its own right. The attic and its arches are awesome!

Amazing - you have to visit. We were slightly unsure if this was worth the 20+ Euros entrance fee but it proved to be worth it. An amazing building with great views from the top and lots of interesting architectural history.

Beautiful Gaudi. Able to visit this building at night after a night out for Tapas. Beautifully lit to accent the shape of this masterpiece. Also Tours available inside with admission. Its amazing this was built in 6 years.
Amazing building. I booked this tour in advance, skip the line, and it was worth it. The house is spectacular, all curvy, design ahead of its time, the terrace was amazing. Worth the visit.

Great free audioguide. We enjoyed it. Online prebooking seems to be preferred but we got in with a short line up and got immediate access. May not always be like that though. Was about 20 euro per adult. Audioguide was free. Tour was good and fairly long, felt like we got good value and took up most of our afternoon. Interesting.

A real delightful surprise. Fascinating architecture and planning; not only the property itself but insights provided into Gaudi's interest in the natural world and its structures. Spent a lot of time here after not expecting beforehand to be here for more than an hour. Great views from the roof (where you can easily spend an hour)

After this one you will want to see all of his (Guell's) works!!. I thought that this would just be another interesting Architectural building to look at. Not the case. The audio visual work that has gone into this is just the best ever. We got here late and paid the extra $7 euros to bypass the line. The line had over 150 people when we got there at noon. Way worth the money to go right in!!The work of this Architect/ artist was 100 years or more ahead of his time. See this on and all of the others you can fit into your schedule.
A visit to a Gaudí masterpiece. Every person with interest in architecture, design, arts and construction would highly appreciate the genius that is Toni Gaudí.

Night is Best. Do the night tour and book in advance. This is a building tour after hours with only about 30 people so you can relax and enjoy. The best part is the light show on the roof. A phantasmagoria of constantly changing lights and pictures are projected against the amazing structures. Sounds Disney contrived, but it works. You also get a night view of the city. A highlight of our 6 days in Barcelona.
Las Pedrera. This attraction allowed one to closely examine the details without hordes of other people around, it was a more intimate experience than the Sagrada Familia.

Architecture at it's finest. One can only imagine living in these apartments. Being on the roof is the experience of a lifetime, and so dreamlike. Feels ever so surreal. The attic tour is amazing. Highly recommend going around sunset....magnificent!

interesting but not the best. So it is still Gaudi and therefore still worth seeing. however compared to the Palau Guell and the Casa Batllo, a lot less to see for quite a steep price. the roof top is great, the view of the city and the cheminee tops are fantastic
Another must. Gaudi's work is amazing, a must visit when in Barcelona. He is an amazing architect, and designer. Well worth the money.

Very interesting. A really interesting introduction to Gaudi. I would suggest visiting here before the Sagrada as the museum part of the tour is a good introduction. Also the Sagrada is so impressive you might be a little underwhelmed by this. Definitely book and I think a must for a trip to Barcelona.

Perfect summer plan. It's the perfect place to star a busy day discovering Barclona. It's also a must see when you come to the city. I've already been a couple times before and it never ceases to amaze me.

Worth it. Yes, it's expensive, yes the queues are long (go around 10am on a weekday after purchasing advance tickets online and you'll fly right in), but it's absolutely worth it. Just walking on the famous undulating roof is worth the steep price of admission. If you're not a fan of Goudy, or you just want a small sampling, this is the one Goudy home you must see. As an extra benefit, in the attic are models and photos of many of the other Goudy homes and monuments in the city, so this is a bit of a one-stop shop for all things Goudy.

Absolutely beautiful. After the Sagrada, this was my second favorite place in Barcelona. I think we spent about half an hour to one hour only on the rooftop admiring Gaudi's ingenuity but also a panorama of Barcelona. The attic serves as a museum that guides you through most of Gaudi's work and thought process.Then at a lower floor you can visit an apartment also designed by Gaudi.Simply a wonderful experience!

Views are great. A not to be missed adventure. Gaddis last commercial venture of 14 apartments with roof top visit for great views. Walk through one of the unique apartments and maybe. Lunch at the ground floor resturant, although a little expensive as this neighborhood I has the best, up scale shops

Work of Art!. La Pedrera is still a functioning apartment/office building so you get to see sections of it including the rooftop, which is a work of art in itself. What I learned is it is purposeful art, everything about Gaudi's designs have a purpose which is what makes it all so intriguing. You also see a full apartment displayed as it would have been 100 years ago which showcases Gaudi's forward thinking and planning so well. This is again an attraction well worth seeng if you have the time.

Absolutely beautiful . This was our first stop in Barcelona as our youngest wanted to see the roof. It is beautiful throughout with access to the courtyard, an apartment and right across this amazing roof. Cue a love affair for the whole family with Gaudi which made the next couple of days activities an absolute breeze to planIt wasn't cheap for a family of four (a 12 yr old is now attracting adult prices), and there was a more expensive option to do a "day and night ticket" Autumn means early evenings though and it got dark while we were there giving us the chance to see it lit up. We arrived about 5.45pm while it was still a daytime ticket, I think it changed at 6pm.

Such an interesting visit. We stopped here on our way to Casa Battlo but were so interested in the displays and videos which were really well presented and very informative that we spent most of the afternoon here. The roof was amazing, as was the apartment, but the section detailing Gaudi's life achievements had us hooked. Highly recommended and much shorter queues than other Barcelona attractions.
Nice Views. Perfect Views! The only issue is that teres always a lot of people in the qoue and its a bit expensive for the parts that they let you see. Perfect for who enjoys nice viewings

Wow, you must go here!. The façade of Casa Mila (La Pedrera) is amazing but nothing compared to the internal décor or the roof top chimneys.Included in the price is audio which is brilliant. You get to see so many levels of the house, the attic, family rooms, servants qtrs. & the amazing roof.Our 10 yr old son absolutely loved it as did we. We actually went on the roof twice. The views from there are amazing

Very unique building!. The building design is ingenious! No load bearing columns/walls so one can renovate their apartments as they please. Of course we cannot see how the current residents did up their place but the rest of the building is breathtaking in itself.
Gaudi creation. Amazing, unique architecture. Barcelona if filled with Gaudi creations & this one is very unique. Well worth seeing.

It's worth a visit- even for the exterior. We have been to Barcelona before and did the full Gaudi visit, but as we were here for an afternoon and evening, we decided to go past some of the nearby attractions and we enjoyed it again (see the photo). We did not have time for an inside tour (which we did several years ago), which I highly recommend.

A Treat indeed - looks small BUT huge inside - and fantastic roof architecture. Great Place to visit - his home is unique and quirky. Well worth the entrance fee. It looks small from the street - but incredible inside. Quite a emotional place that take you back in time - and the attic is beautiful. The ROOF terrace is a joy and great place for ''selfies''.

Amazing. We went about an hour and a half before closing and bought tickets at the door with no queue, which was perfect timing to see the sunset from the incredible rooftop. The audio guide was great and it was fascinating to see the apartment fitted out with historically accurate furniture and accessories. Loved it!

well worth a visit. If you have limited time I would suggest doing Casa Batllo instead, however la Pedrera is worth a visit. the highlight was definitely walking around on the rooftop and taking in the sights. The audio tour was pretty interesting and enjoyed learning more about Gaudi and his inspiration.

Interesting Tour. I liked everything I saw especially in the apartment ! By purchasing tickets online you avoid entry lines . Elevator lines to the top went fast .Rooftop views were pretty amazing . Very informative tour for teens and up.

Family holiday. Queue about 20 minutes to buy tickets. Long queue to get the lift. They did offer the stairs but they did not say that it was a big climb. Very interesting to see and totally amazing in design. In beautiful condition. Clean and well presented. The head set audio was excellent, clear to hear and informative. I left feeling I was well informed. Visited in October and inside and out was very warm.

One of Barcelona's stars. In my mind, Barcelona's best asset is its relaxed, welcoming atmosphere. I would definitely recommend staying outside as much as possible, but for la pedrera I would make an exception. It is among Barcelona's (or, the world's) architectural wonders and the guided tour is pretty educational. Buy tickets online in advance, in particular in the holiday season!

Stunning.... This is magnificent..even if the queue to get up onto the roof is a tad tedious...The design work on the roof is staggering. The chimneys, the walk round, the views, everything is amazing. Then you descend through the building, seeing glimpses of Gaudi's design elements, models and furniture. Then further down, through the recreated period apartments. Be sure to book ahead, so as not to miss this..
Great choice. A few years ago I came to Barcelona but did not go in La Pedrera. You can buy the ticket at the entrance. It worth it really does! It is a masterpiece!

Excellent display of Gaudi's work. The building is full of surprises, from the colours in the light well, and the extravagant structures on the roof, to the excellent series of models and illustrations of Gaudi's methods and achievements in the attic. An excellent audio guide is included. The sample furnished apartment is interesting but not the highlight. Visit is expensive, and is slow when busy because you have to queue for the elevator to get to the roof.

La Pedrera (Casal Mila) was AWESOME!. We enjoyed a private tour of La Pedrera and learned so much about Antonio Gaudi and his inspiration for all the wonderful architecture he designed. This was a gorgeous place and I now understand the true genius of Gaudi. Visit this for sure!

Unique and different home. We did a night tour of La Pedrera and it was very interesting. A little long-winded and the tour guides definitely gush about Gaudi and fanboy over him, but if you can separate yourself from that, La Pedrera is an experience. People currently live there, so parts are off limits, but the areas that are available are really amazing!

Spectacular building. La Pedrera is well worth visiting to experience something of the real Barcelona and the work of Antoni Gaudi. The audio tour was very interesting, but the real highlights were the opportunity to walk over the roof of the building and enjoy both the architectural features close up, and the views of the city, the hills and the sea. The furnished apartment was also fascinating and beautifully displayed. Cost of entry was about twenty euros, which I thought was expensive when paying, but having finished the tour, I can honestly say that it was money well spent.
Incredible property. This is another amazing property designed by Antonio Gaudi. The property was amazing with wonderful attention to thought and details. See for yourself the genius of Gaudi.

Gaudi is a genius. A great example of Gaudi's work - this building is still used today as office and living space. Gaudi's use of materials is amazing and this building is a great example of all of his techniques. Definitely take the self-guided tour with audio, which lets you experience each room at your own pace. The building includes a number of exhibits detailing Gaudi's life, together with many examples of his work.

worth the money. go for a audio guided visit and its enough. great experience, you do need to wait for a group. there's 2 lines- one for groups and other for individuals- make sure that you don't wait at the wrong one
Unique. An incredible building and unique artistic, historic and cultural landmark of Barcelona. Highly recommended !
For the art/architecture lover. One of the best audio tours I have experienced. You can tell how pride is Barcelona of his genius Antoni Gaudi.

The furnished apartment is superb. I visited La Pedera on the same day as Casa Batllo and I have to say that the latter was a more engaging experience. The audio guide for La Pedera is rather more basic and the need to queue for the lift at the beginning of the tour was tedious. Having said that, this is an extraordinary building illustrating the range of Gaudi's mastery of engineering design and his artistic flair. The roof is perhaps the most unusual example of Gaudi's work, but take care - the stepped design can be hazardous and one visitor had a fall whilst I was there.The attic beneath the roof is also intriguing with the succession of catenary arches giving the impression of walking through a giant rib cage!Setting aside the overall design concept I found the period furnishing of the sample apartment set the context of genteel wealth of the era in which Gaudi was working. I'm not sure that the apartment would be easy to live in, but that's a retrospective view of course, and ignores the benefit of having servants.

A fantastic house!. Gaudi's design of the house, and particularly the roof, is imaginative and unique. It was amazing to walk around the roof. And the display of his chairs on the second floor is worth the price of admission.

Stunning! I am converted.. After a previous trip to Barna I just didn't "get" Gaudí. After a wonderful visit to this visionary building I now see the error of my ways. Pay the extra €7 to skip the queue and marvel at a wonderfully curated tour.

Fabulous roof top. The roof top with its chimneys and exhaust towers are so creative they are compelling to look at, the 'attic' is very interesting with its construction and the description of how the pillars hold up the construction and not the walls. But the floor with the residence and shop are crowded and not that interesting.

A pure whimsical delight!. As a fan of architecture I just had to visit this place and was not disappointed. The roof-top terrace is a true masterpiece of playful design and function. I'd recommend purchasing the premium tickets for your visit. For a few euros more you bypass the waiting lines and don't have to book a specific time. You also get special quick access.

Fascinating. I loved La Pedrera. The outside is strange, the inside and roof, extraordinary! It was only spoilt by the other tourists simply having to take photos of themselves against every item on the roof. Good displays in side, especially in the attic bit. The apartment is a recreation of a 20th Century Bourgeois family.

Unique living space in Barcelona by the famous architect, Gaudi. The exterior of this unique 'apartment house' is very "Gaudi" and quite delightful to tour. The various architectural touches on the roof as well as the views were amazing. Touring the attic with lots of information about Gaudi was also quite interesting. Then touring the apartment topped off a unique experience. You must envy the current residents in this important historic building. A great tour to learn more about Gaudi and his talents and vision.
Magnificent architecture!. Wonderful example of Gaudi work. Must go to the rooftop. Most unusual!Attic also very different with informative exhibits. Tour of an apartment also interesting. I

Gaudi brilliance. Would I live there ? No . Did I love it. Yes. The roof top is incredible. The attic originall used for resident storage has vaulted arches worthy of a cathedral cloister . The show appartments are for their time both light and airy. With oddly shaped rooms and revolutionary features, ensuite and basement garage. The engineering of the building is way ahead of its time. The façade Gaudi, brilliant and insane at he same time.

Last tour of the night. On a whim, before a dinner at Gusto, my amazing wife bought us 10:20 PM tickets for La Pedrera. It was awesome. After a quick intro on the first floor where they discussed some of the building's early history - first residential elevator and underground car port in the city for example, we went up to the "attic" which was amazing. It is a must see. Afterwards, there was a totally non-cheesy laser light show on the roof in the open air. Finally, we sipped champagne in the courtyard. Yes, it was expensive, but it was a perfect way to end the day. We would both highly recommend it. The guide was saying that there are still four, rent stabilized (€ 300 a month) private residences in the building and the rest are corporate offices. Pretty weird for a privately (bank) owned UNESCO world heritage site. The tour was very small and intimate (10 people) and the guide was excellent and answered my many questions with a smile and informed responses. Remember to hit the helpful button if this was of any use. Total tour time was about an hour.

Nice attraction to visit . Visited this site with my boys 9 and 14 and to my surprise they enjoyed it. The staff was very friendly and helpful. The free audio tour was a nice offer with the tour. Great appreciation of how ahead of his time Gaudi was in architecture. Not suitable for babies in strollers.

Wonderful Gaudi work. This is a remarkable example of Gaudi's architectural genius. The admission fee is high: I suspect that the owners of this building are making a lot more out of it than Gaudi ever did. But the building is spectacular.

Nature transformed into a living space. Gaudi's "La Pedrera" is a true challenge to any construction and building philosophy, saying corners need to be 90 degrees and sharp edges. Gaudi truly adapt the shape and fractional displacements of nature into advanced building technology -making everything you explore outside as well as inside, surprisingly interesting and you start to wonder, why this approach to building technology is not applied more often…even today. This Master Piece of Gaudi is a "MUST SEE" for sure.

Best Gaudi Museum!. On our last day in Barcelona we dropped into La Pedrera, or Casa Mila as they also call it. We were told that this is the best of the Gaudi houses to visit as it is complete and you get to see the furniture that he built as well. The roof top walk is very interesting as you see much of Passeig de Gracia from it and many of the other fine buildings in Barcelona. That city has the finest collection of various styles of architecture I have ever seen. The Gaudi works alone are worth the trip.

Gaudi's amazing creation -- sensational architecture. While Sagrada Familia understandably get lots of attention, this gem is a must see. You get a better understanding of Gaudi's work. Many fascinating details and the overall ambience is entrancing. Get there early to minimize crowds. The whole area around the building is filled with treasures and is very much worth exploring.

Amazing night tour. We took the option of the day and night tour of this amazing building. The day tour allowed you to go round at your own pace and view the Gaudi exhibits in the attic, the roof with stunning views and the furnished apartment. All stunning and a feast for the eyes. The night time tour is guided and our guide was very knowledgeable and passionate about the subject. There was an introduction to the building and to Gaudi himself, followed by a tour of the exhibits and then on to the roof for a stunning light show. Took my breath away. Then you go back to the courtyard for drinks and nibbles. This is a beautiful building and well worth the time and money, which was great value.

Another masterpiece. It is not enough to just view the outside as it is only when ones moves inside especially with a guide that the details and thought process of Gaudi can be understood. His ideas were extraordinary
Really remarkable architecture. worth the price of the tour. It's a bit confusing to use the acoustiguide, but it is important to try.
Pretty Good. This place had a lot to offer, found the entry price a bit steep. Best to visit this place on a sunny day, so that you can enjoy the rooftop.
Night tour. Fantastic experience. V interesting & lovely people. The light show was excellent and the whole thing felt unrushed. The guides are very passionate about the place.

The Gaudi Effect. Gaudi was commissioned by the Mila family and he managed to create this astonishing piece of architecture. The most beautiful area in my opinion is the roof as the chimney designs are breathtaking. I also admire the work done by Gaudi where he studied the shapes of animal skeletons and applied it in his work which is also found at Casa mila Definitely worth a visit

Fascinatinh. We visited this must see Gaudi creation in our first evening in Barcelona. We booked tickets in advance and were able to walk straight in. The audio guide was informative and the roof with the amazing chimneys was a highlight! The apartment was fantastic. I would say that Casa Batllo was more emersive and complete in terms of Gaudi's work. Still superb!
My favourtie. Amazing place to visit and I highly recommend to everybody. It is a MUST SEE. I will visit again on my return to Barcelona.

Very special. Interesting experience - tremendous buiding. It was also nice to see one of the apartments in the state that it was in Gaudi's time.We got tickets after only a very short waiting time which was a pleasant surprise
Unbelievable. Go early and start at the top. You can hardly believe that an outdoor rooftop can be this fascinating, and have such a great view.

Amazing experience . First I thought the price was too expensive for an architectural place (payed way less for greater museums) but after minutes realized it was worth the money. Audio guide is free and comes with a ticket. I would say it is mandatory to take it because the experience is definitely not full without it. It is amazing and one of top 3 things to visit in Barcelona!

Different architecture!!!. It was a nice visit I would say; but, different architecture and interior design/concept. It was completely different from other places that I've visited, maybe very interesting to others. You should try to find out!

Fantastic but go early. This is without doubt the best place to fully appreciate the genius of Gaudi. The self-tour audio guide is excellent. You start at the top on the roof terrace, which is amazing, and you work your way down. Some of the rooms have been kept the way they were when it was built and small model explain the clever design details. Go ealy to beat the queues and the groups

Wonderful experience . I think this was the best of all the Gaudi sights. They give headsets to wear. Numbers weren't always easy to spot but loved the roof, attic, apartment plus all the extra architectural info. Gaudi was amazing. Loved that he recycled things here & at Park Guell. Impressive.

Nice Night Show. My friends and I did the night tour. The tour guide was knowledgeable and we weren't allow to take photos with flash on in the front lobby as it may affect the paint of the art. The light show was an added bonus as it highlighted the architecture. Gaudi's art was definitely well preserved. We even got a little treat at the end: champagne and some dessert.
Amazing. Do purchase timed tickets in advance. Quite fascinating as are other buildings nearby. Lovely to be able to visit one of the apartments.

A Gaudi must.. Beautiful building you must see if you're on the Gaudi circuit. Access to the inner courtyard, stunning rooftop, attic with exposed brick arches and Gaudi exhibition, then the fascinating appt below restored to period detail. The self guide audio tour is good and included in the price. Even kept my 12 and 15 yr old interested.

One of the top Gaudi homes to visit. This was the only house we reserved in advance. We got into the other 2 we visited right away at the end of Sept. As with the other 2, the outside, inside and the roof are sights to behold and you will never forget. The views are spectacular and you will remember Gaudi's name and legacy forever.

Great visit. Kids loved this (but keep close on the roof as some low walls) amazing shapes and textures and visually stunning with great views of city.bit expensive for entry but less busy than Sagrada familia. Would be good to see all the floors.

Amazing. It's an apartment building, shopping mall, and more. The audio guide is great. Book this in advance. You must choose a set date and time. It's in an awesome area. Give it at least 1 to 1.5 hours to do it justice. Lots of awesome photo ops.You start on the roof and then make your way down through the building. Lots of stairs!

An essential visit when in Barcelona . It's hard to visit Barcelona without getting drawn in to the world of genius artist Antoni Gaudi and his fantastical creations. Even if you think you have little interest in architecture or art, his unique creations will have you enthralled. This is house is on the list of the top 5 Gaudi sites in town, as well as the Familia Sagrada, Parc Guell, Casa Botlla and Palace Guell.We visited mid-afternoon on a Wednesday and there was no queue for tickets, but it may be best to book ahead at weekends or holidays to avoid unnecessary queues. We spent around 90 minutes here and it cost around 20 euros as an adult. For this you get an audio guide with headphones to take you round the house. The queue for the lift to the roof terrace was long so we took the stairs - 8 flights! - so if you're not in good shape, wait! The roof terrace is what people primarily go to see. Roman helmets replace chimney covers, undulating floors fold away around you and hobbit holes bridge sections. Unique, colourful and quite bonkers - it's Gaudi at his best. Beware that if it's raining or has rained recently the terrace is closed because it's slippery under foot. You don't want to miss the terrace and luckily the rain in Spain falls... not too often!The rest of the visit includes a detailed look at the mechanics of his designs, common themes he incorporates as well as his ergonomic furniture. You also get to explore a furnished apartment, which is fascinating.Fir culture in digestible chunks you can't go far wrong.
Almost unreal structure . La Pedrera was the third Gaudi creation we visited. It did not disappoint! The man was an amazing architect. His vision was amazing. Another must see in Barcelona.
Amazing place. Went to this place on a hot day. The architecture is absolutely breath taking. I loved the roof. Gaudi really was a genius !

Interesting. Interesting concept and architecture. It's worth an hour. We had ordered the premium 'anytime' tickets so got right in. No line and they give you a little souvenir book and take you right in. The staff was very helpful and professional.

IMPRESSIVE!. Amazing, beautiful apartments building located at a corner of the “Paseo de Gracia”. Built in 1912 by Gaudi Architect, with a modern and different architecture from the period it was built in. A Barcelona´s icon. Totally recommended to visit it, must enter to view the interior too.

amazing rooftop, average indoors. the rooftop was incredible and by itself is worth the ticket.the interior is cool too but not as impressive and Gaudi-crazy as I expected. I liked the audio-guide.we booked the tickets is advanced - I recommend to do so because there was an endless line of people waiting to buy a ticket and get in and we just passed it happily :)
A nice house to visit. We visited the Haus Mila and styed here for 2 hours. It was nice and really impressive. We like this house and can recommend it for other gursts

This Rocks!. This is a must see as it it one of Gaudi's iconic works. The ironwork near the property are also of interest. BTW La Pedrera means "the rocks" as contemporaries used it as a derogatory description and it is now commonly known as La Predera.

Expensive for what you see. This building costs 20.50e to enter and includes an audio guide. I very much enjoyed what I saw, but I don't feel what I saw was worth the money. Most of the building is still occupied by private residents, so you get to see only one apartment, decorated as it would have been when it was first built, and the roof. The rooves at Casa Batlo and Palau Guell are more impressive in my opinion. If you can only afford to see one Gaudi building, I wouldn't choose this one.

Gaudi Designed home. La Pederas is a modernist building, the last civil work designed by architect Antoni Gaudí the designer and builder of the Sagrada Familia. The apartment house is a study in details. everything from the building itself to the furniture down to the to the door knobs and drawer pulls was designed and supervised by Gaudi himself. I was particularly amazed by the numerous balcony railings..each different and designed to accent that particular apartment. Don't miss the chimneys on the roof, each taking a different sculptural and mosaic approach.

Well worth a walk up the Passeig de Gracia. The Pedrera is one of the 'pilgrimage' sites on the 'Camino de Antoni Gaudi i Cornet'. The roof with its chimneys in the form of freely drawn mythical creatures and view of the tower of the Sagrada Familia in the distance provides great opportunities to observe Gaudy's exterior architectural embellishments close-up as well as have a great view over the Eixample district of Barcelona, so take your camera up there with you. Underneath the roof is the attic space which houses original models and drawings but above all allows the visitor to see the extraordinary form of the underneath supports to the Pedrera's roof. As many others have said before, it really is like being in the belly of a whale. An extraordinary feeling. Further down t he building is an apartment preserved, decorated and furnished as it would have been 100 years ago shorty after the Pedrera was first occupied. This gives insights into middle class life in Barcelona at the time, but more particularly demonstrates Gaudy's ability to use his creativity in order to enhance even the mundane in everyday living.

Spectacular!. This place is amazing. As well as the great views inside, when you reach the roof, you get great views of the city too.It's one of my favourite buildings in the whole city. So much to see, you can take the tour in your own time and explore exactly what you want to see. You have to visit!

Great Tour and The Origins Show. I thoroughly recommend the audio guide tour and also the Origins show. We did them one after the other and it was a perfect way to be spend an evening. I was worried that the audioguide tour and talk that accompanied the Origins show would be too similar (they cover the almost all the same rooms) but actually the information from Origins complemented the other really well. The glass of cava at the end was a bonus!
One of Gaudis best. This man was a genius and greatly ahead of his time. This site is an excellent example of his meticulous work.

Whimsically beautiful apartment design. We arrived early on a Saturday morning - EARLY IS RECOMMENDED! The crowds were light and it was easy to get around in La Padrera. Audio devices made it easy to get around and understand what Caudi did in creating this masterpiece. Many of the apartments were occupied by owners and we were able to get glimpses of their lifestyles. Many details of the exterior, interior and rooftop sculpture garden were delightful and whimsical. We loved the people like "hoodoos" covering vents through the roof. The structural arches below the roof were practical and amazing. The walk through the "museum apartment" was a delight.

Must visit. Casa Milla has some insane views from the rooftop . I loved it . The architecture is stunning ; you just have to watch a little closer and some images will just appear in front of you , like a mask from a knight , but i don't want to spoil it , come and see. La Pedrera can be visited by night as well, with an amazing light show, so even if you will visit it by day , by night it will be different, maybe magical. Beside the rooftop there is a museum , a walk through history how people used to live , but there is a little history of the master himself , Antonio Gaudi, so it definitely worth visiting and hearing how he made this piece of art .

The house that Gaudi's built. Architecture is the signature of Barcelona, and Gaudi is its Magic Prince. Wealthy families would pay him to project their wealth through distinctive design. They sure got it, even if they occasionally didn't appreciate it. Functional beauty, in a quirky way, this makes a wonderful prescheduled visit. Consider a visit in the evening with a light show on the roof garden

Amazing . We didn't book this but instead arrived at 0930 ahead of the queues . Words can't describe the brilliance of the man in what is effectively a block of flats .One tip with the audio tour is look carefully for the numbers , I missed a few

Extraordinary!. Much has been said about the house itself, and especially about its amazing rooftop, and it's all well deserved. But in addition to the house itself, the exhibits explaining Gaudi's revolutionary architectural and construction techniques were extremely interesting. the perfect trilogy to understand Gaudi and fully appreciate him as a genius is to visit this house, Sagrada Familia and Parc Guell.
Beautiful but expensive . Beautiful place wonderful architecture nice service the view from the terrace is amazing but the ticket is expensive according to my opinion...

Interesting piece of history and architecture . Worth a visit, we pre booked which gets you straight on. fascinating place and good tour showing history and architecture, interesting also because people live there, influence pf Gaudi on this building and Barcelona generally is well explained
Awesome Gaudi. Casa Mila was fabulous. Great education opportunity about Gaudi's architecture influence on Barcelona. It is a little expensive, but worth it. Best to reserve a timed entry in advance.

A highlight of the trip. I would recommend purchasing tickets online before arriving. We opted for the premium tickets (only slightly more than standard) and were impressed with the service that came with it. We skipped all the lines and it was fuss-free. What an amazing place to visit!

Must Visit Gaudi Masterpiece. Like everything created by Gaudi, this place will blow your mind! Although you are only allowed to visit the courtyard, rooftop, attic & one apartment it is well worth the effort and time/cost. The views from the roof are fantastic and there is so much information that I can't wait to go back on a sunnier day than when I last visited. The gift shop on the way out is filled with an assortment of interesting books that go beyond art and travel. I found great gifts for friends and family from toddler age to teenagers to my mom!

Beautiful and so intriguing . I actually loved la pedrera (even more that casa battlo) but my best friend wouldn't necessarily agree with me. I just thought the roof was insane! It just once again showed Gaudi's amazingly talented mind blowing work. I also really enjoyed the guided tour with the media devices. This allowed me to repeat certain sections I wanted to hear again and it was easy to use. Loved la pedrera! It really explained Gaudi's work and thinking of the building. Very educational. Loved it!!!
Amazing. Such an interesting roof to see! I was dissapointed by the queues and price but the roof top was amazing and seeing the work up close was worth it
A must see attraction in Barcelona. Make sure you pre-book and do the Origins English Day & Night booking - well worth it for the light and sound show and more! Amazing place to visit !
Under the sea theme. With the ceiling inside looking like the sand under the sea I can only imagine the mind of Gaudi and what he was thinking when he drew his first of La Pedrera - amazing

Best of Gaudi houses!. So much of his work is in this one magnificent house! Do not miss the rooftop, with it's sculptures that inspired George Lucas's Stormtroopers. The audio tour was perfect and the gift shop was beautiful.
Incredible! . To me, the this building impresses most from the outside; the roof is also in another world. However it is worth paying the money to go inside.

La Pedrera evening experience. We took a night tour at Gaudi's Casa Mila. Our tour stared at 9pm. You take a journey around Antoni Gaudi's marvelous building, learn how he drew inspiration from nature. Then you enjoy a dramatic rooftop light show emblazoned on Gaudi's distinct spiralling chimneys. You end this tour with glass of Cava!
Another Gaudi work of art!. Antonin Gaudi had a fantastic mind....and was extremely creative. This is a MUST SEE in Barcelona. The roof alone is worth the price of admission!

A Must See when you are in Barcelona!. You will see the work of the genius Gaudi. It is a must see when in Barcelona! I would highly recommend buying your tickets on line and skipping the line. Headsets are provided.
Amazing views from the roof. So glad we got to go inside, it's as interesting on the inside as the outside. The apartment is especially worth a tour.
Amazing House. The house is a must see. We really seeing more of Gaudi's work.The audio guide provides excellent information.
Another Gaudi treat.. Barcelona is so fortunate to have these houses by Gaudi. This is magnificent. Very worth the time and money. A great experience.
Amazing building and excellent staff. We have enjoyed every corner of the building; audio-guide is very useful; the view from the terraces is amazing and staff helpful and professional.

Beautiful and unusual. Don't miss this amazing piece of architecture. You won't see anything like it. Gaudis organic signature style is so creative and clever. The building has a bit of everything, history, architecture, education, culture, views and a stunning roof terrace.

A must see Gaudi attraction. Whether you are interested in Gaudi or not, this building is a must see while in Barcelona. The rooftop sights are iconic and the information on Gaudi in the attic area gives a really good insight into his work and its development. The green line metro stops just outside but it is also easily walkable from Placa de Catalunya

Fantastic. Recommended for viewing and making photographs in daytime and nighttime. Night show is very nice. Interesting stories by the guide available in many languages. Great looking building from inside and outside. Roof and the attic are amazing.

Interesting arquitectonic solution. The building is an interesting solution to the needs of the family that contracted Gaudi. The roof is really amazing, and has a lot religious meanings. If you visiting Barcelona don't miss the visit. The ticket is rather expensive.
really interesting visit. Particularly loved the fully furnished apartment, and the balconies made from recycled twisted metal. Fascinating insight into Gaudi's design
Worth a visit. I loved La Pedrera I went in October around 630pm so took pictures in daylight by 730pm it was dark so I then took pictures in the evening.

Gaudi's Magic on display in Real Time. A house must really be interesting to be worthy of a museum. And this building hits it. The first main point of interest is the fact the building retains its integrity after a century of scrutiny. It remains an appartment building occupied by tenants, save for one unit, reserved as a showcase for Gaudi's genius, and a witness to gracious living in 1900. The most interesting part of the whole thing is the roof, a veritable sculpture of tile and terrace and chimney and air-vents. The views are terrific. Next, the renovated attic, with its beautifully original arches meandering around the volume above the appartments. Here we find the museum part of the building. The audio guide is a must. Next, one floor down to the model appartment, where period furniture and fixtures show what life was like in the 1900's. Visitor alert here. When buying tickets we were offered a free photograph at the end of the visit. Sure enough, a pleasant young lady snapped a couple of shots in front of a green screen, then asked us which we preferred. We made our choice only to be told we had to purchase one (10 euro) in order to get the "free" one. No need for scamming when you have a world-class venue!Otherwise a great, educational experience.

Nice place. Too expensive. This is a really nice building but too expensive for what it is, once you enter you will visit a couple floors and apartments and then go to the Attic where is the museum with the explanations of Gaudi work like in all the other Gaudi buildings, and then you can go to the roof top and see the city, is a nice view but with thousands of tourist on it is hard to find a good spot. In conclusion, is a nice place and I recommend to visit it but in my opinion is too expensive.

Wonderful. A truly amazing Gaudi inspired building and not to be missed. Apart from the outside appearance the roof area is breathtaking. Then you come down to the under roof area and wow what a space. The man was a true genius.

Breathtaking . This is an absolute must do if you visit Barcelona!Try to visit on a "blue sky" day and your experience will be even more amazing. As you step onto the rooftop, be prepared to be amazed. Absolutely brilliant!
Stunning. Terrace and attic good but I dream of a flat like that. Every detail is stunning. Minutes from his other masterpieces

Classiest quarry I've ever visited. Another amazing Gaudi building, from the courtyard to the roof. The imagination and flare of the man is breathtaking. Only downside to the visit was the number of Japanese tourists taking selfies in front of every available surface. Why ??? What's the point ??? .... and it makes the visit more difficult than it needs to be when one is constantly elbowed out of the way or stepped in front of to enable said selfies to be taken.
Just go there. Just go and sit on the roof top for an hour soaking up the views and beautiful chimneys. Stunning in all lights but sunset is my favourite.

Good light show but there should be more to it. It was a good light show but, If you knew little about Gaudi, the tour did not really tell you a lot about his work - there is a bit more to it than funny shaped chimneys and odd vaults. If you knew more about him beforehand you would possibly be disappointed. It's expensive for what it is though there were a lot of people there so it's definitely popular. I would have liked to see more of the building itself. On the plus side it's all well organised but do book in advance on line.

Best to see at night. We visited La Pedrera at 10 PM at night for their tour and light show, which we had booked online in advance. After seeing a short slide show with music and being shown around the lower level, we were taken up the servants' stairs (you could choose the elevator, and I breathlessly encourage you to do so) seven floors to the attic of the building. The attic undulates and its beams look very much like the skeleton of a sea snake. There are a number of exhibits to view all around it before climbing to the roof for the sound and light show, which imagines what Gaudi's influences were which led to his designs. This was the best part of the visit, as you stand on an undulating roof in the night air populated by a number of oddly shaped structures upon which images are projected. It was a very artistic and novel presentation that we will not forget, high above the Passeig de Gracia. After the show, we returned to the ground floor to enjoy several glasses of cava with our fellow guests. Highly recommended!

Amazing!. The house is really hard to describe - Gaudi was an extraordinary architect. Take the elevator to the top floor, then head to the roof and work your way down. There is a furnished apartment, which is really interesting.

Amazing Gaudí building.... I couldn't stop taking pictures of this beautiful and amazing building. I wanted to capture all the shapes with my camera. I was awed with this out of the box mind of this admirable man. Of course, all of this happens when you like and enjoy Gaudí work. I suggest to buy your tickets on line. You can stay as long as you want.

A step back in time. My wife and I visited La Pedrera and the place is amazing. Unfortunately on the day we visited it was pouring down and the roof terrace was closed which was a great pity. The building is so unusual and like nothing I have ever seen. The tour starts off in the attic which is absolutely stunning and then moves the the flat which is a real step back in time. Would definitely recommend using the audio guide which is included in your ticket, without that I don't think you get the same experience at all.

Perfect. By chance we did not wait for the ticket. You will love whole building and plus roof top is breathtaking also you will see the flat where Mila family lived it is great you go back to those years.
The most fantastic rooftop we've ever seen.. Almost no corners to be found. Although it was crowded, waiting allowed you good pictures of the Views through the circles.

The last residential project of the nation's famed architect. Reflects a more matured and sedated frame of mind of Antoni Gaudi when compared with the more playful designs and interactive exhibits over at Casa Battlo.
Unfortunately, my shopping experience with the staff at bookshop section in the groundfloor souvenior shop marred the visit :(

Fascinating. This amazing building is in my opinion the best Gaudi house, if you are to visit one this will not disappoint. Book on line to avoid queues at the ticket window. A lovely café restaurant is within the building, a gift shop is also available at the exit but these can be visited without paying to enter the house.

Worth a visit as an introdution to Gaudi's work. This house is worth visiting with the audio guide. You can not only see the house inside and outside, go to the roof terrace (amazing views!), but in the attic is a very interesting exhibition on Gaudi's work, thinking, philosophy, way of thinking about architecture and interior design. Book tickets online to skip the lines and save money.

Don't miss out on this. During a 4 day city trip to Barcelona, we vistited the Pedrera building. Astonishing. Not cheap but than again worthwhile. This visit takes about half a day. The best part is on the roof, spectacular
No words.. Amazing architecture. Gaudi masterpiece. Reasonable price. Even the teenagers were excited. It's my second visit and I will visit again. Strongly recommended.

Beautiful La Pedrera. Gaudi so far ahead of his time, another work of art. Really worth a visit to see his genius.Visited nearly all his works and was blown away by this man's talent. Really worth a visit, go early to avoid crowds.

What a sight. If you're a Gaudi fan this is a must see. Once again you must book before you go to avoid a long wait. Be sure to cross the road and look at the exterior from a distance and different angles. Amazing.

Fantastic. The design is stunning. Our hotel was across the street so we had a "bird's eye view" of the rooftop. We chose not to do the tour but discovered that if you go to the back of the gift shop; there are windows that allow you to see inside the courtyard.
Gaudi enthusiast. Interesting tour, but felt a bit drawn out and expensive for what it is. The light and music show at night is overhyped but our tour guide was knowledgeable and keen.

Worth a visit. This is a must see site for anyone interested in 19th century architecture, design or creative genius. Built into the downtown structure of Barcelona, Gaudi has left for us a masterpiece of his creative genius.
Essential Gaudi. The rooftop alone is worth the price of admission...admittedly steep for a family. Gaudi's "green building" was well ahead of its time with natural cooling built in.

Gaudi at his best. Amazing architecture. We spent all morning exploring this building. Audio provided. The rooftop with soldierlikesculptures is incredible. Certainly an experience especially if you are a gaudi fan. Restaurant attached is recommended or small cafe bar attached.
Very good and infomative. Beautiful and informative. Audio guide works well. We spent two hours. One is definetly not enough, but it's not for a full day either.

Most interesting apartment building I have ever seen. Also known as Casa Mila, it was built in 1912 by Antoni Gaudi. The motif is mostly like a place under the sea. Gaudi hid the chimneys on the roof by decorating them, some with broken tile/glass mosaics, and others with fanciful facades. It is a self guiding tour, but well worth the time spent. There are examples of other buildings that Gaudi designed/built on the grounds. Really spectacular, and very avant garde architectural design.Book tickets on line before you go.

Awesome lesson in design. Definitely worth touring La Pedrera, even if only for the lesson in architecture and design. Gaudì was ahead of his time when you consider how very different his style was from others at the time. We were a family but not one traveling with teenagers. We did not make a reservation ahead of time, we walked right in.

New meaning to starting at the top. This fascinating apartment complex designed by architect Antonio Gaudi, gives new meaning to clever design. The highlight of the tour of the building appeared to be for most, irooftop of the building. There you will find the elegant and artistic myriad of chimneys that seem to resemble Darth Vadar in sandstone. Some are covered in broken champagne bottles highlighting the architects clever use of recycled materials to the delight of all. The location is a popular spot for large tour groups so purchasing your tickets ONLINE can help guarantee entry. My only caution, watch out for selfie sticks and tour group participants more interested in photographing the elements of the building that observing and enjoying them in the moment. Worth your time in a city with so much to offer.

Must see Gaudi.... We did several tours of various Gaudi sites and architectural locations. The presentation at La Pedrera is the best. It's more than a display of the building and the apartment of the period... there is a very good demonstration of the engineering techniques Gaudi used to design several of his projects... a pleasure being inside the mind of a master if only for a few moments.We got there early, 10AM, and had to wait only 2-5 minutes to purchase tickets and enter immediately. We had no trouble navigating the structure. It was relaxed and we had time to enjoy individual aspects that intrigued us.
Unbelievable place. Strong recommendation to visit it. you cannot avoid visit La Pedrera if you go to Barcelona. On top of the beauty of the place the view from the roof is amazing

Delicious Gaudi Architecture. Gaudi (and his fellow modern architects) have left their wonderful legacy to Barcelona. La Perdrera is a beautiful monument to Gaudi's genius. The building has been wonderfully preserved and renovated. The exhibits very nicely tell about Gaudi's perspective and building techniques. Working your way up the floors, one ends the tour on the roof, which is delightful. This building is a must-see when in Barcelona. However, like the other Gaudi attractions, buy your tickets on-line to get a reserved time for your visit. Otherwise, you may spend a good bit of time in a long line waiting to buy your ticket and to get in. The tour companies appear to bring all of their guests here - as evidenced by the line of tour buses parked on the adjacent street.

World of Gaudi. At first we backed away from the 20 euro entrance fee but decided to go in the end and I truly enjoyed it, the roof top was unique and offered great views of the city. I spent most of my time in the attic looking at the displays and was amazed about how much Gaudi has influenced today's construction. The apartment was also worth the visit, the lack of straight lines and the artistic flair throughout. I kept wanting to touch the door frames with their swirls. So yes it's expensive but I enjoyed it.

Alright For The Gaudi Completist . I love modernista architecture in general, and Gaudi in particular. But, to me La Pedrera was a huge disappointment. First, since most of the apartment building is occupied, only one apartment is available for viewing, and it is nothing out of the ordinary. Second, the rooftop terrace, where the tour begins and which is supposed to be the highlight, is nice, but in my opinion not as interesting as either the terrace at nearby Casa Battlo or at Palau Gaull, which to me is the best of the Gaudi residential architecture which can be toured.  After the terrace, the next stop is an audio-visual exhibit of the construction of the building, what Barcelona was like in those times, and some photos of some of Gaudi's other projects, like La Sagrada Familia, Parc Guell and Casa Battlo. Much better to see them in person. That is followed by the apartment and, of course, the gift store.  For the high price of more than 20 Euros, you get very little value I am sorry to say. Save your money and go see the much less visited Palau Guell, off La Rambla, which easily is ten times as interesting.

Great introduction to Gaudi. We happened to schedule this as our first Gaudi attraction and are glad as it is a great introduction to his techniques and philosophy. The tour and exhibits are well-designed to give you an insight into the rationale behinds his architectural decisions and the inspiration that guided his artistic choices. It set us up well to have a more informed approach on our subsequent visits to Sagrada Familia, Park Guell, and Casa Batllo.

I really enjoyed being on the rooftop and seeing the different art.. Honestly, I wish that I could have seen more of the floors within the building. I was able to see one floor which was great but going floor to floor would have been worth the money.
The "quarrying" is fabulous. The wrought iron balconies seem like seaweed in front of the wavywalls made of hewn stone. The motifs of the sea continue in the blue green gleaming walls of the Lobby.
Don't Miss!. Even if you're not into architecture or art or anything related to it, this is a must-see. The rooftop, especially, is a gorgeous experience.

City break. Another one of the musts to go and see in city. Helps understand how Gaudi approached his work. Found the roof fascinating with the chimney sentinels. Went mid afternoon and were able to get in without too much of a wait, but it is very popular.
Gaudi at his best. This is the place to visit to understand how Gaudi changed the way we build buildings. Very informative and fun to see.
Magic!. What can you say? Gaudi a genius. Worth the steep entry fee. Book online and avoid the longer ticket buying queue.

Must be seeen even if you do not like Gaudi. Areally must see even if you are not crazy about Gaudi. There is nowhere else in the world like it, it is an experience. On the donw side, acess is not cheap and beware of Selfie sticks

Beautiful Gaudí experience . We really enjoyed learning about La Pedrera and Gaudí. Getting the timed advance pass online made it very easy to enter. The guided audio tour was informative. We enjoyed the time on the roof as well as seeing the original furnishings.

Weird but interesting house. This house by Gaudi is a very interesting place to discover. The building is still mostly an apartment building, and only the courtyard, the roof top, the attic and the top floor are part of the museum. If you suffer from fear of heights (like I do), the roof top is very scary.

Amazing architecture. We came back to visit inside this building after looking at the outside on a walking tour of Gaudi. It was worth it. The audio tour came free with the online tickets and was very informative. I loved the structures on the roof, but it's hard to take a great photo because of the railings everywhere.

Very interesting. After seeing segrada familia and taking a free gaudi walking tour, we wanted to see another gaudi place. Admission includes headsets which are very informative. Great views from the rooftop.

A Must See. If you're visiting Barcelona, a visit to this iconic building is a must. Truly one of a kind and defines Gaudi. Start on the roof and then tour the apartment. Interesting to say the least.

Curves straight from Gaudi. The line for tickets was fairly short. We got our headset guide and started. After a brief walk at ground level we were elevated to the roof where the Whoville-like architecture begins. Great views of the city while walking up and down steps (nothing seems flat or straight) up here. Photo ops at every turn of this unique and creative assemblage of sculptures. Next head down stairs for a film history of Gaudi then on to see the rooms, furniture, balconies, etc. that he conceived years ago. Truly awesome! In what seems to be the attic there are short films, models and examples of his artwork. We could not get enough of this fascinating place. The gift shop (surprise!) is at the exit where you can get books and various items to remember this remarkable man and his work.

Must see. Well worth visiting at night time. The plain stone outside doesn't do justice to the colourful views up the central atrium. The attic and rooftop are amazing and from the rooftop the view of Barcelona is fantastic.Book before you travel, which is easy to do online, to avoid the queues. Whilst there is a lift to the attic, it might not be for people who haven't got a head for heights or can't manage stairs (to get up to the roof and move around it). It was quite difficult to hear and understand our tour guide at the start of the visit when he was using a PA system in a courtyard but it was easier during the remainder of the tour. Would have been good to see an apartment but you only see the atrium, attic and roof going down to the second atrium. It was good but would have made it even better.
A weird but wonderful place.. If you don't fancy an internal guided tour than view this magnificent building from the outside to appreciate the workings of this brilliant man - it cost nothing!
wonderful. visited November 2015 found everything to be spectacular - amazing buildings in average type roads and streets

Interesting. You feel almost like you are in lord of the rings.
Very clean and nice scenery. I would suggest to take the guide/headphones for more information. (minus: quite expensive)

Must see once. It is a very different looking apartment house designed by a brilliant and possibly whimsical Spanish architect Antoni Gaudi.It is a UNESCO World Heritage site. The existing building was demolished. It has 5 floors. Much bigger than Casa Batilo also in Barcelona. The owner lived on the first floor. There still are a few tenants. Gaudi wanted the people in the building to all know each other. So the lifts are only available on every second floor so people are forced to associate with one another. The building, the walls, the ceilings, the windows, the shape of the rooms etc; do not have a single straight line. Casa Milà (another name of this building) is the result of two buildings, built around two courtyards which provide natural light and ventilation to five floors, ground floor, mezzanine, the basement and an attic. The basement was intended to be the garage. The main floor was the residence of the Milàs (a flat of all 1,323 m2), and the rest distributed over 20 apartments for rent. The resulting layout is shaped like an asymmetrical "8" because of the different shape and size of the courtyards. The attic housed the laundry and drying areas, forming an insulating space for the building and simultaneously determining the levels of the roof. The roof has skylights, staircase exits, fans, and chimneys.

Wonderful Tour. Buy you tickets ahead online to avoid the lines. It is surprisingly interesting and you learn about Gaudi and his architectural theory. You get to visit the interior courtyard, the roof which offers a great view of the city, the attic with models and explanatory material and an actual apartment as it would have been in Gaudi's time.

Gaudi .... . Casa Mila or La Pedrera ...Must visit to understand the importance of Gaudi and his thought process. You get to see the the apartment he designed for the Mila family . The attic area which houses the models of the Sagrada Famila , the ergonomically designed furniture , etc

Lovely and fascinatingn. Loved learning about Gaudi and his style, a great museum to pop into on our last day in Barcelona, and a cute gift shop! Only downfall was the confusing headset numbers but that ended up being amusing so didn't detract at all!

An attraction not to be missed. Casa Mila, probably more popularly known as La Pedrera, is situated on Passeig de Gracia, within walking distance of Casa Batllo and even Placa Catalunya. I say this, because many people queue, in the busy season, for a long time to get onto the Bus Touristica at Placa Catalunya, when it would actually be easier and quicker to walk from there (Placa Catalunya) to Casa Batllo. Once that has been visited, you can then walk along Passeig de Gracia to La Pedrera, and catch the bus from that stop once you have finished there. Your hotel should be able to sell you tickets for the tour buses when you arrive and you can ask for a route map, which will show you what I mean. The building itself is yet another of Gaudi’s wonders and today it houses a cultural centre. As with all Gaudi buildings, it is the architectural design that grabs the eye and the imagination. Like Casa Batllo, the building itself is stunning, both inside and out. Also like Batllo, the rooftop is the most breath-taking area, with great views over the city, including a clear view of the Sagrada Familia. It is a photographers dream and the view from the street corner, with the balconies on all three faces in the frame, makes for a great shot, as does the rooftop. However, all internal areas are beautiful, including the staircases.La Pedrera should not be missed if touring the city. Be sure to take your camera, though that could be said of any of any place associated with Gaudi. Entrance costs €20.50 for adults, but is much cheaper for children under 12 at half that price. Children under 7 can enter for free.

Great experience . This weird agricultural building is iconic in everywhere you may think about: the interior was futuristic and fansty, the rooms were normal but weirdly out-of-the-world!Highly recommended!

The Best Example of Antoni Gaudi's Apartment Architecture. La Pedrera is an essential part of any Gaudi tour in Barcelona. The Basilica of the Holy Family and the Parc Guell are the outrageous biggies, of course, but La Pedrera evidence of his genius at the human, family level. His whimsical design style is every where, concealing his superb engineering and structural skills. The apartment that is part of the tour is kept as it was in the early 20th. century and is filled with light and air and large rooms that flow well and he designed much of the furniture himself (like F. L. Wright and H. Guimard). The roof is great fun to explore - there is so much whimsy in just the chimneys that one can't even see from the ground that its worth the trip up there. A well run tour that flows nicely without disturbing the real apartment dwellers on the floors that are not part of the museum tour.
Stunning. La Pedrera is a fascinating place to visit. From the unique roof to the beautifully preserved apartment this is a stunning piece of architecture. Another Gaudi triumph.

There is a reason UNESCO rate this place. This apartment complex designed and built (well he oversaw it) by Gaudi is a must see in Barcelona.In the middle of the city, s few hundred meter from Casa Batilo this is a most amazing structure. You get to see the roof and a level below and the view from the roof is awesome. There is one point where the (as yet uncompleted Cathedral is framed in an arch of the roof - pretty cool. Fortunately there is a lift you can take for most of the up and down.Best to organize e-tickets on the web but we survived the ten minutes queue- on a quiet Sunday

The rooftop is amazing!. Like all major attractions in peak seaon one must buy tickets beforehand. If not there is an entrance that clearly states that you can pay extra to not stand in the hot sun.
The building itself is marvelous! The rooftop was my favourite part

Gaudi rocks! Definitely see this! The roof is incredible. If you want your Gaudi fill, go see La Sagrada Familia, Casa Batllo, Park Guell and La Pedrera.Love the roof. The chimney structures, especially the one with broken champagne bottles for design, are incredible. Get the audioguide as it will give you great little facts, like the arches being linked to view La Sagrada Familia and information on the Catenary arches in the attic. Links ideas Gaudi has about architecture with his love of nature.Definitely do this while you are in Barcelona!
One of a kind!. This is a great spot to both see Gaudi's work and learn about him and his career. We actually liked this better than Sagrada Familia.

Casa Batllo is better in almost every respect, apart from one thing.... I enjoyed my visit and it's yet another piece of Gaudi's work that is worth a view. It's very different architecturally to Casa Batllo, but if you are torn between the two, Casa Batllo gets my vote.Architecturally it is quite different to a lot of Gaudi's work, but the courtyard area inside is stunning, as is the roof and to a lesser extent the attic. Quite a lot of the building is inaccessible as many floors are let to businesses/residents and this is no more evident than when you have to walk up a very, very long stairwell past lots of closed doors to get to the roof at the beginning of the tour.The audio tour is very impressive and informative, but finding the numbers around La Pedrera can be difficult as they're extremely small and hard to spot (particularly in the dark attic), and it also lacks the incredible augmented reality feature that Casa Batllo has.For me the highlight is the roof, which has decent views around the city, but is just a wonderful place to explore with the witch scarer chimneys and vents, views down into the courtyards below etc.The attic was excellent, and had a very, very impressive exhibition about Gaudi and his influences. This exhibition alone probably goes into more depth than anywhere else I've seen in Barcelona and includes impressive cut-away models, physical examples of his methodologies, videos and his inspirations from nature. This really impressed me.There was also a floor decorated as a typical apartment which was fairly interesting too.My complaints, although minor, is that there is a lot of 'modern intrusion' with a few ugly fire doors, air conditioning equipment in plain view on the roof, an ugly lift shaft etc. The irony was not lost when the audio commentary was explaining how Gaudi made even functional things like vents beautiful just as I glanced over and saw lots of fans, electrical boxes etc in plain sight. The building also didn't seem to be in such good condition as Casa Batllo, with the worn/peeling paint on the walls down into the courtyards (visible from the roof) being a bit disappointing. Finally, things like the photo opportunity were not as elegantly done as at Casa Batllo (where you stand on the balcony), whereas here it's a greenscreen and they super-impose you onto a background.If you can only do either Casa Batllo or La Pedrera, then Batllo gets my vote, but the exhibition on Gaudi is very worthwhile and I definitely recommend a visit.

After 11 years we finally got to visit. First saw this house in 2005, but was on a guided tour and couldn't visit. Then it was closed for renovation for a while, so finally did the get here. Was a bit disappointed to be told that we would only get to see the terrace, the attic and one apartment. But that was really enough as the apartment was huge, the attic was full of wonder, and the terrace was amazing.

very unusual Gaudi house. Loved this place, but it is expensive, and one only gets to see the roof and an apartment in the style of Gaudi's time. The roof is very zany and you can walk around for some time. The rest of the apartments are now let out.
Spectacular Gaudi Building. Amazing Gaudi building.The architecture is amazing.Worth visiting the whole building with a guide or speakers
Another can't miss if you are a Gaudi fan!. One of Gaudi's Big 3 (along with La Sagrada Familia and Park Guell). Again, get on a tour to really appreciate the building and its history.
Amazing Building. Wonderful to view, admire and explore. Spectacular and well worth a visit. Gaudi was an amazing architect. Enjoy!
Amazing!. The building facade undulates, the balconies invite, the attic is a wonder, the roof is astounding! There is a cost to enter but do not be deterred!

Distinctive Gaudi architecture. Classic Gaudi style residence. 20 euro entrance may seem expensive but it is well worth the price. You get a real feel for what it was like to live in a structure that was for ahead of its time. The view from the roof is great and you can see Gaudi's Sagrada Familia basilica on the skyline. From the roof.do not miss he attic. There are several displays of the history of Gaudi's work and how he approached design using nature as a guide. Very well done.

Beautiful Roof. Exterior features and the roof of building are very beatifiul. I also liked the old furnitures etc. which are being exhibited in the building. But interior features aren't as impressive as Casa Batllo.
