Interesting. Worth a visit, but try to see it before visiting Casa Batlló because it was designed earlier in Gaudi's career. Lovely bits of Art Nouveau and a good tour of the rooms showing details of life when it was lived in.

incredible building. A chance to see the inside of the most original apartment by Gaudi. Not only can you marvel at the design of the apartment there is a great exhibition of the design techniques used. The breathtaking part of the visit is the unique rooftop which words cannot describe.
Unbelieveable ! !. A wonderful work by Gaudi. His rooftops are so spectacular. Can't believe that it was built for a family. A wonderful tour.
An interesting and enjoyable two hours. Very interesting, well presented, not too crowded, helpful staff on duty. Glad we had booked in advance

Great architecture building to visit and admire. No doubt Goudi was genious...This building is so unique that you cant walk down the streets without noticing.What I think is the most beautiful part is the roof, which has a lot of unique structures with different shapes.Too bad that this building is too small and crowdy, which kind of annoying in some parts.

Roof alone Worth the Visit. Bought tx before we left the States so was easy to walk up and hand them at required time. Walked right in. 4 of us were there about an hour and a quarter. Highlight is the crazy design on the roof plus the great views of the city. If a fan of design and architecture then this is a must, even if you see La Sagrada also. Worth the price. Inside interesting but its the outside and roof that says "Gaudi"

Mind blown!. I will start by saying I fell in love with Gaudi while in Barcelona. And while I wasn't able to make it to all of the sites that he designed, the ones I went to were glorious. La Pedrera was amazing. The only thing to keep in mind is that it starts by having you climb about 10 flights of steps to the roof - its grueling, but absolutely worth it. The rest of the tour works to help the visitor understand Gaudi and his inspirations. As always, skip the line ticket are worth it.

Better go to this before casa Batllo. It's beautiful on the rooftop which you can see the forever building la sagarda familia. The house s beautiful and you can expect the good use of lighting and ventilation system created by gaudi. My only advice is to go to this one before casa Batllo coz the latter one is the best! Absolutely amazing! You won't be surprised if you go there first before going to la pedrera!
Mature Gaudi is really good. I really really enjoyed. You become a ghost, visiting that flat of the begining of 20th century. And the rooftop, you should visit it

Interesting, inspiring and sad. We toured La Pedrera in the late afternoon and spent a good three hours reading about the history of the building in the excellent exhibit in the attic, walking amongst the other-worldly sculptures on the roof and viewing a beautiful apartment. We then stayed for two more hours to see the evening light show on the roof 'The Origins'. I think that it was a bit too much for me. The show was nice, but was really just a projection of images on the sculptures. The tour leading up to it was a repeat of all that I had learned earlier. I would suggest doing one or the other, but not both on the same day. The sad part is that the wealthy couple that commissioned the building in the first place didn't like it and it was very upsetting to Gaudi. It is an amazing building and well worth touring.

25 Eur per person to be bullied by the stinky guard. Main entrance serves as an exit and the guard there screamed at us angrily in local language dhen we tried to enter, and bullied us out. Went around the corner where they made an entrance and waited 5 minutes for the cashier to show up and take of 50 euro. Got tired of wait, left, and spent them on the funicular instead.Worst experience of the whole 2 week trip.

Beautiful work. Everything Mr. Gaudi has created is breathtaking and this house is no exception. I recommend to arrive early in the morning, immediately after the opening because of the less waiting in qeue, and to purchase ticket online.
Beautiful. A must to see when visiting Barcelona. This is a stunning piece of art. Best to buy ticketrs online.

Nice tour . Nice tour of house designed by Gaudi. Takes about an hour to wander through roof, attic and apartment while listening to audio tour. Great for Gaudi enthusiasts and to learn a bit of history of life in Barcelona.
😱👍. It was my first time to go actually inside of the Gaudi's art. I loved & enjoyed the every second of being there. It is just amazing. Its worth visiting.

A must see. We were hesitant to go here or any Guadi exhibit due to crowds. Anyhow last minute we booked on line for front of the line. Only way! very glad we got to experience this amazing architecture.
Amazing!. Beautiful architecture in the middle of Barcelona high street. Highly recommended only bit expensive for visit.
A must visit..... A must visit when traveling to Barcelona. Make sure you purchase the tickets online prior of going there.

La Pedrera Dinner & Tour - Fantastic!. I booked the dinner and night tour for my CEO and some clients after I visited years ago. The feedback was fantastic. Food was "fabulous", ambient atmosphere and staff were friendly and attentive. The clients "really enjoyed it". The comments I received about the tour were "stunning" and "Gaudi was an absolute genius and visionary so many years before his time". Everyone came away wanting to know more and also wanting to come back. I will definitely book this again for the next conference in Barcelona.
Fantastic building. Constructed by Gaudi. Marvellous and unique design. The terrace is worth to see as well. A bit expensive to visit though.
La Pedrera. stunning. Did the tour with the headphone recording. Each Gaudi site is so different from the others.
Too crowded to enjoy properly. . There were too many people crowded into tight quarters who were tied to their audio guides unaware that they were blocking others trying to get by.
Less interesting than Casa Battlo. Each person has a different opinion but for me there were less things to see. We start the visit by the must see, the rooftop. And then it is good but not a must

Don't Miss this Wonderful Example of Gaudi Architecture. Gaudi’s architecture is based on imagination that is fantasy and whimsical, yet is rooted in precise structural engineering. So, you must see La Pedrera to experience his unique architecture...and you will be amazed. The roof top with all the chimneys is both amusing and remarkable. Well worth the tour!

One of a kind.. You can see the outside, and some of the inside, and whatever you get to see is a real experience that should not be missed. There is a light show on the roof at night with a "mini" tour. This is worth the effort, although the light show (in my view) was a little long and got boring. Our friends thought it was too short and loved every bit of it!

Roof best part, except for type fencing they used. Actually I wrote my comments about this under family sagrada so hate to repeat myself. Definitely though get tickets online directly from them and make sure you put in the date you want to visit not the date you bought the tickets. As I did that and they almost would not let me in. But my sincere disappointment must have made them realize I truly was not there earlier and they reissued me a new ticket.

Need to Book Ahead. Building is big but only 1 (top) floor (laid out as a typical apartment of the time with appropriate furnishings), the attic which is somewhat of a museum showing Gaudi's genius as a practical naturalist architect. and the roof and the chimneys. Personally I liked Palau Guell the best.

Lively and creative structure. It is difficult to believe that this building is over 100 years old. What Gaudi has done is remarkable. The tour begins on the roof. It is no ordinary roof, but has many steps and if you fear heights you may cut your visit short. Then it is down to displays and then to visit some apartments. The old way to imagine this as an old building is to see the turn of the century furnishings. Special.

Memorable for its trademark facade and its in-depth attic exhibition of Gaudi's works. Casa Mila/Pedrera, located on upscale Passeig de Gracia, is a 5 floor apartment building with an open central courtyard. It was built for the Mila family who lived in one of the apartments and rented out the others. Their living area has become an exhibition space open only for special displays. We entered through the courtyard to see the unusual wrought iron gate which used varying sizes of circles that reminded me of fish and whale mouths. The courtyard was a public space for the the apartment owners to access a stairwell to their floors. The mural ceiling over this stairwell immediately caught my eye with its speckled colors of green, avocado, rose, turquoise, and white. Having already visited 2 other Gaudi houses, I didn't find the tiled roof top vents and flues that fascinating anymore even though the shapes, clusters, and colors were different. There were also more stairs than the other two as well as an undulating floor surface. The views of Barcelona towards Park Guell and along Passeig de Gracia were good from up here. Next, we entered a large open attic area which had an excellent display of Gaudi's works. Several monitors played videos of all of his houses giving dates of construction, what he hoped to achieve with each different design, and a tour of each.There were small scale models of the homes and La Sagrada. Another display showed how a bicycle wheel design was an inspiration for several of Gaudi's construction methods. Other displays showed some of the things in nature, particularly sealife, that inspired his designs such as seashell, bones, algae, coral. Next we visited an apartment that was furnished in early 20th Century style. Children's bedrooms had toys neatly lined up around the wall perimeters; the master bedroom had a spacious ensuite with tub, pedestal sink, and toilet; storage closet was stuffed with luggage, out-of season coats, tricycle; dining room, sitting room, and kitchen were appropriately furnished; one room was for a maid; another for chores like laundry and sewing. Was this what luxury living was like in the early 1900's? There were also displays showing practical things that Gaudi designed for these apartments like knobs, handles, special mouldings around doors, wood carved benches, and chairs. For me, the memorable moments were the exhibition in the attic and the most unusual facade of Casa Pedrera. Perhaps we were just lucky, but we were able to enter immediately at 11 am on a Sunday in early September without reserved timed tickets. Audio guides are included in the admission rate. We stayed just over an hour.

Share the rooftop with Gaudi's imagination.. We found that an excellent time to appreciate La Pedrera is after six o'clock, in September - it closes at eight pm. This means that very few people are on the roof and so you have the space to appreciate this masterpiece, and to view the city from the particular vantage points that Gaudi's design affords you. The interior is also interesting and you get a true feeling of the structural qualities of the building and the domestic arrangement at the time of building. As it is currently lived in on certain floors you navigate around the building by lift. There are explanations of how Gaudi used the principles of natural structures and put them to use in innovative building. You can see modern reproductions of Gaudi's furniture, painstakingly remade by craftsmen, due to the fact that the original pieces had been dispersed and lost.

Did the night time light show. It was ok. The light show was a bit dull but the building itself is pretty interesting. The tour is informative at night and the guide seemed to be a big fan so she was really into her job but it seemed a bit pricey for what it was. The cava at the end was nice. Might be better during the day.

You Haven't Seen Gaudi Until you Visit La Pedrera. After the entrance when you enter the atrium of the apartments and look up, you will know that you are going to view something different. The atrium is a work of art. The apartments are spectacular. The roof top is like no other. It is fun, whimsical, and has great views. This building is one of my favorite.

Very interesting. Amazing place to know all about gaudi (with audioguide) that was very useful to go after to sagrada familia and park guell since we had the explanations before.The 'free photo' card is hilarious for being such a way to fool tourists !!!!! We were observing the people that wanted to pick the picture and everyone was fooled and many angry! The house worths the visit but still is extremely expensive (like every monument in barcelona...)

Origins Night Tour Truly Magical. We chose to do the night time tour to avoid crowds. We absolutely loved it. The building is stunning. Our tour guide was very knowledgeable and enthusiastic. There is a detailed explanation of the courtyard, a tour of the attic (much more interesting than it sounds) and a final stop on the surreal rooftop. There, special videos were projected on the statues, accompanied by music. It was definitely the highlight of our Barcelona stay.A few notes: The online booking agent Entradas Clorian [entradas@clorian.com] was incredibly helpful. You might want to contact them prior to booking online to inquire as to the language offered at each tour time for the date you are interested. Also- this tour required navigating narrow, steep steps in semi-dark conditions. I would do this tour again.

Polarising Gaudi. Unlike Casa Battlo, which was embraced as a masterpiece, La Pedrera was quite polarising, and considered ugly, due to it's scrap metal balconies and wavelike facade. It took a lot longer than Casa Battlo to build, and the owners hated it. This was the last private commission that Gaudi completed before he threw himself into the Sagrada Familia. The chimneys on top are fascinating, each one different, but overall lacks the wow factor of Casa Battlo.

Spectacular rooftop. Antoni Gaudi's genius cannot be denied . This building is wonderful to see , and the rooftop is a whimsical wonderland of statues and chimney tops . It is a stop , look and appreciate another way thinking . The views of Barcelona from the rooftop are fantastic.

Very interesting. Our first thought on arrival was that 20€ it was quite pricey, but once we'd got our inclusive audio equipment and the lift to the roof we were very surprised, the audio was very informative and the walk through the furnished apartment rooms was lovely, all in all we spent a couple of hours looking around

Fabulous. This was well worth a visit. Really interesting building with an audio tour included in the price. There is a lift to take you to the roof which is the start of the tour, but we took the stairs (8floors) to avoid the long queue. The roof would be tricky for disabled people as it is on several levels. The architecture is amazing and the tour explains a lot about Gaudi's style and methods. There is also a museum area that shows rooms as they would have been in Gaudi's day.

Baby step to more Gaudi's surprises. Our first step to Gaudi's work and opened up our minds. Not as mind blowing, looking back now, comparing to other renowned architecture in the city but still had a wonderful time all the way to the roof!

Quirky architecture. We were taken to the roof of the house where we can see how Gaudi had designed such utilitarian objects like chimneys, ventilation shafts etc. could be disguised as sculptural and aesthetic artefacts. It is a monument to Gaudi's ingenuity.Coming down the roof we come to the interior where they show Gaudi's sources of inspiration and his methods. It is a nice way to spend an hour and a half.The world could certainly use more people like Gaudi.

An Exciting Experience. It is amazing to realize that this building was designed and built over a hundred years ago. It displays Gaudi's forward thinking, creativity and playful humor. His genius is manifested within every niche of this architectural play land. The exterior as well as the interior is a joyous symphony of color, shape, design and art. As visitors enter the courtyards there is a whirl of texture, color, shapes and fantasy. This feeling is enhanced on the roof terrace. The chimney and ventilation shafts, some with strategically placed arches for framing neighboring landmarks, are reminiscent of Star Wars storm troopers! Many of them tower on the edge of the roof and appear to be peering roof top guards.The attic is astonishing with its 270 brick arches. Once the laundry area, it now houses a progressive exhibition dedicated to Gaudi's creative genius and includes models, drawings, photo and videos.The fourth floor apartment is open for exploration and nicely furnished with period items. It features the unique Gaudi details: door knobs, carved plaster moldings, doors, floors, and lighting. The audiovisual is a welcome opportunity to sit and rest while watching the remarkable changes to the city which inevitably affected the final outcome of La Pedrera.HINT: At the main entrance, visitors are offered immediate entry for a premium price. We elected to walk around the corner to the ticket office where there was a short line and purchase tickets at the regular price.

Gaudí another excellent masterpiece. Eexcellent building.Eexcellent to see this building during the day and also during the night.We were at one of the night tours and the end with champagne + sweets inside the inernal court of this excellent building was really fantastic

not as good as Battlo. I recommend visiting Casa Battlo for sure, and going to Pedrera to eat in the cafe or perhaps for the daytime tour which I bypassed for the evening tour with the lightshow. It was not as interesting as I had hoped and a disappointment having already visited Battlo

Night time experience very special. We purchased the day and night ticket and I really enjoyed the full tour during the day and the gorgeous light display in the evening. Gaudi had a spectacular vision and this building looks like it belongs in a science fiction movie rather than having been designed 100 years ago.

Worth a visit. We visited La Pedrera in the early evening with pretty views of the city from the rooftop. The building has some unique design features, different than Casa Batllo (which we toured in the morning). It's worth the visit and worth buying tickets ahead of time. It's laid out like a really good museum highlighting the design choices Gaudi made for his clients. In between La Pedrera and Casa Batllo we had lunch at Coco Vail Beer Hall on Carrer de Arago' off of Passeig de Gracia halfway between the two. Free wifi and great food at much lower prices than the other touristy restaurants right in Passeig de Gracia. We couldn't eat another little sausage!!

An amazing Gaudi building, with an interesting story. Go at night!. Such an iconic building and even better to see it at night. We went to Origins and really enjoyed it. A bit of a tour inside with lots of interesting info re: Gaudi's style, the commission for the building etc and a really great projection to music on the roof. Incredible views of Barcelona. I'd really recommend
Amazing. One of Gaudi's masterpieces erected in the late 19th century.Very astonishing architectural dominates this building . a great view from the rooftop.
The most accesable among Gaudi's Houses. Visit this one, it's the most accessable among Gaudi's houses, yet you'll get very good imagination about his masterpieces in general.
Make sure you book before you go on holiday as two week needed. Could not get in as had not pre booked no books tell you this so don't get caught out book before you go
So So Gaudi. We toured the main Gaudi structures, and this one was our second least favorite. You got to see an apartment designed by him, and the rooftop view was nice.

what a place. We decided to pay and go inside the building and so glad we did. We had a audio tour. It is wonderful to find out about these buildings and their history. The views from the roof top were fantastic and you can take some lovely photos. You can get an insight to how the apartment rooms looked and how people lived. We took a lift up to the upper floors first and then stairs to ground level.

Be pre warned . We did the 34€ evening visit,the highlight being a roof top light show .A lift was mentioned but not the amount of steps if one walked up.There were 120 & by the time some of us got to the top we'd missed the guides introduction. A magnificent building for all that.
Pedrera. Wild, crazy lines, imaginative, colorful, functional, art! Can't believe this was conceived in the late 1800's! Genius! If he would have been able to meet Disney, think of the possibilities!

The rooftop at night could have been so much more. We live in the selfie/social media age. When people visit attractions, especially places as interesting looking as the roof of La Pedrera, they want to take pics and selfies to post and brag.Sadly, the night tour of the rooftop is woefully outdated. They insist on you sitting through and interminably long "light show" where they project a series of stock images and animations on to the artistically wonderful chimneys Gaudi designed, accompanied by cheesy music. Lame and boring.They should bag this late-90s trope and instead work on lighting each chimney and sculpture for selfies and photos. Until they do, see the building during the day where the magnificence of Gaudi can be experienced without interference.However, our guide was knowledgeable and pleasant and they didn't skimp on the post-tour cava. We didn't have a bad time, but it could've been so much more.

Nice place to visit, but need sunny day to visit the attic. Very interesting visit of Gaudi creation for this building very modern and comfortable made in the 1910 years. The attic is very impressive and has nicevew on the city and some monuments like the Sagrada Famiglia

A gorgeous Gaudi gateau!. We saw La Pedrera during the day. Tickets cost us about £17.50 each, giving you an audio guide and also helping to avoid queuing if you book online. It’s an amazing building with its undulating lines and organic feel, making you feel just a wee bit envious that it isn’t you who lives in such an amazing building. It’s still a ‘working’ building with residents and businesses. Not sure how they feel about the hordes of tourists but I guess it's the price to pay to work or live in a World Heritage declared building. The ticket price includes access to the magnificent roof, the exhibition area in the attic which makes you feel like you are in the belly of a whale and also an apartment recreating the lifestyle of a bourgeois family in the early 20th century.

Fantastic tour. We booked this tour in advance and had priority entry, however if you were to do this tour when they first open there isn't a queue. The audio guide for this tour was really insightful and provided lots of information on how Gaudi created some of his architectural designs which was really interesting and something we weren't expecting. The chimneys were really fascinating and well worth seeing.

A BCN must see.. Quite apart from the fascinating Gaudi architecture, this is a must-see for the interior exhibits about Gaudi's architectural work and nature-inspired designs of everything from the building to furniture and door knobs. Still 100 years ahead of its time!

Intriguing. Very interesting residential building designed by Gaudi...
the roof and the interiors are interesting
the model apartment is ok
Stunning apartment. A must see, especially the roof top of the building. Gaudi's works all varry so this is very impressive considering when it was built.
impressive Architecture. In the middle of one of the main avenue this corner building is certainly the most photographed. There is a cafe downstair and also a tour to visit the inside.

Stupendous La Pedrera. On our last day in Beautiful Barcelona we went to see this Gaudy masterpiece. Words cannot describe the experience. The tour guide and exhibitions were illuminating and we were given a glimpse of sumptuous living and amazing architecture. Whether you are a fan of Gaudi's work or not you really must not leave Barcelona without visiting La Pedrera.

Gaudi is Simply Amazing (aka Casa Mila). I'm a traditionalist when it comes to art and architecture yet I surprised myself at how much I loved Gaudi's work. I saw both the exterior and interior of Casa Mila or La Pedrera. It is so impressive how Gaudi was able to bring art and functionality seamlessly and beautifully. (I bet there are some people who will not like it and that's OK.) It's hard to name a favorite part but the brick-lined attic and roof-top views were incredible. I highly recommend not missing Guide's work in Barcelona (especially Sagrada Familia church). I loved it!

Light up your night. If possible go at night to see the wonderful structure and enjoy an amazing rooftop laser show. Almost impossible to believe this was built over 100 years ago. Get tickets online before you visit to reserve best times or expect to wait.
Must see. One of my favourite destinations in Barcelona. Young children particularly love the rooftop it seems. We went after 5pm when it wasn't so busy.

Seeing pure genius!. When you see Casa Mila from outside you can think that Gaudi was a bit crazy. When you see his work inside you realise that he was pure genius. The house is extremely inovative not only for its time, but even now. Soft shapes and natural curves all over the structure are amazing. The way light is introduced inside plus the great view were trendy more than 100 ago, like they are today. I started to think what would be if Gaudi lived in 21st century... magic! Totally recommended visit! I did the day tour this time, but will try night visit soon.
Interesting.. Great place to visit, while shopping, stop by and check this place out. It is work it. the story behind the site it quite interesting.

Great Gaudi site!. My husband and I recently visited Casa Mila (aka La Pedrera) on our vacation. VERY unique architecture by Gaudi! The audiotour was excellent and a great way to get a lot of information. It is a little expensive to visit...but a taste of opulent apartment life from another era. Don't miss the roof!!!!

Awesome roof. Nice place to visit :)Price is little bit higher, but equal for Gaudí lovers :)Roof is incredible scenic :) Sagrada Familia can be seen from it.Underroof is also nice to visit - lot of architectonic models :)And the last floor of rooms with furniture - if you have more time than me is also very nice to see, how it looked like in early 20s centruy :)

Nice roof, boring appartment, tickets to pricey. The roof is nice, but you can just visit Palau Guell for a similar one. Overall the ticket price isn't justified: the visit includes one of the appartments in La Pedrera and a visit of the rooftop.

Beautiful and Unexpected - The Best of Gaudi. La Pedrera is different than any other building that I have seen - anywhere. From the undulating stone facade to the twisting wrought iron balconies and windows, the building stands out. My favorite is perhaps the roof with many chimneys and fragments of marble, glass, and other assortment of materials embedded in the roof.

aka Casa Mila. This is the last civil work designed by Gaudi, and its history is most amusing. The couple who commissioned this house didn't both agree on its style. In fact, Mrs Mila was pretty upset about the inside, outside & the furniture Gaudi designed.Both inside & outside is a constant curve, and the "chimneys" (known as witch scarers) look like they could really do the job. Gaudi's work is always interesting. This place is no longer a home, and isn't really a public space, but just to see the outside and hear the history and stories is worth the stop.
Gaudi masterpiece. be sure to visit La Pedrera.. though it costs quite a bit, it is a masterpiece you must see. roof top is fabulous, apartment and attic also.. don't miss it

Not only the building but greart exhibits on Gaudi too. I think it is his most appealing building. The route is well handled through the building and crowds managed well to allow everyone to have a pleasant visit. The exibits in the attic space were very infromative and engaging. The rooftop terrace is great fun to amble around and we spent an hour up there. Get tickets ahead they are scheduled by time.

The visit was nice and the show was amazing. We visited it by night and attended a show called "The Originals" . The tour was very nice and interesting and then the show was light and sounds amazing show in the roof and it said the history of creating the nature.We all loved it , then they served Champagne or juice and something like cookies
Top. this is one of the interesting place in Barcelona, i love this place, every corner inside it's amazing!

Even the roof vents are extraordinary. From the sidewalk to the rooftops this building is a comprehensive vision of naturalist meets arts deco. You can see how the structure is built on the premise of arches in the attic. You can a restored apartment. And a really good gift shop. My Christmas shopping is done.

GAUDI AT HIS BEST. La Pedrera is a most fascinating building with all the incredible touches that Gaudi has made his own. The view from the terrace is fantastic as are all the chimney stacks and stairwells that are artworks in their own right. The apartment is also an interesting insight into the lives of the wealthy Spaniard in the 1920's and 30's and the attic shows many highlights of Gaudi's though processes while designing these amazing pieces of architecture. Highly recommend a visit to La Pedrera.

Amazing structure with excellent self-guided tour. Be sure to book a timed ticket in advance. The building is remarkable and stunning in many ways, and the self-guided tour gives you an excellent overview.

Good for photographers but very expansive!. 20euros to visit a house is so expansive!! everything in barcelona is so expansive! at least 20euros for each activity or visit!But nice architecture to see but not worth 20e!

Rooftop is nice. Was very interested in Gaudi works. We opted to skip Parc Guell and visit Pedrera. We purchased the self guided audio tour, but the main highlight really is the rooftop creations Gaudi made. You are allowed to go to the 4th floor and see how the floor plan to the apartment was set up, which did not interest me as much. My favorite portion was the roof and the next floor you go to. In this museum part, they describe where Gaudi found his inspiration - in everything he sees in nature. I think its over-priced for what it really is. And did not take us as long as I thought it would. Did hear that casa Batllo was worth the visit though. Will go there next time.
Architecture at its best . Went here today with my husband , what fabulous style so unique . Enjoyed tour and how bougoise families lived
Beautiful. An amazing building built ahead of its time, the architecture is simply astonishing. Definitely worth the visit.

Gaudi's amazing work. Definitely worth a visit!The odd structures on the roof are the main attraction, the museum in the attic area is quite dark but found the apartment less interesting as this was not a previous home of Gaudi.

A must visit when in Barcelona. Because one has to see this amazing place when in Barcelona!If visiting in daytime it's not really necessary to book The Origins Night Show as there's nothing really special on this evening tour and it can still get better.
Stunning building. Not only a great interior and roof, but an interesting exhibition about Gaudi's other works. We didn't need to book, but it could be a good idea.

Traveling Spain 2016. PRO'S:This is a must-see on the Gaudi list in Barcelona. This building gives you more of Gaudi's architectural techniques than Casa Ball just down the street. All Gaudi buildings need tickets to be ordered in advance.  CON'S: Can be hot, crowded and many of the displays are almost identical what you see in other Gaudi buildings.SUMMARY: After you see Sagrada Familia, Casa Battllo, Park Gull then see La Pedrera (Casa Mila).

La Pedrera ~ One of four Gaudí stops. We just spent 5 days in Barcelona and La Pedrera was just one of Antoni Gaudí built buildings/sites we visited. We booked our La Pedrera ~ Casa Milà visit the morning of online. It was late September and not too busy at 11:00am and spent 2 hours. During the visit we started at the courtyard/main floor area and then took the elevator to the roof. The roof is very unique, and like the other Gaudí sites in Barcelona you can appreciate his Neo-Gothic to modernism designs from the structure's tiles, glass, wood and wrought iron. After the roof you walk stairs down to the Attic with its exceptional arched brick design and buttresses. In the attic are many models of his works and a good video/photo history of Gaudí. The last stop is the huge top floor apartment and all its rooms and furnishings. A true sight considering it was 1906-1912. Overall our visit was great and memorable. It was nice to poke around and take pictures and without issue from staff. Staff were all very friendly and helpful. We passed on the audio guide but wishing I had taken the option. A great stop to combine with his other works.

Very nice experience!. The staff is great, the sight is excellent and we had a very good time. The visit starts downstairs with a explication of how the house was built, the name of the house and all the historical things related to the house, then the visit moves to the loft of the building, where we received a lot of information about the building. The most spectacular part of the visit is the roof-top with the lights and views of the city! If you are in Barcelona and have the time to visit Casa Milla do it! If you do it by night is even better (less people and a much better experience overall)

Jazz on the Roof!!!. I just wrote a lengthy review of this place but airport lounge internet messed up and I lost it all. So here is the short version with the photos. Saturday night concerts 2x a month on the rooftop preceded by a 1/2 hour in the attic viewing exits about Gaudi and his architecture. The jazz was fabulous as the sun set around us, aided by a glass or two of the local Penedes wine region Cava, or white bubbly.We didn't do any tours and the building has been well covered by other reviews but suffice to say if you are looking for something different to do in this beautiful building then try this out. You must pre book and the cost is moderate, about 40 Euros from memory including 1 glass of Cava. We saw the sax player 2 nights later at the Flamenca show at La Bodega Flamenca Camaron which I also highly recommend as a cultural and entertaining experience.
Avant garde Gaudi. A wonderful building to visit. Well organised, interesting. Very busy. Good to buy your ticket in advance, and easy to use Tourisrica bus to get there. A must see in Barcelona.

Surreal yet historical experience! . You must go there once in your life! The building was just a few minutes walk away from town and easily accessible by tourist bus. The roof top is a must do! The decors are all an art piece by themselves! Even the door handle design are so detailed! And it's from hundreds of years ago.... Awesome!

Awesome rooftop views. This is a must see in Barcelona do advise Advance on line tickets the rooftop is amazing in the afternoon and evening with the sunset and the objects being lighted it is special
Very cool Gaudi building . Great place to visit esp the roof terrace5 stars if less people just far too busyMaybe arrange a photographers tour 1 or 2 times per day early or late

A bit expensive but worth it . Beside the genius architecture of Gaudi, what I learned in this apartment complex and Gaudi design is how future and forward thinking Gaudi is. Compare and contrast with how modern houses are layout and high density complex and you see that Gaudi was already there more than a hundred years ahead. Concept like open living, wainscoting, maser bath ensuite, bath kitchen layout, entry and parking garage in the basement. I could go on...

Unique Experience. We went to La Pedrera in the evening and the tour guide provided an insightful, interesting overview of Gaudi's Casa Batlo. This was followed by a light and music show on the roof which was unique and engaging. The light show demonstrates where Gaudi's inspiration came from for his designs - well done.

Didn't go in but a spectacle all the same. . Took pictures from the outside. It's like a big wobbly jelly. No straight lines whatsoever. A bit of a strange spectacle alongside surrounding edifices. I bet the real highlights are inside where I hear they're also no straight lines.

Jaw-Dropping Experience. It would be difficult to visit San Sebastian and not cross paths with Gaudi's wondrous architecture... perhaps impossible... but if you only see one or two works, be sure to include La Pedrera, and if you can, book ahead and get a GUIDED TOUR. Our guide was an historian, sociologist and art historian rolled into one, and he allowed us to experience Gaudi's apartment building in the context of the time it was built, something that would likely be missed on simply an audio tour. Also, although buying tickets online is recommended, we were staying nearby, and we purchased our tickets the day before on site and avoided standing in line. Besides Gaudi's sculptural approach to building, he was on the cutting edge of the time with materials and technology (one of the first elevators in Barcelona, and the first underground carriage garage, complete building ventilation system to name a few). Anyway, words cannot describe what your eyes will see... make time to visit La Pedrera!
Another Gaudi icon. See it!. Amazing innovative architecture. An inspiration of creativity. This is a must see for any trip to Barcelona.

Beautiful rooftop views. Gaudi's Pedrera is a must see while in Barcelona. The audio tour is excellent and there is an abundance of information on Gaudi's influences and his vision for the work. The rooftop mosaics are beautiful and afford the visitors amazing views of Barcelona. Plan to spend a few hours to take it all in and book ahead online to avoid waiting to get in. And of course have your camera ready!

Living the Gaudi dream. Well to have an apartment here is not only about the money but about living in art. To wake up everyday with the great architecture of Gaudi is a life lesson in itself as one tries to understand the secret of his genius. the rooftop being explored b thousands of people brings the true appreciation to everyday life in Gaudi's dream.

Early is best. If you can then prebook your tickets online, get there before opening time and you will be first in the building. The crowds build up quite quickly and long queues are the usual.We were there early and so avoided the crush. It was fine on the roof first thing but I imagine that when there are crowds of people the experience is less than good.This is a must see building.

Better than Casa Batllo - book in Advance.. We booked in to visit by day and do the night guided tour with light show. Personally, we found the visit of La Pedrera more interesting than Casa Batllo as by visiting the apartment, we got a better feel for what it was like actually living in one of Gaudi's houses; although Casa Batllo does try hard to cover this with their virtual reality audio guide, it didn't quite hit the mark for me. The night tour is interesting and informative but the light show on top at the end wasn't a must-see. Like pretty much every Barcelona attraction, I'd recommend buying tickets in advance to avoid lengthy queues (this didn't seem to be as busy as La Sag Fam or Batllo) but the express queue jump entry probably isn't worth the extra 5 odd euro a ticket. The glass of bubbly and snack at the end of the tour was a welcome surprise. All in all, a pretty good way to see some of Gaudis work and discover what it was like living in one of his works.

Great introduction to the work of Gaudi. This was our first trip to Barcelona and our first (and favourite) of the Gaudi experiences. It is totally worth getting the audio guide so that you really understand the brilliance behind the various design features. Wear non-slip shoes as the roof top tiles are a bit slippery and have plenty of steps, and do allow a couple of hours so that you can really drink it all in. The ground floor gift shop also has some really nice little Barcelona gifts.

Another great house. We visited the house during the day and also the evening program where they project a light show on the top of the roof. Some of the daytime information were covered during the evening tour but it is worth a visit.

Wealthy family apartments. Very interesting view of how the wealthy families would commission a block if apartments so they could live off the tenant rents for life. Gaudi designed a wonderfully livable area fir all that survives today as an example. Very interesting

Best of Antonio Gaudi houses. This located in Passagia Gracia, little walk from Catalunya square and will be nice in your first day to be familiar with Gaudi style and it's impression from Natural staffs in Architecture.Must do and take Audio guide included in your ticket price.Take your time to go on the Roof and explore it.ImanTour guide
Neat. A really cool building from the street. We didn't spend the money to go in but it was a great day to just take in the street view
Amazing. A must see in Barcelona, its truly fascinating and amazing views from the roof top. Fabulous visit and still lived in to this day

Excellent experience. Excellent experience.
We booked a tour.
The guide explained the history of this building.
The show on the roof was breathtaking.

Nice monument in Barcelona. This is one of the most beautiful buildings in Barcelona. Some days you can enter for free, but you have a long time to wait. It is better to go some day paying the entrance
Beautiful Building and Museum. Another great presentation of Gaudi's work with a mixture of expression of architecture combined with a museum of the history of the time.

A little over-rated. We bought advance online tickets and so were able to walk straight in. The decoration at this level looking up into the central lightwell was impressive, however it was all downhill after that. You are taken straight up to the roof level by lift and out into the daylight. The roof has it's points of interest, it is Gaudi after all, for example the twisted chimneys and the undulating floor but overall it is not a patch on Casa Batllo. A further point is that the lines of the roof and the general perspective are somewhat spoiled by the abundance of safety fencing and fire doors all replete with large notices. A bit over the top in my opinion, no pun intended.

Most unusual design. It is almost impossible to describe one of Gaudi's buildings. One can say he does not like 45 degree angles (corners) but it is another thing to actually see his designs. Barcelona has at least 3 buildings that are a must see, La Pedrera, Basilica de la Sagrada Familia and Casa Batllo.

Fantastic (but Expensive for what you get). I love this building, the colours and shapes of the external and internal building, the almost surreal feel to the roof and the standard look and feel of the apartments by contrast. The only negative I would have is the expense of the visit, is could do with being a little less expensive.

Magnificent!. You should definetely visit la Pedrera. Its a work of art designed down to its every little detail perfectly. You are astonished by how its possible to create something like that in the 1900s. If you dont want to wait in line for long, book your ticket on line.

what a strange architect!. recommend to visit this place before other buildings which are designed by Gaudi. because in this house you find some good infornation about Gaudi and his other works like Sagrada Familia or Caso Battlo. the roof of this house has a very strange atmosohere causes by the human-like structures that has come from Gaudi. the roof also has a very nice view to Barcelona.

Experience Gaudi at his best. You will have a new appreciation for the genius of Gaudi from an up close look at his spectacular apartment complex as well as an excellent audio tour (included with admission) and a great display explaining the principals behind his designs.

Interesting - Different - Inspiring. Well worth the admission. Free audio headset is a must. Gaudi's influence was really out of this world 100+ years ago. The rooftop and attic is a must see for anyone in construction or architecture.

A good place to visit but you need to be mobile as there are lots of steps. A great place to visit. There is a lift to the roof area but once you are up there you need to be able to climb quite a few steps to make the most of your visit. The attic display area is very interesting and informative.  If you are a fan of Gaudi you will greatly appreciate this attraction. We didn't need to pre-book.

Must see. It is one of the masterpieces of the Gaudi's mind, the rooftop is mindblowing, whole house is so interesting and really gets you inside Gaudi's mind. I would recommend to go to La Pedrera before going to other Gaudi's creations because it will help you to understand how and from where he got his inspiration for everything.A must see if in Barcelona, a little bit pricey but worth the money!

Fabulous!. I like this attraction more than any other of Gaudi's works. I thought it was well organized and coherent; the exhibits in the attic space were great: well studied, informative and just beautiful to see. Well done
Gaudí simply amazing.. Such a beautiful Gaudí building,but I think 27 pp is a bit too much even if we got to skip the line,but so glad I got to see it.

Hesitant visitor but convinced after visit. Had some free time on recent visit so booked online. Whilst your will visit a tiny part of this huge structure, you will gain enough insight to how Gaudi thought and designed living space. The terrace is amazing with views of Barcelona and the mountains (look past adjoining buildings - after all this is a city!)The exhibition etc and tour audio guide are informative and allow own pace to explore. Good photography location - take wide and ultra wide angle lenses.Recommended.
Fabulous Gaufi insight . Gaudi up close in these true to life apartments. Fabulous roof top with functional Gaudi sculptures as well as great views. A must for any Gaudi buff.

La Pedrera by day. We went to LaPedreda (Casa Mila) at 11.30 in the morning with having booked the tickets before on line (Which we later noticed was very wise because the ticket lines were pretty long. Because if you go for a short time period like us, we were in Barcelona for 3 days, it is good to have your trip planned hourly, otherwise you may lose some valuable time by waiting in the queues). We got to Casa Mila on time of the booking and we didn't have to wait at all. Right away we got our audio guides and started the tour. The audio guide was very informative and nice. Without it, you may feel a little lack of information. The guide takes you through the exposition in a logical sequence and it is enjoyable to follow it. Sometimes it just plays you music, but it is enjoyable to listen to it and it makes the tour more emotional. Going through the museum (attic), rooftop and the apartment of Mila family, you learn a lot about the architect and not only about this particular museum, but also about the other places designed by Antoni Gaudi.

Guadi's house - just Ok.. This Gaudi designed house is just OK. Gaudi's Casa Botllo house is far superior. Most web sites and books list La Pedrera higher than Casa Botllo. They are totally oiff base.

Loved evening light show . In the evening, for an extra fee, can enjoy a memorable light show on the roof of the structure, with complimentary cava and dessert after. Would highly recommend if looking for a unique nighttime activity in Barcelona!
Stunning. A must see. The building itself if amazing to look at and the way it has been designed. Also a beautiful view from the rooftop

An interesting view of Gaudi's work. I felt Casa Battlo was better and was more clearly signed when inside to know where to go and when the audio guide should be used. However, it is well worth visiting and see the interesting shapes and technology that Gaudi introduced to his work. The roof shapes developed for the chimneys are extremely modern, considering when this was designed nad built. A display is also given in the attic of a number of other buildings designed by Gauldi. The visit to the Apartment was also good to see the architecture, but also how those with means, lived in those days.

Wonders of Gaudi. Nice way to spend a couple of hours, particularly on a rainy day. Interesting historical facts in Attic space of house and beautiful apartment to view. Enjoyed this visit although caught out with 'free' photos which were actually 10 euro.

Wonderful view from the roof top. We booked our tickets on line before we went however on the day we visited the queue was minimal so we didn't save much time. If you visit on a busy day you will also have to queue inside for the left to the roof. However, the wait would be worth it. The views from the amazing roof are stunning and the apartment floor is gorgeous. Lots of things to see on the way round. Make use of the headset as the commentary is excellent. Well worth a visit.

Our second visit in 15 years and it was worth it. Get the advance premium ticket and enjoy the pure magic and joy of Gaudi. From every angle inside and out this is a unique experience everyone must see
Brilliant. A beautifully weird building, huge and maze-like. Starting at the roof and working down through the attic to the apartments is an experience nit to be missed. Well worth a visit.

Worthwhile, informative visit.. Beautiful, unique building and well designed Gaudi 'museum' using modern, interactive display techniques. We learnt a lot about Gaudi, his concepts and his works which complemented our later visit to his Sagrada Familia. Recommended.
Vacation . Interesting building with rooftop the must see. Think a bit over priced, but interesting architecture features.

Another Barcelona architecture landmark. Huge apartment building designed by Gaudi. Still used as offices and apartments now so limited areas on public tour. The rooftop is interesting but the interiors not as fantastical as some of Gaudi's other buildings.

We took the evening tour. The day tour includes a tour of an apartment, the night tour does not include a tour of an apartment but it does include a tour of the attic and a roof top light show, and wine or juice and dessert at the end. There are still a few people who live in some of the units, but when they leave the units will not be rented again. The current renters pay a rate that was fixed in the 1930's and that, by law, cannot be raised. They're in their 90's now and you may see them returning from a shopping trip as they enter an elevator. They should feel very fortunate to live in such a beautiful building which is in the middle of such a lively and beautiful part of Barcelona.

The rooftop takes the cake. Interesting since it is Gaudi's last building before he concentrated all his time on Sagrada Familia--a less personal, commercial design that still manages to incorporate his accumulated ideas to date. There are current businesses there in the building in addition to the museum style exhibit spaces. The audio guide is free and is ok, but not that necessary. The tour begins with an elevator ride up to the rooftop. (Warning to those who are afraid of heights or have difficulty with steps, there is not an easy way from there to the next lower level where the exhibits begin). The rooftop is an open maze of steps and fantastic chimney structures, and nice views of the city. The next level down has nice scale models and exhibits about this and other Gaudi work. Next level down has recreated an apartment with all furnishings of the period, so you can imagine the style in which they lived. Lots of steps down from here, although an elevator is available if you can find it! There is a nice gift shop on the way out. Overall worthwhile, but if you only have time for one or two Gaudi buildings, I'd say this is a distant third to #1 Sagrada Familia and #2 Casa Batllo.
Only saw the outside. Too expensive to enter.. I'm sure it's lovely, but thought the entrance price, just to have a look around, was extortionate. We elected to just admire from the outside.

Brilliant. If you're coming here you know why. The tour is great, the roof views amazing, the apartment and attic incredible to see. I could just sit on the roof for hours. Well worth the entrance fee.
Another unusaul architecture. Only saw it from outside. Too many tourists. Maybe another time when less crowded, we could enjoy the visit inside.

Brilliant UNESCO listed Gaudi building. My wife and I debated as to whether to pay the 20€ per person entry fee (34€ at night) but I insisted we should as this is such an iconic building. Glad we did pay. Totally worth paying the money to walk the rooftop alone. Self guided tour is great and gives you an insight into the brilliant mind of Gaudi. A must do in Barcelona

Gaudi's Magic!. La Pedrera is yet another testimony of Antoni Gaudi's fascinating work. This is a must visit attraction in Barcelona for all those remotely interested in architecture. Also, it is better if someone takes a guided tour or the skip the lines + audio tour to enjoy this architectural master-peice

Rooftop is Cool!!!. Another unique cutting edge Gaudi.Do the preff tour as the que is instant, you get a cool book and it includes the headset. A great deal.We stayed on thevroof for at least 40 minutes. The inside tour is quick and very nice. They havevan apartmentbfurnished with items of the era. Well done. I think alll the Guadi museums/landmarks tours and exhibits are extremely well done.

Architectural wonder. Highly informative tour with an audio guide of a Gaudi masterpiece. You will learn how he designed buildings and will learn the practicalities behind seemingly whimsical elements. In addition, you will enjoy touring this building and seeing a model apartment.
Beautiful!. Again another stunning display of Gaudis works! For me this was not as breathtaking as his others but beautiful all the same. Didn't go in but the view from the street was incredible!
Gaudi classic . Casa Battlo is more attractive but here is also masterpiece of Gaudi , inside also good but need pay , outside is enough if you seen the Casa Battlo inside...

Quirky . Really great to see on a warm balmy night. Guides were very good. The light show at night is spectacular. Forget the $$ and go. If you want to experience something different then this is s must.
Beatiful house. This beatiful house of Mila family is a beatiful place. You can see it whenb you go to Barcelona. It is quite expensive but worth to see it.

Fascinating look into the Past. We did not plan to see this site, but decided to select this building to tour as we walked this neighborhood. It is a truly fascinating look into Gaudi's residential planning, decoration and architecture. The vista's from the very top are beautiful and so unusual. The interior spaces give us a glimpse of living during that time and how advanced it was. The attic area is so interesting and displayed a number of models of Gaudi's work. Worth the visit.

Gaudi masterpiece - still functioning apartment buidling. This is one of Gaudi's masterpieces of modern architecture. Every detail shows as you pass from the roof to the attic and then to the top apartment. Every door has carved details, no matter how unimportant it's function. Look at the door handles, etc. The roof is spectacular, and you can see the Sagrada Familia undercontruction from this vantage.

Sand carving like!. The top of the building spreads and turns back naturally, just as the work of the wind on the sand dune. I am impressed by such an artist who could make his art so much as the nature, the nature so much as his art.p.s. my visit is in July 2014

Origins night show. The Origins night show is quite expensive but you can get a ticket which allows a daytime visit in addition for only five euros more so that definitely makes it worth it. Having done both the night time visit is much better. There's a very good and very useful guide and the night time show of projections on the rooftop is very impressive. The daytime visit will let you look around the building more but the night time visit was much more enjoyable

A must visit. Many people take in this architectural beauty by Gaudi from the exterior only. That is a BIG mistake. The lines and innovative structural design of the inside is something to behold. Then there is the roof that is a fantasy land of shapes and structures. The audio tour is very informative and gives you great insight to this creative genius. The visit will take about 2 hours.
Interesting building. We took a night and day tour of La Pedrera. Have to say the night tour was simply spectacular with the light show on top. Gorgeous at night.

Buildings with "skin". I truly fell in love with Antoni Gaudi's architecture as a result of my recent visit to Barcelona. This home/building is a must see (several times if possible!) Both at night and during the day, it is stunning and fascinating. We enjoyed a special evening tour and light show that was very exciting (despite the drizzle!) Our tour guide (Anna) was delightful. It is centrally located and easy to find while walking the streets and visiting the shops of Barcelona.

Second visit. Second time I was no less amazed, and in fact probably picked up more. Amazing amount of detail put into structure and systems. I love the organic architecture. Visiting in September meant no queue.

A good experience. We took the 11am tour which was guided by Anna (member of staff) Enthusiastic and knowledgeable she made the visit a memorable one. Views from the roof amazing and I believe in the evening they have a music and light show which we missed unfortunately. For us this was a Gaudi highlight.

The Bronze Medal of Gaudi Structures.... I think all of Gaudi is a must-see. That said, Casa Batlló and Sagrada Familia closely edge out La Padrera. Please do not let this dissuade you from visiting...it too is quite unique and inspiring.

Combine the day and night visit . The dayvisit or just the night visit are too expensive for what you get. When combining them (39 euro) you do get the value! During the day I walked through this nice house which definitely has a lot of Gaudi on the outside but you have to remember that it's a house where people had to live with their own taste. The night visit was excellent (mainly due to David) with a very nice tour. The show on the roof is also very nice and the views of the city are great.

Welcome to Gaudi's world. It wasn't my first time visiting La Pedrera, but once again the following the curves created by Gaudi resulted in a unique experience.Even if you look at this building with modern eyes it is something special. Underground carparks, self-supporting facade, temperature control, maximisation of natural light, ergonomic shapes... It is hard to find such a modern building these days... And that one was built 100 years ago!The building also includes a museum that helps understand the way Gaudi planned his works.

Amazing. As for all Gaudi locations in Barcelona, buy tickets ahead of time to avoid queuing. So beautiful and interesting, a real eye-opener. Stunning roof-top, for both the views and the chimney pots. If you like chimney-pots you'll be well-served by Gaudi (see also Palau Guell)!
Very enjoyable. The building is amazing, light show great and staff very helpful. My only disappointment was that the time to see the exhibits in the attic was not long enough.

You need to see this place. Built by Antoni Gaudi, the same guy who began construction of Segrada Familia, this place reminds me of a hobbit house on steroids. Any amazing structure without a square or flat surface in the place. The rooftop is a trip, undulating with spires here and there. Having to go and down the steps is almost dizzying but fun.

Not to be missed. A little more "conservative" compared to Casa Batllo, but we find again the sinuous lines and the art nouveau design. The courtyard and its colors give you a taste of what to expect throughout the house.

One of the cooles things I have ever seen. We went there twice. First time during the day, the second time for the night show. I really loved the place. The audio guide is absolutley recommended. Make sure to take your time for this place, since there is a lot to explore.

A place not to miss!. Amazing, amazing, amazing! :) although the fees for tourist attractions are quite expensive in Barcelona, it is really worth the money to visit Pedrera. Take the audio tour as it is very informative and free of charge. The whole tour will take at least an hour so you can really enjoy each details of this piece of ART.
Night Time Bliss!. Go at night-no crowds and the light display on the rooftop is excellent! You get your own guide and a small group-amazing!

Audio tour is very long. Audio tour is a little too long. We were there in the afternoon and it was hot on the roof. The tour inside was a little lengthy as I felt they tried to make the most of what is essentially a tour of the apartment block. In hindsight I would have preferred walking through without the audio commentary as I felt it was a little lacking and long.

Jazz on the roof. I have been to La Pedrera a number of times over the last 10 years but this weekend I went to the Jazz night held on the amazing roof. I have never been up there before at night - it's spectacular! The views over psg de Gracia were amazing. Really well done and well worth the €30 ticket! Think it may be finished for the year now but if you get to go next summer do it without hesitation!
Architecture - excellent. Very interesting place to visit - excellent architecture, stunning roof top views across Barcelona, apartment level definitely worth visiting

Don't be a tightwad. After 1100am you can purchase your tickets at the premium entrance. It will cost about 7 euro pp extra but you will skip the gueue. Alternatively you can buy premium tickets online as well. What is there to say about the Pedrera that hasn't been said before apart from maybe it's correct name is Casa Milan after the family that commisioned it?

Intriguing Architecture . This building is about the facade, the attic and the rooftop. The futuristic facade is something out of a futuristic science fiction movie. Despite being more than 100 years old, it has the look of something that would be designed to be built years from now. The roof with it's weird and magnificent statue-like chimneys and stairwells is where we spent a lot of time. The up and down layout combined with the views of the city and the nearby buildings and the statues is fascinating.The attic with its arches and play of light and shade together with the informational exhibits is where the amazing genius of Gaudi comes into sharp focus.The apartments themselves were the part we enjoyed the least. Overall a highly recommended visit.

Nice view on the roof and beautiful and unique architecture.. I am not sure if summer is a good time to visit Europe because everywhere you are there are bunches of people are there with you. La Pedrera itself is charming but it is not so interesting in my opinion. Overall it is nice to have experienced it. By the way, luckily that I can understand basic Spanish so I didn't have to get upset at the guard who was trying to tell a lady in Spanish to entry the place next door and she didn't understand so she got very upset until I went to her and told her what the guard said. It could be nice to have someone who knows more than the mother tongue language working in tourism.

Great Views, Astounding Building. La Pedrera is one of Gaudì's most famous creations, and is truly an extraordinary place to visit. You get to visit not only the roof terrace, but also an apartment complete with period furniture, and the attic, which holds an exhibition on Gaudì's work in general. It is all well presented, and La Pedrera is definitely worth an hour or two of your time. The tickets are a little pricey, and you may have to queue for some time to get in, but if you visit at off peak times (such as 9.00 - 10.00 AM) you won't have to worry about this, and will thoroughly enjoy your visit.

Great experience if you like architecture . We were pleasantly surprised by everything we saw while touring the inside (the apartment, the attic, the rooftop and internal courtyards.) His designs are highly influenced by a study of nature, and it is neat to see it all first hand (pictures don't do it justice.)

Gaudi's genius on full display. After seeing Casa Battlo, we walked a short distance to see Gaudi's famous residence/apartment building. Wavy lines and forms are the norm, rectilinear is not. Everywhere you look you are amazed at how fluid and natural the design is, and how comfortable you feel surrounded by Gaudi's work. The chimneys and doors on the roof came a century or more before Star Wars, but they sure look like alien forms to me! Be sure to spend lots of time enjoying the building, and in the Gaudi museum below the roof.

Visit for the unique roof!. The roof of this building is very unique, and makes visiting this building worth a visit, as you get to go on the roof and walk around. The actual interior of the house is not as exciting or interesting in terms of Modernista architecture style when compared to other Gaudi sites that I visited (but that may just be my opinion). We bought some sort of fast pass tickets to avoid the lines, but it didn't seem to be absolutely necessary as the line wasn't very long (visited in September). If you're a Gaudi fan, I'd definitely recommend visiting here!

Very cool. A little less interesting in my opinion than Casa Batllo but still a must see in my opinion, go to the roof and watch a nice view of part of the city. Pre-order tickets cause there might be a line to the tickets booth.

Brilliant. The experience of being on the undulating roof amongst an outdoor sculpture gallery of mysterious forms was surprisingly exhilarating and this visit was much more enjoyable than I had expected. The tickets are pricey, but if you are interested in architecture this is worth it. There was a very good exhibition on Gaudí's other work as well.

not just stone, worth a visit. The place is very busy so booking in advance is recommended. there are many people waiting for the lift to take them to the top, so I took the stairs (8 floors), it is a very nice place to visit,many interesting things to see. enjoy the roof most. had a good lunch at its' first floor restaurant.

Must see !. We visited this Gaudi masterpiece during August, and didn't prebuy tickets. There basically was about a 5 minute lineup and straight in. Plan to spend about an hour to wander through and be amazed at the stunning architecture, and fabulous rooftop as previous reviewers have said. Paid 20.50 euros without audio, as there is so much information on the displays etc. that it wasnt necessary for us. There is a lift to the roof, but I think we had to walk down about 5 floors. There is also a gift shop on the main floor to pick up souvenirs. TIP buy the hop on hop off bus ticket..stops at 40 different places, including Gaudi buildings.
Indescribable. Pictures speak louder than words. This is truly indescribable and what an experience. Makes one fall in love with Barcelona!!

Enlightening. As a person with only a passing interest in architecture, it was a wonderful experience to sense the genius that lay behind Gaudi's work. It makes you feel humble to see what great minds can achieve and to be able to enter the world as it was, when they worked their magic.A visit to La Predrera will help you understand why Barcelonans are so rightfully proud of Gaudi. Don't miss it.

Fantastic. I loved everything about this visit. The free audio guide was very informative, as were the attic level displays with a lot of thoughtfully presented information on La Pedrera as well as Gaudi's body of work and the concepts behind it all. This is a must-see while visiting Barcelona! The rooftop is a strange and wonderful installation that still delights and expands the mibd to this day, 100 years after construction.
Different . Nice place. Take the no line experience. The building is really nice  Very hot on the roof. Gaudi is crazy
Ahead of his time. Sheer Gaudi genius that shows how an apartment block can be reimagined in such a futuristic style back in the 1920's!

A must-see! . Another of Barcelona's architectural gems. And another which has be seen to be believed. Words cannot do it justice. Our visit started in the cafe (which is open to passers by) with its Gaudi ceilings and decor. Whilst the drinks were expensive it was a pleasure to sit in such stunning surroundings. We had not booked this online but seemed to hit it at a rare quiet time in the afternoon. There is a lot to see here on every floor. But all the marvelling we did at the staircases, the rooms, the doors, the lightwells etc, nothing prepared us for stepping out onto the roof. We were speechless. There are chimneys and then there are Gaudi's chimneys!!!! Make sure you have plenty of power in your camera on phone battery as you'll need it.

Must see!. Dont't be fooled by the facade. The roof is the place to be. Very detailed exhibition on Gaudi, the way he worked and from where he took inspiration. Learned a lot. Very nice inside re-creation of the apartments and how people lived. Book online tickets ahead.

Must visit to see the roof terrace . This Gaudi building is equally stunning by day or by night (tickets are €10 cheaper during the day). Building's roof with its artistic forms is breathtaking. And the views of Barcelona are incredible. You can see gorgeous de la Sagrada Família too. Roof was definitely the best part of visit for us. Something like that we haven't seen before. Also they give you a free audio guide upon entrance which tells interesting history of the building and Gaudi. The interior is interesting too, especially the main entrance hall. We went during the day and waited in line for about 10 min before getting in. Overall, it's worth the money and we recommend it to Barcelona tourists.

Awesome house and roof tour!. This is one of the few homes that can be toured currently and it is amazing. It encompasses three areas, the roof, the attic and one floor with an apartment.The tour itself takes about an hour or 90 minutes if you are slow but it is very cool and allows you to see the Gaudi touches up close and personal.

A century ahead of its time. This is another must see in Barcelona and is a unique living museum.The building is much bigger than I expected at about seven stories tall, and your tour goes straight to the roof via a modern elevator. There is a great view Ove Barcelona from the roof, along with the elaborate chimney stacks and ventilation shafts: works of art in themselves. After a time on the roof you self guide through the elaborate attic with various models and then through one apartment decorated as it would have been when first constructed.Departure is down the steps, but an elevator is available for the mobility challenged.This is a unique building and must be visited when in Barcelona.

A Masterpiece!!. My Lady and I toured Casa Milà (La Pedera) on a perfect-weather Barcelona day. We thoroughly toured the rooftop and the top floor. The curves in the structure are masterful and the design is a tribute to the genius of Antoni Gaudi. This architectural and engineering marvel must be seen to be appreciated; words won’t do it.
Gaudi!. Always interesting Gaudi architecture! Colors, forms, rooftop - in a word uniqueness. Would love to live in such a building!

Amazing La Pedrera. Can heartily recommend to give you an insight into Gaudi's approach to his work. The roof is a work of art, and the exhibit in the attic describing Gaudi's craft really prepares you for the rest of his work you will see in Barcelona. The apartment allows you to imagine living in one of his beautifully designed spaces. Loved it all!

Magnificent. I couldn't pre imagine how interesting this house would be. Even the roof took for me a couple of hours so prepare a visit for 4 - 5 hours. Antoni Gaudis architecture looks abnormal but same time very inviting. La Pedrera is a majestic example of a genuine understanding of mathematical principles in architecture making it so special.You can choose between daytime and night visits or to make them both.

Another Gaudi masterpiece. We bought our tickets on line in advance to avoid the line and were even allowed to enter early. La Pedrera offered a marvelous overview of how Gaudi approached his work through detailed models. The rooftop revealed glorious views of Barcelona In addition, the furnished apartment showed what living in La Pedrera was like for an early 20th century family. There is also an excellent gift shop.

The rooftop was spectacular.. We really enjoyed the views and chimney stacks on the roof but except for the preserved apartment, there wasn't much else to see here on the inside . The attic had lots of information but if you have been toSegrada Familla and Batllo then you would have seen much of this. Overpriced compared to those other attractions.
Great attraction. Excellent attraction well worth a visit. Very interesting but it can be hot inside the apartment. Shop expensive.

I love the roof. It was like a scene from star wars. I wish i had taken pictures from my cell to add to this. How gaudi imagined the vents and chimneys to look like spacemen before star wars add howz his genius. The top floor originally was a clothes drying space that was a genius idea. Not only dried clothes but also helped to cool the structure. Go early before the cruise ship passengers arrive.

Rooftop splendour. We again had beat the queue tickets, however once more I found we were treated like second class citizens, in that you're directed down the street or round the back of the building. Why I ask? Inside the huge building was wonderful, so curvy and sinuous as if it had just grown out of the ground. As this is still a working building you are directed quite quickly to the rooftop. There is a lift, but as the queue was long we opted to climb the stairs,slowly! Once on the roof it was amazing, I found the audio tour helpful and it pointed out some fascinating features. Who else would cover chimney pots in broken champagne bottles. However the rooftop was very busy, as you had to climb up and down steps, you had to be extremely careful and constantly watch where you were going. The attic and apartment were fascinating, I loved that the apartment was set out as it would have been when the house was built. The shop was quite extensive and I liked that it concentrated on Art Noveau items. Just be careful when buying things, I was short changed by the assistant. An interesting building,but not in my opinion as Casa Batlo.
Cool place. Very interesting house. Worth seeing.Better to book the ticket on-line as i ended up waiting in a long line.

The colours inside are amazing and the outside breathtaking. Please do not be put off by the cranes and scaffolding surrounding La Pedera. The building is truly one of the wonders of mans ingenuity and ability. It is truly not only a piece of art but a truly great building.The interior architecture and light is amazing. Please go when the Sun is out to get the sureal effect of the light through the windows If you have not had the opportunity to visit yet I envy you the experience to come.

Beautiful and well preserved. Really fascinating place, the architecture is beautiful and as the great audio guide pointed out all of it has a function. The internal apartments have been pro served beautifully and you can imagine life in such a stunning building.In the attic you can find out more about Gaudi's work around the city.

Day and night visit- superb. This house is well worth a visit but allow at least 2 hours before closing as we ran out of time, there is lots to see and read. Audioguide is great. The evening light show is simply fabulous and kids would enjoy too- well worth the extra charge. Nice to be greeted with glass of Prosecco in courtyard at end of show.

Worth the visit. . Beautiful place worth the visit. gives you a brief history of Gaudi design. The roof top warriors are beautiful. I would suggest buying the more expensive tickets as you will bypass the crowds.

Well worth a visit. Located on the main shopping streets this attraction could be missed! Had pre bought tickets on line so no queuing although there was no queue when we arrived mid morning anyway. Nice relaxing appreciation of Gaudi's work, the commentary sets were very useful and the whole experience takes you back to a by gone age, with a view to how the 'other half' lived.

Stunning. Our apartment overlooked this fantastic building. At night it's illuminated and we sat on our Terrace enjoying the view. It's worth the price to see this place. You can tour an apartment in the building. Do the self guided tour. You can buy combo ticket to go day and nothing. Totally worth it.
What a view!. The view from the terrace of this beautiful work of art is breathtaking: highly recommended! Buy the tickets online to save money and jump the queue!

Grandioso y genial. It's a very popular place so prepare that there might be queues.Buy tickets via the Internet in advance to save yourself a lot of time.Ideally, you should create your main route(with selected places) in advance by checking the attractions on the bus touristic ( or city tour) route.Enjoy Barcelona and don't forget to take comfortable shoes (snickers).

Fascinating still today a century later. In the words of my seven year old son who like me has an engineer mind: "this is better than the (Picasso) museum." You cannot really compare both but it's facinating to se La Pedrera and learn a bit of its history.

Marvellous!. Gaudi was a being who lived far beyond his time and the CASA MILÀ is another proof of this.Everything has a purpose, every detail is there for a justified reason, and all very well calculated, well thought out and harmoniously, disturbing ...So is the CASA MILÀ: Beautiful, provocative and, no doubt, beyond his time.I highly recommend it!
Just a great building. It is on the street and you have to pay much to enter. I don't think that the tickets are affordable for this place.

Amazing . Omg. Well worth the visit, did the night show. The Origins and loved it finished with a complementary glass of champagne. Not ideal for children had 2 horrible German children they were so rude. Tour guide was lovely and very informative.

Fascinating and still contemporary. Really interesting architecturally, even though I'm not a massive fan of art nouveau.Rooftop is stunning and the recorded commentary really good at putting the bits into context.There was a jazz band playing on the rooftop (about 7pm).
