Just added to the cool cultured "flavour"I was fascinated to learn that "real" people still live here - must be a GREAT place to live.The flat that we saw inside was amazing ..... airy .... high ceilings ..... fabulous !!!Overall a really great experience !!

Visit before the Sagrada - Pedrera origins tour. The origins evening your is definitely worth doing, you meet outside before going into one of the courtyards for a talk about Gaudi and the history of the house. I think this is where the tour can be a bit variable we did it last year and the focus was very much on gaudi and religion. This year (much better) the guide explored ideas and invited you to guess what could have inspired gaudi from nature - some of it is guesswork but amazing. A lot of the building is still occupied and at night you don't get to see the apartment. You then take a long walk up to the attic floor (or use the lift), the tour continues under the roof arches which feel like being in the belly of a whale you can see the history of the building and explore gaudi's designs and inspiration from the tiles on the street outside the building to furniture and the Sagrada design. A lot of gaudi's later designs are inspired by nature - the rooftop tour and light show is a projection of the history of man evolving with nature, very well put together and beautiful to see stood on top of the building with great views. It helps you visualise the inspirations from nature when you do visit the Sagrada. Make sure you visit after sundown as the light show looks best when it's truly dark. After the show you continue around the roof terrace notice the chimney pots that inspired the Star Wars storm trooper helmets and then down to another courtyard for a glass of cava and biscuits to the end the tour all in all about 1hr 15 minutes. Kids love the light show.
Picturesque. It is smaller than I anticipated but definitely worth the time to look through it. Interesting to see the angles of the columns. Views are pretty special too.

Beautiful work of Art. Lots of fun for everyone. I definitely recommend getting tickets in advance and skipping the line. We were brought right up to the rooftop and worked our way down. Every bit of La Pedrera is a work of art! This was a fun experience for all of us.

Visit both day and night. We opted to see La Pedrera first for the evening, behind the scene tour. The highlight is the rooftop light show, which was wonderfully surreal. Next day went back to check out the building and rooftop in daylight, as well as the apartment on the 4th floor - another wonderful Gaudi experience.

Great evening experience!. Me and my boyfriend have visited La Pedrera for an evening excursion in September 2016 (start at 20:45 in the evening). The tour started in the entrance the hall, where the guide shared with us some information about the building history and the building owner, as well as some other interesting facts. Our tour guide was a Spanish lady and, I must say, her English was not very clear to everyone, unfortunately. After this we were suggested to walk (or go by elevator) to the attic of the building (note that you will NOT see any of the apartments inside La Pedrera during the tour, unfortunately, because there are still people leaving inside those - yes, lucky people!). The attic contained some bits of other interesting things: furniture designed by Gaudi, a model of the entire building which helps you to see the building from every side in more details, and other historical exhibits. After this we were brought to the roof of the building - and the most amazing part of the tour started! The roof was fully decorated with interesting and famous elements made by Gaudi, and additionally to this all the roof parts were lit up with the special lights and accompanied by special music effects - it was a real show! We have spent at least 15 minutes enjoying ourselves on the roof with a great view on the night Barcelona - was very romantic and unforgettable. After we went back downstairs to the hall on the ground floor - we were offered a glass of cava with some chocolate cookies as snacks. We enjoyed this evening!
Night Tour is awesome. the Night tour is great - you get to explore all of the property and get a bit of exercise if you take the stairs ;) The lighting for the night tour is just beautiful.

Impressive Gaudi building. Casa Mila, or "La Pedrera" meaning "stone quarry", is an impressive Antoni Gaudi building in Barcelona constructed between 1906 & 1912. It was controversial at the time because of its undulating stone façade & twisting wrought iron balconies & windows. An innovative feature was its underground garage. In 1984, it was listed as a World Heritage Site. Tours are available everyday & there are great sites from the roof of the city where the tour starts. If you like Gaudi's work this is a must see.
Interesting roof. stepped in a hole outside of Casa Mila, and wretched my ankle, so was not able to walk around the entire facility, but from what I saw, I think Casa Batillo is way more interesting.

Very cool Gaudi buliding. My son (16) and I visited this building, an old house, while my wife and daughter went shopping nearby. It is an architects dream and worth a visit. The roof is very Dr Seussish and not like anything we had seen before. The teenager had a great time and has been telling friends about visiting it
Beautiful. The building is amazing. Would have loved to see one of the apartments. The light show is fabulous. Very much enjoyed the whole experience.

Too expensive . The 20 euro ticket allows you to visit the small court at the entrance, the terrace, the top floor- used initially as a laundry room and to host the elevator gears- and a portion of the floor just below the top. The rest of the house is privately owned and used. The terrace is not bad but I think for this price they could make the museum a bit better. It doesn't take long to visit it but if you have to choose pick la Casa Batlló just five minutes of walking distance unless you are a great fan of all Gaudì work

What an enchanting evening. What a wonderful way to see my most favorite Gaudi building. The tour and guide was quite informative. There was an elevator to get to the top floor and roof area. The light and music show was an interesting way to enjoy the rooftop sculptures.The only caution was that there was no clear signage or directions for someone who could not negotiate the stairs down. The tour guide left us up on the rooftop and we had to figure out how to get down by elevator on our own.However, the greeter out front was exceptionally welcoming.

Gaudi masterpiece. Casa Mila or La Predrera is a fascinating insight into Gaudi's domestic architecture. The visit starts on the roof from where you get great views of La Sagrada Familia. The brick vaulted attics contain a good exhibition explaining Gaudi's technique and showing other buildings then finishes in an apartment which gives a great view of life in the early 1900s. The queue was not long but better to buy tickets online so you go straight up to the audio guide desk (audio guide included and very good).In summer you can also book a "day and night" ticket and return to the roof which is illuminated for drinks.

a good 2 hours is required. Book on line and avoid long queues. go early in the morning and have the whole place to yourself. We could have spent the day examining this fantastic example of Gaudi's brilliance.

book on line to save queuing. The roof top is amazing and it is very interesting seeing the interior of the apartment . The museum part is perhaps not for everyone- our 2 sons were less excited by that - but loved walking round the roof. But do book on line to avoid queuing in the heat
Gaudi was ahead of his time!!. I wonder if Dr Seuss was inspired by Gaudi? Impressive in all aspects, design, engineering, energy efficiency attention to detail. Gaudi was way ahead of his time.

Favourite building by Gaudí. We went to Casa Milá before noon and purchased our tickets there. Even though there was only a small queue, it is probably best to buy your tickets in advance online. There is also a discount for students!Enjoy the beautiful architecture in the Modernisme style. Especially the rooftop is just jaw-dropping! Totally recommended.

A fascinating look at a Gaudi structure still in use today. We really enjoyed our tour of La pedrera. The lines were short, and we had no trouble touring throughout the site. Gaudi's vision and his history are reviewed as part of the tour, which was informative. The rooftop structures are fascinating - functional and works or art.

It is nice, especially to see the star wars original characters :-). It is nice to see the building from inside and to take some photos on top of the roof, with Segrada Familia at the background. Inside the building you will get to know part of Gaudi's history and designs.

Go to the museum shop first!. That's where you can have a glimpse of the center courtyard and, together with what you see from the outside, decide if you want to go in. My recommendation is if you are only planning and budgeting for one, go to casa batllo!

Brilliant design. Barcelona is often characterized as Gaudi's town, and La Pedrera is a perfect example of his unique combination of function and visually arresting design. Refurbished in the early 20th century to serve as an income producing residence for Gaudi (he rented out a number of apartments four floors of which are still rented out today), the "house" is most renowned for his artistic approach to the roof where he created unique sculptures to conceal chimneys and air vents. The facade of the building is also unique and must be seen even if you don't go in to the museum. Like his style or not, Gaudi's vision was like no other. Once you've seen one of his creations, you will have no problem identifying his signature approach elsewhere.
La Pedrera - an absolute must-do!. Fascinating architecture, great views from the roof and excellent internal information meant our family had a great couple of hours there.

Architectural Wonder. Gaudi's work is even more amazing in person. Casa Mila is full of imagination and intricate details. One can easily spend more than an hour exploring the roof! It's a world onto itself and feels like you are in a dream. Casa Mila is not to be missed when you visit Barcelona.

Get there early to get a good vantage point. During the day the fountains are usually off but the displays in the evenings are breathtaking. I would recommend getting there at least an hour early and the best views are from the bridges over the road at the front of the fountains. Both our 6 and 9 year olds got a decent view because we got there early enough to secure a good spot. I would not come later than 45 minutes before the show with anyone short as it gets very crowded. Well worth the wait though.
Πανάκριβο Expensive. The entrance costs 18.5 euros per person. Only the roof is something special. It is a touristic trap. Save your money for something better. Gaudi was smart but this is it.
Inside Gaudi Mind. A great way to see how Gaudi thought - well ahead of his time and this was a great experience to see this

Enjoy jazz on the roof at La Pedrera!. If you are lucky enough to visit in the summer on a Friday or Saturday, buy tickets for the Jazz on the Roof at La Pedrera. Tickets were 30 Euros and for another 10Euros you could visit the site from 3 PM to 7 PM. We enjoyed a beautiful summer evening on the roof listening to jazz and enjoying a glass of cava. Doors open at 8.15 and we began with a visit to the attic before heading up to the roof. There are no chairs but attendees sat on the roof stairs and along the walls. The music started at 9 and lasted about an hour. The sound set up was excellent. If the weather is good like it was when we visited, the roof is a magnificent place to take in the great city views and explore the architectural features of the top of La Pedrera. Totally recommend this as a way to extend your experience of La Pedrera.

Not-to-miss Gaudi gem. One must experience this magnificent gem designed by Antoni Gaudi and well worth the 20 Euro admission fee. To save time, you may want to book in advance, though I went on a Wednesday afternoon without any problem. The rooftop is magnificent--and look out for the way one of the rooftop arches frames the Sagrada Familia. It's best to step back a dozen meters for your photo vs. taking it under the arch itself (like everyone else does--therefore blocking the intended framing/view). In the restored attic, you will find some great exhibits about Gaudi's other famous landmarks and would be reason alone for a visit. The apartment interiors are well done and a glimpse into how residents lived in this landmark. The ground level courtyards are also a sight to behold.

A fun dose of secular Gaudi. Not comparable to the Sagrada Familia (which blows everything else out of the water), but a fine example of Gaudi's brilliance in a domestic building. The roof was fabulous (good views of the city, but it is the roof which was the star), and the attic and apartment were fascinating. It would be a mistake to go to Barcelona and miss this.

See this for incredible Architecture. If you are an architecture fan DON'T MISS THIS TOUR. You get to see the exterior, courtyard, rooftop and an original apartment on this audio guided tour. The rooftop was the most fascinating part.

Nice to be able to see it. The price appeared a little expensive, and would be more acceptable if they limited numbers as at Sagrada familia. Nevertheless the access is very good, from the roof, to the exhibits in the attic, and the apartment presented in period. The evocation of the period of construction is also God. This is a world heritage site and its presentation lives up to this. The gift shop is a bit of overkill and beware of the 'free' photo. You get a second photo free if you buy one for a tenner.

A must . What a fantastic place, from the outside you can only be inspired by the architects brilliance, whilst going inside and starting on the roof before working your way down it is such an eye opener to his brilliance.The views from the top are worth the entry fee alone, fast pass is probably the best way to avoid the lengthy queues

Night tour with rooftop show. Steep pricing as usual (34€) but it seemed worth it. We started in the interior court with an introduction, were guided through the museum in the attic, saw the light show on the roof and were invited for a glass cava in one of the interior courts at the end. You don't get to see the interiors on this tour. The show was a bit too much kitsch for my taste but overall it was a very special experience, probably my favorite of all Gaudi visits.
NIght tour!. This was a great way to see the building. You have the place to the small group tour. Interesting light show overlooking the city. Glass of champagne at the end.

An absolute MUST if you are going to Barcelona.. Visiting La Pedrera is an absolute must - Gaudi was a GENIUS! Ticket includes a visit to the incredible roof terrace and enormous attic museum, and an amazing tour of a fully restored flat, which has been fully furnished from early 1900s. Loved this, loved this, loved this! Great value for money. We went as a family (couple and teenage son) and found this fascinating, awesome and inspiring!

Beautiful day time visit. Did a walk in day time visit here, where you got a free headset to listen to. You are free to explore the building in your own time and the headset give you a brilliant insight into the stunning place. It was interesting and insightful to not just this building but other works by Gaudi. An all round good buy, excellent value for money. The staff here were all very helpful and happy to answer questions to the best of their knowledge. Would definitely recommend.
Worth a visit!. Fascinating architecture and interesting stories. Apparently George Lucas was found inspiration in this architecture for the architecture in Star Wars. We did not go inside.
beautiful architecture. La Pedrera is a must see building in Barcelona. The architecture is astonishing outside and you will definitely like the roof.
La Pedrera. Great place. Fascinating. Informative history of Gaudie. Seeing the roof is a must. Unique architecture. Can see Sacra Familia from the roof.
Should not be missed. Amazing experience. Never expected the VERY informative museum area, and was delighted by the apartment. It was expensive but I think it's a good value.
Such a beautiful place. A must if you're in Barcelona, one of the magical places you can visit.It's worth taking your tickets online, as you won't need to wait in line at the entrance.
Beautiful architecture. Lot of things to see here. Nice view from the roof and beautiful tour about Gaudi. Beautiful appartments inside.
Worth visit. La Pedrera is the Gaudi's art applied to a residential context. Striking the roof, interesting the museum in the attic and fantastic the apartment of the beginning '900. Worth visit

House is amazing, but the experience wasn't that great :/. Firstly, the house is amazing, and the tour guide really knew her stuff... But the night tour does not include a look through any of the apartments, which was a let down. The rooftop was a highlight, but the projection mapping was super lame - a very literal take on the history of the planet/s with very crappy stock video of time lapse plants growing etc, and nothing done with mapping the actual space at all. This location has such insanely cool architecture to work with, please get rid of this insulting work and give the job to a better projection company to make something truly worthwhile. Would recommend the day tour instead, it's cheaper and you'll get a look at the architecture in the apartments.

Magical . If you get a chance sign up for the night tour of La Perdrera the Gaudi house aka Casa Mila. It's a small group, great guides and an amazing view of the city and beautiful sculptures on the roof. One of my favorite experiences in Europe.
Amazing but expensive. It's unique and nice. Don't miss the roof and apartment. In my own opinion the ticket price is so high.
Beautiful Exterior. Did not go up to the roof top but beautiful from the street. Worth a visit. The architecture is just stunning. The balconies are beautiful, and the figures on top are interesting.

Beware Jazz Concerts at Le Pedrera. In addition to tours of the house, which are a highlight of visits to Barcelona, Le Pedrera offers occasional jazz and other concerts on its rooftop. The entry/exit to these concerts is horribly organized because there's only one public elevator and it holds a maximum of six or so people. Once you get to the roof, there are no seats so you're seating on backless steps or the floor. When the concert was over, Le Pedrera did not have sufficient staff on the roof to direct a smooth exit of the hundreds of people who attended. We were told we couldn't take the elevator down and were directed to a winding staircase that we had to walk down about 10 flights to the street. In the case of a fire or other emergency, this would have been bedlam and extremely dangerous. There are no provisions whatsoever for handicap access.

Great Experience. This was a very fun and interesting experience. I thought of aliens as the architecture seemed to give the feeling of "sci-fi" another planet. The tour was very informative and the roof top was "fantabulous"

Really neat modernist home. La Pedrera is one of the most well known homes in Barcelona. The exterior looks like a big stone structure, while the interior functions as a museum. The audio guided tour starts on the roof, then proceeds down into a museum area where you can learn about the architect and the home he produced. This tour is not quite as good as the tour of Casa Batllo, but still worth your time in my opinion.
Unique. The unique building. One of Gaudi's creations. Indeed the feeling of touching the nature through architecture. A lot of interesting details that can be seen for a long time
go!. there is a day tour and a night tour. this building is pretty expensive to visit but worth it. the night show was really cool but strange lol. its especially good for photographers.
Beautilful chimneys. The chimneys are beutiful, and the view from the roof is good. Worth a visit. We didn't buy tickets in advance for this, but the line wasn't too long.

Definitely stop during your Barcelona visit. We visited La Pedrera after finishing the Barcelona Architecture Walking Tour. With our enriched knowledge of Gaudi and Barcelona from the tour, visiting La Pedrera was the perfect finish to our afternoon. Line up seemed long but quickly moved. Entrance was expensive, however I am fine with that when it is maintaining an architectural gem.
Omg. This place was beyond fantastic. You feel like you are walking into another world. The roof top is spectacular and you get a great 360 view of the city.

La Pedrera. After the Sacred Family Temple, La Pedrera is the second place most visited in Barcelona , designed by Antonio Gaudí as Parc Güell;Casa Batlló, and other espectacular buildings.Nobody coming to Barcelona, misses this visit ,due the incredible and special designa of Mr Gaudí with Marble and iron, and the interiors .Is very well located in Pº de Gracia, that is a central avenue full of shopping places, and also other monuments

Yet another stunning Gaudi experience. This was designed and built from the ground up with Gaudi's input evident everywhere.Worth a visit to see how people would have lived in this building at the time when it was constructed - good testimonial museum on site in recognition of Gaudi's achievements and influences. Amazing construction with interesting history with its own controversy during construction.

Gaudí created the Barcelona style...a. We are two couples, about 50 years old, that lived in Barcelona since we were born, but no one of us have visited La Pedrera before. We have travelled together most of the European capitals, and now, visiting this amazing building we have realized that our city is one of the prettiest. We enjoyed very much our visit and we strongly recomend to everyone who come to our town. We love Barcelona.
Interesting. Worth to buy ticket skip the queue lovely room to see with Gaudi chimneys and places where he eats, sleep and lives. Really beautiful place lots to see.

Fantastic, don't miss .. This was a fantastic building to visit and is hard to believe how someone could have the imagination to build it. There is some fascinating displays and information in the attic ...so well worth the visit.

Fabulous architeture. My two children ( 11, 13,) and I visited La Pedrera during our short stay in Barcelona. We spent nearly two hours exploring and learning (via the audio headset and exhibits) about his amazing building. My son preferred the rooftop, with the fantastic views and attic to the apartment itself. Top tip, buy the tickets in advance on line, which I didn't do initially. We naively just turned up and the queues and time slots meant we couldn't go in. However it was well worth going back .

Gaudi's masterpiece. A stunning building in the heart of the city, with beautiful views over the city. At 20€ entrance fee a bit steep if you have a family, but the quality of the experience is mind-blowing. As with all of Gaudi's buildings, a lot of tourists ( the taxi driver said that Barcelona gets 9 million visitors a year (he may have been exaggerating?) The roof top is an amazing place, and if you wait long enough you can get pictures of the sculptures without other tourists walking in front of you.An excellent afternoon spent exploring the thoughts and creations of Antoni Gaudi.

Incredible architecture. I loved La Pedrera. The architecture is strange but incredible. We went late in the afternoon and didn't have to wait to buy a ticket. The audio tour is informative. Once inside, it's hot, especially in the attic, but the chimney pots on the roof are worth seeing in person and the views of the surrounding city are incredible.
Amazing creativity. This is one of the must see spots in Barcelona. Admiring how so many years ago an artist had such modern minded creativity.

Jazz night amazing. Thanks to prior reviews I heard of the weekend jazz concerts. We booked that instead of a day tour. We could still see some of the building inside and we could really enjoy the terrace at sunset and take in all of the amazing shapes in the architecture while sipping champagne.

Amazing!. Again, after Sagrada, Parc Guell, Casa Batllo, the hunt for Gaudi buildings... This La Pedrera is also known as Casa Mila. Truly stunning when it's in front of you, pictures/images is completely different.

Surprisingly good for kids.. We ended up in here by accident as we got into Barcelona early and our tickets for Sagrada familia weren't for a couple of hours. We got the audio tour and were surprised at how much our kids, and we, enjoyed it. The roof terrace is marvelous and quirky to keep the kids interested and the tour of one of the flats was interesting enough to keep them engaged. A very nice morning was had by all.Very random and they provide free lockers for bags if you want to use them, really handy.
must see!. This place is charming by itself, you must visit all the building if you are going to Barcelona. The views from the top are amazing.

Waste of money. We arrived at 7:30pm and when we were half way round we were told we had 10 mins left so had no more time to look at the rest of the house. I would have been fine with this had we been told at the start that we had 1 hour to complete our visit but we were not.

Fascinating experience . I have visited this building many times and always find it exhilarating. We bought tickets in advance to avoid the queues and found this to be easy to do and effective when we got there. The audio systems are simple to use and provide great information about the building and although it was very busy this did not impact on our visit. The wavy roof is my favourite bit and the views are spectacular

Gaudi masterpiece. Book your tickets for this as early as possible to avoid the crowds and be able to enjoy the beauty of the building in all serenity. The entrance fee is quite expensive so you want to take the most out of it.The building is very beautifully designed, very unconventional with intriguing forms and shapes. A lot of interesting information is available that you should certainly read. Make sure you have seen every corner or the house. Go through it at your own pace and take your time to marvel at all the unusual structures.
cool place. Check it out, it is pretty cool the place especially the roof. You wont be disappointed. The building is an actual working building with offices.

Very interesting to see! it is a must!. This is one of Gaudi's amazing architectural creations! and it is nothing short from incredible! The rooftop is the highlight of the whole place, highly recommend to grab one of the audio guides to really soak in all the details and history of this place! Gaudi really was a very detail oriented and imaginative person. I was amazed to learn about his ergonomic techniques inspired by nature for all his creations and this one shows that very well! If you buy the city tour bus ticket you can get a discount for this attraction and the bus stops right in front of the building. I really enjoyed La Pedrera!

Stunning. This is a stunning, must see attraction in the centre of Barcelona. The visit takes you through the house, but it is the roof that s truly breathtaking. With a good view, and astonishing surroundings it is tempting to spend the majority of your visit on the roof, but the tour through the rest of the building is both interesting and informative, though not as spectacular as the rooftop!
Incredible home. Yep its a residence still! The visit to La Pedrera was incredible. He didn't have a straight wall in the place! Be sure to go to the rooftop to see the beautiful Barcelona city!

Casa Mila was my favorite Gaudi creation in Barcelona. The exterior, the rooftop, and the restored apartment were all amazing. I love the fact that the rooftop chimneys were the inspiration for George Lucas' storm troopers in the movie Star Wars.

beautiful but expensive. Probably the most famous (ex) residential building in the World designed by you-know-who. Beautiful all round with interesting hall and staircase paintings and stunning roof. But, at 20 Euro, I'd say it is for Gaudi die-hards only.

Incredible building . Hugely interesting tour round the building the roof, attic and appartment. Well worth the visit. The swooping curves providing a feast for the eyes and cool respite from the harsh August sun. The exhibits of Gaudis work in the attic and a chance to see the ribs of the roof were fascinating.

This Gaudi man is amazing!. What amazing architecture on the roof of this building. Strongly recommend going in so you can go to rooftop to enjoy the various structures and views. Buy tickets online to skip the line.
Simply beautiful. Took a self guided tour with audio aid. The architecture is stunning. The use of designs from nature, colors and textures, all combine for a delightful visual experience.

Night tour disappointing.. My teenage boys loved this night time tour. They were lured by the light show and the possibility of sneaking a bit of the cava that was given at the end! The tour booked for 10pm was just too big, you couldn't hear the tour guide properly and it felt rushed like they wanted to get home. There were some interesting bits in the attic but you weren't able to see these as you had to keep up with the pace of the guide. All in all a bit disappointing given the cost, I would have liked to have seen it in the day for a comparison.

Fascinating place to visit. This is a fascinating tour, even if you know little about Guadi. From the roof downwards, there was interesting information given. It took well over an hour to see everything and the time flew past. The audio guide is free unlike some attractions which was a bonus.There are lucky people who still live there!
Visit here first. Visit here before visiting and Gaudi developments. Here you can learn the history, inspiration, and techniques behind what makes Gaudi's work more than just a building.

Classic example of Gaudi architecture inc visit to flat. Barcelona is full of the works of Gaudi & la Pedrera is an excellent example. From the outside you can instantly see it is a unique work & make sure you take some pictures before you go inside. It is well worth paying to visit inside the building where you walk around an actual apartment that Gaudi designed. The tour takes you through a museum and up onto the roof where the tone giant sculptures reside that are clear from outside. There is a shop & cafe.
Art and vision. It is a must see for Gaudi fans or those that enjoy architecture. Allows for the creative juicies to fly and imagine the vision of Gaudi.

Stunning, especially the roof area. If you like the architecture of Gaudi, then this is one to have on your visit list. While most of the building is occupied by businesses and private tenants the roof area and one of the apartments can be visited. the apartment is set out as a museum and is interesting but the roof is spectacular and worth the entrance fee.

Wonderful location for an afternoon of Jazz. We were staying across the road and heard a band playing and decided to go have a look see. It was a Jazz afternoon with a few artists playing on the top rooftop of La Pedrera. I am not sure how often this happens but we had a great time and were lucky enough to enjoy La Pedrera at the same time.

So artistic and unique. Like nothing else I've seen. Feels like a fantasy house, like you are in a dream. Lots of info about Gaudi. Great views from the rooftop and can admire the interesting chimneys up close.

It was interesting. I was here after Casa Battlo, that's why it wasn't so breathtaking as it could be. I'd put one more star for visit if there would be more advanced audio/video guide. But in any case very interesting building and very impressive roof. I'd recommend to visit this place.
Brilliant. Antoni Gaudi's Brilliant work ; worth visiting ; there is a free audio ; u can buy a gift from the shop inside
Rooftastic. Antonio Gaudi - crazy roofs, crazy guy! Another must see Gaudi masterwork from the main man in Catalan.

More interesting than Casa Batllo. I found the rooftop architecture at La Pedrera more interesting the what I saw at Casa Batllo. Not very crowded at midday and decent views of the city on the rooftop.

Check out the chimneys!. One of Gaudi's most architecturally impressive buildings with incredibly distinctive chimneys - and the roof area really does steal the show, with its stunning views of the city and the amazing chimneys set against the bright blue Barcelona sky! Much of the rest of the building is still in use as apartments but you can descend from the roof to see an displays of Gaudi's buildings and some apartments that have been set up as they would have been when the building was new. We got there early in the morning and already had tickets but when we passed later in the day it seemed much busier - so I'd definitely pre-booking tickets if you can. Absolutely loved it here!

Gaudi's Masterpiece Combines Art and Architecture. This private home and apartment building was built between 1906 and 1912, yet still feels fresh and modern. Purchase tickets on-line in advance to avoid long lines. We went first thing in the morning, and lines were much lighter than when we left mid-morning. You take and elevator to the whimsical and other-worldly roof for good views of Barcelona. Then you take the stairs down to the Gaudi's exhibit in the attic, to one of the sample apartments furnished as it might have been in Gaudi's time (4 of the apartments are lived in by actual people!) and to a temporary exhibit space on the 2nd floor (1st floor to Europeans) which was not open when we visited. The audio guide is included in the ticket price, and really helps to explain what you are seeing. We took about 90 minutes in all, but you could do it faster.

La Pedrera is a must-visit when in Barcelona. A UNESCO Heritage Site, La Pedrera, or Casa Mila, was the last residential building designed by Antoni Gaudi. A tour through the building starts at the roof, then in the attic with an exhibit of Gaudi's life and work, and includes a tour of one of the apartments, decorated in the style of the 1800s.

Good day out. . Really enjoyed this. Book in advance to avoid the queues and take advantage of the free audio guides as it is sooooooooo interesting to listen all about gaudi. Avoid going at midday as it can get very crowded!

Not as expected . Perhaps the wonderful experience of Sagrada Familia basilica had spoiled us, but our visit to this earlier work if Gaudi failed to excite or impress usYes the architecture is unusual and one can see his thinking but the manner or the experience was full, the staff unengaged with visitors, the "free" photo in impressively costing a minimum of 10€ to secure it, and all in all we wished it was over when only halfway round, with a rather boring exhibition in the vaulted attic.I am a civil engineer and love my architecture - so that too tells me this was not displayed well for the public to properly and excitedly engage. A monochromatic flat experience of architecture that is 3 D technicolor in reality. Does not do Gaudi (or Barcelona as a city) justice ...

La Pedrera. There are so many sculptures to see as well as artifacts of the day that we purchased a book to understand what it is that you are looking at. Very well done and you are free to walk around the top 3 floors as there are people living on the other floors. The roof is awesome to see all the sculptures. There is a reasonable cost to enter.
Pretty good for observing. The building looks well designed and beautiful. It should be visited while traveling Barcelona. I wonder know, why people called it la pedrera

A good way to see Gaudi's work of art.... We came here after we could not get into Sagrada Familia.. which we did the following day...The audio tour is helpful in understanding the design and the overall building. Take your time to immerse yourself in the art of design.

Must see for Gaudi lovers. Another excellent place to visit if you are a fan of Gaudi, although I would suggest Casa Batllo if you were only to see 1. It did have a lot more info on some of the other gaudi works through the house but slightly less impressive. They were also much more flexible about letting you in outside of your designated time frame. (We showed up to both here and la sagrada familia about 30 minutes late and the people here were very accepting and allowed us in whereas the sagrada familia turned us away)

Such a lot packed in to a small space. La Pedrera we nearly missed. We were "all Gaudi'd out" having been to other spots. But once we walked there from down town we couldn't do with just seeing it from the roadside. I'm so glad we went in. What a marvellous place.Watch your step as you come out onto the roof as the steps aren't even heights and I went flying.There was much that we heard in the audio from doing other Gaudi attractions but really I was so glad that we visited.
Gaudi, the genius. This is absolutely mesmerizing. It sure is impressive from the outside, but a visit to the terraces is worth every cent. Can't admire Gaudi enough!

The terrace is amazing, a fantasy world!. What is very amazing is the terrace, with its stairwells, ventilation shafts and chimnies. Even though each one has a functional role, its shape is symbolic and opened at different intepretations. It is not possible to visit the building completely, because it is mostly private, but it is possible to visit the attic and one flat. The attic contains a Gaudi museum and the flat, with its furniture, gives a complete vision of Gaudi as a furniture designer. The online ticket management has been very effective avoiding the long lines.At the entrance a check in with metal detector is required, each bag has to be put in a locked wardrobe with a deposit of one euro. It is possible to take pictures during the visit. The audioguides even though are not smart guides work very well!
Jazz on the rooftop was amazing!. We visited for live jazz on the rooftop in August, with cava included. It was a fantastic experience - highly recommended.

Not as much of a "wow" but still magnificent. We visited Palau Guell first and were expecting La Pedrera to be even more exciting. It was worth seeing, but based on other reviews and the exterior of Casa Batllo, we probably would have enjoyed seeing the inside of that home more than La Pedrera. Regardless, if you're visiting Barcelona and have time to see them all, La Padrera is definitely worth the visit, as is Palau Guell (it was awesome!).

Gaudi Genius. Not withstanding the fact that Gaudi was a genius, this tour was one of the most organized and informative tours that I have taken (and I travel a lot) If you go, and you should, go early on the first tour of the day.The tour starts with the roof top figures which oddly look like figures from Star Wars. The level below explains much about Gaudi and how the building was built. There are videos of other Gaudi buildings in case you were unable to see them all.Lastly, you can tour a replica of one of the apartments. Don't miss the gift shop.

Love Gaudi, but this is not worth the money. I have been to Barcelona 3 times before and love everything about the city. I was keen to show my teenagers all the buildings I have loved over the years.They are now charging 20 euros just to enter the house and see the roof, an attic space and a reconstructed apartment. Not worth the money. The Sagrada Famillia is only 15! If you go to Barcelona take a look at everything else but save your money and give this one a miss.

La Pedrera is still worth the visit.. I, love it. I wouldn't necessarily say this is a good deal, but it's a unique tour, as you get to see the first floor, staircases, attic, and roof of one of the famous Modernisme buildings in Barcelona.

Must see. A must see for anymore visiting Barcelona. Beautiful and presented well through a headset that you control yourself and can replay sections of you wish. The rooftop which you see first is incredible and provides an unmissable view of the city. Only downside is the charge of €20,50 for each person which I though was a bit steep for what we saw

Ok, but as not good as Casa Batllo. The only thing worth to see is the chimneys on the rooftop. There is very little to see inside. We think Casa Batllo is better if you have to decide between the twos.

Top notch!. Very cool Gaudi building still in use today. This one is not quite as "crazy" as Casa Batlló or as majestic as Sagrada Familia (but honestly, what can compare?) however La Pedrera offers a different experience as they show authentic view on that priod of time - realistically furnished to help you immerse yourself. The attic also serves as a Gaudi museum offering insights into his life and his works. La Pedrera is close enough to Casa Batlló so you can visit both of them in one day. See Casa Batlló first then head over to tour La Pedrera and score off both Gaudi icons in 2-3 hours.
Fantastic sculptures on the roof terrace. You should not miss it. I have visited Casa Mila/La Pedrera four times! If you buy the tickets online you don't have to wait for the entrance.
I love Gaudi, but not worth the price. It is unfortunate that La Pedrera charges 20.50 Euros per person to enter. The Louvre only charges 15! We didn't see the value for the money.
WAOUW. Don't miss it if you are in Barcelona :o)) It is a great place for all type of people...families...couples.... :o))
More Gaudi. If you are going to visit one Gaudi site it is with doing them all. Again pre book and have the audio tour. We preferred Casa Bastilo but Lauren Pedrera ties it all together.

Gaudi's vision . Visiting Barcelona for just a few days, we wanted to see something to show us Gaudi's genius and this was a great choice. The tour starts on the roof, which is other worldly, then there is an excellent exhibition on the more technical details of the building. For our kids (aged 14 and 11) it was enough to keep them interested. We bought our tickets on-line to skip the queue. Afterwards we ate in the restaurant on the ground floor and thought the food excellent value.
Unique experience. What a genius Gaudi was! The explanation of how he designed his buildings using geometry was fascinating. Very aesthetically pleasing and unique. A must-see.
Beautiful and unique architecture. Must see place when visiting Barcelona, Spain. Go for both day time and night time tours. The light and sound presentation at night is really unique and awesome.

A Fascinating Evening. Our group of 7 adults arranged the evening tour followed by the light show on the roof culminating in cocktails in the lobby. This was an evening well-spent. The building is marvellous, needless to say, and the tour was worthwhile, but the best part was the intriguing and thought-provoking film and light show on the roof at night. Quite unique, just like Gaudi himself.

La Pedrera - a must to visit. One of Gaudi's great designs. The house is amazing especially at roof level where you can experience wonderful views over Barcelona. The roof level is filled with superbly designed chimneys and ventilation shafts.As you descend the staircases and explore the various rooms you can experience Gaudi's amazing architectural and designer skills. Thoroughly recommended.

Disability review. Lots of reviews as to why you should visit but just thought I'd pop in that:I used the attractions complimentary wheelchair and all staff were very disabled friendly and enabling. Ensured I was okay - got to see as much as I could - held doors open for the clean disabled loo - spoke to me and not to my husband as often happens - with a discounted price. You also get to use the buildings original lift which was a real bonus and stunning and not used by the public. It's not an easy building to navigate by its very nature but I was very impressed with staff attitude to help me get the most out of my visit.

Great house...... Another of Gaudi great works, it deserves a visit. Great designed inside and out. I much rather enjoyed the outside of the building. But of course being a masterpiece by Gaudi you have to see it.....

Very enjoyable visit. On our last afternoon in Barcelona we visited La Pedrera and pleased we did. Very well organised and an amazing house with lots of interesting facts from the Audio Information. The roof is particularly impressive with some good views of Barcelona. Not the cheapest of attractions but wouldn't call it expensive as such. Do check it out, an ideal just been kicked out of the Hotel, what do we do before we head off to airport?! Tour takes about 90 mins.

Amazing on the inside too.. We really enjoyed the self guided tour inside La Pedrera. We had walked by the outside a few times and were not sure what could add to just looking at the outside. There is so much more to see on the inside. Loved being on the rooftop.

Perfect Overview of Gaudi. I was initially reluctant to pay 20 Euros for this exhibit, but I took a risk based on the reviews here and am happy that I did. It was a great way to see Gaudi's work. The rooftop architecture was amazing and gave you a great view of La Segrada and other historical sites. We got some great pictures and learned about Gaudi in general not just focused on La Pedrera.

Impressive . A very impressive building, some great photograph opportunities in the roof, lovely interior and includes a guided tour, stunning from the outside, which is free! If you only have time for one of these buildings I would choose Palau Guall which is cheaper, quieter and just as impressive.

Summer jazz concert on the roof. What a treat... The Gaudi building has summer nights of jazz....right on the roof, seeing as far as the ocean with fabulous sunset. A real treat. Hint, get there as early as you can to get a good seat; you have to perch on steps.
Wonderful architecture. We loved the building, in particular walking on the roof and admiring the different shapes. The audioguide gives good explanations about Gaudi and his work.

Courtyard & Roof are must sees. It's one of Barcelona's top ten attractions and doesn't disappoint. The courtyard is so much better in real life and then the roof just blows your mind. This is really well managed and includes fascinating architectural details and models of not only this building but also of Casa Battlo and La Sagrada Familia.

Over prices and no real taste.... Short lunch with my 16 year old daughter. It took some time before we were given the menues. Sat outside - nice. Ordered a salad. Fresh, but no taste at all. Centrally located with a perfect view of the building La Pedrera, but not worth it.

A remarkable architectural and historical experience. A must see in Barcelona. One of Gaudi's most important works. It was very surprising to know that the place is actually a residence. The tour should take between 45 minutes to 1 hour 30 minutes, but it is worth every minute. Make sure to book online to avoid any delays at the entrance and try to go there very early (recommended between 9am and 10:30am). Also make sure to spend some time listening to the audio guide (unfortunately my wife and I couldn't do that properly since our 2 year old son was us and needed constant attention).

A masterwork. Thus house is Gaudis penultimate work and it really displays all via skills and the experience he gathered over the years.Not all the furniture is original but a lot of it is. The audio guide also tells you about the intentions of certain designs, for example ergonomic reasons. You also get to go to the rooftop which gives a nice view of the Passeig de Gracia and of some parts of the city.This house is 100% worth the visit.
To do.... You are flying between past and future... Even with a 5 yo kid, it was more than interesting... Just the price a bit expensive...

Summer 2016. Be sure to get your tickets early. The place also has a daytime tix as well as a night time tix that illuminates certain parts which is a whole different feel. Be prepared to walk about and only stairs going down. You can feel and touch things. The place is handicap accessible to most of the area.

v interesting and visually appealing. attended with four teens. they were interested for about ten minutes but soon wanted to go shopping. apart from them i enjoyed it. The audio guides are good and the place is well maintained. The roof top loses a bit of its appeal with a lot of safety wire but i suppose that is necessary. We booked online and so had no queue.
Lindo. Incredible architecture, lots of detail in it, de opted to their work really, you have to see it to believe it, piece by piece put together great visit
Still great, but not like Casa Batlló . We went to casa batlló first and that was a mistake, after that everything is a little disappointing. But that said, La Pedrera is still worth the visit.

Amazing Roof!. The roof at La Pedrera is amazing, best part of the tour. Audio guide gives you enough information to find out about Gaudi's creations. The apartment is very interesting and allows you to see how the Milo family would have lived.

Beautiful Gaudi art. We did the summer combo appartment, terrace and concert on roof terrace and we were really happy with it! I think the terrace is the most amazing part of it! Especially at sunset when you can see some beautiful landscape of the city. The concert wasn't that great but hey, I'm not a Jazz expert! Am I? Fun fact: Star Wars stormtroopers mask look like the chemeneys on the roof terrace!

La Pedrera. This was an interesting visit, well organised and with good time to experience the venue. It is an apartment block, much of the building is still in use, consequently,you only really get an impression of what it would have been like to have lived there. The atrium is beautiful and the roof and views from the roof are astonishing. There is an exhibition in the roof area which is very interesting and gives a lot of information about Gaudi, his life and work.

Marvellous. My third time visiting here, It's like a playground for adults. Very fun to roam around and appealing to the senses. Very visually stimulating, as with all of Gaudí's word. The exhibitions inside are very interesting.A very beautiful place on the whole. Priceless for those who love architecture.

Fun and interesting. I suggest you buy premium ticket online to avoid the waiting. There is no schedule in it, you can go whenever it's convenient for you and you instantly skip the line. The roof was fun to explore, the displays in the attic were very interesting and the apartment was just awesome. This is a must-see in Barcelona.
So unique. Great visit, did buy the ticket at the door using their WiFi, we save a lot of time doing that. Was more fun do visit than Casa Batllo.
Surrealism Incarnated. The La Pedrera epitomizes the surreal architecture of Gaudi fame. The guides were superb and the light show at night was dazzling.

Enjoyable and interesting, but overpriced. I went to three Gaudi sites while in Barcelona: this one, Sagrada Familia, and Park Guell. Although I enjoyed La Pedrera, I have to say it seemed over-priced for the experience. The rooftop (and view) is probably the most interesting and exciting part of the building, with the apartment and it's furnishings coming in second. Sagrada Familia and Park Guell are better value for your money, but true Gaudi fans will not be disappointed.

Brilliant architectural experience . I have visited Casa Batlo on a previous visit. The rooftop here at La Pedrera was a mesmerising example of creative brilliance given the era it was built. You see more of the interior designs of Gaudi in Casa Batlo but the audio guide is very informative and gives a details history of the building.

Adds great understanding to Guadi's work. This is an apartment building and most of the residences are still occupied. One is open to the public and again shows Gaudi's vision and imagination. Perhaps most spectacular are both the working models in the attic and the chains he used to visualize his creations. The rooftop is a lesson for all architects in how to make the mundane into something special. Buy an advance ticket so you do not have to wait hours to get in.

Do before Casa Batllo. This is not half as impressive as Casa Batllo, so of you have to choose, do not ho here, or go here first. The rooftop and attic is interesting. It os so central so if you do not have to wait for tickets, go quickly.

Mediterranean Cruise Layover. Hotels offer advance ticket sales with slight discount - helps avoid long lines outside. Very interesting architecture and learned about the Gaudi - an architect ahead of his time! Great views from the roof top, the attic was like a museum with different artifacts and videos. Took about 2 hours to go through.

Incredible!! Fascinating!!. La Pedrera is a must!I am so glad I bought two tours to visit this place. We went during the day, and then at night. They have a fabulous tour at night where you can see a multimedia exhibition which is beautiful. I spent about 4 hours in the afternoon at La Pedrera. Please get the audio tour or a guided tour. We had the audio tour and I learned soooo much. Had I not had the audio, I wouldn't have enjoyed it as much. It's a must!Gaudi was just a genius!!! I enjoyed every second I spent at this incredible place. It is wonderful!I could have spent a lot more time, but we already had reservation for another tour, so I couldn't stay more. So, give yourself enough time to enjoy this magnificent place!

3 Visits in 1: Amazing Modernist building with a rooftop to remember, and a highly interesting interior.... We turned up without pre-booking at La Pedrera on a particularly hot July day (almost 30 degrees), but thankfully the queue on the side street put us in the shade, and was moving fairly quickly. If you're reading this before a visit, however, I'd recommend jumping the queue by booking a fast pass beforehand.The building - like everything Gaudi has created in Barcelona - is wonderful: amazing, thought-provoking and delightful to visit. The tour starts back-to-front by ascending firstly to the roof (long queues for the elevator, but the climb up the stairs isn't too bad!). Make sure first to have a good look up from ground level through the large atrium towards the roof; you'll be able to contrast the view looking back down very shortly afterwards!The roof of La Pedrera is what most people visit for. It's an explosion of different shapes, concepts and expressions which changes constantly as you move up, down and around the many surfaces. We found the whole experience slightly dizzying - there are no straight edges anywhere! - so take a minute to sit down and absorb the whole scene, plus the amazing views out over the streets of Barcelona and beyond to the hills and sea.Coming inside, you'll descend one floor into the attic, which in itself is fascinating to wonder around - it has multiple cantilever arches built entirely from brick which are wonderful to look at as they overlap into the dimly-lit interior.The attic houses a very interesting exhibit about Gaudi, some of his designs, pictures of Barcelona around that period and his amazing workshop. For me, it was utter conflict (in a good way) between wandering around enjoying the ceiling, and paying attention to the excellent exhibits on display. I would quite happily pay the entrance fee to visit this again.Another floor down, and we step back in time into a fully-preserved period apartment, giving a wonderful insight into how the wealthy inhabitants lived in those days.Each one of these three wholly-different experiences are worth the entrance fee on its own! The visit is self-guided, with an audio guide included, so you can choose your own pace to wander around and absorb as much as you wish. La Pedrera is much bigger than Casa Batllo and felt much less crowded as a result.If you have the time, buy the combined ticket for a day time visit and the illuminated night time show. If you're not sure and just want to purchase the day time ticket first, you'll have a chance to upgrade for the discounted combined price on the ground floor at the end of the visit, before you leave. We didn't have time for this on our trip, but I would definitely make time for it on a future visit - we will definitely return and re-visit La Pedrera when we next get the chance!If you're shopping for gifts for people back home, the gift shop on the ground floor has a great range of Gaudi-inspired, good-quality items, for a unique taste of Barcelona.Highly recommended.

Really interesting place . One of most famous buildings by Gaudí, it's definitely worth the visit for the amazing rooftop and the views to city. Although I find casa Batllo a lot more interesting and better. So if you have to decide began both of them, go with Batllo! As a building is a lot more interesting and beautiful, and there are a lot more things to see there.

Disappointed after visit. I went to the Pedrera with high expectations after visiting Casa Batlo and the Sagrada Familia as well... We went early in the morning (09.30 o clock) and there was no line so we bought our tickets witch where even more expensive than the tickets for Sagrada Familia!!The roof is very interested and as in the pictures shown, but the inside is not very interested.... I had higher expectations of this place.

Best roof I have ever seen. This was a tour that you listened to through headphones but I would say this was more of a museum type tour rather than a tour of a house but the chimneys on the roof were spectacular and mesmerising and would have paid the money just for the roof tour.

Absolutely Amazing.. This building was the one i enjoyed most in Barcelona, even more than la Sagrada Familia. It is far superior to Casa Batllo. The apartment at the top with the furnitures of that era was excellent. The day&night tour costs 40 euros while the day tour costs 20. I strongly recommend buying the day&night. At night the roof is even more magical, and our tour guide was very entertaining. It worths the extra 20.

Don't miss Gaudí's masterpiece.... Or any other Gaudí . Gorgeous. Went around 5:00 pm (?) and the sun was going down on the roof... Maybe it was later... and the audio was really good. Also check out the gift shop...Gaudí is my favorite architect and I was Not disappointed. So inspiring.
fascinating. must see and appreciate the genius that is gaudi!self guided tour really lays it all out for you + theviews from the top are great!

Another beautiful Gaudi work!. We had a wonderful time exploring La Pedrera. The rooftop structures are fascinating (and were the inspiration for George Lucas' storm trooper helmets) and the views were great too. We loved seeing an example of an apartment inside as well, and the models and exhibits on display was very interesting. The colors in the central courtyard were incredible. I love Gaudi's work and I'm glad I didn't miss this one!

Great place to see, but overpriced (and poor audio-guide). Of course the place is great, but I have two serious reservations:- value: the entry ticket is more expensive than the one to the Sagrada Familia. To me this is not justified (especially when considering that the Sagrada Familia construction probably costs more than the maintainance of this building!).- audio-guide is hard to use, as the numbers (that you are supposed to dial on the device when you are at specific places) are not always quite visible (poor signing)

Wonderfully place. Expensive for what you get. The place is amazing and the guide is good. Even when the show is really good I found it too expense for what you get.At the end you see the hall, the attic and a roof. The 10 minutes or less show in the roof and that is it. They add a glass of wine to justify what you pay..I will glad they modify pricing in the future to allow everybody see the gaudi legacy

Inspiritational Gaudi. La Pedrera is a must see if you like Modernism or not. It is totally unique and outstanding in its architecture and imagination. Gaudi's architecture is so enchanting, that we wished we had more time in Barcelona to see more of his work. We used the headphones to do a self tour, and pre-booked this online. This will save you lots of time not having to join the queue as you get allocated a special entrance area. The roof is just as amazing as the apartment is to experience and there is an exhibition in the roof space which is also educational.

don't go. Huge waste of money. If it had be free or like 10-20 euro maybe it would have been worth it. You do not see any of the apartments and the best best is when you walk in. After that it sucks. Nothing was really preserved so you cant see much and there are no old pictures to see what it was like back when it was new. The light show is also a waste. Barcelona has so much more to offer.

Extraordinary building . Worth a visit to see the inside of the building. You're allowed to see the roof, the attic and the apartment. The roof was slightly challenging for me with vertigo, but made it round. The architecture is beautiful. Takes about an hour and a half to go round.

great place to visit .feels space age and amazing views. definitely place to see and do the opera nights ..amazing on a beautiful summers night..long ques some times ,but go later on in day when not so busy ..great views of this anazing city

Loved it. Great example of modernisma architecture and design by the architect who has been said to have built Barcelona .. Gaudi. Great exhibition, audio guide was informative and interesting, it was very much worth the visit. Book tickets online to avoid the queue. Visiting takes around 1.5 h total with the audio. Lovely building. Would highly recommend

Excellent especially if interested in engineering and/or architecture . Another amazing building full of history and innovative architecture. A visit to Barcelona would not be complete without coming here.
very good experience. Superb terrace with beautiful chimney architectural Gaudi and superb city views.Dont't miss this experience

First impression. Very satisfied with a visit to La Pedrera. For the unprepared visitor the exposition is very informative and comprehensive as it gives a visual representation of the work of Gaudí and the time in which he worked.
MAKE TIME TO VISIT. We paid for the premium tour - with an audio guide and it was worth doing this to understand how special this house is in many ways.
Amazing Gaudí again. Same street but bigger than Casa Batllo, another masterpiece of great architect and builders too. Great to see it and touch it :)

Wonderful architectural gem . This was our 2 nd visit to Barcelona and this time we booked our tickets online . In so doing we avoided waiting in long line at entranceOur tickets came with self guiding tour which was very informative Unfortunately there were some very obnoxious tourists that spent long times posing and looking at the pictures they'd taken making the visit very trying at times
Amazing. Superb audio tour guide of this magnificent building. The roof terrace is a must see. Fascinating insight into Gaudi's inspiration and process with informative, friendly and helpful staff.

Too expensive!. 34€ for a simple tour to the museum in the attic and a simple projection (by night) of animations on the roof (which was not worth it). That's way too expensive (even if a glass of cava was "offered" a the end of the visit)!Prefer go to La Pedrera by day... Or simply skip it.

Living Art. La Pedrera also known as Casa Mila was Antonio Gaudi's last commissioned civil work built from 1906-1912. It is rather simple in contrast to some of his other exteriors but still maintains the fluid architectural lines he is famous for. Going inside offers a glimpse of early modern "apartment" style living as you can go into a unit that remains much as it was in the early days of this building which stands as a deficit Gaudi Apartment building where people do live today. Less fantasy and more modern reality than some of the other sites and well worth the visit for the contrast.
Very nice architecture. Great place. Very interesting to look from the outside. Can fit to a visit in pasage la Garcia. Gaudi's good piece
Fascinating fact-filled tour of amazing building. The tour gives you insights into Gaudi's methods and philosophy of architecture. The building, inside and out, is stunningly beautiful.

I wish I had more time to explore this building. I was very short on time and was only able to view the exterior of this large building. From viewing other photos, the rooftop looks great. It's close enough to Casa Batllo that you can walk from one to the other. I would budget more time for both sites on the next visit. At least 2 hours for each to view the exterior and interior.

Rooftop concert - yes!. We attended a live jazz concert on the rooftop of la pedrera - a glass of champagne, beautiful jazz, the sunset from a 360 degree view of the city - take someone you love and enjoy!
Roof to extraordinaire. Attended their Saturday Jazz on the roof Concert and enjoyed every moment sipping cava, dancing, enjoying the quartet and the views.

Bravo! La Pedrera. Don’t be confuse this place has an event at night that is different than the daytime. The prices are different.I went during the day just around twilight and got to experience the daytime with a feel of what it would be like to see it at night.If you can buy the premium day pass on line, that way you get to be escorted in front of a lot of people and not wait in line. There is a different entrance for us, they will ask you and direct you. I went early to find out how it worked and came back later that day. Plus you get to avoid the crowds of people on the elevator. That’s the way I rolled at this place and it was worth it. I was close to one of the last groups of people to leave that evening. They had to graciously remind us to leave as the gift store closes at night and that is where the day tour ends. Tips: get pass online and get the audio well worth it!

Worth a visit. We visited La Pedrera on our trip to Barcelona. We wandered up only intending to look from the outside but were enticed in by the beautiful courtyard. The queue for entry was quite long so we booked online for immediate entry. It's definitely well worth a visit and the audio guide is helpful and informative. We enjoyed this far more than Sagrada Familia.
Structural lesson. Definitely do not miss the attic where the structural components of Gaudi's design is explained, and it's a great place to enjoy the beautiful sculptural arches.

The Classic Visit. If you haven't visited Barcelona before, Casa Mila (La Pedrera) is one of the required visits. I would highly recommend buying tickets online in advance because you can skip waiting in the line. We bought ours an hour before and it worked out well.
La pedrera at night. Great place to visit at any time but I would recommend the night light show which is truly spectacular.
Another Gaudi masterpiece.. Beautiful building. He also designed much of the furniture. Make sure you see the roof and his many innovations to architecture.

Nice please to Visit in Barcelona, but slightly overpriced. Nice place to visit if you are going to Barcelona for 4 or 5 days. Very interesting house with really good feeling and full of history.The only downside for me was the price, other than that it was great

A true showcase of Gaudi's genius!. Definitely worth the admission price! The rooftop is amazing, as was the attic and the top floor. The other floors are used for residential and commercial space, but this didn't detract from the experience. The exhibitions not only show Gaudi's genius as an architect and designer, but also how the building would have been used in the 1920s and 30s. The highlight of my trip to Barcelona!
Wonderful to visit. An amazing place - beautifully constructed. Lots to see. Don't rush your visit! Definitely worth a second visit next time I'm in the city.

Night tour is beautiful . After all these visits to BCN and La Pedrera I took the night tour. Very Impressive.!The building, courtyards and top terrace look so different. The light show was on but the staircase tops and chimneys lite up were great. Lots of steps. There is an elevator up but once in the terrace there are lots of steps and railings. I did walk down all the way. Yes, do go visit La Pedrera day or night.

The Roof Top is Amazing!!. The roof was the best part of this house. This house has shorter lines. We got our ticket the day we went and did not have to wait too long to get in. You only need about an hour here. And the Casa Batllo is just a short walk you can do both the same day.
great experience. the architecture is amazing, the rooftop is great but the entrance fee is quite expensive. the provided audio guide is informational.

Gaudi's Masterpiece. A must see. A stunning building. Also the finest tour in terms of organization of any attraction we saw in Barcelona. We warned its a steep climb up a dozen flights of stairs to start the visit from the rooftop.
impressive. Worth every penny, children under 7 enter for free, being in Barcelona and not visiting La Pedrera is a crime.
An exciting experience !!!. We had a blast. We enjoyed very much our visit and we learned a lot about Gaudí and modernism. We recommend it to everyone.

A cool experience, and where I learned to appreciate Modernisme. This tour is quite expensive, at 32 euros a person. I wouldn't necessarily say this is a good deal, but it's a unique tour, as you get to see the first floor, staircases, attic, and roof of one of the famous Modernisme buildings in Barcelona. They have some exhibits in the attic that kind of explain the style and I firstreally started to appreciate the intricacies of the architecture. The attic is impossible to describe; the scaffolding of the building is there and it's completely unique. You have to see it for yourself.The tour includes this weird light show on the roof. Apparently it's the 70s. Be careful on the roof.You also get some champagne at the end of the tour. I don't know if that's to justify the price or what, it's still expensive. But because this is the only way to walk through the building, it may be worth it if you're interested in modernisme.

Architectural masterpiece - outside and in, and above. While its possibly to admire Gaudi's genius from the street, do buy a ticket and go inside if you can. The audio tour takes you through the ground floor, roof, attic and apartment, with excellent commentary. The roof is quite astounding. Enjoy :)

Worth every Euro. 27 to be exact for the most amazing tour you can take, I wasn't a fan until this trip and now Gaudi is my new found interest here in the city.I have seen a few other of his ideas, but this one takes it, it's just amazing...

Gaudi .... way ahead of his time. La Pedrera is one of Gaudi's finest materpiece. Too bad he wasn't appreciated in his time. When he built this house for this family, they actually hated it and it was the talk of the town. We purchased the tickets online for the Pedrera along with dinner at the restaurant ... 58 euros each for both. The food at the restaurant was amazing and a great way to start the night. I suggest you booked it at night so you could enjoy the light show on the roof.The Pedrera itself was beautiful. Our guide explained to us the history behind Gaudi's work and it's simply amazing. You get to visit the entrance hall, the stairs that lead you to the roof and the roof itself. Don't expect to visit any of the floors. Once of the roof, yo get to enjoy the view of Barcelona and then the amazing light show begins. The light show shows you what Gaudi uses as inspiration ... nature! At the end of the tour, you get to enjoy a nice glass of sparkling wine or juice and dessert. A great way to end the tour and the night.P.S. Length of visit will reflect Tour + Restaurant
Very nice place. I had the chance to visit the roof and watch a jazz show. It was fantastic. It´s amazing to see this building and all its incredible details.

Cool visit for hot days. Well worth a visit, this is a great place to learn about Gaudi's architectural design genius. Do this and Casa Batllo before then visiting La Familia Sagrada. The attic and apartments are especially interesting and informative.

Absolutely fabulous!. You have to go here if you're in Barcelona. The rooftop is stunning with the iconic chimneys and the attic is so interesting. You learn so much about Gaudi and his methods, it's fascinating. there is a free audio tour available which I would recommend also.

Amazing and unique.. A must see to visit if you're a Gaudi fan . Very interesting unique building. There were various exhibitions showcasing Gaudis work and I loved one of them in particular displaying all the chairs he made to fit the human body. Book to skip the line because the queues are long !

Another Gaudi Masterpiece . Gaudi was an Architect, Engineer and Artist, but to put it more simply, a genius.Gaudi's work is even today ignored by many Architects. Gaudi's genius lives on in his buildings, and this is one of his best.Do not miss the chance to see this magnificent building.The best time to photograph the outside is first thing in the morning, the streets are still empty.
Interesting!. This building is another of Gaudi's interesting works. The views from rooftop are outstanding. Did not find any queue for tickets and even the terrace was also not too crowded.

An architectual master piece! Have to visit it when in Barcelona. This is the 2nd time visiting La Pedrera, and I will probably do it next time in Barcelona also.Book the tickets beforehand on internet and everything will be very smooth. The staff at site are friendly and helpful, and supported us when we arrived in a 10 p group with baby stroller to seniors.Notice the time typical furniture in the very (for the time) modern Gaudi architecture. Wow!

Interesting. The building isn't as pretty or colourful as some of Gaudi's other works, but it is still quite impressive. The rooftop gives spectacular views over Barcelona, and inside the attic there is plenty of information on Gaudi, La Pedrera and his other works around the city (Sagrada Familia, Park Guell, etc.). You also get to walk through the apartment where the owners used to live, which is quite unusual but very detailed. I'd highly recommend using the audio guide, as it gives you so much more information and really enriched my visit.

Amazing!. Having always loved gaudi's architecture I couldn't wait to see la pedrera which is considered the pinnacle of his work and I wasn't dissapointed. I went for the premium tour which included an audio guide, a book about the building and a free photo all for €27. The roof top terrace is amazing the view which are stunning are 2nd only to the incredible architecture you see. Every part of the building is amazing from the door knobs to the beautiful replica furniture, at every turn I found myself taking a photo of another feature that had amazed me. The shop at the end of the tour is a bit expensive but much of the money goes to the upkeep of this stunning building so parting with a few more Euro's was a pleasure. If hadn't guessed I wholeheartedly recommend a visit!

A must visit, gives real insight into Gaudi's work. As a relative newcomer to Gaudi's work I was really impressed by La Pedrera. The rooftop is inspirational but the real gold lies within the attic, with it's serpentine skeleton stricture and interactive exhibits. The apartment also provides fascinating insight into the life of wealthy Catalans in the 19th century. Not cheap at almost €30 to get in, but worth it.
Beautiful gaudi experience. Went today with wife, very interesting beautiful and atmospheric building. Rooftop terrace and views was outstanding.. tip, book online to avoid 30 mind queue...

A must see. We went on a tour via our cruise ship. So glad that I listened to my parents who had previously gone to see the sites. The architecture is amazing! There are dozens of pick pockets in the area though. Stay alert and do not engage them. One will try to distract while another moves in.
Gaudi was and is. Impressive outdoor architecture! Lovely place to take a walk and realize how a mind can be so great... Must visit!!!
Wonderful. Another Gaudi creation that is just like something out of a fairy tale or dream, absolutely spellbound by it !

Check out the rooftop concert. We weren't really interested in doing the standard tour so instead we bought tickets for a rooftop concert. Turns out they let you in early so you can view some of the rooms/exhibits. But best of all, the concert takes place on the roof of the building with all of the cool sculptures. We watched the sunset while listening to experimental jazz. The music was Ok but you cannot beat the venue!

Poorly organized, but Gaudi's work on house is great. The figures on roof are mystical and if you don't mind giving your money only to visit these, then it's okay. If I remember correctly, attic is dedicated to every other building except La Pedrera and it's a no-no. Apartment rooms are mildly interesting, cause it's the only casa I've visited that's fully equipped so you feel like you could live there. Whole visit lasts one hour at most. They have no options for hard of hearing or deaf people (only free audioguides). They give you a free photo if you buy one first (same, but with different background), which is clever commercial trick. You take an elevator to the roof, but from then on you have to use a lot of stairs, so it's not for older people. I don't recommend taking tickets for jazz nights cause even if sight is wonderful, sound of the band isn't one of high quality (also, not a lot of speakers around).

Don't just look outside. Must go inside. There are some tours that only take you outside without going inside. That's a shame because 75% of the beauty lies on the inside. The audio tour (included in admission) is one of the better tours. The rooftop is absolutely stunning. Then there's the insides where the audio guide gives you a lot of good interesting info about how Gaudi thinks about his buildings, plus facts on other works he's done. Although the entrance fee is not cheap, it was a great experience. Plan to spend 75 mins there.

Great Gaudi. Great experience. You get knowing Gaudi closer and that is so wonderfull. He was really unique. You should see this house. The roof is the best part. You get audio guide for free and everything is explained so well...
interesting. this is very interesting attraction i highly recommend to take the audio guide tour as it provide information about the artist his lie and inspiration

Gaudi at its best.. Many people visit Barcelona specifically to view the stunning architecture created or inspired by Gaudi. Calle de Garcia is one of the main streets to walk along to see some of his famous creations. Walk from Placa Catalunya to Casa Batllo - fish scales and all , also look at Casa Amatller and Casa Lleo Morerea on the way, until you reach the Casa Mila - La Pedrera - which includes a Gaudi exhibition, an art collection and of course the rooftop viewing point.
