Interesting to see both the building structure and the apartment however it is the rooftop which you really pay to see, so iconic. This also affords you a great view of the city. It's not cheap but worth the entrance fee
Great View. Amazing views from the top of the building, can get very busy, so a bit of 'waiting around' may be required. enjoyed the visit, glad i've seen it but don't eed to go again.

Overcrowded. Wonderful place but so busy. Need to take great care with steps everywhere on roof. Beware people just shoving to get past including Spanish tour group leader.........sooooooooo rude she was and so impatient. Need to wear proper sandals/trainers not flipflops as saw lots of young people with selfie sticks nearly coming a cropper!! Fab views but wire fencing and cranes everywhere. Attic and rooms fine and interesting if you can hear the commentary on your audio and dodge the the selfie stick seat hoggers!!

Good . I'm an architecture fan and a big gaudi enthusiast. La pedrera is a must for like minded visitors however I would say that the casa Batlo has more detail to offer especially if travelling with younger visitors. The roof is fabulous and the staff are helpful and informed. Worth checking up in advance as they have concerts on the roof which would be magical.
Wow. This place is a must for gaudi fans. The rooftop in particular will fill your camera. Spectacular and confirms the man's genius.

Wonderful Gaudi architecture and designs!. If you are interested in Gaudi you can't miss this! Every little detail is fascinating and the roof top chimney stacks are amazing. Make sure you purchase skip the line and the audio tour.

A step back in time. What a great building to see! The rooftop was stunning with its strange and beautiful design. It was equally beautiful on the inside and the period decor used to design the viewable apartment was marvelous. Would have liked to see more of the building but great to think that most of it is still being used today.

Tourist trap. Extremely poor value for money. The roof is quite pleasant but poor view. Rooms like old offices, old kitchen, old bathroom, with honestly less than zero interest. Unless you are a student in architecture, you should definitely pass your way and save the 20 euro ticket.

The night tour is AMAZING. The night tour is AMAZINGThe sunset is very late in Barcelona so we started the night tour at 10:00 PM.the tour guide was very friendly and knowledgeable, there was a short tour in the attic that explained a bit about guide and the construction of the building, also about the very interesting critic from the locals when it was build.the main attraction is the video show on the roof, projectors are showing artistic videos on the roof creatures - totally amazing!

Great opportunity to see Gaudi designs & understand his design inspiration. Really interesting attraction. Audio greatly enhances the experience. The roof top and apartment are great. There is also an exhibition with models of the building architecture and features explaining his design inspiration. Allow a few hours to fully explore. Suggest you buy tickets online and fast track the queues, which can be long.

Gaudi at his best.. An amazing journey into the creative mind of the genius architect, Antonin Gaudi. The rooms and attic are remarkable but do not miss the opportunity to visit the roof. It is the highlight of the visit.
the roof is so cute. The roof is the first stop and it is just cute. La Pedrera also presents the old lifestyle in that age.

Beautiful architecture. Went for the guided tour in the evening, which gave a good basic introduction to the Gaudi and the building. The light projection show on the rooftop wasn't really interesting, but was able to get a pretty good view of the Barcelona nightscape.

Another Gaudi masterpiece.. Having been to Casa Battlo and the Sagrada Familia and seen Gaudi's work, this is another MUST. Suggest you don't go on the same day otherwise you'll be on sensory overlaod!

Worth a visit. Book your tickets for the early access to avoid the crowds, or even try the pre hours opening & guided tour which I had booked but was cancelled so had a 0900 access, which worked well, the park can be done in an hour. Allow some time to get there though, there are good public transport options, but plan ahead to avoid disappointment .

The rooftop is the best part-interesting learning about Gaudi. Interesting attraction, however not the best to go on a rainy day as the rooftop attraction was closed just after we went up due to too much rain.

Awesome insight on his art and buildings. I love his work. It's so free, inspiring, colorful and useful. A must see for one of his buildings to understand his amazing artistic mind. You must see the roof terrace. It's unbelievably though out. Give yourself time to enjoy all the rooms.

night or day a true experience. you can visit la pedrena in day light or by night.They also have an apartmaent fully decorated with old furniture like it was when the housw was built. The chimneys in the top terrace are truly amazaing

After La Sagrada Familiathis was best sight in Barcelona.. The competing Gaudi residences are Casa Batillo and this one. Rick Steves recommend this one and glad we chose it. It also explains Casa Batillo and the roof here is amazing. It's best to buy timed tickets on line. You can get in earlier than ticket time.
You can buy ticks from Official site on line.

I am glad I didn't miss it. With Barcelona full of activities, history, museums and of course great Gaudi's architecture,I am so glad I was able to make a trip to La Pedrera. They offer night visits as well which are perfect for great pictures.

A Complete Waste of Time & Money. We got completely cheated. This was a complete waste of our time and money. We went on the night tour to see the light show. There wasn't an audio guide. We had a personal tour guide who didn't know what to say. He was trying to stretch to make the tour longer and it was awful. We didn't see any of the apartments. What's the point if you can't see the inside?! We only saw the entrance area, attic, the rooftop. We climbed 7 floors to see where the cleaning people hung the laundry. The light show was on the roof. It was okay. Then we walked down 7 flights of stairs for a cheap class of champagne. Not worth $34per person.

excellent Gaudi price, informative and relaxing. Highly Recommend: I preferred La Padrera over Casa Batllo, which is beautiful but feels pricey and is crowded/stressful. La Padrera has amazing access to the roof and attic, which has interesting displays to understand Gaudi and his approach. The price include an audio guide as well. There is a nice gift shop and the cafe that is attached that is wonderful. Tip, always try to buy online if you can, even if it's the same day or day before. Depending on the time of year, it may sell out online and you might have to wait in line in person.

Rooftop magic. We went for an evening rooftop jazz concert, and it was simply enchanting. The visit included access to the lobby and attic. The view from the roof at sunset is spectacular--all of Barcelona from the Med to Tibidabo.
MUST SEE!. This place is amazing! You must buy the audio tour as it comes with some neat features when you hold it up to different areas of the rooms. I think it was worth the entrance fee!

Fun to visit. Worth a visit. Fun to tour. Spent 40 minutes and covered everything. Paid for the premium pass and was probably not worth it. Lines were not long for regular admission on a Sunday afternoon in June.
I love Gaudi. Book online. Try to go on a non rainy day as sometimes if it rains they close the terrace which is amazing. Get the audio guide it is worth it!

If You Love Gaudi, You'll Enjoy This. Booked reservations in advance for 'Pedrera By Day' online so we walked right in. The entry fee included a pretty good audio guide that made sense of the various rooms/designs and provided good background on the artist. As noted by others, great views of the city from the rooftop and it was easy to see how some of the buildings and characters from Star Wars were influenced by Gaudi's work in La Pedrera.

Nice Building . Pretty funky looking building. Another master piece by Gaudi. We only looked from the outside and I could see the top of the building from our hotel. Very unusual and stands out. I was reluctant to pay 20 euros to get in but I would imagine that I would have liked what I could have seen.
Exceptional!. Great arhitecture and very interesting place. Hope to come back one day. Furniture and all the building is great and a pleasure to visit.
Wonderful building. A fine example of the quality of Gaudi's design. Stunning views of the city from the roof. Madman or genius? I'm definitely in the genius camp!

More Amazing Gaudi. I visited La Pedrera not only for the architecture, but for a live band on top of the rooftop. This made the experience probably ten times better than if I would have visited on a regular day. We were served a glass of champagne with the ticket and got to experience the sunset from the rooftop, helping with the heat issue as well. Worth a visit if you are into Gaudi!
fab visit. excellent value for money the audio device was a brilliant idea never seen before British Stately homes could do with seeing what you do and following suit.

loved the museum and work of Gaudi. loved this !! must see!! FAmily friendly, got tickets to buy pass line. Audio sets at door and enjoyed exploring the mind and designs of Gaudi....off to Sagrada next!!

Beautiful work by Gaudi. A must-see if you're visiting Barcelona. Take a walking tour (you'll see more of Barcelona's amazing architecture and culture, with some surprises thrown in) and make it a Gaudi Day. You won't be disappointed.

Gaudi's last work before La Sagrata Famillia . Casa Mila also known as La Pedrera was Gaudi's last commissioned work before he devoted himself to la Sagrata Famillia. He was commissioned by Pere Mila a wealthy business to build their family home on the very prestigious Passeig de Grecia ave. Its rather unconventional appearance led to the name La Pedrera or stone quarry. It had a wrenching stone facade and wrought iron balconies. There are many innovations including no load bearing walls because the stone was self supporting. The tours are at night. After being taken through the inside including the attic you are led to the roof top for a very unique light show on the very modernist fixtures on the roof. After the light show you are taken back down stairs for a glass of cava. This was a very unique and fun experience that I recommend.
Brilliant. Brilliant, deffo worth money and learnt something about culture and history too! Very enjoyable and chilling!
Beautiful. Loved the late light sure, visited late evening, light show was out of this world, so much of history, hope to be back soon, would not mind visiting again

Amazing!. Booked tickets for La Pedrera 2 months in advanced to make sure I got the desired day and time according to my travel plans, it was a little bit exaggerated since it's possible to get tickets a day before but I wanted to make sure things went as planned. The details in the house are magnificent, after reading the descriptions and the audioguide that comes with the tour it makes much more sense how everything was designed not only for aesthetics in the house but also for function including the little details like the door handles. The roof is out of this world, it is nice to stand up there and compare the architecture of the roof with other roofs around.

An amazing building. We didn't pay to go inside as we felt €23 was asking a little too much so we stood outside and took some pics! Another one of Gaudi's masterpieces, this was once the home of the Sagrada family - and of course, the family who commissioned him to create the Sagrada Familia.

Great audio guide, highly recommend. Beautiful Gaudi architecture, illustrated by a brilliant audio guide that is well worth getting. Perhaps lesser known than Casa Batllo as Pedrera is less impressive from the street, but its beautiful roof terrace and inner courtyards make it more than a match for the former. Buy a ticket in advance to skip queues.

Loved the visit. I didn't know which of Gaudi's residence masterpieces to visit so opted for La Pedrera as it was one that he designed from scratch. It didn't disappoint as the detail in the apartment was stunning and full of beautiful detail. Then the roof terrace was something to see to believe. I arrived at opening time and that gave time on the roof without the crowds. It was quite unimaginable and full of surprises, like the views to the basilica through the arch. La Pedrera is not as pretty from the outside but so much to enjoy when you walk in the door.

Another fine example of Gaudi. Amazing to think this house was designed for a somebody to live in. It is now world heritage protected and a must see. Gaudi was inspired by nature when he designed buildings, Ne this is a great example of his work. I was blown away. Barcelona is a fascinating city.

The best place to visit to appreciate Gaudi's genius. Definitely buy a ticket in advance that allows you to by-pass the queue. Visiting La Pedrera is a much nicer experience than going inside Casa Batllo. It doesn't get as crowded since they are better at limiting the number of people who are admitted at the same time. You get a lot of information about Gaudi and Barcelona, and interesting examples of his architecture and design. Well worth the time and money.

Great building. This was a great experience to see the way a family would live in the modernist apartment. Because the tickets and entry is limited, it keeps the experience intimate. The history comes to life with furniture pieces and room set up. I would definitely recommend this attraction.
Fantastic Gaudi experience. The building itself is a marvel, but I believe we enjoyed the museum in the attic most. It gave insights into how Gaudi thought about his architectural designs.
Amazingly different. Had never seen anything like this before. Again I would recommend having a guide. Also to stand on all the different sides of the road to view the walls and balconies.
Interesting. Another of Gaudi's fine architecture. The fact it is so different, not by any means your usual building that makes his work so appealing

Nice informative visit, interesting look in how the rich lived . This was a good place to visit. I thought that it will be a boring place to see how a family stays. However the tour was very well designed with the audio guide helping to bring the apartment building to live. The detains and tour was highly interesting and was mire interesting than the sagradia familiar. Do spent 1-1.5 hours visiting the place as it is interesting. We paid 41 Euros for 2 pax with the included audio guide. Definitely worth a visit to this interesting place.

Great place to visit in addition to Casa Batllo. This location was only a 5 block walk from Casa Batllo. Great to plan to do both in one afternoon. The rooftop is absolutely worth visiting. Very unique, great views.

Architecture at its best!. Go find this sight in Barcelona, superb architecture to look at from the outside. Took some photographs and posted them on this review page. Really enjoyed seeing Gaudi buildings so even bought a book on the way home.

The ROOF is the best part!. Go inside this structure and get to the roof. It's a bewildering experience - are they chess pieces or the guards? Antoni Gaudi is an absolute genius. What he has done to Barcelona is mind-blowing.

Must see if you are a fan of Gaudi.. Unbelievable. You can tour the entire place yourself including the rooftop with Gaudi's chimneys. Of course, there is a gift shop. Don's buy the LaPedera tee shirt, it will shrink.
If you weren't looking for it.... You wouldn't know it was there. An impressive and imposing structure when you look up. Tours are available but quite expensive.

Rooftop ruined by grey cyclone wire fencing. Loved our visit. Others have said it all. The rooftop looks like a Disneyland set. It would be so much nicer if it were not for the horrible out of character cyclone wire fencing which adds to the sense you are on a Disneyland ride. Gaudi was an inspired and brave crazy genius. Visit took about 2 hours.

Gaudi's Creative Brilliance. Don't miss this incredible Gaudi building. Be sure to purchase the audio tour. Be sure to allow a good amount of time checking out the amazing museum located in the beautiful brick attic. It is so well done and provides insight into Gaudi's brilliant imagination and engineering genius.

Dream house. La Pedrera (Casa Milá) is the last piece of work before he devoted himself in to the sangrada familia. This building has the best roof top. That was totally in an imaginary world. The property now still has tenants and this gives a feeling that this project could be so close to real life. The inside decorations were really nice.

Good collection of Gaudi's works. This is a good collection of Gaudi's works. Apart from the architecture on the roof and of the apartments, there is a museum in the attic telling you of Gaudi's life. With the free audio guide, it gives you a great idea of his life. I think see this (there's no waiting time to get in) and La Sagrada Familia to experience Gaudi, and you'll be sorted.
Not as good as casa batló but still impressive. Another great work by Gaudi (has he made anything bad?)Not has spectacular has Casa Batló but pretty close.The ticket is a bit expensive but worth it.

Don't miss this one. This one is my favourite thing to see in Barcelona. It's hard to describe the beauty of this place. There is a lot to see here. The only negative is that it is crowded. It's difficult to get a photo without someone walking into it.

Fascinating building. Since Our hotel was NeXT door it was easy to visit it by walking.very interesting building.if you like GAUDI it is really something special.A lot of details,remember to og on top since roof very funny and view very good,Shop has a very good selection of books and souvenirs

All about the roof top.. We booked for 7.30 - not knowing that we would be kicked off the rooftop by 8pm to make our descent through the floors of exhibitions. That was the low point. Other than that, the ambience on the roof at dusk is magical, and good time for light and photos.

5 stars just for the exterior!. Didn't have time to actually visit inside this building but give it 5 stars just for the pleasure of seeing the building from the outside. I loved the balconies - they reminded me of autumn - curled leaves and
Good audio guide. The audio guide comes with the ticket purchase, and it was very interesting. Lovely area to visit and a good thing to do if the weather isn't great.

Very beautiful architecture. Gaudi's passione is presented here. This man did not just work. He created miracles if his time and also ours. This beautiful building is eorth every penny to visit. It is 22.5 euro and they includ audioguide.

Go Early - Great Views - Amazing Architecture. To avoid the crowds, go early. The tours start on the roof of the building and then you work your way through the attic and a sample apartment with an audio tour. The views from the roof-top are great. The attic space is a beautiful peek into Gaudi's architecture and design inspiration.

Interesting and informative tour. I was hesitant to pay the money for this tour, but definitely one of the highlights of our weekend. Fabulous how Gaudi thought of the functional, architectural and artistic aspects of living and was definitely light years ahead of his time. Interesting to see people still living there.

Gaudi's work of the finest. A Gaudi design for a Barcelona family. This is a must see. Wow, this apartment is outstanding, you walk up the various flights but also an elevator to the top which has amazing views. The thought put into this building is amazing not to mention the furnishings and workmanship. Admission fee is a little high, you get headsets which are great describing everything you see. Stop in here, especially if you are walking around Ramblas or can't get into Sagrada,you won't be sorry stopping here. Lots of tours stop here. Lots of history here too. Did not take long to get into.
Lovely building. It's a very nice and different building, I loved it. It was very unique. I will go again in the future.

Amazing so beautiful. Just amazing architecture also there are models of the building and how it was built. So much to see you could be there for hours. The other Gaudi buildings are more colourful then this one how ever this building is equally impressive. We wanted to do do the visit at night as they light up the building with different colours which would have looked Awesome however we ran out of time.

Good but not great, too expensive!!. Off course is a beautiful, is a house made by one of the modernist genius of Catalunya, It has a great terrace, not all the employees are gentile and the experience is not the best for the high price. If you have few days to visit Barcelona and you want to visit a Gaudí house, I advice you go to Casa Batlló directly.

Expensive, and More Gaudi--But Definitely Worth It!. La Pedrera costs 20,50 euro (if you add the audio guide--which, in my opinion, is indispensable), but it is pure, completed Gaudi when he was at the height of his power as an architect. The apartment (with original furnishings) and roof top and attic are fascinating. We had no trouble just walking up and buying a ticket to enter, but at sometimes the wait is extensive. Tickets are available (with a specified entrance time) on line the OFFICIAL La Pedrera web site. In my opinion, you should avoid buying from a tour company because the site is easy to reach and the audio guide does a wonderful job of explaining everything about the building. As you tour the attic where models of the structure and furniture are on display, the audio guide will explain the ideas behind the innovations. The roof top is pure Gaudi and looks down on the central atrium which provides light to the apartments, making them delightful spaces. The apartment contains original furnishings and makes it very clear why there are still people living in the building enjoying truly unique places to live--there are no load-bearing walls inside the building; Gaudi wanted to be able to customize each apartment for the owners' needs. When visiting Barcelona, it may seem like "There's just too much Gaudi and each is expensive, so why spend all that money to see 'weird' architecture?" However, having now seen La Sagrada Familia, Palau Guell and La Pedrera (and Park Guell on a previous trip), my opinion is that it's worth spending the money--and I'm not a person who knows a lot about architecture or art, but I found each site fascinating and well worth the time and money.
Amazing architecture. This was probably the best tour in Barcelona, very interesting. The entrance is quite expensive but there is a lot to see.

Gaudi the magnificent!. A must see while in Barcelona. Easily accessible and beautifully preserved. La Predrera is photogenic and some photos will come out postcard perfect. Tip: purchase tickets online and the audioguide is highly recommended.

'A List' must do in Barcelona. The crowds and queue were too long at Sagrada Familia so we opted for a mid afternoon tour at La Pedrera and were not disappointed. The audio option is a must... start at 1 and wait till you are on the roof to press 2, continue thru to 20 as the story and information is facinating. Even if you are not into architecture as I am, you will love it. Gaudi was a genius. A special treat is viewing the 2 apartments decorated in 1912 style showing how they lived in this stunning building. Also the views from the roof are anazing.

Another must do. This is yet another example of Gaudi's stunning vision of architecture. The lovely lines of the building just flow on and on. The waves, the balconies, the unusual windows - all just capture your attention. Photos don't do it justice.

You will never see a roof like this again !. This was a beautifully insightful visit into the world of art, architecture and history. We visited in the late afternoon and the sunshine on the roof added to the beauty.

Amazing rooftop view!. Myself and my boyfriend came here on our recent trip to Barcelona and I am glad we did just for the amazing view around Barcelona from the rooftop. I love Gaudi's work and you could sit for ages in the courtyard looking around. We went later on in the afternoon and it was fairly busy with tourists however we were not waiting long to get our headsets to start the tour.

Very interesting example of Gaudi's work.. This was our first taste of "modernista" architecture on our trip. Unfortunately, it drizzled on and off most of the day and we had already purchased tickets. The staff at the door informed us that the roof was closed, and said we could try coming back in the afternoon. We had other tickets for the day, so we elected to go in that morning; as it turned out, the afternoon was just as bad.The house was very interesting, as was the museum section. I'm sure if you're a big fan of Gaudi, you could spend several hours here. It was disappointing to not be able to access the roof, and it didn't help viewing the open courtyard either. We ran into the same issue with the weather at the Sagrada Familia in the afternoon, as the towers were closed (they did automatically refund us the extra money).The rain was very light, but I'm guessing many of the other sites that have outside access may have closed them as well. It's probably a safety issue as the stairs might become slippery as visitors tracked water on them. We had purchased our tickets well in advance, but if you are buying yours a few days out, I would advise you to check the forecast and plan accordingly to avoid disappointment.

Amazing. I first visited during the day and later when back to see the night show ' behind closed doors'. I arrived 20 mins before my scheduled time but they kindly allowed me to join an earlier time for which I was grateful. This night tour bypasses what can be seen during the day. A guide just gives initial explanations about Gaudi models and then takes you straight to the roof. The lights are stunning – it is an amazing light show – superb – which goes for about one hour, after which we went back downstairs for a glass of cava. Barcelona is so much about Gaudi, this tour (and visiting there in daytime) is highly recommended.

Amazing! Absolute must-do!. If you have a night in Barcelona, make sure you do the origins tour at night. The rooftop projection show was amazing and the building and it's history is an architectural beauty ❤️

If you like Gaudi you will love. If you like this kind of architecture you will love this place it is still a working residence and office building. Amazing creative even if it is a bit odd. It is expensive

Definitely worth a visit. Great place, worth a visit!1 - All types of tickets, comes with free audio guide2 - If you also have Turistic bus ticket, it's the 2nd or 3rd stops from the start Catalunya, on their RED route!3 - Your tour will start from the roof top, then down a floor to the attic, then down to living areas - then you will take the lift back to the ground floor. 4 - The building is still being used by offices.

So so. Not a must see. We much preferred basilica of segrada familia and casa Batlio even though the price is the same as Batlio. We got the premium ticket but had to wait quite some time before a staff showed up to let us in. Not worth it for 27.5 euro per person especially if you have already seen two other gaudi master pieces. The audio guide also didn't give as much info as the other two locations.

I want to live here!. Not only the roof (which is very famous) but the whole interior is fabulous. The appartment you can visit seems waiting for the next inhabitants, with all the furniture in place. Very nice !

Very interesting . If you like architecture, art, modern design or nature then you need to visit La Pedrera. Here you will find all of the above in an apartment building of all things. In a world of full of buildings made to look like boxes, the real beauty is still found in the curves of nature.

La Pedrera - Origins Night Tour. We booked the Origins 10pm tour of La Pedrera through Viator. This is a fantastic tour with a friendly, enthusiastic and informative tour guide. I really enjoyed the tour inside the building and learning about the art and architecture. The tour ended with an amazing light projector show on the chimneys! Amazing view and it's so much fun being up on the roof and when you go downstairs you get a class of cava or juice! So much fun and there is also an amazing little cafe takeaway 5 mins from here that does really good cheese & pepperoni baguettes!
Out of this world. Blown away with this creation of a house. How his mind works when designing this is unbelievable. Having a audio guide was a must to have, which is part of the entrance fee.
La Pedrera. We did two tours here: the day time tour and the night time tour where the roof is lit up and a glass of cava at the end of the tour. We enjoyed both tours.

BRILLIANT and the attic museum is superb. Though most visitors remember the roof top ornate and weird tiles and structure, the apartment on display is also superb, as is the attic museum which is wonderfully informative about all of Gaudi's works - not just the apartment block. Outside is an excellent tapas restaurant.

Simply magic. Great fountain show with lights and music - simply magic and a must in Barcelona! A lot of people and crowded so watch your friends and belongings. Also, there are no restaurants there only simple shops with coffee, pizza and beer/wine. The show goes only Thursday to Sunday.

People still live here!. Not to sound like a broken record but buy your tickets on line & use the audio guide. After checking out the entry foyer, take elevator to top & explore the mind boggling roof & enjoy the views. Winding your way down past private apartments, you will see furnished rooms from back in the day, quite interesting. Gaudi paid attention to the tiniest details including door handles fashioned from clay by the press of the hand & turned into brass fitted ergonomic designs. They look decorative but are sheer genius, like everything else he did. Don't miss the art gallery just a few steps up from the foyer (at the end of your visit). It's included in the ticket & very good, check out Gaudi's ceiling design in here:)

Visit before Sagrada Familia. If you are interested in architecture/engineering, a visit here before going to the S Familia is very useful ! In the attic (part of the standard tour), are skeletal models and a unique mirror exhibit of parabolic arches which are key to Gaudi's designs. Spend a few minutes studying these, and you will appreciate the soaring heights pf the cathedral, supported by the rather thin columns. In addition, the Pedrera ground floor which is the ceiling of the underground carpark I think may use the same design principle as the roof of large arenas, including Madison Square Garden

Origins Tour. I wish I would have read the reviews for The Origins Tour at night before booking. You will find that most people highly enjoy the experience, but think it is overpriced and you only tour the attic and roof. This is a highly accurate description. I thought this would have been a personal tour of the house in its entirety. If you wish to see the house, do not do the Origins tour. Save your money and tour on your own, if you still want to cough up the high price. The Sagrada Famillia and Park Guell are significantly cheaper and have exceptionally more to see.

Can't miss this one. A marvel by Gaudi. One of the coolest buildings I have seen. I visited this attraction during the day as well as at night. I loved it when I was illuminated at night. It;s a definite treat to your thoughts and eyes if you are an architect.

Very impressive!. This is a must see in Barcelona, if you can only do this or the Basilica I would recommend this (or do both but Pedrera first). Also get the flexible / priority pass - well worth it as you don't have a set time and personalized service.

Interesting, but pricey. While we enjoyed walking through the apartment building designed by Gaudi, we found it not quite worth the entrance fee. At over 20 Euros per adult ($50 for a couple), I expected more. The curving roof was a delight, as was the self guided tour through the attic and one apartment. Gaudi was a 100 years ahead of his time in the use of light, space and form. Would not recommend for families.

Sue. Amazing example of Gaudi architecture. Good access to roof and exhibition in the attic. All Gaudi properties are a similar price so we chose just this one to explore inside and weren't disappointed. Thoroughly recommend

That man was brilliant.. Had never appreciated Gaudi's gift to the city of Barcelona but definitely did after visiting La Pedrera and Sagrada Familia. Need to visit both to even start to understand the brilliance of the man.

Only the price has changed . Since I was here last la padrera has attempted to become a lot more of a tourist attraction than it probably is. The integration of the apartment and museum and a very detailed (read overly long) audio guide seem largely in place to justify a very expensive admission price. It's great to see - but it's expensive and quite laborious in parts.

Amazing architecture by Gaudi. This is the zenith of the amazing Gaudi's work. He had turned Nature into an amazing building. The roof terrace was a unique spectacle! I spent hours there appreciating the magic. A must for all visitors to Barcelona
Worth visiting. Definitely worth visiting on a sunny day. We bought online skip the line tickets which were worth geting

Waves and waves. This building will catch your attention immediately as it stands out on the corner of the street. Must see, great views from the terrace, interesting to have a look inside and again, plenty of architecture, detail, color, shapes and shadows.

Fantastic!. If you dont go inside it is not the same. The roof is just something else. Going inside you can see how brilliant Gaudi was and how he put his ideas into a project. We just enjoyed every peace of his work. Buy the thicket on-line , it will save you lots of time .
Stunning. If you are in Barcelona and have few time visit La Pedrera. Take the elevator and be even more amazed by the chimneys in the roof, in the summer they have concerts at night... Lovely

Enjoyed it, but...... Booked for the evening light show - Origins. The guide books/trip advisor all raved about it. Firstly, the house is amazing but you didn't get to see much of it. We were whisked to the attic where our guide attempted to explain the history but he spoke so quickly in his best English, it was really difficult to pick up, especially in our group situation. It felt like it was a case of 'let's get to the roof/main event as soon as possible'. The light show is impressive and atmospheric and worth the visit. I just wanted a little more about the property. Maybe we were just unlucky with the guide. Definitely a must see but feel I need to go again to see the rest of the house.

Amazing. Firstly book in advance or pay for the premium tickets so you don't have to join the queues. Location wise it's a 10 mins walk from Caso Battlo. It is a fantastic place to look around especially the roof where there are some great views as well as the amazing sculptures of Gaudi. Inside there is an exhibition showing you some of Gaudis construction techniques and very interesting.If you are visiting Caso Battlo too then visit there first and save La Predera to last as it's the icing on the cake.

Lovely night visit. While expensive (€34), I'm glad I went for the Origins night tour of La Pedrera. The tour guide was lovely and informative and the light show on the roof was great (though fairly basic compared to White Night in Melbourne or Vivid in Sydney). There are a lot of barriers etc on the roof which are annoying but I guess necessary.
Amazing Guadi Structure. We did the tour and it's beautiful inside and the rooftop is very cool. We did it early morning and the views of the City are cool.
Another classic by Gaudi. Quaint apartment building also near Casa Battlo on Passeig de Gracia. One of the main must-sees for fans of Gaudi.

Very interesting tour and really better at night!. We went to the evening tour and the statues are lit up with a light show. Fun to see the interior and there is an elevator for disabled and strollers.
Good to wander past and admire. We walked down Passeig de Gràcia to see la pedrera and Casa Batllo. Lovely to see and admire Gaudi's work amongst the glamorous shops. m

Another piece of art.... When you look at the various works of Gaudi, you gotta admire thus guy is really a genius. I mean the visits to Gaudi works ain't cheap and easily hit close of eighty but you just gotta spend it. The architecture is unique.

Night Show is great!. I purchased a ticket set for one day entry and one night tour. The two perspectives are very different and yet very well worth to visit both. The night tour guide gives us great background stories about the building. The rooftop light show is very memorable.
SO MUCH TO SEE. Spectacular to walk through, you must go to the roof and look across Barcelona. Everything just makes it our favorite city anywhere in the world

Go straight to the roof. Another Gaudi work planned as a residential building. Still used as private residence. The fun part is the roof and make sure you take the lift as it is 8-9 floors up. It can get quite windy on the roof. Be careful as there are lots of tourists there. The attractions include the skylights, chimneys, fans and staircase exits. These structures on the roof remind me of a Doctor Who character, or is it the other way around. There is a large courtyard around which is the multilevel building. The usual Gaudi style curves, twisting cast iron balconies and undulating facade are present. It is remarkable how Gaudi and his associates made use of the relatively small urban space to construct this large open space building in early 20th century. Part of the apartments are open for visits showing some of the furniture and other household items of the time. A must visit.
More Magical Gaudi. We did not go into this building but did spend time taking photos of the exterior as the special elements were explained to us by our Spanish tourguide.
Awesome Gaudi. Really great to look at, flowing, natural shapes - sticks out as a Gaudi straight away, and a lovely addition to the street!

When architecture is cool ..... I read that one of Gaudi's teachers said of him: "either we have someone in front of us who is crazy or is an absolute genius".The quote was something to that effect, and I think he is absolute genius. His stuff is inspiring, beautiful, challenges architecture to what it could be. I thought La Pedrera was a great visit (as we heard Casa Batllo was as well, but unfortunately we couldn't get to). The Gaudi spots are pricey, especially when you factor in exchange, but it is worth it in my opinion. Don't forget the marvelous rooftop!

Casa Mila. Barcelona is about Antonio Gaudi. Gaudi's houses are all without line.Visited La Pedrera or Casa Mila along Passieg De Gracia, separated by a little road is Prada shop. Its also an UNESCO Heritage Site. Along this road, no vehicle can stop. This house is beautiful both day and night. It has few cafes and restaurants. Must visit when in Barcelona.Visited Cafe La De Pedrera. It served good tasty pastries.

It's worth visiting just to see the roof..... The reviews say it all, this is an interesting structure. A working office and apartment complex still, where you can stroll around, take in the culture and see an apartment as it would have been when Gaudi was there. And then there's the roof.....amazing! Do this!
Spectacular residence. Once a private residence, it's understated opulence Gaudí-commissioned by Milà family. Every detail perfection, brilliantly engineered. Again, a magical masterpiece.

Don't miss!!. The roof top is the best part! Gaudi was/is a genius and la Pedrera only further demonstrates that. Buy tickets online and avoid the line! We got premium online and were ushered right thru, but I saw Know one in the regular online ticket line which is a few buck cheaper.

Gaudy Inside and Out. This "house," Gaudí's last private commission before he devoted all his energies to his cathedral project, is a fascinating example of both his exteriors and interiors. You climb first to the roof, with its elaborate chimneys and turrets and magnificent views of the city, then wind your way down through a vaulted attic museum and restored private apartments. It's all very informative and interesting. Well worth a visit.

Gaudi, he was his time well ahead. This house shows the talent of Gaudi. It is also one of the must visits in Barcelona. You do not need to be an architectural specialist and lover to see that Gaudi was one of a kind, he will never be matched again. What he accomplished in his time.... unbelievable !

Beautiful building, definitely worth your time. La Pedrera/Casa Mila is beautiful. It wasn't too crowded when we went on a Sunday afternoon. We booked the self-audio guide which included the elevator ride up to the top instead of taking the stairs, which was nice on such a hot day. The views of and from the rooftop are wonderful, you can see some of Gaudi's other works around you. The displays throughout the attic space and apartment space are very informative, although a bit repetitive if this isn't your first Gaudi stop. Overall, great stop, don't miss it.
Wow. Very Interesting work of Gaudi! Hardly believe his forward planning...way ahead of his time. This is my top pick of his work...it even gets better when you visit inside. A must see.

Interesting apt. house, interesting man. I've loved Gaudi from afar for years. The real thing is very exciting to experience. Learned many surprising things and the attic and apartment were especially informative. The gift shop was just so so - both of them - and had items from all countries, not just Spain.

Well worth a visit - hard to believe designed a century ago. At €20.50 this is a tour well worth taking, headphones provided. Worth buying tickets in advance if not there early enough to beat the queues. Particularly liked the living quarters as they would have been lived in. Fascinating.
La Perera. it is abstract architectural design by famous Gaudi, again through tour conductor Explore Catalunya!

Gaudi architecture in the middle of the city. this is a building by Gaudi in the city centre. the tour inside takes you through an apartment and then the terrace which has various depictions of Gaudi's architectural work. They also have a display of his various works along with the highlights of the building. An interesting visit though was not able to appreciate much due to a non-creative background!

Mesmerizing - salute to Gaudi. G - GreatA - AwesomeU - UnbelievableD - DiversifiedI - IncredibleI tried to express what I felt about the creator and its creation. I took two tours at this beauty - the daytime tour and the light show. Every corner of the building is full of Gaudi's brilliance. The light show at night was excellent and portrayed the famous roof differently. At the end of that evening - I was content and felt a bliss inside me. Barcelona is full of architectural marvels - and this one is definitely one of the must visits among those.

Gaudi's Apartments. I would love to live here, with it's sinuous lines, magnificent architecture. and balconiesovelooking Barcelona's most elegant street. A total treat. In the summer, it is essential to have prior tickets.In march, it was a breeze to enter.
Interesting. Again, great to see... Did not went inn, as it looked very crowdy.. but you can walk near by, and enjoy yet amazing piece of architecture in Barcelona. :)

Surprisingly exceeded expectation!. Besides an artful rooftop, the details around this architecture were simply fascinating, that we ended spending some time admiring all the artworks in the building! There is an admission fee but definitely worth it!

Great overview of Gaudi's work. Is definitely worth a visit as there is an exhibition on Gaudi's other projects and you have a great view from the rooftop. We had booked the tickets in advance and there were no queues. If you go there later, there might be a lot of people on the rooftop. The fully furnished apartment gives an interesting insight into the life of wealthy people 100 years ago.

Lovely . I was amazed by the artistry! We did the night tour which was fantastic!! I've learned a lot about Gaudi and I'm a fan now! Do not miss this if you like art. Do be careful on the rooftop, the stairs are narrow. However there is an elevator for those who need one.

Interesting place and great night show!. It was a treat to visit here and to learn how all his work came to life. The show was great and the cava at the end sealed the evening. Very nice and just something to do at night as everything sort of closes relatively early.

Another beautiful and unique house by Gaudi. 20.50€ but 16.50€ for students. The elevator takes you to the building's amazing rooftop, full of Gaudi shapes and colors with a great view of Passeig de Gracia. Then you can tour the building's attic, re-designed as a Gaudi museum, and a model apartment. In the middle of the building is a nice open patio as well. Well worth the trip!

Make sure to see this building!. We went with a guide and loved it. There is a fascinating museum in the attic. Make sure to allow enough time to see this floor. We were a little rushed and would have enjoyed really taking out time.

Not necessary to enter the building. . Yes it is good architectural building but, entering price is so high i think. You can spend 28 € to enter Sagrada Familia and Gaudi's home together with audioguide. It is better idea i think ☺

Well laid out example of Gaudi design, and a great visit. A good example of how a museum or visitor centre should be. Interesting, beautiful and informative without being too prescriptive. A joy not to be missed in Barcelona.

the second house created by Gaudi on Calle Paseo de Gracia. when coming from Placa de Cataluna on the boulevard Calle Paseo de Gracia we'll find on the left side the Casa Batllo and further up on the right side we arrive in about 5 minutes to La Pedrera which is on the right side on a street corner;this house has another style in comparison to Casa Batllo;if Casa Batllo has more decorative elements and a variety of colors and is more like an architectural jewelery,La Pedrera is built of limestone,is bigger and more massive but still has the sculptural decorations which define Gaudi's style ;these two houses are in fact landmarks of Barcelona and of the Calle Paseo de Gracia and are a must see when visiting Barcelona ;

Great example of Gaudi's work - book tickets online. I always wanted to go inside, but never had the chance. This year I finally had the time to take the tour and was not disappointed. The rooftop is great, can be a bit crowded, but if you're not in a rush, just sit down and relax for a while. I would definitely recommend booking tickets online (no need for the more expensive "fast track" tickets) - it will get you inside within few minutes.

Evening Regions Tour. The plus side - the parts of the house we saw were great. We saw the two different entrance halls, the attic and the roof terrace with the amazing chimneys. The opening video was unnecessary as it just showed the parts that we were there to see. The guide wasn't clear when she said you can use the stairs or take the lift, that we had to go up 5 floors! Some people struggled. The finale - a projected short display on the chimneys was absolutely beautiful and magical for all of us including our 6 year old grand daughter. Whole experience lasted about 50 minutes and finished with a glass of ok cava Disappointed that we didn't see more of the house and felt it was overpriced . The balancing factor was that our grand daughter had a free entry. Like all Gaudi buildings it was just an amazing place to visit.

Another Gaudi masterpiece . Another amazing piece of architect by Gaudi. The creativity and bold designs are stunning on the roof tops and his flowing curvaceous style is beautiful to behold. Every attention to detail is amazing to see and you get so much information about the period, Gaudi's approach to designing the buildings and the styles. That said you do not need to be any kind of expert in architect or a real art buff to appreciate this and all of Gaudi's works as they are so pleasing to any eye

A 'must-see' for architecture fans. Loved every minute of our visit. The entrance fee is well worth it to get to see inside one of the beautiful apartments. Definitely up there with Casa Batllo for us. We also enjoyed lunch in the restaurant downstairs.

if your into archetechture then this is up your stree. didn't book just qued wasn't long got in about 15 mins , very interesting building but far to many japs taking useless inane pictures and hanging around far to long for everyone else to look into rooms ,selfish dumb people , the roof was very good but everyone wants to take a picture of there child or wife then all you can do is walk thru it ,you cant expect to be in a touristy bit and have it all to yourself for a picture , you should have seen there faces when I walked right thru them ,and I'm a photographer
Good to see. Beautiful building, very modern and unusual, but in reality is not so impressive as in pictures. Recommend to visit it.

Amazing. This is an amazing place to visit , beautiful architecture , one of the places You must see in Barcelona :) it is very busy to go inside better buy a ticket online, and be ready to wait in the queue for over an hour.
Architectural highlight. If you are interested in architecture and design a place you must see. Given the building is more than 100 years old a very proactive approach for this time.

Designed by a real genius gaudi. This place with the way it's built using the shape of waves and the sea is real clever and by utilizing the natural light in the middle of the building is real clever..

There is no way you can miss it.. La Pedrera along with Sagrada Familia is the symbol of Gaudi's Barcelona. Just stop and admire it. There is no other building like this one. It ia a MUST of seeing it and to enjoy it's unique architecture. If you decide to pay for the entrance there is no way you will regreting it. Unique and unusual. A jewel.

A Gaudi Classic but not our favourite. We were lucky enough to be staying within easy walking distance of la Pedrera & as such were able to get there fairly early (10ish) when the queue was very short. Pre booking tickets is advisable, although there is still a queue inside for the audio guide, security and the small lift which takes you to the roof where the tour starts. We spent quite a while exploring the roof, then the attic where there are exhibits dedicated to each of Gaudi's masterpieces, followed by the apartment with its clever use of both light and space. I enjoyed the way his incorporation of nature into his work was demonstrated. The feature on the design of the chairs and door handles was a great example of his attention to detail - everything had a purpose.We enjoyed our visit, but for us Casa Batlo wins hands down. There was nothing to compare with the immediate impact of all its vivid colours and curved walls which will stay with us forever.( I could have lived there today quite happily.) The disadvantages - much longer queue & there is no direct access to the shop from the street. I only mention the latter as we had visited the house & purchased items in the shop previously & I wished to return to the shop ( which is much larger than at this site) . However paying 40plus euro for the privilege of more shopping wasn't an option!

Gaudi is amazing. Enjoyed seeing the wondrous architecture of Gaudi. The tour, with audio guide, took a little over an hour. If you already spent time in the Sagrada Familia, then you will have been exposed to much of Gaudi's background and some of his engineering techniques. His combination of function and beauty is evident in this building. Incredible. Be sure to watch a black and white video of Gaudi's life, with English subtitles, very interesting and informative. Provides some insight into his personal life.

Another highlight of Barcelona. We visited La Pedrera at night. First we had an introductory talk while enjoying a glass of champagne and snacks, then were taken to view plans and eventually went to the rooftop. There we saw the light and sound show highlighting the architecture. It was great fun as well as instructive. The rooftop also allowed good views over the Passeig de Gracia.

Just look at it from outside. Well, it's not as big as sagrada familia, also not as well maintained as casa battlo, also not as colorfull as other Gaudi's masterpiece.. The unusual thing is only it looks form the outside. I dont think it's worth it to purchase a ticket to go inside

Awesome architectural piece.. A must see when in Barcelona. Antoni Gaudi's masterpiece! It was awe-inspiring to picture this architect/artist at work. The modernist feel of Gaudi's work is exemplified here. It is amazing that this building was done in the early 1900's. Its a modern art piece. The roof top is also great to see and take pictures. i learned that the roof top chimney pieces inspired George Lucas' design for the storm troopers helmets!

Great insight into genius. La Prefers is the last of Gandhi's amazing projects and his genius is apparent everywhere you look. The exhibition in the attic space gives a real understanding of his development and his extraordinarily original mind. The visit takes 2 - 3 hours, more or less depending on how long you want to linger. Absolutely worth while!

Cool building, could not take my eyes off, so much to see. On my list to see, we walked right by it on the main drag, so easy to find. Had to take the tour, about 20 euros. Make sure to go on the roof top. When you're ready to go back down, don't miss the museum in the attic, very informative about Gaudi's works and as you continue down we got to see the inside of the apartments.

Right in the mist of everything !!. We were just walking and it appeared this mystical looking building so we got a ticket and went in ,it's very Interesting tour if you get the earphones it gives you an insight of what Gaudi did on a day to day basis along with people of the day . The roof top is fantastic ,of all the rooftops in Barcelona la Pedrera is the best ,you have to go there to see it

Gaudi, amazing architecture. if you like what you see you will love his creativity on this apartment building. What an amazing, creative, clever man. Would love to see more of his style in my home country.
Artwork of Gaudi. If you want to get surprised by how unusual the architecture of a normal building can be, you should definitely check this Gaudi's work. It's really worth to visit the rooftop!

Second only to Sagrada Familia. La Pedrera, Gaudi's last project before devoting himself to the Sagrada Familia full-time, is fascinating on a few levels: it provides insights into his building methods and process, gives you a peek at what it might be like living in a Gaudi space, and hosts a spectaculor rooftop. Tips: don't miss the apartment, and if there is something scheduled on the roof (concerts, etc.) during your visit, by all means go. Also the gift shop and ground floor restaurant are surprisingly good.

Another Chance to Appreciate Gaudi's Work. Another great site to visit to appreciate Gaudi's architecture, after Casa Batlo (if you had to choose, definitely go to Casa Batllo). Definitely spend some time on the roof. There are other exhibits on the various floors of the house that don't take too long to get through.

Gaudi up close. Short line for tickets and off to the rooftop to walk up and down the undulating surface to get close to Gaudi's apartments. Toured the apartment on display as well. Exhibits of the ergonomic accessories quite amazing. This important building has features echoed throughout the city. See why ! Not really suitable for those with mobility problems.

I only seen this Building from out side. Nice structure...! I have not seen much of La Pedrera. It was only a Panoramic city tour and our guide was busy in explaining the other things. So, i am sorry i can not rate this to the best of my knowledge. it is better to ready other review.

Gaudi's Architecture. If you are a Gaudi or even an architect buff, this is definitely the place to visit. The large crowds and long wait for the tour (at the time I went), turned me away from seeing the inside of this building. However, the outside is just as amazing.

Work of Genius. Truly, Gaudi was an artist in the full meaning of the word. This building is simply further proof of that. Amazingly unique, though, like other unconventional buildings, it was hated by locals at first. A must see. Visit for sure and with a local guide if you can. There are plenty of tour companies that offer Gaudi tours that include this fantastic building a little pricey sometimes, but well worth it.

Roof views . I was glad of the lift though I did start walking up the stairs not realising that there was a lift. So went back down the stairs as I realise there was no one on the stairs. The roof views were great but the exhibits in the attic was interesting, my attention was not held like the other buildings I have been too.

Up on the roof. What a masterpiece. The roof reflects Gaudi's comment that crosses on roofs had the artistic quality of a bald man with one hair stretched across his head. So the roof is a sculpture paradise. The attic vault & furnishings are exquisite. Take a break in the first floor restaurant or have some delicious coffee!
Super!. Very interesting visit. I recommend to visit both this and casa Battlo because they show different aspects of the same author.

Amazing apartment . Very unique apartment building with pretty rooftop. We did the combo day and night tour. Whilst I thought they did a great job on having slightly different materials for the audio guide and the night tour, I thought the night tour was slightly disappointing, as maybe I have seen heaps of impressive light show projections so the wow impact isn't quite there. In my opinion if you want to learn more about the building and take your time doing so the day tour was better

Night over day visit. Only the outside (facade + rooftop) are worth seeing... as the interior really doesn't have much to offer.All else been written, so here are our tips:- if you want to read all about the place and listen to the audioguide, take a day tour to have time that allows for it.If so, book the place just after Casa Battlo (10 mins walk from there)... as Battlo is more spectacular and best experiences with less people... whereas Pedrera is nothing too special and can be easily visited with larger crowds.- if you only want to see what Pedrera is worth for (in our opinion)... it is best experienced at night... a tour that includes a guided tour of the building (most interesting areas being the lobby, the attic and the roof), a light show on the roof, some free time on the roof and a glass of cava at the end.- if you take the combo ticket (day AND night), like we did... you'll find some info repetitive.

Pleasing La Pedrera. We were lucky enough to go on a quiet day and did not need to queue for tickets. However I understand that it can get very busy and access can be difficult so would recommend booking tickets in advance.We loved this building, it gave you a real insight into Gaudi, the architecture and the views from the roof were amazing.Would thoroughly recommend a visit to La Pedrera.
Another gem by Gaudi. You wouldn't believe this building is still inhabited today. Great architecture again, the natural shapes are so visible and the roof is just a delight! Great experience!

Great visit, the audio tour brings it to life. A fantastic Gaudi building, the Quarry and how it's design still has the wow factor 100 years after its conception is a tribute to the man. The only warning is that you need to be prepared to climb 6 flights of stairs to the roof and on the roof, if you are uneasy with heights, this may not be the place for you.However, that said it is a great experience and you certainly get an insight into Gaudi's techniques. As with many of the main attractions in Barcelona, book online in advance and choose a time to suit you. You will not regret the experience!

Viva Gaudi!. Visiting the attractions that Gaudi has been involved with in Barcelona is not a cheap exercise. However, having done the rounds then the entrance fees are well worth the expense. La Pedrera is quietly spectacular and the more you look, the more you see. In their heyday the apartments of La Pedrera must have been most spectacular - what's more they still are. Gaudi, genius or madman, was in my opinion was light years ahead of his time. His methods of design were highly visionary and the efforts demanded of the craftsmen used were immense. Long may this wonderful architecture be around to impress the generations to come.

Lovely curved architecture.. This building adds grace and beauty to a busy city street. I'd love to see a whole housing complex designed in this manner using natural curves. We did not get the chance to go inside as we were on our way to nearby Casa Batlo but the views from the roof must be amazing.

Crazy, but interesting.. This building is just so crazy! I really liked how they told you in the tour the reasoning behind some of his architectural moves, like that the designs on the roof don't just look crazy but also serve a purpose. Not nearly as massive as Sagrada Familia so I enjoyed it in a different way. The only thing is that I thought it was kind of expensive for what you get... would have liked it if it was a little more realistic of a price for what you get.
Beautiful oblige. One of the Must see... in Barcelona, a classic that needs to be visit. I stayed outside due to the long lines. There I find out that I can purchased ticket on line.

gaudi!. gaudi, one of the best venues to visit. amazing architecture and typically Gaudi off the wall decorated. the colours and tiles were fantastic. go early morning, be on the queue before 9am if you want less people there

Amazing Gaudi building with interesting roof terrace. Another masterpiece of Gaudi's. A must see. The roof terrace is very interesting. The inside is so so. Not sure if it's worth the ~25 euros entrance fee just to see the roof.
Cool Architecture. If you like architecture and art you will like La Padrera. I wasn't blown away by the tour, but it's worth going up to the rooftop to see the statues and the views of the city.

Roof top is great - look out for concerts. La Pedrera is famous for the statues you can see from below and the modernist architecture. What I really like is the roof top at night, with concerts. Watch out - absolutely worth a try and it gives you also some nice views into other terraces around.

A little disappointing. Compared to other Gaudi buildings, we found this one disappointing. The outside, roof and foyer were amazing, but many of the interior elements were drawn from his other buildings, but less spectacularly presented. This probably reflects the nature of the building. We found that the signs and directions for the audio guide and self paced tour were not well placed or organised, so that it was sometimes unclear where to go next or toget insights into what we were seeing.

Overrated and overpriced. Go to the roof, visit the apartment/museum. That's it. Nothing much to see actually. It might be of interest for architects but from a general tourist perspective it is way too expensive.

Beautiful house. Casa Milà, the other Gaudi’s @UNESCO World Heritage Site is just a few blocks up from Casa Batllo. Also known as La Pedrera (which means The Quarry), Casa Milà is also the bigger among the two buildings and the one you see photographed more often. At least that’s how I have perceived it based on the photographs I normally see of Barcelona. Judging from the crowd on the day of my visit, I would tend to agree.The lines at La Pedrera can be much longer, so I would definitely suggest booking ahead of time, and for EUR7 more, I highly suggest the La Pedrera Premium ticket. You get to skip the line, get the quick lift ride up to the roof without waiting, and you’ll also receive a visual guidebook of La Pedrera. Pretty good value in my opinion.The tour of Casa Milà begins at the roof. If you are a premium ticket holder, you take a separate lift and exit right into a beautiful rooftop view. I’ve never seen such a meticulously designed roof terrace that resembles more of a work of art than a typical rooftop.Just like Casa Batllo, Casa Milà was built as somebody’s residence, the Milà residence to be precise. Can you imagine coming home to such an interesting home, walk up to the roof and enjoy the evening sunset while having a glass of the best Spanish wine?As you walk along the path of the roof, you’ll often time pass archways. Look closely and you’ll see that Gaudi, a religious man has framed the archway to focus on 2 of God’s house: the basilica on Mount Tibidabo, and one towards one of his own design - the Sagrada Familia.The roof features uniquely constructed chimneys in a few groupings around the terrace, resembling guardians that watch over the residents of the house. Staring enough at it, they kinda look like Optimus Primes. Paying close attention to these fellas is actually quite fun. They look the same, but are somewhat different still.The rooftop follows a path around the hole in the middle that brings light into the inner courtyard. Around the terrace, there’s a few things I found interesting:1. The Knights of course.2. The view of Barcelona towards different directions, including views of the Mont Tibidabo, over Passeig de Gràcia and its surrounding areas.3. Seeing visitors jostle for the perfect photo opportunity with the knights.4. I also took note that this is actually quite a modern building, the most modern in its day. There was a lift built in, and it goes to the first underground car park in Barcelona. Progressive!I think I came to Casa Milà at the best moment of the day, just before sunset so you can still enjoy Gaudi’s work of art in daylight and stay awhile to see the changing light of the sun changes the colour of the courtyard.I love how the light glimmers at sun set. As twilight approaches, the roof baths in a golden glow that really showcase the majesty of Gaudi’s design.While the roof itself provide most of the awe of Casa Milà, the rest of the building is a dedicated museum to the building and to the life of Gaudi. There’s an exhibition of Gaudi’s constructions on the loft level, reconstructions of whole apartments inside the Casa Milà, remodelled after the glory days of the building’s origins. Walking down level by level, I felt like I’m moving through time. If there was less people on the visit with me, I can truly imagine myself back in the early 1900s. It would also be nice if my apartment was just right here, perhaps on the 2nd floor.

Another prowess by Gaudi. You may have seen the exterior of this wonderful building on photos, but the inside is amazing since it has been designed for a rich man in Barcelona in the 1910's. The rooftop is unique and has wonderful sights of Barcelona !
A Fantastic Experience. La Pedrera was everything we expected and more. The rooftop was magnificent and the rooms were very enjoyable. Gaudi was, indeed, a genius.

What a pleasant surprise. I had been to barcelona many times and enjoyed looking at gaudi's buildings from the outside. But this was the first time I'd been inside any of them. We visited la Pedrera (the quarry) and casa batlo. I would recommend you try and take in both as they are both incredible. We booked online to avoid the queues but to be honest when we turned up the queue was tiny anyway. After picking up your headset audio guide you enter the atrium which is just incredible. It's as if you're transported from the hustle and bustle outside into a waiting area for tenants!The lift takes you to the roof which boasts beautiful scenic views over the city. The architecture, divine. We spent nearly an hour on the roof just taking it all in. The visit then takes your down to the loft where you can learn about gaudi's design methods. Surprisingly interesting. Finally you go downstairs to a recreated 1900's apartment. That part of the tour was very educational and fun especially as they'd taken great care to restore the old furniture. Great site.

Daytime Great, Nighttime Not. This place is so awesome we just had to return a few years after our first visit. I made the mistake of not booking a few weeks ahead of time. Once we were in Barcelona there were no daytime tours available. So we went for the nighttime tour. I thought they'd light up the roof and the iconic chimney heads. NO! The had some awful light show projected on the larger statues and when it was over we were whisked back downstairs for some drinks. Gaudi would be turning in his grave if he could have seen it. Anyway, the inside is still nice at night. And we were out in front of the building in the daytime.
Amazing.... Make sure you have tickets. Also make sure you are in good shape, and able to walk up 8 flights of stairs.....The roof top is spectacular, views are well worth it...
Nice . It is nice, but if you must visit one of 2, go for casa batllo, it is more beautiful and diversified that this one. But definetely walk by both
Very cool.. We had a very nice visit here with much less crowds than Casa Batllo. We actually preferred this to Casa Batllo. Very interesting to see the apartment.

Impressive.... Like other reviews here...this building is impressive - Only seen the building from the outside - it's easily reached on foot - and is relatively near the Sagrada Familia and Casa Batlló...All 3 Gaudi buildings within 1/2 hours walk

Beautiful rooftop. Lovely building looking around courtyard, attic, apartments and the rooftop. Beautiful mosaic on chimneys and fantastic views over city. Recommend pre booking tickets though no queuing and audio guide very informative.

Expensive but an interesting visit. Thought the ticket entry to La Pedrera was quite expensive (20.50 euros per adult) but this did include an audio guide (and much better value than La Sagrada Familia!). Interesting place to visit to view Gaudi's architecture. The rooftop was particularly good as we had a beautiful, clear day so the views over the city were fabulous. A good way to spend a morning (we spent around 2.5h there in total) and you can view at your own pace without being rushed.

Good rooftop but definitely not worthy of the price. The rooftop is great and good for taking photos, but the apartment is so-so and not interesting as the rooftop. The most important thing is, this place is definitely overpriced, not worthy of 21 euros money. In my opinion, it worth at most 5 euros. Won't ever consider this building any more.

Disappointing Evening Sound and Light Show. After viewing Gaudi's spectacular Sagrada Familia Cathedral- truly a modern wonder of the world, and his famous Casa Battlo - thoroughly worthwhile, La Pedrera at night was very disappointing. After climbing a back closed stairway 7 flights, we toured the attic which featured many beautiful wooden arches- and nothing else. Then one more flight to the rooftop where the sound and light show was held. Images were poorly projected on the rooftop chimneys and structures, and had nothing to do with Gaudi or his works. We were not permitted to visit one of Pedrera's wonderful apartments which is the highlight of the day tour. All that followed was a glass of champagne in the open plaza of the building - definitely NOT worth the price of admission!

Amazing house!. Loved this place. Goudi designed it for a young couple and I have never seen anything like it before. You need to buy a ticket to get in. It's 20 euro each. But I think that's good value. You go up in the lift right to the roof and work your way down with headphones telling you all about the place. I loved it.

Average. The building is impressive. But the trip to the roof of the building is expensive and not worth it. Inside the building is modern and unimpressive compared to the outside. Its a lovely building bit too u don't need to go in, it can be seen from a city tour bus.

Iconic building in Barcelona, saw from the outside! . La Pedrera is one attraction that does not disappoint, in fact it looks better in reality than in any of the photos! Being one of the main sights in Barcelona, one should not miss it.Did not go in since the entry price seemed a bit too much and I am not a big fan of architecture. But must visit and take some photos from the outside!

Definitely worth a visit. We went when in Barcelona on business. We didn't book in advance, but we took advantage of the "premium" entrance, which cost a bit more, but expedited the process; going straight to the head of the line to the elevator. Definitely worth the small additional cost. The architecture and history of the building are fascinating. The audio tour was really informative. We highly recommend it.

Rip off and tourist trap. The night visit: total rip off and tourist trap. You don't even get to see the apartments and inside for 34 euros! We bought our tickets the night before after asking the teller the difference between day and night tours. She never mentioned not visiting the apartments themselves. After our night visit, we went to her to complain. She insisted she had warned us and that it was our problem. Which is false. Spoke to others on our tour and they also had not been informed and felt duped and we're very disappointed. If you're truly interested in architecture and Gaudi, pay less and go see Casa Batllo and Palau Guell instead. Or at least go during the day.

Great Visit. Taken by the figures on the roof and the design of the building. Did not have advance tickets but not a problem as only a couple of people in line. The visit starts with an elevator ride to the roof to wander among the tall figures which are actually chimneys and ventilation shafts. It is much larger than it looks from the ground. Then to the attic which has amazing arches and very interesting exhibits. Next is going through the top floor apartment.
Interesting especially in the apartment. The begining was a little disappointing to us but once we got into the apt. things changed and were very impressive and interesting
Expensive but well worth it. One of Gaudi's must see attractions. The roof is iconic and the exhibition gives engineers and architects an insight into how it all hangs together.

Beautiful, but skip the lighted night tour. Considered as one of Gaudi's best buildings, do visit, but skip the light show at night. It intends to show Gaudi's vision of how nature and architecture should enhance each other by projecting images of nature on the buildings features after dark. Instead of adding to Gaudi's vision, it detracts from it. You can't see the rooftop structures very well. Also, they ruined the roof by putting ugly chain link fences up to protect visitors. They intrude on the experience and also detract from Gaudi's designs. Instead, they could have used unobtrusive thick glass. You can visit the courtyard free.
Absolutely Beautiful. The place was amazing! The views from the top were awesome. The architecture was amazing and the history boy the artist was interesting.
Marvellous!. A great experience by day and night. Wonderful architecture and details about the life in the beginning of the 20th century.
A must. One of my favorite buildings in the city. Amazing work of art and very interesting visit. You also get a nice view of the city from the last floor. Book online.

Fantastic. I really enjoyed this attraction. The roof top was out of this world. I enjoyed the tour around the rooms. Highly recommend. It was nice to go to an attraction in Barcelona that you didn't have to book in advance and just walk in off the street.

On drugs or what? Go at night!. This place is simply amazing! We had a package that included dinner and then a tour at night and a light show on the roof. Dinner was good, not a gourmet feast but very nice and at a reasonable price. It included wine, salad, soup, main and dessert. It also included water and bread but we had to ask for them. Our waiter was very prompt and professional. The night tour started in the ground floor entrance area to the building and proceeded from there. We could walk up the stairs, 8-9 flights, or take the elevator. Once at the top we went into the attic and several very nice displays on the building and techniques used were discussed. Again, our tour guide, in English, was excellent. Then the light show on the roof...totally unexpected but well worth it! And we also had a great view of the city of Barcelona at night. Fortunately we had timed our outing so it was a new moon.

Highlight of our weekend in Barcelona. Visiting La Pedrera was my personal favorite activity! If I could, I would have stayed up there all night long. Coming around sun set is really worth it, too. The warm light is making Gaudi's architecture even more special. Bring your camera! ;)

Didn't go inside - and probably should have. Cool from the outside, but should have booked a ticket with their great booking system and wandered around inside. We didn't have time for all the sights unfortunately - but even just walking past this place is a treat.

Imaginative place to have lunch. Couple viewing this artistic abode with having a relaxed and enjoyable lunch. Cool, calm atmosphere with a varied and interesting menu. Scallops, mussels, oysters, lamb. Great service and even better Campari spritz.

Great Gaudi learning location. Buy your tickets online and save the queues, and go early in day! Very long lines and crowded conditions otherwise. Beautiful example of Gaudí's work, which I didn't know much about before coming to Barcelona but now have a strong appreciation for his genius.

A highlight!. Great example of Gaudi's residential work. Fascinating and really enhanced by the audio tour. Clearly laid out. Every inch is a new discovery. Don't be put off by the high entry price - worth every Euro!

Visit La Pedrera. If you have only one day in Barcelona, make a point to visit La Pedrera. Gaudi's genius shows through everywhere in this unique property. The roof alone would be worth the visit, but you also get to see the attic with its many arches and an early 20th century apartment. Buy tickets in advance on the Inernet.
Interesting place. Visit this place! and check the luxury stores near to it, dring a nice Sangria at a bar nearby and enjoy your day!Nice building, nice story behind it.
So ahead of its time!. This is a remarkable Gaudi building, so advanced at the time. It's really lovely, I'd like to live there today! There are so many details to admire.

Questions answered. This building immediately raises 2 questions for me: How can such a building be built? What is it like inside? The self-guided tour answers these questions and more.
