For example, what did an apartment look like when new? Answer: very nice, even by modern standards! Of how many places nearly 100 years old can this be said? No doubt you will have your own questions, and yes there are people on site who can answer.

Amazing experience for both day and night visits. Absolutely stunning piece of architecture, one of the few places I think are must-sees (Eiffel tower is not one of them), a few things to note:(1) The queue can get quite long especially in the morning so opt for a late afternoon slot(2) Pre-book tickets so you can visit at the allocated time without queueing for an hour (reasons as per point 1) this will put you under the fast pass queue (yes even with fast pass there is still a queue!)(3) On rainy days the terrace might be closed but be patient as they will re-open when the drizzling stops.(4) The night visit is guided, so it is shorter compared to if you were to explore at your own pace, but NO CROWDS because of limited tickets, very nice to have the place to yourself (somewhat). The visit ends with a fantastic night light show at the terrace (see the pictures) - amazing to experience the Casa at night.Ends off with a glass of bubbly cava or juice (your choice) with a group of 15~20 visitors Had a wonderful time and the tour guide was very personable and knowledgeable, definitely exceed my expectations.Summer sun sets around 8.30-9.00pm, so that's when the Casa transforms with all the lighting, consider that when pre-booking a specific time.

loss of money. We read everywhere that we must visit this house. We paid 20€ for one ticket and we were really disappointed . You cant see much from this house inside and its little bit claustrophobic there. It is loss of Money.

A visit worth it. Make time to visit Casa Mila. Photos can't describe what is really feels like to be up on the roof. Tickets are pricey but worth it. Day tickets less than night or combo ticket. Also includes walk through a furnished apartment and the attic rooms with exhibits about Gaudi and his buildings.

Night visit was not quite what I expected.. We went for the night tour and lighting on the roof. The interior tour was ok. Went onto the roof for the light show and although enjoyable, I would not highly recommend it. Not sure what we paid as the wife bought the tickets, but would not do it again. Surprisingly, my wife, who enjoys that sort of thing even more than I do, was a little disappointed as well.

A good summary of Antoni Gaudi. Entry ticket is a little pricey but the tour was quite informative. Although the most unique aspect of the building is in fact it's exterior - which can be seen from the street. But the rooftop is very worthwhile of visiting. The clever and comical design of the chimneys and views of the city from the tip is very charming. Also, the attic provided good information about Antoni Gaudi - which is inspiring.

Architecture outstanding. another place by Gaudi... way before its time. If you consider that this was built before 1930, Must see the interior than the roof as well. Be sure to buy tickets in advance to save the long line ups

Divine Gaudi's masterpiece. One of the most impressive masterpiece of that genius called Gaudi.Don't miss a visit and don't forget to pass in front of it at night when the lights are on.Another show certainly.
More than a crazy design. Discover a creation of light, comfort and ingenuity. The use of natural shapes and the creative approach to meeting the needs of the project are awe inspiring.

Gaudi live !!. Part museum, part high-end apartments this is a great way to explore Gaudi up close and personal. He may be more famous for Sagrada Familia but this is a great example of his uniquely creative approach to form and function.

Apartment building designed by Antoni Gaudi. As a part of the full day tour of Barcelona with Explore Catalunya we visited this unique building on the corner of Calle Paseo de Gracia and Provenca. Completely designed by Antoni Gaudi, it is quite unique. The visit allows access to the entrance hall, the rooftop and one of the apartments furnished as it may have been. There is also an exhibition in the roof space.
MAGIC. The imagination of Gaudi is incredible.. You can admire it from outside..Gaudi's buildings are a must see for all visitors of Barcelona, and this is one of them. Unique in style.
You could live here too!. The magic of Gaudi is everywhere in Barcelona, not least at this great building. People still live in apartments here. The attic is a labyrinth of arches. A must.

A MUST SEE. The work of Gaudi can be overwhelming at times but this building fascinated me. It didn't disappoint. The apartment we toured was so unique and the interior courtyard of the building was wonderful but nothing could beat the rooftop. It looked like a scene out of Star Wars. Simply amazing!

Really interesting and worth a visit. I didn't expect to get so much information on this tour - it's really interesting you get to see the architectural concepts behind his work. Despite the steep price it's well worth a visit. The views from the rooftop are fab, as is the rooftop itself - the futuristic style is still so relevant today.There is a lift if you don't fancy the 8 floors of stairs but the walk is not bad and worth it to not be squashed into a lift.

Must see. The self-guided audio tour that comes w your ticket gives the best explanation of Gaudi style architecture and the role/influence of nature in structures seen here and in Park Guell, Casa Batllo & La Sagrada Familia. This was very interesting. I recommend going to Casa Padrera before Casa Batllo.

Another must see in Barcelona. THe audio guides were really helpful explaining all parts of the building. Be prepared to take the stairs, elevator is a long wait but be forewarned there are a lot of stairs. The views from the roof are great, you can see Sagrada Familia thru a well intended arch. the tour of the apartment was so interesting.

Perfect Gaudi. A must.. The house is well worth a visit and very well set out with great explanation . Perfect example of Gaudis architecture and the interior is exceptional. Examples of his other work covered as is his furniture and interior decor. Highly recommend.
Love Gaudi!. Did the tour around the house with the audio guide. It was all very interesting and Gaudi was a most incredible architect, the building is like no other.

Great museum experience . Gaudi was a MASTER of engineering, architecture and art!! La Pedrera (Casa Mila) is a masterpiece!! Beautiful beyond words!! Could never be built today which makes it even more remarkable !! Form truly follows function here!The staff was proactive and extremely sensitive to my wife's mobility issues, providing access to all areas of the tour by elevator sparing her the pain of stairs. A highlight is or week in Barcelona!

Amazing place. Stunning building and the "museum" in the attic provides some wonderful insights into the genius of Gaudi.The rooftop design is breath taking - I enjoyed it despite suffering from vertigo. Wonderful views across the city too.The showcase apartment is also an extremely enjoyable peek into a past era.Beware of the "Free photo" which isn't free, you only get it free if you buy one other photo for 10 Euros. We thought it was a "value added perk" due to the ticket being so expensive but unfortunately, like most things in life, nothing is free.Overall a very thought provoking and inspiring trip.

Brilliant- took me by surprise.. Inside it looks like someone has just popped out- a real sense of life going on, not soulless .roof top crazy views of chimneys and panaramic views of this vibrant city..
Not to miss. Gaudi made extraordinary architecture and this is the most important building he made. Do not forget to visit the roof !!!
Very interesting. I love the way this building design. If you don't have the time to go inside it okay. At lease go and stop to look the outside.

Another great experience of Gaudi's masterpiece. Another stunning architecture by Gaudi. I visited La Pedrare after my visit at Casa Ballot, still amazed by Gaudi's creativity and master workmanship. The roof garden is even more attractive than the one in Casa Ballot. It is good to go there on a sunny day because you can enjoy a beautiful view of the neighbourhood.There is a restaurant on the first floor of the building which you can see the interior design echoing the design of the building, it is a good place to take rest after tour and to enjoying the "taste of Gaudi".

A Must See!. To understand the creative range of Gaudi's work, La Pedrera will not disappoint. This home gives an insight into the functionality of Gaudi's work along with this genius for engineer feats. It feels personal and human along with playful and full of surprises. Headset guides can often be boring and mundane, not here. Don't miss it.

Incredible architectural home.. Beautifully designed and home created by Gaudi. Different from everything else you have seen and amazingly developed over 100 years ago. Attention to detail, meeting the needs of residents and establishing a home for the ages speaks to Gaudi's brilliance.

Amazing architecture. If you have to choose between this and Casa Batlo, choose this one.. Quite expensive but worth the visit. The architecture is mind blowing from the unusual roof and perfectly well preserved apartments inside. Plan around 1.5 hrs here.

Another of Gaudi's creative concepts brought to life. Please refer to my review of Casa Batllo. Although not as colourful the roof of La Pedrera is something to behold. Absolutely stupefying and wonderful. An alien landscape.

unique night experience. just experienced night visit, which was great. For 34 Euros each we had an overall excursion and magical light show on the roof top. Not sure if it's best value for money, but worth it if you haven't seen anything like it before. Some seating would be appreciated.

Enough to see from outside. La Pedrera was interesting for me only from the outside, the inside is basically a museum to show how people leaved there when it was constructed. Save your money to visit Casa Batlò's inside.
Must see. Don't miss a visit to the pedrera, but the ticket online, the roof is spectacular, the inside of the building and the rooms with furnitures are very interested.

Enjoyable evening. We chose to visit La Pedrera for the evening illumination display. For us, it was a good choice. The group tour was a reasonable size and the guide spoke excellent English. She explained about the history of the building and Gaudi's ideas to create comfortable living spaces for the residents. The ventilation ducts were amazing for their purpose as well as for the construction on the roof on which the illuminations were displayed. My husband was able to use the lifts as he has mobility issues, but he chose to not venture too far along the roof spaces. I stayed to the center myself as I have a fear of heights. The show was interesting, but ran a bit long for my taste. Also, I was more interested in the building itself rather than the music and lights. Glass of cava and sweet treats at the end were a lovely touch.

A Taste of Gaudi. The visit starts at the terrace, where we spent quite some time enjoying not only the architecture of the building but also the view to the neighboring buildings, the Sagrada Familia and the sea. We then head down to the attic and the fully decorated top-level apartment.Learning about Gaudi's approach to architecture and construction techniques is always pleasant we we certainly did not regret the visit, but if you're on a budget or short on time and have to select only one of Gaudi's houses in Passeig de la Gracia, I'd recommend Casa Batlló instead, because it shares the same genius in architecture in a warmer atmosphere.
Good experience of Gaudi. Visited here after first visiting Sagrada Familia. Althoughwe thoroughly enjoyed our visit here it was second to visiting Sagrada familia. Great experience though.

Nature and geometry resounds in this building.. Besides the exterior of the La Pedrera, the rooftop and attic area provide an insight into the engineering and architectural design genius of Gaudi. The apartment and courtyard areas toured were beautiful and amazing with the incorporation of nature. Again, Gaudi was innovative and meticulous right down to the ergonomic door handle designs.

Don't just look from the street, go up to the roof. The roof top terrace is quirky and stunning, with views of Barcelona.
Entrance ticket includes entry to apartment, & headphone guided tour.
We did not buy our ticket in advance & no queues.

Blown away. This was the first work of Gaudi we visited and we were blown away by his artistry that blended form and function. All of his designs symbolizes something but functional at the same time. It was out-of-this world so to speak. It's quite pricey but very much worth it.

Very unique. The owners lived on the main floor and rented the upper floors!
Very unique edifice. Did Goudi read "The Hobbit" before designing.
Must go to the rooftop!
Buy "anytime" ticket in advance to avoid line.

Classic, but oh those stairs. Fantastic experience and certainly well worth the admission, the views from the roof terrace are stunning , the only downside is the climb up to the roof which is really energy sapping, it is something that should be on the tickets , there is a lift but it's a bit of a queue, there is also a lot of climbing to get across the roof terrace but don't let that spoil what is a remarkable piece of architecture

Don't miss the attic!. Be prepared for some surprises and some disappointments here. The guide books rave about the roof and the apartment, but say little about the courtyard or the attic. The roof does not have particularly good views -- mostly scenes of air conditioning condensers -- and the uneven steps make moving around up there arduous. (And note: if you are at all uneasy about heights, you'll absolutely hate the roof!) The apartment is not especially beautiful, even if it is entirely authentic to upper middle class living in 1910; you'll find no gorgeous staircases, ceilings, or architectural details. The attic, though, is fantastic -- like walking though an undulating whale skeleton. The courtyard, too, is beautiful with unexpected murals. All in all, worth the high entrance fee, if not entirely as you'd expect. Note: I went on a Thursday at 3:00 in the afternoon -- no line at all!
Too expensive . We were three students and we had a reduction and we paid 18€ to get in. You can go only to the roof and in one of the houses. It wasn't something special.
Another Gaudi must see. Audio tour provided on entry. Plenty to see inside. Queues for lift to get to roof space. Can walk up steps to miss queue. In attic space exhibits on Gaudi work.

Could you imagine living in this apartment. Definitely a highlight. Again book in advance if you can although we managed to get entry tickets at the door. Lots of stairs, but worth it. We chose to walk up to the rooftop display as the queue for the lift was long. Once on the roof you just marvel at what Gaudi was able to accomplish and then when you go down back through his apartment it still seems livable today even with an ensuite. Incredible furniture and furnishings. Loved it.

Take the night tour - and pre book tickets online. Expensive but worth it. the Light show at night is unbelieveable, just go
watch it. And if you pre order online - it comes a bit cheaper
A Gaudi masterpiece you MUST see. This was one of my favourite Gaudi pieces to see in real life. Around the corner from Casa Batllo and easy to find.

Not much to see except for roof. Went for the nightime light show. Waste of money. The reality is that there is not a lot to see here, as only a small part of the building is available for viewing. Do not go to the lightshow at night, it was dumb. They have some exhibits in the attic about Gaudi which are interesting, but beside part of the bottom and the roof, you don't really see anything worthwhile. I would spend my time at the two good Gaudi attractions: Sagrada and Casa Batillo.

Take both the day and night tours if you can. We bought a combination ticket for both the daytime and night tours. We thoroughly enjoyed the daytime tour and were surprised at how much more we got out of the nighttime tour. There is a very small amount of overlap between the two. The daytime tour gave us a real feel for the building and its design, and the audio-visual show on the rooftop at night was well worth the small extra cost.

Fascinating building, amazing architecture and Gaudi lessons to boot. We spent a few hours on the Audi guided your of this building. It's not cheap, but it's truly fascinating and worth the money. The rooftop is stunning as are the views from up there. The tour also offers interesting insight into Gaudi's influences and techniques.

Amazing - pre-booking recommended!. Antoni Gaudi was commissioned to build this set of apartments for the rich Mila family. The apartments were for self use as well as to rent out. The design was inspired by different aspects of nature but is well thought out and functional to gain maximum space and light into the apartments. Even now the building is multi-use, I.e. not all of it is used as a museum despite it being World Heritage listed. Access to the roof is via the lift - The roof is a key highlight and you realise how well Gaudi planned every archway. Although the chimneys look like Knights, they are functional and truly beautiful. Check the weather before you go as the roof may not be accessible on a rainy day. The interior is also grand full of fluid and organic features mixed with art nouveau.

Casa Mila. Great example of modernisma by Antoni Gaudi. Built in the early 1900's as an apartment investment for a wealthy family, its definitely on my list of things to see in Barcelona. The "Stone Quarry"rocks!

Not good as Casa Batlo. We had a visit to here bıth day and night show. Day was so boring and meaningles and sounded so much like of Casa Batlo as giving reference to Gaudis' work but there was no vision tool so it was all talking and talking. The bast part of the night was audiovisual show at roof it took like a 10 mins. And the last but not the least free Cava and champagne was waiting us downstairs.So I wpuld recommend to have a night tour instead of a day as the night covers all the dialog plus with a audiovisual show and free drinks
Amazing. This building is like something out of a Harry Potter film, you cannot help but stare at it, the people that live there are so lucky

Origins Show and Dinner. We went for this deal and felt it was an excellent experience and good value. The meal was high quality 4 courses and drink. The staff made adjustments to the menu to accommodate my friend who has coeliac disease ( gluten free) The tour of the building was interesting and informative and the 'Origins' show very atmospheric . All rounded off with a glass of Cava - perfect!

Major Artistic Work. One of the most important civil building designed by Gaudi. Easily recognizable on Passeig de Gracia as it looks like a giant sculpture. The roof is probably the most spectacular work letting you believe that you're floating amongst stone clouds.A marvelous place to appreciate the great talent of a brilliant artist.

Incredible Building. We consider this one of the highlights of our visit. The building is absolutely beautiful. We loved touring the apartment to see what life would be like living in this building. The vault expo space had some fascinating exhibits and a lot of information on the architect. The audioguide was also very helpful. However, the rooftop really did me in. As beautiful as the terrace and view were, the terrace steps were difficult to manage, the railings seemed insubstantial, and the crowds did not allow for easy navigation. Purchasing tickets online was very easy and very helpful. We highly recommend this tour.

Top example of Gaudi's vision. An art history professor friend of mine feels strongly that La Pedrera (Casa Mila`) provides a better understanding of Gaudi's vision than some of the other architectural wonders of Barcelona. Having also visited the breathtaking Sagrada Familia and the jewel Casa Battlo, I tend to agree with her. Gaudi designed La Pedrera from nothing and it was completed in his era (whereas the struture of Battlo existed before Gaudi and obviously Sagrada Familia is yet to be completed).I didn't prepurchase tickets for La Pedrera. I worried this would be a problem but upon arrival, there was hardly any wait at all. If the line for the elevator is long, take the stairs up 8 flights to the attic and the roof. On the roof, you encounter these other worldly statues and one of a kind views of Sagrada Familia in the distance and the Eixample district. The parabola covered attic is worth an extensive visit, explaining Gaudi's and his masterpieces. I loved the interiors, perhaps even more than Casa Battlo. Gaudi demonstrates a remarkable understanding of how to capture light and how to combine form with function.

Incredible place to visit. It is advisable to pre book a timed visit, which we did. There is a great audio system to tell you all about where you are and what you are seeing. One hint, the tour directs you up the stairs which we used, but there is a lift! You start on the roof and take your time to take it all in, as it really is the most fantastic experience. We were there for just over two hours which seemed to go by in a flash. A truly amazing place to visit.

Stunning Gaudi apartment block. Gaudi packed many innovations into this apartment building, including the iconic chimney toppers. The roof top is a must, and the floor just beneath the roof contains a sort of museum on Gaudi.

Take the night tour for a more relaxed view. We took one of the night tours which are more expensive than going during the day but quite a different experience. The group was quite small and our tour guide was very good. She told us about the history of the house then took us through the attic and up to the roof for the light show. My favourite thing about the tour was that there was plenty of time to take in the view from the roof after the show had finished and then you could relax with your glass of cava. There was no rush to leave and altogether we were there for a couple of hours.

Rooftop is Filled With Massive Art Structures!. One cannot adequately describe how magnificent and breathtaking it is to walk out onto the rooftop and see the massive art structures emerging like stone statues on Easter Island! La Pedrera is filled with art and history and remains a source of some private residences with central residence and rooftop open to the public. It is easily combined with a visit to nearby Casa Batllo as well as a lovely lunch on the Passeig de Gracia which is lined with tiles made from art molds used in the Casa Batllo...magical. Be sure to purchase tickets in advance for expedited entry which is well worth the few extra Euros and allows immediate entry avoiding all lines!

Amazing designs and architecture--What a genius he was!!. Don't miss this place. We had seen this place on a prior trip to Barcelona, but did not have the time to tour the inside. This time I was determined to see the inside and I am so glad we did. What an amazing place. Don't miss this tour. The roof and views are spectacular.
Night time show . Great light show on top of the roof followed by a glass of cava after .the chimneys inspired george lucas storm troopers in star wars . Apparently

You can't beat Gaudi. One of Gaudi's final works this building is striking in many ways. We attended a friend's piano-recital in the concert space and enjoyed it very much. There are many events at La Pedrera and even if you only have time to see the exterior it is well worth it.
wonderful. after we spent 2hrs looking for this place we were very pleased with the building, and the audio guide is a must. you are not rushed and can spend a good two hours looking around.

Breathtaking!. We took the self-guided audio tour around La Pedrera and were blown away by the whole building. It really does have to be experienced first hand to appreciate the surreal but stunning beauty of this magnificent building

Amazing architecture by Gaudi. As we couldn't get into Sagrada Familia right away at 9am, we headed straight here. At 9:30am on a Sunday we were fortunate enough to just walk up and get a ticket for immediate admission. When we came out an hour later, the line ups were LONG!! So if you can, pre-buy a ticket online. We went up to the roof with the audio headsets and learned all about the structures and reasons for each. He really was brilliant! After you are finished on the roof, you come down to the attic and learn much more about Gaudi the man, the architect, his approach to architecture. His love of nature is reflected in everything he does. down another floor you see an apartment furnished for the era. Apartments on lower floors are actually being lived in. Well worth the time we took here!

Touring the apartment, attic, and roof is more interesting than it sounds.. After the Sagrada Familia, I'd put La Pedrera next on the all-things-Gaudi visit list. Get the audio tour as it will explain much more than you will get from the signs (which are in English as well as other languages). This building really shows you what a creative architect Gaudi was - the building has underground parking and was designed before many people had cars. The apartment is very livable by today's standards. The attic is really interesting with its brick arches and open spaces. And you'll take a gillion photos on the roof. But be forewarned, they close access to the roof if it rains because the tiles get slippery. Plan to spend a couple of hours here to see the apartment, attic, and roof.
Stunning. There's nothing like a freaky Gaudi building to make you wonder if there is life on other planets. A must for architecture lovers.

Excellent for Gaudi Fans. The big event at this site is the roof and you are ushered into an elevator first. Then you can spend time in the attic where there are several exhibits, then you continue to the apartment.If the line is long consider a Premium Ticket which is 27euro (regular admission is 20.50 euro) . You will enter right away as well as receive a nice souvenir booklet with photos and quotes from Gaudi. I thought the Premium Ticket was worth it.

Great attraction. We went at night, you can book tickets in advance, great atmosphere much quieter, guided around. Beautiful light show on roof then finished off with a glass of cave, would highly recommend, perhaps not for children

Wonderful. Book in advance or go late afternoon when the crowds have left. Best to go on a fine day to enjoy the roof top. Another wonderful Gaudi creation. A very good insight into residential living of the innovative rich in the Art Nouveau era in Barcelona. The exterior is easier to see than Casa Battlo, being on a corner.
the technology was great. they give a phone that tells and shows, when u put it onto places, the place's specifications. it was very nice and useful.

Do not miss!. Don't miss the opportunity to see as close as it's possible one of the great Gaudi's architectural wonders. First, save a few hours by booking online! Then enjoy this fantastic architecture and museum and remember that all was designed and built over a hundred years ago, in just six years!

Great Architecture... If you have even the slightest interest in architecture you'll love this place. The queues are pretty long standing in the sun so I would suggest pre booking so you can walk straight in. Its a long climb up to the roof past lots of private apartments . When you get there it's all worth while to see the crazy roof structures that are what Guadi is famous for. Below the roof in the " loft" you get to see the amazing construction of brick arches which look as if they were built yesterday . It really is incredible.
Gaudi was a genius. This house is beautiful and very different. Highly recommended, to see and understand how it was designed. The rooftop is beautiful and very interesting, and so is the museum.
Very inspiring!. It is a unique building with a unique rooftop!It is situated near another building of Gaudi, Casa Batlo. So, you can see their exterior on the same walk.
Take the night tour. I didn't appreciate the deep integrity and quality of this building until we visited. This is no stucco facade but solid chiseled lime stone. The night is great.

Friendly with GREAT tapas. Very tasty food. Even though we showed up without reservation the owner accommodated our need for table of four. Ordering was funny with little Spanish on our side and little English on the staff side. Value for money was very good. Wine recommendation fantastic.

Fascinating insight to Gaudi's work. We went as a group of six and bought a combined tour ticket with the roof top light show later in the evening. The queues are long so I would advice booking on-line in advance. Leave yourselves at least 1.5 hours (minimum) for the tour. The tour of the roof top and the apartment and the attic is via an audio guide which was part of the guide. I think it is essential. I saw some people wandering round without it but they will have missed so much. It is truly an amazing feat of architecture. The evening event is quite pricey for what you get but it is a one off. You get a bit more of a tour with a guide and a short but quite impressive light show on the roof with projections of the creation of the world and the links between natures and Gaudi's work - it is quite clever. And you get a glass of Cava at the end. You are not rushed and the group we were in was quite small so we did not feel squashed. Overall, the building was definitely worth it and the evening event added a little something extra.
Great !. loved it ! :-) what a genious this guy was. I admire people who dare to step out of the box and use people like Gaudi.

Also Known as Casa Mila -- Do Not Miss. I saw the outside of Casa Mila on the free Gaudi walking tour a couple of days before touring the inside. It appears to be less fabulous than the "Gaudier" Casa Batllo, but it if you are interested in Gaudi or enjoyed touring the latter home, you should not miss Casa Mila, a/k/a La Pedrera. It is an extraordinary building, as fascinating as can be, with wonderful, lucid demonstrations of some of Gaudi's innovative techniques. First, save a few hours by booking your tour of the inside ahead of time. It cost 20.50 Euros. I did it on my smartphone, and was modestly concerned (I'm in my 60s) about whether the scan of my phone would work for the entry as I did not have access to a printer, but it worked like a charm. The entry is on the side street. Second, get the included audio headset, but check it before you get going, the headphone wires tended to have shorts in them, which was annoying. (Don't worry about starting the tape while you are downstairs in the entry. You can always press stop and start again when you get to the appropriate room.) Now, enjoy this fantastic architecture and museum. Gaudi's conception of ergonomics over a hundred years ago, is extraordinary, and it is explained in detail here. I listened to and looked at everything, as well as spending time in the store, so I spent about 2-3 hours here. If you haven't already seen Casa Batllo, plan your day, and get the timed ticket for it the same day. It cost 27.50 Euros. It's another wonderful, and quite different, Gaudi building 4 blocks away and across the street on Passeig de Gracia in the opposite direction from Avinguda Diagonal. If you have time to kill, and want a little taste of home, there's a Starbucks diagonally across Passeig de Gracia (same side as Casa Batllo), just before you get to Av. Diagonal.

A must-see - save money for this one!. Achitectural gem way ahead of its time. Every corner is photogenic. It's the best place to understand Gaudi's design philosophy. Buy tickets in advance so you don't have to queue. :)

Worth seeing . I loved the ground floor and the roof. Amazing views from the roof were cherry on top. The rest of the museum was OK. It's a bit pricey imo for what you get, however I'd recommend it to everyone to see once.
Amazing . Got to see this in person the line is long so I'm sure you have your tickets try to get up to the rooftop and get some pics - can't miss

another gaudi work. Gaudi's work is always surprisingly unique and beautiful. This one is not very colorful compared to casa batllo and sagrada familia. But still worth a visit. We just cannot miss any Gaudi-design in barcelona. It's a pity we visited on a cloudy day. Would get better view when it's sunny.P.S. feel a little bit uncomfortable about the staff's attitude. They appears to be kind and warm to the couple in front of us but indifferent to us. That's the reason why we give a 4, not a 5.

Stunning Architecture . What a fantastic place to visit, a must see for any Gaudi fan or lover of modernist architecture. We paid extra for the Premium Upgrade which meant no standing in line. Even in early May there were long lines. Walk straight up to the Premium entrance, receive your audioguide and get escorted to the elevator. The visit starts on the roof with the stunning array of chimneys and excellent views of the city. Don't miss the view of the Sagrada Familia through one of the arches. Then down to the Attic to marvel at the models and design work that went into constructing this incredible building. Down one floor to the upper apartment where you can experience what life would have been like when this was built. Unfortunately the tour ends here as the rest of the building is still in use as apartments. Still worth the price of admission in my opinion.

The zenith of Gaudi's work indeed!!!. The work of a brilliant architect who used every form of nature (plant, fishes, water) in his work. Trully amazing is also the way he used light and ventilation systems and simultaneously tsansformed them into art pieces!!!!! A unique work!!!

I agree with 99% of the Reviews ! Unique Place to visit. We visited La Pedrera as part of the day and night tickets we purchased. It was everything we'd read and everything we were led to expect.The outside - in my humble opinion - doesn't compare with Casa Batilo in any way, but once inside Casa Mila comes into its own. I won't try to describe what it's like because to do that you'd have to compare it with somewhere else and there isn't anywhere else like it!! What you will do is find you keep shaking your head from side to side in disbelief and wonderment as every element of Casa Mila launches itself at you. From the rooftop architecture to the apartment, the attic, the list goes on, EVERYTHING Gaudi did was something mere mortals wouldn't and couldn't conceive of. His mind must have been made from different materials to ours! When you realise just how long Casa Mila has been there, and how revolutionary it was ( and still is now ) in design, you have to wonder if Gaudi was from a parallel universe.I can't do Casa Mila justice writing about it..... Honestly, just get yourself over to it and strap your jaw shut so it doesn't hit the floor when you see the place!!!

Bonkers and gorgeous. I debated about paying the 20 Euro admission fee per person to visit the inside (includes audio guide) and am really glad we did as the close up views are awe-inspiring. I'm not an architectural fan but the combination of the flights of fantasy combined with pure practicalities melt me into admiration. Did you know Gaudi made handles for doors and drawers by getting people to squeeze clay and then taking impressions...so the handles fit your fingers and make using them so easy! The visitor space is really well set out, you have a choice of lift or stairs up to the roof terrace and then wander your way though the attic, into a show apartment which illustrates perfectly how people, owners and servants lived, before coming back down into the courtyard. I made the mistake of exiting into the shop before using the loo - once you're in the shop, you can't get back into the fee-paying area so bear that in mind. Another one to get to early - we walked in at approx 10am and were able to get tickets for immediate entry and enjoy the terrace without being crowded but there was a queue for entry when we left.
It was good. It was good but not the most interesting I'm not a museum person therefore that may explain why I was not very interested but still very good experience

Worth the visit. We really enjoyed our visit to La Pedrera. It was rainy and the rooftop was closed at first. It did open during our visit. Make sure it is open otherwise not worth the $$$ But if you have to chose between this and Casa Batllo I would pick Casa Batllo.
What an amazing sight . Wow you really have to see this . We decided to walk the city and went looking for this amazing building . We weren't disappointed . Truly amazing .

Great night time visit. Go after dark and pay the extra for the light show in the roof, followed by champagne. Fascinating design, whimsical and fun atmosphere. Pair it with an evening at Casa Batllo.
Beautiful site. Very busy as you can expect but very beautiful and worth seeing. Interesting for all members of a family
Unique. One of Antonio Gaudi's most original buildings - it has to be visited and well worth the wait in the inevitable queue.
Night tour!. Really cool, to be in the building at night. A bit of history of Gaudi. The Guide was easy going and answered our questions. The light show on top of the building was unique,

Expensive but interesting both architecturally and culturally. We paid nearly twice as much for this as for sacrada Familia, but we still think it was worth it. The draws are the building itself, especially the roof; the preserved apartment, which was a fascinating glimpse of upper middle class life 100 years ago; and the large exhibit in the attic that illustrated Gaudi's approach o architecture and reviewed his major works and how they fit into early 20th century life in Spain.
Beautiful Gaudio architecture . Would like to explore this more, especially from the inside. We passed by on a bus tour, then walked around on our own. Very pretty!

amazing condo. Gaudi designed this unique condo where 4 families still live. You can visit the rooftop with its unusual chimneys and designs as well as one of the large, furnished apartments and the museum. It's a worthwhile place to visit.

desapointing visit. interesting visit, may be, if you have not seen the casa Batlo before. The roof top is not colored. The apartment you visit is not that of the first floor. This one was destroyed and in now a modern anonymous space of exhibition.
A must visit. This beautiful building is a must visit, great architecture, one of Gaudi's masterpieces, not to be missed.Big queues so book in advance

Loving Gaudi!. The challenge of the stairs is rewarded by the most magnificent views of Barcelona! We visited during the day with brilliant blue skies. Audio tour was limited but models and display in attic were great

The roof top is a must see. At E20.50 this is hardly the cheapest of attractions. They must take some money here as there was a queue and a busy ticket hall. Although the sign said they closed the roof on rainy days and it was raining we were still able to walk on the roof. This was the star of our visit and an absolute must-see - I don't know if they reduce the entrance fee if the rooftop is out of bounds but if not then it would not be worth it.We really enjoyed walking on the roof and admiring the many structures with which Gaudi adorned the top of the building even if it was too misty to see the way the archways frame other Barcelona attractions.The vaulted attic has an extensive display of models, photos and artefacts explaining Gaudi's technique. And the other main attraction is the apartment with period furniture that gives you an insight into both the period and the inside of the building - there are no straight lines.I have admired the Gaudi houses from the outside on many occasions but never visited the inside of any. So glad I did.
Magnificent architecture. A stunning building designed by Gaudi on the Passeig de Gracia. Well worth a visit - the roof alone is worth the entrance fee.

Book online!. We booked online , and choose a time to visit, definite must as the queues are long.We went straight to the rooftop as it had started to rain, it's worth noting that they close the roof when it rains for safety reasons.Interesting visit, the attic is beautiful and interesting.The rest not as lovely as Casa Batllo.
Beautiful! Don't miss!. I loved seeing La Padrera. Loved seeing the outdoor areas that I've only seen on Pinterest! This was one of my absolute favorite sites in Barcelona.
Just a beautiful buliding. It is only a beautiful building with a lot of people waiting to entry. Expensine fee for entrance. Barcelona owes her elevation to Gaudi!!!
Most unusual! . Most unusual shaped building that we saw from the top of an open top bus but would have been good perhaps to get a closer look at it and paid to look inside!
Unique and beautiful. Walking upon the rooftops of one Gaudi's masterpieces is an exceptional experience. Most definitely a sight nt to miss.

Architecture, history and views. A must see in Barcelona. The lines are long so get tickets online beforehand. Admire the exterior , then tour an apartment furnished with period details to see how a family lived. Great for kids. The information about Gaudi under the eaves on the top floor is thorough. The rooftop is simply amazing!Not to be missed.
Great rooftop.. Great roof top. The Attic level was also quite interesting. The apartment below is not very. Overall worth a visit but not as interesting as Casa Batllo.

Architectual masterpiece. This house was designed by Gaudy, a famous architect. He has buildings throughout the city. His style is unique and worth seeing. We took the stairs 8 floors up to avoid the line at the elevator. Also buy your tickets on line to avoid lines at the door. It takes about an hour to go through it. We found it a little confusing to navigate and might have missed a couple of rooms.
Must See!. Definitely a must see. Gaudi's culmination of skills are expressed here, right before his Sagrada Familia that remained unfinished. Really interesting.

The roof top is the coolest. Gaudi is an incredible and creative architect. The roof of this building is brilliant! Well worth a visit. Get your ticket on line. We didn't make it to the night-time light tour, but it looked very interesting. The tour of the attic and the models are so interesting and they tour you through an apartment also! If you are a Gaudi fan you should see this!

An absolute 'must' visit!. Casa Milà, also known as La Pedrera.It is a modernist building designed and built by architect Antoni Gaudi. The six-storied house is similar to a huge rock. Windows and doors remind grottoes.For its uniqueness, artistic and heritage value, it has received major recognition and in 1984 was inscribed on UNESCO World Heritage List, for its exceptional universal value.Nowadays it is the headquarters of Catalunya-La Pedrera Foundation and houses a cultural centre that is a reference point in Barcelona for the range of activities it organises, and the different spaces for exhibitions and other public uses it contains.Remarkable features of this unusual, fairy-tale-like house contain a curved, "wave-like" stone facade, twisted wrought-iron-decorations, a lack of right angles and a preference for naturalistic rather than geometric forms. The rooftop is especially beautiful, with many decorative chimneys and staircase exits.

Another Gaudi must see. This building is one of many Gaudi architectural geniuses in the city and definitely worth the effort to visit inside. Each has its own difference and cannot be compared. This building is still lived in by residents, so even more intriguing! Buy your tickets in advance to skip the queue and there is also a discount with the Barcelona Card.

My imagination ran wild here!. I recently visited La Pedrera for the first time -- somehow I hadn't visited it before. We went at a time when my health wasn't 100% and so paid the extra few euros to have the Premium Entry to the site, which was really well worthwhile. No queuing involved whatsoever -- we by-passed the queue just by paying a little extra. We went straight up to the roof in the elevator, as we were excited to see the wonderful chimneys and doorways and statues up there. It is without question Gaudi per excellence. Once up there under a blue Barcelona sky, with a gentle breeze blowing, it is so easy to let your imagination run wild, and make your own interpretation of the wonderful works of art surrounding you. It is absolutely fascinating -- how on earth did Gaudi have such a fantastic imagination . . . and, even more, how was he able to turn it all into being? Both my husband and I absolutely loved it. I could have spent hours up there. The rest of the house,and the fascinating courtyards, are very interesting, with special exhibits and lots of explanations about how Gaudi worked, and how his wonderful buildings came into being . . . . but the roof-top is the prize!!! I would go there again in a flash!

Great place to visit. ... We did a headphone tour which was good as you can look around at your own pace. We did the day and night tour. The night one is great as you look around the attic with the guide and then watch a light show followed by cava.Whilst the night tour was great, you need to do the day one to really look around the place as they don't let you look inside quite as much.
Meet the practical side of Gaudi. When you want to get a close look on the work of Gaudi, this is the place to visit. Great display of an early 20th century apartment.

Gaudis "La Pedrera" blows your mind. I keep this short: Just go and see for yourself what great building the modernist Antonio Gaudi has built.I was reluctant at first to go and see an apartment building. I am glad I got dragged along, because it is absolutely a must visit when you come to Barcelona.Highly recommended is an online reservation upfront, because then you get a time for the visit and dont need to queue.Its got so much to offer! I will go back for another visit for sure. I loved it.

Worth a visit. You will see unusual architectures and a completely kept and conserved apartment from the years in which it was first built. The terrace is good, the piso or apartment inside is amazing. There was also a photography gallery from a local artist that was very interesting. Souvenirs are just bad, do not buy there, too expensive and you can find the same or similar things outside
Awesome Gaudí style architecture . Awesome display if you love Gaudí's style. It rained when I was there and the rooftop was closed which I heard was the most amazing part.
My favorite Gaudi!. The audio guide of this Gaudi marvel was well worth the price. This building is just so unique with its structure, and colorful courtyard. The gift shop is massive.

Anti-climb acting. Being the pen-ultimate work of Gaudi before he got devoted to La Sagrada Familia, I think La Pedrera is a fine demonstration of Gaudi's architectural competences. Maybe even better than the ones that one can see in Casa Batllo. However, I think I enjoyed visiting La Casa Batllo more. The audio guide was concentrating more on the work of Gaudi in general rather than his work on La Pedrera instead. The roof was really a work of art! However, I would not recommend it for people who have any kind of difficulty with their legs, asyou have to go up and down quite many steps of stairs.
Birthday visit . Just extraordinary architecture. We didn't go in but just looking from the outside was enough for us. Stunning building and colours.

Impressed by so much technicalities in Gaudi's design. Stunning place, especially if you are interested in learning about Gaudi's design and architecture. I was amazed at how detail-oriented this place is. My preference goes to the floor below the terrace for its ventilation feature and its design.

Amazing. Visiting La Pedrera is the best choice for those who want to experience first-hand the main creations of Gaudi. A guided visit via earphones in various languages that provide details regarding each room and each architectural device.
Classic. This is the classic walk to do... Walk stop drink walk stop eat Columbus port U turn and walk back through gothic quarter.Las Ramblas is even more a must tan the Passeig de Gracia!

Super special. A sign of Barcelona, the place you cannot miss. Take a time not only to see it from outside, but try to visit the interiors - it's worth it. Go to the roof as well and enjoy the view. Personally, I like to seat in one of the banks nearby and enjoy the view of La Pedrera. Astonishing.

If you like architecture or construction, this is a must.. We had a private tour guide, Javier Sanchez who took us inside and on the roof to see this amazing place. Javier has studied Gaudi for years and was so interesting with his explanations.Highly recommend him and this site.

An absolute 'must', but get tickets ahead!. Gaudi's creation is second only to 'Sagrada Familia'. The functional beauty of the painted walls, the flues, air shafts, iron work balconies, is incredible. When Gaudi's teacher proposed he (Gaudi) was a genius or a madman. Time has shown 'A GENIUS'. Beware the ticket line can take more than 1 hour. Buy ahead on-line for easy access!

Original. We went here to discover Gaudi's architecture. We discover as well some information on how nobles of Barcelona would have liked to live at the beginning of the century. Very interesting and we'll organized

Cool video projections on roof. Interesting information on the details of gaudi work such as the doorknobs and inspirations from nature. Very cool nighttime projections into the chimneys with music. The tour downstairs lasts a long time and you have to stay with the guide. Book in advance.

Interesting Morning. Tour of parts of one of Gaudi's masterpieces.Numbers controlled as space is limited and you have to wait your turn in places.Very small lift to the roof and you make your way down through the areas open to the public (large parts are offices and apartments).Excellent rooftop views and well thought out historical displays.Found the audio guide useless and you need to be very careful on the roof in view of the many steps.Perhaps a little expensive and booking a time slot essential. Go early before the coach tours arrive!

Another outstanding Gaudi creation worth a visit. This was my 3rd visit to La Pedrera and it never stops to amaze me what a marvellous building and work have been done to maintain it. I'll be going back again.

Required Gaudi Visit. Gaudi influenced architecture immeasurably with his work in Barcelona, and this is an amazing example of what he could do. While the structure was originally built for another purpose, it now houses apartments...however, the tour is stunning. The rooftop structures are other-worldly and worth the price of admission alone. It was like nothing we had ever seen...it also lights up at night, but we did not opt for that option. Be sure to get tickets ahead of time because the wait in line can be lengthy, especially when tour buses are there. Be prepared for a lot of people, but don't miss this!

Must visit. This was my second time visiting La Pedrera. The first time I took a guided tour, and this time an audio tour. I would recommend a guided tour, because you hear even more about this extraordinary work of Gaudi, then in audio tour.

The house is cool but the visit is not worth the price. It's an expensive ticket to get in, and you get to climb up the stairs to the attic and the roof, and visit one fancy apartment. Sure, it's all cool to have the full-on modernista experience, but it's so overpriced... It's a nicely renovated house, the exposition is neat and tidy, the audio guide is free and helpful. But you get the thing also when having a guide book and looking at the building from outside. I don't think it's comparable to the experience you get from Casa Batllo.I'm very glad Gaudi got to design this house, and it's certainly an absolutely unique example of civilian architecture, but in the end that's what it is. A beautiful block of flats, but a block of flats. I felt asking myself 'Would I pay several tenners to visit a strangers' apartment building?'

Great, specially the Night show. Book online or you will be a part of the never ending lines to purchase tickets. As all Gaudi creations very expensive, specially the day & night option, but worth while as you have the space to breath. Barcelona is so much more than Gaudi...but I wouldn´t miss La Pedrera! Children don't pay to enjoy the space. My 6 years old loved it. Amazing night show and guided tour. Very special.

Fascinating building. Well worth a visit to see Gaudi's last project. We arrived at 10 am without pre-booked tickets and got in straight away, by the time we left a sizeable queue had formed. The tour consisted of roof top walk and then a tour of one of the apartments which was decorated and furnished in the Guadi period.Well worth a visit.
liked it! . nice building and arhitecture. Was quite impressed with Gaudi work in the early 1900. Nice presentation also and free audioguide included in the ticket price

Gaudi At His Best. In April there was minimal queuing and access to the roof, where the tour begins, is by way of stairs or lift for which there is a small wait. Disabled may be encouraged by the access by lift but there are many stairs on the roof in order to get around it.The roof offers spectacular architecture and good views. At the roof it is now possible to view the attic space demonstrating the structure and principle of construction and then a early 20th century (?) furnished flat.

Just a load of chimneys. Impressive Gaudii at it again with some stylish chimneys on top of an apartment block -very unusual and original. You can see where the Star Wars guys got some of their ideas. Be sure to visit the attic where there is load more Gaudi including the hanging chains. Get close and see where the parabolic architecture for the Segrada Famila came from

Ouch!. Watch out! Your senses are going to be involved into the life of the local bohemians of Barcelona! It is really amazing to see how this building was designed and how the people in it were using it! To me Gaudi is an architect without any comparison.

Fantasy Building. You can visit several floors of this building. One of the upper ones has wonderful brick ribbed ceilings. From the roof there is a nice view of Gaudi's church. There also is a nice shop as you leave.

maybe its because we came here after the familia, wasn't anything unique. was an ok place, the audio guide which is handed is quite interesting, but the place is a bit lacking, expensive , only the attic was interesting.

In a city spoilt by incredible Architecture Pedrera stands up.. If sombody told me a highlight of my trip would be sitting on the roof looking at a chimney I would maybe check the flights for Rome. But Pedera is just another functional yet incredible piece of work from a man who just can't do anything wrong.

Gaudi designed Apartment Building. Worth seeing but over priced. Visited La Pefrera on the afternoon after Sagrada Familia. Definitely worth seeing, but in my opinion the entrance fee is expensive. The main attraction is the roof top which has ventilation shafts disguised as whimsical figures. You also get to see one of the apartments which is quite luxurious.

Interesting. Gaudi was a genious and all his masterpieces. La Pedrera - Casa Mila worths the effort to arrive there (although I wouldn`t call it an effort because it`s located in a central area). We didn`t visited inside the building but from outside it`s a perfect place to admire by any architecture lover.

Gaudi chimneys... should you visit?. When you think of it as simply as that you would be difficult to think of why you would visit but when you imagine the complete building and its beauty you can fully see the majesty of this impressive sculpture.The mosaic of these organic chimneys are stunning and well documented but to be apart of these and walk around the rooftop to see the city for a different vantage point it amazing.Talk time to enjoy the museum they have included in the lower floors as it gives a great full impression of Gaudi's achievements throughout his life not just this one building.

Amazing museum. Beautiful breathtaking views of Barcelona from this view point. The beautiful centre of political discourse and intrigue in Catalonia. This building is so impressive and it catches your attention from the first moment. Nice place to go.

Afternoon and evening visits - wonderful. We booked daytime and evening visit to see the building illuminated. Go as late as possible so the sky is dark and the stars are out. They were both brilliant experiences and unforgettable. We booked in advance and it was good value for the two tickets combined. So much to see inside, the attic is superb and then the roof top. Go along and be amazed.

not worth the ticket price !. Only attic and roof to visit as rest of the building is private/residential. Audio guide wasn't as informative. The roof though certainly a masterpiece from an architectural point of view, looked underwhelming during bright daylight. Ticket price not worth what's on display. Try the magnificent Casa Batlo instead.

Amazing interior and exterior Gaudi. Built by Gaudi featuring his best interiors designs as well as the exterior. Don't miss the unique chimneys on the rooftop! Located near fine shopping stores as well. Ate lunch in the La Pedrera Cafe which was excellent and the ceiling is amazing to see as well in the cafe as part of La Pedrera.

Check out at night. As Gaudi has become a favorite of mine, I wanted to check out one of his other works. While some people regard La Pedrera his least exciting, it is still interesting to see. We enjoyed it at night. The light show adds to the beauty and is worth seeing. You also have a great view of the city. The tour is about 1 hour and informative.
Cool. Again, we didn't get a chance to go inside this building but from the outside it was visually appealing

Unusual. Booked online to avoid the queue, when you enter you get into a queue for the lift to take you to 6th floor - the roof, very unusual building and well worth a visit, we had an audio guide which was very helpful. You then go to the attic where there is a Gaudi exhibition and down to an apartment furnished as it would have been about 100 years ago. The whole visit took about an hour.
Great structure and the roof top was spectacular.. Not to be missed, great interior. It was well described with the audio head sets. It takes a couple of hours to see it all.

Not as Impressive as Sagrada Familia. It's interesting from the outside, definitely a gem in the neighborhood. But we saved an entire afternoon for Sagrada Familia which dwarfs all else in town.If you are interested in architecture and particularly in Gaudi, then certainly spend your 22 Euros to go into this small space with some examples of Gaudi's work.But for a few more Euros, you can visit his Pièce De Résistance, the Basilica, zoom up one of the towers (we chose the Passion Tower for its remarkable views of the city) and engulf yourself entirely in the spirituality and genius of Gaudi.For more of my Reviews of Fun & Romantic Places to Be, as well as Vintage Travel Tales, check out World Traveler Reviews dot com.
Nice Place. Very nice place, unique architecture from Gaudi, and quite interesting to know not only on the outside, but in the inside either!!

Best of the Gaudi's. This is a fantastic experience - if nothing else visit here. The visit is by timed entry only and covers a typical apartment, the entrance and the roof and attic - so plenty to see. The roof top with its free forms and chimneys and features is stunning and Gaudi at his best.

Fantastic roof just has to be seen. Amazing architecture which just has to be seen. Just loved the huge undulating roof and all the chimneys. A real experience. The attics with their ribs and the displays are also very interesting. Would recommend a visit. Did feel the 20euro entrance fee was expensive especially when compared to Palau Guell which is half that.
Barcelona Icon. No visit to Barcelona is complete without a visit to this place and the casa Battlo, its counterpart. There are always lines of people waiting to get in.
A unique experiance. This is a must location. the thinking that was invested in the design of this building is remarkable and it is also well preserved. a real experience.

Also known as the quarry by residents - book online. As we did not book online, when we got there the place was packed so we viewed it from the outside and went to the other Gaudi houses 10 minutes down the street.

Amazing art on rooftops - well worth a visit. see Barcelona by rooftops with amazing sculpture, imposing above the skyline. The internal courtyard is beautiful, stairwells and original door is majestic.

Don't miss the othe Gaudi's masterpiece. The Sagrada Familia dominates the Barcelona skyline but this other work by Gaudi is definately worth a visit just to see the genius of this man. The whole building is spectacular from the facade to the rooftop terrace, the most unusual designs that also are functional offer an insight into this man's genious and skills.The top floor offers a very interesting history of the buildings commissioning and construction Easy access and allow 1.5 hours for the visit
A must see. Get in touch with Gaudi at la pedrera through the nice architecture, the visualEffect and many others. Two ticket options are available with or without a guide.
Amazing. Very nice place for all types of people. I think its very coustly place for one person . for two person 23 euro its OK . that places should be for free like in sevilla.

Preciosa, però los horarios no tinen sentido.. Be careful beacause the sell tickets for 30 minutes before the closing time. When we bought the tickets we couldn't see the time table anywhere in the web and we had no more than 45 minutes to see all the house and to listen the audiguide (much more long than 30 minutes).After 30 minutes they asked us to go fastly to the souvernir store.

A must do when in Barcelona.. We went to La Pedrera twice, once during the day and also fro the night tour. I highly recommend the evening tour. It's a small number of people in the group and it's much more personal. The colors of the city at night are spectacular to say the very least.
EASL ILC 2016. Excellent place to visit and enjoy the fine work of gaudi. If you love the modern architecture then you shouldn't miss the opportunity to see it while you are in Barcelona

Impressive. Although it's 20 euros to visit, it's well worth it and you get a free audio tour available in 6 languages. They also show what his European contemporaries were doing which makes it more relevant. One of the original flats has been preserved. Modern architects and developers could be so much more inventive than the modern cubes 21st century homes are now. The roof is also stunning. Really enjoyed our visit.

Outside in daylight, The Origins by night. We stopped to take pictures of the outside during the day, but did not take the daytime tour. On our last night of the trip, we came back for The Origins show on the rooftop. The night tour of the interior wasn't amazing, but I did enjoy the models. The light show on the roof was beautiful and enjoyable- I would recommend seeing La Pedrera in this way.
Did not go in but from the outside it looked amazing. Another one of Gaudi's wonderful examples of architecture. We unfortunately did not go inside but the outside was fascinating.

Day and night tour. I did the day and night tour and the day tour you gain access to a few areas that you don't get on the night tour. The night tour you have the guide who tells you about the history which is interesting. I found the night rooftop show slightly disappointing to be honest but the day tour made the 40 euro fee worthwhile. The screens in the attic showing Gaudi's other work were excellent. The views from the roof are also pretty good including seeing the Sagrada Familia. If you're stuck between this or Casa Battlo then choose Battlo. Sagrada Familia might be better than both as well!
Suprisingly inexpensive. Great experience. The self tour takes about an hour. Helpful staff. i did not book in advance and waited about 20mins in the queue, but that was my fault.
Good but expensive. 20 euro pp, no reduction for elderly, La Pedrera is on the expensive side, but what a roof and what a nice appertment.
Great Gaudi building. Amazing Architecture and use of colour. Well worth a visit while in Barcelona.Stunning Architecture
unusual and different. Visited this place mainly to see the unusual roof, was not disappointed, designed by Gaudi there are so many interesting and unusual features. well worth a visit

A must-see Gaudi in Barcelona. We had tickets for a visit on Thursday morning, but when we arrived it was raining. We were advised by a very helpful museum staffer to come back later in the day because the rooftop was closed because of the rain and we should not miss it. She was right! The rooftop is undescribable. It undulates between the disguised chimneys and other rooftop structures, affording amazing views of the city and Gaudi's masterpiece Sagrada Familia. One floor down, in the attic, the arches holding up the roofline are reminiscent of a dragon's rib cage, dipping up and down with the roofline. One restored apartment on the floor below was a delight. There are no straight lines here. But there is plenty of light and space. Don't miss this on your trip to Barcelona.
Lovely in the morning, before the crowds.. The house is charming, with original furnishings, and very interesting and thoughtful details. Wonderful views of the city from the top floor.

Not a Gaudi fan. Barcelona is very proud of Gaudi. I had a friend tell me about this place just before our trip and he was very moved by it. I wasn't. I thought it was nice but in general I've discovered that I'm not a Gaudi fan.

One more chef-d'oeuvre by Gaudi. I already wrote about Gaudi's works. This is one more point to Barcelona's treasures.
Sincerely yours,
Artur

Not Famiglia but Close. This Gaudi apartment building is fantastic on several counts. The archtecture , of course, but the museum explaiing Gaudi's natural models and the exhibits of early 20th century furniture and fittings make it even more special
Stunning!. This building is absolutely beautiful! We did not have the time to go in, but would realy like to next time. This is a must visit when in Barcelona!
Amazing building . Really cool building a short walk from the other Gaudi house. But tickets online, entries are timed. Nice museum shop and audio guide.

A Showcase of Gaudi Genius. While the evening tour was interesting, we feel that we might have enjoyed the daytime tour better. We left with the feeling of not really getting to see the building. We would have liked more time to explore the exhibits in the attic. The light show on the rooftop was nice, but again, we think we would have rather seen it in the daylight.

Gaudi architectural wonder. People visiting this monument start at the roof. What you see is the remarkable imagination that Gaudi used to turn a chimney into art. Then you visit the attic and there you see the marvel of the architectural structure. Inspired on nature, on the skeleton of snakes. Gaudi created his buildings, his furniture based on nature. For instance, the doorknobs he designed were based on the shape of the hand, how it grasps a handle to open a door. This building, still in use, shows the architectural wonder that Gaudi creates.

Great place!!!. This place, Casa Battlo and the Sagrada Familia are a must in Barcelona. We love this place so much we ended up spending the whole morning there and even ended up buying some gifts back which was a very unusual thing to do for us.
Fun Gaudi Building. Took the tour of La Pedrera, very cool and fun Gaudi building. A little pricey, perhaps, but was a good look at how Gaudi created his unique structures.
Just wonderful! But buy tickets in advance!. Just wonderful! It is amazing how this building was made and how beautiful it is. Buy tickets in advance to avoide a huge queue.
Amazing architecture. We went to the evening tour which includes a light show. The tour was excellent and the light show was well done. They provided champagne and treats at the end of the tour!
Multimedia Show at night. This is a must do in Barcelona... Book the tickets online in advance. The show at the roof top is just amazing... I would do it again...

Night tour. We went for the night tour guided by an architect. The tour was very informative and well explained .
The tour end in a show on the roof that was ok

Gaudi at his best. This is a major architectural work- a symbol of Barcelona. You can see the building from the street - free. But to enter there is a charge and tours in various languages are posted.

La Pedrera, Casa Mila. - Thought it would be better to be honest. Wanted to see a Gaudi inspired building and had heard about La Pedrera. Had booked this as part of a tour with Viator (great thing to do BTW). Once we were inside the building we were ushered into a courtyard and shown the amazing Gaudi architecture, all wavy and curved edges etc. But I felt quite claustrophobic in there maybe it was the colours in the hall (green/brown/blue) - its quite a dark building inside. We waited in queues for ages and I was not sure why we were waiting - but this was to go up onto the roof terrace for the views. Quite interesting but not worth the wait in the queue. The roof terrace was quite difficult to walk on with lots of steps onto different levels so not my cup of tea. We then had a tour of two separate apartments (large rooms, light and airy - that was interesting) but otherwise would probably not go again, sorry.

Excellent look into the mind of Gaudi. We've visited Barcelona on multiple occasions, but had not been able to visit La Pedrera because tickets often sell out for same-day entrance. This time, we purchased the tickets in advance online. La Pedrera offers a complete look into the mind of Gaudi and allows visitors to connect with his design styles. It provides an excellent opportunity to learn about his design philosophy and see it implemented before your eyes. We recommend the first entrance of the day, as it gets busy with tour groups, including student groups, as the morning wears on. There is a very nice souvenir shop within La Pedrera that is reasonably priced, considering the location.

If you have time. I went there after Casa Batllo - it was a bit like watching a film after reading the book. It's much more museum-like and perhaps less impressive. A good thing to have seen for the educational purposes as one of Gaudi's works, though. And don't skip the apartment!

Another Gaudi masterpiece. Nature is everywhere in this amazing building, still used by businesses. The visit starts on the roof top, with views across to the Sagrada de Familia, and down the Paseo de Gracia. Moving down to the next level you find your self under the roof looking at the amazing brick work arches and information on Gaudi and his techniques. From here you move to an apartment set up in period furniture, to give a real flavour of the splendour of life in this amazing building. As ever a bit of a queue , we visited early evening so not to bad but a peak times you may have to wait a while. Even so its worth the wait, not to be missed

Gaudi magic.. An excellent attraction. Again on timed tickets. The apartment open to view is on the 6th floor, plus the attics and roof. For those in wheelchairs or unable to manage 8 floors of stairs there is a lift. The staff are very helpful and friendly. Worth the money.

La Pedrera. La Pedrera was a very nice building to visit because of its story and how unique it is. You can read about Gaudi and why he designed buildings the way they are and view furniture, as well as an apartment. Overall, a great experience!

Impressive . Another one of Antoni Gaudi's famous work. The tour and museum gives you a good overview of the work and life of Gaudi. The entrance fee is rather pricey, but its worth it. Highly recommend visitors to buy tickets in advance.

Very Nice. Another very interesting Gaudi piece of architecture. Not nearly as impressive as the Casa Batllo, but that is a tough comparison. I have to say I candidly expected more, but still a must visit. The tour path is limited.

Brilliant architecture. This building is beautiful and brilliant in its novel architectural solutions. Decorative details have function, I. E. roof ventilation, the attic, acting as insulating or cooling space, etc. Recently restored facade is so classy with the original use of decorative iron. We enjoyed the tour of the apartment, a small one in fact, with some nice modernist furniture. We were rather disturbed by behavior of over excited families, sitting on chairs and touching everything. There was no guards in site and when I asked about it, one of the guides told me that they had slashed security staff.This is the place to protect and respect.
Must see if you love architecture or Gaudi!. Pretty cool place! Rooftop views amazing and the architecture is fascinating. Make sure you buy tickets in advance as the lines can be quite long.
First taste of Gaudi !!!. On arrival this was our first visit and introduction to Gaudi and wow were we amazed !! You must go and see the fantastic roof top - you will not be disappointed !!!
Amazing roof features by Gaudi. Absolutely amazing creations by Gaudi who described a roof as a bald headed man with a single strand of hair, thus he added these wonderful designs to the roofs!

It's worth a visit, but it's more beautiful from outside.. An expensive attraction (like everything projected by Gaudi or by his Modernisme colleagues) but not as satisfying as the Batllò House. If you are on a more relaxed schedule, visit both; otherwise, I advise you to choose Batllò instead.

Nice Nissan advert. Shrouded in scaffolding and a huge advert for Nissan, or was it Audi. I appreciate the need for maintenance, but it seems Gaudi stuff is permanently shrouded in protective clothing.
perfect. All Barcelona visitors need to see this place. This is one of the works of famous architecture Gaudi.

Disappointing. Compared to the house Gaudi built, this apartment was disappointing. If you are expecting the same quirkiness of the house he renovated, you will be disappointed. Upstairs where the chimney structures are, is the best part.Had I known the details, I wouldn't have wasted my money. Compared to his other structures, this was boring.

Almost like a storybook house . An amazing tour of La Pedrera gave us insight into its history. The roof top sculptures are just awesome. Gaudi's magic and brilliance are just so evident here. Along with Park Guell and La Sagrada Famiglia, La Pedrera is breathtaking .

Beautiful building and views from the top. This was really an awesome site. Gaudi was truly ahead of his time. The architecture and details on the building both inside and out is fascinating. So much time and thought was put into the details of the building. It is all explained and highlighted in the exit it in the attic. If you are in Barcelona, you must see one of his buildings from the inside.

Unusual architect. House is beautiful, original, but not a lot to see. Roof, than attic with models and expositions connected with general Gaudi's projects, and floor that presented typical flat of well born Barcelona's citizens in '20 XX centuary.It's easy to notice that Casa Mila is one of main the tourist attractions in town, and you have to pay for it, around 25Euro pwe perosn. Outside the building you will find long line of tourist, but it's moving quick, so don't discourage :)
Great to see. My Mom and I saw the outside of La Pedrera. It's nice to see from the outside, but from the reviews, I don't know if its worth going to see the inside.

Gaudí experience!. This place is very unique. It describes very well Gaudi's perspective, tecnique besides a great view of the city. The entrance fee is not cheap but at the end i could understand it was worthwhile the visit, definetly a place not to miss in Barcelona!

Impressive architechture.. This was worth every penny. Our son (10 years) might not have had the time of his life, but his parents were impressed by the splendor of Gaudi and the solutions he made these many years ago. If you are just a bit interested in architechture, you have to visit this fantastic place.

Amazing apartment block.. Outside it is quite understated in terms of colours and appearance architecturally it is a master piece of innovation, imagination and building skills. The roof and attic is quite unbelievable and much of Gaudi's design creativity and genius is on show with designs and models.

Amazing. Absolutely loved this tour so worth every pence & the view from the roof terrace were stunning. We queue jumped by logging onto the wifi & booking the tickets which probably saved us & hour wait.

Beautiful building but Casa Batllo is more impressive (in my opinion). Beautiful Gaudi building, more restrained than Casa Battlo but nearly as impressive. The roof terrace is fantastic, undulating and mosaic-ed. You get to look around the Pedrera apartment, still decorated as it was when the family lived there. The cafe is also worth the visit just to see the ceiling - and that bit is free to go into from the street. if you choose a table by the internal windows, you can look into the court yard too. There is an exhibition hall, that had a photographic exhibition on when we went. The grand staircase is just that - very grand. Worth a visit

Incredible ceilings and the attic is impressive. If you like Gaudi, this has additional displays beyond the building which are interesting - there's a large area through the incredible attic space which gives some general information about Gaudi as well as his work on building La Pedrera. There is also quite a bit of furniture to give a feel for how houses of this period could have been furnished. The roof is fantastic. Make sure to appreciate the view of the Sagrada Familia through the arch in one of the chimneys.

wonderful rooftop. There are so many Gaudi buildings, it's easy to get Gaudi fatigue. Aside from Park Guell, I chose this one b/c you could visit the apartment and also the oft photographed rooftop. It was a gorgeous blue sky which really does the photos justice. The tour is good but a lot of information you already know from visit to Sagrada Familia or other Gaudi buildings. They have an excellent very comprehensive display in the attic where you can spend as little or as much time as you want, same as the rooftop. I enjoyed the visit to the apartment to appreciate the ergonomics of his design. Everything was very well thought out including the use of natural light.There is a light show in the evenings. I had other plans and didn't make it. Tickets aren't cheap but that's the case for most sites in Barcelona, especially Gaudi related buildings.
