Go up on the roof to take pictures, visit a top floor apartment which has been restored and immerse yourself in the life and work of Gaudí in Epsai Gaudí.
1 hour. Worth a 1 hour stop at this location. Experience Gaudi's geometric genius in this creative and complex structure. Rooftop has great view

Awesome Night time show. Had been to La Pedrera before during the daytime, but went this time at night for their Origins show. it was magical. We had a wonderful English tour, which allowed us to see things not usually seen on the day tour. There were only six of us on the tour, which gave us the whole place to ourselves. The lights and music on the rooftop were awesome. After the show, we were treated to some cava wine and desserts. We were so glad we took the time to see this show. Recommended highly!!

Great for kids too!. Extremely captivating and interesting also for the kids (range 4 to 6 years of age). Good itinerary within the building - with audio guides - that gives an organic sense of Gaudì's genius!

Disappointing - don't waste your money!. Don't waste your money - it seems that they are cashing in on anything Gaudi - first of all its pricey, and then when you are inside there was no one you could ask for directions - we kept going up what seemed like endless stairs ( which were ordinary ) and when we reached the roof we were like that's it? Just look from outside and take a picture -

If you are in Barcelona, this is a MUST. Wonderful building right in the downtown of Barcelona. Is more than history, is the construction of beauty: a must to visit together with Sagrada Familia and Casa Batllo. Get surprised of the facade, but get inside and get amazed with the unsimetrical arquitectura indeed. Worth until the last brick.

Behind Closed Doors Evening Tour. This tour was my favorite in Barcelona. Our family arrived for our 8:40 p.m. 90- minute tour not knowing what to expect. It was interesting, informative and fun! I would do it again on our next visit to Barcelona. The tour gave a great history of Gaudi and this amazing building. The guide takes you to the attic to see just how forward-thinking the construction of this building was. You then proceed to the roof to see a wonderful light show on the rooftop structures, accompanied by some great music. Afterwards, descend down the steps for a glass of cava and a few bites of dessert, It was a fun evening for our family and well worth the price of admission.
One of the best. For me, one of the best buildings in Barcelona, where another Gaudi's mastermind is coming to the highest. Beautiful, do not miss and worth every cent!
La Pedrera. Not as good an example of Gaudi's work as Casa Batllo but still worth a visit. The best part of the site is the roof with great views across Barcelona.

Chimney soldiers. Look at all possible Gaudis monument. They are all worth visit, analyze, see the nature in all the buildings and details. On the Pedrera look at the chimneys from different angles and see what story you can see

Gaudi's Gem with Friends. Along with the Sagrada Familia and Casa Batllo, Casa Mila is one of Gaudi's true masterpieces. We booked the premium tour, which provides access to the rooftop, apartments, attic and courtyard. While visiting these spaces was wonderful, the young staff seemed uninterested in helping us enjoy this architectural jewel. Nevertheless, we enjoyed the visit, bought a few things in the two gift shops, and then enjoyed La Pedrera Cafe just as much after the tour (it's quite nice and very reasonable - approximately 12 euros for three coffees and a cream catalana cheesecake, all in a beautiful setting). So, enjoy one of Gaudi's landmark works. You can't fail but be impressed with his genius.

Gaudi Goes Condo. So much fun to see Gaudi redefine Bohemian, apartment building life. As with all of his projects, his attention to every detail is awe inspiring, even using innovative underground parking. From the facade to the roof deck, you'll love each step. Yes, spend the 20 euros.
Go to see. It is one orf Gaudi's buildings in Barcelona. Like all his buildings it is unsusual, beautiful and worth a visit. GO!! Yona S.

Go inside.. Don't just look at it from the outside and think you've seen it. The admission is pricy, so I let my husband sleep in (architecture isn't a high priority to him) and since it has early opening, I saw this first thing. The guided tour was included and informative. The views, curves and lines were all beautiful. The building is much more than it's rooftop, although it was still my favorite. I enjoyed the walk around the attic, it had just as much to offer and the design is genius. I learned more about Gaudi and his natural inspiration and enjoyed seeing it in the apartment details.

Visited La Pedrera with VIP pass, fantastic experience. Visited La Pedrera with VIP pass, fantastic experience. What a place to see, greet exhibition, very interesting and revealing. No waiting time with this vip pass.

Fairly pricey but well worth it.. I figured €20 was a bit much for this, but we found out that you get an audio guide included and you get to wander around as much as you like. The views from the top are incredible and the amount you learn from the fairly short audio guide tracks is really quite a lot! I'd definitely recommend this for anyone who is looking for something a little different to do and doesn't have religion shoved into every orifice either!

An incredible experience - do not miss it!. We visited La Pedrera towards the end of the day, about an hour before sunset, and were able to walk straight up and in without queuing (I'm guessing this may not be possible later in the year!).La Pedrera is one of the most incredible buildings I've ever been in, from the soothing cool courtyard entrance, to the space age roof top and the glorious restored apartment inside. The audio tour is great, but I actually found myself ignoring it in favour of imagining for myself what it might be like to live there. Even the staircases between floors are beautiful - a glorious insight into the mind of a genius.One note to the operators; please, for the love of GOD, ban selfie-sticks from the venue. They get in normal peoples' way and detract from other peoples' enjoyment of the space. If these sycophants can't manage to go 2 metres without taking a picture of themselves, they shouldn't be allowed in. (When one Japanese visitor dropped her stick on the roof terrace and it broke, there was audible applause from the other visitors!).

Amazing Gaudi. This building is in one of the most popular streets in Barcelona (Paseig Gracia) where all boutiques and nice buildings are located. The building itself is amazing from outside. you can also visit inside and there are normally temporary exhibitions of art (Caixa).

Nice original house. It's very nice from outside and also the roof is amazing. The flat is very nice furnitured. The visit time is taking around one hour. I recommend to visit it for the architecture's lovers.

The Roof of The City. This is the grandest and most complete of the three Gaudi designed buildings on the Passeig de Gracia. From the courtyard at ground level through the museum exhibits on each floor to the roof, it is an immersive experience of Gaudi's style, and his world. His inspiration was drawn from nature, from massive rock formations and animals from before the dawn of civilisation and the creation of fantasy warriors, extra-terrestrial fantasy figures on the roof. The roof is amazing. A collection of bizarre but functioning sculpted artefacts, some statues, others chimneys. Some of mosaics and others of sandstone. Well worth the entry fee, which includes an audio guide.

Impressive environment and insightful tour. If the Sagrada Família is Gaudí's pièce de résistance then La Pedrera is his breakthrough - changing the way living spaces would be designed in the future.Whilst not as break taking as the Sagrada, this more intimate museum is just as inspiring and gives a much greater insight into the man himself, his inspirations and his wider approach to art and architecture.I'd advise booking tickets online before you go, and make the most of the audio guide!
One of the must see in BCN. Who does like Gaudí´s works, despite only the roof, attic and one apartment are accessible, it makes sense to visit his masterpiece.

A Must for Architecture & Art Buffs!. This is an incredible example of the extravagant architecture and artistry that Barcelona has to offer. La Pedrera is an expensive but exciting glimpse into the abstract world of Antoni Gaudí.The queues are hefty and the walk around the building is limited but for those who are less inquisitive you can observe the quirkiness of the building from the street. The building has a great souvenir shop where you can pick up a memento of your visit. La Pedrera is walking distance from the other main attractions so be sure to check it out!

A truly immersive experience in Gaudi's world. A very very architecturally interesting residential building that I can describe as peculiarly bizarre - a conscious move to natural shapes that seems somewhat unnatural in our world of concrete square/rectangular dwellings. La Pedrera features an exhibition showcasing the other major works of Gaudi and the thought process behind the as well as the execution. Overall a very educational and enlightening visit that, upon leaving, makes you feel you have just gone out of an art gallery than what is in essence a piece residential real estate.

Don't get lost on the roof : D. Lovely building and a really helpful audio guide.Mind your footing on the roof as the stairs are staggered, and don't get lost up there as I did as it is such a large area - LOL!You get great views and take a camera.I bought the tickets online as it saved queuing.
Simply genius. Gaudí was a genius. Nothing new. Fans and even laics must visit this absolutely stunning house. Prepare almost 20 Euro to go in.

Another 'must see' . An obvious tourist destination whilst in Barcelona. A must see. Costs €20 entry which includes a free audio guide. Unlike other attractions there is no online discount. Great to visit the roof terrace and see Gaudí's work with views across the rooftops of Barcelona. Highly recommended.

I don't get it.... now, the apartment is incredible, don't get me wrong I love Gaudi and everything he does... but the cost vs the experience was not worth it. I would not recommend to anyone to ever pay for this. It is fantastic to see, but compared to other sites (cheaper sites) it falls short.

Fun, beautiful, easy to make a day of Gaudi. La Pedrera is truly grand- not on the same scale as Sagrada... But worth the trip. Buy tickets ahead to skip line. Once inside, no crowded feeling (I went on a weekday). Having an audio guide is so helpful. Definitely worth it. As an American, very interesting to compare the opulence/lifestyle of the rich (though the tour routes them bourgeoisie) at this period in time to the wealthy in America.
Fascinating building. The tour in interesting; the roof views great. Dont let the IMHO horrible exterioir put you off and go in and look at the function and form.

Walking on the roof is worth the price of admission!. Had a wonderful time on the roof and walking through the arches of the attic space. The museum section is excellent. The apartments less so, but interesting too for the scale of the rooms. All in all, a wonderful afternoon.

Informative View to Gaudi's work. Very interesting and informative view as to the workings of Gaudi. His use of spaces to create light for the interior is remarkable. The rooftop, will all of the unusual shapes, mimicking nature. In the attic room you get to see the way the building was structured. The apartment is a great example of the way of living from the early part of e century.I fell in love with the work of Gaudi in Barcelona. He truly was a genius of his time. La Pedrera is a wonderful experience.

Beautiful!. Buy your tickets before you go. It will save time.We didn't have time to visit all of the Gaudi sites so we chose just a couple. We are so glad we chose this one. Everything about it is amazing.

La Pedrera. Again this is a good architecture place to visit, with beautiful views and a roof top area as well, if your worried about the price again the hotels or info places have vouchers for money off.

Take the night tour. The tours are a nice opportunity to learn a bit about Gaudi's work. The night tour ends with a lights and sounds spectacle on the roof that is very nice and also allows for a nice view of the city at night.

Amazing Architecture. Just looking at this place from the outside is mind blowing. It is so cool. I can't imagine creating such a place. The admission price was a bit high - maybe $20 Euros but included a free audio tour, which was free helpful.You'll be taken up to the roof - make sure you go during the day so you can appreciate the rooftop design. It is pretty cool. Then you'll enter the attic and then the 4th floor. You cannot see the whole building as a business is actually operating in there.It is pretty cool. Highly recommended.
Mystical and magnificent. Amazing views over Barcelona from the roof top.Really interesting facts in the attic and a step back in time in the apartment.
Love it. This was one of my favorite places to visit. The building and architecture was beautiful. Worth the wait and the money.

Great introduction to Gaudi's genius. This was the first Antoni Gaudi building we went to in Barcelona and it's a good place to start. From the spectacular rooftop to the beautifully decorated courtyards, there is so much to see, and the exhibits in the attic space give fascinating insights into Gaudi's methods.We just did the day time visit, but it's good that you can buy a day ticket and then if you want to go back at night you can just pay a top up fee.The cafe on the ground floor has a beautiful ceiling and serves delicious tea.

Interesting... The architectural style of this building is unique to be fair.. it is nice.. something different to see while passing down the beautiful passeo de gracia.. worth seeing just for the experience..
Very interesting. The best part is the roof top and the entrance way and the parking lot. The apartment is interesting but that part is not worth the visit. They should have a reduction for seniors.
Beautiful. One of the beatiful examples of architecture in the city of Barcelona. Amazing that all of these place were built in that era. Wouldn't be possible anymore nowadays.
Gorgeous. What a gorgeous design, such impressive and unique ideas. An absolute must-see if you are in Barcelona, Gaudi is a God!!!

Amazing gaudi building. Fascinating buildingStart from the roof and theamazing chimneysGreat views of city and sagrada in distanceWorking down through the floors gives fascinating background to building and gaudi and his methods

If you're a Gaudi fan. Rooftop is lovely and great for a pic and a great start to the tour but, that takes 10 mins. Continuing on to the apartments, it's alright but nothing special when comparing to other sites attached to the Gaudi name. I'm glad i went but can't say i recommend it
Gaudi. A pleasure to wander through and look at what he has created. The building from the outside is also absolutely amazing. Went up onto the roof and photographed the chimneys. Awesome

Beautiful house. Pricey entrance but it's worth it. We really enjoyed the rooftop. The audio guide was really well-made and helped you feel the building's athmosphere. The staff was very friendly and there are free lockers for your belongings.Keep in mind that it if they offer you a free photo - it actually costs money after they take it.

Worth the entry charge and much quieter than other Gaudi sites. . We booked online- you pay and book a time slot. When we got there quite early on a Monday morning there was no queue and it was quiet inside. You start your tour (with audio guide) on the roof which is interesting with good views out. Then down to the attic floor where there is an exhibition on Guadis work, you then go down to a pretty grand apartment which is furnished in the period of the building. Last stop is down at the bottom of the central courtyard which has lots of very pretty mosaic tiling and a view up the centre of the building.

Interesting Gaudi Building. La Pedrera was across the street from where we stayed so we enjoyed seeing the exterior every day. We spent 20 euros to see the interior, the rooftop and an example of an earlier period apartment. It was interesting, but not as good as other attractions we visited. You can buy your tickets in advance, but we purchased ours just before our visit. The line to purchase tickets was not very long. Next door to La Pedrera is Vicens, a shop featuring traditional Barcelona candy. It was a beautiful store with many samples of its products and well worth a visit to purchase gifts for friends at home. Would rate Vicens with five stars.

Typical Guadi design. A little walk from Casa Batllo, Casa Milà also known as La Pedrera is just another few blocks away. Another structure which is typically Gaudi's. In 1984 it was declared a World Heritage Site by UNESCO, and is currently the headquarters of the Catalunya-La Pedrera Foundation,

Antoni Gaudi was an Amazing Man. The beauty and the complex design take more imagination than the average person can comprehend, but I spent an afternoon doing my best to view and understand this exceptional work of art that is presented in the form of a building. Even if you have little interest in architecture, go for the experience, the walk around the rooftop was worth the cost of admission. No picture I have seen to date does it justice, so you really need to view it in person. I have a new respect for Barcelona!
Iconic Gaudi Masterpiece. Words can't do this astoundingly original building justice. The roof is a supreme work of imagination and engineering.
Gaoudi building. An other building by the great Gaudi its stonning to see his fantastic creations all worth visiting any time you are in Barcelona.
Beautiful place. A beautiful, exclusive place in Barcelona, with lots of expensive shops - and Casa Mallo needs to be visited, too.

Very interesting for lovers of architecture. Barcelona is home to some really great modern architecture. Gaudi trail blazed the way with buildings like this. Architecturally and visually this is a fascinating building. The headphone guide is very informative. I thoroughly enjoyed the tour.
The start of any Gaudi itinerary. It is here that we can learn what is the background and inspiration behind Gaudi's design. Recommend to start here before visiting any of Gaudi's masterpieces

awesone place. We really enjoyed our visit at La Pedrera. I recommend you buy tickets online to avoid the huge queue. The building is amazing, due to the genius of A.Gaudi, starting from the unusual architecture to the carefully decorated interior. It's definitely worth a visit.

A must see for gaudi fans. I did this on my own - not cheap for a family at €20.50 each for adults - not sure on kids rates. The view from the top was awesome. A visit round the apartment was really interesting and a tasteful shop is great for souvenirs. The models inside provide a great insight into gaudis works. The cafe had nice cakes but at €6 each not cheap and the service wasn't great but do not let it put you off visiting the house.
Might not be fun to live there. We only passed by an admire the building from the outside. Did no have the time to get in nor to visit the roof. Wondering how live is for the people who live there.

Seaside building. Spend a good hour or so, looking at the apartment, the rooms were just incredible and so modern, I would certainly love to live here. Everything has been thought about, to make the building perfect. Of course the roof garden is stunning, with great views of the city, and the waviness makes for lots of interesting little areas, Once again, you must visit this building.

It was a nice building, not sure if it was worth the money.. The building is nice for sure and we did the night tour which shows some light show on the roof. The guide was OK, we did not get interesting facts, just ok. When the guide was having conversations with some of the tourists, he was telling them very interesting facts, but to the group it was just a rehearsed script. We did not even get to visit inside one of the apartments, just the stairs and the roof, it was not what we expected.They also told us we were going to get some kind of food at the end of the tour and it was just a glass of wine and one cookie.....
Stunning. Every visit to Barcelona I always come to just look & take in this truly stunning building a must see.

I wish I lived here!. Le Pedrera is an intelligent yet whimsical building. I could spend hours sitting on the roof alone. Gaudi's use of glass and courtyards to spread light into the interior is very intelligent.

Good Gaudi showcase! Surreal! . The second time for me to come here! I always like the roof top sculptures best as it gives you a very surreal feeling and thus a very special feelings why Gaudi is such a talented artist! He is able to make you see the world in a very different way!
Nice monument . Beautiful Gaudi building, nicely preserved. Please see it at daytime because at night the illumination does not do the building favors.

Another Beautiful Building. Start with a walk through the decorative chimneys on the roof, then on to the apartments. The arches in the attic are a work of art and there is an exhibit that explains how Gaudi designed them. Very interesting.
Cunningham. Dream place for football fans all you could wish for. Your walking around for a while if you take the tour so wear comfy shoes

Win of a whim!. Didn't have this on my "must see" list at all but, with a couple of hours' to spare before heading back to the airport, I ducked in. And, WOW! I enjoyed Casa Batlló, but La Pedrera was superb. A MUST SEE, folks!

A must see!. We booked the tour with headsets!I thought this was even better than the gaudi park!The architecture was phenomenal! The tour was so interesting and you even got to see inside the old apartments. A must see

La Pedrera - Barcelona. This is a must see attraction if you like Gaudi architecture or simply quirky buildings. The tour through the building is great, complete with audio. Every part of the building is different, from the rooftop and views of other Gaudi works, the attic and apartments. Truly an amazing building, Gaudi certainly had the future in mind with this one.
A Quarry sight.... An unusual building and creation of the architectural genius Gaudi so nicknamed 'La Pedrera' because... go visit to find out!

Entry price too high!. Entry price could be much less i think. When you buy the ticket to get in, you get an extra ticket that says 1 Free Photo but at the end you have to pay an extra 10 Euros to get the photo.

Fascinating....especially the roof top. Another must not miss Gaudi property...so much to see in there...well worth it. The guided tour with personal ear phones...go at your own pace was worth it...I learned a lot

Sceptical because of the entry price, but it was worth it in the end. When you visit Barcelona of course one of the things you want and need to do is to visit the buildings of Gaudi. Because of the high entrance price for La Pedrera (20+ Euro), we were not sure if we would include it, as we had already booked for the Sagrada Familia and the Park Guell.On our last day though we decided to visit it, not knowing when we will again be in the city. And it was worth it! The rooftop is a paradise on a sunny day and we could spend hours on it, in its mythical atmosphere...I can imagine it will be amazing during the nightly light shows! The attic and the apartment that could be visited were very well organized as well and put someone in the living atmosphere of the early 1900's. A lot of information on Gaudi and the building can be found.All in all it was one of the highlights of our visit, although it could be a little bit cheaper...

a visit to a very exciting and essential Gaudí. When you're inside you feel like the walls convey emotions from long ago. Antoni Gaudí was a genius who was able to observe the artistic and essential Nature.I recommend you up to the roof at night to watch the fantastic diorama, even to convert their traditional warriors in living things.A great experience that you can't miss if you visit Barcelona.

"The" place to be!. Wow what an experience! This is a MUST SEE if you ever go to Barcelona. The queue in February (UK half term) was short but if visiting in high season we'd advise buying tickets before you travel or online whilst there if you have wifi. The roof top views, decor, architecture of mosaic, bones/nature and sculpture to disguise the building 'facilities/services e.g. Drainage pipes' is incredible!

Only in Barcelona. Very nice building next to Casa Batlo - a bit cheaper attraction compared to Batlo.As mentioned in my previous reviews - there is 3-4 similar atractions so it's really diffucult to choose which ones to visit.Let's say that Batlo was more worth visiting than this one but of course - unique art of Gaudi and if you are lover of it - do not miss it.Gets really crowded on weekends and especially during spring/summer time.

Quaint, but lovely place. Gives a great insight into Gaudi’s capabilities. I went for the Gaudi's Pedrera: The Origins tour, which is a guided tour at night and includes a light show on the roof. I really enjoyed the tour, although I think a day time visit in which you may be able to see more of the villa, might add more, however I am not entirely sure as I haven’t done that. The Pedrera is a beautiful, strange place and inspires awe for Gaudi. Truly nothing is straight, which is typical of his style, and it is amazing to see that this has been executed in every teeny tiny detail. During the tour you start downstairs in the courtyard where you receive an explanation and a short video that is projected on the floor. That video was a bit overkill in my opinion, as it was not very clear and did not add that much as it was a repetition of what the guide had already told us. Then you are taken up to the attic by the stairs (it’s a lot of stairs!) or elevator, where you get a good look of the “whale” arches with a very thorough and interesting explanation. After this you continue to the roof, where there is a nice light show, although I would have appreciated it more if the light show had incorporated more in relation to Gaudi. It is fun to see an aquarium displayed on some of the towers, however I have seen things like that before. Once the light show is finished you can roam around on the roof for a little bit and actually get a very nice view of Barcelona. Then you are taken down to a reception room for a glass of cava. This room is of course also designed by Gaudi and it is fun to see the extreme attention to detail. You can furthermore go down a beautiful staircase after which the tour is finished. I liked it, but would probably advise you to go and do a guided tour during the day.

awesome. Gaudi's creative ideas are fully displayed in the building, down to every details throughout. It is even more awesome if you compare to the surrounding buildings, as well as think about the time it was built. The fact that it exited saying so much about Barcelona of the time. So precious in every way!

Evening tour: fun and different. We enjoyed the evening tour that started at 7:15pm which featured a lightshow on the rooftop. A glass of cava (oj for the younguns) at the end was a nice touch too. Gaudi was a genius!

Well worth the entrance fee. Three experiences in one - first, the astonishing rooftop with its iconic chimneys and panorama over the city. Then the undercroft, arched like a ribcage, with a great exhibition on Gaudi and his inspiration, which helped inform our entire trip. Finally - the best bit for me! - a chance to walk around one of the apartments and see how Gaudi envisaged his work to be lived in. Amazing (plus a great couple of gift-shops). Totally inspired our tween-aged kids and helped them get more out of our Gaudi-hunting around Barcelona.

Very interesting. This was the last building we visited on our holiday. Having seen a lot of Gaudi's other work and being very impressed this was no different. The thought and effort put into these buildings is so interesting to listen about and each one seems very different from the rest; I was a little worried that information might have started to be repeated after seeing so much of his work but this offers another perspective again. Great rooftop and views, Interesting architecture and a look into how the life for it's residents would have been when it was built. Especially if you enjoyed the Segrada Famillia and Park Guell, this is a great place to go.

VISIT THE ROOF. Another great Gaudi wonder of Barcelona! It's clear to see that Gaudi was well ahead of his time, the rooftop is amazing with incredible views of La Ramblas. Definitely a once in a life time opportunity. Definitely worth paying for and getting a fast tracked tour which is available to listen to in your own language. There's so many items all very detailed and its worth making sure you visit and listen to those! Don't Skip Anything! The gift shop at the end is bordering on fair price to the expensive range depending on what you like. All items are very good quality and there's some lovely quirky and unique books if you take the time to browse around too!

Gaudi - Architect and designer breakthrough. It is highly recommended. Relaxed tour with audio guide is adjusted. You can go back to again and again to discover new and amazing details. Very impressive facade

Worth to visit but very poor service. While you can see La Pedrera freely from outside, waht is really worth to see is th inside (roof, attic and the top level apartments plus a courtyard and staircases). The visit is somewhat overpriced (20,50 Euro for a day visit) however an audioguide is included in the price (Polish not available). Gaudi's unique approach to architecture is well presented here.What was an extremally negative experience during the visit was a service. We reached the counter about 2 hours before closure. As someone already mentioned it, the audioguide description itself is about 1,5h which means only 0,5 hour left for leisury walking around and admiring the details, exhibition (that provides another 10 minutes or so of video materials). There's no warning about that, nor any information how long is the audioguide. While I believe there are many people, who go to a tourist attraction only to quickly go through that and 0,5h is enough for such people for a whole visit, we wan't to fully use what we've paid for. In this case there was no chance for it. It was impossible to listen to full audioguide descriptions, not to mention fully enjoying everything that can be enjoyed there. As a result we were rushed out of the building (oh sorry - to the store on the ground floor) before we really had time to benefit from the visit. We really felt cheated.Except that my rating would probably go up to Very Good... But the service ruined the visit.
Expensive. Expensive to see inside , think that doesnt worth the price to get in , amazyng outside and top floor , but nothing i really crazy.Good to see it once and thats it
good to walk by stop and look at. We did not go in as there is so much Gaudi architecture in Barcelona that the 20+euro entrance didn't seem worth it. Look from the exterior was satisfying to us

Great Rooftop. History and Building Case Mila or La Pedrera is again situated in Passeo Gracia along with another of Gaudi's masterpieces the Casa Batllo. An UNESCO site it is a quirky attractive building and as with Casa Batllo the striking area is actually the roof terrace that has a large number of ornate chimney covers…I mean large ones! It occupies a corner spot on the street and is around 5-6 stories in height but only around three of those are open to the public. There are two main foyers and on level 1 you have replica living quarters, a film show along with bedrooms, kitchen area, lounges, bathrooms and shop that sells 30E coffee mugs! On level 2 you have a complex array of Gaudi orientated displays. The roof top is simply stunning with a circular tour of the ornate chimney pots that are there along with a fine view of the city. Overall it is a great building to see.The TourYou get an audio guide and just follow the direction of the tour. You can do the tour in around 2 hours and it is interesting. Start at the bottom and finish at the top. Plenty of picture opportunities.Facilities and Cost20e standard, 26e premium. Premium allows you immediate entry and hence saves time. Both include audio guides. Free for under 7’s. half price up to 12. No family deals. Wheelchair access, toilets, audio guide, English staff. Friendly.SummaryBeautiful house, great architecture but again expensive and no family deals?? I did this and the Casa Batllo and it cost me nearly 60E...phewee. I enjoyed this visit but it was not a breathtaking deal for me. Great to see and architecturally interesting but the cost is crippling really.
Mucho gusto. A splendid sight sitting viewing it from the Samoa restaurant, across Passig Gracia. Intriguing to see the top half of visitors as they explored thee fantastic roof.

Another must see in Barcelona. Pay the extra few Euros for the fast pass, it's really worth it. You'll get a guide in whatever language you would like and you learn the reasoning behind Gaudi's design. You learn a lot and it's really cool.

WOW!!. Another architectural wonder in Barcelona! Well worth the visit. We went during the day. You can purchase tickets on line ahead of time to avoid the lines. We read that at night it is beautifully lit up so our next adventure to Barcelona will include a night visit to La Pedrera. Gaudi was WAY ahead of his time. Do not skip anything in this tour.

Worth a look from outside. Everything of real interest, aside from the gorgeous rooftop chimneys and some minor interior decor details, is visible from the outside. Pay the 20€ entry fee only if you feel it's worth that price to see the chimneys closer up. There's a small Gaudi exhibit in the roof space but it contains nothing that can't just be read on any of a dozen websites.
Another Great Example of Gaudi's Work. The next time I'm in Barcelona I'd like to tour the inside. It's a bit of a walk from downtown, but worth a visit for art aficionados

Another Gaudi must-see. We arrived just after 9am at La Pedrera and this is definitely a good idea as you will beat the cues and have the place pretty much to yourself. There is a lot to see, from the fantastic rooftop, all the exhibits and information in the attic space, to the period apartment. The entry fee is not cheap, but I think is worth it. It's a fantastic building to visit.

Rooftop is really nice, the rest is informative and OK, but rather expensive. The visit starts on the roof. We were there after lunch time on a sunny day in February. The roof is really a surrealistic experience. The attic mainly explains about Gaudí's inspiration and construction techniques. The apartments floor is more museum-like, showing decorated rooms.That said, the visit is quite expensive at over €20 for an adult.

A must see in my mind. It was closed when I was here in January 2016; however, I was here in 2008 and it was spectacular. If you have any interest in architecture, go to Barcelona, try to ignore how expensive it has become, and go here. Of course I am assuming this remodel is not going to change too much.

Very crowded. This is another one of Gaudí's extremely fascinating buildings in Barcelona. Large parts of it is actually still used as flats and offices. The line looked prohibitively long from the outside, but admission was very efficient and I found myself on the inside after no more than five minutes. You can walk about on the roof, there are exhibitions in the attic and there's a museum floor/flat with period interiors. This place gets very, very crowded at peak times, especially in the flat.
Good but not amazing. very good place, special the roof, but if you have to choose visit Batllo which costs the same. Battlo is more particular.

Nice view. I enjoyed my visit here, and of course the roof was my favourite. You only get audioguide in the ticket, not video as in Casa Battlo. You can only visit one apartment and the courtyards, as the other apartments are occupied. It is unique and the attic is a place dedicated to Gaudi's work. I liked Casa Battlo better, but I consider La Pedrera a must-see place in Barcelona.
Amazing place. We were here many time, and will go again. La Pedrera our favourite place, very well orginized for tourists, good guiding.
Barcelona MUST. A must for Architecture Lovers! Gaudí considered every detail of his creations and integrated into his architecture. Definitely worth to see it!

gaudi must see. if you love architecture, you will be in big trouble in barcelona-there are soo many amazing buildings to see-and this is one of them. we had to chose which one to see first thing in the morning and casa batlo won that one, so for casa mila we stood in line for ever. that gave us a chance to admire in detail the ironwork on the downstairs windows and details that otherwise would probably have been neglected. also, the side walk design and the street lamps designed also by gaudi got their share of attention while waiting in line. So, time very well spent no matter how long the line, my opinion.

Visit at night for a nite of jazz. We visited at night, and purchased tickets for an evening jazz performance. It was a magnificent wait to see the roof top, enjoy music and marveled at the work of the famed architect Gaudi.

For Gaudi fans, but not only. No need to explain the attractiveness of architectures of Gaudi, but interesting thing is also to learn how the bourgeois at the time of Gaudi used to live. By the visit, you can see the unique style of apartment at that time, and there was also a video explaining the scene then. It takes time to make a full visit, but it's worthwhile.
Gaudi Architecture. This residential building showcases the architectural style of Antoni Gaudi with undulating balconies and unusual metal work.
brilliant roof. enjoyed going round the house and the roof, very good to see and the commentary is good( this is provided free) makes it more interesting.

Stunning!. Simply amazing. We went early February, there were very few people so able to take in all the architecture, the views from the roof & chimneys were wonderful, the apartment... Stunning with such detail & the weather was brilliant. A must see when visiting Barcelona.

Great place to visit. Another fine example of Gaudi's work.The rooftop is amazing in terms of both views and architecture. The visit should take you approximately 2 hours and from the roof, you proceed to the apartment area. Gaudi had clearly thought about every detail even down to the door handles.The queue wasn't too bad, but we booked online which was easier as we walked straight through.Only criticism is the number for the audio guides, we missed some of these, so these could be clearer.

Another Beautiful Gaudi building.. Once again the famous architect Gaudi out does himself with creative design. Many of the rooms are furnished as they would have been when the original family lived there. The roof top is also creative and beautiful.
Very Interesting!. This tour was very interesting and it was nice that you were able to tour an actual apartment. There was also a lot of information on Gaudi's past architecture ventures as well.

Das Geld nicht wert / not worth the money. Nichts Besonderes aber teuer. Uns hat es leider nicht gefallen, zumindest nicht für das Geld. Nothing special but expensive. We didn't like it unfortunately, especially for that price.

Beautiful house / museum. I've visit the place two times now (first when I was in HS and last year with my boyfriend) and I also live in Barcelona but because I love visiting museums and learn more about the city, this place is simply amazing and beautiful.

Stunning house!. After Sagrada Familia, probably the greatest of Gaudi's achievements. This house should not be missed by any visitor to Barcelona. It is also only a half block from the Royal Passeig de Gracia Hotel.

Stunning art. Loved the roof of the apartments and seeing the soldiers. Could be from Star Wars. I bought the replica in the shop. Very interesting to walk round the apartment and get a glimpse of life in the past. Not to be missed by the discerning tourist.

What a place to live!. We went for the night-time experience, 'Origins', and it was wonderful. The sound and light show at the end is really quite emotional. Splash the cash and enjoy Barcelona to the full.

Worth the walk. Our group of adults had some spare time to visit La Pedrera. We had to line up a couple of times but everything was well-organized so we didn't mind that much.The tour took us through a beautiful and unique apartment building and explains everything in brilliant detail. If you visit Barcelona, the architect Antoni Gaudi is a central figure in understanding the city. Visiting La Pedrera gives you a good picture of Gaudi and his work.
The most impressive of Gaudi's designs. The house is amazing! Especially the roof.The ticket includes audio guide that helps understand and appreciate the details
GAUDI. Very beautifull monument of Gaudi. There is so much details made by Gaudi. Nice building but i think is too expensive maybe.

Very quirky but weirdly in keeping with the area.. The iconic rooftop of La Pedrera is the reason I dragged my friend here but the rest of the tour was really interesting. You get an audio guide as part of your ticket price and you get to have a nose in one of the apartments, which was an unexpected treat for me. The area under the roof is really spectacular in terms of the architecture.Obviously the roof is brilliant. I loved the chimney designs and the undulating paths. If you can get to look through the arches without selfie-taking tourists, they really do frame lovely views.

Interesting to see the residential work of Gaudi. I found La Padrera to be very interesting, to understand how people lived during the early part of the 20th century. This apartment building is one of Gaudi's finest works.

Worth seeing. We got off the bus round Barcelona to see this interesting building. I would recommend seeing this piece of Gaudi architecture. The tour was well presented and not crowded (it was February). There was hardly any queuing. Barcelona is rightly proud of Gaudi's unusual architectural approach.

Back to the 19ｔｈ century!. I got the fast pass that admit me anytime in advance. So I could enter there at once. The architecture is really excellent ! I spent a couple of hours to take a lot of pictures. All of furniture in each room is beautiful and traditional style. I felt that I was there in the 19th century. I spent very comfortable time there.

Fascinating. Booked in advance the audio tour and it was well worth it. The appartment set out in period style furnishings very interesting as was the detailed explanations of the building's structures

Gaudi Lover. Very interesting place but a bit to expensive. If you love clever architecture this is one of the best place. Casa Batllo impressed me more than that one for a similar price. Between both, Casa Batllo should be the first one to visite.

Quirky Apartment Building. If only today's apartments looked like this! The exterior architecture is distinctively Gaudi, and the interiors are just as great (albeit more functional). A highlight of the interiors is the effective space planning and subtle architectural flourishes. The stream of natural light enhances the space's architecture.
Iconic, educational and interesting.. We spent a few hours here. The audio guide is helpful and informative and the roof top views are amazing. Visitors get a close-up look at Gaudi's amazing works.

Iconic Gaudi structure - must see inside also. The attic with its Gaudi exhibit and the rooftop with its champagne-glass mosaics and the apartments with some Gaudi designed furniture - all what Moderniste movement is about.
Fun to see. I love unusual buildings and the history behind them. You can find this on the hop and go tour. The curvy balconies are appealing. Would have loved a tour inside.
Another Piece of Art BY Gaudi. iT'S A great museum! We learned a lot about Gaudis inspirations and history of his creation. Don't forget to visit the terrace.

Amazing. One of the place to be seen in a lifetime ! Don't forget Casa Battlo and La Sagrada Familia, these are my two favourites ! Gaudi is purely a genius, hardworker and visionnary guy. And his places are so poetic...

Read the small print. Absolutely fabulous architecture but the best is on the inside out and the outside front and the roof terrace which dose not open if it rains which defeats the objective if the architecture is your thing the main attraction is the design and fictionality of the roof design not withstanding the photo photogenic opportunity. Inside furnished with late 18th:19th century innovation design down to the cupboard & door knobsWe wanted to get a refund as the roof and exterior was or main reason to visit but was told we could not have an online refund and that she felt sure it was mentioned in the small print!!!!!!Buy you ticket on the day and only if it's not raining check Pinterest pictures for roof design
Another Gaudi flagship. Advisable to buy the tickets on internet, at least for the high season. Allow enough time for the visit. Exhibition in attic is excellent.
Nice place. In La pedrera You will see a fenomenal place made for Gaudí. I think that is an perfect place to art lovers.
fantastic gaudi building. Fantastic Gaudi building in the absolute center of Barcelona. Go up and walk on the top, absolutely worth it and the the view is fantastic
Interesting building . Jumped off the bus to take a look at at the architecture. Having just left the park didn't see the need to pay to go in and the crows were off putting

Gaudi's apartment. My wife is an artist & went along with her to this tour as my gift for our 20th anniversary. For someone who really is not much into art, I was surprised to find myself enjoying this! We went mid-week which was a good call as I understand it can be quite busy. They also have evening tours which, unfortunately, we did not have time to book.

Looked beautiful as it was decorated in December. Just looked at it from the outside as we had limited time.Very spectacular.Has eating facilities and tours and you can see the amazing detail through windows and gates.

Don't miss the roof visit. We visited here on a sunny Sunday morning so it wasn't too crowded. The structure is incredible but the attic space a bit claustrophobic. The roof is well worth the visit - you can see the sea from here!

Amazing!. We had the night and day pass and this is what I would recommend for everyone! During the night you have a guide which tells you some stuff personal and we visited the roof. There we had an amazing light show which was awesome. On the next day we got an audio guide which provides more detailed information about the building and we walked through the building. All in all a very good visit!

Making the practical, beautiful!. Any fan of Gaudi's must wander through La Pedrera. It's here that you will see his models, his experiments in design and physics and his attention to detail that make your head spin when you think about the magnitude of his buildings. Go at night to really enjoy this beauty and book ahead so you can take your time and enjoy all that his man created.
Short visit. We hoped off the tour bus to view this Gaudi piece of architecture.Interesting and very much his style, but was only suitable for a short visit.

Very Impressive. This beautiful apartment building is a must see attraction. Every aspect of the building is impressive. The doors, woodwork, door handles were all custom designed. The atrium is fabulous. the attic is fascinating. It was once the laundry area and is now a museum of Gaudi. Although we enjoyed this building, we actually liked Palau Guell and Casa Batllo better. All three should be seen and we recommend them highly.

Also known as Cas Mila -a very special and thrilling look at night time. Looking at this musterical house-monument built by Gaudi one more and more admires with the sculpturer talent. If you could transfer design to music that would be named as maestoso and misterioso. You could not miss it

Fantastic Roofscape. Another Gaudi masterpiece, still lived in my some. You start the visit on the roof, with good cause, as here are the iconic chimneys that you see in all the guidebooks. Below is an attic filled with models and inspiration for the architect's work, then there is a suite of rooms laid out as they would have been. Another great sight to visit.

Fabulous La Pedrera. Visited La Pedrera (Casa Mila) as a couple at 11am on a Sunday morning. It was busy but no overly so as there are timed entrances. The building is unusual and the skill and imagination Guadi had makes this building fascinating. Beautiful in its own right. A must have on your top ten things to do when visiting Barcelona

We learnt so much. So glad we visited here and learnt about Guadi and his architectural style and methods before we went onto the other Guadi sights. Expensive but enjoyed a couple of hours here. Some fabulous sights here.
What a house . We visited here and were amazed at the architecture, it's hard to find a straight edge. Absolutely not to be missed when in Barcelona.
PIECE OF ART. It's a definition of art and beauty. It's beautiful from the outside but it's even more interesting in the inside. Worth waiting in the line.

Impressive. First saw this on the top of the hop on/hop off bus, but as so many people had recommended to see it at night when the lights were on, we returned. Completely agree, it is far more impressive.

Impressive building. You cannot miss this building once you pass by, but I still agree with the feeling that people had when it was built. It's bulky, heavy stone like, with no refinement whatsoever.But sill, it attracts attention and worth stopping by for a picture or 2.

The painted chicken fencing needs replacing. . I didn't enjoy this as much as the other Gaudi buildings. The painted chicken wire fencing (for safety purposes) as I'd call it on the roof needs replacing with something more modern like glass as it distracts and detracts from the architectural lines. Inside the roof is amazing though with great brick arches that draw your eyes in every direction.
Interesting. very interesting architecturally!!everybody must see that nice nice nice!! I will come back 100000%

Our favourite Gaudi site. This was unexpectedly brilliant and our favourite Gaudi site we saw. The exterior is amazing. You start up on the roof which gives you marvellous views and is something to look at itself. Then you go down to the attic where there are informative displays and videos giving lots info about the man and his works.Finally you see one of the apartments restored as it would have been when first built. Really interesting and there is an audio guide included in the price of the ticket.Definitely visit this, ideally before you see too much else Gaudi.

One more Gaudi masterpiece. I looks like an artistic piece of modern architecture, but it’s not. Fun fact is that at that time it was subjected to ridicule and disgust. :) If you admire Gaudi's work you should see it.

A Must See in Barcelona. 15 years ago I visited Spain for the first time and La Pedrera was the highlight of my visit. So it was delightful to once again see this amazing building designed by Antoni Gaudi. Even if you are not a fan of Gaudi, this should still be on your list of things to do. Every detail speaks of the genius behind the structure and decor. The roof is particularly great. If you are a Star Wars fan, you will recognize the stormtrooper's helmets in the chimneys. Brilliant.
Interesting . I did not tour the inside because I thought the price was steep but the exterior was very interesting.

Romance In the air. This building had the smell of romance in the air! It is amazing, in every corner of the building is an untold story. Apartments have private tenants and you have to be amazed on how they deal with millions of visitors in their building every year.Purchasing tickets was easy, we were lucky to go when no one was in the line... But people mention is best to purchase online to bet the queue.Worth the visit

Mind boggling building.. This was the highlight of a wonderful few days in this epic city. If you get the time to visit one attraction in Barcelona can I reccommend La Pedrera. It is a truly wonderful example of the abilities of the human mind. Gaudi is a genius and his stage is ever last in the buildings of Barcelona.
Lovely. I simply love this building. The round shapes are spectacular, the parapets are amazing - everything makes it special. I only regret I couldn't see it on the inside.

Another Gaudi Masterpiece. If you are at all an architecture enthusiast, this is one of the three Gaudi building that you MUST visit in Barcelon. Get to the building first thing in the morning to avoid long lines. The tour and experience are second to none. Architecturally it is structurally innovative with a self supporting stone front and columns and the floor plates are free of load bearing interior many columns and walls. At the of the building is a fascinating museum of Gaudi furniture, structural innovations, etc. There are two magnificent interior courtyards that allow light and air to penetrate all the way to the ground level that are wonderfully articulated and detailed. This is one of the first buildings (1906) that included a car park in the basement, accessible by curving ramps. There is not a single straight line in the building anywhere. it is still private residences on many of the lower floors. Go online to look at photos of the roofs caps of staircases, ventilation towers and chimney tops of this building. It is something that you won't forget. By virtue of its spectacular facade and its unique roof terrace , la Pedrera is considered one of the most extraordinary buildings of the 20th century.

Walk the balconies of Skulls & Bones.... The face of Barcelona Architecture...Antoni Gaudi. A unique, extremely creativearchitect, artist, engineer, greatly influenced by nature...Take a tour to see some of the planning, interior spaces, and the roof top over-looking Barcelona...Wear comfortable walking shoes...lots of multi-level steps especially on the roof.There's a nice gift shop for souvenirs on the first floor, side street...Location is steps away from all the A listed designer shops, great restaurants...even helpful drugstores if needed...
Outstanding!. The place is well maintained. It is amazing that the place still looks so beautiful and solid after so many years.

A thorough visit through a Gaudí masterpiece. You can see many parts of La Pedrera on a visit here--the lobby, roof, attic, apartment, and rear courtyard. Gaudí's work is unique, but even considering that, the lines and shapes of the roof are extraordinary and great to see in person. (You even feel them walking up and down the steps scattered throughout.) Even the arches in the attic are pleasing to the eye. It's nice being able to walk through the apartment--although many rooms are set up as they would have been when the building was built, it would have been nice to see more details and rooms (like the kitchen) set up that way. Overall, a worthy visit for fans of Gaudí. Purchase tickets in advance -- you can buy them online easily, and your wait to get in will be much shorter.

Nice view from the roof.. The best thing about the Casa Mila is the roof. On a sunny day you get a nice view of Barcelona. And you can se over to Sagrada. The loft and the apartment witch is mostly as it used to be is nice to see as well. You really get a feeling on how it would be to live in the house when it was new. The down side is the souvenir pushing everywhere you turn.
Wow. The guy really was something. An advanced thinker that still delights and provokes now. Really interesting. Audio guide good
Another Gaudi work of art. I just love this building. It's magical to see every room with its unique furniture. It's an amazing experience to get to know Gaudi's magical mind.

Must see. Its a brilliant building and I will recommend it and there's no way around it. that said, I dont believe I would ever wait for 2 or 3 hours as many people do. This is a fantastic city, use that time on another of the hundreds of attractions in Barcelona. Come back again at a better time with less people. But do go and see it.

I can't get enough Gaudi. The (self) tour starts on the roof - so be comfortable with heights. The attic area provides great detail and I was impressed to learn about how Gaudi designed his ergonomic handles (which I then scoured the whole of Barcelona to find and buy). The fully furnished display apartment transports you back in time. I spend over three hours as there was so much to see.

See it from the street. This is an amazing work of Gaudi, but I wouldn't recommend buying a ticket and going inside as the ticket costs 19 euros per person and I think that's a lot. You should definitely see it in person though, and maybe walk down the street to Casa Battlo and buy a ticket for that one because it has more to offer (and it's around the same price)
Wow. You can spend hours just taking in the view from the roof. Having an audio guide helps to explain how everything was created. An amazing building.
Great visit. Well worth visiting the audio walk through was really good. More to see than I thought and worth the money

Stunning. Designed in detail and amazing to visit. The exhibition on the top floor, in conjunction with the audio tour, gives you insight into Gaudi's inspiration for this and other buildings he designed. A must see whilst in Barcelona.
Enjoyed the rooftop architecture and the views from the top. We chose to visit La Pedrera as our Gaudi house experience and really enjoyed the views from the top and the arches on the top floor.

La Pedrera. It's incredible how Gaudi created a building with a hole in the middle. He was like no other. This place is really cool and the design is amazing. On the rooftop, the sculptures or chimneys are magnificent. I can't imagine how this design popped into Gaudi's mind, and he created it so flawlessly.

Charming Beauty. I strongly recommend to visit Casa Milà (La Pederara). We bought tickets online (it is possible to choose convenient time). I was impressed again by the creativity of Gaudi. You can look at the daily life of people in the beginning of XX century (I mean the interior of rooms). It was interesting to know that nowadays people still leave in the house (only part of the building is available for tourists). It is worth going to the roof of the building and enjoy beautiful view!

Casa Mila. As it was the first Gaudi building I saw I was perplexed as to all this fuss about his work. Now seeing it again did not change my view a bit. Its concrete waves are just extravagance for the sake of extravagance. And the crowd of completely insane people willing to pay €24 just to walk on the roof among the ice-cream-cone-like chimney stacks!

Modernist masterpiece. Casa Milá,, or La Pedrera, is one of Gaudí's best known works. It is a pity that you go only to the museum at the last floor, the terraces (with a very nice view of the city), and a one of the residential floors. Nice but a little expensive (as everything at Barcelona). I suggest purchasing your tickets in advance through Internet. Good audioguides included in the price.

The crown jewel of Gaudí. La Pedrera is a magical, different, full of unique sensations building. Gaudi devoted all his imagination in this work culminated with a spectacular roof, which enjoy unparalleled corners.

Average. Was a bit of a bunch and a lot of great reviews for it, so I went.Surprisingly, I didn't even get off the hop on hop off bus!For me, it was an average building that I personally thank Gaudi had done better.No light show at the time I went, no idea why.Go if you have nothing else to do.

Do not go at the weekend. We tried to go here on a Saturday but the queues were very long and if we wanted to see all the Goudy building it would have cost us over a £100 each. As attractive a they are I am not sure they are worth this kind of money.
Great . It was a beautiful building! My family and I didn't go inside but it is definitely worth seeing. By the looks it would have been fun to go inside!

Great lights show at night!. I went to see Casa Mila for the light show they have in the evenings. The show was beautiful but I was hoping to have seen more of the house interiors. I understand that there are still residents living in the house, but knowing that there was all that architectural history just beyond a few walls that I could get to see and experience was a bit disappointing. Overall I enjoyed my tour and the light show, but I wish I could have gotten to see more of the house.
Must see!. La Pedera is one of the best examples of a finished piece of Gaudi's work, all curves and softness it might make those used to harsh angles uncomfortable at first. Beautiful

One of kind experience. A living, breathing monument to the genius of Guadi, this apartment building is a must-see if you are interested in art, architecture, history or simply want to see how the well-to-do lived in Barcelona at the turn of the 20th century. We took four children to this place and got the audio tour (ages 13-5) and they ALL loved it (the adults did too). The tour was engaging, the opportunity to clamber around the roof was great, and the staging of the old apartments magical. There are also quite a few museum-like exhibitions on Guadi and how he worked so if you are into that, you will not be displeased. Like so many sites in Barcelona, this one is a must-see.

No right angles. Gaudi started the building in 1906 and it took him four years to finish this masterpiece. Its nickname means “quarry” due to its unusual construction. The large stone blocks were first mounted to the facade and later shaped by the stonemasons. The building consists of two houses, connected by the facade and the roof. It is very distinctive and expressionistic work, an imposing building designed with natural forms and there are no right angles in the whole house.
Totally fantastic!!. Another not-to-miss Gaudi dream. This apartment building is just so amazing - and I can't believe that actual people get to live here! The roof is spectacular. Don't miss this!
Stunning architecture. A really fascinating place to visit - well worth the money - the roof and attic are quite unique and the displays well worth seeing

Great stop, Gaudi at his best. If you want to see a through and through Gaudi work, look no further. This delightful estate is Gaudi at his finest, designing from the structure out to the decor. The exhibit gives nice insight to his working style and let's you appreciate how well Gaudi mastered physics and engineering, not simply new design ideas.

Gaudi. Loved hearing why and how this was built. Gaudi's architectural style is unique - leveraging nature everywhere. I was fine till we went to the rooftop. I have vertigo. Putting that adide, Gaudi was definitely a man before his time. Elevators, garage etc - a visionary. Amazing

Very popular work of art. We passed La Pedrera while we were walking down on the Passeig de Gracia.It is very popular with the tourists.There were big crowds waiting outside to go in.Very much like Casa Batllo.Another stunning looking piece of art from Gaudi.A must see.

If you are an art fan, go for it!. We entered it, it cost us around 30euros per person. They provide an audioguide in quite wide range of language. The rooftop was unique. And when we stayed there at night there was this show in front of the building, with the building itself as the screen. Epic.

Origins. Origins is the name for the evening tour at Casa Mila - La Pedrera. Pre-book tickets. It is possible to choose the language of your guided tour. Beginning on the ground floor, there is an introduction to the building, before ascending (via lift or stairs, as per your preference) to the attic space. This contains an exhibition of Gaudi related artifacts and will enhance your understanding of the inspirations for the building. The music and light show on the roof terrace - which follows - is truly wonderful. The tour ends with a glass of cava (or water, orange juice) in the central space. I diverting way to spend 90-minutes in the evening.
Interesting tour. Another expression of the Gaudi's genius with a nice view of the life of a rich family almost 100 years ago.Interesting tour even if in my opinion a bit overpriced.

Incredible piece of architecture by Gaudi. This building is not only beautiful but also very functional .It was actually a family house . Wherever you look you can find a piece of outstanding architecture art of Gaudi .

Interesting. Been here couple of times, and they say that there is not a single "stright" line wall - all of the walls are curved. The design is really interesting and it is a good place to visit while you enjoy your sights in Barcelona.

Nighttime tour. Night tour left much to be desired. It was the most expensive of our entries on our trip to Spain yet we felt we were left confused on what we paid for. Was hoping to see more and learn more about Gaudi. Would not recommend for value.

Amazing, creative architecture.. Unbelievable that Gaudi had this vision in the early 1900s. I spent about an hour ambling around the roof and then traveling down through the building. Well worth the time and the fee. It's a walk through creative history.

Nice building. That's a very nice building. The art it's good... but the price to get in it's exagerated! It's more expensive to get in than other places like it in Barcelona and in my opinion it's not worth the money! For art fans, sure, for a turist... not sure.
Eye For Detail. Gaudi's Eye for Detail will again amaze you, the best part of the house was the chimneys and courtyard according to me.
Good but exponsive. The overall experience was good but the attraction is a bit expensive. We've bought 2 tickets for 68 euros for 1.5 hour visit.
A modernist masterpiece. This lovely building is fascinating to look at inside and out. It's lit up and festooned with decorations and lights around Christmas which adds to its unique charm.
Stunning Gaudi building. This Gaudi designed building which seems quite at ease with its more traditional neighbours shows this architects desire for freedom of design & expression
A stone building designed by Gaudi. This is a stone building designed by Gaudi. Many people thought he was a mad man, but he was genius. The lower level is commercial, and the upper is for offices.
Don't miss The Origins. We visited during the afternoon and then again in the evening for "The Origins"...an amazing tour. Rooftop terrace like never before.
Gaudi architecture . Well worth a visit if architecture is your thing. Amazing Gaudi style although it looks ok with the area. We did not go inside because at around €20+ we feel it is expensive.
Interesting. Had seen a lot of details which makes Gaudi special. We had doubts if it worth to pay for the visit but convinced that was very interesting

Tried the "fast pass" variant. We have visited before and were stuck in long lines. This time we booked online and also the fast pass variant to save time. Well worth the additional cost as you get priority access, with NO waiting in line, we were led straight to the lift and this allowed us to cut at least 40min in the entrance line (wait for tickets and then entry). You get the audioguide thrown in, and this is not to be missed as it is one of the best ways to understand Gaudi and the times. Once in you are on the top floor you are mixing with the normal entrance folk, but this is not a problem as the numbers are controlled so it is not overcrowded. We followed the guide and really got a lot more out of the visit, it does take longer as you become enthralled with the details rather than ticking off the rooms and without the long wait you are still fresh and eager.

Must go up to the rooftop terrace!!. The building is so beautiful and amazing. And it's definitely worth it to pay to go inside and up to the rooftop terrace!Be sure you get the free audioguide that comes included with the admission so you can understand the design and concept Gaudi had in mind. I highly recommend this visit if you're in Barcelona.
impressively. take your breath awayfabulously beautifulhouse of talesgrandiose architectural creationone of the famous attraction
Very nice!. Gaudi architecture is beautiful, highly recommended visit in Barcelona. The interior is surprising and is in the heart of the city

The staff doesn't care . We were considering if we should visit Casa Mila today or tomorrow, because it was already late. We have told that to the lady at the entrance and asked her how long does the visit take. She informed us that it takes about 1.5 hour, but she DID NOT TELL US THAT THEY ARE CLOSING TOMORROW for one week maintenance!
Another amazing Gaudì's work. This enormous building in located along Passeig de Gracia, the most important boulevard in Barcelona, with lots of expensive and trendy shops.

So expensive !. the cheapest adult ticket is at more than 20 euros ! It is a rip-off comprare to the other buildings like Sagrada Familia. You should prefer Casa Batllo, 5 minutes walk from La Pedrera. It is a nicer building and cheaper.
A summary of Gaudi. It's basically a museum of Gaudi's work. It is worth visiting this place after you've been to the Sagrada and Casa Batllo.

Mighty, Mesmerizing and Overwhelming. If I could give 10 stars on TripAdvisor, I would rate Casa Mila as 10 stars. It's one brilliant piece of Gaudi Architecture, a must see for anyone who appreciates art and style. My personal suggestion would be to go after dark as the building and the view is way more mesmerizing. The rooftop view with the chimneys is simply mindblowing. and the audio guide is one of the best and the most comprehensive amongst the ones I have had in BCN.

Gaudi's best in my view!. La Pedrera was one of Gaudi's last buildings before taking on his biggest, last, yet to be completed, La Sagrada Familia. La Pedrera is his best, in my view, being the only one I feel I could possibly live in without feeling too ostentatious, frilly and ornate. In my opinion, it's organic feel marries in quite well with some of the forms of architecture happening around us all today! Seeing it has made me now want to explore Gaudi's architecture a little further.

Nice visit . We enjoyed our trip here but were rather disappointed versus the casa batllo which was far more enjoyable and interactive, the roof is amazing as you can tell from the exterior, if you were to chose just one I wouldn't pick here.

Go to the roof!. I started my Gaudi touring here and it was super exciting to be able to see the spaces as it was designed to be used but also how it has adapted over time. The chimneys on the roof are really interesting.
If your a fan of Gaudi, GO!. Highly recommend La Pedrera, which is furnished, AND Casa Batllo, which is unfurnished. Within walking distance of each other

Great Roof Top experince. We visited La Pedrera as a family of 2 adults & 1 child. We got there fairly early & paid on entry. It was a very interesting visit & thoroughly enjoyed the roof top & attic areas. The audio guides were very interesting too. We visited La Pedrera & Casa Bastilo on the same day. Visiting La Paedrera 1st & then Casa Bastilo 2nd, which in my opinion is the best way to do it.

A very interesting look into Gaudi's work and creative process. Casa Milà now known as La Pedrera was designed and built for a single family who at times did not agree with Gaudi about the design and function but the result is very unique, beautiful, and worth a visit. We originally booked a night tour but had to cancel due to our flight being canceled at the last minute. Thanks Air France. We were however able to visit the following evening during regular hours and were happy that we did. The tour of the building was impressive but I found the attic space to be the most interesting in that it was shaped like the rib cage of a snake and packed with displays on how Gaudi borrows the shapes of nature and uses Funicular geometric hanging 3D models to design his buildings. The coffee shop in front was also a nice place to relax and have a snack.

Stuff you only see in pictures. This is one of the things you have seen in pictures and its amazing to see in real life. I haven't been inside but the view from the outside is enough to make it worth it.

Nice building. Didn't enter and feedback from other travellers I met felt it is not worth the money. However if you are into architecture and Gaudi you will find it good. Many just stood across the road to take photo from the outside. That is as good as it gets for me.
Gaudi at his amazing best. La Pedrera is the best example of Gaudis work in central Barcelona. The roof and the views from it are absolutely amazing. Unmissable

Beautiful! Go early morning for clear street and no tourists. Go early in morning. i was there at 8am...and already few tourists there..If you want to go inside, need to purchase a ticket. Look out for opening hours so be there just intime before everyone starts flocking in.

Gaudi again, with a helpful exhibition covering his work overall. Casa Batllo is more fascinating if you can only do one, (the two are close together), but this building includes an exhibition giving more general info about Gaudi's work, and is a good starting place for visiting his other works. It has the more fascinating and photographed roof , with wonderful views of the city - make sure you go in the dry. Timed admission so best to buy ahead. We used the dearer anytime day access so we could be flexible about timing and also thereby jumped the queue.

Amazing work of Gaudi. Visited Casa Milla (as it is also known) with family in Dec 2015. What an amazing work. Starting from the roof all the way down, once can see the way Gaudi challenged the typical (boring) architecture. I strongly suggest to take the audio guides. There is a place to put the bags etc. at the entrance, which makes the visit very convenient.

Amazing architecture . What an amazing architecture by Gaudi. This is a must to visit for all tourists. I did the day tour. You get a free audio guide for this tour and it is really helpful to understand the ideas and concepts behind this Gaudi design.

A very different night out!. We were unable to book tickets to this attraction during the day but booked the night tour, not quite sure what to expect. The result was a very interesting evening, with a guided tour of the building, a spectacular light show on the rooftop and a glass of champagne (or orange juice) and bites to eat at the end. I'm unable to comment on visiting during the day, or whether it's worth doing both if possible but I would definitely recommend the night tour and would advise to book online in advance so you can guarantee getting in.

the night show is a must. went here to watch the late night light and sound show was absolutely amazing. Made me feel quite emotional. You go to the attic first (if your not very fit take the lift! 6 flights of stairs up) then another flight up to the roof where all the statues light up with different images of flowers, animals, scenes etc. When the show finishes you go back downstairs for a glass of cava.

Interesting. It was great to have a tour through this house however we didn't actually get to see some of the rooms or apartments. It was very general about the house and a lot of history about Barcelona. Light show was interesting but nothing meaningful. Don't make this your primary plan for the night but if you got nothing to do and would like to see the house then go ahead.
New Year's Eve 4 day trip to Barcelona. A must see position when visiting Barcelona. Great views from the terrace and an amazing example of Gaudi's architecture
Fabulous. Fabulous place...the foyer is stunning....the rooftop amazing and inside the apartment gives you a great insight into how people lived and still live...do not miss

Must for Architecture fans! . This was my second timeat Casa Milà and im still taken by it. I love Antoni Gaudí and his works. It would be recommended to buy the tickets online since the line may be long.
Favorite!. Be sure to eat in the attached cafe (and inside) because the decor is gorgeous and an extension of La Pedrera.
Beautiful.... I did not go and explore inside Le Pedrera but the outside of the building alone is worth a visit, both during the day and at night.It must be very interesting inside!
Worth it. You have to see this. The apartments ares so ahead of it's time. Well worth the visit. Get the recorded tour.

Easy Photo Opportunity for this Site. You can see Gaudi's work just walking by. Lots of opportunities to take photos without going inside. It just looks really impressive when you walk near it. Make it part of going from one location to the next.

Crazy about Gaudi Curves!. Another stunning Gaudi architecture which emphasizes the beauty of curves and waves. Amazing to see apartments built in the early 1900s combining the nostalgic decor in a futuristic skeleton of a mansion. Very elegant and worth a look. Pity it didn't open on Christmas Day. It's also a Gaudi attraction worth buying a ticket online first before you go.
Very nice . Worth a visit though Batlo is better! Book your tickets online! There is an elevator to go up but stairs to go back down, view from the terrace is great! But expensive
good art. its a must show a great work from gaudi but the sagrada and balto is prettier . and recommend to go to the roof

The Pedrera is brilliant, too bad they won't let you see most of it!. The only option available while we were in Barcelona was to book the night experience guided visit, that is pretty expensive for what it's worth! The let you see the interior entrance and the guide talks blablabla for 15 minutes! The you go throught the stairs directly on the roof, where there is a light and laser show projected on the roof's shapes! The light show is quite amazing but I feel that the price/quality ratio isn't right!

Very cool. My wife likes museums, I do not. So I was a little hesitant going here. It was great. An architecturally unique and still functioning apartment complex created by Gaudi allows you to physically be immersed in the beauty. Definitely recommend it

GAUDITASTIC...VIVE LA MODERNISME. Within walking distance of one of the world's finest creations...La Sagrada Familia.....which is just shocking...incredible...A true wonder of the world...Having stayed at The beautiful Condes across the road, I would often see the tourists climbing around the roof so why not give it a go....Listening to a tour guide explaining in English the history of the building made the whole experience very interesting...more enjoyable than the Gaudi museum in his hometown of Reus.
