By far one of the most beautiful buildings ever. It is gorgeous on the outside, it really does remind you of the sea, everything about it does. The inside, wow, the hall is beautiful and it has a natural light that makes you feel like you are in a magic cave with the sun coming in. An amazing place and design, just brilliant. You can also visit an apartment they have open to the public (because, yes, there are people who actually live in such a beautiful place!, so you can visit this one and it is worth it) to see how it's like and it also has a shop inside. Then you can visit the amazing terraces there, explore around and just be amazed. Take your time to visit this incredible building.

Intuitive flowing building. If you're in search of a quiet Guell site to visit Casa Mila / La Pedrera off Passeig de Gracia is worth a short one. The tour starts in the first floor foyer/ atrium and takes you up to the roof top thru the attics & apartments.If some of the additional exhibits don't interest you (seen/heard before in Sagrada Familia or Casa Batllo or one of the many other Guell exhibitions across Barcelona) the visit to the apartments which they have made every attempt to be as "in situ" as possible-- with period furniture-- are still well worth a daydreamy walk-through. Don't get me wrong though, the roof, attic itself are awesome.Note the visit requires going up & down (lots) steps and flights of stairs.
Amazing . Stood in line for 40 minutes but was worth it- the place is gorgeous, the audio instruction very good and overall a great experience. Highly recommend!
Great seen. we went there during the night time to watch the amazing light show. very recommended and try to book in advance.

Worth the money and great audioguide. If you don't get into any other attractions of gaudi's, this one is the one to go to. It will give you a thorough insight into all his work. Great audioguide, visual displays, views of barcelona, and tour through one of the apartments.

Well Worth the Time!. One of the highlights of our recent trip to Barcelona was this surprising visit to La Pedrera. Bought tickets on line the morning we went and sailed past a LONG line of folks who must not have heard about the internet. Access to the roof and the great views of the city would have been enough but you also get to tour one of the apartments outfitted in turn of the century style. First floor access is also available to give you an idea of the size of the apartment but it is currently an exhibition hall. Plan on a couple of hours.
Roof terrace . We loved the roof terrace but the interior is a bit underwelming. The entrance ticket is quite expensive but just about worth it as an audio guide is included.

Fun and interesting. Buy your ticket online to avoid queuing. Audio guide comes with the ticket and provides great insights to La Pedrera and Gaudi's works. Starting from the rooftop, you have great views of the city and into the lifestyles and architecture all within. Easily be able to spend 2-3 hours in there and learn a lot of Gaudi's other works as well.

A must see if you like Gaudi. Go inside and visit the roof - definitely worth it. The views of Barcelona are great and seeing the tile-work up close leaves a lasting impression.If you don't have much time for many attractions in Barcelona - see this one and Sagrada Familia... you can skip Park Guell.Then save time for other things like the Gothic Quarter, Picasso and Joan Miro museums...
Interesting building . Pretty curious/interesting building though I can't speak for what it looks like on the inside. Most of the Gaudi designed buildings are super beautiful.

Detailed display. Although it was not amazing like sagrada familia, it still worth to visit.The atmosphere in that time was established with old-fashioned furniture. The detailed design concepts were displayed as well.
STARTLING ARCHECTECTURE. found as you moved along the street Did not take the time to enterMost interesting baloney design and arrangement. Interior left for another visit

The place to start Gaudi journey First!. This is the where we really learn about Gaudi's work and legacy, also understanding of modernism movement that is the beginning of modern Barcelona and Gaudi's influence.

Amazing example of Gaudi architecture. My daughter & I thoroughly enjoyed our visit to La Pedrera, also known as Casa Mila. This is an apartment building where we got to start on the roof to see the views of Barcelona plus the one of a kind designs by Gaudi. There is also an exhibit of his buildings and a visit to a furnished apartment. We loved the whole visit!
Great evening spent here!. A wonderful visit, would recommend buying tickets in advance online to save a long wait outside. A beautiful building nonetheless!

Exceptional. After the tour we felt like we finally understood what Gaudi was doing. His organic architecture makes so much sense once it was explained. This was so much more than entertainment. We both learned a lot today

Fascinating architecture. This apartment building is a revolutionary architecture work or let me say a piece of art in la pedra u have to visit the roof its a story of glory. Gaudi created a theme of everything .. really u will miss if you didnt visit it . Very recommended

A fantastic site to see. I love Gaudi! This is a fantastic site to visit. Although, the lines are long it's worth the wait. Inside of this beautiful building is gorgeous! It was absolutely stunning. I love Barcelona and all things Gaudi. Don't miss out on this wonderful attraction.

Very different but entry fee is a bit too much. Decided to check out La Pedrera aka Casa Mila after reading many reviews of Gaudi's work. Building looks very different from conventional ones and with the audio guide you can get a good understanding about Gaudi's ideas as well as how the building came into being. You get to visit the terrace which has weird looking structures and also an apartment which has Gaudi's design all over. I felt that the entry fee was a bit high. Maybe worth if you are a great fan of architecture or Gaudi.

beautiful architecture, overpriced tickets, recommend night show: "The Origins". The architecture of this building is beautiful, unconventional and intriguing. We visited this building twice- once during the day and for the show "The Origins". There was a lot of overlap between both tours. We thought just the night tour would've been adequate, considering the expensive tickets and the time invested. Our day tour included a free audio guide. Our night show-"The Origins" included a guided walking tour of the building, a light show on the terrace and drinks (champagne, juice and snacks) after. The light show on the terrace was a surreal experience.PS: There were hundreds of stairs to the terrace. People who are unable to climb stairs can take elevator.

A must see!. Very cool visit, especially the rooftop. We were glad this was the first Gaudi work we visited during our stay in Barcelona since the audio tour tells you a lot about him and his background, which is less the case in the other Gaudi designed places in Barcelona.

Expensive . This building is part of the gaudi architecture and is beautiful. The curves and arches of the building really do make it stand out and it's nice to appreciate the design and art in the articecture. It is very expensive to gain entry & explore the chimneys/rooftop. Now used as apartments

Nice but not enough to see.. Majority of the place is closed for public. Some galery on the main floor.Open for public are ground floor, attic and roof.I highly recommend Behind a Closed Door show.First of all just your group, nobody else.Second - great laser show.Third - glass of cava (spanish sparkling wine) and some small sweets.

miracle home with Xmas deco. Another modernist building designed by Gaudi.
Came during the Xmas time and la Pedrera has been decorated with Xmas theme. Pretty cool design! It's currently on UNESCO World Heritage List.
Stunning but overpriced. The building is amazing and especially educational for architecture student. Unfortunately, 18.5 euro for student is definitely overpriced!

Dizzying!. Not for the faint-hearted-or those who get dizzy easily! Gaudi's La Pedrera is a never ending journey of circling staircases, angled heights and worryingly bent walls with no straight paths in sight. Even more nauseating than Casa Batllo, although there are still some grand views to behold.

Incredible place . This was the first of four Gaudí sites I visited. It is a beautiful building. The roof is what everyone comes to see, and it does not disappoint. You feel like you've entered another world when you get up there. Pictures don't do it justice- you have to see it for yourself.

A Masterpiece of Modernisme. Talking about Gaudi and the Modernisme movement in Barcelona will need books and not just a review. In short, this place is one of must-see innovations of Gaudi. All his main themes and tools are employed here.The building was meant to be a residence and a part of it is still used as such.They offer 2 kinds of visits; Day and Night.The day visit covers the ground floor, a furnished apartment, the roof, temporary exhibitions and the permanent exhibition of Gaudi.The roof and the permanent exhibition are the true highlights of this place.The night visit is a guided visit and only covers the ground floor, Gaudi exhibition and the roof. Our guide, Miguel, was exceptionally helpful during the visit. He was ready to explain everything and took us very slowly through the exhibition pointing out the small details.I actually recommend night visit. It was more fun than the morning one.

Another must see. My wife and I enjoyed this almost one century old building designed by Gaudi. It is worth taking the elevator to the top and to walk around the spectacular roof top, filled with different ornamental spires. Then walk down to the "attic" and view the top floor furnished apartment. Actually it is also amazing that the rest of the floors are still lived in by various tenants. By all means this is another amazing Gaudi creation worth going to see. Recommended.

What was this Gaudi guy thinking?. From the outside, the building looks disgusting. There are many other good places to look in Barcelona other than this building. Save your money, and go somewhere else, like Tibidabo, Barceloneta and/or Parc Guel.

Must Visit Place in Barcelona!. Definitely worth a visit if you love Antoni Gaudi's works, which made significant contributions to Art Nouveau. Besides La Sagrada Família, Park Güell and Casa Batlló, La Pedrera is also one of Gaudí’s masterpieces in the center of Barcelona. UNESCO recognized this building as World Heritage in 1984. It is not just a historical architecture but also an awesome art work to demonstrate a fantastic mix of NATURE, CURVES, UNUSUAL MATERIALS. Highly recommend to see the unique and unusual roof and enjoy the view from the top roof!

Beautiful. Very unique. So glad we stopped by. Didn't go in because the lines were long. So buy your tickets online before going. Otherwise silk a gorgeous building. Bought a beautiful Gaudi-style silver ring from the gift shop.

It is like being in Gaudi's world.... This is really an incredible building and gives you an insight into Gaudi's aesthetic completely. It is very busy and popular so book your tickets online to save time queuing up. I used the audio guide and thought it was very good too. It is a must see!!!
Gaudi Gaudi Gaudi. This type of architecture is unique in the world and a must see for all those that enjoy something different! Ricommend looking at night when the lights are on...
simply beautifull. It was so nice to visit the house, I didn't believe you can spend several hours there, and also worth to go to the roof. Very impressive all.

Amazing architecture. Almost century old apartment building designed by Gaudi. You take the elevator to the top and walk around the spectacular undulating roof filled with different ornamental and utilitarian spires. Then walk down to the "attic" and view the top floor furnished apartment. The rest of the floors are still lived in. Another amazing Gaudi creation!
Another masterpiece. Great architectural visit, with skip the line access, Worth all the way up to the roof, great views of the city.

Beautiful; great audio tour . I visited la pedrera with my sister. The building is stunning and the audio tour you're given to listen to during your visit was very detailed but not so long that you'd get bored. The roof terrace is honestly something that everybody needs to see in their life! If you are in Barcelona I'd definitely visit.

Art and math blend into one. Another Gaudi masterpiece. Coming to Barcelona, I was very intrigued by Gaudi. His mind is so unique, blending art and math in his works.There are plenty of great aspects to this building but it's best at the top with the elegant roof structures. The attic is also interesting, the apartments a bit less so for my tastes. This is a must do for anyone interested in Gaudi.

Design Geeks, Get You to Le Pedrera. After you get through the mandatory and overly dark walking tour through the first part of this building, you are allowed access to the Disneyland Fantasia scenery at the top of this building. It is one of the best buildings in Barcelona. You can never get the same view from any place that you stand, and you will constantly need to move around and take in all the lights and designs of Barcelona from every angle. The roof undulates like the waves of an ocean, and takes on the purple, red, blue and silver hues of Barcelona at dusk. Highly recommended for families and architect and design geeks.

A Beautiful Building. The La Pedrera was a beautiful building to visit and a good exposure to Gaudi's work and technique, much more so than any of the other Gaudi exhibits I saw. They explained his style and how he tied things back to nature which was really interesting.The set up of the apartment was also really well done. Plus, it's right in the city so very easy to get to.

If you fancy LaSagrada Familia this is a must in Barcelona. To earn money for his life's work LaSagrada Familia, Gaudi designed may houses in Barcelona, and being very innovative he was very popular. You can see this for yourself if you visit La Pedrera which holds a Gaudi museum in the attic and a full apartment with everything latest fashion at the time of construction, compared to today's standard especially the kitchen is high standard with many in-built appliances that we buy as extras. And do not miss the famous rooftop - this is were you go first, but be careful not to be "seasick", it is curved and bent, up and down, and has the most fantastic view over Barcelona

I loved visiting this Gaudi designed condo building.. This was a brilliant design for a condominium building. It features many eye pleasing details such as elaborate chimneys, a simple way of collecting rainwater, and a beautiful central plaza/atrium.

Step back into Gaudí's time.... The audio tour of this Gaudí masterpiece takes you from the entry court directly to the rooftop via elevator, where you can spend as much time as you like walking around the roof and photographing the unique chimneys and other rooftop constructions. The next stop is the attic, which includes wonderful models and information about Gaudí and his work. The attic itself is a wonderful space to spend time in. From there, you proceed to the 4th floor, where one of the original apartments has been preserved & furnished with period pieces. It's great fun to imagine this as your home in Barcelona, surrounded with Gaudí's unique style of design. We were fortunate to be there in the off-season so it was easy to wander back & forth in the apartment to get a good feel of what it was like to live there. The other apartment on the 4th floor has been converted to a gift shop and public toilets. There is also a gift shop on the main level as well as a restaurant that is open to the public. A must-see for fans of Antoni Gaudí.
Beautiful. I find this attraction with to visit, if not a must see. The roof is just worth the whole entrance fee. It adds then with the interior, and films that enhances the visit

Nice visit interesting . We visited he gaudi designed building and toured. The tour was interesting and explained gaudi brilliance as both an architect and mathematician.The tour was basic and the free audio guide needs a big upgradeThe view is amazing and to see and understand how the building was constructed and the science behind just allows you to appreciate GaudiI highly recommend the tour

Beautiful structure . I bought my tickets online for 20.59 euro for the 9:00am session. The good thing about that is arriving while the Casa isn't crowded. The roof is nice and everyone takes the longest there. The rooms below are more of viewing the structure and learning about the history/inspiration for Gaudi. Going down is mostly stairs. A lot of ppl who were bringing their children did struggle with the stairs. I do recommend this because it is part of the Barcelona Gaudi experience.
Designing Milestones.... The design is extra ordinary and another architectural marvel by Gaudi....The interiors, floor surface and even the different roof top design is worth visiting
Worth it. If possible buy your tix online. It will save u time. Self guided tour is high tech and adds to the experience. Incredible technology

Guide took tourists to the roof and left. Initially the tour started out well, the tour guide took 20-30 tourists to see the light show on the roof. You were given a choice to walk up many stairs ortake a lift. Many of the elder tourists took the lift, including my mom. We got to the roof and the light show was long and boring. The tour guide tells her tour group, she's gotta go and after the show another guide wouldlead us down. No guide showed up. We were on the roof of the building, minimal light,lots of climbing up and down stairs, very dangerous. There were refreshments waitingwhen we finally got down No thanks!!! This is not a tour for the elderly or handicapped.
masterpiece of Gaudi. Tip: to take tickets from the internet.to arrive earlier. The one of the great places to visit in Barcelona. to see ,to feel the Gaudi genius architecture

Check online!. We had planned to go check this out during the day but we discovered they were now offering a night show. However when we got there (hours said 7 pm -10 pm November to February, ticket office opens at 6) they told us that the only English show was already over. I was disappointed that the flyer did not list specific show times or that there is only one show in English a day. We did not have time to stop up on a different night of the trip, so we missed out. It looked really cool and I would recommend checking online or in person during the day.

spectacular. this is a spot!!!really nice and interesting. i founded myself thinking on way of life of people, a century ago in thet house. it was a life full of life... if you are in barcelona- do not misss pedrera!!!

Gaudi's best?. If you have time for only one of Gaudi's creations, this would have to be it. Amazing! The chimneys on the roof are what we see on the postcards, but his interior design and attention to detail are really special.

Surreal. This famous block of apartments is must see in Barcelona, even more soIf you have an interest in architecture. Gaudi's original and innovative designIs breath-taking and the roof with its irregular surface floor levels and statuesque shapes is both practical and aesthetic. The fact that one of the apartments is open is also a bound. Gaudi was obviously way ahead of his time as the building still appears futuristic.

Cool building with good history. Gaudi once again proves his skill.Well ahead of its time - people were not too keen on it when it was built and that's why it's called Le Pedrera (the rockery). Beautiful building - must see.
Gaudi fantastic. Worth the visit. Gaudi's creation allows you to enjoy his creativity and vision. The clever "modern" design was ahead of it's time.
Outstanding!. Interesting and beautiful example of Gaudi's work. It is easy to reach and should be considered a "don't miss" attraction. Lovely views from the roof.

Best Gaudi Art. I'm not an history or art lover, however La Pedrera is the best Gaudi building for me. If you would like to visit only one, I'll suggest you spend some extra time for the entrance line and visit it.
Left an impression. Liked the idea that this whole project was Gaudi ( not a refurb). The roof is amazing. The rest ho-hum, I guess because it is a living building with only limited parts open.

Iconic building The Pedrera also known as Casa Mila'. Building started in 1906 on the corner of Passeig de Graciait is pale grey in colour different from other Gaudi buildings ie Casa Batillo across the road. Four floors of flats and offices. The roof of arches and amazing chimneys make this house famous. Lots of large windows enable you to see the flats from end to end with balconies and twisted iron works. Arches and the interior courtyard are beautiful with fabulous paintings on the ceilings
Purely Anthony Gaudi's piece of work. A must see for a unique visual experience, The highlight is at the top of the building. Book your tickets online as the line is soooo long.

nothing special but costly entrance fee. my wife and i pay 20.5eur for day pass.it is only three floor to walk. the roof should be the best area for taking photo. we expect it is special and worth 20eur, however we did not feel it. we just want to say, it surely great for the ones who love history very much, otherwise just take your way to take nice photo outside.
Anthony Gaudi works. The building is a great example of Gaudi's work. The rooftop is amazing as is the exhibition of Gaudi's ideas. Very interesting.

Breaktaking views. This is a must-see. It is a unique experience, combining history, architecture and the most wonderful example of human creativeness. So interesting, so much to look at and to learn. An incredible experience. We paid the extra to jump the queue, and it was well worth it. It is quite indescribable - champagne bottle ends embedded in the tops of chimneys, eccentric living spaces that would work well today. Just great.

Love this place. If you like quirky then you'll love this, I would love to live here. some of the building is lived in and that area is locked off from the parts visitors see. Use the lift when you start your tour otherwise you have to climb all the way up to the top as that is where it starts and you work down. I did the climb - wouldn't want to do it in the heat!!Describing the place would be too difficult all I can say is I wouldn't have missed it for anything/
Wow! This is really worth seeing!. What a fantastic building! I loved it! Just wish I had a flat there as a little pied a terre! Good shop too and make sure you see the other gallery inside it!

Most creative house in the history of architecture. The grand staircase was astonishing and the apartments within were quite plain but with many interesting items. The crazy looking roof left me wondering what Gaudi had with his Cornflakes in the morning.

An architectureal experience.. Another Gaudi masterpiece, flowing organic structure way ahead of its time. Check out the imperial storm troopers on the roof, the night time displays add a nice touch to the tour.

Simply stunning. Just pay the small entrance fee and get in there! If you like Architecture and modernism all joined together then this building is superb! The lines and design throughout the building is years ahead of the game (and still are in some quarters!) Great design, great building, awesome city! ❤️BCN❤️

La Pedrera: Need to know.... This is a beautiful house, we definitely recommend seeing it!We did not book tickets in advance and, in December, were looking at a line about 30 minutes long. There are 3 ticket options available: daytime ticket, nightime ticket, combination day/night (discounted). We did the combo so we could see the light show at night. For the nighttime visit you have to choose a very specific time to arrive.We had a baby stroller & backpack--checked in both in the locker room. Lockers are for rent, requires coins.There are lots of stairs, not able to use a stroller at all but we had our baby sling with us (thankfully). There is an elevator for going from the first floor directly to the roof; or you can walk the stairs. Then you walk the rest of the way down (this is what staff told me when I asked about taking an elevator back down--no in between floor stops). The roof is quite large, uneven, and lots of stairs. Spectacular views. In December at noon the roof was SO hot & sunny. We were stripping off our jackets & hats & gloves. Wish I had an umbrella for shade & my sunglasses.The house itself has a lot of windows that let in light and heat--it was quite warm walking around. In hindsight, we should have left our jackets/hats/gloves in the locker room.I saw two public bathrooms while walking through the house. I also saw vending machines and some tables/chairs to have a snack at (we had our own snacks/water).Daytime entry is on your own, at your own pace.Our nighttime visit was for 2000 (8 pm) and we were about 3-4 minutes late. Fortunately they let us join anyways. If you get a night time ticket, it is for a guided tour that lasts about an hour. When we asked about dropping off the stroller in the locker room he said no because it would 'hold up everyone else' (the locker room was only about 40 feet away) so we had to take it with us. Fortunately it is a smaller one that folds up. He took us through the house for about 40 minutes before going to the roof for the light show. It was more of a movie; lasted about 15 minutes. Then you take the stairs all the way down & they served us champagne, orange juice, & some little desserts. No bathroom stops or additional stops on this tour--the guide has a timeframe to complete the tour & he does not stray from it.
very impressed!. I would recommend to go there at the sunset to enjoy the impressive atmosphere of the terrace! You will definitely love it!
Nice. Nice to drive past, but it isn't the Sagrada Familia. The hop on hop off bus stops close by for easy access.

Loved it . This was one of my favourite stops on my trip to Barcelona. La Pedrera is such a masterpiece of genius to walk through and see. The museum part of la Pedrera gives a great history of the building and of Antoni Gaudi. Once on the roof you can see his beautiful sculptures. I would go back in a heartbeat.

Paseo de Gracia. We were on a Hop On Hop Off bus when we first saw La Pedrera. There is a stop about a block away. So we hopped off. This is another Gaudi building and is something right out of the dinosaur era. Very pretty and unusual. You can go to the top where there is a sculpture garden.The area is where all the most expensive shops are located. People watching is fun. There are benches to sit on located up and down the paseo. Also the shopping is incredible if you have a very large check book.This is a beautiful part of town.
good to see. been there in general to see the hole area its a different building like everything Gaudi did i didnt go in so i cannot give you a full idea

If you do not know Gaudis work, start here.... This building shows how he was ahead of his time in open space living and design. It even has underground parking. The roof is amazing. Check the price of apartments...
Gaudi in more normal edition?. It's one of less weird Gaudi's works. It seems so normal. But if you look at it you know it's Gaudi. All those decorations, it's beautiful.

An absolute must-see!. If you are short of time in Barcelona and only have time to see two Gaudi works then visit this amazing apartment building after La Sagrada Familia. Book your tickets online in advance to save have to line-up. HOHO buses stop at the two Gaudi houses on Passeig de Gracia. Casa Batilo is just 4 blocks away...It's big, so allow at least two hours to enjoy. There will be a lot of people visiting but the size of the roof will spread them out and you'll get some good photos, albeit with some strangers in them. Inside, when visiting the rooms, furnished as in the 1930s, you'll need to stay in front (or behind) of the herd and get your photos quickly for a clean shot. Between the roof and the apartment rooms is a loft with architectural models and audio visual displays showing Barcelona in Gaudi's time. You can rent audio guides at the entrance. We took the elevator to the roof ( some stairs involved too) and worked our way back down. You exit through a spacious gift shop and Cafe Pedrera has tables on the sidewalk to decompress and enjoy the buskers who stroll by.Hopefully my photos will give you a good idea of what to expect....

Night time light show at La Pedrera. After having seen many of Gaudi's other works, like Casa Batllo, Park Guell and Sagrada Familia, we weren't expecting many new surprises. We were wrong and happy to have gone to see the light show on the roof of the house. If anything, Gaudi was extremely detail-oriented. When he remodeled the house, he intended to extend his art to the attic and roof, areas seldomly accessed by the rich owners that were paying for the renovations. As a result, the Mila family did not want to pay for the roofwork where ventilation shafts where disguised as eerie storm troopers or robot like statues. Fortunately, enough of the work was completed to create a fantasy world. The attic looks like the inside of a massive Leviathan and the light show at night from the roof is not to be missed. An opportunity to drink a little Cava sparkling wine at the end on the ground floor give a nice finishing touch to the visit.

Stunning views of the City. At first, we didn't want to spend another 20€ each to go into another house but I say I enjoyed seeing La Pedrera more than Casa Batllo, which is one or two blocks down the street from La Pedrera. We came around 4:30 PM on a Sunday afternoon, no wait for purchasing tickets or anything during this December month. However, I am glad we came at this time because the first stop on the audio guided tour was to the rooftop of La Pedrera. We spent maybe 20 minutes up at the rooftop taking pictures of the chimneys and of the surrounding areas during sunset. It was absolutely spectacular. You'll be able to see the church at the top of Tibidabo, the Mediterranean Sea, and the La Segrada Familia.You'll then go and explore the buildings of La Pedrera of what used to be an attic and a typical apartment building. You'll also see models of all of Gaudi's work at La Pedrera such as the planning/models for Park Guell, Casa Batllo, etc which was extremely informative information that I didn't get at these other sites. What's also unique is that La Pedrera is also a World Heritage Site.Overall, highly recommended and a must during the visit to Barcelona. Come during sunset if you can!

Unique and intersting Building!. The front of La Pedrera is beautiful. The design is smooth and detailed. We bought the tickets a head of time online to save time and some money. If you just go there be prepared to wait in line. Since we bought the tickets online we got in quicker. They provided you with an audio guide and direct you where to go. You can go on your own pace. To go to the rooftop of the building, we had to use an elevator and then climb some steps to reach the top. The rooftop had a lot of interesting chimney structures. There are a lot short steps that goes up and down throughout the rooftop. As you go through the building, there is a photographer that will ask if you want a picture in front of the green screen. We had our picture taken and it was beautiful. They placed the La Pedrera in the background. They showed you the pics and you can choose to buy it or not. I think it was three photos for 12Euros, which I think is pretty great deal. They also give you a code to download the ditigal copy online.

Yep, got the chimney photos!. Another impressive stop on the "Gaudi tour." The La Pedrera tour includes an apartment furnished as it might have been soon after it was constructed. Art Deco fans would enjoy it. The attic is used as a display area for models of the major Gaudi buildings and providing information about the man himself, and his methods. Of course, the visit is not complete unless you go up on the roof to see the chimneys close up.

One of the highlights of my trip. Walking around the outside, inside and roof top was amazing! Very memorable. We spent about 1 1/2 hours just looking at everything inside. Beautiful views from the roof great place to take photos.

Magistic Gaudi's Work. As all Gaudi's works, La Pedrera is amazing in all shapes and forms.
Take time to walk it, admire it and absorb all it's beauty.

Perfect building, nice souvenir shop. This building is in each manual of modern architecture and is on UNESCO list. It is not modern or art nouveau, it is simply Gaudi. Imagination, combinations, house is like a built symphony from detail to the entirety. You need to go inside, to see inner yards, staircases, light, decorations and specially the terrace at the top with all the chimneys. When tour groups leave the place, look at the building again and later visit the souvenir shop at least for some minutes. You can also visit interesting temporary exhibitions from the corner entrance from time to time. Years ago I saw an exhibition of famous painter Zoran Music there. If you will have two hours for Barcelona, choose this place.If you will have two days, take at least three hours.

Pretty cool!. Only went to the outside of the building. Thought it was quite expensive to go in (27Euros). Not to mention there was a very long line. However, its a very cool piece of architecture in the middle of a city that seems to be slightly more modernized. I would definitely recommend a stop by at least.

One of the top two Gaudi attractions. If you can't visit all the Gaudi sites then make sure Casa Mila/La Pedrera is one that you do visit. Along with the Sagrada Familia, it is a fascination adventure in architecture and creativity especially considering that it is over 100 years old. Strongly advise you to book tickets in advance and to pay extra for the headset guided tour. The recording guides you through the facility and does a great job of explaining what was in Gaudi's head as he designed this great place. Location is convenient and you can walk here from the central area and Las Ramblas.

So far ahead of its time!. We bought into a tour package that allowed us to skip the line at entry -- worth doing!You will get caught up in the magic of this place -- marvel at the sculptural rooftop while taking in a full 360 view of Barcelona.The interiors are terrific too and the exhibits are extremely informative.

Gaudi at his Best!. You get a 20% discount with the Barcelona card.You have to tour this site by night also, or maybe enjoy a night visit coupled with dinner for a memorable experience.To beat the crowds:1) Buy the tickets online2) Go see it early at 09:40 , it opens at 10, or after 5 p.m.To get a glimpse of it, you can enjoy a cup of coffee at the downstairs bar, which also has a first floor terrace(within the house)Gaudi was given free hand when designing this architecture wonder. First he broke a set of rules for the building in the squares of the new Expansion(Eixample) District:The building was to be build at a straight angleIt wasn't supposed to be this highThe roof was not supposed to have the nice ventilation and Starship troopers shaped chimneys.It was revolutionary, the facade didn't have a supporting role, this was done by the columns that were incorporated in the building, it had interchangeable walls since the walls didn't act as weigh bearing structures.the ground Floor was inhabited by the Millas , they had a monumental staircase and the rest of the building designed for the tenants(now the rent is 16000 euros and a big waiting list) had an elevator.The Millas which commisioned Gaudi didn't like the building, and because of his extravagant style he piled up a set of fines for not taken into account the rules for building, they decided to pay Gaudi less than previously agreed(The Name Pedrera- means stone quarry). Gaudi filled a lawsuit won and then donated the money to a convent.Misses Mila waited for Gaudi to die than sells the furniture designed by him and replaced it with a more classical one.
Cool. We saw this building wile we were having a sightseeing bus tour and its also very cool place. It was an amazing place from the outside view.

One the the most unique buildings in the world.. Barcelona is famous for it's architecture and this is one of its jewels,. Even the roof is cool! A must see and part of many tours so please do not miss.

Great for Learning about Gaudi. La Pedrera has an iconic rooftop and an amazing entrance. For me the best part is actually the museum in the attic because it gives newbies a great overview of Gaudi, his life and work, and is a good preparation for visiting the other main Gaudi sites in the city. Of two main houses to tour (La Pedrera and Casa Battlo, which is right down the street) I put my money on Casa Battlo. La Pedrera is certainly wonderful however but touring the Casa Battlo is superior to the apartment tour that La Pedrera offers, but La Pedrera may be more interesting for aspiring architects since he designed the entire structure.There is a good museum space on the primary floor which is run separately from the house tour. They often have interesting exhibits going on so you may want to check it out when you're there.
Gaudi fan delight.. This is right across the road from Casa Battlo. And, both are situated on Passeig de Gracia (the best quality shopping in Barcelona). Do both in the one day.

One of Gaudi's Most Stunning Creations, Fascinating Detail from Top to Bottom. Take a guided tour if you can for some fascinating insights into the history and creation of this iconic building, along with a look in the courtyard/lightwells, attic and on the roof.

Don't leave Barcelona without seeing LA Pedrera!. Amazing architectural wonder! Gaudi was ahead of his time with the way he designed this condo in the main streets of Barcelona.All the details and materials are incredible. Check the roof top to see a nice view of the city along with the amazing sculptures adorning the area. Not to be missed!

Well worth a visit but a little expensive. We both really enjoyed exploring this iconic building. The audio and information boards throughout were excellent. We spent a good hour and a half looking around. You do need to be fairly fit and ok on your feet as the roof is of course on different levels and there are lots of steps. The only reason for 4 not 5 stars is I thought it was a little expensive and also the staff a little unfriendly the lady giving out the audio set made it very clear she did not want me to take a written guide as well which I wanted for my scrapbook and at the entrance price I thought this was a little off.

If you only have time for one, make it this one.. This is probably the most typical example of Gaudi's residential buildings in the city of Barcelona. It is the most visited too, so be advised and plan your visit. It will not disappoint you. You can visit it in the day or at night as there are also night visits possible. The tour is very well planned and you can make it at your own pace although it gets very crowded around touristic periods of the year. Casa Battlio is also just around the corner.

Great views. I love the chimneys, the view is great, Gaudi is a genius. The exhibition explaining his technique for designing the arches is fascinating. When we visited we found that this was the least busy which meant we could take our time. I really enjoyed it.
A Gaudi creation. A wonderful example of Gaudi's work. Very imaginative. There are pieces of his work in numerous locations.

romantic building in Jules Verne style!. I first saw it in 2011 and then again in my later visits. It is again an hymn of love for the sea, at least that's how I saw it. It is like a dream come true and everyone should see it at least once in their lifetime. It's true that currently, the ticket price is a bit higher but at least you know that with thet money you support European culture not the Isis forces. If you are a pretentious tourist, you can see and read all the small notes and it will be like a very pleasant lesson at school. The greatest reward you can get is to see the sunset from the amazing stone terrace, not to mention if you have someone dear beside you. All in all, the colours and shapes made me dream with open eyes. It is indeed a declaration of love for Spain...again, from Antoni Gaudi.

Barcelona is so lucky to have the work of Antoni Gaudi. Book and entry time online ahead of time. Try to arrive early in the morning. Restaurants are available in the neighborhood. Don't miss this treasure.

Worth it just for the fantastic rooftop. As with all Gaudi tourist spots, this one come with a high entrance fee. That aside, La Pedrera is a fascinating building which is actually furnished with period furniture (unlike Casa Batlla). The highlight of the visit here was the rooftop, with its strange & wonderful stone forms. If you book the ticket online, the audio guide is included which provided interesting commentary on the building.

Superb. This is another masterpiece by Gaudi, he was so ahead of his time. The tickets. Are expensive , i omly went day one however when i visit there avain I would defo see it at night with all the colours on tje stones and surrounding music etc
Views from the roof top amazing. After seeing Gaudi's other house was surprised that this was apartments but again his designs were before his time!

Fascinating place, night tour less so. Since there are so many reviews of the house itself, this review is just about the night visit, if you're wondering whether it's worth the extra cost. The night visit does allow you to see the entry hall with late evening and night lighting, which deepens the colors and heightens some of the shapes. The tour consists of a quick introduction in the entrance, a quick visit to the attic, and then a sound and light show on the roof, followed by a glass of cava. The sound and light show is cheesy, to put it mildly. The theme is life on this planet and it starts with images of space, then volcanoes, on through the development of humans, war, and then back to abstracts. Kids might enjoy it, despite the cheesiness, because it's very noisy and colorful. (There is a brief, not-eroticized image of a topless woman in the section on the rise of human life, if that would be a concern.) It's projected onto the chimneys and air vents, but doesn't really add anything to them, I found. So if you're mostly interested in Gaudi, but not so interested that a chance to see some parts of the building at with night lighting is worth it, you can probably skip the night ticket.

Origin furniture and nice roof. In this building, beside the details you see at Casa Batllo about arhitecture, you can also see some furniture from 1900.There are more colors in here and seem a little bit bigger to me.You don't have to book your visit but you can get better rates online.

An incredible place designed by a genius ahead of his time. There really is no way to describe this unique place designed by Gaudi' 100 years ago.Pictures cannot do any justice to all the details involved in this building.You must make a stop next time in Barcelona. It will be worth your time and money.

another masterpiece. Some travelers pick either one of the two, La Pedrera or Casa Battlo, but really if you have time and luxury, visit La Pedrera too! It is worth the visit seeing the apartment. All the little details are wonderful, and of course the rooftop is nothing like I've ever seen before. Gaudi is really a genius, because it seems like nothing is made randomly but with a purpose!

One of Gaudi's masterpieces - well worth it!. This includes an exhibition of Gaudi's life and work as well as a tour of the roof and top floor apartment. Definitely a must for any visitor to Barcelona! We visited really in the day when it was still quiet.

A must see in Barcelona. An icon of architecture. The visit allows you to enter in most rooms (the building is inhabited). A prominent place is the terrace. Do not forget your camera. There are audio guides in several languages.
Rooftop Gorgeous at Sunset. La Pedrera ia a luxurious home Gaudi designed for the Mila family. The building looks organic and curved. We particularly enjoyed the rooftop at sunset.
Not the best Gaudi. I loved all the Gaudi spots but this is the one to skip. The roof is pretty spectacular but Park Guell, Sagrada Familia, and Casa Batllo are all more impressive.

Nice view at the top and interesting museum . We choose to visit the casa mila over the casa battlo because of the view and the cool rooftop and we didn't regret our choice. I never been to casa battlo, so I can't tell what's best of these two, but we did really enjoy this museum.

Casa Milà " ‘La Pedrera’. - La Pedrera (1905) meaning the 'The Quarry' is the last civil work designed by Antoni Gaudí and was designed as a fashionable home to the wealthy Milà family.- La Pedrera is located at No 92 Passeig de Gràcia at the junction with Carrer Provenca. Opened: - Monday to Friday: from 9 am to 10 pm. Saturdays, Sundays and holidays: from 10 am to 2 pm and from 6 pm to 10 pm.- Transportation: Metro: L 3 estación Passeig de Gràcia,, and L 5 estación Diagonal.. Barcelona Turistic Bus (Blue Line). - Entrance fees: €20.50 (20% less for Barcelona Card) ... - It is another piece of Art. I like every part of it especially the Façades. The Design represents modernism design. At night it is illuminated with beautiful colors. - All the floors are accessible through lifts for wheel chair visitors, Bravo.- I did not go inside because it was very crowded and the lines were long, added to the expensive fee....!!!!- Enjoy a nice walk in the Passeig de Gràcia and don't forget the Museu Egipci 5 minutes away ...!!!!

Interesting building. The information offered about Gaudi and his works was very interesting. The rooftop offered great views of the city and the rooftop statues were very interesting to look at. The apartment was beautifully recreated and it was fascinating to see how Gaudi designed the building to get the most out of the natural light and to make great use of the space.

Intersting to see.. Went to see all the Gaudi buildings but only went inside this one. Slightly expensive but very interesting. Given an audio guide so you can look around at your own pace. The rooftop was amazing and the best bit. Brought some photos at the end as not badly priced.
A go to in Barcelona. If you want to see and feel how someone plays with the idea of rounding everything. Plus to see the genius of Gaudi.
Stunning. Amazing! This was one of my favorite places while in Barcelona. This spot cannot be beat. We are looking forward to going again!

Get ready.... This is the biggest of the Gaudi apartment buildings open to the public. Well it's partially open, as some of it is still occupied with resident/commercial tenants. It's big and bodacious. I found the famous roof area to be a bit unnerving as it brought out the worst in my fear of heights, but it was worth the battle to have the experience. A must see if you visit Barcelona.
Interesting to see. We did not go in our to the rooftop. The lines are long. The style is not for everyone but is work going to see.

Wow!. A must-see while you're in Barcelona. This building is unlike any apartment building that exists today, back then, or anything we'll see in the future! This building seems to only exist in a fantasy...or at least in the beautiful city of Barcelona.
An enjoyable building. An enjoyable building to visit. The architecture is superb.My only complain is the audio service provided, dated. Anyway, it is worth to go.

Great example of Gaudi's work and a well organized tour. Easily accessible on Passeig de Gracia. We booked ahead the priority pass which gives no queuing entry any day/time within 6 months. Probably not essential as we were off season, but worth it for peace of mind. Very interesting tour plus a special exhibit. WOrth the entry fee and a must see in Barcelona.must see

Go Inside!!. We had read some reviews on this place and weren't quit sold on paying to go inside (even when we arrived we didn't really think it was worth it to pay) BUT we are so glad we did!! This was a very organized tour that gave so much information. The view to start with from the roof is AMAZING! the construction and design is just cool!! Then it takes you inside to learn all about the designer. Then you visit an apartment that is furnished with replicas of what they used to live like. It was great and so enjoyable!It was one of our favorite attractions in Barcelona.

Book in Advance - A must see when in Barcelona for Antonio Gaudi fans. This building was beautiful with works of Antonio Gaudi. I strongly suggest buying your entry ticket in advance to not be disappointed. Before you go up to the roof to check out the chimneys, look straight up and see the inside of the apartment. Once on the room look down. Great views! The chimneys on the roof are very interesting and a great view of the city from the roof top. Do not pass this by it is well worth a few hours of your day!

Better of the Two Houses. I liked the terrace and the attic area. There is a good exhibition on Gaudi and his works. The house is bigger than Batllo and if you do not have time, I would go to the Pedrera.

Amazing Gaudi who never fails to impress.. The colour, the rounded shape. called the quarry by the locals, Casa Milà stands out without effort. It has a natural ventilation system and Gaudi even made provision for a lift although that wasn't added until later. What a genius.
City tour highlight. Again, Dolca, our guide was able to impress us with her overwhelming knowledge of her city. This was a must see.

A MUST GO!!. Beautiful modernist building. Deff a must go in Barcelona, so you can appreciate modernist architecture at its sublime point. The whole building flows along with its furniture inside, its really a dream!! Plus the staff is very friendly.

Definitely Worth It!. We went to La Pedrera right after seeing Gaudi's Sagrada Familia. It is a little pricey so we hesitated about visiting this other Gaudi building. I'm glad we did. The entrance fee included an audio guide which was really informative. The ticket also included entry to the museum housed in the building. I believe this exhibit changes but when we went it was basically a display of art nouveau items and their history. It was beautiful and fascinating. The rooftop is worth the entry fee itself! This is an iconic building and a must-see!
Nice souvenir shop. We didn't go in the house but rather only the gift shop which was one of the good ones and I accidentally stayed for over an hour looking through all their books.

AMust see in Bacelona. Absolutely a do not miss site of Barcelona. Using of the hop on hop off bus makes this place and another half dozen places easy and inexpensive to get to. This place is not only magical but rivals anything at Disneyland. I was in awe of the creative genius of Gaudi.

Visit the rooftop!. The building is quite lovely but the highlight is definitely the rooftop! It's just amazing. There was a free exhibition on Modernisme at the time of my visit on the first floor, which was also very interesting.I purchased my ticket online, which I would recommend. Again, an audioguide is included.Be sure to return to the building to see the facade lit up after dark.

Worth it!. Obviously Sagrada Familia is a must see, but honestly, one Gaudi masterpiece isn't enough. La Pedrera not only offers in depth coverage of the building and its architect, but the exhibits also cover other Gaudi works throughout the city (including a short video tour of Casa Batlló). Gaudi is a genius!The rooftop was spectacular and I could have easily spent more time in the sun overlooking the city (and the chimneys and vents which inspired the Stormtrooper helmets in Star Wars). I was skeptical at first about paying money to go inside the building, but it was worth it! The audioguide (included in the ticket price) and the exhibits really added to the visit. It took about 2+ hours (spent a lot of time on the roof) during the day. My audioguide battery died when I reached the apartments, but one of the staff quickly switched it out for me. If you have the time to visit more than one Gaudi masterpiece while visiting Barcelona, put this on your list.

my favorite Gaudy. lots of forms and large building but it seems most complete Barcelona's Gaudy projects. it has great presence on the Blvd. one of those projects that seems work well functionally as well as highly decorative.

nice, but for the price?. nice architecture, especially all the chimneys on the topthis was the most expensive attraction we've seen in Barcelona and among others we visited sagrada familia, casa batllo, camp nou, park guel and I like all mentioned more

Loved it BUT. Wouldn't do both day and night.Absolutely loved it during the day. The audioguide was great and being able to move at your own pace is great. The night tour was also good on its own. Not as detailed as the audio guide but the guide was great and good at answering questions. The light show was awesome.Felt that by doing both day and night tour I didn't learn anything new at night and was just paying for the light show. Which although is great it isn't worth the much steeper price. If I could go back I would only do the day tour.

Aother Gaudi Master piece. This is the place for Architect lovers, students or just interested in Gaudi. One of his Masterpieces, with great exhibit inside, showing Gaudi working tools.Take the audio guide and dive in Old Barcelona walking for almost one hour thru the different floors and ambient of this magnificent house.
Another must see place. Very unassuming but once you see it you understand the brilliance of Gaudi's work. Book online in advance. Very well preserved. an architect's candyland!

Visiting BCN for the day. Incredible to see it. Not only in books, as well as in real. Make sure you also see it at night, with all the lights on. Remember to read a bit before you go. So you can understand why of those shapes and the tops of the roof....

Star Wars inspiration!?. Love learning the story behind the building of Casa Mila - even without going inside - the charm of the backstory entrances. there are often shows/exhibitions - a light exibition - was on at the time we visited which are rumoured to be brilliant to view!

Interesting building. I loved this building. The art and history are very interesting.I would highly recommend the night tour, the tour guide was brilliant. Do add on the €3 to do the day audio tour visit along with it, both tours complete the experience.When looking back on my visit, I would not just do the day visit on its own, it wouldn't be worth the 20 or so euro that you pay, so do both or just night tour.You can do both tours on separate days as well, you can fiddle around with the days on the website when booking online, I accidently noticed that when booking tickets. Just adding this comment incase someone didn't notice this and it doesn't suit them to do on the same day!
La Pedrera. I didn't enter in La Pedrera, but you can see how nice is the place just looking outside. It's beautiful and with a lot of details. It's near to the subway and Casa Batllo.

Informative and Interesting. We hesitated about going into La Pedrera and wondered whether it would be worth the money. A man coming out urged us to go and visit and we are very glad we took his advice. The audio tour was so informative and we learned so much about Gaudi and his inspirations for his work - what a genius! The rooftop, inside and out was amazing and the views across Barcelona, quite spectacular. Visiting in November meant there were no queues but I imagine at the height of the season you would be better booking online.

Spectacular. Excellent tour with informative audio. Book online to avoid queues. Learnt such a lot about Gaudi and the architecture. The rooftop is the jewel in the crown and views across Barcelona are excellent.
Better than expected. Amazing views from roof and you get to walk they an apartment and how it used to look. Interesting exhibitions. Well worth it
Very unique. We had the opportunity to view this building as we were on a tour with Barcelona Day Tours. The unique architecture makes this worth a visit.
Interesting but not a Wow. I expected more from this tour, but somehow it didn't impress me that much. Just seeing the building from the outside would be enough.
outside. Personally I think the outside is more worth looking at than going inside. Depends on what you like.

The rooftop makes it worth the visit. Not all of this building is available to the public as people live and work here. However, what you can see is very interesting and the rooftop chimneys/air vents make the whole experience worthwhile. Informative audio guide and extensive gift shops too.
More Gaudi. This apartment building by Gaudi is interesting for its architecture and worth the time to visit. Buying tickets online and avoiding the wait is well worthwhile.
Very interesting architecture. Good tour to do before the Basilica of the Sagrada Familia, we learned A TON about Gaudi, really interesting.
Great architecture!. Everything Gaudi built is spectacular. La casa Pedrera is no exception. The view of Barcelona from the roof is spectacular. A must see for every architecture aficionado.

Casa Mila Barcelone. House where architect Antonio Gaudi leaves ; it's all Art Nouveau and realy nice to visit
i see it only from the boulevard.;

I developed a real appreciation for Gaudi after visiting Casa Mila (La Pedrera). At first I thought his designs were whimsical and out-there but after I took the night tour (with the light show on the roof), I did develop an appreciation for his designs. Once you know what to look for in his designs (nature) - you see it everywhere.
Beautiful. Our experience was merely from looking at the building from the outside. The architecture of Barcelona is stunning and the Gaudi influence is everywhere. Kind of other worldly.

Incredible architecture!. Loved the architecture and design of this building. Unfortunately, we did not go inside but we did see it from the outside several times. Our schedule was quite packed this trip, hopefully we can go inside next time.

Integrated design. You get to see how well Gaudi established functionality in his designs: they weren't just about looking different and interesting, they provided daily convenience, energy efficiency and thoughtful traffic flows to the inhabitants. Man, what he could have done with LED lighting, modern glazing systems and aluminum building products!!! The roof's fun, the design museum in the attic is extremely insightful, the apartment would have been very comfortable. Yes, this building worked for its inhabitants, didn't need the very beautiful artisan decoration of Lleo i Morera or Palau Güell or Batllo or Amatller--they were extras to his fabulous designs for living, which you see in this building.

Marvellous!. Casa Milà, also known as La Pedrera, was a modernist building in Barcelona. It was the last civil work designed by Antoni Gaudí, built from the year 1906 to 1910. It was an innovative project, with a self-supporting stone front and columns, and floors free of load bearing walls. This connected to the internal structure of each floor by means of curved iron beams surrounding the perimeter of each floor. Such constructed technique would allow free structuring of the different levels, so that all walls could be demolished without affecting the stability of the building. The owners then might modify the interior layout at will.Pere Milà, a developer, bought a house and hired Gaudí to design his new home. After the work completed in 1910, Pere Milà and his wife, Roser Segimon moved in a year later until Segimon’s death in 1964. Gaudí allowed them to rent out the other floors. The building changed hands/management several times and underwent several repairs/restorations. On July 24, 1969, Gaudí's work received official recognition as a historic-artistic Monument. In 1984, UNESCO declared it a World Heritage Site. Gaudí conceived of this house as a constant curve, both outside and inside, incorporating multiple solutions of formal geometry and elements of a naturalistic nature. Casa Milà actually comprised of two buildings around two courtyards and had nine levels: basement, ground floor, mezzanine, main/noble floor, four upper floors, and an attic. The basement was designed as a garage, at that time, was an innovative idea. The main floor was the residence of the Milàs. The rest, over 20 homes in total, was for rent. The layout was like an asymmetrical "8". The attic housed the laundry and drying areas, forming an insulating space for the building and establishing levels of the roof. The roof, topped with skylights, staircase exits, fans, and chimneys. Fabricated with tumbrel coated with limestone, broken marble or glass, the design of the roof not only carried a unique architectural purpose also displayed well-integrated (into the building) sculptures.When we visited this building, the roof indeed was the area we took most pictures. “Noble floor” looked modest by today’s standard. In addition, the “waving shape” of the whole structure made us marveled by the genius/creative idea of Gaudí.
La Pedrera, Casa Mila. A most see when in Barcelona. The architecture is amazing and when you go the the roof you will be amazed yet again.

Amazing looking building both on the Roof and Outside!. The outside of the building is amazing, mimicing ocean waves and seaweed. The courtyard and roof are also pretty magical. The apartment was a little disappointing to me. They just look like normal rooms witih traditional furnitures. It is worth a visit, but I thought the outside was by far the best part.
Magical. This place is awe-inspiring. Could easily have spent a whole day in there. Will definitely revisit on my next trip.
La Pedrera Barcelona. This is a beautiful place, a should see. The architecture is so very different yet adds beauty to the structure. Why can't all building be this unique.

When visiting other Gaudi constructions, it will get 'under your skin' so La Pedrera' is a must!. Almost like a pilgrimage to the great architect, once you have visited a few of his other works, La Pedrera' is an absolute must. Just stand outside and soak up the unique shapes of the facade. Once inside marvel how Gaudi engineered the structure to allow natural light to flood the two entrance-ways. You will eventually end up in the shop, no bad thing as they have some great things on offer. Recommended.

Well worth a visit. On a previous visit to Barcelona we had visited Casa Batllo which we really enjoyed, so this time we went to La Pedrera.You start the tour by taking a lift to the roof of La Pedrera. The roof itself is interesting with its different levels and structures - and the views across the city are spectacular.You then go down to the attic where there is an exhibition on Gaudi and his architecture.You then walk down the stairs to one of the apartments which is laid out as it would have been lived in originally - and how envious we felt as we walked down the staircase passing the apartments that are still lived in today! What a place to live in!There's a shop on the same level as the apartment you can visit as well as somebody who takes your photo which is then superimposed onto three different backdrops - there's no obligation to buy them (it's 10 euros for two). We didn't buy them.You then carry on down to where there was an additional exhibition on show at the time we visited (November 2015) and another, larger, shop before leaving La Pedrera.We had the audio accompaniment for the tour and you have to look out for the relevant number to listen to an explanation of where you are in the building - sometimes the numbers weren't easy to spot so we had to backtrack to get back to the right place.On the whole, I would say we enjoyed Casa Batllo more as La Pedrera wasn't as vibrant and colourful but we still had a really good visit to La Pedrera.

Batllò house is better, but this is ok too. If you can only enter one of the two houses (Milà and Batllo'), you should definitely visit the Batllo' one. The Pedrera House is very beautiful to see from outside, but I expected to see much more things inside than what I saw.
great visit. one of the highlights of our visit to Barcelona, you get the elevator to the top and work your way down the landings, a must for visiting

Most Enchanting At Night!. In general I prefer Casa Batllo to La Pedrera -- I find it more intimate and charming, despite the lack of furnishings. Today just did a "day/night" ticket, however: visited in the morning and saw the beautiful rooftop in the sun and enjoyed our trip, but then visited again at night when the building was much more enchanting. The same courtyards look much more beautiful and mysterious at night, the light show on the rooftop was impressive (as was the nighttime view down over the Passeig de Gracia), and touring in a small group (there were probably only 10 of us?) was much more intimate than the crowds during the day. I also enjoyed the contrast between the day and night visits -- glad to have done them both. (The combo ticket is also a considerable savings over purchasing separately.)

A Must!. Amazing! Well worth the time. Went before the visit to the Sagrada Familia and helped to understand the Gaudi experience. Utilize online ticketing to avoid lines. Wish we also had time to visite the Gaudi Gardens.

Expensive light show. They make you go 7 floors by the staircase when there is nothing to see. The guide was not qualified in the art-nouveau architecture.The combination light show with the diner at night is to expensive. After the 3 courses I was hungry.

Pricey but worth it. Right close to downtown and easy walking distance from many hotels, this is a must see stop in Barcelona. Its a bit on the pricey side but at the same time its way neat to see. Be sure and buy your tickets online ahead of time and you'll get to skip the long lines. Plan on a minimum of one hour, maybe a bit more to see it all.

Don't bother going inside. A stunning Gaudi building from the outside, but one of the most expensive destinations in the City and really disappointing inside.You can only see a small apartment, basically furnished, the roof structure (interesting for a short while) and the totem pole chimneys on the roof. Very touristy. Very dissapointing

Last one to serve!But first one to come in!. Rude staff!!! bad manners, they just want you out of there. we get first and they take us last... because we order just coffee. What a bad experience.
1* is for the location the staff deserve 0

Interesting perspective. It's a great place to visit to see the work of Gaudi, and to have an overview of what life was for wealthy families. If you want to be flexible and not very tight on budget, i would suggest purchase an all-day ticket in advance on the website, that will allow you to enter at your own convenience time and skip all queues.

Gaudi's finest, a must see!. This remarkable edifice is an excellent deal, because not only will the view of the roof knock your socks off, but the interior rooms and attic are extraordinary to see, and the excellent audio that comes with price of admission (15eu) will tell you everything you want to know about Gaudi and how he created the dazzling structures he did. Then you must go to Guell Park!

Gaudi again. This is supposed to be the most representative art of Gaudi, but I find it rather dull. I strongly recomend you take a look across the street from it, and see another building by him which, in my oppinion, shouws his true colours as an artist

Unbelievable!. If you only have time to see it from the outside - do. There's an upscale cafe on the ground floor that was nice. However, if you have the time, go for the full entry. You go up to the roof where the views are fantastic and the roof itself is incredible with all its Gaudi-ness. Then you go down into the attic area which I really enjoyed - lots of models showing and explaining the construction of the attic and roof. Then you go down one floor to one of the apartments that has been maintained and furnished as a turn-of-the-century family dwelling and that was wonderful too. Really enjoyed this.
Another wonderful building. We only viewed from the outside but this is another impressive Gaudi building in Barcelona. On the list for a better look next visit

Gaudi at his best. Amazing work of architecture made by genius Gaudi. Place where you can see how Barcelona's rich people used to live (and envy them). Enjoy looking over Barcelona's roof toops from the roof of La Pedrera which is work of art. We hav bought VIP ticket and therefore did not wait in the line and were taken to the lift immediately upon entrance. I recommend this service.

It is just beautiful. I went to La Pedrera a couple of weeks ago and I just loved it. It is more beutiful than what you can actually see in the pictures! I can't wait to go back to Barcelona next spring!
One of Gaudi's must see. Other than Parc Guell and Sagrada Familia, this is the only other place I visited.What a beautiful mind to think of all the intricate details and turning function to art.
nothing special. If I come to Barcelona one more time I won't be going back here because this isn't anything special and is similar to Casa Batllo
Another masterpiece of Gaudi. What can I say? It's Gaudi and therefore amazing. The rooftop is simply spectacular, you must go up and have a look. Queues are long but worth the wait. Really cool!

Sorry to go against the grain. I felt this was disappointing. Entrance tickets were 20 euro and we were there an hour. The views are ok and there is a little history about the place, some rooms with beautiful floors are furnished to show how it would have looked, you then go into a gift shop where the heating is on to such an unbearable extent you feel you are in a sauna and about to pass out, and then it's over. Sorry, but it was not worth the admission in my opinion, but I would like to go back and see the exhibition (available at 3 euro separately) which did look interesting and we did not have time for.
Fantastic. Gaudi was a genius! This house is something that you can loose, take YOUR time and discover every particular
Knights on Top. Gaudi's "the Quarry", is a modernista building based on a wavy facade. It isa beautifully designed building capped by chimney's resembling knights.

uniquely beautiful even only from the outside. We didn't have the chance to visit the inside even though we would like to, but even from the outside it was such an amazing architectural piece. love it!

Gaudi does it again.. I really did enjoy this place, luckily there wasn't much of a line but I would always recommend getting tickets online. The building was very unique inside, you get to walk through the whole complex seeing the living quarters which are inside and see how it looks within. But clearly the best part by far is the rooftop which the chimneys. Then Gaudi did something genius in which each corner you can see a loop through and see Gaudis work around the city.
Beautiful!. Walked here from the Catalunya square. Beautiful building to see, never went in unfortunately. At night it was great to see too!

Yet another amazing piece of Gaudi architecture. I thoroughly enjoyed my visit and would recommend it to anyone.Frankly, I'm at a loss to understand how anyone would not enjoy visiting this amazing, fabulous building. It was expensive but it must take a huge amount of upkeep. Admittedly the architecture and decor may not be to everyone's taste, but it's definitely worth seeing if you can afford the time and money to visit. Like Casa Batllo and Palau Guell, the roof is fantastic, but be aware that it may be closed off if you visit when it's wet. The coffee shop is lovely too - make sure you go upstairs as there's a great view of the atrium.

Don't miss!. Second only to La Segrada Familia, this Gaudi designed apartment building in the center of the city is one of Barcelona's highlights. It was named Casa Milio after one of the financiers, but the people called it La Perdrera, or "the stone quarry", which stuck, because the stone for the building was cut in the street. Order your tickets on line and have them delivered to your smart phone so you don't have to stand in line. Get the audio tour. You will start at the top of the building with it's Darth Vader chimneys and marvelous views of the city. You will then go down one floor to the laundry where the museum is located and the details of the building are explained. You then will walk down stairs to see one of the apartments decorated in elements of the era. It is gorgeous. When you get back to the ground floor you will exit thru the gift shop. Check it out; it is one of the best in town.
Another fantastic art noveau building. A stunning Gaudi that is right on Passeig de Gràcia with easy access to hop on hop off or just walking in the area.
Aoartment from the 20's. More Gaudi to see. This is an apartment building, unique and one of a kind. You'll love the spacious rooms!
the best Gaudi building for a visit.. Plan your trip at the end of the day and enjoy the great view at night at the roof. Buy online tickets to avoid queing,

Fabulous architecture. It's a very peculiar building the façade of which reminds a bit the waves that can be seen in big masses of water. It can be said that everything in it is irregular as compared to the average constructions. The interior, especially the ceilings, are in line with the outer part of the building and it is worth being visited. Once there was a boarding house on the first floor going in through a side entrance in calle Provenza, there where there is now an office appertaining to the autonomous administration of Catalonia. The undersigned stayed there at the beginning of October 1965.

Magnificent Rooftop. Visited this magnificent apartment while I was staying in Barcelona. Anton Gaudi's last work before he spent the rest of his life at the Segrada is well worth a visit. The guidebook I read said, "the artwork down to the door knobs is magical" and I agree. Spend the money and do not miss this masterpiece. Great picture opportunities especially on the rooftop.
Wow!. We happened upon it while walking and were immediately struck by its beauty. We did not visit the interior.

Would love to have seen the rooftop.. We only saw in from the road. There is a restaurant with the same name, with beautiful vavey ceiling. One needs a least week to see Barcelona. Another time for sure!

Another Gaudi masterpiece!. This is certainly a stunning building both in terms of its architecture and situation. The views from the roof terrace are fantastic. Being able to wander at leisure through the "attic" and an apartment was a real treat and the standard of displays and videos was excellent. An audio guide is provided free with the admission ticket and this is very informative. On entry one is required to put bags through a scanner, a bit like airport security, but if like me you happen to be carrying an unacceptable object it is simply removed, a numbered tag issued and then the item is collected on departure.

The genius that was Gaudi. Used a voucher to enter which took price down to 18 euro. Still a bit steep but it is in line with other Barcelona attractions. The inner courtyard is interesting with a very organic feel. A lift takes us up to the roof. This is fantastically designed with ingenious use of shapes put to practical effect as chimneys arches and doorways. I visited as sun was setting so the light was excellent for photos. The views over Barcelona were very good. The attic below has diagrams of how gaudi built the house. It's fully supported by the external structure. The audio guide gave a wonderful quote. Gaudis professor said upon giving a degree to gaudi " I don't know if I am giving this degree to a genius or a madman ". Sums up the house entirely. And all his works. The top floor is preserved as a museum with living quarters of past residents still intact. The lower floors remarkably are still inhabited. I thoroughly enjoyed my visit but as an enthusiast photographer I am perhaps biased. But I count it as one of the better attractions in Barcelona.

Gaudi building. The first time I saw this building I did not know the story behind it. The second time I came here I heard the story and the building takes on a whole new concept and meaning. It is amazing the artwork put into the Gaudi buildings. Well worth the time.
Another Gaudi gem. Visited in the evening when it had quietened down, but still extremely busy. You can't help but marvel at this architectural masterpiece of Gaudi.

Must see for Gaudi fans. Don’t miss this great building if you are a fan of Gaudi. In fact, our intel was that this was a much better value for your money than Casa Batlo which has little inside of it. The architecture of course is unique and superb. There are a few Gaudi furniture pieces and furnishings contemporary with the original apartment dwellers. Worth the trip.

Wonderful Gaudi building. Great architectural, historical building to visit. Especially the roof top and the views of the city. Probably not for you if you don't like heights. Loved the inner courtyard, the apartment, attic and rooftop. Audio tour was very good giving plenty of information. Unusual shaped building from outside. Good souvenir shop shop.

A Fascinating Work of Gaudi's Maturity. Gaudi designed this amazing apartment building from scratch. It is one of his later works. It is notable for its structure of stone, brick & metal beams that carry the load bearing functions. Interior partitions can be removed without affecting the structure of the building - a revolutionary concept in its day. This building has an underground car park & winding ramp from the front door through the vestibule - another first! The facade is undulating curves both inside & out. The intricate wrought iron railings are magical. The building is light filled and contains a myriad of fascinating ornamental detail from the mural paintings in the vestibule to the details of the carved doors & especially moulded door handles. The chimneys on the roof with tops like helmets are a fantastic & iconic feature of the building, clearly visible from the street. The audio guide is good.
Amazing. Amazing Gaudi building. A must visit. Beautiful architecture. You have to pay to go in and it is very crowded.

A GAUDI GEM AND MUST SEE. Normally a long line to purchase tickets but on this last Sunday in October and late in the afternoon we were able to purchase tickets (20 euros each) for the self-guided cassette tour after only a few minutes wait. The living nature at the heart of the building proves to be the iconic gem of this brilliant architect. Designed around a circular courtyard the apartment on the fourth floor recreates how a well-off Catalonian family lived in the early 20th century.
