It was right in the shopping district, so a bit of a no-brainer to go. An interesting building, with unique architecture and design, but not really my thing. I went through in 30 mins, but I think most people take about 60.
Worth it! . It's amazing!!! the art within this house is unbelievable. The only thing I didn't like is the audio guide I was kind of lost everywhere but besides that, it was great.

Classical Guitar on the Rooftop. I attended a classical guitar performance on the rooftop of this building as the sun was setting and champagne in my hand. The music was grand, the setting exquisite, the view breathtaking. A very memorable experience!

Don't miss that rooftop. This is worth visiting for the surreal rooftop. If you are a Gaudi fan you should definitely go. I think it is one of the better Gaudi monuments - second perhaps to Sagrada Familia
Interesting, but overpriced. You get an audio guide which is helpful, there is a lot to see and some very impressive designs. Reminded me a bit of Dr Suess and Tim Burton creations.
Include on a walking tour of city. Excellent if you are looking for different buildings to see the unusual architecture of Barcelona. Book ahead as the queues are rather long.

Good visit if you have time. We booked our tickets in advance but found the queue in the mornings to be fairly small anyway. We spent about an hour here in total and it was interesting to see but not as visually impressive as Casa Batllo.
Impressive but not like Gaudi's other work.. Impressive but not like Gaudi's other work in Barcelona, can be avoided or seen from outside if pressed on time.

Unsure. La Pedrera...the exterior is of course beautiful. I'm not sure how i would rate this of we were able to go in. The queue was so long that we gave up easily. But then again we enjoyed just walking about Passeig de Gracia.

Impressive but over priced . Gaudi's work is amazing, and I particularly like the way he combines eye catching design with incredible functionality. In many ways he was years ahead of his time. The tour with audio guide is ok, basic information, but a little unclear where to go next at times, or when to press the next number. Overall the house and views would score a 5, but I particularly dislike being forced to make a "donation" to support good causes. I prefer to donate money to causes that I believe are worth while, rather than be forced to pay double what you would pay for sights in other cities (and I have seen many sights that would rival this in many cities). Hence overall a 3 - if you can avoid it, then do it in the knowledge that you are paying over the odds to support their choice of good causes (looking from outside does not give you any real appreciation of it).

Incredible architecture -go late in the day to avoid the lines. If one has any interest in the work of Gaudi a visit to La Pedrera is a must. Admission (which is not inexpensive) includes a helpful audio guide. The visit to the rooftop terrace is worth the visit alone though there are also several more floors to see. We arrived at 7:15 p.m. and there was no one else in line. The last visitor is admitted at 7:30 and the building closes at 8:30. This gave us enough time to visit La Pedrera.

Stunning Building. This building was absolutely stunning. went by one afternoon and the queue was massive, went back next day and queue was non existent. foyer was really beautiful but the roof is something else. sagrada famillia beautifully framed through once of the arches. steep entry price but well worth it
beautiful. A lot of info on gaudi and very beautiful!amazing views of the city and very easy to understand would highly recommend we paid a little extra and went in VIP,

Great!. You must visit la Pedrera if you are in Barcelona. It's a must! The special fish-desifn of the facade; the incredible work in the walls inside, the magic architecture...is a delight for the senses! Don't miss it!
Amazing. Probably my favorite place we visited. Gaudi really is a genius and a madman. We spent almost an hour just on the roof. We arrived ear;y in the morning and avoided a lot of big crowds.

The quentessintial Gaudi. A must see if you really want to see Gaudi. Allow enough time to see the roof. It is on Paaio de Gracia street, Barcelona high street. So you might want to plan your shopping that same day.
Architecture. Try to come as eraly as possible in order to avoid a lot of tourists, there is also the option the get ticket on-line which helps. There is a nice shop there with tastefull gifts.

Wonderful Views. We booked 'Fast Pass' tickets online, for a few euros more per person, which was well worth the money to skip the queues of people both inside and outside the house. The house was fantastic and the guide very informative and interesting. The roof is the most famous parts of the house and you get fantastic view from up there of the Sagrada Familia. If you have limited time and are not sure which of the Gaudi houses to visit I would recommend Casa Batilo over La Pedrera, but if you can visit both to compare and contrast.

Interesting building. Interesting house with amazing roof. It is well worth a visit, but if you have limited time or money (an adult ticket is 20,5€!), I'd recommend some other Gaudi sites: Casa Batllo, Sagrada Familia and Park Güell.

Not To Be Missed. An important reason to visit Barcelona is to take in the work of Gaudi, and La Pedrera should not be missed. The rooftop alone is worth the ticket price to see the chimneys plus the surrounding neighborhood, including La Sagrada Familia in the distance. Admission also gives you the opportunity to walk through an apartment and view the detail work.

Our favourite . We visited a few Gaudi works whilst in Barcelona and actually enjoyed this the most. But your ticket on line and you can skip the line and go in at your allocated time. There were less crowds than Casa Batllo, and from a personal perspective the apartment was one we could see ourselves living in so the example they had laid out allowed us to get a feel for the design.

wierd artisitc loved it. loved this place. the roof top terrace and the amazing chimneys and views over the city. didn't know much about Gaudi before my trip but I am now a fan. My 12 year old daughter loved it to as would most children just for the amazing roof top. good value . Tip. buy a skip the line pass to save time and go later in the day. I visited around 5pm and managed to take photos without strangers in them!
Impressive. Casa Mila was one of pur favorite places in Barcelona next to parc Guell. Even though it's quite expensive to enter and visit you won't be sorry.

Gaudi's rooftop madness. If you have limited time for Gaudi's buildings, visit Sagrada Familia, then Casa Batllo, then Casa Mila - in that order.Casa Mila is cool, especially the roof, where you can view Sagrada Familia as framed through an arch he made. We cracked up at how many times the word "undulating" was used, but it is an apt description.

Gaudi,Gaudi,Gaudi. Again due to the high entrance fee we only viewed it from the outside which was enough. You can supplement your education of Gaudi through outside sources like the net and texts and ads etc.

Wish I lived here!. The building that bankrupted the wealthiest family in Barcelona at the time ... if only they knew what would become of such an unusual and architecturally unique building. Stunning at night, would highly recommend it!
Mommy and daughter. Excellent! you have to do this it is worth it! beautiful and interesting! buy your tickets online straight from their website!

Get up on the roof - it's amazing!. This is definitely a unique experience - Gaudi was a definitely a one off, some would say genius, some would say goof-ball but all the same the roof area of this landmark offers unforgettable views and unforgettable architecture. La pedrera also offers a courtyard, furnished examples of the apartments that Gaudi designed within the building (and he lived in at one point) and then the loft area (just under the roof terrace) has been transformed into a museum detailing how the building was built with it's unique whalebone construction and lots of other interesting stuff. Not sure if young kids would find it of interest but it's definitely a must-see for anyone 12 and over visiting BarcelonaOh and there's a very nice café / tapas bar at street level for when you're finished too :-)
Luuuv the Gaudí architecture. Stunning building, I cannot get enough of the Gaudi architecture. We visited Casa Mila on the way to Casa Batlló

Gaudi at his best!. I love this building and probably visit it every time I am in Barcelona. The roof is like nothing else. Gaudi had a skill in my opinion and I do not tire of his work and this place.

See the Goofy Roof. When this was designed and built, it must have been the talk of the town. It surely is creative. The tour starts on the roof and that is like no other you have seen. Entrance is unduly expensive, but its uniqueness deserves some cost. I think Battle is better overall if you have only time to see one Gaudi house, but each is worthy.

360 view of Barcelona. I was stuck between visiting this, Casa Batilo and La Sagrada Familia and in the end we chose this one, but we didn't really miss out much on the other two because the guided tour gives you all the information on them. You receive an audio guided tour and walk around the house following the directed route. You get to see a full 360 view of Barcelona from the viewpoint on top of the house. The views were stunning. The architecture as well was incredible. You can go at your own pace because the audio is controlled by you. My mum and I ended up spending 3-4 hours walking round taking in the spectacular surroundings.Definitely a cool place to take pictures of,

Rooftop views and Attic worth the visit. The uniqueness of the attic with the support struts resembling the backbone and ribs of a whale and the walkway around the rooftop for the views of the Barcelona Skyline make this a place to see. The Audio tour adds much to the visit.

Great tour. La pedrera is spectacular building designed by Gaudi. One of the most amazing places in barcelona with walking distance from city centre (20min walk from placa catalunya) Price of ticket €20 includes audio guide, it's worth to buy tickets online if you want to avoid queue. Fantastic view from roof top. Tour will take 1,5 - 2h

Must see in the interior. Exterior and interior are both very must see attraction of Barcelona. Expensive entrance fee, but worst the visite with the magnific roof, "Dartweder statues". The kitchen and the bathroom are also interesting as the technical presentation of the age.

Wonderful rooftop, great attic exhibits, though expensive. The rooftop design by Gaudi was beautiful, artistic, and fun. The attic space is interesting and it has a great explanation of Guadi and his work and how he was considered a genius of geometry. I had always thought he was just artistic but I learned a lot about what an amazing mathematician he was and the level of detail he did. It really added a lot to my understanding and enjoyment of seeing the works of Gaudi all over the city. The apartments themselves were not as artistic and cool as I was expecting. I think it should be about 1/2 the price.

Wonderful place. It is a great place to see the skyline of Barcelona. Its a unique place. The tour starts from the roof. There is an elevator, but if you do not want to wait you can reach it by stairs. The attic is a museum of Gaudi's works and one of the flats remains as a museum. They provide audioguide, do not forget to watch the numbers on the walls.

Nice Architecture and Design. Actually, the ticket price was too expensive so we viewed that building just from outside. I have got no words to explain its architectural beauty. Just go there and have its look.. Really beautiful. But I think the management team of that monument should work on reducing its ticket price.

Disapointing view and light show. This was one of our more disappointing tours in Barcelona for the price of 34 EURO. We did the late night tour expecting this amazing visual light show that exemplifies Gaudi's work but its not that great ....The view of the city is ok but there are other places to do that. The Casa Balto tour of Gaudi's is way better and less expensive.

Closed when I visited!. The front of the building was closed when we visited, but the museum was open, unfortunately we felt it was overpriced, and did not think the experience would be worth the money. I understand it is an icon of Gaudi's style and legacy, but did not impress me at all. Perhaps next time.

All about the rooftop! . The rooftop of this unique building is what it is all about! We went there with a 7 year old child who was entertained jumping up and down all the steps. The architecture and views are (just about) worth the expensive entrance fee!
Gaudi's style.. Very nice design. From Sagrada Familia by walk 20 minutes or from station Sagrada Familia take M-L5 - two stops - get off on Diagonal and then 4 minutes by walk.

Twisty Turny. Gaudi was one of the masters of architecture and his work is sheer poetry. It's wise to book tickets in advance and online, otherwise you will have to stand in line to first buy the ticket and then stand in line to get in - and that's a pretty long wait. Once in, I found the interiors to be just about ok, but what I loved was the rooftop and the attic - that's where the magic is. The forms Gaudi came up with for the room are amazing. Don't miss the attic either - here you will see hundreds of arches that hold up the undulating roof above.

Beautiful rooftop!. I bought Casa Mila day and night ticket. At day, indeed it was very beautiful! You'll be amazed with the architecture, the shape of the chimneys, which look like soldiers, and how Gaudi's vision and calculation when he designed the building. So beautiful. There will be audio guide that will explain you every little thing in Casa Mila. At night, it's more amazing and more beautiful. At the rooftop, the chimneys will be illuminated by special lighting. Make sure you bring your camera when you go there! It's just amazing :) In the end of the tour, I was given a glass of Cava (the famous Spanish sparkling wine), and also some snacks. Nice experience.

quirky arty building. bought tickets online, seemed the best way due to queues outside. this gives you priority entry at any time or day (daytime ticket) it's a bit disorganised inside as we had to ask guide where to start or go. you get audio guide with headphones. with our tickets we had the lift access stright to the roof top. it's busy here with lots of people all trying to get the same photos as you! some people were courteous but others walk into camera shot as you're about to photo family next to the chimneys. our ticket cost 27euros each on the main pedrera website. halfway down they take a photo of you and these are worth it, as it only cost 12 euros for 3 different photo's. you also get an online code to download them as well. highly recommend this to see.
Love inside and outside. The beauty of outside of the house is only a part of this building.The shop stocks very good quality souvenirs.
Style & good food.. Beautiful building designed by Gaudi.The restaurant inside serves good food. The waiters are lovely too.

Should see. It was my first trip to Barcelona with 2 friends that I went to La Pedrera and fell in love with Gaudi once more. You wait a long queue if you are not an early bird, which we were not :) HOwever it is not a killer so we waited and entered the building. From the first moment till the last, I felt like I lived in a dream. It was so genuine and do untouched the decoratiom from the earlier times. I still remember the children's room and the stroller in the room. The roof! Oh the roof is amazing. YOu will feel like you are in a 4D world with all the curves and the shapes you are not used to see in daliy life. Definetely a must see!

Magical. what a beautiful building....Gaudi was a genius....our visit was spur of the moment, thankfully we only had to wait about 15 minutes to get tickets and start the tour...ticket price includes an audio tour device which was very informative....I wish we could have done the night tour, I can only imagine how it would look lite up....loved it...I would say 1 hour will get you through this tour.
A must see!. No trip to Barcelona is complete without a stop here. Like the design or hate it, the interior is amazing. Worth the price of admission and worth the time it takes for the tour.

People always neglect the outside of the house which is as amazing as the insude. +++ You are handed an audioguide, a thing that was not in place back to my first visit to the Casa+++ Visit well organized, you start with the terrasse, and you go downstairs until you reach the ground floor. You cannot get lost, and the circuit is a real trip to the past.--- Expensive if you come with family--- When you enter, they give you a coupon to get a free photo with the house as a background. Once you get your photo, they let you know you have to buy a photo (that costs 10€) and you will get another photo for free (with the Casa Batllo as a background). The trick is that they also suggest a third photo (with the Park Guell as a background), and you can get the three for 12€. At the end, each photo in reality costs 6€Tips: get your ticket online to avoid long lines
Stunning!. This was my second visit. Did not do tour inside as I did it on first visit.Recommend going early morning if you wish to take photos without the tourists!An outstanding building!

A different style by Gaudi. another Gaudi's art work in Barcelona. This building is definitively different than any other house built (especially Casa Battle) but is a multi-appartment building. The roof is impressive, the other rooms more conventional.
Impressive. Another amazing piece of work by Gaudi. A must visit whiles in that area. Each of Gaudi work has a different yet amazing story behind.

Very nice design . It's like a small gem on the corner of the street! We didn't go inside and I think is not necessary the beauty is the facade! This small terrace with hand made iron with very different than usual shapes.Giving one special spirit to the city!

Outstanding site!. The rooftop is amazing as the rest of the building. Be prepared for many steps - every one of them well worth it as the views from the rooftop are the best!! Purchase your tickets online to avoid the wait. Audio tour is included at not extra charge. There is also a restaurant on the ground floor - to the right of the main entrance.

Best of Gaudi'e work!. All throughout Barcelona there are tourist attractions to see the architecture of Gaudi. In my opinion, this is the best one out of his residences to visit. It takes roughly an hour to go through, unless you really spend some time there. Each ticket comes with a free audio guide and walks you though the entire building. The rooftop is of course the best part. With its amazing sculptures and views. In high season, the lines wrap around the building. I suggest purchasing a premiere ticket. It does cost you more but you can come any day, at any time and skip the line. Definitely worth the few extra bucks to be able to relax and not worry about scheduling it at a certain time, and being able to see everyone's face as you stroll by them in line.
Stunning. Amazing art piece... Definitely for someone who knows how to appreciate Gaudi... Impressive, although I am not a fan of Gaudi but I do appreciate his fantastic piece of art.
Must see. Just visit this place, once. And book tickets in advance and schedule 90 timeframe max. Its beautiful and staff is friendly. Has the best Gaudi roof.

It looks good but the evening tour is rushed and annoying. I really look forward to this because I was so interested in the Gaudi concepts and the history of the building . But the staff are terrible , they really are . The building is wonderful , absolutely . Let that do the speaking in future . The tour guide was shocking , absolutely lost herself . She rushed through everything and it was so annoying as I had made the plans months ago , and she had no interest ! The roof is amazing , I loved the skyline the lightshow is fabulous , hence the 3 score . They then give u some wine and then its very , theres the exit door , get out ! The personal touch , the customer service is dire , it really is !
roof top lights. We saw the building at 9 pm for the rooftop chimmney light show. Both the rooftop lights and the informative tour before were well worth it.

Magical architecture . This building is straight out of a fairy tale. Strongly recommend for anyone who in the very slightest enjoys design, architecture, history or just art in general. Admission was a bit expensive at €20 per person, but totally worth it.

Highlight of our trip. This is a must see experience! Try to go early in the day to avoid the crowds.Gaudi's visionary engineering is inspiration, from the outside to the inside to the centre opening to the sky, and the rooftop!! WOW!
Early in the morning no queues. We went without e-ticket early in the morning. No queue at the ticket office and we had a quiet visit.

VIP Entrance. We were in Barcelona for only one day. We hired a driver to take us around the city. While others started their tour around 9 a.m., we got to leave the cruise ship at around 5:30 in the morning. We also managed to get pictures of the sun rising at the beach. This was our 2nd to last stop of the day. We booked the anytime VIP ticket online. All you need is the PDF confirmation saved on your phone because they can scan your reservation for entry that way. You are given headsets for an overview of design. From the private entrance, you are taken to the roof of the building. You can also visit the apartment sections as well. I felt as if I was walking around in a fairy tale book. It was worth the visit and the best part was not having to stand in line or be there at a certain time frame.

You must visit it!!!! <3. Casa Mila is unique! From the outside it's amazing, inside is beautiful but the roof is magnificent!! It offers great views and a lot of fun. It really is something special!!

Genius. Another World Heritage site and you can see why. The visionary Gaudi's last civil engineering work. Originally intended as a family home and apartments for rent. I particularily enjoyed the floral motif murals. The attic provides a glimps of life for the laundry facilities is also displays the genius of the brick arches and Gaudi's genius. Every stunning detail puts the viewer in awe. Highly recommend this.

Lots of information on Gaudis way of working. The main attraction is the roof. It is just amazing. I was also rather impressed by the way the loft was build. There is lots of information on what inspired Gaudi and how he worked.
The appartment is nice too but to mee the loft and the roof is the best part.

Unique . We only looked at the outside since the line was longer than we wanted to go inside. The architecture is very unique. Down the street a few blocks south is another Gaudi building you should not miss either.

Casa Mila. Well if you like Gaudís work, you should definitely come here to see his home. Pretty fantastic to see and great view from the rooftop. It is a cool building in it self, if you don't want to go inside, at least take the time to pass by it while you are there. Nice thing to do on a rainy day otherwise!

Amazing. A quick glance at the outside is not as in-your-face like casa botello (sp?) not far away, but details pop out as you start looking. The most popular area seems to be the roof, with wild chimneys, tour then goes into an actual apartment, can't imagine actually living there, seen photos of private apartments that are very different. Must get tickets in advance, very easy and cheap.

Transformation from the covered building. What a wonderful lookng building from the outside since it has been renovated. Typically Gaudi in style. As we had limited time here on this visit we decided not to visit inside as you are restricted with what you can see inside the building and thought it is quite expensive with these restrictions.
Must see. To be honest, it is a picture of La Pedrera made the decision for us to fly to Barcelona. That says it all!
Feast for the eyes . Gaudi never fails to impress, he is a true visionary. Spectacular building inside and outside. Buy tickets online to avoid long queues.

Fascinating. I loved this. The audio tour is fab, so informative and very interesting regarding gaudi's works. I also learnt about park guell and sagrada familia whist I was there! Really interesting and close to other attractions.

Eye catching building. Amazing building. Its definitely something you should stop and look at. The detail in the structure and the unusual balcony's are definitely worth seeing.it's nicely lit up at night too. Disappointed we didn't realise it was open to public

Not quite as interesting as Casa Batllo, but still interesting. We again opted for the fast pass flexible option that allowed us any time any day access. The audio guides provided are not as advanced as the ones at casa batllo, but did the job well enough. Starting on the roof after a short elevator ride you do feel like you have been transported to another planet. The views are splendid, with some amazing chimney tops. You then proceed down into the attic level and finally into a recreated apartment including many of the furnishings. A must see for Gaudi fans, and I would be tempted to do the night tour of I was returning.

A real treat!. Another fantastic Gaudi building! The building is fully occupied so opportunities to view its interior are limited. My daughter and I were lucky enough to get tickets to a jazz concert on the top terrace. The main floor is a sight to see! With a champagne glass in hand, we were permitted to explore the open air upper deck with its fanciful wave-like patio and beautiful tile work. Prior to entering the terrace, there is an opportunity to explore a Gaudi exhibit, including samples of Gaudi's furniture design and examples of his design inspiration. Fantastic views!

Fascinating architecture and historical building. The tour we did in daytime made good use of the audioguide which gave some good context to the building and Gaudi's architectural process. Amazing to think how long ago it was designed and constructed. Fascinating tour. Note if the lifts are busy (there was a 30min queue....) then you can just take the stairs to the RHS after going through the ticket hall- and takes 2 mins to the top. Avoid the long wait.

Night tour is okay, but overpriced. We did the night tour of la pedrera on our last night in Barcelona. You see only a few parts of the house with a tour guide, most of the time is spent in the attic in a small Gaudi museum. The rooftop is beautiful, but not sure I would pay 34 euro again.

Unique Gaudi Arquitecture. This is one of Gaudi masterpieces and this alone is enough to make it a compulsatory visit. As I always insist you must read about it before you go and you will enjoy it much more. Some years ago it was free to visit from the regular exhibitions (also free) that were made regularly. Now you must pay to enter. If you like arquitecture its a total must. If you hate arquitecture this will be the building that will make you change your mind about. Some points to know: the front wall is inclined and this technique was completely unexpected in the time it was built (check the date on wikipedia). Gaudi was working for rich people but some people considered him too much excentric and he had to fight against many prejudices to achieve his goals. He was not apreciated like today at his time. All the buildings he made were made using best materials and most skilled professionals from all around spain. Funny fact: they are still some private owners living in his buildings and every time they have something broken (like a piece of ceiling) they must wait several months for the expert to come and repair the broken part.

It's worth a stop. I didn't visit the inside, but if it's anything like the exterior this is a must see! The architecture is so interesting and unique. It's tough to get good pictures from the exterior because it draws a lot of traffic. But it is definitely worth a try!

Amazing Caudi!. Yes, this building is one of the "must see" places in Barcelona. The tour is organized with audio guide that was bit difficult to use. Anyway the first impression of this building is vow! There´s a elevator that takes you up, but visitors use stairs on their way to down. The tour starts from the roof and i think it´s the most famous part to take pictures. But, there is also lots of things to see inside of the house. Take your time, and enjoy atmosphere of museum. Remember just take a breath and watch all the details. Mind that you might need to wait before you can get in. We visited here during hours of late afternoon and we were surprised that there was no waiting at all. There´s also shop with free entrance.
Stunning. I visited it on rainy day, got the ticket easily, audio guide is free. Rooftop is what I liked the most. I think, after Park guell it is the second best Gaudi's masterpiece, Must-see

What a wonderful place. As Casa Batlò it's impossible to miss casa milà (or Pedrera) beacuse are very close (in the same street) and beacuse it's an enchanting work of this incredible artist that was Antoni Gaudí. Every details is to get a picture outside and inside the building. We love it and you can buy also a nice souvenir in the shop at the end of the tour for a reasonable price. What a great place!

Incredible inside and on the roof. Whilst this building is amazing on the outside, it's when you get inside and then onto the roof that you truly get to experience its beauty. The inner courtyard and walls are decorated with elegant, delicate paintings of flowers. The roof is stunning and a highlight of my visit to this wonderful city. You can see the whole of the city and its highlights from the roof.
Stunning. Fabulous tour of amazing building. Get your picture taken before you leave and buy the little album. Great value.

Gaudi's works continue to amaze. La Pedrera is a wonderful visit. This house is so much fun to walk thru and explore. The audio tour explains so much about how he designed and created his work. You can even grab a drink and reflect on what you just saw in the cafe located in the house.
Casa Millá. The other beautiful building by Gaudí found during our walks through the Eixample district. Also you can visit this building but it is a little bit expensive.

A highlight of our visit to Barcelona. Along with the Sagrada Familia, this was the highlight of our trip to Barcelona. There is so much more to this building than you can just see from the street, a visit inside is really worth it and the tour is done superbly.

Interesting building, extortive entrance fee. The apartment building transformed in museum is a very interesting tribute to Gaudi. The style is not my cup of tea, but the visit is informative and entertaining. The use of the building as a museum has the added value of saving people of living in a Batman style nightmare apartment. It strikes me how genius architects don't usually create pleasant places for us to live. The roof-terrace is specially daunting. At 20.50 euros per person, the ticket price is a rip-off.
Piece of Art.. Genius piece of work. It reflects how people at that time understood and appreciated Art and intelligence.

Nice from the rooftop at night but nothing more if you do night visit. We wanted to do an all Gaudi tour while in Barcelona and had been quite impressed by La Sagrada Familia and Casa Battlo so thought we shouldn't miss this one. We could have and wouldn't not have missed much. We did the night tour as it was advertised as a light show with wine. The night visit does not include a visit of the actual apartments. Even if some are still occupied by families, some are empty and it seems that the day visit includes that, which in our sense must be the best part of the visit. We visited the attic, nice ok, but still an attic. We climbed to the rooftop and then got a light and music projection show, it was ok, but very average if you have seen that kind of shows elsewhere. The views of Barcelona were very nice and that was the best part of it. There is no comparison with Casa Battlo in terms of visit. At the end of the visit, we were served some sparkling wine with sweets, that was nice.

Jazz and sunset at La Pedrera. Magical evening on a hot Barcelona summer night, listening to cool jazz immersed in the surreal Gaudi sculptures, sipping on cava. A definite highlight of our holiday in Barcelona.

Stunning Gaudi at it's Best. Lovely tour to marvel at one of Gaudi triumphs, would off loved to of seen it at night but my schedule was not possible. Best to book ahead and you can save yourself 7 euro per season if you pick a specific time.

Fascinating!. We visited Barcelona this week as a family of 6 adults for 3 nights and stayed at the Condes De Barcelona just down the street from La Pedrera. We had a full itinery so only got to marvel at the architecture from the outside. Great photo opportunity. However, when we return to Barcelona this will definitely be on our list of future visits along with Casa Battlo.We did however, get time to relax at La Pedrera Cafe on the pavement under parasols outside the building, and thoroughly enjoyed this experience. Along with our drinks we ordered the most delicious "cakes" which were actually our equivalent of desserts. Cafe staff were OK but have had better, friendlier service at other establishments.

The craftsmanship of the woodwork and furniture. Well worth a visit not a great fan of the outside but the inside is amazing the beauty of gaudi in my opinion is that there is not too much of it so that makes its special art nouveau on speed

La Pedrera Is Superb, Tour Guide Was Mediocre. Casa Mila, also called La Pedrera (stone quarry), is one of the iconic places in Barcelona that people tell you that you have to visit. A group of six of us did and, for the most part, we were happy we did. The ingenious architect Antoni Gaudi (Park Guell, Sagrada Familia) designed it. He is known for his child-like mix of fantasy and function that together create things of beauty. La Pedrera/Casa Mila was an apartment building for decades and it is astonishing inside and out. Today only two of the original apartment renters remain, both very old; the place is becoming a museum only. We paid extra for the guided tour and this is where there were negatives: our female tour guide seemed more intent on keeping to a schedule than on accommodating individual needs; for instance, several in the tour group had physical limitations and had great difficulty climbing the many flights of narrow stairs. There was a small elevator available but she never told us about it and plunged ahead. The building itself, on the other hand, seemed to reveal one amazing feature after another, from handsome furniture, fixtures, and appointments in the apartments to beautifully crafted interior roof beams in brick. Even the wavy roof offers surprises, like the chimneys that look like guards or sentinels in helmets.

Do both the day and night tours. We did a combination ticket of both the day and night tour. I would suggest doing both because the price difference was not that much more. During the day time tour, you get to see the apartment which you don't see on the night time tour. The night time tour, called Origins, was guided so we learned a lot. Also, the laser light and music show on the rooftop was very memorable. I enjoyed being able to experience the rooftop botht during the day and at night. The night tour ended with a class of champagne and some fancy chocolate covered cookies. Being that this was our anniversary, it made it extra special and romantic.
Great view from the roof. Great view from the roof, while listening to jazz music with a glass of shampagne. The atmosphere is incredible.

I chose wisely.. When I was planning my trip I decided I would see one Gaudi attraction in addition to the Sagrada Familia. I narrowed my choices down to La Pedrera, Casa Batllo and Park Guell. I chose La Pedrera because it was closer to everything else I wanted to see than Park Guell and because dragons are cool! While the entire building is amazing I was most impressed with the roof. There's a spot on the roof where you have a great view of the Sagrada Familia in the distance. I would have loved to visit Park Guell but that will have to be the next time I visit Barcelona. During my adventures I waked by Casa Batllo. While it looked very interesting I was glad I visited La Pedrera instead.

Okay. While this is a nice building to look at from outside, it is nothing that I would recommend going out of my way to see. High entry fee. Would not put it very high up on my itinerary of things to do and see in Barcelona considering its price.

Great view. From the rooftop you get a nice view of the city and in night time, you can also watch a music band while enjoying some drinks. The exhibition also has interesting aspects from Gaudí and his work.

The Origins at La Pedrera. We went to the after dark experience, The Origins, at La Pedrera (Casa Mila). We were able to see the the courtyard, the attic, the roof, and they had a little cocktail reception afterwards. Someone mentioned that in a normal tour you can see an apartment-I don't know if that's true, but I think that would be really interesting to see. The attic was great for learning more about Gaudi's work. They had a lot of models/examples to better understand where his design inspiration came from. The roof was definitely my favorite part though. For The Origins they projected onto the different parts of the architecture-it was beautiful!It could be difficult for people who are terrified of heights; it's not overly high, but there's not a secure feeling with some of the fencing.
Great. Give you a better felling od the culture and people in spain......this was nice trip....highly recommend...........

Another solid item in Barcelons's menu. Due to the time constraints explored only from outside. It made positive impressions, still unique but in our humble opinion much less controversial than other Gaudi's projects. definitely worth seeing.

Not worth it. I felt to go inside was a rip off and not worth it. The audio tour was good but the amount you get to see for the price paid wasn't good. I would recommend to just visit from outside and maybe go into the shop to have a look.

Jackie b. Every year i go to barcelona and there is always something new to see this is a very interesting place to see you start at the very top of the building and work your way down the sights at the top of the building are amazing you can take many fab photos.

La Pedrera Origins not worth the money. Decided to see this night show on the roof with dinner included for @59 Euros. The dinner was in a cool room but the food was the worst food I have ever payed money for....period.All seven of us absolutely hated every course, even the dessert.I can't imagine preparing a worse meal than that. We were so starving afterwards that we went to McDonalds on Catalunya Plaza as soon as the show was over.The show was similar technology Disney World uses on it's Cinderella Castle show only not nearly as entertaining. No place to sit as well . Just not worth the money.The Mila House( Casa Mila or La Pedrera) was interesting but you do tend to get over Gaudified in this town.Don't get me wrong, you should see this but not at a high price unless you are reeeeeeealy into Antonio Gaudi. But that dinner, honestly I wouldn't have eaten it if you paid me 5 Euros. Maybe pay me 10 Euros I would force it down.....Maybe.
Was under renovation 07/14. Unfortunately the much acclaimed Casa Mila was under renovation when I'd visited and just a single room of it was open for the public to see.

An architectural treasure day and night. We visited this amazing place at 10 am and found no crowds at all. We had tickets online, but there was only a short queue to the ticket sales and no queues to get in.We got elevator to the roof and started audio guide tour from there. Audio guide was very informative any very well presented, easy to follow. The roof looks like “Star Wars” or something close, amazing it is. This is one place you have to see for yourself. After roof top you take steps to the attic and then follow steps down to furnished apartment, which is beautifully decorated. Take time to explore the details, all an all we stayed here 2 hours.We had bought tickets also to night visit (La Pedrera day and night). The roof top light and music show was great experience. We saw how to chimneys awoke to life. Mysterious and magical when music was involved. What we found a bit too much was the approx. 1 h guided tour before the night show. As we had already listen audio guide in the morning there was no need to have all story repeated. Guide was good but we got very little new information. We had night show at 10 pm and night was by then dark enough.We highly recommend both day and night time visits.

My favorite stop in Barcelona . I just found this place to be so captivating, both outside and in. At first I questioned the 21 euro admission, but it was well worth it, if only to see the out of this world rooftop area. The second level (attic) was educational and interesting in terms of gaudi's techniques. The apartment level was expansive and outfitted true to the time period. I even felt like the gift shop was great! I would definitely go back to see this again.

To see the perfect Gaudi roof, it's a must. You will get the elevator to the roof, which is the most interesting. Please notice that the roof is closed when it is raining. Afterwards you will have to go down via stairs to the Attic first, the on the 4th floor the private rooms. Afterwards it will be downstairs until the ground floor. If you plan this visit, the best time would be before 10 am, before the groups come in.

Awesome and educational. If you like art, architecture and the unusual, this visit is for you! I love how Gaudi did not follow conventional rules and his creative but practical vision. Loved the apartmen and rooftop pieces.
La pedrera. We were really amazed of the building and how Gaudi designed it. He truly was a special one. Take your time at the roof and enjoy the art work of him

Great views . The roof space on La Pedrera provide some excellent views across the city. The chimneys are a personal favourite of mine, especially the ones with built in arches. The thing that spoils this place, unfortunately, is the number of selfie stick weilders! It seems enjoying the visit has been replaced with taking pictures to prove you've been somewhere, instead of actually seeing the place.

Amazing building. In one word - beautifully. One of the Barelona's finest and crowded places. We were wery tired of walking and exploring Barcelona, so we have just seen the outside of this great architecture.

Crowded. Yes I love the architecture, Yes it is wonderful, but you can't move without stepping on someone else's toes or getting in the line of fire of what appears like a complete Asian wedding party photo shoot. If you're smart, take the steeper priced tickets (27€ PP) and avoid the waiting line.
Amazing!. I found it really expensive at first time, but the visit was really worth!The building and apartment are amazing, and the sculptures in the rooftoop are unmissable!
Fine museum. Easy to get to the place, and the tour start from the roof. The roof itself is great and the arctic will give you good introduction about Gaudi's works.

Different to Battlo. An apartment building like Battlo but totally different really... we're not architecture "buffs" but really enjoyed it never the less. Amazing rooms, unique designs everywhere and a great roof of course. Just something great to see.

It wasn't worth the hype, very disappointed.. My friends and I bought tickets online (on Viator.com) ahead of our trip to visit Casa Mila at night. But I was really disappointed in the overall magical night rooftop experience. The exterior facade of the building is amazing during the day and night. The people who led the nighttime tour were very knowledgeable about the history of Casa Mila but dragged the tour for a good hour because they were waiting for complete darkness in order for the rooftop show to be effective. The rooftop magical show was all about how nature influenced Gaudi's vision. I would agree that the views of Barcelona at night and La Sagrada Familia from the rooftop were incredible, but otherwise I would suggest visiting this building during the day time. I was really disappointed by the entire experience. I would rather visit Casa Batllo twice because it was my favorite of the two Gaudi buildings.

Interesting, but somewhat overrated.. Another of Gaudi's "masterpieces" in central Barcelona. Of course tickets in advance are a must as they limit entrances. A tour would have been helpful but short of that we got the audio tour. This really enhanced the experience in the lobby and helped to point out some of the details we might have missed. Once on the roof it had more of the feeling of a dog run in a prison yard as everything is fenced off to keep the tourists in line. Certainly get a sense of the imagination of this artist, but after a bit was not that interesting. the apartment they allow you to visit was drab and uninteresting, which I guess was a good thing since we were being rushed out of the building at that point to make room for the next group.

A must visit in Barcelona. Amazing that this building was designed and built in the early 1900's. Gaudi had an incredible vision that lasts today as a modern piece of architecture. The rooftop is equally beautiful and ornate. Do not miss this site.

Marvel. I have only visited the courtyard and the roof but this building is truly amazing and ultra modern even today. Some of the ideas Gaudi had in development of this project are just amazing. The view from the roof is also spectacular.

Another crazy building in Barcelona.. An architecture by Antoni Gaudi. This is entirely different structure from what he had made. Built in the early twentieth century , you find this in a short walk from catalunia center.

Stunning Building. Worth a visit just to see this amazing Building by Gaudi from the outside and visit the Gaudi gift store to get a glimpse of the interior square. You can also pay for a tour of the interior.

Not worth the money.. I must be honest here and I do feel a bit of a Philistine but I left this place feeling a little conned. We queued in the baking sun for nearly an hour in 100 degree heat to pay 22 euros each to visit this house which is in fairness a Gaudi masterpiece. After rising up in the escalator to the very impressive roof with its variety of chimneys including the one made from glass from broken champagne bottles we then went through the motions of the other floors. Whilst it was interesting for a short period my wife and I found ourselves becoming a little glazed over and losing interest rapidly and in under half an hour we were back out in the front street again. Don't get me wrong, for the Gauid afficianado or art lover this is the place for you and no doubt fascinating but for the average Joe like my wife and me, it needs something else to keep us stimulated. Was it worth 44 Euros for the two of us and the eternal wait in the heat? Definitely not I'm afraid!

Unique!!. La Pedrera is an impresive building, not as colorful as Casa Battlo but the details in the architecture and design are unique. It is fully furnished too and the views from the terrace are amazing. Like most of Gaudi's works around the city, book it in advance.

Another Gaudi Triumph. The only Gaudi house which still has furnished rooms. A bank now owns the building.The highlight is the rooftop view with all the sculptures. It is not cheap so be prepared to spend 21 euros to visit. The museum store is a must as it has some beautiful one of a kind things to bring home.

Worth a visit. This is a bit of a hidden gem. Don’t just look at this building from the outside, its well worth going inside. Tickets can be bought to tour parts of the building, including the amazing roof which is well worth a visit. Views are excellent too! This is a Gaudi house and gives a lot of insight into who he was and his life. Definitely worth spending a couple of hours visiting.

Fantastic. We were not planing on visiting La Pedrera, but after going to Park Guell and Casa Batllo, it was a must and again we were not let down, Gaudi's work is fantastic. We went at 6pm, there were no queues and not to many people inside.

Loved the rooftop. One of my favorite places. I went very early in the morning so was able to take good pictures as it wasn't busy at all. Interior is nice but not as good as the rooftop.There's a cafe as well and I had an amazing mojito.

outside better than inside. Book online for early in the day so as to avoid the hordes that will descend upon this place.my impression is that the outsde of the building and the roof are the standout area s the actual aparment is a bit of a let down by comparison.the courtyard is also a knockout.

Fantastic building!. Great and spectacular building, build in the modernist catalan style, La Pedrera (Casa Milà) was one of my objectives for visited in Barcelona. I spent about 3 hours, and for sure, when I return in Barcelona I'll visit again this beautiful, amazing and full of art place. If you want to visit Barcelona, don't miss to visit this place. The words are not enough! Your eyes will see that!

La Pedrera Well Worth Visiting. Its a very unusual building with a very quirky roof top. Its hard to describe, Very impressive in design and the the roof structures are amazingBuy tickets before going to avoid queues A very very good work by Gaudi
Impressive. We bought tickets for 34 Euro per person for a tour at night with the guide and assisted the light show at the roof top. Great view, show and explanation. Should be visited.

We all loved this Gaudi house! Make sure and see it!. This was a fantastic experience to see the amazing genius of Gaudi represented throughout the house. For me, this was 5 stars and for the rest of the group as well that included my 15 year old future step-daughter and my 22 year old daughter, my fiance and her sister.The roof absolutely blew me away! We took lots and lots of great photos from all different locations on the roof. Great views of surrounding buildings and city as well.Everyone in our group loved the house and the audio tour and please put this on your must list.We purchased tickets on-line directly from the La Pedrera website for 9:30am skip the line time and went very smoothly. There was the expected crowd but not too crowded so our thought was it is good to do this early if you can.Terrific gift shop also (you can get in without visiting).

More Gaudi brilliance. Superb to see Gaudi's work for everyday living after visiting the Sagrada Familia. The art nouveau apartment is superb. Wonderfully creative touches on the roof, and superb furniture to admire. The gift shop is tasteful. Not the usual 'tourist junk'.

Another impressive Gaudi creation. Like his other creations, Le Pedrera is unique in many ways. The rooftop has lovely views of the Passeig de Gracia and some really cool sculptures. The guide was useful in knowing the intention behind the design and his inspiration from nature. Definitely worth a visit.

Gaudi was amazing!. This building is another example of how brilliant Gaudi was. It is also near Passeig de Gracia so there are plenty of dining choices as well as other sights nearby. If you're in the area, check it out, it's amazing!

Brilliant - not to be missed!. We bought skip the line tickets from Julia travel but this made no difference when we turned up at 9am as everyone else in the queue also had pre booked tickets ! After this we had no problem the audio guide was great.

A must go. Absolutely fantastic thing to do! The design of the place really makes you wonder how ahead of his time gaudi was. The building is unbelievable. We had someone in a wheelchair and the staff hopped up whenever we turned a corner offering assistance. We were able to use the old style wooden elevator and it was such a gem!

I'm now a Gaudi convert. Great tour - an elevator to the roof to enjoy the view and all the odd chimneys etc on top. You walk down the stairs to the restored attic area which is amazing. This guy was way ahead of his time. Lots of videos and examples of how the place was built, thinking behind it, etc. Down another couple of staircases to an apartment that has been done up as it would have been when the place was opened. Fascinating stuff. Interesting that people live in this building.Bonus - the self guided tour headsets are free!Tip - buy your tickets online so you don't have to queue in the sweltering heat like we did!

very interesting. tickets were bought just before entering. You then take a lift to the rooftop. Amazing view of Barcelona.you then walk down some stairs and come to an appartement from the early 20th century
Wow. I'm not a fan of guided tours - at all. But I took one here and it was quite a bit of fun. The building itself is stunning. Plus, you get to go on the roof! That alone was worth it.

Very interesting, engrossed in Gaudí. Loved la pedrera. It's cheaper to enter and quite easy to get to. I was happy to have bought the fast pass. I think this really shows how Gaudí worked and is quite an incredible place. If I had to choose, though, I would go to casa batllo. Thankfully, I didn't have to choose!

An outstanding example of Gaudí's genius!. A virtuoso display of forward thinking, brilliant architectural design, originality and functionality. Possibly Gaudí's masterpiece among masterpieces (I still prefer Casa Batllo, though). The chimneys are fabulous; but then every aspect of this building is fascinating. Try to catch a performance or a light and sound show. A must!!!

a way of life. interesting to step back in time , I loved the house , although very very overpriced -70 euro for a family of 4 I think is a bit much and they should erect some shade cover when waiting outside in the huge queues

A good healthy dosage of Gaudi. amazing architecture, obviously, outside and inside, but also good work on museuming the experience. english audio guide wasnt to boring, and the items in the complex make for a fascinating hour or two attraction. orders tickets ahead online if you can!

Historically and architecturally intriguing . Informative and educational. Great photo opportunity here too. The staff were friendly and the services met our needs. The design is amazing and story behind the building was too.

Batllo is better.... It may be that we visited mila after batllo and guell, but we felt a bit underwhelmed. We didn't learn anything new here and compared to batllo you don't get to see that much (we did the evening roof show - so it's possible other areas are open on a day ticket). The show itself was a bit underwhelming too and felt like a good idea poorly executed. I walked away thinking just how much better it could have been.

A must see in Barcelona!. How could a 100-year-old apartment building be a must see, you ask? Don't ask, just go -- you will not regret it. Every detail of this building was thought out by true genius. Long before air conditioning and worries of sustainability, Gaudi designed this beautiful and surprisingly functional buliding. The tour takes you from the roof with its strangely phallic chimneys and ventilation shafts through an introduction to the architecht and the design in the attic and then to a model apartment. I recommend seeing La Pedrara in combination with Casa Battló which is just down the street. Buy your tickets online choosing an early entrance time to beat the crowds, then use a "fastpass" (albeit not cheap pass) to bypass the lines at Casa Battló.

must see. One of those buildings people just expect you to have seen whilst in barcelona as it is so special the city. Its easy to find and easy on the eye to look at, I would recommend going even if it is just to walk pass

A lesson in Gaudi design and innovation. While many may prefer other Gaudi attractions that may be more colourful with great mosaics La Pedrera highlighted the design and engineering brilliance of Gaudi. His construction techniques and innovation was far ahead of his time. While the entrance fee was a more than I would have deemed reasonable it was a valued experience that I would not miss. This is not an attraction that children would enjoy. Buy your tickets in advance to avoid queues

Another amazing Gaudi creation!. What can I say - I was once again smitten by Gaudi's genious and by Casa Mila, particularly by the famous roof with the "forest of warriors" chimneys. It was a perfect day with clear-blue skies and the stone colored chimneys against it were truly breathtaking! Also enjoyed viewing the furnished apartment in the building with the period kitchen, very interesting bathroom fixtures, and exquisite wood bedroom furniture.

Casa Batllo is Better. I must agree with other reviewers who think the admission price is a bit steep for what you get at La Padrera/Casa Mila. Without question, the roof is the star of this show (I kept thinking I had walked into the original 1968 version of "Planet of the Apes"). I think it alone is worth the cost of admission. But after working my way down into the apartment, I was surprised that it was over. That's it. Done. Head down to the exit. Having visited Casa Batllo the day before, I was struck by how much there was to see there compared to here. I think they could lower the price at La Pradrera by a Euro or two and it would feel more just, but if you're a fan of Gaudi or unlikely to return to Barcelona it's probably worth reaching into your pocket to pay for a ticket.

That rooftop!. Defo worth all money we paid for it, the guided tour is very very interesting all the way, but then when you get to the rooftop...just amazing! Clearly Gaudi was not from this planet, this rooftop is the proof. The view is breathtaking, too!
Too expensive. 21 euro is not much but it is too much for this place. Only the roof was interestingYou can admire Gaudis masterpieces elsewhere in BarcelonaNot recommended

Expensive. This was the least favourite Gaudi landmark of mine. In contrast with Casa Batlo there just wasn't enough interesting thing in here to justify the 20 euros asking price. You only have access to the roof terrace, the attic and an appartment. The appartment was quite interesting.

Stunning place. Lovely building, just imagine living there! As ever with Gaudi the roof was the best bit, those chimneys are stunning. Comparatively simple and plain compared to the likes of Casa Batlo, creamy white colours, not all the garish trencadis, but probably better for it.
Striking. Chimney pots on the roof are striking and the structure under the roof is interesting to see but not much else in the house was particularly outstanding.

Fabulous, especially at night. It's well worth it to plan a trip at night, where the rooftop is illuminated spectacularly. An Incredible architectural masterpiece. Views from the roof are amazing any time of day or night.
Cool. It's a really unique building and worth seeing - I am so impressed by Gaudi's work - no matter how many times I come to Barcelona I feel the need to go by.

Must see when in Barcelona. I loved this Casa, allow plenty of time to explore all levels - at least 2-3 hours. 1. The roof terrace. 2. the Espai Gaudi - the attic with really cool arches, videos & models explaining Gaudi's style & construction techniques. 3. The Pedrera apartment is a beautiful, opulent "museum" showing how they lived in the 1920-30's. 4. the courtyards & exhibition hall with the grand staircase which is also a work of art.When i went the front was under renovation so i didn't see the outside but the insides was great. Very quirky & oh so cool! Go early to avoid the afternoon crowds or go on a summer night. I went during the daytime but I believe the lights are fantastic at night - check out the web site https://www.lapedrera.com/en/what-is-casa-mila. Buy tickets online to avoid missing out.

Gaudi best residential creation. Gaudi's last residential commission was his best. Not only does he show innovations that are still used today, he builds a house that appears to be something from the sea. The more we saw the building, the more impressed I was with it. After reading about the crowds, I purchase the skip the line tickets on line before leaving. Not only do you get to enter from the front, you get to go immediately to the roof at any time you visit. It is hard to say what is the best or most impressive part of the house but the most profound and memorable is the roof. Even in the mid afternoon heat, I could have stayed here for hours. Gaudi is simply amazing in the design. The stairwells and the smokestacks are so well designed and amazing features on there own.What I had no idea about until visiting was the attic which is also impressive and a notable innovation for its time. Next was the apartment. It was amazing the way the courtyards provide so much natural light to the building and the way he designed interior halls around the courtyards, brilliant.Finally you come back to the ground and you really never see the house the same again. Now you are drawn to way it undulates like the waves or the seaweed on its balconies. You have to visit and experience. If you ask yourself then which building to visit as our guide said, Casa Milla is culmination of Gaudi and all of his style, Palau Guell shows not clear style and Casa Balto is a retrofit. While I had already bought my ticket, our Gaudi guide said La Pedrera was the best one if you could only get to one. I will say after visiting I wish I had seen the others, but there is only so much time. So don't waste it, buy your skip the line before you go.

What a view!. We splurged and bought the Fast passes to gain quick entrance and the extra fee was well worth it. You start on the roof with these amazing chimneys and air shafts to see up close, as well as a spectacular view of the city. The floor directly below has marvelous exhibits on the building, of Gaudi's designs, of his way of working. Give yourself ample time to spend here. There is an apartment that is open to the public and it is quite interesting. Allow at least two to three hours here.

Casa Mila. If in Barcelona, put this in your top 10. It is one of the oddest architectural statements of the last century. Surprising at every turn. Anything Gaudi is remarkable, but this is among the better of his achievements. Get tickets at least a day early. Hope for a sunny day. Be sure to look behind you as you pass through the halls or you will miss something.

Must see in Barcelons. Went to Casa Mila after seeing Casa Batloo. This tour was also well worth the 20 euro cost. You begin on the roof then go down one floor to the attic which has wonderful displays and videos about the architecture. Then you go one floor lower and visit an apartment in this beautiful building. Many of the apartments are occupied. What an incredible place to live.Gaudi was truly a genius
Must see. Superb - a real gem. We had a walking tour of Barcelona and finished here - what a place to finish - it's an absolute delight. Couldn't recommend highly enough

Beware of evening entry times!. La Pedrera is beautiful and a truly awe inspiring place, but the website allows timed entry tickets to be sold too late in the evening to completely enjoy the place. Don't book tickets after 7pm unless you want to run through it. We booked 7:30 and while we were on the roof with only a handful of people (that was great!), we didn't get to linger and completely listen to the free audio tour. When we arrived for our 7:30 entry time the attendant at the door told us that they recommend 1 1/2 hours but the place was closing in 1 hour. We asked why they sell tickets for 7:30 when they don't recommend you enter she shrugged her shoulders. She said we could return anytime the next day (instead of going in that evening) but we'd already paid for a taxi and made the effort to get there so we went in. We enjoyed the museum and exhibits but the 1 hour available until closing was not enough time.

Trip back in time to the Spanish belle epoque. It is recommended you buy your tickets online and be punctual at the time selected. Most of the areas of this building are open for you to visit, although people still live here. Visitors focus mainly on the upper floor and roof top terrace that looks more like a Dr Seuss in 3D movie set. My daughters spent like 45 mins up there just taking pictures and selfies with the various background possibilities the Gaudian architecture offer. However, I found more interesting the visit to the apartment which has many of the original Gaudi and art nouveau furniture or reasonable facsimiles of original furnishings, everyday conveniences and decor. The audioguide is helpful to understand the building. Don't miss the commentary about the interior patio and garage. Definitively this was a futuristic building designed by a visionary genius. After visiting this place go meditate about Modernismo while eating a tapa or bocadillo at any local cafe in the area.
Awesome. We visited the building two days ago, and inside of this we could see amazing things from Gaudí. But the worst thing is all the people...

Jazz and Gaudi - A great combination!. In the evening - jazz on the roof. What a venue. A great way to appreciate Gaudi's architecture and listen to fun music. Either arrive early or skip looking at the exhibits and head outside to be able to choose the seat that you want (not chairs, sitting on the steps). They have something similar at Casa Batllo but we did not have time to try it out.

Most see!. We had our hotel book for us skip the line tickets the day before. It was worth it. There was a line to get in to take the elevator up to the rooftop but if you want some exercise take the steps. The rooftop was amazing. I think we spent almost an hour up there alone. Also, you get to tour an apartment. Again, really enjoyed it. Original tile work through out. And the courtyard is pretty incredible too. This apartment building is occupied by several tenants so you don't get to tour the entire building. The attic space was also pretty incredible as well.

A must to visit!. Firstly a tip, buy you tickets on line prior to your visit, it will save you spending time queueing outside.These apartments were designed / refurbished by Gaudi and they are just fantastic, particularly the roof and chimneys. The tour allows you to walk through visit an apartment to view Gaudis work and get an insight into his genius mind ( see also Casa Botllo in Las Ramblas). Allow time to visit this place, it's well worth it, undertake a little research before you do it to enhance the visit, you won't be disappointed!

Interesting sight, didn't go in.. We walked down Passeig de Gracia to look at some Gaudi projects including this and Batllo, but decided not to go inside. You can look up information about the structure online or in guidebooks.

Gaudi....Again. You will leave Barcelona in awe of the brilliance of this man; he was so way ahead of his time. Expensive to get in although there was not much of a wait when we went. Take lots of pictures!

Fantastic introduction to Gaudi.. We attended an evening concert on the roof (part of their summer nights series) which I highly recommend. Seeing the rooftop at night, and engaging with the art and music is a more immersive way to truly experience Gaudi. We also took the tour after the concert---too many people all at once. And, to be honest, if you buy a concert ticket you get to see both the attic and the roof, which are the main things worth seeing, so I'd skip the tour of the apartment. Others have noted this too. Go to Casa Batllo right down the street for a better tour of Gaudi's "inside" work.

Don't miss. This is the pinnacle of Gaudi. This was our favorite site (after the Sagrada Familia) in Barcelona. It was amazing and the modern use of Gaudi's art (think Star Wars storm troopers). The detail, the structural details of Gaudi's architectural prowess and more.

Nice place but not worth the money. I feel a bit mean only giving this an 'average' score, but considering the value for money I didn't feel that I could put it any higher. The rooftop and the attic were great and I loved the views of the city and learning a bit about the history and construction (the audio guide was good but the information it gave was sometimes contradictory or didn't match with the information on the exhibits). The visit to the apartment was not as good as I was expecting as it had been decorated and wasn't as Gaudi would have intended it (I know that owners are free to decorate their apartments as they wish but it just detracted from it a bit). We were only in there for an hour and didn't feel that it was worth the 24 euros we had paid.

gaudis masterpiece. totally amazing experience, i bought a package online that included a meal, that was the only negative part for me, you get no choice and not everyone is into raw sea bass. water wasnt included and i was followed outside by waitress for payment. but that was quickly forgotten because Casa Mila was mind blowing, like walking around in someones dream. if you go to Barcelona and dont see this then you have missed one of the most intriguing places in the world, evening tour was best smaller crowd.

Very cool night time tour. What an amazing work of art as well as an apartment building. Gaudi was really something and the origins tour with rooftop light show showcased his masterpiece in such a modern way.

Can buy tickets on line on the day for easy access. Been before, super place, see other reviews. My tip is if you do not have a prebooked ticket and the queue for tickets is long do not pay the premium price to shortcut the line. Use your smart phone and book on line for a ticket, (we did it for instant admission) and walk straight down the prebooked tickets line
Not worth the 20euro fee at all!. We paid more to skip the queue, ended up waiting in another queue, staff didn't know what they were doing. Only took twenty minutes to walk around, disappointing.

For the Complete Gaudi Experience . . .. you need to go here or to Casa Battlo. This was good - there is one apartment that is decorated as it would have been at the time the building was built. There is also a very good exhibit about the design and construction of the building. The best part is going up to the roof and wandering around the "Darth Vader" chimneys.We went towards the end of the day and had no problem getting a very prompt admission. Might be better to buy tickets in advance if you're going in the peak summer period.

What a roof!. The tour starts with the roof and works down through an apartment refitted with original style furniture.The undulating roof area is incredible with the 'Storm Trooper' chimney pots and the huge ventilation towers all decorated; one with broken Champagne bottles! The views are wonderful too, so take a camera.Next step is the under roof space which houses information on Gaudi's creations including models and very good explanations on the audio guide.Then down to the apartment which has been refitted as it was originally. Very interesting!Then back down to the 'courtyard' with the painted pillars and ceiling before departing.The exterior is a unique shape and you can understand the nickname 'The Quarry'!Well worth a visit and a must visit place on any Gaudi tour!

Not worth the money. We had already visited the casa battlo and compared to that, this building was a huge disappointment. It was very expensive and there was not much to see other than models of his work... Unless you are a huge gaudi fan then skip this and go to battlo instead.

Origins of Gaudi. We really enjoyed the evening Origins of Gaudi tour at La Pedrera. It's only a couple euro more than regular tickets and we enjoyed a lovely evening light show on top of the building as well as a glass of cava to cap off the evening. Would highly recommend.

Beautiful architecture, very interesting.. An absolute must visit in Barcelona. The building is stunning and completely unique. Would recommend a free audio guide as they provide endless, interesting information about La Pedrera. The museum with in the building contained huge insight about Gaudi's work and I have learnt a lot purely from wandering through and listening to the audioguide. The replica apartment is fun and is great for kids.

Start your Gaudi tour here . The best place to start your Gaudi tour. Excellent models, explanations and other information in the attic which is second on your visit after the roof. It's busy but manageable and there are staff on every floor. Disability access is just average with many groups of 3 to 12 stairs but they are Gaudi so quite go if you use sticks. Much better than the Casa Batllo and the Parc Guell house I believe.
Impressive. Loved the visit. The architecture is so beautiful and the art work on the roof is amazing. The apartment open to the public was really beautiful. What can I say more than it was great.

Cool House. We booked our tickets in advance. We got there early and wandered up to another Gaudi House - Casa Vicens to kill time. This house was closed so we just took photos of the outside. No biggie. I can say that I have seen it. It would have been nice to see the inside. I really liked the Casa Mila. I loved the colors and decor. It was an interesting tour. I liked especially the rooftop. Do a little research before so you can appreciate some finer details the tour may not cover. The home is a stone's throw away from Casa Batllo. I think if you like photography, you may want to come earlier in the day or about noon so that the courtyard is lit up and you can appreciate the colors. We came about 3:30 so my pictures we a little dark. Though this may be due to user error.

Not worth 20 € if you aren't an architect. First of all the entrance fee is bery high just to see the roof. Ok the roof was really great but there aren't anything special about the inside of the building. If you already visited sagrada familia there is no need to pay 20 € per person.

Outstanding. Another outstanding building. Spend some time inside winding your way up the internal staircase. Witness the lush plants and the natural lighting of this bypuilding. Truely a work of art.

Great house- start here to learn about Gaudi . This was the first place we visited in Barcelona and I'm so pleased we did it this way round as there is an exhibition in the attic on Gaudi- and the audio guide explained a lot about Gaudis life and influences.

Where imagination goes wild!. We chose to visit Casa Mila over Casa Batllo due to time and $$ constraint. Every inch of this building speaks of nature, fantasy, and beauty. The audio guide did a really great job taking you through Gaudi's vision and seeing all his work in a mini exhibition within the building. The rooftop is must see and stay for hours type place to let your imagination go wild and create your own stories with each chimney stack!

Amazing, worth a visit - buy the fast pass to avoid the queues. We just popped in without booking in advance. We bought the fast passes, something like 7Euros on top of the aprox. 20Euro entrance fee, and meant you jumped the queue - seemed well worth it. It's actually an extensive audio tour, including a trip up to the amazing Gaudi rooftop, then the loft then the apartments and all the way back down to the ground. The loft includes a museum/explanation arrangement showcasing lots about Gaudi and how the ideas and architecture came about - excellent.Rooftop is crowded though - you won't get a photo without another tourist in it!Not wheelchair or pushchair friendly as far as I could tell (unless there were separate arrangements), and lots of steps and uneven surfaces.
Amazing. An architectural marvel! Wish we had more pioneers like gaudi to create more out of the ordinary buildings
weird but beautiful. This was a beautiful building really different and smack bang in the middle of modern Barcelona, well worth the visit

Lovely building, great roof. Like the other Gaudi properties in Barcelona, the tour of this one is very well organised and both informative and interesting. The audio guide is very good. Even for those who are not that into architecture there is still plenty to keep you engaged, not least the crazy (but practical) roof with its great views of Barcelona. I was surprised by how long we spent just wandering about enjoying the feeling of the place. Nice.

Very beautiful and one of the best Modernisme buildings in Barcelona. I didn't go inside the Casa Milà because the entrace fee was very high and there were too many groups so it would have been too crowded. However, it's very beautiful to see the building -- one of the most important buildings if the Modernisme in Barcelona -- from the outside. There are benches (also in Modernisme style) around to sit down and study the details of the facade and balconys.

Well organized. This is a well organized tour through a Gaudi designed house. The history of the building is very interesting, as well as the unusual architecture of Antonio Gaudi. Well worth the time to visit here.

La Pedrera- One of My Favourites. You can’t help but notice examples of Gaudi all over Barcelona, but we wanted a closer look at some of his unique building style. Admission includes a good audio guide and you can take your time walking through each area. We went early in the morning, and although there was a small line, we were on the rooftop, where the tour starts, in around 10 minutes. I was not prepared for the quirky sculptures and chimneys on the roof, and the winding twisting paths that give you a 360 degree view over the City.Once you’re finished on the rooftop, you proceed downstairs to the attic area where they have an extremely interesting history of Gaudi, explaining his design principles and the influence of nature in all of his work. He was a brilliant architect and so far ahead of his time. There are also models of some of his other buildings and commissions. As you leave the Attic you go down another floor to the apartment that is fully furnished with period pieces. It shows the lifestyle of wealthy early 20th century living, equipped with all of the latest gadgets and appliances for that time. The building is truly beautiful, with curving walls, balconies looking inward with metal balcony railings, also designed with nature in mind. This is a must see for your visit to Barcelona. Sagrada Familia is obviously his best work, but there you need to deal with crowds, people snapping shots constantly, being pushed around like cattle. La Pedrera provides the ability to truly appreciate Gaudi’s work at your won pace.

Organic!. While not the most famous of Gaudi's projects this one has a serious impact. Gaudi's work is known for its organic nature and while it is ever present in the church and park projects it seems in most contrast to traditional buildings here in the city, nestled among the square, geometric shapes.
