Take the time to go up the attic where the structure was inspired by the skeleton of a snake and tour the roof for the whimsical treatment of chimneys and vents. Amazing.

Curves and Chimneys. This is like walking through a fantasy. Starting on the rooftop which consists of different levels accessed by a variety of curved sloping paths and steps. The chimneys are works of art and the mosaic makes a fab photo against the contrast of clear blue skies.The views spread out over the entire city of Barcelona to the Mediterranean Sea. The Attic has the most amazing ceiling with an openly veiwable structure. Also good for the opportunity of a reflective selfie against the backdrop of the curving brickwork of the ceiling. The entrance ticket also includes access to the museum style route through period living areas with beautiful Art Nouvea furnishings. The veiws from the windows look beyond the curvaceous balconies to the courtyard below, the beautifully painted walls draw your eyes over the entire building. We took the lift up, and the stairs down. There are decent toilets, a souvenir shop and a photography sales area. There is also a handy tourist bus stop right outside.

Gaudi Warrior Roof. Go at night for the experience of the light show as well as seeing the Warrior Chimneys and the furnished house. The light show was good and although you can see the balcony railings better during the day the light show added to the experience.

Amazing Gauidi Building. La Pedrera, the home and apartments by Gaudi. We made it to all floors, even to the roof. The architecture, furniture, iron work, painted walls, everything was as wonderful as we remembered. We watched a film about his work which was very well done

Inspiring look into Antoni Gaudi's process. It was so exciting to see such revolutionary architecture, that today still feels revolutionary. The rooftop tour was very dynamic, with all the levels and perspectives as we walked around. Going into the attic was equally intriguing, as we learnt about Anotoni Gaudi's process and inspiration from nature.

Another Gaudi marvel. Just stunning, top to bottom, inside and out. Words can't describe Gaudi's genius, you really have to see it to believe it. If you like architecture or art or history or culture just make sure you go here if you're in Barcelona.

Not as impressive as Casa Batllo. Although undoubtedly interesting and beautiful, this is not as impressive as Casa Batllo nearby or Sagrada Familia. It has a guided tour which is worth doing if you decide to go. Chimneys are famous, but if you are pressed for time or money and have to choose, go to Casa Batllo.

Nice but expensive. The place worth a visit however the visit is just for the roof terrace, the attic and an apartment. I have liked it much, Gaudì was an absolute genius (no doubts) however 20,50 EURO is to much for this visit....

Expensive but a must see!. A nice way to see the interesting and quirky designs to peoples home back then. You can't see the whole building as most of them are occupied privately but you pay to see an example of an apartment and also the access to the rooftop. If you look closely, you will notice that the apartment layout is designed in a circle, so when you walk one full round you will end up at the front entrance again. Of course this is not obvious because of the security bars that are meant to lead the crowd in one direction only. We had much more fun on the rooftop, where you can see quirky chimney designs and a view of Barcelona city. You can also see the Sagrada Familia from there.

Yet another Gaudi treat.... You can't visit Barcelona without being affected, influenced and inspired by Antoni Gaudi. Obviously he's crowning glory of the Sagrada Familia will no doubt be regarded as his masterpiece and it is indeed spectacular. However, also make sure you visit Casa Batllo ( my personal favourite ) and this great gem too.....La Pedrera. It's not quite as exotic and grand as it's neighbour the Batllo, but it's simply a relaxing, impressive, beautiful and highly enjoyable way to spend a couple of hours. The thought and genius of Gaudi goes way over my head, I just can't conceive how brilliant and far ahead of his time this man was. However, go and visit La Pedrera and the Batllo and you'll start to get a sense. I can't think of anywhere in the World where beauty, nature and yes, mathematics have come together to create wonders that have inspired and influenced so many. Thank you Senior Gaudi :-)

A piece of astonishing architecture, engineering, and art. A very impressive piece of both engineering and architecture. Gaudi managed to create this building in the beginning of the 20th century but in terms of space management and utilities it is more like something from 50 years later - elevators, central laundry with shaft, movable interior walls, ventilation... amazing.

Gaudi or made in Sweden?. In this house you can find a bathroom with a watertap in a sink that looks exact like Mora Classic made in Sweden. And they say that all is made by Gaudi...I love this place!

Unque structure!. Luckily we've found an hotel 200-300 meter from this stunning building. Pleasure seeing it everyday during our strolls in and out.We are in love with Barelona :)It was best romantic getaway for 6 years since we have kids.

Awesome architecture. Great place to visit. We loved architecture so this was a must see place. If you get a chance take the tour. Otherwise, they have a store with a lot of cool souveniers to take home. Luxury stores are within walking distance. We really enjoyed visiting this place.

Gaudi's work like no other. We toured Gaudi's La Pedrera during our visit to Barcelona last month. The chimney-like structures on the roof seem to appear in every Barcelona tour book and I was intrigued to see them up close. We recommend spending a few extra euros to get the English audio guide which provides some context and information about Gaudi's life. During the tour you able to visit the roof, the attic, and a floor featuring an apartment as it would have looked at the turn of the 20th century. We were able to wander the 3 areas at our leisure and it did not feel overly crowded. The structure is unlike any we have every seen, with Gaud's trademark undulating walls and mosaic patterns. The roof top structures were fascinating and kind of eerie, It is unlike any building you will ever see- very much worth a visit.

Worth it. Almost didn't go in due to the cost and queue but the queue moved quite quickly and the view from the roof was stunning, as was the roof architecture itself. The decor inside was quirky and interesting and the story behind it all, fascinating

Good Intro to Gaudi. We happened upon Casa Mila the first day in Barcelona and had a nice time wandering through the building and taking in the scenic views from the roof-top. We also got to see the inside apartments and Gaudi's furniture as well as learning about what inspired his work. Like for everything in this city, you have to buy a ticket and it's not that cheap, so if you want to see only the "best of", go to Gaudi's La Sagrada Familia instead, which is beautiful.
not just a block of flats. another classic gaudi building worth the vist this fine apartment block still ocupieped with the museum in the roof and one flat open to view too

Beautiful structure!. This building was beautiful! You're unable to walk throughout the whole building but you get a good sense of how people lived and styled their homes back in the day.Once again we pre-booked our tickets and arrived early in the morning to avoid the tours and crowds. Definitely listen to the audio guide and look for the numbers to avoid missing out.

Exceptional staff at a great venue. I recently visited La Pedrera with my wife who is disabled and in a wheelchair together with two friends. The staff where incredible, not just in the help they gave us but in the warm and friendly way in which they gave it. We could not have asked for a better day a great building and great people. Thank you very much to all the team.

Not for us. This is a personal opinion, and Gaudi is not for me. As such, were completely underwhelmed by this building. Not pretty, did not enter, preferred to spend time elsewhere. Very busy, tours everywhere, a lot of other sights in Barcelona were prettier.

How can you go to Barcelona and not experience this?. Its impressive from the outside but I was not prepared for the enormity, spectacular design and quirkiness of this building. Goudy at his best. The apartments are occupied but they have been designed to maximise the light and breeze.. the roof and chimneys give you spectacular views of this amazing City. There are queues to get in and as ever a gift shop to visit on the exit but so worth it.Not for the faint hearted as there are lots of stairs to climb but there is a lift to the top for the disabled.

Night light show worth it even if a little weird. Only saw La Pedrera at night and they put on a light show on the roof top that was interesting and historically significant but not to Barcelona. We didn't know it would be this so surprised and not sure it's work the 30 Euro but saying that I'm still happy we went. Great view of Barcelona. Inside you don't get to see much as the rooms are rented but from the ground floor looking up its magnificent. Also if you have mobility issues be aware it's about 8 flights of stairs. Take the lift. Other Gaudi sites are more alluring & amazing than this one. Visit if you have time.

Fascinating architecture. Antonio Gaudi's work here and the history behind it is fascinating. Well-worth the entrance fee. Don't forget your camera. Be sure to go to the roof to see where George Lucas was inspired to make the storm troopers and tour the attic and apartment for a trip into Gaudi's world. He was well ahead of his time, and this is yet another testament to his genius.

Expensive but we did really enjoy it. We toured Sagrada Familia and wanted to see one other Gaudi site. This seemed like the best example of an interior building and the most complete history of Gaudi. We booked our tickets ahead online. The admission is quite expensive (everything in Barcelona is to my mind), but I'm glad we went. The admission includes a very good audio guide and although it was busy, it wasn't mobbed the way Sagrada Familia was. We could actually enjoy the visit without bumping into a selfie stick at every turn. The building is beautiful, the story and history of Gaudi and the Mila family was extremely interesting. The rooftop terrace is beautiful as is the Pedrera Apartment. The attic contained many unique exhibits and was really well done. Highly recommended.

Stunning building. We really enjoyed exploring another of Gaudi's masterpieces. The archecture is stunning and you simply cannot come to Barcelona without visiting. The only reason I'm not rating 'excellent' is because we felt it was a bit overpriced for what it was.

Don't miss the Pedrera. One of Gaudi's best buildings and a must see for visitors to the city. You can pay to go in and go up to he roof to an iconic terrace or go and see the apartments below. The Pedrera is Spanish for "The stone quarry".

"Gaudi's Fanciful Apartment Building". This is another Gaudi masterpiece built around 1905-10. What you'll see here is the ground floor entry area then up to the top floor apartment. Both spaces show very curvy/organicstyling in the wood trim, stairwell and window shapes. The apartment is set up in the lifestyle of a well-to-do early 20thCentury family. Curvy shaped rooms are the norm. The attic has a small display of Gaudi's models, plans & other information.Out on the roof is perhaps the best part, with chimney potsrising all around with human-like features. There are night tourswhich make the roof area come to life.One can also buy premium tickets which allow entry anytime forthirty days after purchase. Check the website for more info.

Amazing example of modern architecture. Very interesting example of modern architecture. People still live in this house. House is very nice looking inside and outside. A lot of curves instead og straight lines. Metall balcony lattices looks like ocean floor with seaweed and crabs. Tour starting point on the roof. Watch your step on this multilayer roof, a loot of stairs. After that you can visit the apartment with old interrior from 1910. Gift shop available at the end of the tour.Hint: If you take the line on the right side of the building you'll pay 17 euro for person. Line on the front of the building is express line for 27 euro for person.

Le Pedrara. It was shame, when we went their was lots of local building work and we could not take in the real beauty of the building. However, the inside of this building is breath taking and well worth a visit.
Gaudì in Barcelona. Do not miss this masterpiece of modern architecture! Even if you simply walk around it looking nose-up, the feeling those smooth curves will give you is an experience.

Top notch. This was a great place to go in the mid-day heat, as it's all inside, apart from the roof top section obviously! Very interesting & inspiring, expensive but well worth the money. We got there at 13:30 & only had to queue for 20 minutes before getting in. Whole tour took about 2hours, & the audio tour was very good. It seems to be faster entry if you buy online, but you need to print out tickets to do this. Incidentally it's nearly impossible to find an Internet cafe with a printer in Barcelona!

Beautiful. From the street it is beautiful. Someplace I have always wanted to see. The line to enter was fairly long and as I remember it was fairly expensive. If I had more time that day I would have paid the price just to see the interior. Unfortunately I couldn't, hope you do
See this. amazing place, well worth the 20Euros entrance fee, Gaudi was ahead of his time Spent a cuple of hours here, fascinating
Must see!. Just saw the outside and was marveled mostly by balcony ironworks. There is not a single straight line in whole façade. The HO-HO bus rides past it and there is s stop close by

A little pricey, but it's cool to experience. The tour is setup so that you start from the rooftop - the neatest part - then work your way down the top levels of the building. The audio guide is included in the ticket and I recommend listening to it. Cool architecture from top to bottom! There was a line for tickets, but it went quick. We were there at 1030AM on a Monday. With the Barcelona card we saved €9. Still, €32 for two people is expensive.

Genius Gaudi- a must!. I went here with my sister and a couple of friends. We started with mila restaurant, def worth the visit but i wouldnt recommend to stay for lunch 40 euros a person. We then went and did the tour of the building, it was 25 euros a person and it was well worth it. Im a big fan of gaudi so i loved all his work.

Overpriced and commercialized. We did not go inside because it just seemed outrageous to pay twenty euros per person including kids. Architecture is meant to be admired and appreciated and this just seems too commercialized.
UNMISSABLE. As well as La Sagrada Familia, it representes the courageous revolutionary, creative and extremelly technical architeture develloped by Antoni Gaudi. Nice vew of Quadrat D'Or.

Definitely worth a visit. An audio guide includes the bottom level, the roof, and a tour of one of the apartments inside which is set up as a museum and houses l the furniture and decor from the time period of when the house was first built. It really gives you an idea of what it felt like to live in the building. It takes about an hour to go through the house and it's definitely worth it.

Amazing architecture! Brilliant Gaudi. La Pedrera (meaning The Quarry) or the Casa Mila is the last private commission completed by Gaudi and a building well bore his time! People wanted to ban it but thank goodness -NO! So much information as to Gaudi's design & vision with his love & influence of nature in the min museum in The Attic area. Disabled visitors are catered for & have the added privilege of using the original lift designed by Gaudi himself, while the general public walk down the stairs to the beautiful courtyards. Definitely recommend this visit as also gives an insight to life in Barcelona at the time.
Inspiration and education. A good starting place for visiting Gaudi sites, since it's wonderful and has a nice exhibit up top. The roof is beyond words. Don't miss it.

A night out at A very special house. La Pedrera or the Casa Mila is the last private commission completed by Gaudi. It is thought to be his ultimate creation bringing together all the design elements of nature that he was well known for. The exterior facade is simply different even for today and looks like a giant sand castle.La Pedrera or The Quarry was the diminutive nickname given to this very modern home of its time which unfortunately was not well regarded by the community then. The casa is now owned by a Spanish bank and open to the public for tours.A tour through La Pedrera is a must to understand Gaudi's vision. The building has no straight lines at all and it felt like it alternated being part forest and part sea at various times. The first floor was owned by the Mila family and the rest of the 4-5 floors were rented out. I envy the four families who come from the original renters that are still entitled to live there for very little rent due to controls. They are however, the last generation to be accorded this occupancy privilege. Couple facts that I found interesting which you could check out yourself - La Pedrera was designed to have electricity and elevators - two modern inventions in the world in the early 1900s. More fascinating was Gaudi's foresight to design undercover car parking accessed through the front doors when not many cars were around! The attic area meant for laundry drying was a fascinating space of parabolic curves. It now houses exhibits to explain the design of the building in relation to nature.We decided to explore La Pedrera at night and took The Origins tour, introduced only in the last three months. This is an audio-visual light show telling the story of the beginning of life projected onto the awesome "guardian-like" sculptures at the rooftop of the casa. The show which was for about 30 mins was magical.Booking is recommended as there are limited spaces for the night visits. There is a choice of tours in several languages, with the English tour starting at 9.15 pm for about over 1 hr. At the conclusion, drinks and sweets were served at the foyer area enabling the patrons to enjoy the atmosphere of La Pedrera. Note that there is a discount ticket to The Origins at La Pedrera if you take the Barcelona City Tour hop on hop off bus. Enjoy - we did!

Another great Gaudi experience. Buy advanced tickets to avoid long queues!
Staff provide free audio guides, which were great to listen to as you walk round. The rooftop chimneys were out of this world and amazing to photograph! Lots to see and read, and to discover about the wonderful mind of Gaudi. Definitely worth a visit.
All Gaudi. If you want to see Gaudi's work, come here. Definitely worth a visit. The tour started on the roof top. Get the audio guide to get the history.

surprising on every step. Wonderful building surprising at every corner. The biggest surptise is on the roof. The only disadvantige is the queue in front of the ticket office- if you can, book it in advance. And don't be in a hurry, there are so many beatifjl details in the building.

Wonderful rooftop. We took the nighttime tour. The building is occupied by residents so when we went to the front door, one of them bawled us out! Go to the side door. The tour shows a film, the attic (a lot of time spent here and it should be maybe 10 minutes), then the roof which has the amazing statues, and then back to one apartment. The interior is plain compared to Gaudi's other buildings. A glass of cava and snacks wraps up the tour. 30 Euros per person and must be booked ahead.

Beautiful Architecture!!. Such a great glimpse into the mind of Gaudi. We had a great tour and it really gave us a lot of info into the life and times of Gaudi and Barcelona during his lifetime and a better understanding of what it was like to live in Barcelona during that period.

Highly Imaginative Architecture. His highly imaginative architecture got Gaudi in trouble with the owners, the Mila family, The whole city making fun of their building that cost them a fortune. The city was not ready to understand such type of architecture and quickly found a nickname for the building: “La Pedrera” that means “the quarry”. Especially the rooftop is amazing with all the stairs.This is last Gaudi building before the architect decided to completely focus in the Sagrada Familia.

Well worth a visit - a wonderful building with great mini-museum. We booked the any-time access tickets online before going, and it was well worth it as we skipped the queues and entered through the main door, and received our audio-guide and access to the roof lift with no delays or crowds.The building is wonderful and we loved exploring the roof and enjoying the views. However, the mini museum on the top floor below the roof provided a wonderful perspective to all of Gaudi's work and buildings. The apartment that was open to the public was also a nice touch. Highly recommended.

A must visit in Barcelona. This is a very interesting and unusual building to visit. The displays were excellent and more time consuming that I was expecting. I'd highly recommend a visit. We didn't book in advance but didn't have to queue, though we were there early. There is a more expensive fast track option on the door for those who can not wait. It might be worth considering booking in advance if you can. To do the house any kind of justice, you need to set aside a minimum of 2-3 hours, there really is that much to take in.

Fascinating -- way ahead of his time. This apartment building is the work of a true genius. Even compared to other Gaudi buildings (Casa Batllo, Palac Guell), this is unique and worth a special trip. Gaudi was meticulous in his designs to consider light, ventilation and water drainage and storage. Find it on Google maps --- in the satellite view, you can see large "holes" in the roof which are the open spaces inside the structure designed to give every room natural outside light. The roof itself is a sculpture garden of mysterious chimneys with an undulating surface that would be tempting to skateboarders. The attic has a very good museum with upside down models that show how he designed his structures. Also videos of his other buildings and examples of furniture. In this respect, a visit to Casa Mila gives you a better and broader appreciation of his work than Casa Battlo. Also the apartment you tour has period furniture, which positively adds to the experience, where as Casa Batllo has no furniture other than a few Gaudi chairs. Don't miss the on-demand hot water heater in the bathroom --- a brass box on the wall with gas and water lines obviously so the water could be heated as it flowed to the sink or tub. An example of technology that even most U.S. homes still don't have today!Buy tickets on-line at https://www.lapedrera.com/en/home. For an extra fee, you can get 'premium' tickets to be able to enter any time, an advantage if your schedule is uncertain. Lines for Mila are likely longer than at Batllo. My personal priority for visiting Gaudi works : Sagrada Familia, Casa Mila, Parc Guell, Casa Batllo, and Palac Guell. You can't do them all in one day-- need two or three at least.

A must wen visiting Barcelona. Spectacular exhibits of Gaudi's work which I enjoyed more that La Sagrada Familia. There are plenty of photograhic opportunities that will thrill any tourist and leave lasting memories. A great close-up encounter with Gaudi's work.
Don't miss this!. Any or all of Gaudí's spectacular architectural gems are a must-see while visiting Barcelona. Filled with color, shape, and organic forms, this was a wondrous place to visit!!!!

Amazing. This is the most fabulous building, some of the apartments are actually lived in! We booked tickets online in advance to avoid the queue.Price included an audio guide. The rooftop is accessed via a lift and is like stepping out onto a different planet. Superb views as well. Now a huge fan of Gaudi.

A Must See even if Not Familiar with Gaudi. Barcelona IS Gaudi. I recommend seeing any of his houses as well as his park. Architecture I've not seen anywhere else in the world. None of the places take a lot of time, but are so different and all have a wealth of info on Gaudi.

Worth the Trip. Was only staying in Barcelona for a few days so I wanted to stop by all the major attractions/sites. It was the latter part of the evening (around 9pm) and as I was walking by just to enjoy the exterior of Casa Mila i was surprised to see a group congregating inside. They host a late now tour for 1/2 price and we just made it. We were really excited. It comes with an audio tour in the language of your choosing Which was very convenient although the tour guide spoke English. It was so amazing to see the beautiful and unique design Gaudi created and to learn that there were still some people who resided in those apartments. Exploring the apartment was fun but the best part is of course the rooftop terrace. The view of Barcelona is breathtaking and we had a great time wandering and exploring. At the end we were greeted with a glass of cava. Had a wonderful time and would recommend it to anyone visiting BCN.

Ridiculous Admission Charge. I have never before cavilled about an entry fee but, at €20.50, this is simply ridiculous. I cannot recall a more overpriced "Attraction" in Europe. The influence of Gaudi and the Modernistas is all over Barcelona and can be enjoyed without this sort of price gouging.

For architecture lover. If you have time to spare while in Barcelona then I would recommend for you to visit this place and enjoy the architecture. This apartment by Gaudi is amazing and unique. However if you are not to fond on building architecture, on a tight budget and time is a factor, then I believe you can skip this attraction. Instead I would recommend that you visit La Sagrada Familia.

Yet another State of Art by Gaudi. As we all know this is one of Gaudi's masterpiece located in Barcelona. The uniqueness of the building structure is something one find it hard to build in today's world.. It's a shame i didn't enter the building .. But by just viewing the external view of the structure is impressive enough!!
just the terrace. the house is huge, but the only 21 eur - worth-visit site is the terrace with the view over BCN and the Gaudi chimneys..the rest is like a normal house in bcn,

Espectacular, if you love Gaudi. It's a great place to visit, the roof is amazing and the top floor has lots of explanations about how it came to be, very interesting with many models, very well done. The visit to the apartment is pretty cool, it's neat to see how it all flows together, lots of light, very pleasant. There are also some of Gaudi's furniture pieces, I sat in one and was surprised how comfortable it was. They told me seeing Casa Mila takes an hour but I would say scheduled at least 90 min, it's easy to wander and loose time. And the included audio guides are helpful. But €21 is a bit steep if you just 'like' Gaudi.

An Amazing building well worth seeing. Once upon a time there was an Architect called Gaudi , who must have been an engineer as well . This building has no columns the walls are all self supporting as is the roof structure . Its quite a feet in a world prior to computers and simulations . The spaces are wonderful , the roof is beautiful with its sculptural elements that act as chimineys and vent shafts for the building . The visit is about an hour and well worth it

Well worth seeing but book ahead of time. The tour is well worth the time and very interesting and easily reserved online for a specific time. While it's not always easy to be on a schedule, I prefer it to waiting in line. We found that right before dinner worked. We went here at 6:30 and to Casa Batllo afterwards then it was off to drinks and dinner.

Fascinating and worth the visit!. Le Pedrera is an apartment building designed by Gaudi, and open to the public for viewing on guided tours only. My wife and I went for the evening tour and found it to be fantastic. The foresight, planning, and style of this building were decades ahead of anything else. There are so many interesting diversions that it is tempting to stick around and take a few extra photos....but then you miss what the guide is saying. The rooftop at night is particularly enchanting and has a theme very reminiscent of Star Wars (not kidding)....makes you wonder where the inspiration for Star Wars costumes came from. Absolutely worth your time and hard-eared travel funds.

A must Stop..... If you are in Spain, for sure you will be guided by someone to go to La Pedrera. It's a beautiful piece of architecture that you must see to understand and appreciate. The lines to go in do form rapidly and can become really long. Go early to avoid the crowds.
Truly amazing. This is another Antoni Gaudi design and a must see while in Barcelona. The building is beautiful in its form and functionality.
Loved it!. Loved our self-tour of Gaudi's Casa Mila. Most of our time in Barcelona was taken up with Gaudi architecture.

Wonderful summer evening's concert. We visited La Pedrera as part of the summer evening concert events they hold. We loved our visit to Pedrera as we were able to look around the wonderful and quirky building but at a time when there were less people there so we had time to spend really taking it in and appreciating it. You get a headphone set so you can find out more about the rooms and about Gaudi's wonderful masterpiece.The building is astounding, Gaudi's imagination is unbelievable! We had a wonderful time looking around the building, taking in all the little quirky bits and interesting rooms. It was particularly lovely to go up on the roof terrace and watch the sunset whilst taking in the wonderful views of Barcelona and the towers on the rooftop.After having explored la pedrera we made our way down to another terrace and found a small table to sit at, ready for the concert to begin. You got one drink with your ticket and then were given a card so that you could have further drinks or small appetisers and they would be put on the card and you could pay at the end. Although we did not have the food, it looked delicious.The entertainment was wonderful and the singer had a beautiful voice and performed for around an hour before the set was finished. The entertainment did not go on for as long as we would have expected, but what they did they did well and it created a wonderful sound to sit and enjoy a beautiful summers evening. Although we went here last year, the memories are still fresh in my mind and helped to make our trip to Barcelona a memorable one.
Stunning. I was not inside the building,but I truly think it's stunning from the outside. If you have the chance, you should at least pass by.
Well worth a visit. Well worth a visit. It was one of the highlights of our trip. Seeing Gaudi creations in the flesh is spectacular something that doesn't come across in a book.

amazing experience. My experience in Casa Mila ( La pedrera) was absolutely famous and amazing. You must wait for ticket before entry ( we wait about 1 hour for ticket) This house has not any corner inside, wau, the view from roof was great. For me was La Pedrera better than Casa Batlo or Park Guell

If Gaudi's were alive today he still would be the king.. Brilliant. Gaudi was really a master architect and innovator. The shapes, forms and functionality were brilliantly conceived and then delivered. People are still in awe of his power and skill. Go and be overwhelmed.

Fabulous. Amazing functional design and layout
The tour inside the apartment was fantastic- seeing what this amazing man produced so many years ago . A must for Barcelona

Expensive. I'll be honest, we did not go in. We turned up by the premier entrance and were offered an entrance for 7 Euros (or so I thought) - fair I thought- fortunately the girl said at the moment there won't be any queues so try the normal entrance so we went and asked for two tickets...40 Euros!! Having come from Sagrada Familia and Park Guell which are less for a lot more I was staggered and declined it. We went back to the premier queue girl and said they wanted 40 Euros - Oh yes she says you pay that inside - I'm left wondering if she would have told me about the 40 euros up front or just taken my 7 Euros and let me find out too late..So it may be fabulous inside but but from what I read from others we made the right choice for us.

If you go to Barcelona this is a must do. A great human achievement of the imagination and architecture, book in advance and take the tour, it is well worth it and it will explain some of the unusual methods of design used by the master Gaudi, he literally tried to build with all the power and beauty nature has and like her he did not believe in straight lines. When you get to the top of the building you will see his other buildings through the sea monsters (chimneys), that is a great photo opportunity no one should miss.

Make this your first Gaudi sight.. This beautiful apartment building designed by Gaudi should be first on your list of Gaudi sites because it explains the evolution and development of his design philosophy and technique. You will appreciate Sagrada, Casa Battlo, etc. more if you go here first. It is advisable to get tickets ahead of time. For a few extra euros you can buy premium access which allows you to show up whenever you want and gain quick entry - well worth the cost!

Worth a Visit. This was a building I was not aware of until arriving in Barcelona and spotting it on the open top bus tour. We booked in for a tour and were not disappointed. The highlight of the tour for me is the roof terrace with some of Gaudi's fantastic chimneys and spectacular views over Barcelona. I would recommend booking in advance to avoid queuing. We were in La Pedrera for a couple of hours.

Evening jazz on the terrace. We didn't do the whole building as we were there for the evening jazz concert on the roof top. It was magical - truly gorgeous setting and the roof setting quite spectacular. Well worth getting tickets if you can.
Worth visiting . Fascinating place to visit. Well worth the money. Book in advance or go early to avoid the queues that build up by lunchtime
Unmissable. This is the most beautiful house and Gaudi's hand is everywhere. Such attention to detail is amazing and the chimneys are unmissable!

amazing architecture. I heard it for million times before going to Barcelona. it is easy to find and is really a shocking masterpiece by Gaudi.I met my friends accidentally in Casa Mila and we were shocked when we saw each other. so amazing!

Best Gaudí attraction in Barcelona.... To be honest, when I was planning my trip to Spain, seeing rooftop photos of La Pedrera/Casa Milà was the main reason I booked a trip to Barcelona. As a fan of architecture, I was intrigued by his work, and in Barcelona you can't go 2 minutes without hearing about or seeing something designed by Gaudí. As I stated, the rooftop terrace was my favorite part, each beautifully designed chimney stack reminding me of a chess piece. The view of Barcelona is incredible. I also loved the Attic, the above view from the ground floor courtyard, and the beautiful wrought-iron curved balconies (best viewed from street level). I'm telling you, this attraction is NOT to be missed.I will admit though, I found the interior rooms themselves/kitchen/furniture/etc. not as impressive, but that just may be me.

Advance night tickets no good if rain. We booked tickets in advance to see la Pedrera lit up at night and we disappointed that all evening tours were cancelled due to rain. We had a similar experience earlier in the day to go up into the towers in la Familia Sagrada. The rest of the cathedral, however, is always open rain or shine and the top attraction for us in Barcelona. Tess

Spectacular place to see.... Millions of tourists. So crowded , yet quintissential Gaudi architecture. Try to go late and you will miss crowds. Loved seeing the turn of century furniture and how the other half lived then

Nice building.... The building looks unique. I think it's a bit ex to go in and visit though. It is one of Gaudi's masterpiece. But men be careful. It's right in front of the Prada shop. So your lady may end up in the shop than admiring the Casa Mila.

Night Tour. We visited this building during the day and decided to do the night tour as we considered it would provide a different view. It was disappointing I appreciate that people live in the building but the tour consisted on a slide show in the entrance foyer, a trip in the lift to the attic where the exhibition was and then a film show rehashing what we had been told plus some footage of a seed being planted and a woman emerging from a pool played onto the ventilation shafts. The guide continually went on about this being the best Gaudi building and to a certain extent dismissed the other Gaudi works. The apartment that is open to the public during the day is shut to the night tour and frankly if you are going to visit I believe the day tour to be a better option.
Beautiful Building. Well worth a look around - especially with the audio tour! The roof top is absolutely stunning and gives you a great view out across the rest of the city.

Interesting to visit but a little expensive. This Gaudi house is located in the heart of the city and looks impressive from the outside. We had a tourist discount book from our hotel so we were able to get 10% off our entrance fee, although it is still quite expensive at nearly 20 euros pp. Entry includes an audio guide. The best part of the house is the rooftop with great views of Barcelona, but the inside apartments are also of interest.
Interesting. A little pricey and expected more inside. Probably wouldn't be back. Good to see Gadi's architecture house at least once though.

Expected a little more. We doubted about visiting la Pedrera or Casa Battlo and chose to visit la Pedrera first. We especially liked the roof of the building and were not so interested in the furniture which is displayed in the apartment. It was worth seeing one of Gaudi's buildings in Barcelona (besides Sagrada Familia of course), but we skipped Casa Battlo of our itinerary, partly due to the pretty high entrance fee.

Ranks fourth on the list of four Gaudi places we visited. We followed advice to add this to our visit to La Sangrada Familia and Parc Guell, and it is good to see, especially the fascinating rooftop goblin-like heads that top the chimneys, but we later visited Palau Guell and found it far superior to Casa Mila, with its own fantasy roof but a much better audio guide and more to see.
GAUDI LOVELY NOT CHEAP. Not cheap like 15 to 20 USD to visit this I am not sure of is worthy maybe better go to Park Gueil and is free also gaudi heritage

Another Great Gaudi experience. Walking back from Park Guell we stopped in and enjoyed this tour. The more Gaudi you see, the more his genius is realized. How did this man do so much? His work is so important to the architectural world and this tour helps you realize it. The roof top is amazing, we wished we had time to come back at night. It's unfortunate that the costs are on the high side, I think everyone needs to be able to see and interact with his work.

Very neat, but a little pricey. This is a neat house to visit if you like architecture and design. The cost was 20.50 euros a piece, so it was kind of expensive. It was fun to see, but I love HGTV and seeing the inside of houses. One floor is furnished the way it would have originally been, so that was fun to see.
Beautiful . Absolutely beautiful home! It is a must see for any art fan just to see what is possible when you're different from the norm.

Great rooftop. Although I preferred Casa Battlo, Casa Mila has a very unique rooftop and furniture in the rooms. I would recommend visiting both, if possible. We experience a short line after four in the afternoon and the attraction is suitable for strollers and wheelchairs.

Amazing rooftop, its a must see on a short trip to Barcelona. This was the most stunning rooftop I've ever seen. We booked online and paid a premium to be able to visit at anytime (27 EUR) rather than a set timeslot, which was well worth it as the weather was overcast and we were able to go when there was a bright blue sky against the rooftop. Stunning exterior of building too. I was initially unsure if we would visit this sight but I am so glad I went up to the roof, it was one of my favourite things to do in Barcelona. You may want to time a visit when its less busy if you are into photography (we were there around lunchtime and there were a fair few visitors on the rooftop), you end up with a lot of other visitors in the photos when its busy or waiting until they have moved on. Fantastic experience, totally recommend it.

no sorry but no!. i am really disappointed! first fromthe price!!!!! then because we had to wait 15 minutes due to bad personal (only 5 persons before us), exagerated security sytem, then again a check of a ticket.... nothing special inside and more than 20 euro per person!!!!! DONT GO THERE
Nighttime walk on the roof.. Le Pedredra is quite unique. See it night and day to experience different aspect a living, breathing piece of architectural history..

Very cool. Our family of four enjoyed this much more than Sagrada Familia, although both are can't miss places for visitors to Barcelona. Maybe because this building is complete, and so amazing that Gaudi was so far ahead of his time.

Amazing apartment building. We thoroughly enjoyed the self guided tour, booked at the Barcelona tourist information centre. Gaudi was a genius and miles ahead of the times when he designed this building, built in 1906. A unique building.

Nice views from top of building. We enjoyed our visit. The different smoke stacks on top is where you start the visit. The different styles and views are great. You work your way down each floor to see what you like.

Make time to visit at night . We bought the day and night pass for La Padrera and were not disappointed! The day time tour allowed you to explore the building and learn plenty about Gaudi and his work. The night time show is highly recommended. It involves a tour with a tour guide and then a light show on the rooftop followed by a glass of cava. You get a deal with both a day and night pass too. €20.50 for day and €34 for night separate but €37 for both together.

A phenomenal Gaudi Art work not to be missed. There is another Casa of Gaudi on the Passeig de Gracia and I would recommend to visit both as they are pretty different and will give you a full picture of what the genius could imagine.Like other Gaudi and Modern houses in Barcelona, the photos are worth a thousand words !All the bestStephane

Very Interesting. This is a fascinating house with great examples of Gaudi's works. The rooftop is particularly interesting and also has great views.We came on a Sunday morning and the queue was minimal. It is not cheap, but very much a "must see". The night time viewing would also be an interesting experience.

La Pedrera (Mila House) never disappoints. What a wonderful building and another lovely masterpiece by Gaudi. One of the "must see" things in Barcelona but very worth the time. Absolutely awesome attraction!

Night Tour of La Pedera. My daughters and I did a late night tour of La Pedera and it was well worth it.The tour began with the interior courtyard and took us through the attic/museum area. It include time on Gaudi's surrealistic rooftop, with a light show that was simply amazing.Great views of the city as well. the experience concluded with a glass of cava in the courtyard. A fun evening!

Wonderful architecture and well curated exhibit. When we visited La Pedrera, the facade was hidden behind construction scaffolding. However, the inside was more than amazing to make-up for this. The ticket line personnel were quick and courteous, and I appreciated that they brought families with young children (like ours) to a different line, so everything seemed to move much faster. There is a locker facility for strollers and backpacks, once inside the gates.Even the wait for the elevator is lovely, since you walk through the organically shaped interior courtyard with apartment windows facing in and sunlight streaming down from above.The tour begins on the rooftop, which is more beautiful than you'd imagine an apartment roof top to be. There are great sculptures where the chimney flues are and recycled glass bottle walls, as well as great vistas of the city. (It can get scorchingly hot since it is a roof, in the city, in Spain so go early, late or wear a hat).Inside the attic is a nice mini-history of Gaudi exhibit with videos, photos and edificio models- my children really liked this part, especially the chairs to sit on and the cool interior.I enjoyed the Beaux Arts/ turn-of the century staging of the apartment portion of the tour. It is easy to imagine how lovely it would have been to have lived in such a light-filled, gracious apartment overlooking Paseo de Gracia.The bookstore was a notch above the usual tourist store. It had pretty trinkets and many different architecture and Gaudi books in various languages.After your tour, there are lots of nearby cafes to relax in the shade.

Beautiful . It's a fabulous work by Gaudi that stands in the middle of an also great avenue. This is a must visit place if you are into Arquitecture and art (or even if you're not, it's well worth it!)

Ridicously overpriced. We didn't actually go in as we couldn't get our head around the entrance fee. Think about it: the ticket to visit this house is more expensive than Uffizi or Academia gallery in Florence, Louvre museum in Paris, or even the neighboring Sagrada Familia (a much more majestic work of the same artist - Gaudi)!

A Must See. Best to get advance time entry tickets--it's easy to get online. Gaudi designed the exterior/interior/furniture/hardware (basically everything) in this apartment building built between 1906-1912 for the Mila family whose apartment was on the second level. The family lived here for 20 years and tenants still live on the upper floors. The Audio was quite good with tours beginning on the roof with its 30 some colorful chimneys and ventilation towers. The attic's many brick arches support the roof and now house an interesting museum with very good audio visuals about Gaudi, the current events of his time and his works. The next floor was a 19th c apartment with a large kitchen, separate servant's dining room, children's room, servant's bedroom, a very large modern bathroom, bedroom, lovely living room and dining room separated by sliding doors and master bedroom with an adjoining bath. The curvy handles and ergonomically designed furniture were both functional and beautiful. The gift store on the lower level has a variety of well priced books, jewelry and other items that are perfect for education as well as gifts. Save enough time to see everything without being rushed.

Really Interesting and beautiful. We took the night tour. It was a group of less than 50 people. The inside was interesting and informative, but the roof . . . Wow! They offered a music and light show that was memorable. And champagne afterward. Pure delight!

Amazing ! Amazing !. This apartment building designed by Gaudi is one of the most unique structures I have seen. It is an amazing combination of functionality and creative architecture. For architects this is a must see. For the rest of us it is also a must see.

Essential Gaudi. We only had time to visit one of the Gaudi houses on Passeig de Gracia, so we chose La Pedrera (Casa Mila). We did not reserve tickets online so we aimed for very late afternoon (between 5 and 6 pm) and it was the perfect time...only a short line to buy tickets and enter. We did not feel rushed exploring the roof (best part of the tour) and got some good pictures. I also enjoyed the beautiful interior and courtyard area. Gaudi had such a unique vision! The audio guide was very helpful. (Note: they show a short video during the tour of the apartment...skip it if you don't have time. The video showed footage from the time period of Gaudi but not much about Gaudi or his work). I would definitely visit La Pedrera to see some essential Gaudi architecture. Tip: In general, we found that late afternoon was the ideal time to visit other top attractions (Sagrada Familia, Picasso Museum) if you are not able to reserve online and commit to a definite time.
Fabulous imagination. We did the night tour and light show, which was great. The views form the roof are wonderful, and the rooftop itself is inspired.Highly recommended

Definitely worth a visit though not exactly cheap but.... If you are interested in Gaudí or architecture in general then this place is definitely worth a visit. A word of caution though - get there early as the queues can be quite long.Another word of caution - one can pre-book tickets for this venue but when we visited, the queue for collecting pre-booked tickets was longer than the queue for buying tickets on the day!If you are staying in a hotel, ask the receptionist for a book of discount vouchers. These are pretty readily available and will give you a 10% discount on the entry price. Every little helps!!La Pedrera (also known as Casa Milá) was a pretty outlandish piece of architecture when it was first built and encountered considerable resistance from the planners. However, it is now of course regarded as an iconic building and another testament to Gaudí's genius.The roof-top and attic are particularly unusual but, because so many people are 'pushed through' this attraction, that getting some decent photographs is quite challenging.Don't be put off too much by the queues. It is worth the wait.
Unique. A different kind of museum. Unique. Interesting. A must see when in Barcelona. Wish it can be cheaper. Its not a really big museum.Location is excellent, close to many stores, metro stations.

My Favourite Gaudi Visit. This was a good visit. My favourite Gaudi site of our trip. We bought tickets online in advance [night before] so no queuing.  After going through the ground floor of the courtyards [which are arranged beautifully themselves] you are taken straight up to the roof. Where I could of sat all day. It is a very special space. But if you are very timid of heights be warned it is a bit vertiginous. The parapet is fairly low around the outer edge and with the changes in levels you do feel a bit exposed. The attic space under the roof is almost as perfect with its thin thin brick arches. The apartment is furnished in period [although doesn't manage to convey the feeling of having been lived in like that - more museum and less apartment] .Then the temporary exhibition space in which we saw an extensive exhibition of documentary and promotional photography.You get an audio guide included which for that sort of thing is quite good with some musical interludes. It was starting to annoy me towards the end as these things tend to. I dislike being told what I will of noticed and some of the level of the commentary was aggravatingly shallow but as attempts go it was a good one. Exiting through the gift shop twice! [ one near the end and one at the end] and the scheme for getting your photo taken in front of a green screen etc cheapens it a bit.All in all I felt like I got a lot of visit for my money. The roof is the star attraction by a long way but most of the rest adds on.

A Remarkable Building. We are certainly glad we took the time to tour Mila House. If you were unable to purchase tickets online, do not be deterred by the line-ups. In our experience they moved pretty quickly. We could have spent hours on the rooftop alone - the structures are incredible, considering when they were built. But the tour through other parts of the building was also very interesting as it explained many of the concepts behind much of Gaudi's work.

A Magical Night in Barcelona. We took the night tour and it was magnificent! After touring the building they took us to the roof top for an incredible light and projection show on the very unusual shaped chimneys. It was one of my favorite memories of the trip. After the light show they had a reception for us in the lobby with Cava which is their local type of champagne. Before your tour be sure to have dinner at eh Cafe Pedrera but make reservations ahead. It was a wonderful evening.

Gaudi at his best. A UNESCO World Heritage site and you can can see why. For me Gaudi is great and Barcelona is full of his work which is why this city is a great place to visit. Go visit this building along with others to see the beauty of Gaudi

Well worth the visit. We visited La Pedrera yesterday as part of our Gaudi day in Barcelona. We started with La Pedrera at 9 am, when it opened, followed by Sagrada Familia at noon and Park Guell at 3. For all three sites we had booked tickets with timed entries online, which made life a lot easier. The lines at Sagrada Familia, in particular, were very long. Booking the tickets online is easy - waiting in long lines to get them on-site is not.La Pedrera was fascinating, with an audio-tour that comes with entry that is quite helpful, though it's easy to miss the numbered sites and get behind. The tour starts on the roof, with great views of the city, followed by a tour of the attic - my favorite part of the tour. The attic was beautiful, with vaulted brick ceilings filled with displays about both Gaudi and the Mila House. You then get to tour one of the apartments in La Pedrera with original furnishings. All in all a well laid out tour, which took us about an hour and a half to complete. Of the three sites we visited that day, this would be our second favorite, behind Sagrada Familia.

The nightime show puts this over the top - amazing.. I love the work of Gaudi, so of course had to visit this house. They were currently having a nighttime show: "Gaudí’s Pedrera: The Origins.” This included projections and lights highlighting the architecture, and an altogether beautiful audiovisual show on the roof terrace - which is the highlight of the house. While I prefer Casa Batlo, with the show this experience equally equaled (possibly surpassed) my visit to all other of Gaudi's structures.

Excellent Gaudi Masterpiece. Along Passeig de Gracia. Stop for red/blue hop on hop off bus.We visited La Pedrera because it's UNESCO World Heritage site. Indeed it is. The rooftop is unique, every angle is different. Truly a masterpiece.we went in a 7pm tour, and we were not able to see everything coz they close around 8pm. Tip: go in the afternoon around 6pm and the line is empty. We did online but we regretted it coz you can get 10% off when you purchase a hop on hop off ticket.

Gaudi again. The building is just beautiful. As long as people are living in this house, you cannot visit it from inside. But go to the top, it is possible and enjoy not only Gaudi art, but very nice views from the city.

Rooftop. I wanted to see the rooftop and it was interesting - lots of steps and great views of the city. Lots of people there. Buy tickets online - you can do it if you are in the queue- saves waiting!

Without Gaudi where would Barcelona be?. The Pedera is worth a visit but not worth it if you will miss the casa de Batllo. The roof top is not to be missed. Because the building has been bought by different owners some of the interesting features have been ruined.

Excellent attraction. I really enjoyed the designs by Gaudi on the top. Personally this is what I came for. The tour was alright and the inside was ok but the roof was really what I found special. Definitely worth paying for it. The outside is quite nice as well.

A must for those wanting to understand Gaudis work. We did not have time to visit casa batllo, so I have no comparison, but we have spend an amazing afternoon walking through la pedrera, having a good done audio guide with is it was an ideal insight into Gaudi's life, philosophy and magic of his creation! Really fastinating, don't miss the walk on the roof top! Ticket costs 21 euro, audio guide inclusive, plan approx 2 hours to visit.
Interesting but too expensive to get in. it is an interesting experience and fun, but it is 20.50 euros for a adult ticket, overpriced in my opinion.

Nice but expensive. La pedrera is one of those building that you have the feeling of "I need to see it" my first visit to Barcelona a couple of years ago, I refuse to pay such a high entrance fee and this time I just did it without thinking much about it. Saw it and that' s it. If you have to choose based on running a low budget, save the money and choose the Sagrada Familia, I think this is the best work of architecture that reflects the glory of Gaudi as a master.I disagree with such a high entrance entrance fee but it is always crowded and tourist will not stop visiting it, so if you wait for justice for low budget travellers like I did, it will not happen, prices will remain, so up to you to prioritize according t your travel budget.

The roof top is memorable.. Not as impressive as the Sagrada and the Casa Batllo but the roof top is delightful. The entrance foyer was pretty with a lot of pastel used on the walls, and to think Gaudi thought of underground parking back then already is amazingly creative. The walk through the living quarters of a typical apartment was average. The visit through the attic is like a visit to a Gaudi museum.

Mesmerizing!. Wonderful, innovative, awesome building.
Gaudi was very talented and brave to design architecture that is this whimsical.
Really a must-see.

Another of Antoni Gaudi's works. Another masterful work by Antoni Gaudi, he was employed to build this structure for a wealthy aristocrat, to date a lot of the apartments are occupied by either offices or households. There are some really good displays of Gaudi's work, he was not only an architect but also a designer of many things like door/cupboard handles, chairs etc. This is definitely worth seeing as I'm sure you will appreciate it as much as me

Gaudi's Stone Quarry in the City. A unique genius reflected in this amazing apartment block. Tolkien must have visited and been inspired (surely)! Too expensive but I can't really knock off a star (blob) for that.
After Sagrada and Batllo La Pedrera Is The Third. Beautiful and functional design of the building. Every detail and solution has a role. The rooftop is fantastic. The view is breathtaking.
Good. A trip here would hold interest for people who are not necessarily interested in architecture. I especially liked the woodwork.

Gaudi at his best? Personal Opinion. The trip (not cheap and if you intend to pay with a debit/credit card you will need photo ID) was very well organised - You enter (obviously) at the ground floor and then start the tour from the roof - A lift (elevator for those of you from different climes) takes you to the roof where you observe Gaudi's principles that rooftops need not be 'boring' - Then you descend into the attic and on to the apartment.You are supplied with an audio guide pretty much covering most languages and there are prominent signboards and explanations as you descend the levels explaining the designs, the theory and models of methods Gaudi used to complete the designs. Fascinating and very informative - the staff on hand were very nice and helpful - a little expensive, maybe BUT worth the visit.

Rooftop chimneys and great city view. The highlight of this attraction is the rooftop chimneys and the great views of the city, including a good viewpoint to Sagrada Familia. It is certainly expensive (over 20 euros per person) and that adds up for families - children will be less impressed with things like architecture and Gaudi's models. Given the choice between Casa Mila and Casa Battlo, I would recommend Casa Battlo.However, if you have the cash and the inclination to see both... then Casa Mila is a fine excursion. By tickets online to avoid the lines and plan for about an hour for the average tourist interest level. We enjoyed this attraction.

Try the nighttime event - Origins. Having seen Casa Batllo during the day we thought we'd try the nighttime program at Casa Mila. The house is fascinating (if you are into Gaudi) and the light show on top is a lot of fun, if a bit cheesy. You get a great view of the neighborhood and spend about 20 minutes or so up there - followed by some Cava when you finish. What is not to like?
very good. very good place but i prefer casa battlo ,easy to find in passei di gracia,i think it is not necessary buy in advance ,the line was ok.
Intriguing. Upon visiting Barcelona, don't miss Gaudi's masterpiece, "Casa Mila", or La Pedrera. You can also visit during night-time for a night-experience. The entrance costs around 18 euros.
Go!. I was wandering through this section of town and decided to visit this place. It is so unique. They provide a free audio guide with entry, which is very informative.

Very wheelchair friendly. The more I go to this place, the more I love it.One of our party was in a wheel chair and the staff were fantastic. They couldn't have been more helpful and it's really wheelchair friendly.If you want to go up to the roof, you will have to climb a few steps though, so if you can't walk at all you'll miss this bit.All in all a fabulous time and well worth the money.

If you're in barcelona, you've gotta see this place!. Whatever your interested in, this building is amazing and definitely worth a visit. I went with my grandmother and we both found "la pedrera" amazing. We both usually loath audio guides, or any guides for that matter, but actually the guide was clear and extremely well done. I'm sad I didn't get to see it by night, given the reviews, but if you want to go by day I can tell you it is still amazing.

must do for architects, if u love to c period lifestyle . Gaudi's other masterpiece. Not as colourful as battlo but as innovative. Also contains architectural models and details of his other buildings and construction so a must do for architects. Not as pleasing to the eye for laymen. Lower rating primarily as it tends to become expensive (21 euros per person) when u add all monuments in case you want to prioritise. It's a great place to see period lifestyle as this building also has furniture, beds, kitchen, bathrooms designed and maintained as per that period so you get a vivid display of life in that era.
Go for the late night light show!. Worth every euro to see the light show at night! Very special experience! Some cava and pastries end the night! A must!

Definitely worthwhile. We visited on a gorgeous day - you could see for miles from roof and got great photos of La Sagrada Familia. We took our time, enjoyed the exhibits in the attic. Purchase your tickets online ahead of time!

Chimneys are the highlight. Chimneys, chimneys, chimneys!!!entrance ticket includes audio tour.The rooftop is beautiful with great views of Barcelona as you wander along the walkways between the chimneys.Attic is a feat of construction....over 300 brick archways, all of slightly differing size & shape. There are several good video screens in the attic area showing Gaudi's other works with good information commentary.People still live & work in most of the apartments. One apartment is open to the public & included in the tour. It is furnished with items from the era the apartments were built. I'd have liked to have seen more of gaudi's own design furniture in there, but perhaps that would have been risky due to the value of the items & the large number of people wandering through.Worth visiting for the chimneys alone, the rest is a bonus.
A must. Can not miss the piece of architecture.. Gaudi does not need any other comment that what history wrote. I can say what a visionary man. Very happy to see one of his master pieces

A night at the museum, excellent!. A visit with an English speaking guide late in the evening was a very nice experience. She explained everything very well and we had time to look for our self. The lights and music up on the roof was the best part of al for me. A glass if cava in the end before leaving out in the night was also nice.

Spectacular. This was awesome....great insight into Gaudi and his designs for the building itself, the furniture, the lifestyle. Be sure to spend time on the roof and enjoy the views of the city all around but also appreciate the way Gaudi designed the roof to take in cool air and so forth. I loved touring the apartment...gave you a sense of how a wealthy Catalonian would live around the turn of the 20th century.

Walk, walk, walk.... Gaudi another Gaudi, another Gaudi... all in walking distance from the famous church. close to Las Ramblas too. But you can also take the Metro close by. If you tired of walking take one of the hop on hop off tour buses (best value 2 days). Check out the souvenir shop and take lot's of pictures. Inside visit (fee). recommended as all the other Gaudi attractions in Barcelona. MeuterMedia
The strangest house. Interesting, yet very odd.Nice to look at but a bit expensive.My kids could not appreciate architecture and were a bit bored

Good view of Gaudi's work. Good look at Gaudi's work for an apartment house. Good audio guide. On-line ticket was for any time of the day but there were no lines in late May so a ticket could be purchased on the spot. Good audio guide.

Interesting but disappointed . Went to the 2 Gaudi houses in the area. Casa Batllo was the better tour of the 2. The roof, which is the most photographed part of this house is where the visit begins. The rest of the visit is disappointing. If time is limited, skip it and visit Casa Batllo.

A unique piece of architecture but spoilt by oversupply of tourists. A truly magnificent building that lives up to Gaudi's name. Full of interesting features and centrally located. Avoid the queue by purchasing tickets online. We brought ours online after seeing the long queue which allowed us to have a relaxing lunch before we enter the building at our designated time. However the journey up to the rooftop is less pleasant as they try to ram as many tourists as possible into a small lift. Once there the chimneys will give you plenty of amusement and photo spots but again not easy to get round with the large flux of visitors fighting over the same photo spots. The ground is not level and paths are narrow, so extra care must be taken, difficult for families with strollers and wheelchair users. The tour of the top floor apartment was good but not amazing to be frank. Overall, this trophy building is not to be missed, but it doesn't have as much wow factors compared the the Sagrada Familia, and certainly should not cost more to visit.

Wow!. One of the most amazing things you learn when visiting this absolutely unique building is that all but one apartment - the one opened to visitors - is lived/worked in. Real people live in this fantasy! Before our visit we had lunch in the building's restaurant - that in itself was an experience.

Gaudi's Finest Work--Now Reopened. This was an apartment house designed by Modernist Architect Antonin Gaudi' for the Mila family, an industrialist. The style is unbelievable, even if you don't like modernist works. It has undergone several ownerships (even a bingo parlor). The foundation has now reopened it for tours. Don't stand in line: make your reservation online and save an hour in line. You see the lobby, the rooftop, an apartment, and a stunning museum in the attic. If you are interested in architecture, just getting in the attic is marvelous, so you can see the constructions techniques. The entry fee is about 15 Euros.
Beautiful. Definitely take the tour with a guide. You will obtain SO much information on Gaudi the man and his history. Very worthwhile and beautiful building.

This place is incredible. As with any Gaudi creation, it is designed to inspire and amaze you. One could easily spend hours wandering through the building, checking out the famous rooftop, and photographing the sculptures. Highly recommend to all Barcelona visitors.

Magical Building. We visited Casa Mila with our 3 year old daughter who absolutely loved it, especially the roof. There are A LOT of stairs to climb to the top, which again our daughter loved, and when you arrive at the top you are just bowled over by the design of the whole building. It's one thing looking at this building from the street, it's quite another seeing just how mad it is from the roof.I'm a Gaudi fan and seeing his work up close and 'experiencing' it was wonderful. Seeing a fully furnished flat inside is great too.Book in advance as you can then skip the long queue.
One of the greatest Gaudi's projects. If you are interested to see Gaudi's work, then you must visit it. Is a unique building, great example of Gaudi's way of thinking.

Love Gaudi's architecture - see it on a 'small scale'. We purchased VIP tickets which were excellent. We only had one day in Barcelona and were seeing Sagrada Familia as well so didn't know what time we would arrive. The VIP entrance and no set time worked really well and we avoided quite a long queue. My favourite parts were the roof and the attic. Excellent and well set up displays in the attic. The roof was amazing. The gift shop had some of the nicest gifts I have seen in a tourist attraction and many of them were made locally which I love.
Another Gaudi Design. Another gem by Gaudi in the heart of central Barcelona. Get here early if you want to take a tour.....it gets crowded!

Roof top is something else!!!. The roof top is something else- so impressive and the view from up there is incredible!! But the inside is just as picturesque- different rooms and examples of his furniture. This really wasn't on my list of things to see but our travel agent added it to our tour- glad that she did.

Great rooftop and attic but all areas overcrowded and not worth the high price. We got there early, which helped, but it quickly got crowded, and the apartment they show you is not sumptuous, with authentic Gaudi furniture. It was a small apartment with period pieces and claustrophobic for me (and that takes a lot of people), and the attic was filled with videos that could be seen on You Tube? I didn't go in there to see movies and slides. Hard to photograph, better to buy a nice Gaudi book even before the trip (and do check amazon); mine was waiting at home!

Least favorite of the otherwise exceptional Gaudi sites. i was surprised by my disappointment with the evening tour. I throughly enjoyed Casa Batllo and Park Guell, and was astounded by Sagrada Familia. I don't think I was overdosed on Gaudi by the time I got to La Padrera, and the building's exterior and lobby are exceptional, but also mostly visible without paying for the tour. For the money, you basically get to walk through the "attic," which houses a nice musuem depicting the home's construction, but the light show obscures rather than highlights the beauty of the roof chimneys, and I suspect Gaudi was rolling his eyes at the whole show from his crypt. Also, be warned, you do not get to see one of the apartments as part of the night tour, that is only on the day tour.

Gorgeous Cafe with delicious food. We did not tour the Gaudi House, Casa Pderera except to look at the exterior, but we did have lunch in the gorgeous cafe, inside where we could appreciate the Gaudi ceilings and interior space. The service was excellent and the food was both beautiful and delicious.

Must Visit For Gaudi Lovers. You should see all those extravagant sometimes bizarre homes along the "Avenue of Discordia" this one is no exception, unlike Casa Batllo this building was entirely designed by Gaudi. Yes it's expensive but this no ordinary building!!! Go

Mystical place. La Pedrera is one of the best place to see in Barcelona and it's absolutely worth of its fee. Guide is included in price and gives you a lot of useful information about the building, Gaudi's life, ways of work and inspiration. It's easy to say that the roof is the best, but honestly, only several places is able to push your mind in this way. You start a trip with an elevator straight to the roof and then going downstairs to the ground floor. Excellent place.

Gaudi's Art Nouveau Masterpiece. On our recent whirlwind march inland from the Mediterranean to Paris, we spent two nights in Barcelona. This was not our first trip to the city. In 2001 we'd visited the narrow corridor from the airport to the seaport and back. That's barely enough for a first impression. This time I had the better part of two days to take a closer look at the city and particularly two architectural works by the Spanish turn-of-the-century architect, Antonio Gaudi. I wanted to see his famous Sagrada Familia church and his brilliant, Art Nouveau, apartment complex, la Casa Mila (known more commonly to the locals as La Pedrera--the stone quarry). If you're visiting, keep in mind it may be listed on maps either way. There's much more to see in Barcelona than that but we were on a tight schedule and in any case, could not have done justice to any attractions if we'd included other attractions.We in the 21st-century are somewhat accustomed to seeing radical architecture, and even today, Casa Mila would appear to fit easily into that category. Imagine then, what the Barcelonans must have felt and thought around 1906-10 when Antonio Gaudi's apartment house and home for the wealthy businessman, Pere Mila and his wife, Roser, began to take shape. The style was called Art Nouveau and Gaudi was not exactly an unknown entity at the time. His Casa Batllo on the same street (Passeig de Gràcia) dated from as early as 1877. However, it was Romantic in style, only slightly resembling the new Mila home with its wavy lines and impressive height, not to mention a undulating roofline topped with whimsical sculptural chimneys (right) unlike anything imaginable at the time . In fact, the floor plan reveals there was hardly a rectangular room in the entire building. With its seven floors, six of which containing four spacious, luxury apartments, (plus a huge attic and underground parking garage) Pere Mila was getting his (wife's) money's worth.Gaudi's radical new Art Nouveau styling did not stop with the sweeping and swooping of his carved stone façade. Two well-like open air courtyards brought an airy lightness to even the interior rooms of each apartment (two apartments shared an elevator and stairwells). Even the attic (or perhaps, especially the attic) was radical, its hyperbolic arches resembling the ribs of a giant whale, except that they were made from shaped bricks. Whereas most roofs are treated by architects as necessary nuisances of no other function than not leaking, Gaudi's Casa Mila roof more nearly resembles rolling hills or ocean waves, a delightful fantasy experience in and of themselves, not to mention an impressive view of the Barcelona skyline. Today, only one apartment is open to the public. The rest of the building serves as office space for the organization owning and managing the structure. The single apartment presents some fascinating anachronisms as the Victorian furniture tries to appear comfortable inside curvilinear rooms that even today, would present an interior decorator with some vexing problems.(Gaudi custom designed Art Nouveau style furniture for the Mila's apartment.)Even before the house was completed, Mila's wife complained to Gaudi that without straight walls, she had nowhere to place her much beloved grand piano (which she played exceedingly well). Gaudi's reaction was typical: "So, play the violin." The Milas occupied the ground floor of the building with the upper levels carved (an exceedingly accurate term) into some twenty surprisingly large apartments. The attic contained the laundry and storage space. Today it features an insightful museum display of architectural models, drawings, and historic photos of the building. Tickets are 27 euros (roughly $30.) and best ordered online to avoid waiting in line.

Great views from the roof. The roof provides spectacular views of the city. We booked ahead on line to skip the queue and went early, which meant we could go at our own pace. We were provided with audio sets which provide information about whichever area you were in. Slightly overpriced- but must a must for Gaudi fans.

Excellent example of Gaudi's work with lots of info about him also. Do this before you do the Sagrade Familia for an intro to Gaudi! I felt I learnt a lot and it was a good introduction to his work.
Gorgeous fairytale building with 1920s apartment.
I booked ahead so save queueing up. It took about 1 1/2 hours to go round.
Gaudi attraction. Great architecture. Passed it many times (our hotel was a block away) and took many pictures each time! Cost to go inside was 27 Euro per person!

Not a straight line in the place. As others have said the roof is the best part although it scared me to death as there are no walls just wire netting.I thought entry was a bit expensive but then it can't accommodate that many people at one time.

A Place to Encourage the Artist in Us. Casa Mila is Gaudi's domestic masterpiece. It is constantly moving in its design. Rolling, undulating movement from basement to attic. Even his wood furniture moves in its stillness. Movement, always movement, that is Gaudi's intent and his signature. His organic forms are drawn from life, from tree bark and skulls and skeletons. He was not only revolutionary in his time. He is revolutionary in ours. His vision was singular and universal. Precious few can share his vision, but at least we can try to emulate it in whatever form our passion cares to take.

Dissapointing experience. If you get here after visiting Palau Guell, Sagarda Familia and Park Guell, you might be as disappointed as we were - considering the high price (20.5 Euros) of entrance, only the rooftop worth your visit (even if reminds the rooftop of Palau Guell a little), but inside the house you'll see same Gaudi building models that you have already seen, a movie about him, and an apartment from the turn of the previous century - if you've seen those somewhere else in the past, there's nothing new for you to see here.

The Origins . I want to help you decide whether or not to take The Origins tour at La Pedrera. I did. I don't regret it, but I wouldn't do it again. Pros> Tour groups for the night presentation are small so you get the place almost to yourself. > The light show on the roof top is spectacular. With a good camera (one that does well at night) you'll get phenomenal photos not possible during the day. > Because of the later start time, your day is wide open, which is great if you have limited time and want to cram as much in as possible. Cons> 34€ is too expensive for this tour, really, but it's the only way to see the light show on the roof. > The shop and cafe are closed at night, so no souvenirs unless you return during the day. > The tour is pretty short.
