An hour, I think. And once the roof show is finished, you're not really welcome to hang out up there. They don't kick you out, but they don't leave the roof lit so you can take pictures either. They really want you to leave so the next group can come out to see the show. I'm glad I went because of the small crowd and light show, but it was a bit pricey for this budget-conscious traveler.

Imaginative to the max. This residential building is like no other. The building is more sculptured than a normal typical building. To go back and design a facade like the one on this building today might seem like the norm but to go back in the early 1900's? Geez this guy was good.

The roof may be the best part of this incredible building!. Definitely get tix online that give you special entry any day/time and get the audio guide.Learned a lot about Gaudi and his design workings in the museum. Nice to see apartment furnished as it would have been. Innovative man ahead of his time. The level below the roof is actually another roof of sorts...top of building is so whimsical and great views!
Stunning. Don't miss this one. The roof alone is worth the ticket. Make sure you buy tickets online as the queues can been rather long.

We Were Very Impressed. This building is a living museum, and quite impressive even for today. The tour includes the upper attic level, roof and a large apartment. All I can say is it is unlike any other tour we have had and was most enjoyable.

Insightful-impressive-accessible look into the mind of Gaudi. I was thoroughly impressed by the tour of La Pedrera. I had gone to La Sagrada Familia the day before, so I was not sure that this tour would even compare, and I was hesitant to spend the euro 21.50. Though nothing compares to the Sagrada Familia in scope, I found this home to be much more accessible. The tour included and audio guide and I got to the house just before 9:30 and there was no line! The tour begins on the roof, which is just a fanciful playground even for adults. I guarantee you that you will smile when you see it. The tour continues in the attic, where there are a plethora of demonstrations and audioguide information on Gaudi's architectural style, geometric models, nature-based inspiration, ergonomic furniture, etc. The models include other projects that Gaudi completed including Park Güell and Casa Batllá, so I felt like I truly got both an overview of Gaudi's complete works and an in-depth look into his artistic/architectural process. Keep in mind that this was the last project Gaudi completed, and he had full control over the building and design process (unlike Casa Batllá, which had a skeleton building in place -- though I'm sure the tour is still impressive) so it shows his full range of talent. If you have 2 or 3 hours to spare in Barcelona, I highly recommended a trip here.
A Must See. A stroll on the Passeig Gracia is wonderful. Many beautiful buildings to see but this is one of the best.

Gaudi's remarkable building.. From the outside this looks like an amazing structure, but it gets even better as you go inside. A lift takes you up to the roof where the curves and staircases invite exploration and there are great views. On the way down you can visit the museum in the attic and see an apartment complete with period furniture.

Another interesting Gaudi building. Barcelona sports world famous architecture, the most famous of which is Gaudi. There are several other architects of Gaudi's period that were also outstanding, but not as famous. La Pedrera is an example of an apartment complex that Gaudi designed and executed. It is definitely worth a visit, but I would suggest seeing this building before going to the Sagrada Familia. Compared to the Sagrada, the other Gaudi sites are not as awe inspiring. I particularly found the vaulting and ribs of the roof structure very interesting...I have to believe that this was done free form without tight blue print control. Gaudi, in general, reminds me of the freedom of expression that a child has when they discover mold-able and malleable wet beach sand for the first time, spending a whole day making castles, tunnels and moats.
Night time visit to La Padrera. To visit La Padrera at night is such a different and amazing experience. The roof top being a high light of the visit.

Beautiful example of Gaudi's genius. A beautiful example of Gaudi's genius work, right in the middle of Barcelona. Plan to buy tickets and audio guide for the best touring experience. Tour take about 1 hour. Most of toured space is handicap accessible except for the roof. A must see.
Outside is interestingly beautiful. Only seen the outside, but very interesting! Bigger than I thought. Worth the visit and I imagine the inside is just as interesting.

Open Your Mind. Simply superb. This is an amazing building that just gets better and better as you walk through. So much detail to see and admire. You get a good view from the roof as well, you can see La Sagrada Famillia in the distance. This is a 'must do' in Barcelona.

I loved this building. From the entrance to the roof, this is one of the most magical buildings in the world.Most of the apartments within are occupied, but there is one that they keep open for visitors. I just wanted to move in and live there immediately! Every tiny aspect of it's design is in keeping with the grand vision that Gaudi had for its residents. I was astounded by the attention to detail and the beauty of the fixtures and the furniture. The vaulted roof in the room at the top is stunning and when you step out onto the roof, the chimneys are even more beautiful than the pictures in the guidebooks can portray. Loved it.

How did he think it up?. This is an amazing building highlighting Gaudi's modern style. Start in the central courtyard with shapes and colors in the stone and iron work: tour the apartment that is not lived in but set up in the style of his time; see his avant garde ways of bringing light into the building with a central courtyard; admire his lack of straight lines and load bearing internal walls; visit the graceful brick arches of the attic to see exhibits showing the inspiration for his work - everything from trees, leaves, snakes, snails and the sea; and enjoy the pinnacle, the famous fun roof on top of it all. The roof was our favorite place of the visit. There are different levels, with easy steps up and down; almost Star Wars or Easter Island inspired architectural sculptures which decorate stairwells, ventilation towers and chimneys. There are fabulous views of the city and you can find two places on the roof (pointed out in the audio tour) where you can take a picture of religious buildings through a rooftop archway - the Sagrada Familia and another church perched on top of a mountain, all done on purpose by this grand architect.I recommend that you buy your tickets online ahead of time so you do not have to wait in line and go early in the day to avoid the crowds. Many people chose between La Pedrera and Casa Batllo since they think that seeing one of his buildings is enough. I have to disagree, for myself at least. The two buildings are so very different. Both showcase Gaudi's style and very avant garde ideas, but La Pedrera shows his thought process using the stunning attic space while Casa Batllo showcases more of his decorative touches.

A Must Do. A surprise around every corner. From the helmet shaped chimney pots to the design of the furniture this building is just stunning and a must do if you are in Barcelona. Make sure you have the audio guide you someone who knows what they are talking about otherwise you will miss some of the details like the way two of the arches on the roof frame the Sagrada Familia and another church. Such attention detail is in every aspect of the design of the building. Fascinating.

Kind a Museum and interesting deco inside also roof top.. All most all tourist visiting to here in Barcelona. one of Famous Gaudi 's. We went with out tickets so have to make line to buy a tickets. lees than 30 mintus to got a tickets counter in the morning. If you can make a plans of day. easy to buy a tickets by online.

Typical Barcelona architecture. We started our visit of great Barcelona architecture with Casa Mila. This building is a great example of how Gaudi doesn't really believe in straight lines. The building also stands out on the Passeig de Gracia between all the expensive shops. There is a less of a queue than at Casa Batlo, so if you don't want to wait but do want to enjoy Gaudi's architecture, this is where you need to go. Casa Batlo is only 2 minutes walk away.

worth a visit. This is right across from one of the stopping points for the City Bus Tours so you can't miss it. We visited on a rather threatening day, weather-wise, but that just enhanced the other-worldly feel to the rooftop terrace. The exhibitions provide lots of info re Gaudi's creations (not just this one) & there is an excellent model of La Pedrera which you can view from all angles. The apartments were of less interest, in my opinion, but they do provide a counterpoint to the rest of the visit.

Wow!. A quick note about entering. The front entrance has a shorter queue, but costs a few Euros more (and there's no discount for kids). The side entrance has longer queues (coaches unload here), but you can buy the cheaper tickets online and skip the queue - I bought tickets on my smartphone while we waited. So, to the review.La Pedrera is a true Gaudi masterpiece, from top to bottom. This was my second visit (first visit a few years ago), and it made me smile just as much the second time around.You'll start in the central courtyard, where the colours and shapes of the stone, the wrought iron-work etc will start to draw you in. Up to the top in the lift (or via the stairs) and you'll find the wonderfully bizarre sculptures on the roof (chimneys, access to stairs etc). The undulating roof just adds to the playfulness of it all.The exhibition a floor below (under the functional but beautiful brick-built catenary arches) gives just enough background to Gaudi's architectural techniques and a bit of background to Barcelona of the early 20th century.Down a further floor to the apartment, and you must take your time and look around to enjoy all the details. No line is straight unless it REALLY has to be, no surface is without playful embellishment. Over the top? If it sounds like it then I haven't done it justice - it's SO beautifully done!Please, please visit La Pedrera - it's just as worthy as the Sagrada Familia.
a one off. I couldn't believe my eyes when I stepped out onto the roof. Took dozens of photos. Stunning and unique

After the Sagrada, this was my favorite Gaudi sight. I love everything about La Pedrera. I am blown away by Gaudi's genius style of architecture and this house is perfection. Reserve your ticket before going on your trip as they control the number of people they let in every 15 minutes (which is a good thing because it doesn't get too crowded) and the time slots to fill up fast.

Do not miss ! Pricey but well worth it.. Can be reached on the red and blue bus tours. The discount book with the tours gives you 10% off the admission price. This is a Gaudi building with no straight lines ! We took the self guided tour with free multi-lingual audio headsets which were marvellous. The tour starts with a lift trip to the roof. When you step out onto the roof you cannot believe your eyes with the wierd shapes around you and the steps going up and down between them. There are two arches which Gaudi buiit to frame two other buildings - the Segrada Familia is one of course - his masterpiece. The tour then takes you into the attic where there are curious brick arches which are explained later when there is a demonstration of how Gaudi designed his buildings. There are also reproductions of some of the furniture Gaudi designed with the exact contours of the user in mind - also door handles and drawer knobs originally moulded in clay exactly as the user had gripped it to push or pull. One more floor down and there is an apartment laid out exactly as it would have been in the early 20th century. The lower floors are still in use as offices.
Gaudi's finest. We took a guided tour of Gaudi's buildings in Barcelona. This one is an apartment building. On the floor of the street are tiles made like a bee catacomb. Very interesting
Beautiful house. Another beauty from genius Gaudí. It looks like it is some kind of an underwater mansion. Whole building resembles waves with bseaweed as balconies. Roof is a must see!

Classic Gaudi. You travel from the entrance courtyards though the attic onto the roof and into an apartment preserved in the style of early 20th century. This is an amazing unusual building, every turn brings more beauty. The roof with it's amazing dynamic structures is wonderful and there are good views of Barcelona up here. The attic space has flowing brick arches and resembles a church more than an attic, truly beautiful. Lots of information about Gaudi and his work in here too.

Well worth a visit. The roof top sculptures are brilliant. Love Gaudi! I spent ages taking photos from lots of different angles. Great fun! The rest of the tour is also worthwhile but not sure it merits the 20.50 Euro admission fee. Walked past at night I managed to catch some of the night-time show from the road with changing colours and patterns on the sculptures. It looked amazing but on checking the cost it was very pricey!

Fascinating!. What an fabulous experience to see Guadi's works up close and personal. If you are going to go inside one of them, this is the one to choose. Get your tickets online to avoid the long lines, especially during the most touristy times of the year. The roof itself is amazing and well worth the price of admission

Amazing architecture. We took a guided tour of Casa Mila and were blown away. As you can see from many of the reviews, it is just so interesting to hear about the design, history, and development of Case Mila. Here are a few suggestions, if you want to really learn about the home then take a guided tour and GO EARLY. We went right when it opened and it was great. It really gets busy in the early afternoon so avoid the crowds, plan ahead, book a tour, and enjoy.There is another Gaudi designed building nearby, but it is smaller and crowds pack inside. If I were to pick going to either go to Casa Mila. The views from the roof are lovely.
Viewed from our terrace!. Is it a twisted chess piece, an owl lit up at night or just magnificent sculpture and architecture.Clamber around and take in the views!

One more masterpiece. Casa Mila is a wonderful example of Gaudi's masterpieces. The house is not just a beautiful building but also a museum i which one can see how it was constructed and get acquainted with the household and life in those times. There are long lines of visitors so you will have to wait. If you are planning to visit several museums and art galleries in Barcelona, I would recommend to take a multi-ticket for MNAC, La Pedrera, Tapies Foundation, Miro Foundation, PIcasso museum, etc. - it will save money.

A Gaudi masterpiece. To me, Barcelona is Picasso, Gaudi and Miro. There are several ways to enjoy Gaudi's genius including La Pedrera. The roof top is a highlight.To avoid long ticketing lines at all of the Gaudi attractions you should book online. Unfortunately the multi-museum pass does not cover the Gaudi attractions such as La Pedrera, Casa Battlo and Basilica de la Sagrada familia. Tickets are not cheap. If you are time poor or Euro poor, perhaps choose only one of La Pedrera or Casa Batilo, and I would go for the latter. Museu Nacional d'Art de Catalunya has a larger collection of original Gaudi furniture and is included on the multi museum pass. I think La Pedrera is definitely worth visiting.

If a Gaudi fan - visit. Book on line so you have a booked time to go straight in. Otherwise join the queue !!, they only let a set amount of people in at a time. The roof is fascinating with beautiful views. Rest of building unique- enjoy.

Cool, must see for at least a quick walkthrough. I loved this place for the rooftop, but it is easily and fully appreciated in under an hour. Make sure to go on a good weather day for best views and experience. I am not sure if it is open at night but I would have to imagine that would be an even better experience. You walk through the building and apartments after the rooftop which is cool but also just old apartments so can be done quickly. Try to go when it is not busy so you can get the best pictures and move at your own pace.

Interesting. If i had to choose between seeing La Pedrera or Casa Batllo, i would have to take Casa Battlo. La Pedrera does have some interesting architecture (especially on the roof) and the free audio guide doesn't hurt either, but i just didn't find it as impressive as guell's other work.Don't get me wrong, La Pedrera is still quite a sight to see, but personally not my favourite.

Excellent!!!. No visit to Barcelona would be complete without a visit to Casa Mila - or La Pedera (the stonepile) - one of architect Antoni Gaudi's masterpieces. Built for a private family, this house offers many great lessons about how this man created buildings. While the exterior is unlike any other, do take the tour and don;t miss the vaulted attic, which is now a museum showing how Gaudi worked and what influenced him. Of course, one must visit the roof and pay respects to the alien-like sentinels that not only cover the chimneys, but provide a other-worldliness that is strangely comforting.Lucky residents still inhabit the building, but visitors can tour one floor and the main floor. The gift shop offers miniature sentinels to grace your desk back home. Well worth the time to learn more about this amazing architect and bravo to Barcelona for embracing these treasures.

Stunning, but plan ahead and chose your time of day. Amazing house and worth the admission fee although it's expensive. Very popular and crowded with tourists so you need to book ahead on-line to avoid long queues at busy periods. We didn't pre-book and the waiting was only just tolerable. There was a lack of visitor information outside the building as to the options for entry and they would benefit from a team of marshals to help visitors. Many people were milling about aimlessly outside the entrances, not knowing what the system of entry was.Inside there are more queues to gain access to the roof but once in the experience is awesome. Visitors are admitted to the ground floor area, the roof, the attic which houses an impressive display of Gaudi's work, and a residential suite open to the public.We enjoyed the whole visit but, with queueing and viewing, it took up a whole half day out of our weekend which some may feel is excessive.
Nice roof top!!. The best part is the roof top.The rest is rather interesting, as always creative and captivating but the best part is up :)
skip this one. Would go to Palau guel and casa batllo before this. Nice but it's overpriced and mostly just about the attic exhibition and not the building itself
Magical. Want to see a building with no sharp edges? This is it. Inside is an exhibition of the the designs and furniture. The roof is amazing

Some unique areas, but not the best of Gaudi'. We opted to tour Casa Mila because there were no crowds here, and the street in front of Casa Batllo, a couple blocks away, was full of people from the entry to the curb, all in front of the bulding. Regarding Casa Mila, one cannot help but marvel at the free-flowing rooftop. And I found the entryway and stairs to the second floor to have an understated subtle beauty with color and non-linear shape. Check out the ceiling to what I believe is the second floor gift shop, just off the atrium up steps to the left of the entry -- it looks like ocean waves. The "attic" of the building is under a vaulted ceiling. After that, I was less impressed. The apartment that was open to visitors was well-designed considering the space available, but otherwise unremarkable. Do opt for the audio tour equipment, which I found useful.

Beautiful, if strange Gaudi's perfect example of the architectual design of his style.. We went to see La Pedrera as a second thought after seeing Casa Battjo (pronounce Casa Batyo'). As the latter is a masterpiece of magical, fairy tale designs and a plethora of colors enhanced by the natural light, La Pedrera seems a bit murky but equally fascinating. Black wrought iron balconies in a wave line with the lime stone background is kind of intriguing. So we paid the extra bucks (or Euros in this case) and entered without waiting in line. La Pedrera is still occupied by people and hence only the courtyard (very interesting), one apartment, attic and the roof are to be viewed by tourists.The apartment was ok but not extremely interesting unless you are into that era's furnishings, layouts, etc.and we were not. The attic has an interesting collection of Gaudi's history, maps, different projects, etc. Since we ran out of time we did not spent too much time there. What really "made it" for us was the roof. It was again a fairy tale kind of shapes that he created - chimneys had rounded, twisted shapes, there were all kinds of structures normally never seen on the roof. And it also offered a magnificent views of Barcelona, you could even see the Meditterean Sea in the distance. One word of caution - you arrive there by the elevator, but the exit is not marked and the entry to the elevator was blocked. We were going around and around laughing that we cannot find the way out of there. Well, we were not alone. We ended up forcing our way into the elevator's entrance (followed by 5 or 6 other "lost souls") and getting down that way to the surprise of the staff at the bottom....

Pricey but worth it.. Still stunned by the fact that 3 families are still living in that house. I enjoyed Casa Mila over Casa Batllo. The admission is around 20.5 Euros but I think it's worth it. I figured, I wouldn't know if I'll ever come back so I'll visit all of Gaudi's architect. Doesn't take more than 3 hours to really thoroughly see the entire thing. The free audio tour is sufficient.
Fine if it's on your way. Nice building but very expensive to visit!Just had a look at it from the outside instead.Wouldnt walk all the way there if it wasn't on my path.

The Secret Pedrera: amazing night. We really enjoyed La Pedrera by night. Our guide Ana was wonderful and outgoing. She gave us useful information in a very spontaneous way. It was both interesting and enjoyable, rooftop views and cava included.

Interesting Architecture . We have traveled a lot of Europe and nothing compares to the architecture of this building. It's a must in your travels through Barcelona. Very interesting design and great views of the city from the roof.
Super cool building. this place is worth a visit to see Gaudi's unique architecture design and how rich lived back in the day. the roof alone is worth the price of admission!

Not Worth the Money. This place is not worth the money they charge. It cost us 20 euros each to tour it. The only attraction is the roof which has imaginative Gaudi sculptures, but the roof is so crowded with tourists that you can hardly take a step without bumping into people. Save your money by buying a postcard of the roof instead.

An interesting building. We did the night dinner and English tour. The 7.30 light dinner was good but was served very quickly and finished an hour before the 9.15 tour - a bit odd it would have been easier to eat elsewhere. The Gaudi building is interesting, particularly the roof, and is well worth a visit.

Fantastic.. Every time we visit Barcelona,I want to visit La Pedera.Usually there wasn't time.But this time we walked from our Hotel Royal Ramblas,And there it was.Breathtaking.Found the normal visit queue too long.So ended up in the Premium visit Queue.Which was very short!.Found out it was for the premium Tour which went everywhere.Slightly more expensive but well worth it.We were given headsets and ushered through like royalty.Straight up to the rooftop.Absolutely fantastic,All these years of never getting to it.and I was there.Superb views,every where.just delightful.then down each floor in all the available rooms.Next time I'd like to do the evening tour,with everywhere lit up.

Gaudis apartment. this is an 8 floor apartment block designed by Gaudi as one of his important additions to architecture in Barcelona.When you walk round it seems that none of the walls or ceiling are square - that is because they are not!. inside there are circular courtyards surrounded by apartments looking down. it is quite an amazing sight as is most of Gaudis work.well worth a visit but I would suggest you prebook tickets to avoid the usual queues and try yo visit in the morning which seems to be less crowded.

UNDERWHELMED. Although this was on the street, the absence of trees enabled us to take photographs but it was not particularly interesting as it had none of Gaudi's usual colours. We didn't go inside.

Fascinating example of the best of Gaudi's design. We have been to Barcelona many times and toured major Gaudi buildings including the Sagrada Familia for little or no admission fees before these sites were privatized. One must consider whether 42 Euros for an audio tour is a prudent expenditure. We had not been to the Casa Mila before and I must admit it was well worth the expenditure. Since being purchased by a Catalonia Bank, the building has been painstakingly restored to much of its original state making it into a museum and a tribute to one Gaudi's most significant monuments. We went on a Thursday morning shortly after the site opened for the day and there was but a short line for tickets and admission. When we left about an hour later, the line was enormous, so go early.

Surprises in the attic. What I like about Gaudi is that his artistic originality is built upon extremely practical architectural design. La Pedrera is a wonderful example of this with the way the design of the central courtyards bring light into the buildings and are then embellished with artistic flair. The famous roof allows him to have a bit of creative fun with the chimney pots.But for me, the most interesting part was the attic space. Not an area for common view it is here that his innovative and practical design is seen at its best in the way the graceful brick arches provide both structure and strength whilst maximising the use of space. The design is also energy efficient (intentionally so) and illustrates how forward thinking Gaudi was.Yes, Gaudi's work is good to look at, but it really is important to read the exhibits and listen to the audio guide to better appreciate the elegance of his designs. Like many of the Gaudi exhibits, the visit here is not cheap but it is worth it. Buy tickets in advance as it seems that those that don't wait a very long time to get in at peak times.

La Pedrera Barcelona. Well worth a visit. We used the "Express Entrance" which has a smaller Q, but it is €27 per person as against €20 for the regular Q. Touch of Ryanair there alright. Would not have missed it - unique.

Another Gaudi Marvel. Antoni Gaudi was a genius, Barcelona is full of his genius and this place is just incredible, from the floor to the unbelieveable rooftop.
If you visit Barcelona and don't go here you are really missing out.

Excellent!!. I highly recommend this visit for anyone visiting Barcelona. We did the 21 Euro self guided tour with the audio headset. It does a great job of explaining not only the building but the architect and his other works. We spent about 90 min here and that was the perfect amount of time. Buy your tickets online to skip the queue. FYI - lots of stairs (6 flights up and 6 down) to take this tour. Long lines for the lift.
Beuatiful. If you like architecture or Guadi then this place is really recommended.. Just make sure you book online or early enough in the morning so you won't wait in the queue too much.

The right man at the right time in the right place. The right man at the right time in the right place. A genius no doubt but also a salesman, lucky for us. How genuinly amazing to find his use of nature's principles resulted in energy and material efficiënt buildings. Buildings that are at the same time pieces of art. one cannot but admire such people.
Amazing property!. We went on an evening tour. Stunning building! The apartment as was is incredible. I would love to live here! Beautifully designed and so far ahead of the game. Don't miss it!

Great Gaudi. Definitely precook to avoid the queues which may be long. From the city views from the roof to the remarkable Gaudi design, it's a not to be missed site when you visit Barcelona. Stroll the neighborhood to feel the city.

Interesting design if you like Gaudi. There can be a very long line to buy the ticket. Inside, the visit of the building designed by Gaudi is interesting. I don't enjoy its style but it is creative.The view from the terriers is beautiful.

fascinating. We went on the evening tour - pre-booked. It was a great way to walk through the building and hear many stories of it's construction, Gaudi and the Mila family. The walk on the terrace was amazing and well worth the evening.

Great Rooftop and guide... but expensive. We paid 30 euros for an evening tour (Secrets of La Pedrera) and had a very enchanting guide. However, we didnt necessarily learn a lot more about the house than what we got as info from internet / sources and unfortunately this was the third Gaudi building we had visited so a lot of his background information was already known to us. I still think this house is worth a visit but a regular tour could do if you have already gotten a heady dose of Sagrada Familia and Casa Battilo. The terrace is amazing with the chimney figurines and evening views.

Impressive from the outside alone. As a Gaudi designed building, it is at the top of many architecture lovers' must do list. Lines are long. Tickets sell out. If you have only a passing interest in Gaudi and his designs, view this from the outside or take a Runner Bean Gaudi free walking tour. Then head for Park Guell's Monumental Zone (fee) and see his plans for a housing development (a housing estate was the term). Just have to see it to believe it either way.

Do the Night Tour. The night tour was well worth the money. The house was neat to see and the roof was amazing. This really gave us some great insight into Guadi so that we appreciated Sagrada Familia even more. Go to their website and make reservations in advance.

Closes to early. Beautiful building unfortunately we waited till later in the evening as I had seen a review at night and it looked amazing. It shuts at 8.30pm so we missed seeing it. Very disappointing

Fantastic. Another Gaudi property, set just off the Passeig de Gracia. We again had not pre booked but there was only a small queue which moved along swiftly enough. This property is once again awe inspiring and is worth listening to the audio guide to understand why Gaudi designed it the way he did. The tour takes you right up to the roof, so you need to steel your nerves if heights aren't your thing. People still occupy some of the apartments here so courtesy is advised during the tour.

Awesome Roof!. Seen it from the outside on two previous trips to Barcelona. This time I pre-ordered tickets through the internet and went inside without having to wait on a long line. This is a very popular attraction, second only to Sagrada Familia so there are usually crowds. It is on a lovely street, Passeig de Gracia - Barcelona's version on NYC's 5th Avenue. . The best part was the roof but the apartment was awesome too. Next time I am going to do the roof at night which is a different fee ( a tad more expensive but limited to 20 people at a time so less crowded). The roof looked surreal and I imagine more so at night. Can't wait!Visited May 2015
Outstanding. A real In site into a Gaudi house, nothing to dislike , and an easy walk from the Ramblas. Lots of places to eat on rute
An absolute favourite. Another wonderful building.form,colour,light,design,art. It has it all. Gaudi has given the world tremendous beauty.

Beautiful Gaudi architecture inspired by the sea.. Loved the tile atrium which provided daylight to all the floors of this very interesting, sea inspired residence. Also, large picture windows in the main living area and mosaic tile garden area, all in sea shapes are beautiful hallmarks.

A must see for Gaudi and architecture enthusiasts. A beautifully restored and maintained tribute to Gaudi. The museum tour takes you through the design stages of this incredible building and the thought processes of Gaudi. It continues to the roof top where the amazing shapes of ventilation shafts and chimneys. Fantastic views of the city and the Sagrada Familia Bascilica. The tour continues through an apartment recreated and furnished in the original style.

Amazing place. I recommend purchasing tickets online for this attraction together with Casa Batllo, to avoid long waiting time. I loved it! He really was a master of creating beauty at every turn. He aSo has the knack of adding playful little quirks throughout his designs as only Gaudi can. I preferred this house to Gaudi's other including Casa Batllo which is located just down the road. Do yourself a favour and see these to Gaudi exhibitions.

Worth the trip. Wonderful example of Gaudi's work. I especially enjoyed seeing the apartment with the period furniture and the roof top is amazing. Be prepared to climb lots of stairs so don't go if this is hard for you.
Must go. Ticket includes audio guide which is great, suggest to go in late afternoon, can avoid the queue, better chance to take good photos. Gaudi is awesome!

Excellent museum and beautiful apartment building. The entire experience was delightful. The guides and audio guides were excellent. The museum that is in the 'attic' has such good information and wonderful videos and displays. Very much worth the time and effort to see this.

Gaudi accessible!. You can't stay in Barcelona without being exposed to Gaudi's original work (like casa Battlo or Sagrada Familia). There are great but crowded (booking online is highly recommended as otherwise you will have to prepare for a 2 hours queue). But it means you will have also all this crowd around you when visiting. La Pedreira, 5 minuts walk from Casa Battlo on Passeig de Gracia, is maybe less exuberant but more accessible and worth the visit. The roof is a must have seen but the appartment ( a 400 m2 appt!) decorated and furnished as it was around 1920 worth the visit also. Less queue, less expensive and more understandable!

Gaudi at his finest. The roof terrace of La Pedrera took my breath away. The bold statues and arches coupled with sweeping views across the city made me want to spend all day on top of this beautiful building. The audio guide was brilliant and gave me invaluable insight not only in to the thought process behind the building but also Gaudi as a person. A definite Barcelona must-see!

La Pedrera by night a tour behind cloed doors. Highly recommend it if you are not tin the mood to stand in line and be pushed through in the mass. Has its own charm at night and is just as impressive to get a look behind the great works of Gaudi

Flowing architecture surprises and delights. We were the fools who didn't book in advance and had to stand in line for tickets for about half an hour, but it was well worth it. The audioguide was included on our tour. We went to the roof on a small elevator, and it was worth exploring-the views!-but if you fear heights this will make you wobbly. Descend to the attic for more audio lessons on Gaudi's architectural philosophy, then to a representative apartment.I got some cute sticker books for the grandkids in the giftshop also.

Gaudi's masterpiece. It could be longer to queue for tickets than browsing inside... So it's much better to buy tickets online. The whole self-guided tour takes about an hour and gets you through all floors of this massive building. The tour goes as far as the roof with its lofty terraces. This was our first encounter with Gaudi's design, so it was all new and we remembered quite a lot, but when we got to our last one - Palau Guell - it was all just the same, and I wouldn't say a difference between them seeing just a picture.

Worth a visit for the roof terrace. The roof terrace and it's views are spectacular but other than that I wasn't blown away. There is a nice exhibition in the attic area but I was kind of Gaudi'd out by this point in my trip & didn't fancy an hour in hot attic looking through. It had a nice gift shop without the usual tourist tat. Two big tips. 1: The entrance on the corner of the building on the road intersection is for premier tickets and is more expensive - the entrance to the right is the normal entrance. 2: The queues were long to get in so we walked a few metres to the nearest cafe, got a beer and bought tickets on my smart phone. Then back to the separate entrance right at the front of the queue and straight in. Queuing saved and got a beer in the sun as part of the deal. If you do one Gaudi building in Barcelona then my recommendation would be Palau Guell.

Fabulous . Amazing place. Loved it. Beautiful. Much better than expected. Great audio service - to the point with great information. Start at the top & work your way down: roof terrace, attic & an apartment.

A place worth visiting . I can only said Gandi built the place with his heart full of artistic feel and every detail is considered to make everyone feel at home and comfortable. Book the ticket online in advance inorder to skip the line at the entrance. Take the tour with the audio guide which is worth it to fully understand his art of building his dreams house.You can take the metro Line 3 or 5 to Diagonal station which is only 2 minutes walk to there. It's cost only €2.15 per person to get there one way.

Worth a visit. It took me around 90minutes to explore all, definitely worth the entrance fee which was 20,50eur.I arrived at 10am without having the ticket booked in advance, wait like for 2 minutes, buy the ticket and went in.

Go at night!. La Pedrera is absolutely beautiful day or night but at night it truly seems to come alive! It's like you can really see what Gaudí wasIntending when he made it. The tour is so much better too rather than the audio guideDuring the day. (Very good too but a live guide is always better) buy your tickets in advance!!

Gaudi Masterpiece. This is a masterpiece by Gaudi. Very interesting to visit. Although the price is on the higher side as 20 euros is a little expensive. The architecture is very unique! Should definitely visit this place.

Fabulous. This shows all the things from nature that inspired Gaudi's artistic buildings. It was fascinating. The roof top was totally amazing. Do not miss any part of this. There is a dark room with a small model building that is animated with dragons, skulls, everything as part of its animation. This place really lets you know how incredible Gaudi's talent was! Good gift shop. Beautiful exterior also.

Amazing architecture. Another reviewer said "this is a must" and they were right. Besides the interesting, unique architecture inside and out, the upstairs attic museum explains much of Gaudi's thinking and reasoning. Brilliant and imaginative man and a visit to La Pedrera helps one appreciate that fact.

Gaudi is a genius!. An amazing architect Gaudi... I have been learned about him many many times as I study spanish. And when I finally was in Barcelona I had to go and see this beautiful, extraordinary building. It is very nice from the outside but it is always better to see it also from the inside. If you don`t have any guide with you, there are audio guides available. There is everything explained about Gaudi and the house itself. You can also go to the roof! The only problem is that this place is overcrowded. There are a lot of people every day and you always have to wait to get into the building which can be a bit annoying (in summer especially - too hot outside).
a thing of beauty. lovely building. go early to avoid the queues. not as busy as the nearby casa batllo, but still enough people to get in the way of any decent photos!

Waste of 20 Euros & WARNING (for older/handicapped visitors)!. This attraction isn't worth your 20 euros, time & effort in descending the stairs.. (plus see WARNING below!)The only part of the building which is worth seeing is the rooftop. Even this isn't so impressive. There are a few funky chimneys by Gaudi, but the rest is pretty mundane. Yes the views are good, but you can get this from a hotel rooftop as well (google "top rooftop bars" in Barcelona as there are many..).The most boring task in this building is to have to descend the endless stairs to go down to terra firma. You must pass numerous tacky exhibits, most of which are fake. Then you wind around a representation of an old apartment (though it's totally fake!).. yawn..Forge this for a sightseeing objective in this beautiful city. There are many others which are most stunning and worthwhile!WARNING: this is not a place for older/handicapped visitors. The stairs are endless and there is only 1 elevator/lift, and even that is mainly for going up, not down!
Amazing imagination and fore sight. Gaudi was a amazing architect. To build this amazing building in those days is very impressive. No wounded people from around the world que to visit.

This is a must. Besides showing off this beautiful building, the exhibit in the attic explained Gaudi's architecture, his other major works very well with slide shows, small scale models. The audio guide is very helpful. To see the apartment furnished completely in the style of its times including every day objects like childrens' toys, shaving kit in the bathroom and nut grinder in the kitchen is very interesting also. The temporary photo exhibit that is included on the main floor was good too. One can spend 2-3 hours here, including enjoying the view from the roof onto Passeig the Gracia. It is very crowded as a major site, would not recommend it for children.

Expensive but worth it. I'm slightly biased as I'm a fan of Gaudi's architecture. Unfortunately when we visited the outside of the building was covered up for renovation which was disappointing but just unfortunate timing on our part. A lot of the building was used for offices so the cost was expensive for the length of the visit, but so pleased to have seen the chimneys in person so it was well worth it.

Eyeopening. An amazing building you must see. To think the was designed and built 100 years ago and to see the amazing way the place was put together. Art with function.To wander round on the roof feels like another world.
la pedrera. great example of guadi. quirky architecture, funky design, the rooftop is spectcular and the interiorjust as gaudi meant it to be

Interesting visit with information on way of living in Barcelona in the old days. Interesting visit explaining the way Gaudi designed this house for day to day shores and tasks. One kay point was the description of the stanard way of living in Barcelona in early 20th century.

Casa Mila. Another impressive building from the workshop of Gaudi.Impressive building with a beautiful roof but no more impressive than Gaudi other works and it's possible to see less inside the building than other buildings, so it's unclear to me why pay 27 euros entrance per person.Still, worth a visit, impressive place!

Underwhelmed. I am a fan of Gaudi's work but left unimpressed by the whole visit. Although we booked online there was chaos at the entrance caused by some people have unofficial tickets or not having converted their voucher to tickets first. Saying that we didn't have to wait long and would definitely recommend online purchase versus queuing for tickets. The roof offers the most interesting aspect, but leaves a curiosity as to how much has been restored and how much is genuine. The most attractive feature is the foyer but the whole place is far less impressive than Casa Batllo. If you are short for time I would recommend that over this overpriced and underwhelming example of Gaudi.

Gaudi was truly a genius ! . It's a beautiful house both from inside and outside . The roof deserves special mention . All the structures are beautiful and utilitarian and each one is different . It's like being in a magical place . The house is well maintained and gives a good insight into Gaudi's works . His nature-inspired style of architecture is truly worth a visit . Please do buy tickets in advance if pressed for time .

Gaudi did it again. Not far from Casa Batllo, on the other side of Passeig de Gracia I'd La Pedrera, very busy area full of tourists but it is worth a look at least from outside as it has got amazing balconies

Amazing architecture. Arguably the most architectural corner of the world. With the always obvious and impressive intervention of Gaudí, this building becomes a visual Spectacular all those who pass by in front of it, and leave wondering how was that made? Well, Barcelona has throughout its metropolitan area countless architectural works created by the genius of the master Gaudí; so keep your camera ready when you are walking around Barcelona, Gaudí may appear even over your head.

A very nice example of Gaudi work. The visit was very nice, the building, excellent colors and shapes. The terrace upstairs is unique. Much superior from Casa Batllo. Perhaps a night visit is worth it too. Buy tickets online to skip the line.

Finally visit,the highlight is the rooftop view. Again,better to book online in advance to avoid queuing up and the chance of ticket sold out of your preferred timeslot.Or you can choose to pay Euro10 more for premium access,enter immediately.The original ticket costs Euro20.5 with audio guide.The staff will tell you the sequence to visit this building.First to take the lift up to the rooftop first and go down every floor to look around different rooms inside.The highlight must be the rooftop.Interesting and unique architecture that never see in other countries.Already know how it looks on TV or from the pictures.But when you were there,it's a different experience.And you can take a look of the city from the top.The rooms inside maintain very well and in a good shape.You can see the details of Gaudi's work from the old days.Actually only a few floor are opened for public to visit.But it is good and something you can't miss when you are in Barcelona.Go to visit any of Gaudi's works.

Caso Batllo is better, but Casa Mila is still lovely. Go see Caso Batllo if you can only see Batllo or Mila. If you can see both, do both. (Palau Guell is good, too.)Casa Mila only has the roof, the attic, and the apartments. The attic is more of a museum. There's really only one floor of indoor 'stuff to see' because Casa Mila is in use as a true business building. Therefore it is less exciting than Caso Batllo which has multiple floors, the roof, and the backyard to discover. That said, the roof on Casa Mila is delightfully alien. The view is very nice. I enjoyed that strange little attic, and some of the ceiling paintings in the lower foyer were quite nice. We enjoyed the temporary art exhibit, too.
Gaudi genius. Not far to walk from las ramblas into this swankier end of town to see this amazing building. There's also a lovely cafe inside.

Brilliant place for architecture. We thoroughly enjoyed visiting La Pedera. The visit to the roof and attic especially interesting and the views amazing. Not really into art/architecture but this was well worth the visit

Majestic and Magical!. Although I had seen La Pedrera from the street several times on shore excursions with cruise groups, this was my first time to tour the house and go onto the roof. Going onto the roof is a stunning experience...like being in ancient Egypt! The size and beauty of the art structures is awesome. This is the personification of utilitarian art. Each structure is utilitarian yet majestic, unique and awesome art! Simply not to be missed!

Awesome Rooftop!. We were able to buy tickets early after the opened without any lines. Go directly to the rooftop before it gets too busy for the best photos! Then tour the house on your way down. The exhibits & models of Gaudi's designs displayed in the attic were also very interesting. The gift shop is great too!

Great design. With the audio tour, you start in the courtyard, and quickly ascend to the roof. After the wandering around up there (go early, as it gets hot!), you had through the attic and then down to one apartment. Really beautiful spaces.
tipical arquitecture. A must if you go to BCN, and you like to see the arquitecture of the city.You wont be dissapointed. Not difficult access.

A must-see. This building and the tour will help you understand Gaudi a bit more. The information played in he Attic gives you all you need about him and his works. The chairs, door handles etc he designed are in this building.I advice you buy yoru tickets online and make sure you choose the right time when it is not that crowded (come on it is a tourist attraction, of course it will be full of people!).
fantastic. This was well worth the queue, a fantastic few hours spent walking around, views from the roof were not to be missed, you could see for miles across Barcelona.

A work of genius. Antoni Gaudi was a genius. Eccentric, visionary and with unbelievable imagination. La Pedrera is a proof of it. The roof is a world in its own. Truth is that a visit is quite expensive (price is higher than to Sagrada Familia) but it is worth of it. Only slight negative thing is that staff is quite useless but that cannot lessen the overall experience.
Only ok.. The building facade promises much, but the inside was disappointing.Far too crowded, with few real opportunities for quality photos.Not really value for money

Very interesting. Although it is a little expensive a visit there takes you to another world!! The feeling on the roof of the building is just unique!! you get also free headphones and you get many interesting information about Gaudi, the building, the way he worked...
Gaudi. One of the many architecturial monuments of Antonio Gaudi not to miss in Barcelona.Read about him at Wikipedia.

You can skip Casa MIla in your Barcelona visit. Not a lot to see when you visit inside in a relatively high price admission fee and need to book in advance. You can take a look from the outside and continue to other much more interesting things to do.

Long queues and expensive.. I must admit I didn't pay to go into La Pedrera as the queues were always long and I wasn't sure the cost would be worth it after having already seen Park Guell and La Sagrada Familia. Instead I had a coffee in the coffee shop attached to it and also went in to the gift shop which you can do without having to pay. You could see part of the inside through the windows of the gift shop and it looked very different to the usual architecture.The outside is quite eye catching, especially the fantasy chimneys and when the sun catches the facade it seems to glow. It is wonderful architecture and adds to the streetscape, and also the crowds! It is worth a walk to see it.
Another world. When I walked onto the roof, I had to pause to catch my breath. I was speechless. It was like another world. Gaudi's vision was amazing.

Quirky but too expensive compared to others. Enjoyed our visit around this UNESCO building but found the organisation not up to the standards of other attractions. Given this and the fee, we would probably have chosen another attraction.

The best of Gaudi's residential work?. In all fairness, we did not go inside, or on the roof. However, you can get a good look at some of Gaudi's famous fantasy chimneys from the street level in you cross the street and give yourself a bit on a angle.The architecture, though challenging, is fascinating. What seemed to work best in the modern city environment was the wrought iron balustrades that flowed over and out of the terraces. They are supposed to evoke seaweed, and they do feel like metal plants growing down the building. If you are in Barcelona, you should definitely go take a look, especially as this is a shorter walk from the "Block of Discord" which had three famous houses (one by Gaudi).

Impressive visit to an original house. We visited this big, fantastic Gaudi house in September and it was an unusual and stunning experience. In the house you can visit an apartment and go up on the roof where several details and sculptures are available for touching, resting upon and for photo shooting!

A premier Gaudi attraction. Tickets an be ordered online, which if you plan to go later in the day will avoid the lines.This is one of the top ten Gaudi attractions and, quite rightly so. This has a more traditional interior than Casa Batlo but it is not to be discounted.The external structure, the roof and the internal lobby is amazing, no one can rival Gaudi's building exteriors during his mature period.Enjoy.

Do the night tour and you'll literally have the place all to yourself.. This place gets VERY crowded during the day. Go at night and you'll be limited to a special group of approximately 20-30 others. It costs a bit extra in the evening, but.......you'll find the place literally all to yourself and you'll avoid the sweltering sun. You'll even have the attention of a tour guide for the entire evening, capped off at the end with wine and small bites as part of the visit.
More interesting inside... ..than outside. Worth money to emerge into that visionary creation of comfortable living. Take a break on the roof, and some nice picture, too.

go early. We are very happy to have taken this tour. Went early and missed the crowds that were lined up when we left. We learned so much about the designer and how he influenced the city. Thought it helped us understand the ideas that Gaudio had and is inspirations. Well worth the visit
Very quaint. Well worth visiting...but if you are trying to rake photos be aware that it us almost impossible to take one without people walking in front of you...

Wish I had a flat there ....if only for a day!. Well, I thoroughly enjoyed the visit to this gorgeous example of Gaudi's creativity. Despite the long queue of people who also wanted to go inside, once in the house, it was possible to admire the various rooms following our own pace. The staircase is incredible as it shows the various flats that form part of the building and the view from the terrace is quite breathtaking. The shops sell interesting merchandise. Worth a visit, maybe it is advisable to purchase the ticket online.

Beautiful Gaudi building. Our second visit to this wonderful building and just as good as I remembered. Rooftop is the start of the tour and sets the scene for the amazing shapes that Gaudi incorporates in his architecture and great views of the city in all directions. Move on to the exhibition of models and videos explaining Gaudi's work and finally the apartment laid out in original style. Not a cheap entrance fee but well worth it and no one rushes you through so take your time to enjoy looking.

Good experience. From the three main Gaudi works I would have to say this tied w Sagrada Familia. Prepare for a long walk up several flights of stairs w the final stop on the roof. The view of Barcelona from the roof was awesome. And all the Gaudi embelishments (?) were right there for picture taking (you might have to wait a few minutes to get a clear shot tho). The tour ends in an apartment which was very interesting to see the layout of the bedrooms, kitchen, living and bathing areas. We walked by at night when there were no crowds to see how the building was lit. We could see additional details in some of the lower apartments - very unique. I would say this is a do not miss (along w Sagrada Familia).

Worth It For The Rooftop . The roof is the highlight: otherworldly architecture with great views of the city. The tour starts there and it is where you should linger. The interior of the building is less impressive compared with Casa Batllo, though not uninteresting. Most of the block is closed to the public. For the price of admission you see a typical apartment, the stairwells, the rooftop (worth the price), some museum-style displays and an exhibition space - showing lacklustre photography, not associated with Gaudi, on our visit - that we found very disappointing and a poor note to end on. The audio guide was probably the least substantial we heard while in Barcelona.

Very different and interesting.. Well worth seeing another Antonia Gaudi designed building and as usual, an amazing structure quite different from the norm. A must see. Probably worth booking ahead although we didn't and did not have to wait too long.
Beautiful Apartment. Well worth a visit, the audio guide was very informative. Would have liked more of a description on staged room exhibits, particularly the pieces of equipment.

Wow. Antoni Gaudi was truly an amazing architect, and this building is as stunning as the others which he built. Combined with a nice audio guide, you can enjoy the place for well over an hour, especially the rooftop.

A must see. Part of a Gaudi fest on our recent Barcelona break. Strongly recommend booking online, worth waiting to do when you are there as you can download your pass to your phone and pick a time that suits other plans.At first, I thought that La Pedrera was overshadowed by the grandeur of Sagrada and the uniqueness of Casa Batlo, but stick with it. The roof is incredible and the exhibition in the attic on Gaudi and his architecture is excellent. The refurbished apartment is also excellent, though a wee bit jarring' in the 'fit' between Gaudi's brilliant design and early20th century style. The colonic irrigation kit in the bathroom is also a curiosity!

Most unusual architecture. Gaudí built La Pedrera for the prominent Milà Family. This is the most unusual architecture I've ever seen and so innovative for the time. Have a look at how Gaudí designed the peepholes (mirilla) for the doors. Definitely worth a visit. There are people still living and working there.

Worth seeing if you have the time. This was a pretty neat architectural specimen, especially considering it is/was an apartment building. There's a pretty neat view of La Sagrada Familia from one of the rooftop archways which makes for a pretty cool Gaudi within Gaudi shot.
Magnificient Surprise ..By Night. A `Must See' if you want to understand Gaudi architecture, close-up. The tour at night is a `One of its kind' ..
Gaudi masterpiece.. Not too busy in the morning so we really enjoyed our visit. The apartment was simply fabulous, how wonderful it must have been to live as they did.
Just fantastic. It was busy when we went but such an amazing place to visit. What a genius he was! We bought tickets prior to our visit which was well worth doing as there was a long queue

Elegance and style. I have been twice to La Pedrera. Once during the day with an audio guide and the second time I did the Secret Pedrera, which is the evening tour. The plus of the first tour is that I enjoyed more the roof and chimneys during the day. But the night tour gives the possibility to enjoy the house without crowds, the group is limited to 30 persons and you have all the space just for this small group. I liked that the tour ended with a glass of champagne, which makes the tour more special.In any case, seeing the house from inside during the day or in the evening, is like being a guest of the wealthy people who lived there. I would recommend booking in advance to skip the queues.

More from the genius. There are 2 types of people in this world those who appreciate Gaudi and those who don't. After Segrada Familia it's hard to give 5 stars to any other building but that would so unfair on all the other wonderful architecture around the world. The queue was about 15 mins long. the interior is not as spectacular as the facade until you get to the roof. Got to be the most famous roof space in the world and worth the admission fee alone. There was also an exhibition in the attic space (also worthy of praise) explaining some of the great man's influences and techniques together with some furniture on display. Well worth a visit if you appreciate Gaudi

Slightly Overrrated. My husband and I did the night tour on the day we arrived at Barcelona. Probably we were expecting something more grand and ended up feeling disappointed. Others in our tour, liked it and not sure why :)Feel its overrated, Casa Batllo is much better in comparison.If you decide to visit, better to book it online!

Must visit to see the roof statues and views!. One of Gaudi's most innovative buildings, with beautiful wavy lines, balconies resembling seaweed, and so innovative for the time. The roof is quite astonishing with incredible statues (actually covering up the boring utilities!). Lots of steps so don't attempt if infirm. Wonderful views down the Passeig de Gracia and towards the Sagrada Familia. After the roof you walk down through a museum of rooms, all containing period pieces. Even the underground carpark was the first of its kind.

Timeless and Outstanding . Booked on the Internet 20 mins before we went so no need to pay extra for the Premium access. First we went to the roof. Take EXTREME care in moving around as the steps are either very small of very deep. Another tourist had a bad fall hitting her head. First Aid assistance was there in a flash. The roof is certainly different, with a great description on the free audio guide. Spectacular views. We did the daytime tour but can imagine that at night it would be breathtaking! Next we entered the loft with its hundreds of arches. The short videos are really informative. The apartment is fabulous and a great way to imagine life at that period. The temporary photo Exhibition was excellent and well put together. On leaving we were given a 10% discount voucher for the Cafe. We had lunch outside which was served by friendly staff . The menu was either a snack menu which was what we went for or 2 set price options. The flatbreads were great , simple but very tasty as was the salad.
Overpriced and overcrowded. We arrived before 10 and it was already packed, mostly groups of schoolchildren who didn't want to be there. Interesting place but not worth 20 euros.

Gaudi's masterpiece. An incredible building with an incredible history. A "must do: visit for Barcelona. We did the night tour and saw the roof lit in all its glory. True art work that you can walk through. Being on the roof is like being in another world....the glowing statues remind you of an army or of some historic time. Quite amazing.

Introduction to Gaudi...and Barcelona. The real start of our Barcelona visit. The morning of our first full day we went directly to La Pedrera. We did not have time to reserve tickets on line so we showed up at the 9 AM opening which worked out well - only about 20 people ahead of us. The entrance fee is 16.5 euros; audio guide is 4 euros. The outside façade was under restoration and shielded by screening.The visits to the apartments, the attic and the rooftop exceeded expectations. The apartments are a time capsule of Barcelona life in the early 1900s. The attic is for lovers of architecture - most fascinating were the upside-down models he developed to analyze the structural elements of his work - well in advance of computer analyses. The rooftop offers great views of Barcelona as well as the whimsical chimneys of Gaudi.This house, as well as the other Gaudi works at Parc Guell and La Sagrada Familia, are the premier sights in Barcelona in my estimation. This site is worth 2 to 3 hours of your time. They will be forever engrained in your memory.

beautiful and full of great info. this place has what Casa Battlo was missing - a demonstration of how to decorate and use the rooms - it is a beautiful building. Again the rooftop runs with the most attention - it is insane how every detail is super cared for and lots of great info.

Really worthwhile. So pleased we visited this block of apartments designed by Gaudi, it is stunning from the outside but the roof and period apartment are really worth seeing, as is the Gaudi exhibition in the attic space, all included in the ticket price. We booked timed tickets online but there was a very small queue when we arrived on Sunday morning at 11.30am.

So amazing, a must-see!. Such a beautiful place with amazing architecture. I would recommend getting tickets online to avoid the lines. It is very crowded and only made worse by audio and video guides given to each visitor. These things aside, it is amazing. My second favorite part of Barcelona (next to Park Guell)

Awesome. We arrived without a reservation, joined a short line, and paid 27 euros each for priority entry--7 euros more than the regular price. It was well worth it. We got right in, and went to the head of each line, escorted by a nice young woman who seemed to know where we were at every moment. Because I walk with a cane, we also got to use the residents' 100 year old wood-paneled elevator. The place is awesome (the word is not used lightly here) especially the rooftop. The outside of the building,and the interior courtyard, are incredible. I would not want to be living in the apartment, but it was interesting. The details, such as the furniture and door handles, were fascinating. Wow

Unique!. Another must-stop place if you want to see the artistry of a genius! The architecture was ahead of its time, as it is unique even today! The facade detailing is beautiful! Get on top of the roof to see the architectural chimneys! Like nothing you've ever seen before!

Overpriced, but AMAZING. As with all things Gaudi, book in advance to avoid the line. You don't get to see as much of the building as in Gaudi's other works, but the rooftop alone is worth the visit. In my opinion, La Pedrera tops Casa Batllo (although mine seems to be the minority opinion). I could spend all day on the roof!

inspiration for Star Wars. Stunning building, a real masterpiece of Gaudis, and reputedly the inspiration for Star Wars when George Lucas visited....see the rooftop sculptures. The exhibition in the attic explaining Gaudi's inspiration and techniques for this and his other works was particularly fascinating.

Interior design is stunning. Lovely.. The outside is an attraction in and of itself but if you venture indoors and take the tour you will not be disappointed. I believe there are still residents here. The film presentations throughout are great to watch as they describe Gaudy's thoughts and ideas. Wonderful exhibit. Don't miss this one & very close to the Majestic Hotel.

Inside the mind of a creative genius. Our 13 year old granddaughter had seen pictures of the roof and just HAD to see this. We took our chances and all agreed the wait was worth. Absolutely amazing! Granddaughter: "A look inside the creative genius of Gaudi's mind." A chance to see how the bourgeois lived.

Easy touring. We go there early and had breakfast at the resto there. Good service. Great views of the city from the roof. Love the architecture. The furniture and hardware are inspiring. Learned a lot about Gaudi.

Well worth a visit. We were two adults and two teenagers and we all loved la Pedrera. It's a beautiful house full of great designs and the rooftop is magnificent! You can buy tickets online before the visit to avoid any queues.

As nature intended.. Only Gaudi can design something like this. With his love of combining nature and architecture he once again shows the world that there is and only ever will be one Gaudi. Great talking recorded guide, nice short video films and the models gave us the behind the scenes background. This museum home will bring out the dreamer and artist and remind us to dream big and create our dreams and bring them to reality. Gaudi did this... A definite on any Barcelona trip. Well worth the 20 euros.

Expensive. The entrance fee is 20 euros - and that makes this attraction overpriced - not worth it. However we paid 3 euros to see a photography show on the 2nd floor for 3 euros and then just climbed the stairs to the top floor and roof (good exercise!) - for that price it was worth it. The apartment is furnished in 50s style and its redeeming feature is that there are no straight lines - interesting but not gushingly so - and the roof is worth a look. Its not very practical though should anyone want to use it for anything useful - no level spaces. For 3 euros I would see it if you can sneak in!! Nice gift shop on 1st floor.

Stunning example of Gaudi's twisted brilliance. A superb example of the true genius of Antonio Gaudi, the shapes and structures are like something through the looking glass. If you have the chance take the night tour, we were lucky the night was perfectly clear and we could even see the Sagrada Familia through the arch on the roof. The attic is an engineers dream to see.

Bizarre looking building inside and outside. This is one of Gaudi's creations and he even lived in it. The outside, the roof and inner court are funny looking (some call it modern). The intern is a museum of his works and the apartment he lived in, with all the furniture. There is an entrance fee.

Another surprise. I was a reluctant visitor but my partner wanted to see this Gaudi inspired creation. As it happens I really enjoyed the visit and the roof walk was just the beginning. The attic and museum were really well done and although pricey I was reassured to know that the euros were going to a good cause-supporting disadvantaged Catalonians. Another long wait to get tickets -better to buy on line if you can

One of the biggest enjoyments.... ...for me. The Barcelona Card made it easy to see all these famous places in Barcelona in one visit...and I was lucky enough to be early there to enjoy some quiet times over the roof tops of Barcelona in the early morning, "strolling" around on the roof of the building and listening to the audio guide, which I thought, was very well done and worthwhile to listen to. It got me really in the subject of Gaudi. I will go back again for a 2nd time.
Don't miss this. Again, this is one of those architectural wonders where it helps to have your brain engaged. Look closely and listen closely to the audio tour. It is amazing what Gaudi did.

Bad timing. Unfortunately this building was shrouded in scaffolding and builders sheets, such a shame. Could just about make out the tops of the building. I would love to visit Barcelona again and add this to my list!
Must-see architecture!. Went on Gaudi tour with ForeverBarcelona. This was included. The roof is spectacular as are the views. Gaudi's creativity and innovation are so evident in Casa Mila!

Just stunning. Start by having a coffee in the cafe at the foot of the building and enjoy the most exquisite and strange ceiling you are ever likely to see. The Casa Pedrera is a must-see - from the inner courtyard and staircase to the apartment set out with Gaudi's ideas for living to the attic with its amazing brickwork and very informative museum to the magnificent chimneys on the roof - and that does not take into account the great view you have when you get there.

Genius Ahead of His Time: Gaudi. This is a place for those with interest in architectures and interior decor. Standing right in the middle of trendy Paseig De Gracia, it is an eye catching building with its curves. What amazes me is that every thing seems so contemporary although designed and built over 100 years ago. The designs and decor of the lifts,the hall, the kitchen, the doors are so efficient and clean. The pre recorded head phones are useful to introduce one to the history and detailed planning by the architectural genius, even without a guide. The fellow visitors are obviously art and architectural lovers who think nothing of spending 2-3 hours to leisurely examine this place. In all a good learning experience about Gaudi & his works.

Fabulous tour. We booked in advance and paid extra for the premium tour, this was well worth it as we were able to go when it suited us and had no need to queue - a bonus with young children! We found the audio guide really useful as we gained lots of info but at our own speed! The rooftop is stunning and even though there were quite a few other people up there with us you can still get to look at it with ease. The attic space is fantastic and the audio guide was really useful here as it explained how Gaudi designed the building and my girls came away with an understanding of the architecture, I doubt they would have picked up with just the visuals. The apartment was also interesting and gave you a different way to view the building as usually you only see it from the outside! My girls particularly enjoyed the roof and the scale models of the buildings. A must see when in Barcelona.

Get to understand Gaudi & his works. We went here after we went to Parc Guell and it was the perfect sequence to better understand the work of Gaudi and his impact to Barcelona. He was a man before his time and my bet is other architects have since copied his style.

Great architecture, but under renovation. Went here, but disappointingly it was under renovation. But the gift shop still open and I visited it. But it was very disappointing that the building was under construction and the whole building was covered up. There was a fee to go inside but we decided not to.

Interesting, stunning and well worth the visit. Again with all attractions in the city get tickets in advance or pay extra to go in. Gaudi designed apartments with light, space and ingenious design features

extraordinary. I decided to take the time to visit Casa Mila. Outside, of course, beauty. But inside, say something extraordinary. Unfortunately, already paid, I learned that not all floors and rooms are open for viewing. To be honest, a little expensive it turns out, if you count the time stay inside. But at least once to see - it's definitely worth it!The excursion starts from the observation deck. Queue waiting for a lift, slowly people rise to the top and then walk down the stairs and open to the public visiting the floors. Upstairs beautiful! View of Barcelona! And somehow comfortable on the court. People enjoying the view, waiting quietly in front of them when someone makes a photo in the place where they, too, would like to be photographed. You can just sit on the steps.Next is a room with information on building layouts, movie. Going down below, you get on the residential floor. There, each apartment with amazing interiors.

Amazingly quirkiy and in the heart of a shopping area!!!. If you like shopping and architecture you can combine the two. The La Pendrea house is in one of the main shopping areas of Barcelona. We weren't heading for it but stumbled upon it, so glad we did. What a delight. Designed by Gaudi it's a wonderful experience with a very quirky roof top twist. Highly recommended. Then off to shop!!!

Worth the visit. I had limited time on my visit to Barcelona and had to choose between this and Casa Battlo for a Gaudi museum. I chose this on the advice of a guidebook, but after walking past Casa Battlo I was doubting my choice. I suspect both are good. Interesting exhibits and nice to see the interiors of the period. Also happened upon a photography exhibit in the gallery downstairs that was quite good.
Brilliant - don't miss it!. Fascinating commentary and an amazing insight into Gaudi's life and work; this is, in my opinion, more interesting than Casa Batllo. Don't miss it

Excellent. It looks like there are no cheap attractions in Barcelona. Casa Mila, named also La Pedrera, is one of the places that must be seen. Is an amazing exerience. A ticket costs about 18-20 euro and as almost everywhere in Barcelona, the best thing to do is to order it on-line and to avoit the long waiting lines. But i must say I don't regret paying so much time and money.

Excellent introduction to Gaudi. We bought our tickets in advance on line and paid extra for no waiting. The lines first thing in the morning were short so we did not have to spend the extra cash, but it was nice knowing that we would not have to wait. The view from the roof is stunning- next time we want to see it at night. The display in the attic was informative and it was nice to see an apartment. This is a must do event when you visit Barcelona.

Evening tour. Fantastic we booked before we travelled for the evening guided tour in English starting at 8.30pm. Our guide was informative and clearly spoken able to answer any and all questions we where lucky only to have a small group of around 15. We where given plenty of time to explore and a lot of time on the roof enjoying the views of Barcelona by night followed by a glass of cava and sweets. If you are going to Barcelona this should be high on your list of things to do well worth the entrance fee. Make sure you book online before you go direct with the casa Mila website is best.

Private evening tour!. This was fabulous. I wish I had been Mrs Mila ( or even just the maid) - how could she have not loved living here. Fancy giving away all your furniture and moving out after your husband died! We did a private guided tour once the museum was closed and was worth every penny. The guide was v informative. The loft space that was used as the laundry area was awesomely amazing - would make a great apartment especially with access onto the roof. Would have loved to have gone in the summer to attend a jazz concert up there.

nice..... to view. was located at a cross road, just view from a far....was expected it to be more secluded and in a less traffic area. we didn't go in for the tour, it was just enough to look from outside for us. perhaps we are not such architecture fans

Beautiful building - only spoilt by the weather so that we couldnt make the most of the views from the rooftop. Beautiful building with absolutely fabulous views from the rooftop - Apartments were beautiful and generously sized. The history of the building and Gaudi's influence on other structures in Barcelona was fascinating
Amazing to see. This is a classic Gaudi, the exterior is impressive and breathtaking! Gaudi makes amazing buildings that are not only beautiful but also useful! Great Place
a glimpse. Very neat little tour. Good attic museum that explains a lot. Expensive, but a must for those who love the architecture of Barcelona.

Classic Gaudi. We were able not only to see the interesting exterior architecture, but to go to the rooftop and to see an apartment decorated in furnishings of the times. The views of the city from the rooftop with the uncompleted Sagrada Familia in the background were phenomenal

Great architecture with museum information and its still in use apartment building. La Pedrera is still an in-use apartment building! What the tour does is take you to the top floor to see the brick arches and lets you look through an architecture museum there of Gaudi's work (very interesting). Then you get to see the roof with unusual chimneys and a pretty good view of the city. The one apartment you can tour through is set-up as it would have been a century ago with all the period furniture. The audio guide is well done.
