Chimney!!!!. Another Gaudi mastepiece, not to be compared with Casa Batilo as they are different and both spectacular example of his work.My favorite was the roof top, what a way to do a chimney.The attic had an exhibition of Gaudi's works including models and descriptions on how he designed.

breathtaking. This was our first introduction to Gaudi and was a wonderful experience. The sheer genius of the man is stunning. The chimneys and vents on the roof are incredible, and had we known we would have done the evening tour but it would have been too expensive to do both. The museum is a tribute to such a genius

Best of Guadi. La Pedrera is the best and the last work of Guadi. the design he made is still contemporary untill now. For me Casa Batllo is a bit out date. Don't get me wrong casa Batllo is unique and very beautiful, and totally enjoy to visit but it look like something obsolete. But La Pedrera is Classic. A real design and architecture Gems. A rare Jewel. it is beyond time. Its not only unique its also real master piece of master piece.even the ticket a bit high, Still wanna pay again to go back there.

Casa Mila from top to bottom. One of the most amazing buldings I have ever been in. I was so lucky to have friend living in Barcelona who knew somebody that lived in Casa Mila. This lady lived in a 300 sq mt or more apt. where her parents and grand parents had lived before her. I was able to explore the building from top to bottom. Most of the furniture in her apt. were original to the period Casa Mila was built and and some were original pieces designed by Gaudi. She took the time to show me how the plaster moldings surrounding the doors had been hand formed by pressing ones thumb into the fresh plaster. I think the highlight of my visit was when she showed me the bedroom that had been hers as a child had a poem inscribed in the ceilings plaster that has been written by Gaudi himself. Oh, the stone work, the wrought iron work, the tile work on the interior courtyard, the tile work on the chimneys... endless awe!

Good place to visit. We went to La Pedrera not expecting to enjoy it as much as we did. The tour is interesting and the headsets and information great to follow. The rooftop is stunning and a great place for photos, the rooms inside are very ornate. We spent over 2 hours here when we expected to be there only about an hour. Worth seeing.
Great building leading to.... The inside is o.k. But get on the roof. Magnificent chimney pots. Gaudi was a genius. This cannot be seen properly from below.

Worth seeing, but expect to wait.. If nothing else, the location and stroll up the Passeig Gracia is worth it. Gaudi's works are all stunning, but this one draws long lines. I wouldn't recommend this for kids; it takes a while to work your way through the entire building, and you'll want to spend some time up on the roof admiring the chimneys.

Another Gaudi Masterpiece. We viewed this building externally as part of a free walking tour dedicated to Gaudi's works, but did not view it internally because of time constraints. In its time it was greeted with a mixed reception, with many locals nicknaming it La Pedrera, 'the stone quarry' because they thought it very plain for the times and their expectations of Gaudi. It is undoubtedly a significant contrast to the ornate Casa Batllo further down the same street; I personally loved it because I think that the whole thing works in harmony - fine materials, detail and quality of finish but not as colourful.It is possible to go inside but for a significant entry fee; given the wealth of other things to see and do in Barcelona we didn't return.

Impressive. The team of La Pedrera managed to create one of this very unusual experiences - both entertaining and intellectual. I had a guided tour but I suspect that the one on your own would be great too. Very nice mixture of different formats and activities. And of course cafe on the ground floor. Must.

Amazing even at 100 years old. This was inspiring and brilliant. What a visionary and organic architect. You don't need to get into the queue and wait for an hour. Go to the front gate and ask for a premium ticket. It'll cost a few more euros, but it'll save you an hour.

Amazing but nit as good or worth the same price as Casa Batillo. At Casa Batiilo you get six floors or so of Madness, here you'll see the ground floor courtyard and the roof, the rest of the building is still in use. So if you are short of time do Casa Batillo and segarada... that said the roof is stunning and in the attic of the roof you can see some exibits, there are some glass cases containing some odd things, such as A pine cone, an animal skeleton ..... odd you'll think, unitl you look again...then you'll see where Gaudi got his inspiration for structures, water proofing and strength from...quite inspiring if you like to know what made him tick! Oh P.s Its alot of stairs up to the roof!! My knees hurt like hell by the end ! worth the look though!

Top sights. If you are not familiar with Gaudi´s work this is will blow your mind. La Pedrera is completely different from any building you may have visited. Rooftop is crazy, attic is amazing and the architecture details in the building are impressive.A "must visit" in Barcelona. Audio guide (included in tour) has a very nice description of everything.

The Rooftop Alone is Worth It. We saw both La Pedrera and Casa Batllo and the two complemented each other wonderfully. La Pedrera is huge and not nearly as intimate, but is another great example of Guadi's modernism. The museum was very informative and explained a lot of features also found in Casa Batllo, but were explained much better. It is not only a fantastic aesthetic achievement, it is an engineering one as well. The rooftop is spectacular with all of its fanciful chimneys. We must have spent 45 minutes on the roof. The museum occupies the attic, with all of its catenary arches, which were used in Casa Batllo and the Sagrada Familia and allow the entire structure to be supported by its walls -- no interior wall is load-bearing. The apartment tour was also very interesting. While there were many modern conveniences (very modern for the time!), the apartment is modest and contrasts somewhat with the spectacular building itself. I think we ended up spending nearly 3 hours going through the whole tour -- we were very thorough and you could do it quicker, but if you want to savor it, there is a lot to savor.

Second to Casa Batllo and third to Sagrada Familia. I take the night tour as I want to get a different feeling of Gaudi's work. I am not disappointed and our tour guide Maria does a very good job in explaining the history of the building and relationship of Gaudi with the owner. Like other say in there that a small group of people basically has the whole build itself and there is no other traffic. The tour is very well organised and it reflects Gaudi's talent completely. We tour around one of the flat on 4th floor and then move no to Attic and finally at the roof top. I would not say much of details in here because you will need to be there to understand the work behind it with the real thing in front of you. The tour ends with champagne and Q&A. It might be a bit pricy comparing to other two main attractions. However, you are with a small group and the building does not have other people around you. You can really enjoy and feel the work of Gaudi. Our tour guide Maria is informative and patience. If you want a full experience of Gaudi's work, I suggest that you go for the night tour.

La Pedrera - quite a place. Since my last trip to Bcn, I was hankering to see the LaPedrera aka Casa Mila. This is one of the top sights to see here so prepare to spend some time queueing. The earlier you arrive the less legnthy the line is. I recommend to arrive at 10 am. The entrance fee is quite high (20,50 ?) but you get bang for your money. The view from the upper roof is breathtaking. I do not recommend this place persons who are not confortable with walking in steep stairs. The roof is practically made of stairs without sturdy reelings. All in all, place to see.

Gaudi again and again :-). This guy has done so much for Barcelona and architecture and interior design since 100 years ago that is unbelievable. Maybe a bit pricey to get in but the story and the views are worth it. Enjoy.
My favorite one. I've spend the last days exploring the city and this one is my favorite one above all of Gaudi's structures.Take at least 1,30 hours to really know it

Really interesting. Although quite expensive to get in, the visit was really worth it - starting at the top, the roof was fantastic and then inside the roof space was impressive. The design of it all was the highlight!
Gaudi's Art. Another masterpiece of Gaudi. The building is unique and beautiful. It's not as elaborate on the outside as some of his other works, but definitely worth visiting.
Just Amazing!. Another stunning masterpiece. Not only is the facade of the building unique, but the added touches such as the laced balcony rails compliment the designs so well. Another must see.

My favourite activity whilst in Barcelona.. My husband and I decided to visit in the late afternoon/early evening, which was great because it was not at all crowded and we felt that we almost had the place to ourselves. It is not a cheap visit. However, there is a lot to the museum and there was a lot of very interesting information to take in and the audio guide was included. Being able to go out onto the rooftop was amazing; the views of Barcelona were stunning and you can even see La Sagrada Familia through one of the arches - at sunset this was gorgeous. My husband is a very big fan of Gaudi and he was bouncing with delight at every different part of the building that he encountered. We both agreed that this was the best thing to visit in Barcelona. We spent over 2 hours here and, if we hadn't arranged to meet a friend at a certain time, we would have probably stayed longer!

A magical tour by night. We booked the "Secret Pedrera" tour, which was really enjoyable. The organic shapes of the house seem to become alive at night. Even though only a limited part of the house is accessible, it is still amazing. The cherry on the top was the rooftop walk, overlooking Barcelona by night. Peaceful and magical. The tour ended with a glass of fizz and we then had dinner in the Cafe de la Pedrera, which is worth a look. The food was very nice too, albeit not the finest we've had in Barcelona. All in all a wonderful experience.
Another Gaudi Masterpiece!. This is our second visit to Barcelona, and we didn't visit La Pedrera on our first visit, but wish we had! It really is Gaudi at his best. Put it on your list!
amazing view especially at night!. It's really worthwhile to visit. Best visit time should be evening before dark, then you can enjoy both day view & night view. Also save the qeue up time.

Amazing :-). We took a guided tour, which is worth the extra 5E.
The tour was from 18:00 to 20:00, so we got in at daytime, and finished after dark. That was cool, because the building looks different...
Buy tickets online - and skip standing in the line... :-)

Amazing place. Get the audioguide.. Antoni Gaudi's ability to blend form and function are clearly demonstrated in this unique building. The audioguide is excellent, and helped me to better appreciate the intricate and thoughtful planning that went into Casa Mila. Plan to spend a fair amount of time on the rooftop looking at the views that have been carefully framed for you by the architect. The attic exhibits are also excellent.
No words !!. There are no words, this house is just amazing, we can see all the genious of Gaudi. This is definitely my favorite

Second Favorite Gaudi Work. I really enjoyed the building. Well worth the price to go in a tour the rooftop, attic, and a floor of apartments. The price seems high, but it is worth it. I put in above Casa Batllo since there seems to be more to the building in terms of structure, form, and function. The whole attic space is dedicated to Gaudi. You learn a lot more about him at this attraction than Casa Batllo. Don't use a tour guide, just get the free audio guide so you are free to move about on your own will. The ticket line was not bad, but it was not at high season. I would suggest buying tickets online during high season.

awesome !!!. Casa Milà, popularly known as «La Pedrera» (the stone quarry), an ironic allusion to the resemblance of its façade to an open quarry, was constructed between 1906 and 1912 by Antoni Gaudí (1852-1926). For its uniqueness, artistic and heritage value has received major recognition and in 1984 was inscribed on UNESCO World Heritage List, for its exceptional universal value. Nowadays is the headquarters of Fundació Catalunya-La Pedrera and houses a cultural centre that is a reference in Barcelona for the range of activities it organises and the different spaces for exhibitions and other public uses it contains.

An extraordinary Apartment House. Barcelona was so lucky to have wealthy industrialists/businessmen who used their wealth to employ Antonio Gaudi over a century ago to build such unusual homes. This building dominates a corner block and is so different to the neighbouring buildings. Once again the roof terrace is a key feature of the building, but throughout there is so much to see. Yet another "must see" on a visit to Barcelona.

Do the night tour if you can.. It's an amazing buiding to see any time of day, but we chose to do the evening tour and it was unbelievable to stand on the roof of the Pedrera and look out on Barcelona lit up at night. I would suggest buying tickets online ahead of time because tours are limited in size.

Very interesting building. I was a bit sceptical about what we will get for the ?21 entrance fee, but I was very happy in the end. The ticket includes an audioguide at no extra cost. You will start in the inner courtyard, which was the least interesting bit for me, but you will quickly proceed to the roof which is very much worth the visit, both for the design of the roof itself, and for the views over the city. The next stop is the attic, which looks amazing, consisting of corridors of thin bick arches. The last stop is the apartment on the top floor, which is also quite beautiful. Visit when sunny!

Overpriced.... Overpriced and pretentious. Not worth the entrance fee for a tour around an "example" apartment and a questionable view from the rooftop. Two separate souvenir shops, which you MUST walk through to exit, make it clear what this place is: a money filter for tourists. Even if you are a fan of Gaudi, there are better, more enjoyable examples of his work than this; this is nothing more than a tourist trap.

Secret La Pedrera. We booked an evening small group visit at 20.30 with dinner at 55euro, not cheap but worth it. It was not rushed, we had time to look and enjoy. The guide was excellent. We were on the roof and had the whole place to ourselves, a rare privilage. The visit ended with a glass of bubbly and the restaurant waited for us with dinner. We also had the whole restaurant to ourselves. Truly romantic!!! Thanks Gaudi for this unusual house. I wish other architects had courage and vision to build fun buildings. But please no more 'walkie talkie buildings' - The ugliest building in London!!!

Another example of Gaudi. This is his penultimate work and is very much a working house,so not all is on view.However the roof and attic are worth the visit alone to understand his thinking and skill.Whilst not my favourite Gaudi work it still makes you take a breath.

20 euros to get into a block of flats!. didnt even bother going in here as everything to do with Gaudi in this city whilst beautiful is expensive, 20 euros each to walk up the stairwells and see the roof is a little expensive, took my photos outside!

Amazing. A must see from the inside and out! Not only is the outside amazing, the inside is well worth 20 euros (if u also do the bus sightseeing tour they give you a discount voucher for many of the big attractions like Casa Mila, Segrada Familia, Montjuic cable car and many more) We were given free audio guides which were very good. They take you to the roof by lift first and you work your way down by stairs. The interior is spectacular.....the structure and design unbelieveable.

Fantastic!. We went here for a visit and found it amazing. Right on the main street, next to all the big shops, it looks great! Well worth the money and the views and photos from the top make it worthwhile. You should visit here, this is what Barcelona is all about.

Lovely!. Another incredible Gaudi building! La Pedreda is a beautiful building that has amazing details inside and out - from the doors, to the walls and all the impeccable details. Fascinating. Worth the entrance fee to take a look inside this magnificent edifice. Simply outstanding. Most highly recommended.

Amazing. What an amazing building and I wish all architects put thought into their designs just as Gaudi did. His attention to detail was astounding, the architrave's around the doors were beautiful as were the doors and handles themselves. It was lovely to be allowed to walk through the historic rooms and expedience the flow without being held back at the door. What an amazing experience, sorry hubby I now have different expectations for my home!!

Superb, mad but magnificant. We loved this building, there is nowhere quite like it. Gaudi was a genius and way before his time. If only buildings were built so beautifully today. Barcelona would not be the same without the Gaudi influence.

Another place not to be missed when you are in Barcelona. I would say it is a no 2 in Barcelona. It is a beautiful building, and it was really interesting to visit and learn something about Gaudi's amazing work. We booked tickets in advance.

Very impressed. This building was having its exterior worked on so everything n the outside was covered over so we could'nt see it. Tickets were not hard to get for a look on the inside. We were given a receiver that gave us information on each position we passed. This I highly recommended. You won't be disappointed if you go. The apartments are very impressive and the roof top views are out of this world and breath taking.

Amazing and unique building. Our fourth Gaudi work during our stay in Barcelona, breathtaking how Gaudi did designed this more than 100 years ago, a must see when you are in Barcelona. We get with our Barcelona card discount on the entry.
great. It's just simlpe great.I wish just would live in it. The roof is one of the best, and the view is excellent.

My boyfriends favourite. Like all of his work it is amazing!
This was my boyfriends favourite, im scared of Heights but pushed passed my fear to see it all.
We booked the audio tour and loved every minute of it!
Defo worth a visit!

Amazing building . Great place to visit , well worth the 20 € from the outstanding roof top to the wonderful rooms cascading down with in the building , ensure you go when it's not raining as they shut the roof section off which is a must see .

A house build by Gaudi. It cost 21 euro, but it is well worth seeing. You start at the roof were you can see the city of Barcelona and building build by Gaudi. The chimneys are strange, they look like soldiers.
Inside many things to be seen
Weird & Wonderful. Another amazing creation by Gaudi. We never did go in the building, another entree fee of €20. But truly enjoyed the outside.

Fantastic architecture worth seeing. We were a bit sceptical about going into casa Mila as we aren't big art/architecture fans but this place is really something else and I can only imagine how fantastic it would have been to live in this apartment block. The tickets are expensive at €20 each but I think you get to see a lot for this price. You can visit the main entrance, the roof top, the attic space and one of the apartments. Casa Mila is easy to get to using the tube stations and is only just up the road from casa batilo. We decided to only do this attraction rather than both as we had read they were fairly similar.

La Pedrera-Mila House,Barcelona,Spain. La Pedrera it's one of the Gaudi's amazing creations.For its exceptional value, in 1984 was inscribed on Unesco World Heritage List .The roof top reveals the genius of Gaudi and the view of the city is spectacular !!! Purchasing online tickets is the best way to avoid the queue for tickets.
Not the most interesting tour. The audioguide was quite boring. The line was extremely long. You do not get to see much for what we paid. I much preferred the Casa Batlló which is also by Gaudi.

stunning creation. It may not be a cheap tour but La Pedrera ( translates to "the quarry") is well worth the entrance fee. From the moment you step into the inner courtyard to the ascent to the rooftop and down again through one of the apartments you are awe-inspired. This is a work of true artistic and engineering genius which anyone visiting Barcelona should try and see.

Amazing Apartment. It is probably a tad too expensive but still should not be missed if you are a fan of Gaudi. The rooftop with it's strange chimneys is amazing, the atrium is stunning and a great insight to life in Gaudi's time is the visit inside one of the apartments with it's period furnishings.
La Pedrera - Mila House (Casa Mila). IT'S AN AMAZING PLACE, Antoni Gaudí is a genius to create something so specular in his prime time. Must visit

Amazing. Worth a visit just to stand on this iconic roof top. It's an amazing journey through moderisim and you will not be disappointed. This city has so much to see and do and this is one of its high lights.
Beautiful. Worth doing the night trip, the view of the city looks amazing from the roof top. The guide was not that good but the view was worth it.

going back 100 years. Worth visiting the roof and the rooms with old furnitures. You need to enjoy design or architecture to profit most from the visit as the small details are the nicest thing. Definitely book in the internet and jump the lines. The audio guide that comes with it provides good information.

Not worth the 20 euro per person. Aside from the roof and the level below which were not mind blowing to say the least，this is totaly not worth your time and money，unless you like taking pictures of an old stove，hanging portraits and dusty dinning table...

Fascinating, don't miss this, it's not just for Gaudi lovers. Get there early because the queues can be long. Your ticket gives you head phones for a tour that takes you through the central lobby, up onto the roof where you walk amongst the strangely shaped giant chimney pots, into the attic area which has been turned into a Gaudi museum and finally through an apartment. This has been decorated and furnished as it would have appeared when it was built. All are fascinating, the architecture is incredible. Don't miss this. Allow about 2 hours.

the roof and outside only. Is it worth 20 Euros+ each to view some old furnitures etc.Except for the interesting roof and front of the building ,there is nothing else for me anyway.I stayed at a nearby hotel and get free views from the hotel.Not worth 20 Euros.Despite asking to pay in euros,I got dynamically currency conversion (which is more advantageous to the Casa Mila),another negative
casa pedrera. Very nice and intresting if you like arts' design and beautiful designs art nouveau stile. It is recommended to buy a ticket in the internet !

Positively Awesome. Visited La Pedrera in August and, although the outside was covered for cleaning, the roof was worth the price of admission. Couldn't believe how unique Gaudi's roof was. He really was a genius! I believe that Darth Vader was created after viewing the chimney covers on the roof. It was very interesting to see the furnishings in one of the apartments. Although the building is very modern looking, the apartment was very traditional. Great view of Barcelona from the roof, too!

In Barcelona then La Pedrera. La Pedrera was built as an apartment building by the amazing Gaudi, very well run museum(you just go to see the building) and the views are great from the roof, you see La Sagrada Familia and take great photos

Not to be missed!. You cannot come to Barcelona and not visit La Pedrera (aka Casa Milá), Gaudí’s amazing apartment building. The rooftop features an astonishing set of architectural sculptures that function as stairwells, ventilation towers and chimneys. We purchased tickets that allowed us to skip the entrance line and come at any time on any day within a month, and included an audio tour as well as a coffee or other drink in the café. Well worth the few extra euros. This is my favorite of Gaudí’s structures in Barcelona.

La Pedrera at Night (Secretos de la Pedrera). I booked the tour at night, having been to La Pedrera during the day on a previous trip, it was great. I felt as though I had Casa Mils all to myself. The guide was great, very knowledgeable. The rooftop was a different world at night. After the tour, we went to the salon for a cava toast. My favorite way to see La Pedrera.

A great way to spend an afternoon. On an earlier visit to Barcelona we visited another of Gaudi's creations "Casa Ballto". This time we chose to visit La Pedrera. Both are amazing and well worth visiting. It would be hard to say which is best, both are great in their own way. The surprising thing is how far ahead of their time Gaudi's designs were. Much of what Gaudi included is only now being championed in Eco design.

Well worth a visit. Great to see some of Gaudi's work first hand. Audio guide included which was really useful without being long winded. The building is fascinating. The roof terrace is beautiful with stunning views across the city.

Great. This block of appartments has amazing architecture you wont see anywhere else. With a reasonable entry price of €20 (children €13) the Pedrera is a great family sight seeing spot. An audio guide lasting approximatly 40 minutes guides you around the roof terrace, attic and one of the appartments. The rest of the appartments are sold as appartmentst to live in so these are not available to look around. A lift offers a break for any tierd legs as you dont need to walk up to the roof terrace. However, there once you get up to the roof, there are quite a few steps that would cause quite a pain for a buggy or wheelchair. At the end of the tour, there is a gift shop which sells some memorabilia of Gaudi's architecture.

Another good example of Gaudi's genius. Definitely worth visiting to complete your exploration of Gaudi's work in Barcelona, but not as complete or impressive as some of the others. You get to see some parts of the building (ground floor courtyard, attic, roof and one of the apartments), with an extensive exhibition covering Gaudi's work. If you have limited time, in order of priority, I can suggest starting with Sagrada Familia, Casa Batlo, Palace Guell, and only after that Park Guell and Casa Mila.
A must. Fascinating place. Beautiful building. The roof top is incredibly intriguing with great views of Barcelona.

Casa Mila, Barcelona Spain. Visited Barcelona mid Nov 2014, exterior of Casa Mila still covered in renovation materials, so unable to view outside at all. But still well worth a visit. Late afternoon light was beautiful for taking photos of the rooftop, a highlight of my trip to Spain.The lift takes you past 3 floors not opened to the public, allow for at least 2 hrs to see everything if you are a Gaudi fan, we were on the roof for an hour alone! Lovely views of the city.The attic has amazing parabolic arches & a very informative display of how it was built. Has little seats where you can rest & watch continuous slide shows.Enjoyed the fully furnished apartment showing what it was like to live there in early 20th century. Check out the floor of the photo display room, interesting green patterned tiles, unsure if originals.Wandered around the ground floor court yard where beautifully painted staircase walls are floodlit, shows off the ironwork & railings. Cafe & usual gift shop on bottom floor, also a few seats out on the street just to gaze at the structure. Hope to visit again when the facade is unveiled, in the meantime, bought a postcard to remind me!
Beautiful . This is an amazing place. The roof top was so intriguing. I would love to be able to live in one of those apartments. I found it most interesting to see the apartments from the inside.

Excellent example of Gaudi architecture. For anyone interested in Gaudi architecture this is a must. There are several floors but only one is open for tourist . This floor is furnished in period furniture and gives a good idea of an upper middle class apartment in the late 1800's. The use of curved walls rather than the straight wall with which we are familiar was of special interest to me. It is well worth a visit . I suggest getting your tickets online to save a little , but more importantly, avoiding lines.

Has to be seen to be believed. What a splendid building. Hardly a straight line anywhere in the is architectural wonder. From floor to rooftop there is something different everywhere. Well worth a visit.

Worth passing by!. Walk up Passeig de Gracia and be sure to at least stop for 5 mins and admire this wonderous and unique building. There's a cafe inside on the street level. Can't say I've been there...yet. But the structure is absolutely one of the most original you will ever see. Interestingly enough, they used to actually rent the apartments out as residences.

Amazing. I loved this place! however my biggest recommendation is book tickets in advance and get there EARLY as it gets really busy. We were first in the line for entrance on the day we visited and it really paid off - we were the first people to access the roof top and it was stunning (with the added bonus of having tourist free pictures!) the views across Barcelona are pretty good, but in particular the sculptural aspects are amazing. That said if you aren't good with heights it may not be the best place to go! I am really scared of heights and I could just about cope - not sure I would have if it was busy though.The museum section is great but one of the best bits is being able to look around the apartment that is restored to how it would have been in it's original time - beautiful!Seriously recommend a visit to see a truly amazing piece of history!

EXPENSIVE, BUT VERY IMPRESSIVE MODERN BUILDING!. I Went to see this Antoni Gaudi's masterpiece by hop on hop off bus. When the audio commentary mentioned now we approach the La pedrera casa mila, then only I realised the building! Because this building adjoined with other apartment buildings. Tickets comparatively expensive, I bought online for 20.50 euros. However it's a must to go inside and see the great modern architectural marvellous. Specially the roof top. Ventilation towers, glass towers, paintings on the ceilings, even the staircase everything marvellous! Must see, then only realise the splendid modern work of the great Gaudi! I strongly recommend to visit place!

Love the roof top. I love the work of art especially the beautiful and quirky rooftop! My advise is to come early when the crowds are lesser than later part of the day! The audio guide tour will start from the roof top all the way to the bottom of the house. And.. Buy ur tickets online to skip the line!

Amazing. Interesting. Just okay. This apartment is simply amazing. It is beautiful, historical and designed like nothing else. The audio tour was informative and detailed. It's worth going, however you after a few gaudi buildings, you have seen a lot of things.

Interesting, but not my favorite Guadi house!. I enjoyed my visit to La Pedrera but it wasn't has amazing as I had hoped on the inside. The view from the roof was worth the admission fee though. If you have 2-3 days in Barcelona I would add this to the list but if pressed for time you may want to skip it.

Incredible Gaudi. A Gaudi masterpiece, also known as La Pedrera, or the Stonequarry in English. There was no queue (rare for Europe!), so we bought our tickets and walked straight in. The tickets are fairly expensive by European standards, but you have an audioguide included in your entry price. The audioguide was very informative, if a little wanky, and Clinton frequently chuckled at the unnecessarily verbose descriptions of the architectural features. The rooftop, with its chimneys topped with glass fragments and broken Valencia tiles, and amazing views over Barcelona was a highlight for me. We also learned about how Gaudi created his works in the impressive attic, which has been set up as an exhibition space. It has an arched roof and exposed brickwork, and despite being built more than 100 years ago, looked very modern. Gaudi often hung chains from boards that were suspended from the ceiling, which would fall in the parabolic shape that he featured so prominently in his designs. By looking at the reflection of these chains in a mirror, Gaudi would see what his creations would look like. An amazing tribute to a man well before his time!

expensive but amazing!. It's so enjoyable to visit the past, and present, Barcelona in this beautiful building. The building and apartments are still in use. The historically accurate apartment you visit is just lovely. The rooftop is breathtaking with it's sculptural city views. Dislike the chain link fencing, but I suppose it's the price for safety. The museum in the attic is fascinating. The gift shop is full of wonderful, if pricey, things. It only takes a couple hours. Yes, it's expensive, but it's Barcelona, it's Gaudi, it's one of a kind!

Great from the outside but too expensive to go in .. It was the second time that i have been to Barcelona and not been in !It looks great from the outside but the entrance fee seems very expensive and although I can afford it I resent having to pay it as that just makes it worse for those who would like to go in but genuinely can not afford such an exorbitant entry fee !

Located in shopping heaven!. Gaudi left his mark on Barcelona. This building is on a popular shopping high street. Impressive on the outside as well on the inside. A bit of a bother to buy tickets, which was not immediately by the entrance. This building houses apartments for local residents.

This visit changed my mind!. The visit and tour of Casa Mila showed me that Gaudi was, in fact, not just a mad man but a brilliant architect and an absolutely genius engineer, way ahead of his time in designs and execution of a exquisite work of art. The exhibits on the attic floor show his genius and the tour of an apartment highlights his gracious and original designs. And walking on the roof top is an exciting adventure, like a tour with Alice through Wonderland. True, the cost of entry is high but it is worth every penny.....

My favorite Gaudi building. The roof top and all the chimneys are impressive to look at and the arches are perfectly aligned to some other attractions - so bring your zoom lens for the perfect picture. My recommendation is to go late in the day 1-2 hours before sunset - for getting the best pictures on the roof top. The inside is also nice showing his apartment /office - i would definitely go back again. If your not into architecture then you might not love it as much as i do.

Quirky to Start, Amazing Engineering/Archetecture. More than worth a visit; this building which was originally an apartment block looks stunning from the outside. The rooftop features are wonderful and once you see the exhibition which shows the genius of Gaudi's archetectural vision and construction you can't fail to be impressed. Like most of Barcelona's museums and galleries it isn't cheap, but is worthwhile visiting.

One of our top excursions in BCN. Was reluctant after reading some of the reviews but I have to say it was a solid 2 hours of info. and a well laid out and presented tour. Overtook Parc Guell and Casa Batllo IMHO. We did the basic tour and felt neither rushed or pressured. If we return to BCN would consider doing the evening tour and dinner.
expensive entry fee. We wanted to visit the inside of the property but though the entrance fee of €23.50 per person was expensive. Beautiful building from the outside

A Tourist Trap. La Pedrera may be a nice exhibition of the work of the genius of Antoni Gaudi, but it is also a tourist trap. You may have a better (and less pricey) experience by visiting Sagrada Familia church or the Guell Park in Barcelona. I suspected by the beginning that La Pedrera would be a tourist trap since it was "recommended" by a taxi driver. Second, it does not display the price of the entrance ticket in the ticket counter! When I asked the price (with lots of people lined up behind me) I was told 20,50 Euros, which is a outrageously high price (most Barcelona attractions cost half of that). I realized it was planned to force you to buy the ticket - after all, we are already here, aren't we?.... But I refused to pay. Instead I went to the beautiful Barcelona Cathedral and, for a 6 Euro ticket, had a wonderful experience!

No crowds, no sunshine. . As the weather was grey, we were able to get in immediately. The downside was that the photography options on the fabulous roof terrace were limited. The building is stunning, and the exhibition space well-presented. However, I was disappointed at the rigid limits to our visit. Some of the most innovative and striking design features are out of bounds. Leaving only the roof terrace, apartment, a courtyard and the attic.Still worth the visit, despite the high price and grey skies.
Gaudi at his best. A beautiful and unique example of the work of Gaudi.Good value for money and a must when in Barcelona!

Amazing roof!. The architecture of the building is breathtaking. Gaudi was a visionary and this building is a great representation of his mind. If you enjoy art you must see this. It was my favorite attraction in Barcelona. A must see.
Is not the best, but you have to go. Is not the best, but you have to go.I choose Casa Battlo, but this is a nice Gaudi's house. dont forget to go to casa Vincens
Trash. Pure trash hated it!Pure trash hated it!Pure trash hated it!Pure trash hated it!Pure trash hated it!Pure trash hated it!Pure trash hated it!Pure trash hated it!Pure trash hated it!

Amazing roof terrace!. Fantastic views of the city from the quirky roof terrace, especially on a clear sunny day, I didn't want to come down!If you're trying to choose between going inside Casa Mila or Casa Batllo, I would go for Casa Mila, the interior is a lot more interesting, plus the roof terrace is worth the money.If you're a student bring your id card and you'll get a couple of euros off.

Educational. Really excellent trip here and wonderful to understand Gaudi as a man and how his incredible properties were constructed and a sense of just how Avantgarde he was. We really enjoyed the trip with really excellent staff on hand to guide and inform.

Impressive but expensive. It was interesting but expensive, 20 euros. It's only the roof top and the top couple of floors that you get to see. The rest of the building is private apartments. I'm not sure that it's worth the cost, especially when you see much of the same information on Gaudi at other exhibits.

Childhood memories. Apart from the completely commendable surreal architecture of the building, the Children's Room had a display of children's toys and music that brought a lot emotional memories of my innocent childhood. The music is still echoing in my mind right now.Therefore, La Pedrera is a great place because it left me thinking more about how (from my experience) better Barcelona is than London. I should not just come back to Barcelona, I should live there.PROS: Unique architecture, and like the Geffrye Museum in Hoxton, London, a lot of history about homes and interiors.CONS: Although I booked in advance, I observed that queues for tickets on the day are always long, every day.TIP: Morning times are quieter.

Night tour with dinner. We enjoyed this beautiful small group evening tour with an excellent dinner to follow. Our guide Maria was very knowledgeable. It is a beautiful building, and it was so interesting to see how the wealthy lived at that time in another Gaudi masterpiece.

Surreal. So different to any building I have been in before, would definitely visit again.Unfortunately there was scaffolding up on the outside of the building when we visited, they were doing a deep clean of the exterior of the building. Nevertheless it was a beautiful building.The views from the roof were spectacular and loved the chimneys.

a private house to live in!. the terrace is just incredible! not only the apearance but the architectural solutions Gaudi found.the visit to the apartments is also very interesting and the idea of somebody building such a house to live in and to have income from tenting a great part to other families is very curious.

Not to be missed!. I was new to Gaudi but my wife brought me along. I am happy I did not miss it. Fabulous and unique do not begin to describe this house. His approach to the design of the roof top is very interesting and the views from the roof are not to be missed.

Another masterpiece. I am a huge Gaudi fan and have seen all of his major pieces on my trip to Spain,However even without an interest in the architect, this building is unlike any other and worth a visit for that reason alone.The price is fair and includes an audio guide, and the roof top is so unique that it must be seen to be believed.If you travel through Barcelona and don't stop in, you've missed out.

Art Nouveau architecture. As an Architect, I was particularly interested in visiting this building designed by the Spanish architect, Antoni Gaudi. There is an exhibition of his architectural models in there; and the rooftop with its unusual chimney stacks and parapets is marvellous. The views out over the city of Barcelona from that vantage point are good. The balcony railings on the outside of the building are designed with curvaceous lines and naturalistic curving patterns. All in all, well worth a visit.

Awesome architecture and stunning view on the rooftop.. This famous place always gets a big queue to get a ticket. Try to book online and avoid it. The interior design is awe-inspiring and the rooftop is like being in another universe. Highly recommended!!

Beautiful!. Unfortunately for us when we've been there they were refurbishing so we couldn't go inside, but even on the outside the building has a stunning architecture and is beautiful to watch. we had tea and deserts across the road while admiring the building and reading it's history. Having a bit of knowledge about this Gaudi's art makes it even more both interesting and beautiful. Thank you

so so for me. ive been here after sagrada familia, parc guel and casa batlo. maybe that's why it didnt leave much impact on me. rooftop was quite gorgeous but they blocked the main entrance of which the ceiling has coral marbling. 20 euros for the rooftop.... felt a bit pricy. if u r running short of budget, i think u don miss much if u skip here.

Gaudis mastery of architecture. Went on a wet rainy day - no matter because you should imerse yourself in the way Gaudi used the natural plant and animal form in his building technique. Absolutely obvious and amazing. Take time to study all the models he made before he built, an ideal visit on a rainy, or hot, day!Go up to the roof first maybe, but it doesn't matter which way you do the visit. Didn't book and queue was short but waited a fairly long time because they restrict the numbers inside. A good plan really as some rooms in the apartment are small - but perfectly formed!Average price versus quality of visit at €20 although if a family child prices cease at age 12!Very easy to find and great photo opportunities.

Putting Gaudi in Order. Perhaps this might be a fitting final venue. Gaudi's Guell house, Guell Park, Casa Batllo, Sagrada Familia may be appropriate orderly prelude to this stunning current "live-in" masterpiece.

Stunning building. What an unusual and lovely building. Right in the middle of the modern and funky town. We were just shopping (my boyfriend and I, 24 and 22) and we came across it by accident. It's just a lovely juxtaposition that is just amazing and breath-taking. I would definitely recommend, regardless of age or gender or culture etc.

The roof is the pièce de résistance.. So you are already in the Gaudi mode while in Barcelona, you might as well visit Casa Mila. Another of his undulating façade but less ornate compared to Casa Batllo has a Goth feel with its black iron beamed balconies. This building has a lot of innovative elements in its design foremost are the free of load bearing columns and walls. The chimneys on the roof are reminiscent of Chateau Chambord in Loire Valley but this time with a warrior-esque niqad and burqa inferences.

Most wonderful experience in Bcn. As an architecture student, I tried to visit as many Gaudi's works as possible, and this one is the purest and most magnificent. I stayed in Barcelona for half a year and this building never ceased to amaze me. It's worth visiting from the inside, great museum exhibition and beautiful rooftop decorations by Gaudi himself with a view on neighbourhood where is also located his Casa Batlo. 5 stars experience!

Excellent, Inside and Out. We trekked over here about an hour or so before it closed to see a Gaudi masterpiece and weren't dissapointed. Everything about the structure was impressive in its own quirky and unique way. Next to La Sagrada Familia, we considered this our favorite sight (and must see attraction) in Barcelona. The exterior is impressive and iconic, but it is really the rooftop and interior that steal the show. The roof is amazing for views of the chimneys/structure itself and the surrounding city. We went at dusk, which I highly reccommend, and got some excellent photos. From here, there is a museum in the attic that shows Gaudi's design methods/thought process, which is very interesting. The highlight for me was the ergonomic furniture and designs of door handles, chairs, etc. that Gaudi made. The other highlight was the floor showing how high-class Catalans would have lived in early 20th Century Barcelona. This provided context into the building, the city, and Spanish life and history that we didn't get anywhere else in Barcelona.We didn't visit Casa Battlo, but chose this because of its 1) cheaper entry fee and 2) interior attractions, whereas Casa Battlo is more or less bare inside (from what I understand). We didn't regret our decision, especially since you can walk past Casa Battlo if you're coming from Placa de Catalunya and glance at the impressive exterior of that building on the way to La Pedrera.

A must see. There is so much to see in this one place. The walk through the apartment is fascinating then on up to the roof which is just amazing. Great views of the city from the rooftop are an added bonus. There are also displays and videos on all of Gaudis other works giving so much information and interest. We went there in the late afternoon and there was no queue to get in unlike other attractions and museums.

More interesting Gaudi, strange rooftop. Never knew what this building was about, now I know. A study in curves and arches, and creative (& weird) use of sculpture to hide/make artistic various rooftop mechanicals. Got to walk through an actual apartment where you understand the light that comes in from outside the building but also the inside courtyard, and how people of that time would have lived. Very gratifying.
Do not miss Gaudis work in Barcelona. Go off season to enjoy it at the best. So much to enjoy in both Casa Battlo and la Pedrera. The work of Gaudi is incomparable.

Well worth the queue to get in!. What a totally amazing place! Just sitting there on the corner of a very busy Main Street with the locals passing by and continuing with their daily business. If you are lucky enough to find yourself in Barcelona this is a must visit place, amazing architecture, fantastic history, wonky wavy walls and doors to die for and when you go to the roof....wow what a view! Not forgetting the totally wacky & fantastic chimney pots that also live on the roof. Makes you wonder what was going on in the head of the genius that was Gaudi. I would love to be able to live in one of these apartments. Seriously worth the entry money and the time spent queuing up.

The roof is a must. Another masterpiece of Gaudi's architecture, La Pedrera is a highlight of Barcelona.However be aware that the best is the roof ( you can see even sagrada Familia from there).Would recommend to visit.
Great to see Gaudi's work. Take a stroll down Passeg de Gracia and enjoy the views of Gaudi's architecture. It's like nothing else, and simply a must see if you are in Barca!

Definitely worth a visit. We used the 10% voucher out of the tour bus guide, well worth having, but still seemed very dear to get in, over two hours later we had changed our minds..what an amazing place, we must have spent an hour on the roof in the sun, then the displays in the attic were fascinating. We were surprised at the interior of the apartment but people have to live in it rather than look at it. We loved it.

What a view. As you walk up to La Pedrera you can't believe the beauty before you. That is, until you get to the top of La Pedrera and see that all of Barcelona unfolds before you. It'd be hard to choose between La Pedrera and Casa Batllo but they are both magnificent works of art that you'd find it hard to believe that people do still live in a few of the apartments!You get the opportunity to see some of the empty apartments with furniture pieces of the time and you're transformed back to a simpler time and for a few short minutes, you'll forget you're a tourist. The entrance fees are steep but worth every penny to those who wish to see beauty through the eyes of a genius.

Overpriced. Ticket to Louvre - 12 euro
Ticket to La Pedrera - 20.5 euro
Make your own decission about a visit, in my opinion don't worth the money. Better go through Passeig de Gracia and enjoy the street

Unique. This may not be the number one Gaudi attraction in the city of so many but we made it this time and are glad we did. Gaudi fans will still be in heaven even if this design leans more towards the practicality of living. His solutions are simple and yet brilliant.Avoid the lines and buy a ticket online, they are not cheap but worth it if you have visited the other main Gaudi attractions already. Also visit early or late (before 10am) and in off-season if you can to enhance your visit. Audio guides included. Nice Cafe.

Neat is have time.. If you have time and are a fan of Barcelona architecture, go see. A bit pricey in my opinion, for what you see overall, but if you're there, why wouldn't you spend that money. Can be a bit of a line.

Not a great experience. I love Gaudi and this is one of the must-sees in Barcelona and I did enjoy visiting here. What I would like to talk about is my experience with their premium entry passes. With those passes, they promise: 1. A smile awaiting upon arrival 2. Fast lane 3. A drink at the cafe before or after the tour whichever the visitor chooses. None of them were true expect for number 2. I wanted to go to the cafe before the tour but I was told I would have to go after the tour. When I asked them politely if I could go before the tour, they reluctantly but eventually let me go. The cafe was very busy but understaffed so I had to wait forever for the service. While I did enjoy the fast lane and the decor of the cafe, you shouldn't expect the special treatment they claim to offer on the website.

La Pedera Pedestrian. If you like Gaudi's architecture this building is a "must see", sure its an apartment building but as you tour the interior you'll see that Gaudi's design makes full use of natural daylight throughout each apartment. The bulk of the building is occupied (lucky people), however you can visit one apartment which has been kept in it's original form and both the roof top and roof space are amazing.As you would expect the exit is via the obligatory gift shop.

Stunning Landmark. I visited Barcelona over the Christmas and New Year period and took in some of the amazing landmarks that this city has to offer. A favourite was La Pedrera with its curving walls and balconies and the ability to go up and explore the roof area and the spiralling parapets. It is an amazing piece of work and over the Christmas period the front of the building was lit up in a tapering style depicting a Christmas tree. Inside the work is even more stunning. It is a fantastic example of Gaudi's work and well worth a visit. We bought tickets in advance so we didn't have to queue. Tickets were 20 Euros each (Adult) which allowed us access to the most important parts of the building. There is a cafe in a stunning setting on the ground floor, but is is a bit pricey.

Interesting. I'm glad to have seen this home. Fascinating that it has inhabitants, except on the top floor, which you can go through. Rooftop is interesting with great views. If you have bad knees or balance issues, you may not want to explore it. Very hilly and small steps. Went with my daughter who has visited casa batllo. She liked that better.
Awesome rooftop. The rooftop of the building is certainly iconic but the rest of the interior is actually very ordinary... not as amazing as Casa Batillo or Palau Guell.
Now restrucured. the entry can be bough online, inside is better than outside but I personally prefer the casa batllo

Expensive but very good. This is not a cheap place to go inside but it is worth it in order to see the surreal roof terrace and the fabulous interior. If you go at dusk the roof is extra special as it is illuminated.

One of Gaudí's landmarks in Barcelona.. I have visited La Pedrera already a number of times and love the ingenuity and the beauty of the house. The level just under the roof I found the most surprising. And walking on the roof is like walking in a hilly landscape, with a beautiful view on the city of Barcelona.
There is a nice Gaudí Shop downstairs.

One of the few really fasinating buildings. So this is Gaudi, and it's of course got that distinct Gaudi flavour. Inside there is a atrium style opening, and you've probably seen the pictures of the crazy roof. Where you can take pictures of yourself with the Sagrada Familia in the background. For me the most interesting part were the rooms decorated in early 20th century, and you can actually use one of the original toilets (I know juvenile, still pretty cool).

Not what I expected. The outside of this building is stunning. The light wells and the roof of the building with the 'soldiers' were amazing - the apartment however was overrated and frankly, rather uninteresting.We paid extra for the evening tour which was lovely to be in a small group and not be rushing around with crowds of people.
A Gaudi must see. This man was a expert in designing something extraordinary. Dont miss the roof.. a can't believe building.

Very neat, crazy Gaudi architecture. As admissions for both Mila / Batillo are quite expensive, we decided to choose just 1. We ultimately picked Mila for the unique rooftop architecture and the view of the city. It was worth it, but of all the Gaudi architecture, the Sagrada Familia still had the biggest "wow" factor.

Different. Gaudi has a masterpiece. The roof of the building was amazing. The attic was equally great. Gaudi designed the roof and the attic as a double insulation for the building. The apartments are ok and since they are from the older time, they look pretty depressing from inside, but I guess that is how people used to stay in those older days.

Enjoyable - but not as good as Casa Battlo. I enjoyed my visit, although it was rather pricey for what you got. The roof was definitely worth a visit, and the free audio guide was good. Allow plenty of time to listen to all the commentary on the self-guided tour to get the most from your visit.If funds are limited, I'd recommend seeing Casa Battlo instead.
Crazy architecture. A standout in the big avenue where it sits, and somewhat different, more edgier than the other Gaudi buildings in the same avenue. Worth a visit to the roof.

Skip It - See Casa Batllo instead. A tour of La Pedrera starts at the roof and works it's way down. The roof and it's architecture are gorgeous - but that's about it. The rest of the self guided tour is not as great. The apartment is not special at all. Rather ordinary. The staircases and inside are OK. The outside is stunning but you don't have to pay 20+ Euro to see that. Casa Batllo is the real deal and so much nicer. Go there instead and save your hard earned money.
A very interesting building. This interesting building was a gaudi masterpiece. Nothing like I have seen before. The stone is a lovely colour. Definately worth a look.

Book The Secret Pedrera. We booked the Secret Pedrera, a tour that takes place at night and you get to visit one of the apartments and the roof. It was really worth it and the tour ends with Cava. If you have the time, book this tour, you will enjoy it. Plus you get some nice photos of the city at night.
Fascinating architecture. Definitely a must see. the architecture is great, the apartments terrific. The rooftop view was incredible.

An unexpected surprise!. We spontaneously decided to visit La Pedrera as it was it one of the stops on the official hop on hop off bus tours. We weren't quite sure what to expect as had very little knowledge about the building before entering but were pleasantly surprised at what it had to offer. Another masterpiece by Antoni Gaudi with fantastic architecture throughout the building, especially the innovative chimneys found on the roof. We opted to take the audio tour guide which were a great decision as you get to choose the different parts of the building as you progress through it, giving you the ability to go through the building at your own pace.
Can't believe the story of how it was built. It would be a really good idea to get a walking tour guide because there is a lot of things that you can discover about the building.

treasure in the city. we went on a whim to see some proper attractions an litterlly spent 4 hours inside looking at everything! so interesting and it shows bits of all gaudis art too.Definately worth going and if you get on the tour bus the official one they give you a voucher book so the cost was only 5 euros including headphones, much prefer the headphone giude as you can then go at your own pace and dont need to wait around!

SUPER- Must visit. It is an amazing place and you MUST visit this place, you will never regret. There are people living in that block of flats, and you can visit the roof and the last floor. The roof is very interesting, and you can see very nice "The Sagrada Familia" and the whole city. The last floor has an exhibit with plans of Gaudi for his famous buildings but also you can see how the flats were looking. The waiting time is about half an hour, in September, but it really worths.

Mind-blowing...... What a fantastic place - probably our favorite Barcelona attraction. Gaudi must have been on something, when he created this site. WOW !!! Can only be seen to be believed. He was an outrageous eccentric - THANK GOODNESS...

My favourite Gaudi experience. It is hard to explain why but this place is just so much more intimate and a place where you can really feel what the man was all about . Takes my breath away -I always go here when in this fabulous city .

Amazing place. Amazing place. Well worth the visit. We booked the premium tickets online (about EUR 7 extra) which allowed us immediate access without specific entry times and said it included a free drink. After the visit, we were told we could redeem the tickets for a free drink at the Cafe outside. Free drink turned out to be either coffee or a bottle of water, not even a hot chocolate for the kids. While the premium tickets are good value if you don't know what time you will be arriving or which day you might decide to visit Casa Mila, the free drink seemed to be a bit of a rip-off.
Great architecture. Another gem from Gaudi's creation, worthy of a visit. It gives you another good insight into the genius of Gaudi, his vision and application of his learning from nature.

One of Gaudi's best works. Locked up in the streets of Barcelona is La Pedrera, one of Gaudi's masterpieces. An apartment which is still functioning. The roof itself of the building is worth a visit alone. It is one of a kind. With unique designs and brilliant ideas portrayed on the roof, it showcases the brilliance of Gaudi.After visiting the roof, we got an insight into the beautiful apartment designed by Gaudi which is very well maintained with antique furniture. Overall, I would say it is a must visit for all those architecture-buffs, and Gaudi fans, but even for all those who simply love to see a beautiful work of art.

Worth it for the roof alone!. Very interesting building right smack in the very centre of Barcelona, designed by the genius Gaudi of course. There is a very interesting central circular courtyard surrounded by apartments, some of which are still being lived in. Most of the upper floors are available to walk round, and have been preserved as they were when Gaudi was alive. There is an audio guide available as part of the admission price which is very interesting. The roof covered in the unique chimneys is worth the admission price alone. Amazing views over the city and the chimneys themselves are of course completely unique. Especially the one covered in broken champagne bottle pieces! There is not often a long queue for this attraction. In fact there was no one queuing when I visited on a Wednesday afternoon in December.

For children of all ages. Any of Gaudi's work that I've seen has been well worth it. We were told that people purchased a space in the building and then arranged it as they chose. Our guide explained most of what we saw. In the furnished apt., my favorite room was a child's room with in incredible doll house filled with miniatures.
what a way to live!. Gaudi made this apartment complex seem like a stage from a movie - some apts. intimate, the view from the top floor down dizzying, the roof top absolutely otherworldly! LOVED IT!

Attic with brick catenary arches is worth the entire visit. Gaudi was an architect with a sculptor under his skin. The attic, framed in his famous 'catenary arches' (math majors will especially love them) has wonderful models and descriptions of how they were designed and constructed. Rooftop has a nice 'framed' view of Sagrada Familia and a specially decorated chimney (fragments from wine bottles used at building opening)

A pillar of the history of Barcelona. On the long list of things to do and see in Barcelona, La Pedrera should be towards the top of your list. The eccentric nature of Antoni Gaudi's architectural vision permeates through Barcelona in many instances. La Pedrera is one of the best examples of Gaudi's architecture and also shows many exhibits demonstrating the function behind his structural nous. Some will say the price of admission is a bit on the steep side. It may be, but I would say it is worth it to be on the roof of this building, overlooking the Passeig de Gracia, and absorbing the influence that the maker of that roof had on the area.If you're going to take the time to explore the entirety of the property available to the public (people do actually live in the building), be sure to grab one of the portable audio guides to explain many of the ideas behind Gaudi's architectural style. For a more grandiose display of Gaudi's work, I would highly recommend visiting the Park Guell or even the Casa Batllo down the street. As for his work in Barcelona, La Pedrera should be your first stop.

Extraordinary Gaudi house. Situated just near the Diagonal metro station (make sure you come out of the right exit) as others have said, this is fairly expensive. You do however get the audio guide included which I found very interesting. We also got a small discount using vouchers from the Bus Touristic city tour.The roof is the first stop (by lift) which is amazing with all the slopes and turrets plus fantastic views. Below this is quite a good exhibition about Gaudi and his designs. On the 4th floor is an apartment furnished as it was when the house opened around 1906. Two extensive souvenir shops on the way out.The place should definitely be seen, it's like no other house I've visited. Bear in mind it is slightly strenuous clambering over the roof and then working your way down.

Expensive. Nice architecture but the tickets are too expensive. We came as a family of 4 and I very much regretted paying to go in. Thank goodness the weather held up and we were allowed up to the roof!

Must see in Barcelona. If you are excited by Modernista architecture, include La Pedrera on your itinerary. While not as breathtaking as La Sagrada Familia, it is well-worth seeing. The insight into life in an earlier time through touring the apartment is very worthwhile and gives an exciting view into the mind of Gaudi and shows how far ahead of others he was for his time. So much of Barcelona is about the architecture and this is an important aspect that is not to be missed. Lastly, while in the area of La Pedrera and Sagrada Familia, be sure to check out the other buildings by Gaudi and his contemporaries. Touring these is a very nice walk if the weather is good.

Fascinating insight into an extreme piece of architecture. As others have noted, the entry price to this building is high at €20.50 so you need to have an interest in the architecture of this period to make it worth the fee. However, if you do have that interest it is a fascinating visit. The building is almost organic in its design.An audio tour handset is included and the tour proper starts at the top on the roof of the building. I understand that if it is raining the roof is closed and I'd certainly recommend postponing your visit if that is the case. The roof not only gives some great views over the city but has some surreal constructions on it ... yes they are functional as chimneys and ventilation but they look like owls, chess pieces, knights in armour ........The tour then continues through the attic with a very well presented exhibition about Gaudi and the building itself. The attic itself is so very organic it almost feels like being inside a great beast. Finally you are taken through a couple of the apartments furnished and decorated to the period. Actually, finally you leave through the gift shop, of course :-)

Nice architecture. I was choosing between casa batllo and this. Eventually I came here because I heard more good things about this. The fee is too expensive. You could see the terrace of the building, and antic and the highest floor of the apartment. With furnitures inside and also they provide an audio guide for it.

expensive. nice but to expensive 20.5 euro the roof is very nice but i think have a look and do not go in. and if
is raining do not get in becouse the roof is the best.

Must do for Gaudí lovers. Part of the outside of La Pedrera (Casa Mila) finally isn't under construction any more, so you can see most of the beautiful facade for free. The inside and the rooftop are nice, but pricy to visit. What made it worthwhile for us, is that there is an exhibition inside that also shows videos and models of all the other houses/works by Gaudí, which kind of brought together our visits to all this different locations.

Fabulous innovative architecture. Loved it - I have become a big fan of Gaudi and his innovative architecture. I particularly enjoyed the apartment and seeing the historical furniture and accessories, the differences between English and Spanish. And of course the roof tops are fabulous and amazing views.

Good, but for the price you feel like you should get to see more. It is really beautiful place, but for ticket costing 20 euros you get the feeling that you should really get to see more at the end of the tour.You basically get to see the roof, the attic and a single level of living space (rooms with preserved furniture and such).When we went to Palau de Guell, we felt like there was much more to see (even that we didn't get to go to the roof because of the rain), and ticket price was much more reasonable too. I haven't been to Casa Batllo (which cost also 20-21 euro per person), but I have really enjoyed Palau de Guell and would recommend it instead.

Fantastic roof garden of Gaudi!. My family and I visited here together with other famous works by Gaudi in Barcelona. The building and objects are typical Gaudi, excellent. On top of that, the special remark of this place is the view from roof garden. You can see Sagrada familia under construction and the town of Barcelona. The view reminded me of the down town of Osaka in which I grew up.
Wonderful guided tour.. One of Gaudi's great creation. The guided tour gives you much of the history and details of the house, fascinating and great view of Barcelona from the rooftop.

Great. I had to go to the ticket counter 4 times, in order to go in. The days that I was in Barcelona it was raining and during rain most of the rooftops are closed. As soon as I got up to the rooftop one of there employees came and said that we had to go back down. I stayed up there for few minutes, it wasn't enough to enjoy the view but I guess it was enough as most places didn't even open up. However it is totally worth the visit if the roof top is open otherwise it almost like the other attractions in Barcelona.

Amazing. Beautiful house and the roof is a must. WARNING don't go in if its rating the beautiful room is tiled so they have to close it if it rains. They will warn you when it is shut before you buy your ticket.

A 1900 Style house with Gaudi's design throughout. Next time you look at a tree in nature reflect on the structure of the branches, the tons of foliage that it supports in summer and you can begin to understand Gaudi's genius. There are no straight lines in nature nor in his buildings. It's all here in an excellent display of his unique reach into architecture.

Worth it just for the view.. After ditching my exhausted family and a visit to Casa Batllo I walked the few blocks to this Gaudi Masterpiece. The roof was really cool. I kind of breezed through the exhibit on the top floor because it was very dark and I knew a lot of that info from my other Gaudi stops. The furnished apartment was a great picture of life at that time. I felt that it was a great cap to my visit to the Segrada Familia, Park Guell, and the Casa Batllo.

What a rooftop. Casa Mila was very different from Casa Batlo. There is a darker quality to Casa Mila and the level of architectural detail on the inside and on the rooftop sharply contrasts that of Casa Batlo. Where Casa Batlo is more colorful and light with its blue ombre tiles and outdoor garden and mosaic rooftop and outside details, Casa Mila has multi-layered arches within with a ceiling that mirrors the spine of a python. Casa Mila's rooftop with its sandy colors and sculpted towers evokes desert dunes.

Beautiful but be warned. We visited Barcelona last weekend and seeing this building and its roof was my number 1 mission. Unfortunately it's having some work done on the facade so there's scaffolding up and only one small side section is visible.We paid €41 to visit the interior and we loved it however because it was raining / drizzling outside they closed the roof.Had we been told about the roof closure at reception we wouldn't have paid to visit that day, we've gone back on one of the other days.Just be warned that if the weather is poor the roof could be closed so it's worth checking prior to paying. For us it means another visit to Barcelona in the future - there's a silver lining!!
A little disappointed. When we went there, the front of the building was under construction. Unique rooftop and internal decor.
Expensive photooportunity. Nice roofing but way to expensive to visit. Buy a postcard in the shop. Come early or late if you are looking for good lighting.

Spectacular roof. This is one of the Gaudi's creation. Now it's one of UNESCO's World Heritage Sites. First I saw the iron glass door of the main gate, then the patio in the middle of the building for the light to shine in, bringing light into every unit of this house. Then the roof top is a spectacular sight, beside the city view. All the chimneys and ventilation disguised like soldiers with a helmet, it's so unique, Change your mind about all that boarding chimneys and ventilation. Paintings on the ceiling and the curvey staircase,There is a small area explaining where Gaudi's inspiration came from, it's very interesting. that worth your time to visit.Happy Travelling!

Rooftop is good but IMO Casa Batlio is better. Long lines for tickets, long lines for the elevator to the roof, After the roof and attic space, you visit an apartment which is interesting but not in my opinion, not in the top 5 things to do in Barcelona.

Classic Gaudi residential building, spectacular rooftop terrace. Well worth a visit. The well known external facade was covered for renovation during my visit. But the internal spaces and the mind boggling rooftop terrace made up for it. This building is still blowing people's minds today. I can't imagine the reaction it got in the early 1900's. This and Sagrada Familia are the two must see attractions in Barcelona.

Gaudi's work. Well, it is not just a simple building, you can feel Gaudi's touch very obvious. Outstanding from outside, the wavy balcony shapes and on top of the building you can imagine a dragon coming out to invade Barcelona.

Fantastic Building - Great Views!. A long wait to get in but definitely worth it. The view from the top is really great and the weather was fantastic which helped! The apartment itself is beautiful and I enjoyed it a lot. I wouldn't necessarily go again, but I'd love to check the outside of this apartment out when the renovation work has finished.

Not bad but a bit expensive. Kind of strange where in all travel blogs or books, they refer the sight as Casa Mila more than La Pedrera. This is my very last sightseeing visit in the entire trip. Unfortunately, they are restoring the outside right now until Dec 14 but it hasn't spoiled the visit that much as there is a small section which can still show you what it looks like. Signages around the house are quite misleading so is kind of confusing especially with the audio guide. There are small steps around the roof top and do bear in mind when you visit as I saw an old couple who just stood at the entrance to have a look without walking around.There are lifts available but not sure which floor it would lead to as the lift was middle of the visit before going to the musuem. so whether you need to return the route you came in to take the lift or not, is better to ask the staff.Not a cheap visit and the visit at night is more expensive and is advisable to prebook.

Can't miss it if you are 1 day in Barcelona!. It is one of the most emblematic piece of architecture from Gaudi. A must see, together with Sagrada Familia, if you want to get to know Gaudi's works.The building is amazing (it was with works outside - a pitty) but in the interior you have the opportunity to visit downstairs, the roof top and 1 apartment that recriates the apartments from Gaudi time.You can learn about Gaudi history and for that Ia also advicethe audioguide visit.If you do not want to stand in queue, just by your tickets in adavance by internet with time for entry.

Gaudi at his best.. I was there in October of 2013. Despite a long wait to get in, I really liked La Pedrera. In true Gaudi style, I dont think there was one straight angle in the entire building. I loved the attic with all the exposed beams and common items that inspired his designs, the fantastic view from the roof. and the wonderful metal doors.

Creativity unleashed. Just captured an outside view of La Pedrera while strolling along Passeig de Gracia not far from Casa Batllo. Did not go inside because of time constraint and it was lucky that although major parts of the building were covered up for renovation, the builder did leave segments on the side street where one could have a glimpse of Gaudi's creativity, boldness and indeed prolificity in turning out so many masterpieces like the Sagrada Familia, Park Guell, Casa Batllo etc etc. Should return to Barcelona for a few days in the future to really go through the interiors of his work. I guess it must be like a wonderland for artists and architectural professionals alike.
Very intresting attic. Am impressed of Gaudis works specially the attic of Casa milla. I think thats the only part i enjoyed the most. True it is overpriced.

Amazing building; sadly, renovation obstructs much of the exterior. We did not do the tour but our kids wanted to see the exterior. Due to the renovations you couldn't see any of the main facade - only a small bit on the side street - and you couldn't see e rooftop chimneys either. This was disappointing. Of course the visible part is amazing and I'm sure the interior is also but these entry prices are not for the faint of heart and we couldn't afford to go in every single attraction.

An apartment block with a twist. From all the buildings I saw in Barcelona designed by Gaudi, this was, undoubtedly, the less appealing to me. It's an apartment block with dashes of originality, no doubt, but somehow it seems to lack the colorful creativeness that are so outstanding in (most of) Gaudi's other creations.I enjoyed the paintings on the walls and stairways by the access gates and the visual effect of the arched structure of the attic. The roof terrace, unique as it undoubtedly is, came to me as a bit gory.The admission fee was 20,50€, the most expensive of all the attractions I visited in Barcelona (as a comparison, the admission fee to the Sagrada Familia was 14,50€). Personally and comparing it to other local attractions, I don't think a tour of La Pedrera is worth this much.

Yet another fascinating Gaudi building. The rooftop is the attraction here. It is fascinating, as is the attic below. I was a bit disappointed that there wasn't much more to see, but most of the building is still private. There was an excellent exhibit by a Russian artist when I visited, but unfortunately, I did not have the time to absorb all it had to offer. What I did see was extremely well curated with lots of great explanatory signage. This is not a cheap attraction, so give thought to how much of Gaudi you want to experience and support. That said, it was an interesting stop.

Night time is the right time?. Visited in a small intimate after dark trip, and really enjoyed the tour and the architecture, felt like we had the whole roof and views to ourselves. Very atmospheric lighting/shadows etc.

Glad I visited - a little overpriced. This is the place I wanted to visit most on my visit to Barcelona. It was really interesting and I'm glad to say I've been. I felt the tickets were slightly overpriced and one side of the building was covered up due to the ongoing restoration works.
