The ticket includes a visit to the roof terrace with its iconic sculptures, the attic now an exhibition space and a restored appartment which wasn't as grand as I expected it to be from the outside! A little disappointed but still glad I've seen it.

Rooftop of delights. Another beautiful Gaudi house. Whilst not as stunning as Casa Batllo this is worth a visit too. As a good part of it is still inhabited you don't get to see much other than the attic which is of interesting structure & the STUNNING roof with it's peculiarly fantastical 'chimneys' & 'statues'. I visited on a bright sunny day & could have spent hours sitting looking around me at their weird & wonderful shapes. There are a few 'staged' rooms to visit on your way back down thru the building. Sadly most of the exterior is swathed in scaffolding & tarpaulin for renovation so not much of the building is visible from the street at present, so I am glad I paid the entrance fee.
Worthwhile. Couple this with a tour of Casa Batllo and you will be impressed. They heavily marketed Pedrera in Barcelona, but I feel Batllo is easily just as brilliant as Pedrera.

Take the night tour. Check to see on which nights of the week they offer the Secret Tour, a guided tour. What you see that you might miss during the day are the amazing shadows cast from Gaudi's lamps and ornamentation--truly magical. The night view from the rooftop is also spectacular. The exterior is currently covered while they do restoration work, but the interior by night more than compensates for that disappointment.

Very funky residential building. La Pedrera is a bit similar to Casa Batllo, but more like a proper apartment (covering the whole floor). The admission tickets include the free audio guide as well. And it starts from the hall and then straight to the roof and walk your way down (or take the lift if you like) to the apartment.Unfortunately when we visited last weekend, the external are being maintained, so it is covered in scaffoldings and we could only appreciate the internals. But it is still nice. The colour in the building is just fascinating.Strongly recommend you visit on a sunny day, and the pictures of the roofs will be amazing. There are interesting framing on the roof sculptures, one of them looks at Sagrada Familiar. The attic room is very educational as well.Inside of the apartment, it is quite interesting to sea how rooms are links and doors are positioned. There is no load-bearing walls, and it is a truly ingenious design.

Another Gaudi Masterpiece. We toured Casa Mila late one afternoon and loved it. There is a lot to see. The rooftop is probably the high point, literally and figuratively. The creative treatment of chimneys as art is amazing and the placement of arches shows Gaudi's highlighting of Sagrada Familia. The courtyard and stairwells are innovative and the display of period pieces in an apartment is very interesting. The attic contains an exhaustive exhibition of Gaudi's work on his various works. The only disappointment was that 80% of the building's facade was covered for renovations.
Amazing Gaudi architecture. A must-see if you visit Barcelona - get the audio guide and you learn loads about Gaudi and his avant garde approach to architecture. I loved it!
Nov 2014. Just a tip: at this time the exterior is completely covered in cloth and scaffolding. It may be fine on the inside. We were on a short trip so we didn't have time to go in.

Favourite of all of Barcelona. Absolutely loved La Pedrera. It is simply stunning.We booked tickets before hand and got them printed at our hotel so skipped the queue. Would definitely recommend this, we then did this for all attractions (especially for La Sagrada) Obviously the best bit is the roof top. It is in pristine condition. Could've stayed up there all day. You can even see La Sagrada Familia from up there!You also walk around the inside and watch a short film.The only downer was that the outside was being renovated so didn't see it at all! So so sad.You would be silly to miss this when in Barcelona. Some great higher end shops around this area too.

Gaudi rooftop. One of a kind rooftop sculpture. Unfortunately, currently the outside (part of its unusual charm) is draped in sheeting and undergoing rehab/cleaning(?). Definitely a must while in Barcelona.

Great living Gaudi building. Working apartment building that offers tours of the roof, attic, and an example apartment. This was the least crowded and my personal favorite Gaudi building that i had visited.
Beautiful house. This house is very beautiful, as usual, Gaudi has a very wonderful and unique taste in his architectures

Fantastic roof and much else. This Gaudi designed appartment block is an unusual and attractive place to visit. The visit starts at ground level in one of the courtyards, but rapidly translates (by lift) to the fantastic roof. This has to be seen to be believed and is what confers world heritage site status.After exploring the roof and its views, the audio tour (included in the 20 euro price) takes you to the attics, with their spectacular brick vaulted roof. Here is a comprehensive exhibition on Gaudi and his many works.This is followed by a visit to one of the appartments (the rest are still occuppied) that has been furnished in the style of the period.How does this compare to other Gaudi properties. Clearly the Segrada Familiar is a world-class must, but as a church difficult to compare. The Palais Guell shows you more interior, and if I was forced to choose only one, I'd go for the Palais. But the Palais is early Gaudi, and La Pedrera is late, and there are lots of differences, so best to do both. Sorry, not (yet) been to the Casa Battlo, so cannot help there.One last thing. For safety reasons, they close the roof if it is raining. And as this is such a big part of the visit, I'd go elsewhere if its raining and come back when it has stopped.

Expensive entry fee but great gaudi building. Enjoyed our visit to this phenomenal work of gaudi. Would agree with some of the other reviewers regarding the over priced entry fee. We spent around an hour and a half viewing the property which includes the roof terrace, attic and the top floor. There is a locker to keep your belongings. Since we had a pram with us we used the locker for this purpose.
Fantastic!. Another Gaudi masterpiece that will surprise you at every turn. We loved this building & would definitely go again if we had the chance.

Wow. That sums it up, this architecture is astounding. Amazing use of light and form. I cannot believe that this was created so long ago. Definitely not to everyone's taste but I think Gaudi was a genius

Beautiful Gaudi Building. We decided to visit one of the incredible buildings- we decided to go to one of Gaudi’s buildings and chose La Pedrera over Casa Batllo. Definitely walk past Casa Batllo. We walked over to La Pedrera late- around 5 o’clock and walked right in without a line. We were disappointed that have the façade was under scaffolding. Tickets were steep at 20.50 Euros, which includes the audio guide. The guide was helpful. The tour starts in the courtyard and continues with an elevator ride up to the roof terrace. The roof terrace is impressive-there are nice views of Barcelona including one of the Sagrada Familia There are a lot of small few steps on the terrace- and you need to watch where you are walking but the structures are beautiful.After the roof, you head down a few stairs to the attic and also get to see examples of Gaudi’s furniture and then down two flights to a restored apartment.I’d pick one of Gaudi’s work to see – and this is the one if you have the time and $. It is a great example of Gaudi’s work- and a must see for those into architecture.

Loved it, roof top is incredible. I saw a huge queue when I arrived so quickly bought a ticket on line for an hour later and went and had a coffee nearby, then walked straight in at my allotted time.It's an incredible building and I spent about two and a bit hours there. I loved the roof, the views, the architecture and the attic inside is stunning. It's not a cheap outing but I really recommend it, the stairways, the mosaics. Do watch the short films about the wood, ceramics etc, up in the attic as you get more out of the apartment visit.

worth visit in a lifetime. Most favorite one apart from Familia Sagrada. I prefer this more than casa batllo. Although the facade is covered now for refurbishment, the roof is spectacular, and so did the museum inside. Impressed with their exhibit.

Amazing building but the visit is overpriced. My wife and I visited in October and at the time the building was surrounded by scaffolding so there is little to see from the outside. The price to visit was €20.50 which I felt was very expensive for what it is. It is a similar price to La Sagrada Familia but not even close to being as jaw dropping an experience. While waiting to enter we were encouraged to spend an additional €3 to jump the queue, but unless it is very busy I would not recommend this option. Once inside you are provided with an audio guide and taken to the roof terrace in a lift. From there you simply walk around at your leisure and key the number into your guide that is indicated by the various displays. The roof terrace is impressive, as was the loft but there was little else to justify the excessive entrance fee. There are plenty of photo opportunities on the roof as many of the landmarks are visible. Definitely worth a visit if you can overlook the hefty entrance fee.

Gaudi's Work!. Antoni Gaudi was a great artist! You can definitely feel his presence all over Barcelona! I was recently there on vacation last month and I had to stop by Casa Mila to see some of Gaudi's work in person for myself! I was amazed and very impressed. The man was many years ahead of his time!

Amazing architecture but overpriced. If you're in Barcelona, you should check out Gaudi's work, but sadly it's become incredibly overpriced. If you're on a budget, definitely go to the Segrada Familia, but Casa Mila should be your second choice. We enjoyed our experience there, but as many have posted already, it's not necessarily worth the price of admission if you're not there to learn about the building's history.

Awesome! Gaudi Rocks!. We were doing Modernista architecture in Barcelona today. Of course, Gaudi's La Pedrera had to be one of our stops. The price of admission is a stiff 20.50 Euros, but it is worth it. You start on the incredible roof with its interesting flow, artwork, and vistas, work your way through the fascinating attic and it's Gaudi Museum, into a restored apartment and finally out. It's a great place to see the organic nature of Gaudi's work, and learn about the man.Highly Recommended!Be warn, however, there are lots of stairs, so if you have mobility issues, this is not for you.

The Roof and So Much More!. We visited Casa Mila on a 5 day trip to Barcelona in October 2014. Be sure to get tickets on-line ahead of time--very easy process. The audio guide was decent but we sometimes had trouble locating the posted numbers to hear the commentary. Highly recommend getting tickets for opening time, 9:00 am. With this, we were the first to enter the building and the first up on the roof to see the amazing forms Gaudi designed to make the chimneys and other unsightly things more pleasing. All alone on the roof of La Pedrera! I ran around like I was on a playground! But take your photos sans crowds fast--it wasn't long before other ticket holders made their way up to the top. It was awesome while it lasted. As you stroll around the roof, each turn presents a new angle on the construction and new views of Barcelona behind it. You'll even see La Sagrada Familia in the distance. The fanciful structures can remind you of Star Wars Storm Troopers at times.The other floors of the house are interesting, including the cave-like attic and some furniture. Although Gaudi's furniture looks uncomfortable, we discovered, by sitting on his benches at Park Guell, quite the opposite! He designed it to mold body parts perfectly, even though that resulted in unusual shapes. We spent a lot of time here--almost two hours. Allow one hour minimum. To note: the gift shop has nice things which we thought we'd see in other souvenir shops but didn't. Therefore, we were pleased to learn that the shop is open to the street as well, allowing us to return another day to buy something without paying to go back through the house.PS: You are likely to visit Casa Batllo the same day as it is just a few yards across the street. Buy that ticket ahead of time on-line as well and it is for a certain day, but no certain time. Therefore, visit Pedrera first, staying as long as you like, and you don't have to worry about leaving for a specific entry time at Batllo.

Gaudi! The magnificent chimeneys-Jaw dropping rooftop. This is a place to visit to experience the incredible work of Antoni Gaudi.The roof terrace requires time to enjoy the dynamic and symbolic forms as well as the views

Nice visit. I was not going to pay the money to visit La Pedrera as it was covered up and I felt there should be a discount at least. Anyway my son fancied it so I booked up The secret Pedrera which is a night time guided tour at 30 euros each. When I got there I was disappointed as I did want to see the facade the tour only had a small group of around 20 and started off well but the guide lost control and was all over the place as he had to keep disappearing to close doors etc for the next tour. All in all the inside and roof were worth the visit with great views and Gaudi's work is a pleasure to experience but for me I much preferred Casa Batllo.

wow. I really loved this building. Its so great story how Gaudi was building, match animals and vegetables world in his art. And btw u get free audio quide in La Pedrera and found out great info about La Pedrera and every room in it.

Interesting concept and execution. My my what a place to visit. Fascinating to see Gaudi's concept in the flesh. He thought about things in such depth and detail and this has resulted in a most interesting venue to visit. The entrance fee may seem excessive but if you explore the property properly it can take a few hours. Well worth the money.

Insightful and Interesting - Good Spot to Visit!. After much research, we chose to visit Casa Mila vs. Casa Batllo. Following our visit, we were not disappointed and felt we made the best choice. The outside of Casa Mila is under construction so I would recommend walking past the exterior of Casa Batllo. The combination of going in Casa Mila and walking by Casa Batllo was great for us! Also, my husband and I ordered one audio guide instead of two. This worked out well for us and saved some money. You start on the roof, which is breathtaking. Not only do you see great views of the city, but you also see the architecture and chimneys up close. Truly spectacular! After the roof, you move into the attic. We were amazed as we read and studied the exhibits about Gaudi's work. There were many examples of his work and inspiration, which was very interesting to us. The archways and construction itself were fascinating. From the attic, you can tour an apartment that is setup as living quarters. It was neat to see how a family would have lived during that time.

Amazing roof. Really worth seeing for the architecture but the roof is amazing and worth exploring. Even if you are not a Gaudi fan it is worth visiting and not just looking at the beautiful external free part!

More interesting than I expected - better than Casa Batllo. It was a grey, cloudy day but views from the roof were still spectacular, and overall this was better than Casa Batllo which I think is the more popular place to go to. The audioguide was very comprehensive and the museum of Gaudi's work very extensive. We spent well over 2 hours here even though it says an hour is sufficient. Well worth a trip to go and see.

Well worth visiting, with more insight into Gaudi's work. Was not expecting this trip to be as good as it was. You cannot do justice from the outside as scaffolding covers much of it, with renovations taking place.The price is a little steep at 20€ but we ended up spending nearly two hours inside!The roof is amazing. Yes it's Gaudi, but you can see up close the functionality of the sculpture and his brilliance. There are impressive rooftop sculptures that can be viewed as one walks around the roof area.The design of the Attic with inverted arches (instead of columns) that support the roof above - the result is a wide-open space, which houses different exhibits.For any students of architecture this must surely be a place to visit. It highlights Gaudi's interest in the natural world which had such an influence over many of his subsequent designsA really interesting building / exhibition, and the self guided audio tour - included with ticket price, is ideal for allowing you to go at your own pace and digest all the information.The building has an apartment as designed and constructed by Gaudi - living quarters, kitchen, children's room, and servant working / living spaces. Below the demonstration apartment, one can see the floors below which contain apartments in use today. A great tour.

An outstanding example of Gaudi's genius. My family and I travelled to Barcelona in during the months of July and August of this year and fell in love with Gaudi's work. The Casa Mila is a wonderful example of the artist's versatility and even something as mundane as an apartment building could become a work of art. Gaudi was definitely ahead of his time and the individuals who chose to live in this building were as well. We absolutely loved the rooftop sculptures and walkways, the central atrium, and the tour of the apartment with audio. This is a great experience for the whole family to enjoy.
One of Gaudi's best. My husband and I did the audio guide tour of the house. Interesting and enjoyable perspective of Gaudi's work.

Just another piece of the jigsaw. Every one of his creations just seems to add a new element to the 'mixing bowl'.This is yet another example.It does assist in one's understanding of the man, which is always a good outcome.
Interesting but pricey. Cost was $25 euro to access the roof, attic and apartment. It was an unusual experience to say the least, but not worth the $.

I love gaudi, but this is overpriced. I have to say I love gaudi. I am very impressed by all his work, nonetheless 20 euros for this visit is a little excessive for me. The exterior is beautiful and the roof as well, but inside itself it is just an old house. Make sure that if you only see one piece from gaudi it is "la sagrada familia"
Worth it. smaller place than I thought but overall worth the money. The roof is the most beautiful part. Almost go perfectly with the blue sky. The terrace and the apartment is less interesting...
Casa Mila. A Very recommended site to see. I think that the best option is to take the audio tour because you will look and understand elements you could miss otherwise.

Great homage to Gaudi. Very enjoyable to visit at night; the sculptural work on the roof is at its dramatic best, and in the floodlit darkness, there's a playful spirit shared by all guests, starting at the top and working their way down.
Take the Enchanting Night tour. A bit pricy, but well worth it .. a very kind and knowledgeable guide. The Night brings out the best for this wondrous beauty of Art. Its a must see

Interesting architecture and the story behind it. The visit was part of a conference during an evening. We had a young lady as a guide who was very much interested in passing on every single detail in the story of the Mila family. The night view of Barcelona from the Roof was breathtaking. The appartement we visited furnished with original furniture, some of it designed by Gaudi demonstrated his endless love for nature being his source of Inspiration. Next time in Brcelona I will have to visit it during the day.

Great building.. The only reason I have not given this an 'excellent' review is the hefty 21 euros it costs to get in (no reductions)...The view from the top with the crazy chimneys is amazing, and the rest of the house that you can see, the attic and the apartment, are all worth seeing, you MUST be a fan of Gaudi though, otherwise it is a little too much whimsey!!!!

Amazing place -totally unique and inspiring. I thought I woul have to visit because it was so famous..... But found it an amazing building. Unique, inspirational and beautiful. I was amazed at the size of the apartment open for viewing. The architecture of the roof was crazy but equally beautiful. A lot of steps but there is a lift if you need one. Rather than thinking it was mad, I wondered why every building couldn't be this inventive and unique. Before we went in I thought twice about the cost of entry, seemed a lot.... on the way out I was happy it was worth every penny.

Gaudí building. This is another beautiful Gaudí bulding, I went there some years ago and the onteriors and the terrace with the chimneys were awesome, but this summer they were fixing it so it wasn't possible to visit everything.Also the price is quite expensive (around 20€) but I think is worth it.

Gaudi wonder. This home designed by Gaudi shows off his "ahead of his time" design, environmental sensitivity and structural genius. There are displays in the "Attic" that clearly demonstrate Gaudi's genius and give an idea of how he went about his design and construction. The self guided tour is good. We also got the audio guide which we thought was worthwhile.

If only one guadi House, this one. at $20 euros a head, can get expensive to see a Guadi designed house. So pick this one, and splerge the extra $10 for the NIGHT tour. MUST have a reservation a few days, or week in advance.otherwise, come late in day, no lines

I'm glad that I went. Casa Mila is very beautiful and shows a side of Gaudi very different from the Sagrada Familia. You definitely want to buy tickets in advance. Of the entire site, I enjoyed the attic most of all.

night tour of La Pedrera. A strange and eerie place, excellent tour and well worth the visit, takes you back in time!! A strange and delightful building, friendly and helpful tour guides, with a glass of fizz at the end.

Nice landmark. This house is designed by Gaudi and has a very interesting roof. Inside you will find a museum about his thoughts and about the life during the mid 1950's. Was kind of intersting. Certainly a must see!

Magical Moments. We book the night time tour online before we arrived. At the time, I thought it rather expensive. How wrong could I be. It was beautiful to see. The guide was really knowledgeable and spoke excellent English. We went onto the roof at the end of the tour which was spectacular. Afterwards, we enjoyed a glass of cava. An unforgettable experience.

Worth visiting. Houses roof is definetely an amazing place to see. And also all the other parts are very interesting. Ticket price is a bit too high, but if you are deciding which Gaudi's work to visit, La Pedrera is a good choice.

Excellent Introduction or Exploration of Gaudi. We were fortunate to have a guide for the initial portion of this Gaudi museum. The exhibits and explanations are expertly done and will provide insight as to Gaudi and his architecture. The apartment visit provides an education as to how a very comfortable family in the early twentieth century may have lived in Barcelona. If you want to learn more about Gaudi, this is the place to start.

It's Going to Be Crowded But You Still Must Visit. Barcelona and Gaudi are inseparable and this is another must visit, it's not as popular as others but there's still going to be a lot of people. The audio tour is free and well worth taking the time to listen to.

Another great master piece of Gaudi. This is the number 2 "must visit" location in Barcelona (after Sagrada Familia). A great design. I recommend to visit the after sunset, because it looks great with lighting.
Fabulous at Night!. A tour late afternoon leading into dark is well worth it as the lighting on the rooftop emphasizes the beauty of the chimneys.

Well worth visiting. This house was not on our list of must see things in Barcelona, but we were staying very close so decided to visit. Having already done quite a few Gaudi things already we were unsure how good to visit it would be, but it really was great. From the interesting architecture to the superb views, to the audio tour which was better than that at the Sagrada Familia, it was a great visit. They do a night visit as well which I imagine would be fun.

Well worth seeing!. This place was well worth the visit. I recommend purchasing tickets in advance so you don't have to wait in the long lines. We bought our tickets at our hotel. The views from the roof were fantastic. The visit to the apt. was great with the period furnishings.

A don't miss venue.. Ended up here by mistake, but what a mistake! The chimney structures were fantastic, the exhibition, and explanation of his works in an amazing attic complex was fascinating and the architectural details in the rooms were fun. If you have wondered about how the towers at the Segrada were made, the answer is there. As well as being a visitor attraction, it was lovely to discover the building is still in lived in, how jealous am I? Thoroughly commend to anyone.
Another must see. This is another must see for art enthusiasts and architecture buffs. And the fact that people still live and work in this building is awesome and makes me VERY jealous....LOL!

Whimsical Gaudi. Casa Mila architecture is unlike anything we've ever seen in our travels. From the wavy lines on the outside to the chimneys and ventilation towers on the roof terrace, it was a sight to behold. The inside courtyard was impressive and the rooms were beautifully decorated. The attic has an exhibition decicated to Gaudi's life and work. Chains hanging from the ceiling and reflected in a mirror below show how Gaudi designed another distinctive building in Barcelona. Highly recommended.
Structure was awesome. The structures on the roof took my breath away. I took pictures to show friends and family just hoe lovely this attraction was. So glad I went.

Pricey. This costs very similar to the Casa Batllo, but there is much less to see. The best site is of the Segrada Famillia through one of the arches on the roof. Quel spectacle! There has one furnished apartment to see which was a treat, but other than some mock-up models of some of Gaudi's works, there was nothing more to see. The Palau Guell was so much more dramatic and more extensive. One jaw dropping room after another. La Pedrara is just not enough bang for the buck, but still quite a work of art to behold. MOMA costs less and shows so much more.

Our favorite Gaudi building - don't miss it!. This was our favorite Gaudi sight in all of Barcelona. Don't miss it. You cannot do justice from the outside (the rooftop is not fully visible from outside, you would miss the Attic, and the Apartment). Scaffolding covers much of the outside, with renovations taking place.We decided to see Le Pedrera last minute - we had already pre-bought our tickets for the Sagrada Famili and Parc Guell. The price is a little steep, but we are so glad we listened to the advice of friends. We ended up spending nearly three hours inside!The roof is amazing. Yes it's Gaudi, but you can see up close the functionality of the sculpture and his brilliance. Beneath the rooftop sculptures house the water tower, elevator pulley shafts and roof supports for inverted arches of the Attic one floor below.The design of the Attic with inverted arches (instead of columns) supports the roof above - the result is a wide-open space, which today houses different exhibits.The building has an apartment as designed and constructed by Gaudi - living quarters, kitchen, children's room, maid and servant working and living space. The wood craftsmanship was truly amazing - the cabinets, inlay floors, ceilings.Below the model apartment, one can see the floors below which contain apartments in use today. The building was designed for the new bourgeoisie that were moving into the Eixample neighborhood. Am sure that those living in these marvelous apartments are today's bourgeoisie.Get your tickets in advance (and print them out) - avoid the ticket line.

Well worth the ticket price. I thought the tickets were quite expensive but this is one tourist attraction where it was worth it.It wasn't as crowded as I expected and if you BOOK YOUR TICKETS ONLINE, you can avoid the queue entirely! So easy!Wonderful views of the city, then an attic space with an interesting exhibition about Gaudi and his work. Downstairs you can walk through one of the apartments in the building, which is exactly what you hope you will be able to do (wish I lived there!).Highly recommended - just remember to buy tickets online before you leave - you don't need to print them out.

Just like stepping back in time... Thoroughly enjoyed our tour of Casa Mila, loved the attic space. The roof terrace was spectacular, the chimneys and ventilation towers standing as if ready to go into battle.The apartment set out as it would have been in the early 20th century made the history come alive. I loved everything about this beautiful building, the Courtyard, the wrought iron balconies, the fact that absolutely nothing is straight, everything has shape and form, loved it!! Now when can I move in??? Next trip we will book the night visit, they just better check I go home though :0)

astonishing. I liked this masterpiece of Gaudi very much. Although the night tour was very nice, the group was no more than 20-25 people and the guide spoke English, I thing it's a bit overpricy. But all the multimedia effects were excellent. I had a great time there!

Unique Catalan marvel. Definitely worth a visit, don't let the hefty admission price and the doom-laden warnings about queues put you off. We had not gone on a couple of previous trips but this time got organised to get there earlier. It is important to use the free audio guide!The rooftop, as expected, was amazing. Other-worldly, and fantastic views. The extensive exhibition on Gaudi's work is almost too much information but makes sense if you have already seen some of his other buildings. Also interesting to see the lovely apartment. At the beginning I thought it was less impressive than Casa Battlo but it's just different, more subtle. It's worth seeing as much Gaudi as you can take/afford! The fact that it's a charitable foundation supporting so many good causes cheers you up at the end after forking out the hefty entrance fee.
Gaudi. I had never heard of this amazing person until I went to Barcelona. To have the imagination he has and put it into his architecture is fantastic.

If the weather is good, take the Secrets of La Pedrera nighttime tour. Gaudi's houses are best toured at night, and the La Pedrera's night-time tour is pricey, but worth it. We chose to do this our last night in Barcelona as a fantastic end to our trip.The night-time tour is led by a live guide (we were on the English tour) and was a very special experience with a climb to the attic and roof as the big highlights. The glass of cava included at the end is just icing on the cake! We booked ahead online and presented an electronic ticket on our iPhone. I can't say enough about this experience and would say the same for the Casa Batllo, which is just a few blocks away down the Paseo Gracia. If you can't take this nighttime tour, don't miss this house. It will be just as interesting in the daytime..
A Must See. This was a delight and an education. I have never seen anything like it. The architecture and design are amazing. La Pedrera is a must see!

Don't miss the after hours night tour. We signed up for the English after hours night tour. First, no people other than the 20 in the group. Our guide spoke wonderful English and presented the house in a wonderful manner. Visiting the roof in the dark with the fireplaces spotlighted was worth the price of this tour. Ghostly, and the special light show added to the experience. We ended with a complimentary glass of cava. Always a good way to end a day.

What a pleasant place to live!. Unfortunately when we were there the façade was covered because of repair work, so the apartment was rather gloomy. Nevertheless, the layout with the quarters for the maid near to the kitchen and sewing room all together is such intelligent design. I was impressed yet again with the marvellous roof space which used to be for airing laundry, sweeping round the building with the parabolas of the roof arching above as in a cathedral. The staff are incredibly kind and helpful to the frail (I was hobbling around with a walking stick). They left their posts to open up lifts which were not available to the able-bodied. which really did cause them extra trouble. I was very grateful to them.

Only a 4 of 5 in the context of Gaudi's other structures in Barcelona. I have to rate La Pedrera as a "tourist attraction," and in that context, it doesn't have the impact of Casa Batllo, Palau Guell, or Sagrada Familia--although there is no arguing that it is an architectural marvel. Visitors are well advised to book tickets in advance, first thing in the morning being ideal in order to reduce the crowds, particularly on the rooftop. For that reason, consider spreading out visits to the key Gaudi sites (which we did not, scheduling Casa Batllo, La Pedrera, and Sagrada Familia in one day which had its pros and cons). Had we not been part of a horde by the time we entered La Pedrera at 11 am, my reaction might have been different. The crowds had more of a negative impact on the rooftop experience than on the visit to the apartment. Take time in the apartment to peer through the gauzy curtains to see the the scaffolds outside.

Pricey, But Interesting. If you appreciate Gaudi's work, La Pedrera is worth the price of admission. The visit comes with an audio guide at no extra charge. Use it--it will enrich your visit tremendously. We were disappointed that much of the facade was covered in scaffolding, but that didn't dampen our enthusiasm for long. Once we reached the roof, it was as if we had entered another world, a Dr. Seuss-like world that reflected the imagination of an imaginative architect. We wandered around the roof for awhile and could have stayed up there much longer. The exhibits in the attic really help you understand and appreciate Gaudi further. The apartment is interesting, too, but a bit of a let-down after the roof and attic.

The Roof!. I visited Barcelona October the 17th- 22nd 2014. La Pedrera is a must but, I have to say that it is going to the roof that makes it really worth it. The rest of the house is actually the living quarters of actual families. There are also business offices, etc. The atrium is also beautiful. Be advised that there is only one elevator to go to the 8th floor where the tour actually begins. I had to go up by the stairs, otherwise, the waiting would be an hour, maybe more. The structural design could be seen and it is the second most interesting thing you will find there. It shouldn't take you more than an hour or so to see the house.

Gaudi's amazing architecture.. On the beautiful passeo de Gracia, even if built almost a 100 years ago, still is very modernist in its concept and execution, I would imagine it was revolutionary at the time, it also explains the pride Barcelonians cherish his works, and their flair for architecture in this beautiful city.

Spectacular, worth the price of admission!. We arrived shortly after Casa Mila opened because most guide books, online forums, etc. all warned of long waits for tickets. Even though the line was fairly long, it moved quickly and we were in the doors within 15 minutes. As with all things Gaudi, the casa was filled with people, but it was possible to avoid some of the most crowded corners. Plus, Gaudi’s work offers ample opportunities to feast the eyes; if one space is blocked, simply turn around. The audio guide provided an abundance of information; however, one could easily enjoy the space without its history. We wandered around for at least 2+ hours, savoring the space, especially the roof, always my favorite. Those chimneys and views! A must see if your budget allows.

A Little Expensive. I was having fun seeing all of Guadi's works of art (didn't get to the park) and this was the last on my list. It was an amazing building from the outside. There was a bit of a line all outside and it took a while to get in (could use some more desks for tickets). The way they have you go about touring this building is a little odd and it wasn't what I expected. The roof and halls met my expectations but the rooms were bland...
This makes Gaudi come to life. The excellent examples and explanations of Gaudi's thoughts and creativity puts you in his mind. The apartment very interesting and the roof totally unbelievable.
More Scaffold & Netting. Again long lines awaiting entry & not cheap.Top of building was again covered in scaffold & netting

Must see !. Take green Line L3 and get off at ''Diagonal'' Metro station. Almost opposite is the Casa Mila. We were not lucky in mid October, since the biggest part of the building was covered for renovation Works. So, we saw just a small part. Of course people could enter the inside , but we had already paid 21,5 euros per person to enter Casa Batlo, so we decided not to enter. Then we walked down on the same street, Passeg de Gracia, and got on ''Passeig de Gracia'' Metro, which is just opposite the Casa Batlo.

tickets are quite expensive for small children. we expected out 2 children to enjoy free or small fee, but they were charged 50% of adults. Other than that, the rooftop is incredible. My 10-year old daughter enjoys the apartment. My 7-year old son loves the rooftop.

Make sure repairs are finished!. I was looking forward to visiting this Gaudi work and was so disappointed once we arrived and 90% of the outside walls were covered for repair! Make sure when booking this that renovations are complete!

Overpriced but worth doing. The title says it all really, it's overpriced for what it is but the roof top is pretty spectacular and I'm glad I went there. We paid over 70euros for 2adults and 3children. The rest of the building was OK but the kids didn't get much out of it to be honest, it is really the roof top your paying for. There is a lift up which is necessary for the children and a good few steps back down. At the current time Oct14 the while building is scaffolded and screened so you can't see the building at all. Great place for sunset, it closes early evening though 7ish?

Another must in Barcelona. Great fun to look round -the roof is particularly fine. Unfortunately the outside is under repair but you still get a good impression of the overall effect. The audio guide explains the functionality which is then ornamented.

It's something unexpected. We went for a night tour. It's definitely a yes tour. It's a small tour (roughly 40 people in a group). and they finished the tour with a glass of cava (which only makes is better :)

Expensive for Gaudi's tamest work. This is like the nth Gaudi work I went to and I would say that I should have used good judgement and skip because for >20€, this was the simplest or tamest of all works. There has been a good attempt to provide more than the roof by putting some exhibit behind Gaudi inspiration on his designs on the attic as well as some view of how the working middle class live during that time. It also provided a good city view but for this price, really, no need. I can't say it is poor though but may want to think twice before spending this much.

unxpected high price for mediocre visit. when we got to la pedrera and stood in line, we couldn't see the the price of entrance. you could only get that info from the cashier, when he will tell you that the cost is 22 euro per visitor!!! if we knew we wouldn't have waited. on top of that, once we were at the cashier and heard the price we were not even given the time to ponder if we still wanted to get inside- the cashier just printed the tickets or was willing to escort us to the end of the line to rethink. going in was a mistake. it was nothing spaciel, mabey nice but defenitly doesnt worth 22 euro, and defenitly not a must!!

UNIQUE!. I'm so glad I went to see La Pedrera-Casa Mila. The tour included a visit to the roof with the unusual shapes & designs, a visit to the attic where Gaudi worked & a visit to one of apartments which is kept decorated as it was originally. Yes, the price of admission seems high but considering the cost of preservation & upkeep of such a unique property it is worth it. Don't miss it!

a must see; wild architecture, expensive. Our hotel was across the street from Casa Mila and so we walked over one morning and got on the line for tickets. The cost, counting 3 Euros for jumping the line, was almost $60 for two seniors, somewhat pricey. The place is magical, especially the roof, where Gaudi went completely nuts with his designs, but the staircase and the apartment are not bad either. Well worth seeing.
amazing. I didn't want to visit La Pedrera, but another traveler convinced me. I was very thankful as this house was very unique and interesting.

Overpriced. Walk round the roof with the remarkable chimneys, good attempt at a visual display in the attic, an apartment with furniture. So interesting and impressive, like all the Gaudi buildings we saw, but greatly overpriced.

The terrace is the point you want to be. This house has a nice interior with huge windows and nice tiles but its great place is the terrace where Gaudi has formed all the elevator or chimneys to his magical forms. Don't miss it although it is 20euros / person! Prebook it online if you know when you are getting there, in order to avoid the queue

Architecture like you have never seen before!. We spent 2 hours on visiting this apartment building having booked our tickets online before going - which is worth doing. We had an audio tour included in the price which was very good as it gave so much information. We went out onto the roof, then to the attic where a lot of the history of the place is given and the best bit was going through an apartment furnished as it would have been when first lived in.

Rooftop chain-link fence is a travesty.. A very worthwhile and well-done museum. The multi-media presentations in the attic are particularly well done and informative. The definite low-point, however, is the unsightly chain link fence on the rooftop is heinous and horrible. It ruins every view, every photo, it's completely out of character--it's a travesty. Beyond that, it's ugly as sin. Anyway, best as I could tell from the historical photos, there was no guarding whatsoever originally. So, they had to do something. They just chose very poorly.
Gaudi. Very expensive tour of Guadi designed apartment and roof. It is a good experience, but you will share with tons of other tourists. Go when it opens so you can limit the crowds.

piece of art. the place is a piece of art,starting from the entrance,you meet the security guy that's originally from alexandria,he is so friendly nd helpful,then you enter and the amazement starts,as you go you see the house of gaudi,and you just know how genius he is!then you reach the roof top!!! wooooow!! is all i can say!this is a number one attraction, this is barcelona! a must see!

Gaudi does it again. So how clever Gaudi was simply astounds me and this top block of apartments which we were able to go inside were furnished and so interesting. The interior of the ceiling under the quirky roof gives you a small understanding of this genius arcitect's ability. The roof has amazing sculptures which all serve a purpose as chimneys etc and are great photo shots. This is a must see in Barcelonia as is the Sagrada Familia if you can bear the long queues and wait!!

Fantastic. This was an amazing site. One not only gets to see how people actually lived in these amazing spaces, but also how Gaudi worked utilizing models. And of course there is the wonderful rooftop with its bizarre chimneys and views of the city. Time and budgetary restraints allowed one Gaudi tour; I'm glad I opted for this one.

Limited access . I visited Casa Batllo right before La Pedrera so the beauty of this building did not take my breath away. But it was still worth the visit! I would visit the two buildings on a separate day to fully appreciate Gaudi's hardwork.The reason why I did not feel that I appreciated this experience to the full extent was because we were not given access to many rooms and therefore, I felt that the works we were allowed to see overlapped with that of Casa Batllo.So if you do not have time to visit La Pedrera don't cry over it. You must visit Casa Batllo and La Sagrada Familia though!

Amazing place to visit. The exterior was under construction while we were there, but it was still well worth our time. The difference between this Gaudi casa and Batllo is that this one is furnished, so you get a better visual of what the home would be like in that time.

All about the roof!. Since a large section of Casa Mila's facade was covered due to construction, we thought that visiting the interior and the famous roof would elevate our moods and give us the full experience. The roof is worth all the fuss; it is interesting to imagine George Lucas in Barcelona gazing at the strangely formed chimneys and finding inspiration for Darth Vader. Of course this wasn't in the audio guide (it should be, shouldn't it?) but the guide is still informative and it's nice to move at your own pace. I really loved the mosaic details and how Gaudi used old champagne bottles to decorate a few of his functional ventilation towers which just proves that every detail has a meaning. The iron gate near the gift shop is also something not to be missed.We arrived relatively early, around 9.30am and the waiting line was not more than 15 minutes. The admission price includes an audio guide and it is rather pricey and other downsides include that everyone gathers at the top on the roof and the tour of the apartments is somewhat uninteresting but it's still a must do for any Gaudi fan like myself.

A Gaudi Gem. This has the Gaudi wow factor but it may not be obvious until you visit the roof where you feel you've entered an alien world. The roof sculptures all have a purpose masking staircases, chimneys or water tanks for the apartment below. The views are remarkable and you also get a sight of the Sagrada Familia. The apartment block is lived in but one apartment has been opened up to visitors and is fascinating for both its architecture and furnishings. The vaulted area under the roof of the block houses a very interesting Gaudi history with models of many of his buildings. There is a good gift shop on the way out. Don't miss it.
First place visited!!!. This was the first place I visited in Barcelona. It was really worth starting from Gaudi`s work. He was really a great architect. I lke his work very much.
Gaudi's contract!. This apartment is one of Gaudi’s art works. There is a small elevator which is not suitable for children.Entrance fee is expensive for this building!Always is very crowded.

Put this on your list for sure!. We had visited Familia Sagrada and just happened to see a sign to buy tickets for Casa Mila so we brought them just in a little shop. We had a 12.30 appointment so we had a breakfast in a little café then strolled to Casa Mila.Once again we were very glad we had brought the tickets as we went straight in.We loved it. We actually loved this place better than Familia Sagrada. I am not sure why but both my husband and I were very impressed. So many levels so many monuments and then the accommodation inside as well. What a fantastic building Casa Mila / La Padera is.The roof – where do I begin. You need to go to believe it. We took picture after picture as everywhere you walk there was more to see, different angles etc it was just fantastic.The apartment was amazing. The detail of the whole building is just awesome.This is a definite to visit – I do not understand why it is not higher in the rankings.

Interesting Gaudi Building. This is an apartment house by the architect Gaudi. The ticket lines tend to get long and it is a bit crowded as you go through the house, so try to go on a slow day. The room of this building is pretty cool and has some nice views. The apartments themselves were also unique with rounded rooms. I enjoyed the visit and recommend this place. My husband was not so excited about this building.

MUST SEE. The Csa Mila is phenomenal! It really shows you how people lived around the time it was built. This is the most interesting factor about it.It's a very big building and it gives you a lot to explore.Security is very tight and tickets should be bought in advance
Amazing. Now you pay but you get a recorded personal tour thru the roof, the attic and one of the apartments. They even have some of his furniture. Great gift shop. Buy tickets on line.

Superb Gaudi Attraction - a Must-Visit!. We were able to skip the long lineup by purchasing our tickets online while in Barcelona. You don't need to print your tickets - all you need to do is give them your name and booking/reference number and they'll print your tickets for you - so easy! We had booked for the 12:30pm visit but we were able to enter around 11:30am after picking up our tickets from the office. The audio guide is free and you learn such interesting facts about Gaudi and his other works as you tour through la Pedrera. After passing through the courtyard (lovely to take pics here!) you can either walk up the spiral stairs to the rooftop terrace (where the tour begins) or you can wait for the elevator. The elevator doesn't take you straight up to the terrace (you still need to walk up two flights) but it does cut down on the amount of walking. The rooftop terrace is so captivating with the chimneys that look like knights from Star Wars. Here you get beautiful views of the Passeig de Gracia, the roof terraces of other apartments, and of Barcelona. Be sure to take pics of La Sagrada Familia! There are lots of steps around the terrace and the roads are winding but fun!The next stop on the tour is in the attic (though dark) with all the arches where you see the architecture of Gaudi's other works and learn where he gets his inspiration from. He's a genius with geometry! When you walk down another two flights of stairs you will arrive in the apartment - be sure to wait for the 5 minute video where you can watch how Barcelona looked and developed between 1905-1929. It's fun to walk through the apartment and see the various rooms (e.g. Servant's quarters, office, living area, dining room, kitchen, child's room). I loved the natural light from the windows. The apartment was so modern for its time and well thought out. Even the door handles are ergonomic!Once you finish viewing the apartment you will arrive at the gift shop where you can buy vintage posters. There are a wide variety of souvenirs here. You can spend close to two hours here! Once again remember to buy your tickets online to avoid the long lineups!

Overpriced, and not much to see.. Could be passed if visited any other Gaudi design houses.
A nice roof but that all. visit only if got extra time\money.
Beautiful. Absolutely worth the trip to see this amazing building. I got some amazing pictures. The architecture is unlike anything you have seen.

Don't avoid this because of the exterior renovations!. We hesitated to visit when we saw the sections of the exterior being renovated while riding by on the tourist bus. Later we decided to visit anyhow and discovered vast areas that are still visible, despite the renovations, true to Gaudi style. Inside we were amazed at what Gaudi had created at La Pedrera. Having been to Sagrada Familia, we were aware of his incredible talent. La Pedrera is remarkable on its own though. This was designed for personal living and Gaudi knew how to put his touch here also. Besides the rooftop, which blows one's mind, between the unique chimneys and the view of Barcelona (including Sagrada Familia), one must see the clever ways Gaudi handled the interior design. Whether to view the furniture styles, the flow of rooms or the unmistakable Gaudi colors and tiles, the visitor must see this work! I highly recommend using the audio tour to fully comprehend the tour. Also, I found the gift shop perfect for many authentic gifts and souvenirs.

Terrific Modernistic Architecture. Took a guided tour (highly recommended), This place has to be seen to be believed, and it is worth the visit. I am not a great modern art fan, but the building was imaginative and well done, worth the time to visit.

Don't miss this!!!. Even if you're not a huge fan of Gaudi, this place is not to be missed! The tour is a nice self-guided one, with lots of background on the building.The building itself is an absolute masterpiece! You start out on the roof, which is alien in design, and beautiful. Next into the attic, which shows the architectural design unique for it's time. Then it's into one of the apartments, which are still large by most standards.There's not a sharp corner to be seen anywhere. Everything flows. Amazing. This was one of the highlights of our trip - so unique. Go see it.

Shame the exterior was covered. €20 entry makes it more expensive than the sagrada familia so didn't go inside but the outside gives you another sample of Gaudi. As title says though, at least 2 thirds were covered.

La Pedrera. Most people associate Gaudi with La Sagrada Familia as this is his most famous creation, but La Pedrera is equally if not more impressive - a functioning apartment block built entirely in his beautiful and unique style. You can take a tour across the roof (it is absolutely incredible!), through an exhibition of blue prints, prototypes and other pieces of Gaudi paraphernalia in the attics and also visit some reconstructed apartments, furnished with genuine period pieces. It's a fascinating experience and the audio guide does a wonderful job of explaining the life and times of Gaudi, and why a lot of his choices were made the way they were. Sadly the facade of the building is currently undergoing restorations but for the roof alone it is worth the price of entry.

Excellent visit. You can visit this house without the stress of long queues. It is amazing as any other of Gaudis wonders.It gets a bit congested as there is no much space open to the public and only one lift to go to the roof.The roof is where all the magic is! It is like landing in an alien planet! Then you learn (by the included audioguide) that behing the eccentricity in the forms there is a lot of functionality. Only a true genious can blend engineering and art like this!
Interesting. Lovely architecture of Gaudi. This place is beautiful and from the rooftop you can see the Sagrada familia cathedral and other landmarks.

It's all about the roof.. Well the façade was wrapped up. The roof is simply magic; just a lot of fun. Of course the eccentric nature of the building makes it difficult to furnish but there is a flat and in that flat there are a few pieces of furniture that follow Gaudi's thoughts.

A masterpiece. Amazing place. Sad to not be able to see the outside due to the renovations but at least the hoarding gave a flavour of the site unlike when there was a huge shop advert there when we went in March 2014.Able to see the roof and the attic and the apartment with it's furniture. Loved it.

Mad but Marvellous. Barcelona probably wouldn't be the same without Gaudi . The man was obviously a man out of his time but he makes Barcelona fabulous. The building is beautiful and well worth the 8 Euro's entrance fee . Every part of complex is strange but wonderful to look at . The exhibition in the loft ( the old wash house ) is a great insight into Gaudi and his inspiration's mainly taken from nature. When you reach the roof you are literally blown away by his fantastical creations , it's that incredible . There is even a photo opportunity , when you can sit in an archway and be in shot with Gaudi's Sagrada Familia in the background . Dont miss the apartment downstairs , it is still decorated and furnished as it would of been at the the turn of the last century , they certainly did live well back then . Don't miss this incredible building with it's marvellous roof . A must do whilst in the city.

Incredible architecture!. Awesome architecture! I've never seen anything like it. The tour includes access to the building, a tour of the roof, the attic with displays of Gaudi's work and an apartment decorated with furniture from the time period.

La Pedrera at Night. We purchased this tour opportunity on Viator. La Pedrera at night was, in a word, magical. SO many nuances of the architect's genius were evident in the evening! It was great to take the tour with a small group, allowing plenty of time to view each of the sights at our leisure. The champagne and hors d'euvres at the end of the tour were a neat plus.

Roof spectacular - facade a no-go. Unfortunately the façade is covered so did not get to see the outside.Pre-purchased skip-the-line audio (9:30) tour tickets via the website; there was no line-up so not sure that this was necessary. After the intro in the entrance hall, the order of viewing is roof - attic - apartment; a small elevator takes you to the roof. Because of the direction we took after we exited the elevator it took quite a while before we found a number coinciding with information for the audio tour. The design of the roof was fascinating and we took our time exploring. That said, by 10:30 it was +++ hot; cannot imagine being there in the afternoon sun. The attic had lots of visual displays and provided opportunities to sit while listening to audio information and observing exhibits/videos. Apartment was less interesting.

The must see of Gaudi. For me it´s not so amanzing as Batlo BUT, if you see this place firts you will love it too. The structure of the building it´s quite unusual and the roopflop is the must see that you will never forget! Don´t miss it!

Especially furnished apartment.... We were able to see just one: Casa Mila or Casa Batllo. We chose Casa Mila, after virtual trip on its website. This was amazing! Especially furnished apartment from that age.

Spectacular rooftop. Part of the facade was covered up due to reconstruction but you can still see part of the beautiful exterior. The rooftop alone is worth every Euro and will definitely blow you away!!

Great visit, very informative. Went there because we couldn't stand the queue at the Sagrada Familia (we booked online tickets and are going in 2 days!). The building is amazing both in its looks and engineering and the information provided by the audio guide very good. The renovation work is amazing and it will look even better once finished.

Another of A. Gaudi's architectural wonders. One has to wonder what was going on in Gaudi's mind, but whatever it was, it was awesome. La Pedrera is across from two other of Gaudi's creations. Unfortunately for us visitors, about 1/2 of the building is covered with a tarp because of on-going renovation/restoration, but it is still worth the visit. There is a fee is you wish to visit the inside.
Really worth the time. We went early and there was no queues. Standing on the roof terrace, admiring Gaudi's interpretations of nature is so inspiring and the bonus of veiws across the city.

Gaudi's Incredible Work. This privately owned living accommodation is an incredible example of Gaudi's fertile mind. It is within walking distance from the Sagrada Familia and on the metro line. Sit and enjoy the "newer" part of the city, people watch and amaze at this building.

Stunning and nicely presented as a visit. We took the highlights audio tour, which was very good. In hindsight, I may have gone for the full 75 minute audio tour. The architecture is stunning and the apartment was equally fascinating. We really enjoyed our visit.
Pay attention to the smaller, subtle detailing, like the floor coverings and the ceiling lighting- quite lovely.
must see. extremely interesting and different. Hope that it isn't under restoration. go early or late. Also have a "fast Pass" option which is worth it if you get their when busy.

Summer Evening Jazz night is a MUST!. We looked at buying general entry tickets for La Pedrera, but instead were drawn to the evening Summer Jazz for a very small additional price. The ticket gives you entry to the exhibition, access to the stunning roof and a glass of cava to watch the band with. The views were breath-taking, the band were incredible and everyone at the concert was grinning from ear to ear!Honestly the highlight of my trip to Barcelona, felt like a totally exclusive, once in a lifetime experience!Visited July 2013

Another great work from Gaudi!. So much to see inside here! Another great piece by Gaudi! spend lots of time on the rooftop and feel the art of Gaudi! It's hard to imagine such a lovely place and a very different and interesting architecture in the middle of a busy city! Price is expensive to visit all the Gaudi work, but it was well spent here. We decided to visit this one instead of the Batlo. But if price is not a concern definitely visit both!

Worth a visit!. Amazing building with great views from the roof - although do be careful of the many little steps & the low walls around the outside of the roof! We visited around 6 in the evening, by which point it was a little quieter - a very enjoyable visit.

Unique Architecture by Gaudi. A must visit for those having an eye for architecture. I suggest the audio tour. The commentary is brilliant. The view from the terrace is decent. You could finish the tour in less than 90 minutes. The staff are very helpful. The ticket costs €16.50 + €4.00 for audio. You could share the audio kit between two people.

Beautiful building. Besides a great building, Casa Mila has all the genius of Gaudi through his harmonica combination of functionality and unique style.If you want to understand more about Gaudi inspiration, you can assist the 4D cinema (next to Park Guell). During 10 minutes you see a 4D movie that attempts to explain the origin of his ideas in a playful and entertaining way. I loved it!
The facade is being renovated. The facades are a major part of the Gaudi buildings and this one's facade is covered up. If you've only a limited time available then pass on this one.

Interesting. Okay, I confess to not being much of a Gaudi fan but I'm glad we visited this apartment building, which he designed and built. The roof along is worth the price of admission but even more interested was the exhibits in the attic showing how he built La Pedrera.

Great chimneys!. Not for people who are afraid of heights. the tour starts as you enter the courtyard and you look up. then the lift or stairs in our case, takes you to the roof. Well its just amazing that a recreational space has been made on the roof. i did find it a little disconcerting that there were steps eveywhere and only a small fence to hold you in. The chimmneys are surreal. then down to the attic where there are models of how the house and others were built, and then down to the apartment. Well this was fascinating to see how people lived/ are living in these apartments. and they were a lot bigger than i imagined. the front of the building was covered for building work, but if you walk along the side you can see how it looks. not disimilar to the balconies on casa batllo. worth the money.

Real Art Nouveau. Just amazing! Great art everywhere. You can realize that Gaudi was not only an artist but an architect who could make practicable apartments where you can enjoy your daily life. The roof space was awesome. Artistic and functional. The top floor you can walk through and enjoy good old 19-20 centuries.

A piece of art! must visit. This was the highlight of our trip. We were introduced to Gaudis brilliant craftmenship. I did not know who Gaudi was before this visit, but it has affected the way I look at architecture from now on.

Well worth the price of admission and audio tour!. Upon entering a courtyard, one gazes up at the spectacular space created by Gaudi. An elevator takes you up 6 floors to the large roof area with fascinating chimneys of all kinds with beautiful views of Barcelona. There is a bit of up-and-down and steep/off-angle stairs with fencing so be careful. You then go down one floor to the attic that shows how Gaudi constructed the support for the roof. Here are models and descriptions not only of Casa Mila, but for many of his other buildings. Then go down to the 2nd floor to a Gaudi-period furnished apartment with about 9 rooms where one can get a real sense of living there. Choice of audio tours: 75 minutes detailed or 40 minutes highlights. We took the 75 minute one and enjoyed it immensely. We came 15 minutes prior to opening with online tickets, so the building was not crowded; spent 2 hours. While Casa Battlo is more highly rated in TripAdvisor, both Fodors and Rick Steves prefer Casa Mila over Casa Battlo if you had to pick just one. So choose wisely if you have limited time or money.

Classic Gaudi. A classic Gaudi at a decent price. You can pay an additional 4 euros for an audio guide but we passed on this and focused on the architecture and enjoyed the trip just as much. The best parts of the building are those outside, the roof terrace and looking up when you initially come in. One floor has the interiors done up in the original style and there is also an exhibition on Gaudi but the real attraction is the building itself. In terms of waiting, the visit involves a wait at the bottom for a lift, which can take a little while and buying tickets on the day involved a short wait. Both were well-worth it.

Mi Casa Su Casa. If this would be my house, WOW oh WOW indeed!!! And yet again Gaudi do really stands out with his own unique ideas and design. Another great experience and another beautiful Gaudi creation. We got to the rooftop and enjoyed that marvelous view and walked downwards to every floor therein, and it just never stopped, to give you bits and pieces of the history of this beautiful house, the wooden arches, the sample model houses of Guadi's work, painted ceilings, etc. We rather not ruin the fun and have you experience it for yourselves. All worth the visit.

Shame about the covering!. Sadly during our visit they appeared to be undertaking work on the facade of this amazing work of art. The corner facade was covered up - although the covering was a huge picture of what lay underneath. Fortunately there was an area to the right that remains uncovered and allowed you to see this part of the building in all its glory. Hadn't realised you could go inside so had not planned time to do this on this visit - but would next time. If the covering hadn't been there this would have been excellent.

Beautiful Chimneys. Casa Mila's outside is being restarted right now, so you cant enjoy it in its full glory. But the ceiling is the most important part of the house. Beautiful designs of Gaudi. Some look like an army watching over the house. You can also get to enjoy the view of Passeig de Gracia from there and have an experience with the projections that they offer inside. You can even imagine yourself inside of a dragons skeleton on how the attic looks.

Gaudi is fascinating. I was excited to visit La Pedrera during my trip to Barcelona because I had heard great things about it. I was disappointed off right off the bat because the entire exterior of the building was covered in scaffolding. They did print a graphic of the real exterior on the fabric covering but its wasn't even close to seeing the real exterior.The audio tour was good but I lost interest. At the start of your visit you take an elevator to the roof. This was the highlight for me. I really enjoyed the great views of the city and Gaudi's masterpieces on the roof! Then you take the stairs to the attic. Here you see lots of models and info on other Gaudi creations. Then you take more stairs to the apartment. I enjoyed seeing the antiques. I spent the majority of my time on the roof and then skimmed the attic & apartment. I booked my tickets online (paid $29) and booked a specific time to visit. I would highly recommend you do the same. I was able to skip the long ticket line and enter at my allotted time. If you have to chose between Casa Batllo and La Pedrera. I vote for Casa Batllo. If you have time to visit both then great. La Pedrera is worth it just for the roof.

Interesting exhibition to summurize impression about Gaudi. The frontage is closed for restoration, so don't spend time if you don't want to get in (but you surely should go in if you have time, after visiting Casa Batlo, Sagrada Familia and Park Guel). Whenever you go, always buy your tickets online, it's not an exception, you can save a lot of time. It's a great view from the roof, exhibition about different Gaudi works and excursion through one of the flats of the building. I believe that it's the best way to summurize all the experience from other Gaudi works, get known about technics, designing and developing, but if you are short of time, you should better visit casa Batlo or Sagrada Familia. Audioguide, as for me, has too long openings to each sections, so I started it before come to the next point and it was ok.

The building itself was beautiful!. We were disappointed in the Nightly Tour. We could barely hear the soft spoken tour guide - a microphone was needed.. The main entrance was beautiful, but the tour of an apartment was too warm, overcrowed and not all that interesting. The attic was huge and interesting but the rooftop was our focal point. I would not recommend the rooftop for anyone with disabilities. As you entered the rooftop there was a two foot drop - difficult to see with the blinding lights. There were numerous elevations on the rooftop...it was not a comfortable feeling. No railings or markers to guide you. You had to look for steps with glaring lights in your eyes. I stumbled, along with another person - it was quite a shocking jolt. The cava was served in an open stark white room. We were ready to leave and we were walked to the beautiful entry on the first floor. Gaudi's work priceless - we just felt the tour was expensive and not as enjoyable as we had anticipated. Our tour of Casa Batillo was by far a more enjoyable experience - and should not to be missed!
Best rooftop in Barcelona. Gaudi at his best. Still looks modern and contemporary in today's world despite actually being about 100 years old.

Good for an overview on all Gaudi works. Casa Mila was good for an overview on all Guadi's works, with an informative presentation in the attic but I found there was less of his actual architecture on display and less colour than at other sites.

Go in the night. I'm a fan of Gaudi's work so I traveled around looking at all the incredibly beautiful and interesting places in Barcelona that he designed. I am very glad I chose to do the Secret Pedrera in the evening, which was further enhanced by deciding to attend a jazz concert on the roof. This was a different way of looking at things. I felt it allowed me to feel what it might have been like to live there in some small way. The concert on the roof was just brilliant. I was there in August so I had the setting sun as a backdrop. The views of the city were spectacular. If you have the opportunity you won't be sorry.

Another Gaudi building. It is about 15 minutes from Catalunya Square and some 5 minutes from Casa Battlo (also a Gaudi). This one looks as if it has been made from the beach sand and boasts the easily recognisable Gaudi shapes.

Challenging the senses!. Having purchased a two day bus pass from one of the two main tour bus operators, one of our stop off points was La Pedrera. Work was in progress on the outside of the building, so it was covered top to bottom with a giant picture of what was behind it. It only slightly detracted from the overall experience, because what was inside was amazing. Gaudi was inspired by nature: so straight lines are rare but the high production and maintenance costs are probably covered by the revenues such a wonderful building generates.We were with two friends. As part of the tour, you enter an elevator which takes you a few floors up to the roof. The building encircles an open space and it is walled, but the inner safety wall is made of toughened glass. It is all perfectly safe as the walkway round the building is about 4 metres wide, but it was at this point my friend and I each discovered the other had an extreme fear of heights. Our wives have no idea what vertigo is and leant over the sides and took some magnificent photos for us. Eventually, my friend shuffled round the walkway, whilst I sat on a step trying to figure out where the exit stairs might be.Actually, I don't want my vertigo to detract from the views as they were quite stunning. We then took the stairs down floor by floor and saw a plan of the building, some original apartments and several pieces of Gaudi designed furniture.The building is extraordinary and really challenges the senses. We arrived in Barcelona on Friday afternoon and left the following Monday morning. We definitely needed at least one more day. The Pedrera should be very high on your list of places to visit in Barcelona.
Wonderful experience. It was just fascinating..... Wandering around this building is just a truly amazing. I would recommend this to all visitors to Barcelona.

Another Gaudi beauty, for sure!. When in Barcelona, DO GAUDI! (it will be a treat)! This was my third Gaudi adventure for this trip, following La Segrada Familia and Park Guell. This visit just added another layer of understanding and appreciation for Gaudi up close and personal. We purchased tickets on the spot, the line was not too long, and moved very quickly. We also splurged for the guided tour (and I would recommend it) which added some great background facts. Visiting this "re-furnished apartment suite" provided a very real look at the unique thought process behind the living space design and their layout. And, the gift shop! .... (and I do love a good gift shop) ...Just a perfect way to end the tour, another beautiful merchandise mix of jewelry, art, books, cards, etc. (I agree with another of the contributor - the exterior was covered for cleaning, which completely hides the grand exterior .. so don't walk past it by mistake). I believe this will be another great Gaudi experience you will truly enjoy!

A must see in Barcelona. As many have said, getting to the roof is priority one as this is the best way to start the tour. We did have a slow ticket buying experience but not terrible. Next to the roof, the attic is the other must see place in this Gaudi building.

Fabulous stone facade a spectacle to behold. The fabulous stone facade with the twisted iron balconies is a spectacle to behold. Named for its rough exterior which resembles an open quarry this residential project is another wonderful showcase of Gaudi’s inventive designs and illustrates how well ahead of the architectural design of the time he was. It would have been an amazing place to have lived.The facades of the courtyards are an array of colour, light and varied forms. Murals decorate the ceilings and walls of the entrance lobbies and the main staircase, injecting more colour. Plants cascading down from lower balconies also create colour and enhance the sense of openness and nature.There are some great things to explore inside as well. On the fourth floor, an apartment has been recreated, providing an insight into the home and lifestyle of a wealthy family in Barcelona in the 20th century. Following the original layout, the home is filled with furniture and household items of the time. Decorative elements designed by Gaudi also adorn the apartment, such as the window and door handles, moulded to ergonomically fit the hand; doors and flooring.Up in the attic, made up of brick arches, is a tribute to Gaudi’s life and work through scale models and plans, drawings and photographs. It provides interesting insight into Gaudi’s work throughout his lifetime.Perched on top of the building is the roof terrace, filled with a fabulous collection of interesting forms, designed to also fulfil a function, such as chimneys, ventilation shafts and stairwells. Some of these are decorated with shards of broken tile, stone, marble and glass, providing further dimension to these dynamic forms. Affording magnificent views of the modern city of Barcelona, wandering among these fascinating forms offers a nice respite from the bustling streets below. Plan to visit on a fine day as the roof terrace is closed when it is raining.Would definitely recommend booking ticket in advance online, it’s easy to do and you will be pleased when you arrive and can bypass the crowds without a ticket waiting to enter. These queues were quite lengthy when we visited at midday. You can also visit during the evening and see everything lit up which would also offer a great perspective.A camera is set up so you can have your photo taken and super imposed in front of the whole building and purchase the photograph to take home. You can select a few including day and night time photos. As well as hard copy the photos are also available digitally online for you to download. Quite touristy but a great souvenir to take home. It is easy to get to. It is one of the stops for most of the hop on hop off buses. Otherwise a variety of local public transport will get you there. Would definitely recommend a visit.

Gaudi building. Tip: definitely buy admission on line !Wonderful we'll preserved building and apartment to view. The rooftop with its numerous chimneys and views are incredible - however try to visit when there is no rain forecast because they can close the rooftop.

Wonderful. I was recommended to visit by my sister who had been in Barcelona earlier in the year, otherwise I may not have bothered. I'm so glad I came! I knew very little about Gaudi but feel I've learned a great deal. We hadn't got tickets but went straight in by paying an extra 3 euros each. The roof was fascinating but not the most interesting part of the visit as far as I was concerned. The attic was fascinating and I could really appreciate Gaudi's architectural genius looking at the way the roof is constructed. The exhibits here were very well presented too, and helped explain how the building was constructed. The best part of the visit for me was the apartment, it was beautiful. I loved the way it was furnished and it gave a real insight into what it must have been like to live there when it was first built. So glad we came.

Love Gaudi!. Beautiful Gaudi masterpiece. Unfortunately, the exterior was complete covered by a decorative cover hiding the scaffolding as they were clean the stone. Hopefully it'll be gone soon. Bought my tickets online, but for me, it was not necessary as we got there in the morning and there were no lines. In fact, it was the only place that they actually let us enter early! The house/apartment is beautiful and the museum is interesting, but the roof top with all the chimneys is the real attraction! This is a must-see while in Barcelona.
