Gaudi, Gaudi, Gaudi --. An excellent example of Gaudi's work --- interesting and in his unique style.The waits again can be 30" to access the site.

Gaudi!. The recommended start of the visit is to head from the rooftop down. We took the lift to the rooftop and once you get out of the lift, it felt so surreal. Such amazing architecture with the beautiful blue Barcelona skies as the backdrop. Tip is to buy tickets online to avoid the long queues!

Excellent Gaudi site. The rooftop of this building is fantastic and reminds me of a place Dr. Seuss created. Tip: buy the skip the line ticket in advance for the opening time slot. As soon as you get the audio guide go directly to the rooftop so you can get your photos in before other people are distracting the shots. You can then spend time looking out over the city. Then proceed down to the attic and apartment that don't require getting there right away. Very interesting place but the rooftop is the highlight. Also, if you suffer from vertigo, you want to skip this. You can see most everything in about an hour & 1/2 or two. Nice souvenir shop (a bit pricey as most souvenir shops are that are part of a major tourist attraction, but nice stuff). When we went (Sept. 2014) they are doing construction with scaffolding & screen wrapped on the exterior façade of the building and cannot see anything of the exterior. Worth the visit.

A Must-see. This attraction is definitely a must during a visit in Barcelona! It is so interesting and nice that even someone not keen on architecture could like and enjoy.The roof terrace alone is worth spending at least one hour enjoying the city view and taking pictures from endless different perspectives.I recommend advanced online booking as the queue builds up pretty fast at all hours of the day.

WEIRDLY BRILLIANT. Spent a couple of hours wandering about wondering what sort of mind Gaudi had to come up with a place like this. The views from the roof and the roof itself make it worthwhile visiting.

Great Gaudi Architechture...Best overall example!. La Pedrera is one of the best places to visit in Barcelona...you not only learn about Gaudi's great inspirations and architectural work in this attraction, but also get glimpses into his other works...including La Segrada Familia, Casa Batllo and more.The chimneys are fantastic, the apartment is impressive, but the attic is incredible! Totally worth the price of admission!

Quite something. I didn't know too much about Gaudi and am glad I visited. We visited in early evening and had "skip the line tickets" which you can buy online and is a must. This architecture is unlike anything I've ever seen and am glad to have experienced it. Be sure to take the audio tour and go up to the roof.
Impressive house. This is one of the greatest places that I have been. So different and inspired. Gaudy made a smart and functional house. So impressive, must seen.

Amazing roof, inside not exciting. We booked online so didn't have to queue but for 16.50 EU we expected to see more. It was more expensive than the Sagrada Familia and not nearly as impressive. You start on the roof which is pretty cool, but the apartment is quite plain and ordinary for Gaudi. Also the front facade is all covered up so you can't even see the outside from the street. Maybe if we'd bought the audio guide for 4 EU each we would've heard things that made it seem more impressive, but from a purely aesthetic point of view I think don't bother unless you're an architecture buff.

La Pedrera. Without a doubt, a truly inspiring place, especially if you're interested in all things Gaudí. The whole architectural aspect is very beautiful and it'll be very strange if by the end of your visit you don't find yourself thinking Gaudí was a genius. The entry fee is not too high, but the most remarkable souvenirs are expensive. All in all worth it if you have the time to visit more than one of the Gaudí buildings.

i want an apartment here. It seems like an apartment building would cramp Gaudi's style, but not so. The color palate is neutral, but the rooms are not square, though big enough for furniture, and full of graceful moldings and details. The attic will thrill any engineer or architecture fan. The best part is the roof. all ups and downs and chimneys that look like alien beasts.

Gaudí at his best. Using the English audio guide, we were able to see and understand everything that's open. The building was originally designed to be apartments, and some are still being lived in, while other spaces are now offices or part of the excellent museum that we toured. The rooftop alone is fascinating, with all of these shapes that made me think of Dr. Seuss, but are actually functional (chimney vents, air vents, etc). Down one floor in the "Attic" - which used to be the laundry area - the exhibits tell Gaudi's life story, explain his work, and show some of the history and culture of his era. Then you go down another floor where you walk through a "sample apartment" complete with furniture and appliances, etc., that would have been in an apartment during his times.

Getting work done it. We couldn't see much of it from the street as it had people working on it. We went to line up to go inside but the line was massive. I would recommend buying tickets online. A nice lady let us in the front for 5 mins to walk up the stairs and take photos.

Gaudi at his most approachable. After visiting the Sagrada Familia, it is wonderful to see Gaudi´s genius working its magic in a domicile environment. I absolutely loved La Pedrera and the pictures do it absolutely no justice. Do take the long audioguide tour - it is absolutely worth it. Also take your time looking around the apartment and -why not- day dream about living there! Added tip: The little cafe opposite la pedrera makes excellent salads

Gaudi's La Pedrera at Night. We took this tour though Viator for a Behind-Closed Doors tour, starting at 9:15 pm. Very fun to be there at this late hour without all the many people. Very fun to see this unique building on the inside. Good Tour guide, Even included a glass of Champagne.

Wacky Roof. A note for all: the exterior is currently covered in scaffolding so if this was your main purpose for the visit then you will be dissapointed. The entrance fee is €18.50 each or €21.50 with an audio guide, of which you can chose a highlights guide or a full guide with all the information you could ever need. The living areas were unexpected but great to see although none of the furniture was actually from this building and just from the time same period between 1906-1912. Have a great time in Barcelona :) the roof can be closed if the rain gets too heavy so if you wake up and its raining, have a back up plan!

Wrapped and scaffolding until February 2015. The only way to see the outside is to go through the store underneath on the left. Proceed up the stairs and out the back door to where the store sells patio furniture. From that vantage point you can see the back which is not wrapped. The store itself is quite historic. Notice the fireplace, ceiling and original floors.

Great Roof!. I enjoyed my visit and highly recommend that you do the audio tour I chose the shorter one (40 minutes) as it narrated a straight forward tour. Visually you will find movement in the construction and as it's hard to find right angles. The roof is spectacular not only will you get a splendid view of Sagrada Familia and the wonderful skyline of Barcelona but the whimsy and forms of the chimneys and water tanks make for great pictures! Make sure to choose the audio for ultimate immersion into the works of Gaudi.

Expensive. How unfair that many people won't be able to afford the extortionate entrance fee €20.50! On arrival a lift takes you to the roof top, you view the Gaudi chimney pots along the undulating terrace. Next walk down to see the arched attic floor and finally down to view the apartment. The apartment is magnificent.

Make this your 3rd Gaudi Choice. Visited here August 2014. La Pereda is now an office building that used to also include some dwellings. You wait in line then take a elevator to the roof where you find some interesting chimneys and get a nice view of the city. You can listen to the audio lecture which adds some much needed context. The roof doesn't need more than a few minutes before you start winding yourself down the interior where you are introduced to the background behind the building's development. Although there are some interesting aspects none of them need you to spend much time here. Unless you are an architectural student or Gaudi lover this place is simply not as visually interesting compared to the church or Battlo. If you are pressed for time or simply wanting to prioritize your Gaudi visits make it third on your list or go the park which is free and no waiting in line. Tip: plan to attend between 12 - 2 pm when lines are not as long.
A must if you want some background on gaudi!. We were walking by and decided to stop to check this historic Gaudi building. Also, I recommend the full audio tour for only 4euro more.

Not something special. La Pedrera is the last civil work designed by Gaudi.In my opinion is much more beautiful the outside view and the roof view than inside.For someone that is interested/enjoyed architecture maybe is very interesting, for me that I don’t have much knowledge it was just average. Believe there are much more interesting/beautiful places to see in Barcelona than La Pedrera. This is just my personal opinion. Maybe is because we first visited Sagrada familia and we impressed so much and we were expecting something similar.

Noteworthy visit. Sadly the exterior of the building was covered but interior was fabulous. Gaudi's attention to detail and balance is evident even in his curves and apparent assymetry. His work is calming and invigorating at the same time. Visit first thing in the morning to avoid the queues.

Its been renovated on the outside still worth the visit. We were disappointed that the outside is under screens- apart from the top but the building is still open and worth the visit to appreciate the genious of Gaudi. The roof is wonderful and apparently there are jazz concerts at night which we would love to do next time.

Worth the visit for the works of Gaudi in the attic! . After visiting Sagrada Familia, this place hardly held any interest to us on the face of it, especially when we learnt that this was an apartment complex. We even began the tour (with audio guide) with disinterest. But we were in for a surprise! The tour includes a visit to the roof, the attic and one apartment floor. The floor below the roof, called the attic, was what gave meaning to the building structure and gave insight into Gaudi, his genius, ideas and the way he designed his brilliant structures. We spent over an hour on this floor itself. There was information about other structures that we could not visit on this trip, which made it worthwhile for us, in a way. Recommend the visit, but with a guide to understand the work of the artist and appreciate it better.
La Pedrera. very impressive and the view from the roof terrace was stunning. Although a little disappointing that the front of the building was covered.

A Gaudi masterpiece. Designed by Gaudi and built between 1906 and 1912, this building was considered very innovative becuase of its curtain walls - the facade is self-supporting. The stone facade looks like it's undulating - my husband says it looks like it's melting. Either way, its a masterpiece and so worth seeing.

Jazz on the Roof. I've visited La Pedrera by day and it's definitely something you should see when In BCN - although I much prefer Casa Batllo. But in my opinion, the best way to experience it is to take in one of the night time jazz concerts they run in the summer months. The rooftop is stunning by day, but late at night, with a glass of bubbly and live jazz creates an incredible experience. Well worth the ticket price

Incredible despite the renovation. Despite the fact the front of the building was all covered (very disappointing!), the interior and the roof are absolutely impressive! Gaudi was a genious, not only with his amazing architectural style but combining it with efficiency!

A real masterpiece. The bullding itself is a real jewel. No 90 degrees angle can be found on it. You can enjoy from the outside but a visit inside is highly recommended. Be prepared for a long queue, and to pay more than 10 euros to visit it. Once in, you can visit two appartments made one, furnished and decorated in pure art deco. Afterwards and below the terrace, there is a rounded floor where you can see some of the extraordinary work of Gaudi. Terrace is also amazing, sometimes there is music in it. Bit expensive though.

Facade under renovation, reconstructed interiors. We booked the Pedrera by night guided tour. The tour leader was excellent but the interiors of this building do not have a WOW factor especially if you have already visited the Casa Battlo, Parc Guell and Sagrada Familia. This is a huge apartment complex, designed by Gaudi. The tour takes you to one of the apartments where Gaudi lived. The rooms are reconstructed and does not match the Gaudi-modernista style. However, the attic is nice and resembles the skeleton of a whale. It used to be a laundry in the past but now it houses an interesting exhibition of a few of the many concepts which Gaudi designed and developed. The roof-terrace has tens of nice features including architectural structures decorated with ceramic fragments. We were given a glass of Cava (the Spanish champagne) and we were allowed a few minutes of free time where we could enjoy the nice views from this roof top. Our ticket included a dinner at the Pedrera restaurant. Unfortunately, the restaurant is not well decorated and looks very bare and dull. We were given a menu which was totally different from the one they had sent us via email. The portions were very small and the food was crappy.TIPS: check if the renovations are ready before visiting. Do not go to Pedrera restaurant.

Outstanding architecture. This building is a masterpiece. The apartment open for visiting is over 600m2 in size and is amazing. The famous roof and attic are also not to be missed.Worth travelling half way around the world to see as part of the Gaudi legacy.

Interesting building and architect.. First time in Spain and unaware of the significance of Gaudi's work, I found the Mila House very interesting and worth visiting. Gaudi's imagination and creativity was very impressive. The only negative was that the outside of the building was covered by drop cloth while undergoing renovation so the exterior was not easy to view and appreciate.

Go for the night rooftop jazz concett. The outside of the building was completely covered up due to renovations. We were not aware of that so that was disappointing. But we had reservations for "the secret tour" and then the night rooftop jazz concert. The building is stunning. The rooftop at night has a beautiful view of the city. The concert was really nice and they serve Cava. Such a romantic setting. My boyfriend actually proposed to me up there and it was a such a beautiful setting and a lovely night. Loved this place

A night on the tiles. Having already seen so many buildings of Gaudy i chose to try Gaudy by night complete with a jazz concert on the roof. They let In the summer they have a late night concert on the roof.They let you in at 21.30 and you get to walk through the house but not enter the apartments. You do get to see the museum with models of the house and information that I found interesting. After that you are out on the roof. The music was good and the view, ambience, lighting and Gaudy surrealistic back drop was really enjoyable. They play for about 90 minutes then you leave. it cost me €56 for two tickets so not really cheap but considering you get a jazz concert I think it was worth it. Ironically although you pay so much they give you what is called a free drink. No choice except yes or no to what I think was champagne. There was a bar as well but it only had Gin and tonic for €12 or water. i think it was a good evening and made a change to walking around the other Gaudy bulidings with a head set on.

Another Gaudi Masterpiece.. This Gaudi masterpiece is my second important after the Sagrada Familia. It's curvy facade and the beautiful sculptural l wrought iron railings makes you want to see more, and here I definitely advise you to enter the building and explore it's roof with it's warriors like chimneys.

Gaudi Immersion. This amazing apartment house is a fabulous way to immerse oneself in the fanciful architecture of Gaudi. We toured with our 2 teenage kids, who really enjoyed it. Our time in Barcelona was limited, so we chose this one house as our way to expose the kids to Gaudi. We bought passes online to skip the lines, and spent a good hour on the roof and in the 2 floors of museum below the roof. By immersing them in Gaudi at Casa Mila this way, we felt okay about not going inside any of the other Gaudi masterpieces.
Awesome. We really enjoyed the visit here. Decided to get tickets after our recommended as must see. She was right! The views were amazing. Great scenery.
Nice. Nice visit, the roof and the entrance are intresting...Disappointed for the works at the external... Covered!Nice... Not incredible

Cannot see anything from outside. "Casa Milà reports that the restoration and improvement of the building’s facade, which is currently taking place, is compatible with all the scheduled visits and cultural activities." That's what I found on their website today.Oh man, this is a notice? "Compatible??" A lame excuse and a misleading information to be exact.Let's be honest: the WHOLE facade is TOTALLY covered in big billboards, and you will see NOTHING but white billboards with some blur drawing of the house on them from the street. That's what I call honest.On 24 Aug 2014, I paid 5 minutes visiting this one, having a look at the billboards from the street, capturing picture of peoples waiting in queue under the sunlight to get in. 18 EUR wait in queue and to get to the rooftop? That's ridiculous and shamelessly selling anything attached with the name of Gaudi. You can give it a miss. I've read the reviews on Tripadvisor so I didn't get in.Wanna get extraordinary view of the city? Go to MNAC uphill, go to Parc Guell, or take a cable care trip. They worth more than paying to get to this house's rooftop.

re: not much to see. This is my first time in Barcelona and as I'm an interior designer, I feel I should visit all Gaudi's design. When we got there, the facade is all wrapped up for renovation. The area for visit is very small too. If you're on a tight budget and you can only select a few of the museum, you can omit this one as after visitng the other Gaudi's museum and site, La Pedrera is the least exciting compare to the others.

Interesting but Under Construction. Even though the exterior is under construction, the tour was interesting. You get to go up to the rooftop (although you can do this on weekend evenings for a jazz concert as well). you also get to tour the museum on the attic level and an apartment as well. The rooftop has spectacular views of the city and the structures up there are amazing.

More Gaudi Magic. A must for everybody interested in architecture. Even with ongoing construction (the facade was completely covered with scaffolding and tarp) the visit was still worthwhile, especially the roof.
4th visit - still fab!. Well worth it - the roof terrace is amazing and the apartment is fascinating. Thoroughly recommend. We only waited for c.20 minutes in a queue.

Excellent views of the city. We attended a concert here at night and it was wonderful - offering amazing views of surrounding Barcelona. The architecture is very interesting and the concert set up of simply sitting around in the steps was relaxed and cool. I would definitely visit again.

Sadly, the exterior is currently being cleaned and repainted,. So, the entire exterior is covered by scaffolding and a huge advertisement curtain through the end of the year according to one of the employees. There is no way to appreciate the entire structure as intended while this work is going on, so go with that in mind. Meanwhile, the interior of the building is open to viewing as is the rooftop terrace with all it's fanciful forms. The roof affords some views of the city including Sagrada Familia. The attic, with all it's brick arches was stunning. Overall, we were disappointed we were not able to appreciate the building in it's entirety, but still glad we went. Admission is 15 euros in the long line, but look for the fast admission entrance at the corner and pay the extra 3 euros to go right in.
Reconstruction. The whole building covered with a shield for reconstruction, so actually you can't see anything. You'd better move on directly to Casa Batllo

Expensive rooftop visit. I didn't like the experience of visiting casa mila rooftop for 18 Euros. That was a waste of money just to see the rooftop. When i visited Barcelona the facade was being renovated so i didn't even get a good look on that.You pay the entrance fee and take the elevator to the rooftop. Have a nice view of Barcelona and then visit an exhibition that shows Gaudi's work (the same thing that you see in Sagrdada Familia, Casa Batllo etc). You then visit traditional flat with traditional furniture and pass by the gift shop and that’s it.

Amazing roof terrace. This attractions unlike casa battlo cannot be really appreciated from ground floor ,the roof holds these amazing architecture and when you descent you visit the other rooms designed by Gaudi ,it is a lovely attraction to see in Barcelona

beautiful roof terrace. Another Gaudi building with his special architectural style!You must visit the roof terrace for taking an overall opinion of the building!!!Also, an expensive ticket for what you see inside...
way more than a famous roof!. Beside the famous facade and roof there's an exhibition of an apartment in art nouveau style with really amazing ceilings and furniture. Really takes you back in time!
A must see. One of the must see attractions of Barcelona. Designed by Catalan architect Antoni Gaudi it gives the city a nice flavor of unique architecture and taste.

Another masterpiece by Gaudi. Casa Mila (or La Pedrera) is a private apartment complex built by Gaudi. Now it is open for public viewing. Located right in the middle of the city and close to Diagonal Metro, it is a must visit attraction in Barcelona. You can skip the line by paying an additional 3 EUR and grab an audio guide. The thoughtful and attractive construction in the roof and the interiors are interesting. But when we visited, the outside walls were covered with a curtain (probably some maintenance).
Fabulous. This is simply one of the great things to see in Barcelona. The rooftop is absolutely stunning. Marvellous.

Its worth a look.. Anything Gaudi inspired is well worth a look and this place is worth a visit if only to take in the facade of this building.Once inside the architecture is beautiful and the terrace and roof structures are stunning.

worth the visit. I loved Casa Mila. Unfortunately at the time the exterior was being renovated so we were unable to see it.However the interior and the roof were amazing.Be sure to pre- purchase your tickets so you can skip the lines.

Too expensive for what we sow. The visit to Casa Mila is cost around 18€, they don't make much of discounts for students or disable people, just shamelessly sale anything with Gaudi's name. And this place did not cost so much, we sow only white walls that have a nice shape. Inside we mostly sow rooms with souvenirs. I think it's much better to go only to the park Guell.

Fascinating and whimsical architecture. Even our teen boys enjoyed seeing the interesting architecture of La Pedrera. The tour allows you into three parts of the structure: the roof, the attic, and one apartment (which is furnished to represent what it would have looked like at the time of construction). The roof structures are great for photos.

Amazing Gaudi. La Pedrera is a spectacular architectural feat. Gaudi was briliant in his use of form and line, creating magical fairlytale like formations. the roof is glorious, not only for it's architectural marvel but for the view of Barcelona from above. A must-see on anyone's trip.

Gaudi is Great. Another must see Gaudi creation. This apartment building is simply a work of art. Gaudi's typical inverted parabolic style is masterfully employed and executed. Unfortunately, current restoration prevented full appreciation of the exterior features, but we were still blown away by the architectural and design features of the apartment, attic and rooftop.We went as part of a tour package, so entry was quick. Long lines outside suggest any advance reservation or package that bypasses the lines is worthwhile.

Outstanding. The tour of the Gaudi building is all internal, bar for the roof, which is like nothing I have ever seen before. You will also get to walk completely through one of the apartments and see it in its original state. Unbelievable.

Fantastic Gaudi mansion.... Very crowded, so try and go at an off time. Well worth the visit..interesting to see apts inside w furnishings, which you do not see in Battlo.Great rooftop views.. A bit nerve wracking if you fear heights. Self guided, but that was fine..great gift shop.
Great view from the roof. I visited Casa Batlo just before visiting La Pedrera... it's really amazing, the interior, the details, everything. Loved Gaudi's art
attractive large building. It's a Cool one & its the symbol of Art noveau architecture which is designed by the master GAUDI it has a nice gift shop the interiors are amazing
Beautiful and interesting. We saw Casa Batlo the day before, which I thought was more spectacular than Casa Mila. This apartment block has a good exhibition on Gaudi and lovely views from the roof.

Beautiful inside and excellent view of the city.. If you're going, get there early. The cues get a bit horrible during peak times. I'd recommend first thing, lunch time or late afternoon when everyone goes for a sleep.The view over the city was beautiful, the construction works going on next door were a bit annoying but it can't be helped.

Architectural marvel. Really nice attraction, the terrace is spectacular. It is worth getting the audio guide, as there are no tour guides or much to read once the tour starts.
worth the visit.

Views Vanquish the Vanity. Part of the facade is still covered but once inside you are absorbed by the content and quality of what you see if you are impressed by Gaudi and what he stood for. Vanity springs to mind at some point. The roof top views from this building makes the visit worth while but owning to the number of people visiting it does prove difficult at times to get a clear view from all the advantage points. Once again an online pre book is advisable to avoid the queues but at 16.50 Euros it is worth the visit. Take your time to look at the internal displays as they paint the history potrait.

This is not worth it.. This is the weakest exhibit I have ever scene. It's like someone decided to make an exhibit out of nothing. The roof is nice but the rest of the exhibit is filling space and time. I wouldn't have been that upset if they only charged €5 or so but they're charging €16.50 which is a total rip off.

All Gaudi, all the time. Our hotel was a block away, so we had to visit. Absolutely spectacular, speaking as someone not normally interested in architecture. Make sure you take lots of time on the roof. Don't make this your only Gaudi experience: take in Casa Battlo, Parc Guell, and la Sagrada Familia as well. You won't be sorry you did.

An exceptional evening!. I recently went to a live jazz night which was held on the rooftop of La Pedrera and it was absolutely fantastic! Complimentary cava, excellent live music and the most stunning setting - a must if you're visiting Barcelona!
Just WoW. What a superb building, do not find the wright words to describe what I have seen but just go looking for yourself. You won't be disappointed.

Dont miss. Well worth a look ... Unfortunately wjhen we visite the entire frontage was covered up for restoration ... However the rooftop and particularly the apartment inside was still well worth a look

Disappointed. We turned up to la Pedra after noticing it in an advertisement magazine and recommendations from hotel staff as it was down the road from Casa Batllo we thought we would have a Gaudi day...However, at the moment you can't see the front as it's been covered up due to some form of, what we were told was maintenance work, so that was a total disappointment!It is also rather expensive to go around, €16.50 and from the disappointing outside we didn't bother going in

The roof was the climax. If you are tied for time, I would pick Casa Battlo over Casa Mila. The price of both is about 20EUR but you get to know more about Casa Battlo from the self guide audio. Back to Casa Mila, once you reach the roof, you will be blown away at what's staring at you. It's amazing why no one have replicated what Gaudi did with the rooftop elsewhere.

Intimate night stroll on the corners of the Mila house, the house with out corner.... We got the tickets in advance and it was worthy to do so. Very different tour guided with music and projections that made the tour so magical. The trip on the house ended with a cava cup after enjoying the night view of the city at the terrace. Gaudi's work of art, reflect his imagination in this house, a man who lived in time ahead. Be aware of the timing of the tours, according to the language you want to.

Beautiful Gaudi house. This was a beautiful house to visit. You started at the roof which was really nice with great views and interesting structures. You then tour the attic and then the apartments. It is really nice to see and can do the audio tour which is helpful with all of the explanations. Very recommended.
A Must SEE. Gaudi Gaudi Gaudi at his very best. A must see. Architecture like you've never seen. Buy tickets on line for quick access. Lines can be very long.
Expensive and average. This expensive attraction in Barcelona is not a jaw dropping place unless you really enjoy architecture.

Fascinating- a must-see. I am continually fascinated with Gaudi's architecture. Get your entrance ticket to La Pedrera in advance, otherwise you will have to wait on yet another long line to get in, and allow 1.5 hrs+ to see it all. Also get the audio-guide, which helps to explain everythingand the history behind it.

Disappointed!. Turned up to la Pedra after noticing it in an advertisement magazine- at the moment you can't see the front as it's been covered up due to some form of, what is believed maintenance work, so that was a total disappointment!It's rather expensive to go around, €16.50 and from the disappointing outside we didn't bother going inside but took a trip around the gift shop- next time in Barcelona shall visit and get the full experience.

Amazing building but expensive entrance. It is another unique place and a must see in Barcelona. You can spend hours just on the roof! Book in advance via the internet to avoid the queues. We would have liked to go at night but it was a ridiculous price - about €30 each - it was expensive enough in the day. After the roof, the next most interesting part is the attics. You get to walk though and see all the supporting structures. The apartment is quite interesting but there are too many people going through to really look at everything you want to see.

secret pedrera what a disappointment. we recently visited barcelona and were keen to see La Pedrera as its mentioned in all the guide books. we decided to visit at night booking the "secret pedrera". this was a real disappointment as currently the exterior facade of the building is undergiong a clean up and is therefor covered. Also in the summer it does not get dark till late and therefor the special lighting effects are minimal. The tour inside is limited to the roof and one of the appartments. this tour was rather rushed with minimal information. The roof was the only worthwhile attraction. Not worth the money. No need to book in advance as very few people visited it when we were there.To see Gaudi at his best visit casa batllo or basilica la sagrada famillia !
Ahead of its time. Really different type of building. Amazing roof with unique chimneys. Antonio Gaudi was a genius. Really neat building to tour. The only down side was the exterior was covered up.

Amazing Architecture!. A must-see when you are in Barcelona, this apartment building is a whimsical and beautiful example of Guadi's work. It's hard to believe that people had the privilege of living in this amazing piece of architecture! The tour is worth the time and money, as you can experience different aspects of the beautiful interior. First you walk through an inner courtyard, then go up to the rooftop terrace to see even more amazing sculptural details and terrific views of the city. The attic portion of the tour is an exhibit of Guadi's work, including a model of the building. The last part of the tour leads you through an elegant apartment space staged with period furniture. Unfortunately, during our visit, we were not able to admire the outside facade of the building, as it was wrapped for renovation. Regardless, this was a unique experience and worth the visit.

Dont do the night tour!. We did the night tour. Even though there werent a lot of people on the tour I think I would of preferred the day tour. Some of the areas were closed at night. The elevator to the top can only handle a few people at a time so the rest of us had to walk up 4 flights. Take the elevator. The attic had some areas that were closed off at night so we didnt get to see the models or other things that were probably available during the day. The most interesting thing about casa mila is the roof top. During the night tour only some parts are lit up so you dont get that same wow effect that you would during the day. And the photos dont come out as well during the night because it's not all lit up. DONT do the night tour.

Brilliant. Going to the roof of this building is amazing, did Gaudi see men from mars? We knew a little of what to expect, but this was something else. What a fantastic place. Loved it. Not to be missed.

Unique and worth a visit. Take the 90 minute audio guide around this amazing piece or Gaudi architecture! It is incredible! Your tour takes you up on to the undulating roof space where you have views of the city, into the attic where you have an exhibition of Gaudi's work and then into an apartment which is staged as if it was a family home of a century ago. Fascinating and unbelievable.

Probably one of best places to see in Barcelons. Personally this was the place I loved most in my short visit to this city. The building is impressive and the visit helps you well understand Gaudi's architecture, as well as the time when this took place. We booked though internet in advance and took the audio guide. Both are highly recommended if you want to understand and if you don't want to suffer a huge queue. Also recommend that you go first time in the morning, at 9. Still not excessively crowded.Great visit.
Summer night concert on rooftop. Fabulous and unique venue to listen to a jazz concert during their summer night series and drink some cava!

Incredible!. Loved it! Buy your tickets on-line. It is not cheaper, but you do avoid the line. We were there at around 10 AM, on a Monday, and it was great! When we left at around 12 PM, there was a huge line to get in - so, again, get your tickets on-line :).

Interesting building, go with the self audio guide. We took the nighttime guided tour. It was twice the normal price, but the only way to go at night, which wasn't that much more interesting, as we've been before. The audio guide is fine with the normal visit. This nightime tour is hokey and not worth it. The guide, while sweet, didn't project well enough, her English was not cadenced properly and worst of all, the tour was way overcrowded. There should only be tickets sold for the amount of people that can fit in one room. There was more time spent coordinating the group than learning about the building.

Best thing I've ever visited. Visiting the Pedrera was an amazing experience. Our guides were extremely good at explaining everything and they were also pretty funny. The house is just beautiful, especially the roof. We also went at around 10-11PM and it was beautiful!Anyone should be obliged to visit this house. It's worth it.Not to mention they give you food and drink at the end of the tour! :) They were so nice!

Covered!! :( . I was looking forward to seeing this house but unfortunately it's undergoing renovations and was covered at the time of my visit last week. Be aware that you might not be able to see it if you are going in the next few weeks. I guess I'll have to go back!! :D

Exquisite.. Another masterpiece of Antonio Gaudi located in the heart of Eixample. There's enormous queue to La Pedrera. But they get in quite fast. The trip starts from the small hall and leads right to the roof. Roof offers some very impressive views over Eixample. Than everybody goes down. In the attic there's small exhibitions of Gaudi masterpieces, sketches and buildings models. After the attic, visitors are invited to one of the appartments, that has been converted into museum. The rest of the building is still residential. Better be preapared to spend 2 hours for visitng La Pedrera. Audio guides are also very helpfull.
Rolex watch on the exterior. Got quite disappointed to find the exterior wrapped into a Rolex watch. Prioritize this fantastic Gaudi piece of art when maintenance is completed.

My favorite spot in Barcelona . Spooky and eerie sculpture garden of sorts on the roof of a upscale Barcelona apartment building. Save some time for the museum which is a floor below, learned a lot about Gaudi's philosophy. The apartment itself was the least interesting but still worth a walk through. All in all, must-see.

Beautiful view, Phantom of the Opera eyes. While I have been to Sagadra Familia many times, I'd never been to Casa Mila, but came here with my husband last summer and am so glad we did. It gives you a totally different perspective on Gaudi, who designed this apartment building, and the view from the top is worth the price of admission alone. We made reservations through our hotel. From the outside, the windows look like something from Phantom of the Opera. The roof, with the clay soldiers and mosaic made from broken champagne bottles, offered an amazing view of Barcelona and, since it was near sunset, was the perfect time to visit. Inside the apartment was also interesting, as they explained different inspiration of nature that recur in Gaudi's designs. Since we visited Sagadra Familia afterwards, this was helpful. Nice gift shop. Sorry no photos, but my computer is on the fritz. I had walked by this building the last two visits to Barcelona, so glad I finally made it in.

Jazz on the roof . My husband and I went to a 'Summer Nights' jazz event here. They run them thought the summer on Thursday, Friday and Saturday nights. The concert started at 10:30pm and the cost of the ticket included a glass of fizz. The experience was magical; excellent music in a wonderful setting. I would really recommend going to one of the evening concerts.

Gaudi at his best. We were staying opposite this wonderful Gaudi building and took the time to line up and see inside. As other reviews have stated the roof is as impressive or more so that the inside of the building. The exterior is currently covered for cleaning but this does not distract from the wonderful light filled apartment that is on show, along with the interesting museum that tells you about Gaudi designs. The views from the roof top of Barcelona are wonderful - such a genious to put the laundry area on the roof top!

prepare to be dumbfounded.. A stunningly beautiful structure, even for non-fans of architecture. The roof is the best section! Up there, you will be dumbfounded, in a visually orgasmic way! It's indescribably mind-boggling. The gift shop is above-average, in both its range of gifts and its price points. Oh, just get something to remember this extraordinary building!

Secret Pedrera and Concert - Wow!. We were able to schedule the night tour with a jazz concert on the roof immediately afterward. The night tour was intimate and informative and a nice change from the typical daytime crowds. Enjoying the night concert above sparkling Barcelona (with a glass of cava) was fantastic. This was a splurge but will be a memory we'll cherish forever. Details: We stopped by the Casa Mila Foundation office to pay in person after emailing a bit because the bank transfer suggested would not have been workable. You should know that there are no chairs; we sat on the stone steps around the rooftop. Getting around the rooftop at night could feel a bit scary if you have a fear of heights. Highly recommend.

Stunning roof. It isn't often that the roof is the most impressive part of a building, but both above and below the design and views are fabulous. The only downside of our visit was the current outside cleaning which meant scaffolding and an omega advert. Def worth a visit

La Pedrera at Night. We did a small group tour at night which was the best way to see La Pedrera as we were in a small group and avoided a lot of the daytime crowds. The outside of the building was completely covered in scaffolding though (for cleaning) and will be for about 6 months. The tour guide was very insightful and the information provided was very informative. You get to visit one of the floors of the building, the attic, a courtyard and the roof. The roof was the highlight for us, especially lit up at night.The glass of Cava offered at the end was a nice touch, even if it was only a mouthful rather than a glass.There were quite a few stairs but there is the option of an elevator but it only fits a few people so most are encourage to walk the stairs.
Another great Gaudi masterpiece. Love the view from the rooftop and the unusual architecture.The gift shop always has something that makes a great gift for friends and family.
A little disappointed. Only because the entire outside facade was under construction. But the inside tour was wonderful. The attic was my favorite part. The brick was breathtaking.

A Gaudi-fest. We pre-booked tickets so were able to go straight to the front of the queue. The views from the roof are amazing and the architecture of the roof of the building is unusual. I would have enjoyed it more if we didn't have a downpour which required finding shelter of which there wasn't much! Back into the building, you are taken through Gaudi's life and his buildings. It was wonderful to gain an insight into his thoughts and how they transpired into his buidlings.

Worst Museum, gives this one a miss. I enjoyed this one the least. At 16 € it is way overpriced. Currently the outside is under going restoration, but unsure why they had to cover the whole thing, rather than just one side

Provides great insight into Gaudi. We visited La Pedra after Sagrada Familia and Casa Batilla. The museum in the attic helped to unify our understanding of the work of this true genius.The view from the roof, and the door of the apartment were just icing on the cake.I wouldn't bother taking the kids here. Casa Batilla is much more accessible.

Amazing way to learn about Gaudi!. This house is fun to explore with windy, twisty designs and arches everywhere. There is an awesome view from the center of the ground floor and also from the top. This was a great first stop in Barcelona and glad I didn't miss it! I wish I would have known about the live music performances at night though!

Not worth the hype. I have visited the other Gaudi attractions like the Park Guell and Guell Palace but this one is somehow not worth it's entrace fee. The entrace fees to the Gaudi attractions are not that cheap and usually worth it. Here there is nothing to see except the roof, the rest of the building is just full with some pictures and photographs. I was running twice through the building to see whether I missed something but definitely there was nothing to see!

Beautiful. We booked a night tour and were very glad we did. We got to see a different side to the building not everyone sees. It was wonderfully lit up with great views over the city at night and the house took on a different appearance than during the day. We also had a guide and there were only 30 people so we got a good luck at everything. Highly recommended. It was a shame the facade was covered for renovation when we went.

Fun for photos. We went when the facade was covered and lined up for tickets (about 20minute wait...not too long). The courtyard at the bottom and the rooftop were the parts worth seeing. It's just great fun walking along the rooftop trying to get quirky photos of the quirky chimneys! On the way back down you are led through rooms which are meant to demonstrate the typical Spanish lifestyle of the era in which Casa Mila was built and inhabited. Not as interesting. As a sidenote, the gift shop has a good selection of English books regarding the history of Spain, Barcelona, etc, which I was really craving (and struggling to find elsewhere) by this point of my trip!!

Veeery good. On of Gaudis masterpieces of art also. Not good as Sagrada familia but still worthy of admiring. I admire Gaudis sence for details and organic design. Too expensive when I compare it to Sagrada familia but stll my recomenadations

Good but pity about the renovation works. Having read previous reviews we were aware of the outside being hidden by renovation works prior to our visit but decided this was something not to miss. The roof was, as expected, the highlight of the visit where Gaudi's abstract shapes were amazing. The attic showed shapes & form not seen elsewhere although some of the rooms on lower floors were very forgettable. Could have been 5 stars had the outside been visible.

Construction on the facade. Unfortunately, the facade of La Pedrera was being renovated when we visited, so we missed out on one of the most interesting aspects of the building. The roof is the obvious highlight, but the rest of the building was rather forgettable. For your audio tour, opt for the express, as it provides plenty of information and makes the best use of your time.

Worth a visit, but would prefer Casa Batilo if limited on time. I would rate this as 3.5 if I could. It was worth seeing, but compared to other attractions in Barcelona I would say it was "good" not "great"

You cannot miss it!!!. All visitors of Barcelona should visit this marvellous place. It's one of those Gaudi buildings that have much more than architecture. It's magic. It was build for a person with a very biased ethics. Gaudi's response was a severe, stone made, all rounded forms and very little decoration. But if you climb to the roof, then all the sense of this magnificent building is discovered. You should see it. You'll never forget it.

Another Gaudi masterpiece. It is interesting to contrast this modernismo masterpiece with the austere but beautiful Barcelona pavilion. They both work and are so different. Apparently Gaudi never liked a straight line or a perpendicular corner, but somehow it works. This building is worth visiting. The rooftop chimneys alone are worth a photo op. But tickets online and go early when it is cool.

Don't miss the roof. One of Barcelona's structures built by Antonio Gaudi, Casa Mila, or la Pedrera, is basically an apartment building. The part you get to tour should start with a walk around on the roof with its vents and chimneys looking like some sort of medieval soldiers. Down one level is the attic with many displays. The apartment you get to tour is full of period pieces. Allow about an hour for a good tour.

Really cool work of Gaudi, a must-visit!. A really interesting and completely unique building. It is a bit on the expensive side to get into, but then again so are almost all the attractions in Barcelona. If you decide to miss out on some attractions because of the price, don't let it be this one! The roof terrace is the best part, really interesting architecture and weird chimneys, plus you can enjoy great views over the city. Again pretty crowded, like most places in Barca!

Another Barcelona Must See. This is a very strange building, especially when you realise how long ago it was designed and built. Really worth seeing. The city tour bus stops close by but the queues can be very long. Book tickets on line if you can or get there just as it opens. There is a café right on the corner of the building that is also worth a visit, prices may be slightly high but it is decorated in the same style as the main Pedrera so is part of the experience.

Under Reno but so much to learn - GET THE AUDIOGUIDE. So I bought my tickets online because I hate lining up. I recommend going the day before to pick them up. If not, you can pick them up just before you go and don't have to wait in the ticket line, but if there are other people with reservations you may have to wait a little.We got the audioguide and I can't stress enough how worth it this audio guide is. I can see people being mad that they paid a good chunk of money to go and the exterior is under renovation and then cruising through it. But the audioguide is very informative and we took quite a while to see everything. In fact I totally recommend going here BEFORE going to any other Gaudi places. It prepared us well for all the other places we went (Palau Güell, park Güell & Sagrada Família)

One of a kind. Unfortunately ,you can't see the facade at the moment. The building was very interesting with the unique roof, although my favorite part was the model appartement. Even the ceilings weren't straight.My only dissapointement was the entrance fee: 16 euro was too high.

Favourite Gaudi Experience. This was by far my favourite of all the Gaudi sites. Not only is the building gorgeous but there are exhibits on Gaudi inside the attic area which is really cool. Also, make sure you head up to the roof.

Brilliant. Don't miss this amazing Gaudi creation. Self-guide with headphones is excellent. As well as seeing the outside, courtyards and rooftop you get to walk through an apartment furnished for the era it was built. We loved it & highly recommend.

Worth visit ever. From outside you can't see anything, because it's under renovation. The building is covered with huge billboard covering photo of the building. We were about to go inside, but you have to stay 1-2 hours in the row to by them.

Interesting, but under renovation. We chose La Pedrera over Casa Batlo based on T/A reviews. We did not know beforehand that the building was under construction, so I was quite disappointed not being able to take photo's of the exterior (they have a huge billboard covering the entire building with a photograph of the building on it). We had also been sightseeing and shopping beforehand, so we kept up the entire line of people waiting to enter as we had bought two jamon knives and had some fruit in one of our backpacks. The security guard could not speak English at all and kept pointing towards her screen showing the content of our bags, but would not allow us behind her counter to understand what exactly she was so upset about. In the end we left the knives with her and were allowed to enter with our backpack containing a small bag of cherries. The design of the chimneys entices the imagination, but the amount of fire escapes, construction gates and fencing on the roof does little for an authentic experience. The apartment was probably the most interesting and is what I remember fondly when I think back on the visit. It is built in a circular form and every room is decorated with historical pieces. The walk through the attic is also informative. My kids ( 12 and 14 yrs old) were not too excited about this visit once completed. Entry is 16.50 per adult, 14.50 for under 18's and 8.25 for kids aged 7-12 yrs.

Worth a visit but pricy. This is a review of a not-super-fan-of-architecture. Visited based on the waves of good review. Chose this over Casa Batlio because this costs 5 euros less. There are three areas for visit: (1) rooftop was nice, wasn't spectacular, (2) attic with video exhibition and models on display, was interesting, (3) one home unit showcasing how the house would have looked like in the olden days, was alright. Paid an extra 4 euros for an audio guide. I chose to liten t the long version that lasts 75min (short version takes 20min). To be frank, it was one of the least worthwhile audio guide. Most info could have been learnt online before the visit. The exhibition on the attic floor was quite well explained on itself the audio guide did not add too much value. Being one of Gaudi's famous work that's completed and still in functional use, it is worth a visit if you can spare the 16.5 euros. Otherwise, to see Gaudi's work, you can take advantage of the free entry to Parka Guell after 9:30pm (in summer it's still bright then).

It's on renovation.. The facade of La Pedrera is under renovation, nobody warned us about that so when we got there, it was completely covered with a huge billboard and we couldn't see anything. The shop was open, though, as was the houses itself, but you have to pay 18 Euros to go in, so we decided to skip it and go to Casa Batló instead. The website does mention that there's a restoration going on and that "all activities are compatible with the restoration process", however, it fails to mention that you can't see anything, not a tiny bit of the facade.

awesome and another work of a master. Only able to see the inside and roof top not much as due to restoration but worth it. The Chimney and ventilation shaft is beautiful design which very interesting.

Again master Gaudi!. Beautiful architecture by master Gaudi but unfortunately when wanted to visit it was in renovation and has all the facade covered and couldn't be seen. The interiors are definitely beautiful too, but I think it is too expensive to visit this building seeing that the facade was almost impossible to be seen. There was a lot of tourists that did not entered after seeing the price... so the administrators of the building lose some money in this case. Instead a good price will bring a greater flow of tourist and more money. Sin! Some attractions should pay more attention with the prices that they ask. Free dots for the service!

Amazing roof terrace. We did try to visit here later on in the evening but due to inclement weather were kindly told that, we could go in, but the roof terrace would not be open to view (for obvious reasons). Taking this into consideration and making sure it wasn't going to rain, we visited around 9:00 am and joined (what was) a very small queue. Walking through you enter into a beautiful courtyard that turns and descends downwards - where you queue for the lift, which takes you straight up to the roof terrace. The amazing roof terrace provides a 360 view of the area, lovely view of Mount Tibidabo, Passeig de Gràcia and La Sagrada Familia. The building is structurally stunning, but the apartment (whilst lovely), compared to Casa Batllo seemed a little bland

Terrific displays and videos. An amazingly well done intro to the art and style and living quarters. Everything one needed was here: video footage of the "olden days," layouts and architectural and engineering methods, a tour of the roof and access to a period apartment. Loads of fun and arrivals are scheduled so it's not too crowded at any time. Another great option.

wonderful architecture. The Casa Mila worth the visit, although we didn't have "skip the line" tickets and waited about 45min to enter. The architecture is very interesting, original, it seems a fantesy but it covers a very functional and advanced for the epoque building. Fascinating!

A must!. If you are in Barcelona don’t miss Casa Milá. The building is beautiful, although at our time of visit the outside was covered because of reconstruction works. But even the inside is worth a visit. Gaudi’s architecture, play with forms, shapes and colors is just amazing. You can get to know Gaudi’s artwork and a lot of interesting information about the history of the building. The rooftop is the greatest part. You feel like in a Star Wars movie. Great statues, forms and nice view on the surrounding. Visiting is a must!

Interesting and different. Great, interesting and different architectural design. Lines to enter are long, so it is better to buy tickets online. For me, it is better with audio guide, because I like to hear a story about ideas, meanings and realization of that ideas. Also, building is under construction so it is not so interesting to see it now, because the exterior gives her that special look. Now, what is worth to see is the roof with strange tower heads.

Overpriced & Overhyped. We read a lot of good reviews about this place & that's why visited it during a hop on hop off bus tour of Barcelona. First of all the building was under construction/ repair/ maintenance & the whole exterior was covered up. So we did not see even an inch of the famed facade of Casa Mila Further more just to see the mildly interesting roof with multiple fancy shaped towers & few interior rooms which we found to be pretty ordinary the entrance fees of €16 without any audio guide was far too much. Definitely felt cheated when we exited the building, there are many more better things to do & see in Barcelona which don't cost this much!!!
Expensive to enter. Expensive to enter, but you can see it from outside, it also one of the must see things in Barcelona. PS: Again Gaudi...

Majestic chimneys. Together with Casa Battlo, located just two blocks down, Casa Mila (also called La Pedrera) is an amazing place to admire Gaudi’s unique architectural style. While the interior is less interesting than Casa Batllo, the roof-top alone, characterized by its popular chimneys, makes the visit worthwhile.I would recommend buying tickets online before you go.Visited in April 2010 and June 2011

Must do this in Barcelona. We jumped off the Barcelona Bus Tour and straight into the line nice and early. While I would not normally do this type of thing on my travels, I have to say it was well worth it. The different levels with the different styles made for an interesting visit.The gift shops had some very nice things, a little bit expensive though

Fine Gaudi Work. Unfortunately the outside was under wraps for repair so could not take in its beauty but have seen enough pictures to get the idea. The tour takes you right up to roof top where you can explore the many shapes he created, facinating and nice views. Then you head to attic to explore different exhibits and finish in a recreated apartment. Really enjoyed visit.

Important Architecture. Gaudi's unique architectural style is fascinating, with no straight lines and plant and animal forms. A real strange building with its famous chimneys. and balconies. After the bright sun on the roof, I forgot to remove my sunglasses and fell badly in the dark exhibition room, which shouldn't be missed. I was very bruised as I failed to see the black plinths (plinths and floor covered in black carpet) where the exhibit stands were . Perhaps the lighting has improved. I know the Palacio is well worth visiting, too, but I didn't see it myself. Barcelona has such a lot to offer but you do need to beware of pickpockets.

Don't miss this. Barcelona is all about Gaudi, and visiting Casa Mila (also called La Pedrera) will give you a great idea of his work. One piece of advice: buy your tickets on line before you go to avoid waiting in line. We took teen-agers with us and pre-arranged for a tour guide. It was well worth it. The roof-top alone makes the visit worthwhile! My 13 year old granddaughter commented: "I think Gaudi had a sense of humor".

Gaudi all over!. Take the audioguide, buy tickets prior to visit or arrive early in the morning. The Pedrera is great, the view from the roof is phenomenal, the attic is filled with anything Gaudi did and the appartment helps you imagining living there. The 'free photo' is a scam though!

Where did Gaudi get these ideas!. An incredible building right on Passeig de Gracia. Built in the early 1900s this is Gaudi's masterpiece of urban living quarters. Together with Casa Battlo just two blocks down, you must see the Pedrera and definitely go to the rooftop to enjoy mystical elements of his architecture and the view of Barcelona

Great Architectural Features. It is phenomenal how Gaudi built this building without any of the interior walls being support walls. The brick arches in the attic are wonderful. Audio tour available and I would recommend buying tickets online before you go.
Expensive. The same as house battlo. It's too expensive. I was disappointed by the exaggerated price and didn't enter.

So cool!. I was debating between visiting this house and Casa Batllo, and I'm glad I chose this one. The building truly reflects Gaudi's architectural style on both the exterior and interiors of the building. My favorite part was the top floor, where not only could you get a great view of the city, but the structures at the top are awesome as well. There is a fee, but it's well worth it!

Mind blowing. You can't visit Barcelona without this Gaudi masterpiece , we've been a couple of times and it still takes my breath away . When you go on the roof you think what a master he was you could sit and look for hours and still not take it all in . The shapes are like something from Star Wars !!!!!!!Word of warning best to visit out of season , July and August are mobbed ......

Beautiful. I got there at 6PM to get the last entrance slot. Book online to skip the queue.The inner yard and the roof are amazing. Got there at the magic hour, with the sky clearing up from the clouds and showing a rainbow The inside of the house was uninspiring and I rushed out.

visit to a masterpiece. La Pedrera is expensive but worth it. The view from the roof alone was incredible. You can see all over Barcelona including a great look at Basilica de Sagrada Familia, Gaudi's other masterpiece. The roof is the best part of the building. The tour of rooms is cool but the roof is the best. I tried to book a Tour of the roof at night but sadly it was not running during our 3 days in Barcelona at Christmastime. We got tickets same day which was not an issue. There is a cute little restaurant on the corner which serves hot chocolate and coffee.

Night time marvel. We did a night time tour of La Pedrera which was fantastic. Our guide explained all about Gaudi's thinking and ideas for this his last project, an amazing feat for it's time. We were able to tour one of the apartments as it was when it was lived in. It has a very interesting history and great nighttime views from the rooftop. The chimneys were designed to hold water and are illuminated at night. Champagne was served after the tour. It is close to Las Ramblas.

Excellent place to see more of Gaudi's work, easy location. If you want to learn about Gaudi, this would be your second most-important stop in Barcelona -- after La Sagrada Familia, of course. In contrast to some of the Gaudi sites you can tour, La Pedrera includes a furnished apartment and a little museum that gives a sense for the time in which Gaudi lived and worked, as well as some of his other projects. It is conveniently located on the Passeig de Gracia, and you can tour it in an hour or less. First they send you to the roof, which has those soldiers you see in all the gift shops (look like Lord of the Rings), and wonderful undulating surfaces. Then you descend to a museum in the "attic," where there are lots of displays and audiovisuals -- spend as much or as little time as you like. Then you go down another floor to an apartment that gives an interesting perspective on what it would have been like to live in that building during the early to mid 20th century.There is an elevator that takes you to the roof, and then most visitors descend via the stairs. However, I saw some people going down on the elevator, so if stairs don't work for you, just speak to them at the entrance.

Casa Battlo is the better choice.. We were torn as to which Gaudi house to visit, since they are not inexpensive to vist. As it turned out,Casa Mila was shrouded with safety nets while being repaired or painted. So we went to Casa Batllo. You can go in the lobby of the Casa Mila at no charge and see the atrium. It's worth a one block walk and ten minutes of your time.
stunning. the beauty of this building is just amazing and the furnished apartment gives areal flavour of how it was lived in

Great architecture!. We went here whilst on holiday in Barcelona. We really enjoyed it and thought the architecture was great.If you have any university students with you this is worth mentioning at the ticket desk as you get a discount without needing to present proof of an international student card.Unfortunately the building is currently not viewable from the outside as renovation work is being carried out.During the visit you are able to go up onto the roof top terrace, into the attic museum and then through one of the apartments which has been furnished in traditional decor with lots of furniture and household items.

Interesting but pricey unless really into architecture . Had a nice walk around and found it all very interesting. Despite that not sure it's worth 16.50 + 4 for the audio guide. When there's so much else to spend money on in the city ?40 is a lot for a couple to spend 1.5 hours.

Great European breakfast. During our stay in Barcelona we were very close to La Pedrera and many times we went for their special breakfast in the outside terrace. We had a glass of orange juice, a great cafe latte and a fresh croissant with butter and jam for 6 or 7 Euros, I do not remember exactly. Meanwhile we had the opportunity to enjoy the movement of tourists in Barcelona, the weather which was nice and had a good beginning for our planned tours.The place is clean, the service acceptable and the vibrant spirit of Barcelona and the Gaudi gorgeous building is right besides you.An experience to repeat.

29 on the List? Really?. I can't believe this is #29 on the list of Barceloan attractions. It should be in the top 10 in my opinion. Unfortunately the xterior of the building is not visible at this time due to renovation in progress. The interior is not as beatiful as Casa Batllo, but roof is geat. Also enjoyed the courtyard. Made a mistake of purchasing tickets to a special exhibit next door. It was a photography exhibit and could have been more interesting had I known more about Spanish pop culture and politics in the 70's.

Scaffolding covers the sides in June 2014. We did not realise the lift takes you immediately up to the roof - not a great idea when one of you suffers from vertigo and you have to cross the roof to get to the stairs.. It was an interesting idea, but apart from the roof most of the rest of the building is private and the information we found here is repeated at pretty much every Gaudi attraction in Barcelona. The outside is covered up at present for maintenance work, so probably not the ideal time to visit..

Gaudi's Architecture. This trip to Barcelona we decided to follow Gaudi's trail, not only La Sagrada Familia. And we visited his houses, but only outside, lines were too long to go inside and it started to rain while we waited.From the outside they looked great and like the rest of his work, very strange!!!!!!

Unbelievable!!!!!!. Thank God there was a time that rich people gave serious money to artist like Gaudi to "create" their houses! Unbelievable building, each corner is an art declaration!!! U must to visit it! And don't forget the roof!!!!!

Incredible compound of architecture and art. La Pedrera is must see in Barcelona, without it you can't really feel Gaudi. It's incredibly compound of architecture and art, especially visible in use of colors of ceramic tiles from ground floor untill the top of the building. It's expensive but absolutely worth it!

not the best gaudi visit.... amazing place, but if you want exceptional gaudi... casa batllo and the guell park will offer more "wow"... huge fans & architecture students; this is a must... for us casual vacationers... it's a maybe... the roof top views are almost worth the price of admission on a crystal clear day like we had... the guts of the place... ah... so-so
The roof alone is worth the visit. While the interior is less interesting than Casa Batllo, the roof and interior exhibits make it just as great a place to visit

Wow!. A most interesting place to visit with the added bonus of great views across the city. Marvel at the fantastic chimneys. Gaudi's apartment is a lovely step back in time. Even the gift shop is great and the coffee shop is a great place to sit and watch the World go by as you enjoy the great cakes and pastries.

We enjoyed this home.... Before I visited Barcelona I knew nothing about Gaudi and his architectural genius. Our first stop in Barcelona was Casa Mila... I learnt so much about how Gaudi thought about his designs at this museum/home that I was inspired and excited to visit the other Gaudi masterpieces you will find everywhere in Catalonia..
Glad we did this first!

Visit this Gaudi masterpiece first!. I visited 4 Gaudi locations during my visit... Casa Batlló, La Sagrada Familia, Palau Güell and La Pedrera. One was more ridiculous then the other but the one thing I did realize after visiting all of them is that I wish I did it in a different order. I visited La Pedrera last and should have visited it first. The audio tour had the most comprehensive information on Gaudi's life and his entire life's work. The museum gives you a full overview which would have been helpful to learn before visiting everything else. Between all of the models and photos, you really get a nice perspective. The apartment was gorgeous and the rooftop with the views of La Sagrada Familia was amazing. Buy the ticket is advance with the audio tour.

A great rooftop. The roof top is delightful, but the furnishings in the apartment are not Gaudi-esque. They’re nice and interesting, but more like what one might find in a fine home in the late 1800s or early 1900s. There was a long line there when we went by the first time, but later the line was gone and we went right in.

Very expensive for what it is.. The venue is good but not worth the entry price.If you are a mega Gaudi fan the it may be worth it to you but if you are considering a visit out of interest then I would not recommend going.

Pretty good. I thought palace Guell was better, but I'm still glad I saw this one. Best: the top floor is like being inside a whale. There are video presentations showing 12 of his buildings, so I got to see interiors of some private Guadi buildings. However, one must stand to look, and the audio guide might be helpful(I didn't rent it). There are also touchable models of many items, for the sight impaired. It was a little disappointing not to see more of the building. One can glimpse the main entry, and see one living floor(apartment rented to 1 family) plus attic area and roof. You can't see main area mila family would have used. Waited only 10 min in line on a Friday afternoon in June. The block has several amazing buildings , and view from roof is indeed great.

Don't miss it!. Awesome house! We all enjoyed the roof top, museum and apartment visit. We learned five families still live there.The design is just so "out of the box" that I hope it inspired my Minecraft-loving kids to be even more creative.The gift store had very unique items.We felt the admission price was a little expensive for our family of 6 and it prevented us from visiting other historical houses, as we felt we had spent enough on such things.

Worth a visit. I would favour La Pedrera vs. Casa Batlo. It's worth visiting La Pedrara for the roof top and the attic is quite impresive as well as the appartment which was much biiger than expected. Yes, shame the front is covered but well worth visiting inside. Book online to avoid the crowd as although you need to exchange your confirmation for tickets there, you do not need to queue to get in. I say about an hour for the visit.

Another Gaudi Masterpiece. We, too, were disappointed that the building exterior was under renovation, but I understand these things happen. The interior was wonderful and magical...what a FANTASTIC apartment that would have been for my husband and I, wow! It was crowded but the best part of the exhibit was the display that discussed nature's influence on Gaudi construction; before us, in a glass case, was a skeleton of a python. Above us, those same exact dimensions "ribbed" the Attic space. It was incredible to see how much nature inspired his work. This was a moving piece of our day.Another "don't miss" attraction in Barcelona.

Sympathic visit. You can spend 1 hour visiting la pedrera, nice house and representation of Gaudi's spirit in the centre of Barcelona. Unfortunately the outside is hidden because of work on the frontage

amazing gaudi architecture. loved it! Wish they had had one of those video enhancement things for my 4 year old. And I thought the picture they sell you was ridiculously overpriced (they always are, I guess)

So Disappointing. This was one of the sites in Barcelona that is most expensive to visit, and was our most disappointing to visit. The exterior is shrouded in netting due to repairs so you are unable to see the exterior at all. Inside, you only get to visit a few rooms on one floor. What about the rest of the house? It's a huge home, so there must be more to see? Not worth it at all.

Great roof top, shame the front of the building is covered. We almost missed this building as it was obscured by big covers for restoration. The roof top garden is certainly surreal and well worth a look and there is an interesting courtyard. As it is an actual residential building, it has less of the magical feel to it compared with the Casa Batllo nearby and therefore I'm not sure it is worth the quite steep entrance fee. I'm sure when it is restored to it's full glory it will be amazing.

Best Rooftop & View. In my opinion, Batllo's interior (and exterior for that mater) is more interesting but Casa Mila has the best rooftop and views of the Gaudi apartments. The major letdown of our visit - - the facade is being restored, and is completely covered with large advertisements, so you literally can't see any of the exterior (as of June 2014).

Never been a place remotely like this!. Book on line, avoid lines at the place. Yes, it is under remodeling, but it's still a knockout. The roof alone is spectacular. Hard to believe that this was finished a hundred years ago. Next time, we'll do the night tour. Our 10 year- old grandson was impressed.

A very special tour. A very special tour..What was supposed to be the best night out of our holiday turned out to be a big disappointment..One year ago we went to Barcelona. After our visit we decided to go again the next year, and this time to the special night opening to casa Mila. After all, Gaudi brought us here so we couldnt miss La Pedrera! We were looking forward to see this! Special holograms, small groups, and a glass of cava. A complete night out! It costs a lot more than the normal tour, but hey, with all the extras it must be worth it! And this is a one time experience, so lets go for it.When we went to get the tickets there was a very nice woman who helpt us buy the tickets. We were really looking forward to this special night out!Friday we went to 'The Secret Pedrera' at night. The things the guide was telling were really interesting. The building is very beautiful, the inside was even more spectacular than the outside! We took nice pictures and saw the building. Still we have a bad feeling about this tour. The whole time i was feeling I was in a hurry to see everything. There was a big group of people (+/- 30) who wanted to see everything. When I think of a small group this is not what I imagined. I couldn't see what the woman was talking about half of the time and the guide was constantly getting people who were left behind. This caused there to be less time for her telling stories.The guide also was constantly rushing us thought the building. Why If I pay half, I get to stay as long as I want, and with this "special night" I'm getting rushed?The special holograms (the s at the end means more than one) were not really visible because of the large group. Also I only saw one..? Another disappointment.Then when we came down from the roof, after being rushed around the statues on top of the roof, we went to get our glass of cava. But first I wanted to tell my experiences to the woman who helped us buy the tickets. I went to her to tell the way I felt, because I had the feeling she really cared about this building and the tour. After I told my story i went down to my girlfriend to drink the glass of cava at the end of our visit, like it was written in the flyer. My girlfriend than told me she had to drink a juice because there was no more cava. I couldn't believe it. When I went to get something to drink the men told me that there was no more. I was shocked.. Are you out of cava, is the group so big that they drank it all? What do you mean, there is no more??What was supposed to be the best night out of our holiday was a big disappointment. The things that were promised in the brochure weren't there. Not even the easiest promise, a glass of cava. I feel mislead and I feel I have paid way to much for this all. After all, all of things I paid extra for weren't there. No small groups, no hologramS, no glass of cava and as a bonus a bad night.Before I would have told everybody to go to La Pedrera, in fact, we did. Now we won't do it, we'll send them somewhere else..
Interesting. Apartment building designed by Gaudi, presented like a museum with furnished rooms. Interesting to explore. Quite busy.
The Night Tour was wonderful!. The Night tour group had the Casa Mila to ourselves, no crowds. The tour was very informative and the views of the roof at night are just incredible!
impressive gaudi. we went in as part of a private tour so we had some very good insight to the history etc of the building & gaudi. also could not see the exterior due to renovations.

Gaudi's building from a fairy tale. Another Gaudi's masterpiece- a modernist building, situated on Passeig de Gracia street- metro Diagonal. It was built for Mila couple, who occupied one of the flats in the house, and other flats they rented out.While visiting the building it's better to take the audio guide that will guide you through the building. The first and the most beautiful point is the roof- worth of seeing, with a picturesque view on Barcelona city. The other point is the attic where the history of that house construction will be shown. And the third- the flat itself- is an example of those times housekeeping.Very interesting and beautiful building.

Neat but probably wouldn't go again. We did the Secrets of the Pedrera tour one evening while in Barcelona.
