It was neat to see the house and how the apartments work but the hallways are small to be with a group of people all trying to see the same thing at once. Also, it is VERY hot and stuffy. It seemed a bit long and drawn out without much interesting information.We went to Casa Batlo the next day and preferred seeing that house and at our own pace with the recorded tour. We also liked how we could go whenever we wanted throughout the day rather than a set time like the Secrets of the Pedrera tour. If you want to see a Gaudi house, I would recommend skipping this one and seeing the Casa Batlo instead. All in all, somewhat interesting but wouldn't do it again.

Covered up. Did not have time to go in but was disappointed to find it covered up whilst some work takes place therefore no photos .so do not make special effort unless you also want to go in ...ok if you are on hop on hop off bus as you can hop off as the Gaudi Casa Battlo is across the road and that is not covered up and will give you fabulous photos

Great place to visit. This house is really worth a visit with excellent displays, the apartment of the day is very interesting with some surprising designs of the day, the rooftop has excellent views & chimneys like no others!!! Get there early & you can avoid what probably is a busy place later in the day.

visit before Casa Batllo and Parc Guell. We went after visiting both Casa Batllo and Parc Guell but the full audio guide gives a lot of detail, even about other works by Gaudi, and was definitely worth the extra cost. Would have loved to see the facade but it is covered due to restoration works at the moment.
Amazing. A master piece of architecture and design, with all the curvy edges making a nice living space. The museum is also great and you got to know a lot about Gaudi.

You can get "Gaudi-ed out" - make sure you do Seguada Familia first. I thought that this was quite expensive. 14 Euros and no reduction for seniors. There are 3 elements. The roof, the loft and an apartment. The roof is just what you expect from the photos. Wavy lines and whacky chimneys. The lost is interesting if you are unfamiliar with Gaudi's work. It explains his interest in natural shapes and how he tried to incorporate them in his work. The apartment gives a glimpse of life at that time - 2 coal bunkers in the kitchen for example. I would not have been sorry to miss this if I was short of time, so long as I had been to Seguada Familia first.

Very interesting peak into 1920ish. Beautiful exterior architecture and roof top. The apartment allows you to peer into the way a wealthy family lived in 1920ishs. We purchased tickets on site, after standing in line for about 30 minutes, We arrived about 30 minutes in advance of opening time and there were about 50 people ahead of us. We spent about 90 minutes seeing the rooftop and the apartment.

Very surreal experience but worth doing. La Pedrera means "quarry" in English and when you get there, you'll know why! A very strange apartment block by anyone's standards, don't expect to have seen anything like it before but after a few days in Barcelona, you'll be getting used to it! Worth visiting, not too expensive by Barcelona standards and the audio guide is worth paying the few extra Euros too, you learn so much more and get more from your experience there aswell. Busy, but not horrendous like La Sagrada Familia (although a must do) and on a clear sunny day, you'll get some brilliant photos on the roof terrace, not just of the strange statues there but also of the city itself.

Stunning apartments. The most surreal rooftop you will ever visit. I can't begin to imagine what it must have been like to live in one of the apartments in this building and have this as your rooftop garden. No doubt most residents felt like they were constantly tripping! You also get to see the attic and one of the apartments which are also worth a look. its a little overpriced for the time you spend there (and definitely don't do the twice the price evening tour) but you'll kick yourself if you don't go.Better than Batllo which is prettier on the outside but has none of the random rooftop sights.

Amazing. I had researched all attractions before arriving in Barcelona and was most wary of the reported long line ups for entrance. For this reason we arrived at la pedrera about 8.45 on Saturday morning and had breakfast (nice but a bit expensive) at the cafe out the front on Paasieg de Graccia. We bought our tickets about 9.10 am. No line at all. It was perfect, we shared this amazing apartment block with probably only 50 others at this time. Highly recommend an early start to this attraction.

Outstanding. You are taken into the world of the unique ..both of the houses are worth the visit .they are within a couple of blocks of each other ..get your tickets in the morning and then return in the afternoon ..light is better

Gaudi Lovers Will Like It, But.... Since the rest of our day was booked, we decided to see one more Guadi building. Too bad the exterior is covered. I wonder why the covering is not a picture of what is behind it so at least you can get the idea that the Guadi building is there. We got there just as the night tour started. The tour guide did a good job of explaining the history of the building and some of the changes. Hard to believe that 3 of the apartments are still being rented. They say after this generation of renters, all will be empty and the whole place made a museum. I think that is a good idea. They offer you the lift or you can climb the 6 flights of stairs to the top floor where they have set up some of the apartments back when the place was built. Obviously for the well to do folks. Next you take stairs to attic which is very large with some good history. Since it was the night tour some of the areas I the attic had the lights off so we couldn't see those areas. I think they should have allowed it. We the went to the roof which is a great sight to see, especially at night. They did have a small light show on one of the towers but it was less interesting than the other views from the roof. Down at the bottom, they had a small dessert and glass of champagne. With only 3 units occupied, I think that more could be seen? This place does not have the same flair as Casa Batllo so I would chose that one if given a choice. But I think they could make it as good if they change a few things about the tours. Day or night, if you like Guadi, you will still like looking around.

Unique building - worth seeing. Typical of Guadi, this is a very unique building. you can see that from the street but it's worth checking out the inside, as well as going up to the roof. I didn't get to go to any of the performances there, but I've heard it's a lovely venue. If you're into the funky architecture, you should definitely check it out.

Do not do the nighttime tour. I purchased a ticket for the nighttime tour and it was not worth the money. Our guide did not speak very good English and the tour was slow and drawn out.The only good park about it was being on the rooftop at night, there were some beautiful views! If you have extra time give Casa Mila a visit, otherwise I'd skip it altogether if you are tight on time.

Evening tour. We did the evening tour of La Pedrera. Mainly because it wasn't that much more expensive than queueing during the daytime and we thought it would be less crowded. It was definitely worth it. If you're a Gaudi fan (and it is possible to be over 'Gaudi-ed' in Barcelona) this is a must. The exterior facade is currently being renovated but that doesn't detract from the stunning interior. The courtyard is beautifully painted and upstairs there is a lovely apartment to see which is in original condition. The views from the roof are incredible at night too. Two things to remember if you do this evening tour, first is that you have to go up four floors to see the apartment and then more stairs up to the roof. There is a lift, but getting into it can be a bit of a scramble. And the second, once on the roof, it's floodlit with lamps that are placed low to the ground. These can be rather dazzling and there are lots of steps it would be easy to miss. The glass of cava at the end was nice. If you're planning to eat after your visit, don't forget to check what time your chosen restaurant closes

What a creation!. We took an entire day to enjoy a Gaudi day and La Pedrera was a stop we thoroughly enjoyed also. Gaudi was an amazing person and his creativity comes to life in this building. It is beyond ones imagination to see this skilled man and see how he creates such beauty and use in buildings. This is another must see in my opinion!

Beautiful Architecture. The line to this attraction moved quickly & we opted for the listening devices which played information in your choice of languages about the architect & history of Casa Mila. Great photo ops from the roof!

Very special evening at this venue. We really enjoyed a performance by DeuDeVeu, an acappella group who sang everything from Coldplay's Viva la Vida to Jason Mraz I'm Yours, and some lovely Spanish numbers in between. It was a lovely way to see the building, and I would highly recommend it if there is a performance at the venue. I understand that there are regular evening performances on the roof too.

The last apartment Gaudi built. If you like architecture, then this is a must-see in Barcelona. Casa Mila is the last apartment Gaudi designed before he passed away. This is known as the quarry because it looks like one. The exterior right now is under renovation so you cant really see it, but inside, its a masterpiece. Quite pricey for the entrance fee, but it is worth it. Gaudi loves nature and thought that it is perfect, so all of his designs were inspired by nature. He also doesnt like replicating, so even the columns of the building are unique from each other. From the rooms to the walls, to the columns to the attic of the apartment, Gaudi's true genius is clearly shown.

Great tour of the inside of the apt and rooftop. We just loved this tour, rooftop was great to see but I really enjoyed the apt, beautiful design and we were just so glad we saw it, I think its a must in Barcelona.

Visit Casa Batllo instead. Right now--May-June 2014--the exterior of the building is being renovated and is under wraps, so you can't see it. Visiting the interior is expensive (16.5 euros) and like some other reviewers, I found it less interesting than Casa Batllo (which is also expensive, but worth it).

Very cool gaudi.. This building is about a 15 min walk north of placa catulunya along passieg de gracia street. That street is a big shopping street. It's pricey at 16.50 but neat. Courtyard was cool but the real deal is the rooftop. Such interesting and imaginative structures. I agree with others go Imon a sunny day. I think this is better to see inside vs batlo. But you can pass batlo en route and see the outside of it

Worth the time, but prebook. Like everything else in Barcelona, La Pedrera is expensive, the lines can be long, and you will most likely be given an entry time during the busy season. You can book online and save the wait and avoid the line.That said, this is (next to Sagrada Família), one of Gaudi's truly fascinating works. The rooftop alone is worth the price of admission. The museum is a little boring unless you are a true Gaudi fan. The apartments are either equally as interesting, or equally as boring. Again, depends upon your level of appreciation for Gaudi.In you have read my other reviews of Barcelona, you may be getting the impression that unless you are a true Gaudi aficionado, Barcelona will leave you a bit underwhelmed. That is true. If you couldn't care less about Gaudi, make Barcelona a day trip and check it off your bucket list.

See This- But Don't Go On Rainy Day. We had difficulty finding this building because our guide books called it, "Casa Mila" Every local we asked said they had no idea what we were looking for and we walked past it because the the outside was obscured by scaffolding and fabric. So- if you are lost- be sure to ask locals for "La Pedrera" The line was short and everyone commented about having a hard time finding the building. We enjoyed being inside and seeing Gaudi's creation as well as scale models, plans, drawings, photos, and videos. It gave us insight into the fundamental aspects of his architecture. Unfortunately the roof was closed because it was a rainy day. We could catch a glimpse through a few windows but would have loved to be out there exploring it. We were told that the roof wasn't open, but it was our only chance to see the building.

Very overrated compared to other Gaudi buildings. I must admit that i've been very disappointed by La Pedrera. OK, the entire building was covered in scaffoldings and tarps (May 2014), but I was still looking forward to what is being announced as one of Gaudi's Masterpieces. At the end of the day, you access coutryards, the roof, the attic with its Gaudi Museum and an appartment done up "as it was" in the 1920. At the end of the day, you don't have access to most of the building, and it's rather disappointing.Even more so when, even though you've booked your ticket in advance for opening time, you still have to queue to get in, pay extra to get an audioguide, and then wait for the lift that will take you to the rooftop...If you're lucky, you'll have to wait for 10 minutes as the lift only carries 9 people, but if you're stuck behind a coachload of American seniors, you could be there for 25 minutes.Once on the fabulous rooftops and its famous chimneys, you'll have to find a way to avoid having tourists in the way if you want to take pictures.Fortunately, things improve when you go one level down to the attic, mostly because most of the tourists don't really care about the Gaudi Museum. This is probably the most interesting part of the visit.And then you get to the 1920s appartment, which once again, is very disappointing if you're there to see some Gaudi architecture.There is another courtyard and a temporary exhibit area with some interesting features, but to be frank, better spend your time and money at Casa Batllo or Palau Guell.

A Barcelona icon not to be missed. La Padrera was one of the Gaudi masterpieces we were interested in seeing on our recent trip to Barcelona. It was definitely worth seeing. The outside of the building was hidden by scaffolding and fabric when we visited in late May 2014, but there was plenty to see inside and on top. Amazing rooftop and some very interesting rooms to visit with unique artifacts.We arrived late in the afternoon and the ticket queue was quite short. The entrance fee was quite reasonable but had to be paid in cash.

If you have to choose one Gaudi location.... ...choose this one. In my opinion, this is the better value of the privately-owned and prohibitively priced Gaudi homes. This simply has more bang (square-footage) for the buck, and the price is less than many of the other locations (i.e. casa batilo). The roof is impressive and the apartment you get to tour is a chance to immerse yourself in the life of people who might have lived in the building during Gaudi's lifetime.
Awesome!. This is definitely worth seeing. yes, it was unfortunate to have the scaffolding but I was not disappointed. Gaudi was not only ahead of his time but he was very creative.

Rooftop Splendour!. Short queues here but could buy tickets online - NB only cash accepted at ticket kiosk, could be annoying if you have queued and then need to go and find euros.The roof is amazing - get the lift up and then work your way down through the museum and the apartment. Views from the roof across the city and the chimneys themselves are very different indeed. Unfortunately the front was covered up for renovation so we didn't get the full effect but it was worth it just for the roof alone
WHAT A ROOFTOP!. Building was covered which was a shame but renovations have to be done sometime. The rooftop was amazing and has great views.
Our favorite part of trip. Most beautiful site we saw in Barcelona. Definitely go! Worth it for views and architecture! Amazing!

A building worth seeing. La Padrera was one of the Gaudi masterpieces we were interesting in visiting on our recent trip to Barcelona and it was definitely worth seeing. They were still working on the outside of the building when we visited in early May 2014, but there was plenty to see inside - and on top. Amazing rooftop and some very interesting rooms to visit with unique artifacts.

Not as good as Casa Batllo. This attraction is currently covered in scaffolding and the audio guide is not included I the entrance fee. The attraction lacks the interest of the other Guadi house, if you only see one of the go and see Casa batllo. That said the roof is notable, but the rest is dull and the i ternal signing is poor.

Another Gaudi masterpiece. Compared to the fantastical Casa Batllo, Casa Mila is a little more down-to-earth but is still unmistakably Gaudi.Unlike some of the other Gaudi buildings, Casa Mila gives a sense of how the apartments were originally furnished. The roof terrace echoes that of Palacio Guell, undulating wildly, and some of the chimney stacks are reminiscent of Casa Battlo or the art of La Sagrada Familia.There's an interactive exhibition in the attic, describing Gaudi's design process, and referencing many of his other buildings.

worth seeing. with the facade covered for restoration, the inside and roof were definitely interesting, but not as much as Casa Batllo. Our day was dreary and rainy, and rooftop crowded, so maybe not as magical as some of the other reviewers. Still beautiful Gaudi!

Not to miss. If you are a fan of Gaudi architecture this house will not make you disappointed. Although the facade was covered because of construction work the inside is magnificent. You start on the roof, then via the attic down to a flat. Compared with casa Batllo they have less on display and the tour is considerably shorter.
Don't miss this. A walk on the roof is worth the price of admission alone. This house is so typical Gaudi. The visit gives you enormous insight into Gaudi's style and skills as an architect.

Should not be missed when in Barcelona.... Certainly, there are other important structures to be seen, but for sheer fun and insight into the works of Antoni Gaudi, this building has to be seen. Regrettably, the facade is now covered over, but exploring the inside more than makes up for it. Starting with the roof and the surreal turrets, the undulating walkway steps with more artistic structures added, it's a photographer's paradise......Take your time during the visit and take in as much as possible, only to think back later and remember what you might have missed......And, the obligatory gift shop does have some unusual items, just in case......

Absolutely worth the price of admission. Aside from being a welcome escape from the hot afternoon sun, we found this to be a wonderful structure, with plenty of beautiful architectural details, and even more interesting exhibits which showed many of the details and history behind this and other of Gaudí's works of art. Unfortunately, they were renovating the exterior during our visit, so we could not admire that part. But the inside was wonderful.

Romantic Night at Casa Mila. You can enjoy very well at Casa Mila although it is being restored now.We visited there at night. At the first time, we had the gastronomic dinner at the atmospheric restaurant in Casa Mila , where it has the strange and wavy ceiling. After that, we visited inside this building, listening to the explanation by a Japanese guide. They said that the so beautiful tiles used in the pavement on Gracia street were the same one at Casa Mila. We also could enjoy the lovely and powerful installation art inside this building and on the rooftop. And from the rooftop, we could see Temple de la Sagrada Familia etc……, the wonderful night view at Barcelona. As the end of this tour, we tasted the chilled “CAVA”, seeing the lighted up and fantastic Casa Mila from the patio , where the candles were burning.How about visiting in Casa Mila at night , and spending the moment of the romantic night here ?★There is a wooden elevator.

Modernista Masterpiece. This place is amazing, not a straight line in sight.It weaves and undulates and plays with your mind as you make you way through, with the emblematic roof being the icing on the cake.It’s a magical experience picking out every detail of Gaudi’s genius, the light fittings, doorknobs, everything! The strikingly surreal roof plays with your imagination as your picture dragons and the serried ranks of medieval warriors.The attic holds a fascinating exhibition of Gaudi’s work and how the building is constructed.Finally you gety to look around the rooms furnished as they would have been in the Modernista style.Lastly as always there is a shop and café.This is on the must visit list on any trip to Barcelona.

A Gaudi masterpiece!. I must start by saying I was disappointed that the exterior was covered for renovations, but the interior more than made up for it! What can you say about Gaudi - he was a genius.The rooftop is amazing, and unforgettable, and the entire apartment is so much fun! This was a fabulous visit, probably one of my favourites. We avoided the long lines by prebooking online - a must do! Just go!

If Martians come to Earth this stop #1.. Way impressive!!!! The mind of Gaudi was certainly on a diffrent level than that of the normal person. This is the kind of thing someone may have a strange dream about, Gaudi built it. From the supporting structure to the roof everything is a work of art. A must see! Looking at the outside one can not imagine what is behind the restoration veils.( Much like finding the Ecstacy of St. Teresa in Santa Maria della Vittoria in Rome.)
Gaudi, wow... I liked the house, the design of it...gaudi was a genius...his talent was undeniable...loved the champagne glasses at the top of the chimney. A place to see while in Barcelona..

Shame they have covered the outside of the building with a screen.. Building works will be starting to save this house, so they have put a plastic screen around the front of the building, showing a picture of how it should look. Sad I couldn't take original pictures of the house. Bought postcards instead. We had an on line ticket for the night tour 9.30pm inside and up onto the roof. I do recommend you buy your ticket a few weeks ahead online. They are restricted to I think 22 people. The rooms were fascinating our Spanish guide had very good English. It was our American customers who complained they couldn't understand her. The best part was going up to the roof and seeing the view and taking pictures of the various chimneys. The guide gave us plenty of time for this. Then it was downstairs for a glass of champagne and nibbles. Felt very safe walking back down the main road to our hotel. Two ladies by ourselves just make sure your handbags are zipped up and hold them in front of you. During the day as well.

Another Gaudi wonder!. I am in love with Gaudi! Viewing this apartment building was so much fun! Gaudi thought of everything, amazing design, use of color and light. The roof top was an awesome, happy place.

One (of many) Gaudi's masterpieces. Barcelona is full of beautiful architectural lovely buildings, but I think that this one is the best. Very popular, so be prepared to wait in the line for a lot of time, but at least the feeling when you enter the interior is worth it! The roof is a masterpiece, start from there and you won't get disappointed! It is exquisite, so unusual but still a masterpiece.The exterior was covered when I visited (April) and I think it will be for some months covered for renovati, which is a pitty, but still the tour of the interior is a must visit. I think the entrance admission should be cheaper, though, as should many other attractions in Barcelona.

Must see. Were were unlucky that it was being renovated to couldn't see the building from outside, but we went inside. The rooftop is awesome with great views of the city (inc. Sagrada Familia). Absolutely stunning and great place to take pics and selfies.Tip: Make sure you book online and you'll beat the queues. Go to entrance and straight to counter, in front of queuing visitors.
Night tour. Book ahead on line makes things easier.. What a fabulous building from outside but this tour takes you inside and wow. Gaudis brilliance shines...and the roof top statues are amazing

5* Attraction - small mortgage to get in!. Lovely building and lots to see but does it have to cost so much? Be warned that if you go to Barcelona you need a small mortgage to see all the sights which is just such a shame as my lasting impression of this lovely city is 'what a rip off'.Having said that eating out anywhere was so so reasonable!

When Architecture becomes a cake!. Barcelona is certainly full of beauty when it comes to architectural buildings. You get almost lost rambling the city and watching at right, left, in front, but when you pass the main door of LA PEDRERA and start admiring the interior and up to the roof, then is when you feel like being inside a cake!Full of visitors round the year. Avoid summer if you do not like being packed in a visit. In any case it is worthy.
Monumental!!!. Absolutely exquisite, well worth the wait to finally see La Pedrera!!!!We walked up the stairs all the way to the top floor, helps keep you fit!

Reminds me of a Dr Seuss design. This was advertised in a well known tour book as the purest Gaudi interior in town. Further, it was executed at the height of his acclaim and built from the ground up per his vision and engineering skills. I must admit that the architectural style is more than unusual, but its functionality came through clearly. I reversed my opinion and ended up appreciating the creative and novel use of space. That is, if you can get over the cartoonish and somewhat nightmarish facade.  The queue for entry was acceptable, only ten minutes. We got the recorded tour, which was very good. The ride up to the roof might be stressful for some, as its a small elevator and crammed. You start of the roof and walk down thru the attic and the residential apartment, each with rooms and displays which present a complete picture of the structure.

A piece of history that it definately a visit. The exterior is covered and will be for some months for renovation but do not let that detract you from going for a tour of the interior. It is a house that is lived in by the locals but a couple of levels are retained for the tourists to visit. The history is interesting and some of the andecotes are great i.e. the glass bottles after the first night party.It is a nice slower pace that can take you out from the heat and bustle of the big city for a couple of hours.The secret tour at night is a particularly enjoyed experience.

Appreciate the Change in Architectural Design.. La Pedrera-Mila House (Casa Mila) is a place highly recommended to visit. The house was completed in 1910 however the live-style of the owner reflected in the architectural design that Gaudi created for him. Time had changed and much of the functions within the house does not cater to present day needs. Looking back the beauty and the efficiency of the house created by Gaudi is magnificent. Do give the place at least 2-3 hours to study the creation of the architect and his thought behind it.

La Pedrera By Night. I bought tickets to this especially for my husband (and I), a builder and a fan of Gaudi. It was a thrill for him to get to see it with a small group. As an artist I greatly enjoyed seeing the added under water frescoes in the main entry area, although I know Gaudi did not favor such post construction decor. It gives a languid underwater feel to the area at night, is tastefully done and in keeping with the naturalistic style of Gaudi.The lighted roof area of course is the show stopper. Well worth the ticket price for an up close uncrowded view , a glass of cava at the end and a relaxed viewing with a live guide.

La Pedrera by night(The secret Pedrera). I was a little bit tired of hundreds and thousands of tourists around me during the day, so I was pleasantly surprised that this really interesting guided visit was held in such a private and informal atmosphere. In the end of tour everyone got a glass of cava)))

Magic at Night. We took the La Padrera at night tour during our visit to Barcelona and what an absolutely amazing experience it was. It costs slightly more than usual but you avoid the crowd and the play of light and shadows in this seemingly organic building makes it worth every penny. The building is very stylishly decorated and the lighting makes every bend and nook and corner come alive. This was a guided tour and the lady was very well versed and knowledgeable. The best part I would say is the terrace and and entire floor shaped like a whale's rib cage. The light and music show on display is amazing and from the terrace on a clear night, you can see the temple at Tibidabo glowing in a bright yellow light and Barcelona passing by on Gracia road beneath. Truly amazing experience and very highly recommended.

See this First before Casa Batllo. Not so crowded, it's covered the time where there for some renovations, much cheaper and well organized, another brilliant works of Barcelona's famous son, Gaudi, what is this city without him.

Outside covered up. Rooftop spectacular. This was easy to get to and the views from the rooftop amazing...including a cute niche to see the Sagrada. The flat was interesting but not the best of Gaudi.. the lobby is amazing and the walk through the exhibition spaces entrancing

Must see in Barcelona!. Another breathtaking specimen of creativity of Antoni Gaudi. I was here for a second time and unfortunately this time the building was under renovation. Still worth a visit as the museum appartment inside and the roof terrace at the top are absolutely beautiful.

The presentation of this masterful piece of architecture made this one of my favorite places in Barcelona. La Pedrera is more that an architectural feat, it is presented in the time period of its creation, and the true genius of Antoni Gaudi is presented here. We made a walk through several of his creations and this was my favorite.
Disappointing. Unfortunately, the frontage is being either cleaned or restored so not visible which leaves only the roof and the apartment to be seen. I was disappointed.

Another stunning Gaudi's masterpiece. Unusual,stunning architectute,like any other Gaudi's creation.The interior is arranged as an apartment from 1900.There is a nice terrace on the rooftop that offers you beautiful view of the city.
Big queues at entry.

Definitely pre book tickets!. If you enjoy Gaudi's work then Casa Mila is perfect. The building itself was covered due to maintenance, which I was a little disappointed about however, the work and views in the terrace more then made up for it. Amazing unique sculptures and views that go way beyond. I advise pre booking tickets as you jump the queue- there are lots of online companies which issue tickets for unspecified times and dates which is perfect. Loved it!

A must see to undestand Gaudi. We spent 2.5hours with an audioguide to vist this outstanding building. A little bit expensive (19 € with the audioguide). You start the visit on the roof terrace with the strange chimneys designed by Gaudi, then you continue downstairs visiting the Gaudi museum and go down in one flat. It was a sunday and hopefully we didn't make the queue.

interesting to see. well I won't talk about how pedrera is a must seen as it s all said in others reviews. I will just give an advice: go there earlier: at 9am, so you can visit the roof before it became crowded.

A Gaudi Gem. This attractions was very interesting to see Gaudi's style of architecture for an apartment building. The area that we were allowed to go into was fully furnished with period furniture, clothing and other household necessities. You really felt like you were going way back in time to see how other people lived during that period. We really enjoyed this attraction and if you see this, you should not feel compelled to see Casa Batllo. This is a much superior attraction so I would suggest you see Casa Mila and if you have to see all of Gaudi's works in Barcelona, then by all means go.

Definitely worth a look. They were renovating the outside when I went so I can't speak for that, although I have seen pictures and it looked impressive, as you'd expect.The inside was great, the roof is excellent, with good views of the city. There's an interesting section telling you all about Gaudi's inspirations and some information about his other works. There's also an apartment you can walk around which is presented as it would have been at the time and is really interesting.Definitely worth a visit, although it looses a mark from me for being slightly overpriced and more so for having two gift shops and a slightly tasteless (in my opinion) super-imposed staged photograph thing.

You just have to take this visit. this is purely stunning. You can stay for hours & still find little bits of amazing colour, texture & architecture unfold before your eyes. Pure magic & the view from the roof top is brilliant. the museum of the apartment is breathtaking. So beautiful, huge apartment, workmanship just wonderful.

Fascinating sculptures and wonderful views. We liked the many and varied Gaudi sculptures on the roof terrace and the wonderful views over Barcelona. I would also recommend the La Pedrera cafe for a snack - the cappucino coffees are the best I've had (if on the small side).

Took time looking at the drawings and models. We went to the Segrada Familia the day before we visited La Pedrera, and yes, the SF is much more impressive, but we were delighted with the apartment house. And yes, work was being done on the exterior, and yes it costs 16,50€ for a ticket (plus 4€ for the audiophone ) which is around $28-29 US. It was worth it. We pay that amount in NYC to see one of the Museums or homes after all. Buy your tickets on line in advance. We chose 10 on a Sunday morning (opening time) and there were very few people. They send you to the roof first. We walked around it to get a feeling and for the views. Then we went down into the attic. Many people rushed through. It was our favorite part of the building and not just for the arches. There is tons of information on the materials and building techniques--way out there for the early 1900's and a presager of some of the techniques used in the SF. There are comfortable little seats to sit on and several places to listen to the audiophone (which we found indispensable!) we were intrigued by how Gaudi hung his models upside down and tested load bearing, well before computer models. None of the interior walls are load bearing, so this building could meet various family needs. There was even a garage.I enjoyed the apartment portion, my husband less so. It is easy to get caught up in the period pieces but take some time looking at the leaf motifs on the floor tiles, the curves in the door frames, the door knobs, the lighting. This is no dark Victorian era home.Staff was helpful offering elevator help so people did not have to climb as many steps

Like Modern Art.... You can't believe the sculptures are from 100+years ago....the feeling is great when standing on the roof top, enjoying the breeze and admiring the different styles of sculpture. It takes at least one hour to run through the whole building... When u are on the sixth floor looking at the design, try to take a photo from the mirror on the floor.

Steep price for a roof. At the time we visited, the building was entirely covered by scaffolding and tarps, so we could not appreciate the beauty of the facade. We booked online and went first thing in the morning (first inside) and rushed immediately for the roof. We had 15 to 30 minutes to take all our pictures on an (almost) empty roof, which was great. Then, we got back to the beginning and restarted the visit.First thing to know, the booking process is the same than the Sagrada Familia, the Palau Güell or the Parc Güell, you have to book online and choose a precise time frame. There's little chance you'll just walk in and get a ticket for now, plus the queues are long and in the middle of the construction work noise. Next thing to know, for the outrageous price of 16.50€ per person, the audio-guide is not included. You have to pay 4€ more for it. If you're like us and think they are out of their mind, just do the whole tour without watching anything, and when you reach the end, grab one of the audio-guides left by previous visitors. It's not honest, but they started it.Overall impression is quite mixed, the roof is amazingly strange and picturesque, we stayed there for probably an hour in total. So many things to look at. The rest of the visit is disappointing. The recreation of a golden era apartment feels fake and forced and more than anything, uninteresting. You also have to suffer though yet another small museum dedicated to Gaudi, its life and death. I say 'suffer through' because if you did any other Gaudi building before, then you've already seen it. Then, you walk down a gazillion stairs passing by every floor of the house that you can't visit and that's already the end. They force you through not one but two boring and overpriced souvenir shops and off you go.Overall, a deception. Outrageous price for a roof visit.

If you love apartment architecture.... Then you will like this - otherwise it's a bit bland (though the rooftop view, and rooftop architecture, are grand not bland). Yes, Gaudi did some incredible things, but this is nothing compared to his other things (Sagrada; Guell; even Batllo).
Beware currently covered over!. Went here today but unfortunately we didnt realise its covered over undergoing work (see photo) so unless you are planning to go in its not worth going to see!

outrageous decorations, greate views from the roof. You wont see any houses like this in the US. We enjoyed the architecture. We skipped the audio, so might have missed some info. Loved the crazy chimneys on the roof and the views.
It's all about the roof. One of several Gaudi Must see attractions. genius, original. The roof is a masterpiece. Interesting to see the inside as well. Plan to be here for 3hours max.

Architecturally Unique!. Touring La Pedrera, it's hard to believe that it was designed and built more than a century ago. Fortunately, the lines were short the day we visited, and I was able to take a lot of photos. The roof top is amazing.

Too Much € for La Pedrera!. It is €16.50 to visit then there's an additional charge for an audio tour device and then you have to decide on the type of audio device you want--full or highlights! I opted for the highlights device and wasted €4! Not all of the #'s throughout the tour even have highlights! The architecture is "Disneyesque" with frills, curves, textures, etc. The roof affords fabulous views of Barcelona which does not have much of a skyline but is none the less a beautiful city. It's disappointing that there's so much construction going on that it detracts from the appreciation of La Pedrera. You also must pay attention to where you step when you are on the roof because there are "short steps" and you could easily mistake it for a full step and twist your ankle. This is not even "high season" for tourism and Barcelona is not prepared for the crowds. They have so many guides working at these attractions but they trip over themselves instead of providing any assistance to the traveler! I sell real estate and the apartment was interesting but nothing exceptional and could have been staged better. I personally felt ripped off and would recommend you walk on by, take a photo, read about it on the Internet and say you were there! I wish I had!
great creativity!. Everything about it is really fantastic. Gaudi a geniuos, great observer and innovator . You can spend hours there.

Out of the Box Architecture. Fantastic building by Gaudi, still avant guard after a century. The creation should be number one on the a list of places NOT to go to when under the influence of some chemical, since it is so weird by itself. The roof top is amazing, but don't miss taking time visiting the apartment. The apartment exceeds any art neuvo, art deco collection in any museum.
okay. Not sure it is worth the entrance fee. The rooftop is the highlight and it's a wonderful view of Barcelona. Great shots of Sagrada Familia ... bring your super zoom camera lens.
It has to be seen to believe it. One cannot imagine the genius behind such creation, it is unique as with all the Gaudi buildings. His love of nature is reflected in every corner of the building.

Disappointed. I was very excited when we decided to see La Pedrera. But after our visit I walked away disappointed!A few recommendations:Think about how much you really want to see this sight as it will cost you min 16.50 euros.Get your tickets on line to avoid the extremely long line up. However as we found out the ticket we purchased on line, was only a receipt and we still had to get into a smaller line to get the actual ticket.GO EARLY...if you want to take photos, it's almost impossible to take them, without having strangers walking into your photos, lingering tooooo long, people pushing you out of the way and generally everyone wanting the same photo at the same time. PATIENCE is a virtue here as some spaces get a little too crowded.The roof is interesting, the living quarters ordinary. There is so many places you do not have access to, hence this museum is overpriced. Also as of May 2014 the outside is covered with scaffolding. Read reviews and comments and hopefully you will make an informed decision and not be disappointed as we were.

Astonishing!. When we visited La Pedrera unlucky the facade was subjected by the refurbishment.Anyhow the inner part of the building was amazing, specially the roof where one can experience an amazing view over the town.

Very informative. Worth seeing but not as good as the other two Gaudi attractions we visited. I opted for the full length audio guide which was very informative but the attic became very hot by the time we left. Unfortunately the whole of the outside was covered when we visited.

Gaudi overload. We saw this two days after Sagrada Familia. I didn't especially care for the chimney pots on the roof nor the Gaudi exhibit/information. Too much Gaudi for me. I did like the interior courtyards looking up. Exterior facade was undergoing renovations when we were there end of April. They recently starting offering a "hidden" Pedrera which is about double the cost and starts at 20:30 at night.
If your time is limited, skip this. . This is an overrated experience. If your time in Barcelona is limited, skip this. Not worth the wait and price. Casa batllo and casa lleo morero are much better.
Nice house. I could not see the facade because of renovation works but I would love to live in such a house. Every Gaudi's work is amazing. Less corners, more light, great space's decisions.
La Pedrera. We were disappointed, it is too expensive (16.5€), not to mention that the exterior is under construction and completely covered.

Very disappointing. We were very unlucky as the whole building is clad in scaffolding and impossible to see the exterior at all. Not only that the price of the ticket has gone up incredibly since I'd last visited - more than doubled in only around 5 years. Didn't go in this time.

The exterior is far more entertaining than the interior. You can only visit the roof (which is nice), top floor (disappointing "exhibition": no explanation!) and an old styled apartment (boring). Ticket price (€16.50) is too high for what is offered. VIsit Casa Batllo instead (also very high ticket price!).

Make Casa Mila your first stop of Gaudi's work. To understand Gaudi's genius and fully appreciate his other extraordinary projects, spend time in the attic and see examples of the many aspects of nature that inspired him. Do not rush through these displays in the attic. If you are a visual learner, you will have an ah-ha moment as I did and it will all fall into place. Then you will swoon as you see the rest of Casa Mila.Side note: Ask for the longer audio guide. It costs the same as the short one and has extras that you may want to hear.

Outside completely obscured. At the moment the exterior is completely obscured.I can't comment on interior as having done Battlo felt this would be overkill.I do think the tip of seeing a concert here is worth it. The ticket prices for those seemed great value.

Stunning rooftop but ugly fence. A fabulous expression of Gaudi's work, particularly the rooftop where you can wander among the extraordinary shapes of the chimneys and look out over Barcelona. Unfortunately, Gaudi's rooftop artwork is not enhanced by the ugly steel safety fence extending in every direction.We had to queue for 30-40 mins to get tickets but the fully furnished, period apartment and the fabulous attic made the wait worth while. Don't be put off by the current scaffolding on the building exterior, the interior makes up for it!

Secret Pedrera Tour. As noted by a few other reviewers, unfortunately the outside of the building was covered in scaffolding during the time of our visit (April 2014) which was a shame. We booked to do the evening secret Pedrera tour and found this to be a fantastic experience! The group was small so you had lots of room to explore the building and the little touches and stories by the tour guide really added to the occasion. The tour ended with a glass of (very nice!) cava and a few nibbles which was a nice touch. We booked our tickets online, we unfortunately did one of the tour busses the next day which had a voucher for half price entry to the secret tour but did not grudge paying full price for this.Would also recommend visiting the cafe next door afterwards for a few cocktails or a glass of Sangria.
Gotta go roof. Unlike casa battlo the wonderful sculptures cannot be seen ground floor. Its very interesting place to go visit. Amazed by gaudi works
Covered in scaffolding. Unfortunately when we visited (22/04/14) the building was covered in scaffolding! I was so disappointed. We didn't go inside as it was expensive and had a wait of a few hours.

Fantastic! But.... Right now they are cleaning the façade, so you get to see a giant picture of what it looks like. It's open for visiting, though, and there's even a night tour that we missed but has extraordinary reviews.

Nightime tour of La Pedrera. Just come back from a hour and a half tour of La Pedrera by night, the group was around 30 in number but the entire experience was fantastic.The tours are organised by language, and the tour guide was excellent with lots of knowledge, a great sense of humour and happy to answer any questions.You end up with a complimentary glass of Cava, and some fantastic memories and pictures. The rooftop really is something else at night, and the experience is so much better with a smaller group and not hundreds of tourists!The best Guadi experience of Barcelona, even with the exterior facade being restored and covered in scaffolding! You need to prebook, as they were turning people away at the door!
Visit at least one gaudi work. Small place. Interesting architecture. Darth vader-look-alike chimneys is most memorable to me. Has a story to casa mila so can find out when you go.

No reason to spend money there. Barcelona is a very nice city for food , weather , some shopping , and Gaudi ... but let be honest . After you visit La Sagrada Familia , Palacio Guell , and some more Gaudi thing , why would you spend money to visit a roof and an apartment ...absolutely zero interest , a total lost of money .A total scam if you ask me , the only interesting things its outside , not now because they are working on the outside , but in the future , inside ...nothing to see
The place to go if you want to learn about Gaudi. provides an amazing insight into the genius that Gaudi was. Book tickets online and go early in the morning

One of Gaudi's masterpiece. A very beautiful (and strange) place from Gaudi. Very beautiful terrase and information about the influence of gaudi organic structures. The living are is very interesting.

Great roof top, prefer Casa Battlo inside. Casa Mila is well worth a visit, but if you have to choose one of the two, go visit Casa Battlo. The appartment in Casa Mila was ahead of its time, but the roof top is what is remarkable here.

Good for getting more than enough of a feel for Gaudi. La Predrera was the first attraction we visited in Barcelona. It's a Gaudi inspired apartment block. It's crazy. It's quirky. It would not get past planning laws in most country's in 2014! As an attraction it is a lot briefer than it looks as you start on the ground floor, very quickly end up on the mad roof top where you will spend most of your time, then you meander through the typical museum reading info board bit before finally find the apartment section. It's amazing to see into the mind of architect and his creativity, even down to the door handles and coat hooks.But for nearly 17 euros and were out after just over an hour? All I will say it did help me decide on whether I should pay to go inside every other building he had a hand in that I could see. Yes it's good to get a feel for Gaudi and see some quirky stuff but unless you are absolutely enthused by it then go and take pictures of the outside of the others, but don't bother going in. Apart from the Sagrada Familia. Just do a bit of reading on his other attractions on TA and choose one.And don't do this one if it is raining, as the roof would not be that much fun!

Really beautiful and interesting, but expensive. I really liked La Pedrera, it's a really interesting building and the recreated flat helps to imagine what it would have been like to live there at the beginning of the 20th century, but I thought it was really expensive to get in.I recommend booking a ticket online to avoid having to wait in line, especially if you plan to visit during holidays or in summer.

Great design. Although there are some works going on now for restoration, is worth a visit. The roof is very nice and there is a lot of details and a very nice view. The explanations and the audiovisual stuff are very interesting and helpful to understand some of the points of Gaudi´s architectural works. The visit to the bourgeois floor was a pleasant surprise. Still, 16,50 € is somehow too expensive.

Fascinating design experience. We really enjoyed our visit to La Pedrera. It doesn't take very long. You start at the roof which is really the best part. It's like a playground of archways, twists and turns that is quite imaginative and unlike any place else I've ever seen. From there you tour the building which was originally an apartment building. There is one unit set up as it was furnished originally which is very interesting. There is also a floor set up as a Gaudi history museum. Definitely a must see if you visit Barcelona

Gaudi's gem still delights. A must see on the Gaudi trail and in Barcelona's top 10.The outside hidden under scaffolding robbed us of the famous view from the front. There was a long queue, fortunately hidden from the sun. Coach parties arrived regularly. Was it worth it, yes, judging by the amount of photos I took. A self guided tour allowed you to move at your own pace, and once inside the crowds seemed less. the building features many of the stylistic features seen elsewhere, e.g. inspiration from nature, no straight lines and mosaic decorations. It gives you a better understanding of Gaudi and his times. We shared an audio guide which helped enormously.See this before the La Sagrada Família or you might be disappointed.

Amazing views from the rooftop. We didn't have to queue for long for this and felt that it was worth the entry price. The rooftop is just amazing - weird and wonderful architecture and wonderful views of Barcelona. The apartment was interesting and the exhibition gave an insight into the influences behind Gaudi's art.There is a lift, although the floor of the rooftop is very uneven and has steps, so may be difficult for those who are less mobilr.
Beautiful!. We went here at 9 am and there was no queue at all. It is amazing, the only bad thing was that the facade was hidden because of building works!

This was disappointing. I saw a few of the Gaudi sites while spending 4 days in Barca. I found the reviews for la pedrera were hot and cold. In the end I went to see it with my wife and son. We found it interesting but really couldn't see 16,50 euros (times 3) of value in the exhibition. There are a lot of thing to see on the Gaudi trail, and I think I should have gone to see Casa Battlo instead.

Fascinating. Excellent, Very interesting. We have a 6 and an 8 year old and they were fascinated. The museum explains the influence - well laid out and moving images as well as thought-provoking displays. The apartment was worth a look and the rooftop architecture was.......weird and wonderful. Highly recommended and well worth the entrance fee.

Visit it!. This was well worth a visit and the money it costs an entry (€ 16.50 for adults). Get up to the roof terrace and enjoy a magnificent view of Barcelona and the amazing building you are visiting. Floors below contains wind pivoting with the exhibition and additional downstairs visit to a fantastic museum depicting 20th century in the house.
Wonderful. I booked a private night tour of the house. It is a magnificent place and has many wonders... Keep in mind that the house was built in the 1920's otherwise you wouldn't be amazed enough.

Fantastic site. We visited in September 2013 and really enjoyed it - the apartment inside is interesting, but my favourite part was the roof - great views over the city and of course the amazing sculptures. When we walked past the house during the day the queue to get in was huge, so we decided to come back later around 5 pm - the queue was much smaller and we got the evening sunlight when we were on the roof, perfect for photos. Definitely recommended.

Glimpse of 19th century home life in Barcelona. A visit to this Gaudí building included a visit to a family apartment still furnished as it was when it was built. I never get tired of this building. I noticed yesterday as i passed by that its facade is being renovated. So it is not looking its best
Not Our Cup of Tea. Place being refurbished. Full of scaffold and sheets. Could not see the outside at all. Best part was the roof. Felt it was a waste of money compared to the other sites we saw.

The most interesting apartment I've ever been in!. Another masterpiece from Gaudi, this is a famous and distinctive apartment building. You get to go through one of the inner courtyards, up to the roof with those unique chimneys, then down into a reconstructed apartment, which was my personal highlight. It gives you an insight into the life of that era for a wealthy family (even the servant's rooms were a decent size). As other reviewers have said, the building is currently being renovated so the facade is completely covered up, and this really ought to be reflected in the entry fee.

Great night tour. We opted to do the "behind the scenes" tour which meant we were in a group of about 15 people. Best part - you didn't have to fight with hundreds of other tourists like we did at other attractions and you get your own guided tour. This involves seeing the apartments, internal courtyards and stunning views from the roof at night. Be aware that if it's raining you won't be allowed out on the roof so bare this in mind when choosing a night to do this tour. Also as other people have mentioned the outside of the building is currently undergoing work so it is completely covered in sheeting.Would definitely recommend the night tour!

currently under work. Just want to say, the house is currently under renovation-work, therefore outside completely covered by ads and similar. Go there only if you want to enter but not if you want to look from outside: no point!
Gaudi Gaudi Gaudi. If you visit Barcelona, you know you will have to dig in to the life & times of Gaudi. These places are an excellent testimony and a must visit while in Barcelona.

Interesting. Unfortunately the distinctive facade is completely swathed in plastic and scaffolding and cannot be seen. The interior can still be visited, or at least, some of it. The flat that you can visit has been constructed for viewing but is not original as such. It is still quite interesting. The wow factor comes from visiting the roof. This is authentic and quite bizzare unless you have 'got into' Gaudi. It is expensive to visit but you will never see work like this except in Barcelona so it feels obligatory.

must see. Another Gaudi's masterpiece.Visiting La Pedrera , nearby Casa Batillo and inside of Sagrada is something unforgettable.Worth every euro,don't miss a chance to see them.The facade is under construction ,but interior and the roof with the futuristic chimneys are something far beyond imagination.

Wonderful Gaudi - exterior of building under renovation. It is worth knowing that the entrance fee is quite expensive and only allows you onto the roof, which is an architectural delight and into one of the apartments. I preferred Casa Batllo but others in my family preferred La Pedrera (Casa Mila). They are very different buildings. Casa Batllo is a rich person's home whilst La Pedrera is an appartment 'block'. Quite a contrast but the roof of La Pedera is Gaudi at his most excentric with wonderful wavy chimneys and adornnments. When we visited the exterior of La Pedrera was covered in scaffolding and masked from view which was a shame - I know buildings require upkeep and maintenance but I imagine it will be many months before it is on public display again - worth checking progress before you visit.

Beautiful light filled appartments - sooo Gaudi!. This building was so ahead of its time. Light filled and amazing details. The roof is a must see! Make sure you book on line ahead of your visit to avoid the lines and the audio guide is a must. Enjoy.

Wow, just - wow!. Stunning. So worth it. The roof terrace is incredible, kept walking round it. The attic exhibition is great. The apartment is also excellent. Audioguide very good and worth having. Book online, as you don't want to be in that queue. A must visit in barcelona

Nice place, nice experience... but why so expensive ?. The Casa Milà is quite a nice place. The terrace is so beautiful, especially when the sun is coming down. The inside is also nice, but I feel the price is extremely high and not worth the 16 euros... Especially as the building is currently being renovated... Too bad !

Enjoyed the museum element particularly. Compared to the other works of Gaudi, this is more restrained, however the key elements are there and the roof top is particularly enjoyable. The museum brings the place to life and is a good context. We went here before Battlo and found it a great warm up for that building (which is spectacular)

Good Gauldi. An amazing place to visit... I did the secret tour there was only 14 on it and was great fun!!
Go visit where the Mila's once lived and get to the roof top for amazing views of Barca!

Covered up from the outside but still worth the visit. When we visited La Pedrera it was being remodelled or something, so it was covered up from the outside and we could see nothing of the facade. Still, the roof was stunning and the view was spectacular. I enjoyed the apartment and the attic, too. The entrance fee is high, but La Pedrera is not something you see every day, so don't miss it!
what a beauty!. loved the rooftop views! Be sure to see the Sagrada Familia through the arch! the attic was lovely, and the apartment was very interesting.

Don't bother until refurb done. Place being refurbished.... so full of scaffold and sheets, cannot see the outside at all. Raining too so roof closed, so all you could see was the apartment and attic which was like a museum. Not worth the money and would not offer a partial refund. We had booked in the UK

Amazing Gaudi!. They are in the process of remodeling the outside of the building so it is fully covered on the outside. But do not let this deter you from visiting the inside. The architecture, design, workmanship of the house is worth the price. The best part are the beautiful chimneys and the view from the top. A one of a kind. I bought my ticket when I got there and the wait was less than 5 min. It was in early afternoon in March.

Superb. I absolutely love Gaudi and this is an architectural treat if you love buildings and the architect himself. The interior is just as superb as the roof, which takes you through Gaudi's modernisme visions. I was shocked to learn that 3 families can actually afford to live there. The entry price is a little steep but well worth it and the shop also sells some genuine Gaudi souvenirs (not the knock offs). There is a little museum inside which houses some furniture and the original architectural designs of some of Gaudi's most recognisable works - including Sagrada Familia. You get to vista an actual apartment, which is a treat in itself. You start from the top and work your way down. The benefit of this is that you do not have to walk up the stairs! The rooftop offers stunning architecture as well as fantastic cityscapes of inner Barcelona. Well worth a visit!!!!
Fantastic Architecture. Gaudi was a truly unique architect, with incredible vision.La Pedrera is an amazing building.Highly recommended.

Interesting to wander over the roof!. I would say this was a bit on the expensive side for what it is, especially as the outside is covered in scaffolding and a protective wrapper just now (no discount because of the work being done). Luckily it wasn't busy, so no massive queue for the lift. The roof was lovely in the sunshine, with great views. Interesting exhibition in the attic and the apartment.

Creative building, but far overpriced and limited tour. We saw lots of Gaudi sites in our five days and this was my least favorite, due mostly,to the price and also,to the poor design and limitations of the self guided tour. If I came again to Barcelona, I would far prefer a walking tour of Gaudi buildings, the Parque Guell and the Sagrada. All are well,worth the prices and all are inspiring. This Pedrera, in contrast, is an interesting building but one sees very little of it in the tour- the roof, one apartment, and a poorly curated exhibit about the building. The views of the interior atrium are quite nice...Bottom line- put this at the end of your "Gaudi must see" sites.

I didn't used to be a Gaudi fan, now I am. I like architecture and art, but I didn't (and still don't) see much in the drippy, sand-castle outsides of Gaudi's buildings. Touring La Pedrera at my wife's insistence has opened my eyes to the utility and beauty of the inside of Gaudi's buildings.La Pedrera is about an hour's self-guided tour. You start at the roof and work your way down through the attic, to an apartment on one floor, to the lower levels. Exhibits along the way explain some of Gaudi's inspirations and building methods.I just loved the apartment. The organic flow, the light, the organization, the materials, all worked together so well. You can poke around and linger as long as you like.

Completely different. Lovely Gaudi designed apartment block - shame the exterior was under wraps when we went but there were plenty of pics of what it looked ike.A truly interesting flat that went round and was furnished as per the times it was built.

Incredibly creative!. Have been to Barcelona on several occasions but never had the chance to visit La Pedrera... was I missing out on some incredibly creative architecture! This is such beautiful work by Gaudi!!! Don't miss out on the experience to visit La Pedrera on your next Barcelona visit. It really is a most! I recommend going there an hour and a half before sunset and watching the sun come down on the city from the rooftop, or even better, book the night exhibition as well! Stunning views!! Modernism at its best!

Another must see. Absolutly amazing!. Unfortunatly this fabulous building is undergoing some outside restoration but don't let this put you off! We queued for a very short time. We had our bags scanned as a security measure but this was very quick and easy.A lift is taken to the roof top where we spent a long time admiring the views across the city along with the amazing architecture on the top of the building. Take care to watch where you are stepping, it is easy to trip when not looking where you are going! After the roof top you go to visit the attic space, again very interesting in its own right. There is a exhibition of Gaudi work with some beautiful examples. The actual attic space is fabulous in its own right. From the attic you go down to an example of an apartment, very well set out which gets you thinking of life back then....... On this floor is a opportunity to have your photo taken against a green screen and on leaving you can view your picture and decide if you want to purchase. The background is a great view of the house with your picture super imposed on it. We were with a group of friends and we shared the cost of this, only 14 euros for 4 photos in a presentation folder!On the way out is the obligatory gift shop with something for everyone!Well worth the entrance fee and very good value for money, if you visit you will not be disappointed................

Visit near the start of your holiday. I think its true that La Pedrera is probably best as an introduction to the modernist buildings of Barcelona. There's a danger that coming here after Casa Batllo, Sagrada Familia, the Palau de Musica and Casa Lleo Morera that Casa Mila will seem a little plain by comparison. It was a pity that the facade was covered by scaffolding and it was a pity that the grand staircase in the courtyard was blocked with a wooden barrier. I wish that we had booked the evening visit as I think the place would have looked amazing all lit up. The roof is amazing and offers terrific views across the city. The apartment is interesting if a little plain and the museum is interesting too.Its definitely worth a visit but maybe best near the start of your trip and before the other, more colorful sites.

Really beautiful. We booked onto the night exhibition in the Mila house and I would definitely recommend it as it is quite a private experience with just a small group which is a way to avoid the crowds during the day. Included in the price is a visit to the restaurant beforehand which had gorgeous food however the waiters were quite impolite and condescending.

Fantastic. This is all it's cracked-up to be. Amazing. Unfortunately, the building is currently covered in cladding as it's being renovated.The apartment on the top floor is to die for! The roof is fantastic.

amazing recital. Managed to get tickets to a recital here on 16th March, beautiful music, beautiful venue- what a perfect evening. Would definitely recommend having a cava in the cafe before had to soak up the amazing building.
Spectacular view from the roof. A fantastic example of Gaudi's architecture. The audio guide was a must. Plan at least 1.5 hours. It was a treat to get through such a marvel with a minimum of crowds.

Dont go here now. There is some restoration or construction project going on in the facade. So you cant really appreciate the real beauty of this building today. And I dont want to spend less than 20 euros just to see what I can watch in youtube. Will just visit this when the repairs are done and have my photo taken in front. For now, reading about this building and seeing the photos over google will be enough.

Outside and Inside, WOW. The views will take your breath! The history of Gaudi's planning and construction of this building was amazing but you MUST have the audio guide. We spent about 2 hours here and loved every minute of it.

Not to be missed. Best way to understand the architect Gaudi is to visit La Pedrera. Such imagination and creativity. My eyes were unaccustomed to buildings and rooftops without straight lines. What a wonderful surprise to see something so incredibly different.

Simply Gaudi. All i can say about any Gaudi work is stunning, bautiful and amazing. This does not dissapoint. Staff were very friendly as im disabled they couldnt be more helpful in letting me know where all the lifts were, and on way back down one of the staff called us to go down in the lift and not the stairs. The rooftop terrace is just amazing and again the views are amazing. The building as a whole is stunning and beautiful and shows what a master and how talented Gaudi was! Make sure you do on the same day as Casa Bilbao as its on the same street.
Amazing. The building was wrapped in scaffolding, but the interior is a trip. You visit an apartment as well. We didn't buy tix in advance and the line wasn't too long.

Just looking (again). I saw it from the outside which was enough for me. Why waste good money for entry when you get the gist of it from the outside. Maybe I am tight but I didn't think the entry fee was worth it and we were short of time. I don't think my life will be less fulfilled for not going inside.

One key to understanding Barcelona. The tour of this building, especially with the audio guide, was particularly helpful in helping to understand why Barcelona is considered by many to be the world capitol of the cultural and architectural movement called Modernisme in the early 20th c.

really quite amazing. the queue was small (5 - 10 mins). Good audio guide. The rooftop is spectacular and inside there are many models and displays that explain the architecture. It is a must see. Unfortunately, in common with a lot of the sights it is covered on the outside as they are working on it which is a pity. You can easily spend an hour or so there.
Must see. Unfortunately they are cleaning or doing something to the façade and have the exterior covered with "ADVERTISEMENTS" of all things, really horrible. But the interior is always work a visit.

My girlfriend was kept happy.. If you have read my other reviews you will see that there is so much great stuff (sorry for my use of the vernacular) to do in Barcelona. In my humble opinion this wasn't one of them. I found it a fairly expensive exercise to go to the top of a roof and gaze upon some weird looking cement. I know that this will incur hostility amongst the intelligentsia who by now will not be reading this review. Save your money here and go and spend it seeing the Sagrada Familia - now that doesn't disappoint.

Gaudi is Amazing!. The facade of La Pedrera was under renovations but don't let that put you off in visiting. The interior of the building is beautiful! We booked the night tour with an English speaking guide. The tour was very informative and we learnt about Gaudi's vision for La Pedrera as an architect as well as an artist - fascinating. Book your tickets online to beat the queue, with a top of of about EUR $15, you can also enjoy an amazing 3-course dinner at La Pedrera Cafe. Highly recommended!

Mind the steps. The frontage of the building is currently undergoing renovation so the famous facade is not visible - completely shrouded in tarpaulins. The interior is open. The roof is just amazing - I'd seen the pictures but was taken aback by the reality. The roof is much bigger than I had expected and crammed with fabulous structures. However it is on all different levels with two or three steps going up and down every few yards. There are plenty of warning signs. I have eye sight problems and although I was aware that the roof was pretty lethal for me, I did lose concentration while framing a shot, missed one of the steps and have massive bruises to show for it. Entirely my own fault! So do take care. The apartment was a fascinating insight into life at that time.

Lovely apartments and a great rooftop. La Pedrera is one of Gaudi's architectural masterpieces. Located a short walk from his other apartments, Casa Batllo (which in my opinion are the better apartments), the main and most widely publicised features here are located on the rooftop. Roof top vents/chimneys that would ordinarily not be given design thought are treated with the same respect and design time as the apartment interiors. On the interior roof space is an informative exhibition of Gaudi's design work for this apartment complex. If you want to spend sometime on the rooftop taking in the surrounding views, make sure to pack a hat and sunglasses as there is no shading from nearby buildings. To avoid the queues downstairs, you can preorder and print tickets online.

Consider the night visit. A must see site, we tried the night visit this time and loved it! You must buy tickets in advance as only guided visits are available at night. Great views of the city at night.
Impressive. Very interesting how one person had such power and money to have a house built this way. The terrace, where most of the interesting sculptures are, offers beautifil views of the city

Wouldn't bother. The outside is covered with advert as obviously work being done - very disappointing and to be honest with the exception of the roof wasn't that impressed. You only visit 3 areas - the roof which was pretty impressive, the attic museum which I personally found boring after visiting other Gaudi attractions (repetitive) and an apartment in the building which was ok. I wouldn't waste time or money on this one.

Amazing concept of architecture.. A very impressive work by Antonio. the idea of the selfstanding building before fornt and rear wall, is a genius.The apartment-musem worths a visit. a very modular and modern concept. A lesson that every architect should learn when building houses...

Couldn't See the Facade. Was extremely disappointed to arrive at the Pedrera (in late February) and see that it was covered with a giant car advertisement because work to the facade was being done. It really ruined the experience. I'm not sure why construction required them to cover the entire building at once.

Padrera. Really enjoyed the visit here, there was a lot of information about Gaudi, probably better laid out than in a museum.We eecially enjoyed the view from the roof and had a good meal in the restaurant there.

Nice place to visit. It is advised to visit the place before the busy times. The lobby is nice but can be left to the end of the tour.After entering the lobby, go immediately to the elevator at the right end side, to the rooftop, which is the peak of the visit. Then go down slowly to the top floor to see the rooms. The rooftop was spectacular with its curves, towers and chimneys and nice view of barcelona, and of the building from up. Spend at least 1 hour here, and then 1 more hour for the inner building's room. Inside you learn a lot about Gaudi, and appreciate him more and more, for his Genius. Note that the building is covered by a builder's shroud which meant that you could not see the outside architecture.

funky wacky place. great place to enter - start from the top and work yer way down - the terrace is weird wacky place - pity not there to eat n drink esp on lovely sunny day more so towards the evening - lightings inside at night is brilliant!!

Disappointing. When we visited La Pedrera was undergoing some work so the entire facade was obscured by scaffolding and sheeting. The roof was great, however I didn't feel it lived up to Casa Batllo which was outstanding. If you eat at the cafe/restaurant attached don't expect much, the service is good but the portions are minuscule.

Gorgeous rooftop!. The rooftop was my favorite - even with construction it was beautiful and what a nice view of Barcelona as well. Once inside, you learn a lot about the structure of the building and wildly amazing inspirations that led to its design.

Disappointing. Unfortunately the building was covered by a builder's shroud and scaffolding which meant that you could not see the outside architecture. However, it does appear to need some renovation as what we could see of the inside courtyards was in dire need of cleaning and re-painting. Regardless, the roof was quite spectacular with its curves, towers and chimneys and view towards the Sagrada Familia and the main metalled door is an amazing piece of craftsmanship. Also, despite it not being peak tourist season, the place was quite busy and it was hard to see some on the museum displays and the apartment properly. I would hate to be here at peak times. With this and other Gaudi buildings at the Park Guell, I was disappointed and dismayed to a degree with the actual windows / frames that had obviously been fitted during previous renovations as they were too modern and not in keeping with the style and spirit of the buildings. Surely something more fitting could have been crafted ?Overall I was disappinted with this building and felt it was not worth the EUR 16.50 I paid to get inside.
Amazing rooftop. We spent a couple of hours just marvelling at the architecture. Simply breath-taking. Take time to explore it and take loads of pictures.

Was on wife's life list. Casa Milo like all the Gaudi properties was amazing and only surpassed by Casa Batllo! The imagination of this man was other worldly! We were there on a mid-week morning in early October and did not experience any long lines, we had purchased our ticket in advance at the Tourist Bureau in Catalunya Square.
Shrouded in tarpaulin. We did make a bit of a pilgrimage to this block of Gaudi-designed apartments but it was completely hidden behind scaffolding and tarpaulins (this was in late Feb).

On the rooftops. Unfortunately the outside of the building was completely covered in scaffolding for our visit but the rooftops were incredible. We had pre booked our tickets. The system was a little confused but it did save us a massive queue and the staff were happy for us to go in ahead of our allocated time. The views from the roof were fantastic and the thought behind different parts of the design absolute genius. The attic and apartment also very interesting.

Captivating night experience. Don't be put off by the fact that this beautiful building is undergoing external renovation, this doesn't affect this fantastic tour at all. After a hectic day in Barcelona, this gentle tour was a real treat. We took the Viator 'Gaudi's La Pedrera at Night: A-Behind-Closed-Doors Tour' and it was a fantastic experience. After a short introduction from the highly informed guide, under the stars twinkling down on us from above the central well of the building, we and and only a few other visitors were taken round the interior of a home on the upper floors. There is much freedom here and a chance to photograph and see at first hand, how a wealthy family lived inside this extraordinary residence. Visitors are taken upward to the loft, where there are examples of Gaudi's furniture and display cases, featuring some of the inspiration behind his ideas, all explained in detail by the guide. We finally emerged onto the rooftop, where stunning, sculptured chimneys stand. A return to the bottom floor and a glass of cava under the beautiful ceilings concluded the visit. I would highly recommend this tour and urge you not to forget your camera!
