Average. We visited the main Gaudi properties whilst in Barcelona. If there was one to miss it would be this. Not cheap for the limited amount to be seen.
Glad we went.. This is an iconic sight in Barcelona. Unfortunately it is currently covered in scaffolding so you can't see the exterior. However the interior and roof are well worth a visit.
night tour. fun to see it at night and loved getting to be so intimate with the building, going on the room and in many rooms.

Really cool architecture. When we visited La Pedrera, renovation was being carried out. This meant that we weren't able to see the outside of the building, which is a pity. However, we were all awed by the rooftop. The rooftop is absolutely stunning and worth every penny but the weather is very hot even in February. There is one original apartment remaining for you to see inside. Plan your visiting time carefully because it can be very crowded. You may not get the authenticity that you planned for.

Great. When I visited Barcelona last week, they were renovating the outside of La Predrera. Nevertheless, La Predrera was a great visit and worth every euro. The roof was the best part of my experience and I recommend spending a lot of time there. Even if you're not a big fan of architecture you can enjoy Gaudi's work in Barcelona. La Predrera is a must see for everyone.
Amazing!!. Is the perfect place to go and see the decoration by Gaudi!! Is a little bit expensive but you can pay it for what it is!!

Beautiful building but expensive admission - only for true Gaudi enthusiasts. Overall, I would not recommend visiting either of the houses unless you are a true Gaudi fan or are traveling on a generous budget. The Sagrada Familia is equally expensive but gives you the same taste of Gaudi style and, with its breathtaking interior, provides a much more fulfilling experience to the passing tourist with an amateur appreciation of Gaudi's work. During our visit to Barcelona, we did some extensive research about whether Gaudi's two houses (Casa Mila and Casa Batlo) were worth visiting. We decided to visit only Casa Mila because it had a slightly cheaper admission fee and had the beautiful rooftop and might be better for snapping photos. We went in November when there was not much of a line and paid the discounted price (~15 euros, available to students or Hop On Hop Off Bus ticket holders). We did not get the audioguide as it cost extra, but it would have been nice to have some sort of guide explaining about Gaudi's inspiration and specific work on Casa Mila. There's a guard standing in front of the elevator who lets a few people up to the rooftop at a time - it was not crowded at all, so we were able to stay on the rooftop as long as we wanted. It's really stunning and is exactly what you see in photos online, only with some other fellow admirers wandering in the background. The rooms were less impressive, as we were mainly interested in admiring the architecture. We spent about an hour total in Casa Mila, which was ample time to take plenty of photos and see everything.
A Must See. Although the main building and towering atrium are fabulous, the roof top is out of this world and a must see.

Watch out they are renovating the outside. Shame that they were renovating the outside of the building and we could only see the scaffolding... did not stop them charging full price to visit the house and roof. Completely taken aback by Gaudi's work. Just love the detail of the roof and views over the city. Enjoyed looking at the rooms in the house. All preserved to how it was.

La Pedrera. La Pedrera is brilliant. I would recommend it to anyone, the chimneys are brilliantly designed and the view from the top of the building isnt bad either with a view of the Sagrada Familia one side and Montjuic on the other. The price is quite high but its definately worth it.

Amazing site...if you could see it.. The entire facade of La Pedrera is covered in scaffolding and tarps so be prepared that you will not see what you expect. We did pay for the evening tour (in advance) so we saw the inside, the rooftop and capped it off with a nice glass of cava. Don't know how long the renovation will take, (we visited in Feb. 2014) just wanted you to be prepared that it's covered up!

Before going, see if they've completed the facade. We were in Barcelona in mid-February and the entire facade of Casa Mila was under a tarp. That definitely detracted from the experience. Much preferred Casa Battlo, just up the street. It gives a better sense of Gaudi's genius.

If you love Gaudi, you must see this!. We adored this marvelous building with its clean organic lines and sensual shapes. Its difficult to imagine that the same architect designed Sagrada Famila. This house is not to be missed! Best part: the roof! Go at dusk if possible.

Stunning chimney stacks!. EUR16.50 to get in, no audio tour, that was extra. Lift up to the roof area, views are amazing. BEWARE of the steps up and down on the roof. Unusual chiment stacks, but Gaudi didnt do conventional.
Apartment was interesting but very dark.

A house full of surprises. La pedreda is one of the most beautiful architectural works of Gaudí. It was an 16€ entry, because we were students, but it was worth it. All the rooms are forbidden to touch, but they are all opened: the bathrooms, the kitchen, the living room, the terrace ir awesome because you have an awesome view to the city, a panoramic view. And then it as a courtyard inside the building to hangout! It as also an exposition inside, just when you enter the building, about the house, the inicial building, models of the original furniture and everything. It has also those phones to hear the explanation of the visit in several languages. Anyway, you have to visit, it´s like an hour of visiting or more if you are very curious like me! At first i thought it was very expensive, but after i got in, it was totally worth it!
Dont go sice covered in scaffoliding. My family and I went in Feb '14 however we were deeply disappointed as you could see completely none of the building.
Disappointed. La Pedrera was under renovation - the entire front of the building covered up! Did not pay to go in but would have loved to have seen the facade.

LA NISSAN ADVERT. Shame really that they didn't have the full frontage in the cover for the building instead were treated to a huge Nissan advert, I'm sure they are paying a fortune for this ad and hopefully all the money will go towards the restoration Did not detract from the rest of the wonderful Gaudi Tour

Beautiful building. Loved this building, loved the lines, shapes and simplicity of it. Attic and roof are stunning.Almost hard to believe its the same architect from Casa Batlló, Palau Guell and Sagrada Famila. It seems so plain in comparison. It's a shame that you can't see more of it and that what you can see is limited to one flat, the attic,roof space, replica furniture and the gift shop. Good audio guide, but you had to pay extra for it. Could imagine a night time viewing would be magical, especially if you could take in one of their concerts. It felt very commercial in comparison to Palau Guell, mainly as the gift shop was so large compared to what you could see.Can recommend the cafe/restaurant in the bottom of the building too (you can go here without visiting the house and it indicates the style of the house inside).

Stunning rooftop. You could spend an afternoon on the rooftop of La Padera looking out on to the rooftops of Barcelona in the sun and we did just that [we went out of season in Feb] where it was quieter and more relaxed. Not only is the architecture stunning there are countless photo opps to be had. Another must see when in the city.

Magical place. We visited on a cold sunny day and loved strolling on the roof top with its amazing chimneys and water towers. The building is very beautiful. The museum within was fascinating. Well worth a visit and a fabulous example of Gaudi at work.

Amazing!!. La Pedrera is one of the most beautiful places in Barcelona. Thankfully I didn't have to wait a lot to get in and the 8 euro ticket was totally worth it. The terrace gives you some of the greatest views of the city and the museum inside lets you know a little bit more about Gaudi and his work.

As of February 2014 this is effectively closed. Avoid.. La Pedrera is completely covered in scaffolding. Given that its 'quarry' facade is the major draw, it isn't worth walking up to, never mind paying for the expensive tour.

Amazing. The work Gaudi did here was purely amazing. Love how he got inspiration from nature and was able to apply that to pretty much everything in the building. Was also quite surprise how much the kids enjoyed this attraction.
Breathtaking!!. This is a must see, just amazing. We found it best to take the bus that you can get on and off. Plan on spending hours so much to take in. We enjoyed having lunch across the street.

Very special building. Take a walk along the Passeio de Gracia and see the beautiful buildings. La Padrera is something special. This tour inside is also interesting, although a bit expensive. The building is being renovated so the fassade is not be seen.

wrong time to do the tour. we bought our tickets online a few weeks before hand to avoid ques, when we arrived we found the la pedrera covered up with scaffolding and a car advert!! this was a bit of disappointment , but the tour itself was really good and worth doing as long as you can see the front of the building as for me that is the most amazing part!!!

A very unique building. We enjoyed walking around this unique structure. Spent a lot of time on the rooftop and upper levels learning about the history of the building, Gaudi and surrounding neighborhood. Expensive to visit but you are in Barcelona so it is a must do.
under renovation. This was undergoing renovation in feb 2014 when we visited. so you might want to check if they are done , before planning a visit. understand the view from the top floor is amazing.

Not really worth the entrance fee... The outside was being renovated (as at beginning of Feb 2014) so it was a shame we couldn't see it from the outside. The roof is probably the highlight of the visit with some nice views of the city but takes less than 5 minutes to walk around. For 16 euros I wouldn't say it was worth the money.. there are plenty of other Gaudi buildings you can admire (for free) from the outside.

Worth it for the rooftop. The inside is fine but the rooftop is where you'll be blown away. Inside you visit the courtyard and an apartment (kind of interesting but nothing spectacular) and learn some history about Gaudi, but once you get to the roof, you'll forget it all. The sculptures are fascinating and make for great photo backdrops. These are the photos from the trip we're asked most about. It definitely wouldn't be great for someone who has a hard time with stairs as the rooftop requires going up and down sets of stairs over and over as you make your way around. We saw a young adult fall just because some of the stairs catch you by surprise.

Expensive and not worth it. The outside of the building is currently under constuction for the next 1.5 years. The roof is really nice and while the rest is interesting, we were very disappointed especially given the cost.

Beware the facade! . Beautiful and striking, especially the roof. However it's under renovation now and has a giant facade over the front with an advertisement for a car over the top. The roof is work a visit but make sure to go to the design store next door, go up stairs and go out into the terrace! It's beautiful AND you can see the back work of this beautiful building
Too expensive. It may have a great meaning for the Catalan art and architecture and it was interesting, but for a 16,5 Euro the ticket - please.

Took the The Secret Pedrera Tour. Really enjoyed the space and time the taking the nighttime tour afforded me. The building is remarkable, but being on the roof at night really enhances the otherworldly feeling.I took the English tour and the guide spoke very well. Often he would be leading the group "down the hall" or wherever, and either the group was so big and/or I was taking so many pictures, that I missed what he said.The opening videos were pretty corny, but were short and easily dismissed. Definitely would recommend others do the tour.

Remarkable. This is a must, the roof is not like anything I have seen before, Goudie was inspired when he designed this. The building was covered in scaffolding though which I didn't read on their website an that was a bit disappointing but still worth going inside.
Gaudi. Just Gaudi, professional, unique, amazing, beautiful just couple word how i can describe the building. This building is an "another not miss to see".

A Gaudi must-see. This is a fabulous example of Gaudi's work. Once inside you can take an elevator to the roof top and see the chimneys, styled as warriors, as well as lovely views of the city. Then you walk downstairs through a gorgeous attic space that is a sort of gallery and then an apartment decorated as it would have been in Gaudi's time. This was my favourite stop in Barcelona.
Wacky rooftop. You whizz up in the lift and find yourself on the wackiest roof ever, with great views of the city and loadsof ups and downs among the chimney pots

Amazing Gaudi. The guided tour explains a lot of history about this building. Way ahead of its time with the internal design features much of which we take for granted today. Unique art on the roof top disguising vents and stairs! You can appreciate some of Gaudi's inspiration from the exhibits in the old attic/laundry room under the rooftop.

Rooftop Fantasy. Although it is on the expensive side to get in, and the interior is not as interesting as some of Gaudi's other houses, the rooftop is a wonder to behold. The flowing lines and statues make it quite a romentic location.

Interesting. Have not given a higher score because of some reservations, If you are really keen and prepared to pay the quite high entrance price you will find this a great experience particularly the roof visit. However if you are on a budget and just want to have a look at the outside be warned that it is being renovated and is scaffolded and covered. If you cross the road to the opposite corner you do get great views of the sky line.

Liked it on the outside. Book the tickets online! Otherwise, you will waste your time in line. We had no line at all for online booking. Its really cool on the outside, but not that interesting inside. Just the tour about how it was build etc

Love Gaudi. Every single site with Gaudi signature is worth to visit. I would suggest get all your tickets online so you avoid the wait, make sure you print them and you will not have to queue, this is good to keep in mind for La Sagrada Familia and Casa Batllo. It work great for me, not even one minute of wait!

Great Gaudi Building. Took the night tour of Casa Mila and found it very interesting how people lived in the building throughout the years, and that people still live in the building. Cava and dessert at the end of the tour was nice. I think I would prefer to go during the day and explore at own speed as the night tour was just a little rushed and was busy with the whole group in the same areas at one time. Also preferred Casa Batllo, but if you visit Barcelona I still recommend very much to visit. Great Architecture and history.

architecture. amazing architecture of what we could see of it. sadly work was going on so scaffolding covered the front hence the average score. would love to return and see this properly. theres a fee to get inside, we didnt bother becasue of not being able to see the outside but other gaudi buildings are amazing so feel this would be worth it!!
Worth the view from the roof. The rooftop is fantastic with it's fun pillars and amazing architecture. The courtyard is also fun too.

Interesting. We saw this building a couple of times from the city tourist bus and decided to pay a visit. It gave you some insight into the earlier days of Barcelona. The rooftop had some good views too

Gaudi delight. We enjoyed our visit to La Pedrera tremendously. It's amazing to think that interesting and non-traditional architecture like it, was built over 100 years ago!The audio tour was well worth the time and cost, very interesting. I would recommend buying tickets in advance, online. This seems to save time, to avoid standing in long lines. The views from the roof are wonderful!

Unique place, worth it for the rooftop. We had already been to Gaudi's other house, Casa Batllo, but this one was great as well. Batllo was better for the inside, but Mila was better for the rooftop. I was bored with the inside to be honest. We were here this time in the late Aug/early Sep so the line wasn't long, which meant we did not need to reserve in advance. We walked in on a sunday (Sep 1) and were given tickets right away. I rushed though the house but thoroughly enjoyed the rooftop.
Bravo Gaudi!. What else can we say about Mr Gaudi - amazing experience and creativity. Well worth the price of admission and to compare to the other Gaudi properties in Barcelona.

Expensive but worth a visit. This house was an unexpected surprise, we found it doing the hop-on-hop-off tour in Barcelona. It is really nice, a pleasant surprise, take about one hour to see, has a really nice gift shop. Only problem is the price, 20 euros (including the audio tour) is really too much..... But if you want to see Gaudi architecture and not wait hours for the Sagrada Familia (and see something that is actually finished and has been in use) this is an alternative to consider...

Don't bother with the exhibition next door!. We really enjoyed the tour of the Casa Mila and all the information and exhibitions in the attic. The rooftop alone is worth the cost of admission. However, the exhibition next door was a waste of time. Going in to the exhibition is a staircase that makes it worth the cost.

A Must when visiting Barcelona!. Intriguing, to say the least, and a great testament to the genius of Goudi.The rooftop is slightly challenging if you are not keen on heights, but the view alone is well worth the climb.There is a great souvenir shop on the street level of the complex, with a great range of tasteful souvenirs. You can access the shop without paying to visit the apartments. However, don't hesitate to pay the entry fee - you will be well rewarded when touring the complex.
Splurge and do the night tour!. We read about the night tour on TripAdvisor and decided to try it out! It was great because there were far fewer people touring with us! Definitely worth the money!

The rooftop is totally worth it!. Just the rooftop alone is worth the ticket. You get a 360 degree view of the city including the Sagrada Familia and also really cool sculptures. So many cool photo opps! By looking at the pics, it seems like at night it's even more beautiful. Recommended!

The roof is major attraction. I love Gaudi work so i might be biased to this building,the roof is major attraction but unfortunately if you do not go in and go to the top you will not get to see these amazing sculptures from ground floor

Worth waiting in line. Instead of waiting in line at the Sagrada Familia we walked here. We took the extra 4 euro audio tour for 75 minutes and were very happy with all the explanations and descriptions of Gaudi, his life and some of his creations. Although the rooftop is amazing I was thrilled to get to actually go into an apartment and see how it was designed. I would go again at night.
So incredible. It´s art, it´s time travel... it´s simply unique! It is very unfortunate to miss... it is refreshing to the soul, and the roof is really zany :) Enjoy
not interesting at all.. there was nothnig to wiew inside the house. just a film projection witch describe gaudi's monuments. it was the same thing every where.

Fantastic Gaudi Building. Never fails to impress I came here many years ago when studying Interior Design at University It still inspires me I am sure this is where the inspiration for Star Wars was born too. Take a look on the roof top

One of Gaudi's masterpieces. You cannot go to Barcelona without visiting this amazing house. While the rooftop is certainly a highlight of the tour, take your time strolling throughout the building. Catch all the details of the great interior design work of this genius, Antoni Gaudi. Avoid going late in the day, to ensure you get the full benefit of the sunlight.

Spectacular. We went 4 times to visit at different times of the day. Early morning (6:30am) without people around when the day is just starting. Great pictures. Late at night, when everybody is gone and the lights are giving the building an incredible play of lights and shadows.

Even Better on the Inside. If you love Gaudi and you love Barcelona you have to visit La Pedrera. Although personally I prefer the Casa Batllo a little further down the road - this is the big one. Best visited out of season if you want to take some great photos - in January and February the weather is kind and the queues are non existent - although be careful it does shut one whole week in January so check before you go.There Is a wonderful exhibition in the attic which does explain what makes Gaudi tick - and they have refurbished a whole flat complete with furniture to give a real feel of how it was to live in a Gaudi home. If you made it to Barcelona then it would be criminal not to make it to here. The gift shop has some great books and you can finish in their coffee shop with a lovely coffee or wine! Enjoy!
Fasscinting. Very Unusual and fascinating - the artist is just awesome. Thoroughly worth a visit. Would go again next time in Barcelona

well worth the queue to see this Gaudi masterpiece. As usual, a long queue to get in but well worth it. The roof terrace sculptures take your breath away & transport you to another country- Morocco? Egypt? Astonishing.
Unique!. Amazing architecture, very beautiful building, but very busy and lots of queues best to book pre-tickets for entry.

Don't MIss This Goudi Gem!. This visit provided us with a depth of understanding of Gaudi's work. The "attic' is a treasury of explanations of his ideas and the roof top is one of the treasures of Barcelona. The lines were long, but, everyone was in a great mood!

A weirdly interesting place..... We came to Barcelona to visit the sights and in particular for Gaudi. La Pedrera is a very interesting place from the chimneys on the terrace which are awesome to the beautifully stunning vaulted attic room. What strikes you is the design and visual impact as soon as you step into the place. You can see an apartment as laid out in the era, including the kitchen bedrooms, bathrooms and reception rooms. Worth a visit and it cost 16.50 euros per adult. That does NOT include the audio guide that is 4 euros - other sights the cost is included so be prepared to pay extra if you want an audio guide. We didn't pay extra and got along fine....This attraction has too many stairs but does have a lift by the way.

Rooftop rocks all rooftops I've seen!. I gotta say...another one great, must-see places!I went alone on this and paid entrance. It did not disappoint and I was so sad that hubby didn't come with me to see this. Photos galore with the wonderful colors and shapes of Gaudi!If you can, go early and head straight to the rooftops in the morning to get a good view of the city around and get the good light and avoid the crowds.
Worth a visit to the top. Beautiful architecture on the roof. Also provides a nice view of the city. Gets pretty crowded up there, though, so be prepared to have lots of strangers in your photos.

Superb.. I enjoyed every moment of this visit. Really clear descriptions on headset and great films and exhibits complementing the building. Seeing an actual apartment was amazing. Great gift shop too.
The Rooftop is great. After a climb on the stairs, your eyes are open with the wonderful rooftop. The courtyard is grand as well!

The Stone Quarry House. You must visit this as a contrast, comparison to Casa Batllo. Different, and less visual impact but impressive non-the-less. Be sure to visit the Gaudi Museum inthe the attic and walk the roof to see the chimneys and "guardians". Go with a guide to skip the line

creative and pricey architecture. although the entrance fee is quite expensive - like every other entrance fee in Barcelona - it is interesting to see the architecture from the inside and to go on the famous roof to enjoy the view. from a certain angle, you can see the two sides of Barcelona: the rich one (Passeig de Garcia) and the less well-off one. both sides are divided by a castle on the mountain.also part of the ticket is the attic which probably only architecture fans will enjoy and finally, walking through one of the apartments, which is very elegantly furnished.

Night Tour the best way to experience this. We purchased tickets ahead of time online and purchased the night tour. Excellent way to see the building (free of the masses) and get a nice view of the skyline at night.

Visit, if only for the outdoor roof sculptures.... Such imaginative sculptures on the roof, like a child'splayground. Impressive building, although I preferred the Casa Battlio. If you only have time to visit one house, choose the latter.
My least favorite a Gaudi work. Because you have to pay to visit all Gaudi's works. This is the one that I think you can skip. Casa Batillo is a better choice.

Gaudi's masterpiece. One of Gaudi's masterpiece located on Passeig de Garcia. There are three areas - the roof top, the attic and the apartments.We spent quite a bit of time waiting in the line - online booking is highly recommended.

La Pedrera. Another Gaudi must see!!! But unfortunately the price was very expensive compared to the rest of the Barcelona attractions. I paid €16.50 and the Sagrada was only €13.50 so you cant really compare!!!! The la pedrera is a completly different apartment block that you must visit if you love Gaudi and if you dont mind paying the very expensive admission fee. My husband loved the roof top which was so original but I loved the apartment block which again was so different to normal apartments. Again well worth the visit but the price is a bit steep.

A queue but worth the wait. Casa Milà, popularly known as ‘La Pedrera’, is a most unusual building by the architect Antoni Gaudí (1852–1926) and declared UNESCO World Heritage in 1984. We waited 20 minutes to get into the House and were pleased to have done so. The audio guide is a must. The tour is split into three parts: the rooftop with the curious chimneys, the attic (an informative look at Gaudi the architect who was heavily influenced by nature) and then the museum. Do the tour even if you are not a Gaudi fan. It will give you a better insight into the city and its ongoing love affair with Modernista architecture.

Lovely architecture. Actually liked it more than Sagrada Famillia. Probably because it's more close to daily life. Loved the way Gaudi designed handles by squeezing mold and used the squeezed shape on everything from door handles to drawers. Better to purchase ticket online prior to visit or you will stand in line forever.

Expensive but very interesting. 16, 50 ?, little bit expensive but it worth. This visit explains Gaudi's history. You will enter his world and discover details about Gaudi's architectures, inspirations, ideas... beautiful mind.

Interesting - but expensive. I`m very interested in the work of Gaudi and so I took the chance to visit La Pedrera on my last visit to Barcelona. I was lucky that it wash`t very crowdy at the day on my visit. The terrace on the roof is amazing, the rest of the building interesting but not spectacular. The price of 15,- Euro is quite high

Amazing - book ahead & go on the night tour. I love Gaudi & this apartment building is no exception. On my first visit to Barcelona I did a day tour. On my second visit, I did the evening tour, which was really unique. After doing both, I would recommend booking ahead & going on the after dark tour. Benefits of the evening tour - the roof is especially dramatic at night, it's nice to tour the building in a far smaller group & with less children running around, & who can resist a complimentary glass of Cava & treats at the end?! The tour guide was also very sweet. The only downside is a reenactment that's pretty hokey, but we all laughed it off. Note that there are steps (especially on the roof) & they can be a bit tricky if you either have problems walking or poor night vision.

An Incredible Glimpse of Gaudi's Genius. When Gaudi graduated from school, they said he was either a creative genius or a madman. La Pedrera is a must-see in Barcelona where you can wander across the roof of this fabulous example of his moderniste designs and then amble through what had been the glorious Gaudi-designed apartment of the Mila family. Be sure to pay the extra for the headphones so you can learn all you need to know to truly appreciate his design work. And make sure you stop in the gift shop! My husband treated me to a pair of fanastically beautiful earrings in the Gaudi style which I will cherish forever. The only sad thing was I later learned on a another tour of Barcelona (with headphones, again) that Gaudi was run over and killed by a tram and taken to and died in a hospital for indigents because nobody recognized him.

CAN I LIVE IN THESE APTS?. This is my second trip to Barcelona and I remain obsessed with Guadi. With that said, I hadn't been to La Pedrera until now. Wow. Guadi was such a visionary and this does not disappoint with his use of arches, graceful lines, color. The parquet floors in the apartment are tremendous. Really impressive.

Gaudi at his best. Didn't have a chance to visit internally this trip but fascinating building, a 'must see' on your Barcelona trip. We viewed from outside and took photos. Discount tickets available (10% with a minicard, usually available from your hostel or hotel. Recommended.

its richer if you do your homework first. i came to barcelona primarily to see this attraction. i was not disappointed. three very cool areas to view - the crazy rooftop chimney decorations, the arches inside the attic with the space used to give audiovisual and models of this and other Gaudi constructions, and a reconstructed 1920s appartment. we took 2 hours. this time of year and mid-morning it wasn't crowded, so pre-booking was unnecessary. the price was fine for the time we had and the range of sights to see.my friend did not know about gaudi ahead of time and enjoyed herself. i think my experience was so much richer as i had done my homework.

Wait for a Sunny Day. Wait for a sunny day to experience the fantastic roof of Casa Mila - nothing greater than the sun reflecting off of mosaics and the large chimneys contrasting against a bright blue sky. The apartment portion is quite interesting if you like small details - intricate patterned wood floors, portraits crocheted into the curtains. Other portion of the museum less interesting...

Missed the night tour. For the night tour, you need to book in advance and the group is limited to 30 people, so make sure to come early in the day and buy the tickets, or book online. The tickets are 30 euros.We planned to take it on Sunday evening, but it turns out that in the winter they are available only on Wednesdays-Saturdays (already updated the info on TripAdvisor). Either way, the building is beautiful on the outside as well, so it's worth seeing if you're in the area.
OK. Interesting building.Nice view from the roof.We got ripped off for "free photo"...Don't take it it's not free..It's 5€.Attic of the building is very nice..Entrance is 16€

Interior spaces. Casa Mila is a particularly engaging example of Gaudi's work. Different to both Palau Guell and Casa Batllo, the spaces are set up as the original apartments may have looked, with furniture and utensils just like someone had walked out the door to go to the markets for provisions. This gives the space a homey feel and gives the Gaudi aesthetic for form and function greater significance as you get a strong sense of how the space was actually lived in. Perhaps I just like interior spaces, as I was also very taken with the dolls house in the child's bedroom!

La Pedrera. Gaudi was a very special man with brilliant idea's, futuristic. The entrance fee is expensive but it is such a special house one have to see it. You can be shore that this kind of architecture is one of a kind.

Casa Mila. I enjoyed my visit to Casa Mila. The entrance fee was steep and you have to pay extra for the audio, but for me the audio was worth it. The first stop was the roof, which was just amazing with all of the cool chimney's. The view was great too. The attic has displays of other Gaudi monuments and explanations of how Gaudi went about his work. The tour takes you through one of the apartments and has displays of what the interior would have been like back in the day. A tour through this house is worth it if your in Barcelona.

Casa Mila. Nothing so special to me, and yet they charge the sky price to enter the building. I would rather spend more time at the beach or shopping around the areas. Unfortunately all shops closed on Sunday. Sigh.

Gaudi is a genius. I will never fail to be amazed by the genius and perfectionist this man is..... It was rather expensive €20 + €4 audio guide but I felt it was worth it. My favorite part is the roof where u see his chimney designs and the beautiful attic.

Excellent attraction. This is a very worthwhile building to visit. The main attraction is probably the rooftop and chimneys but the very large area just below the roof is of great interest. It contains details and information on a number of all other Gaudi monuments in the city. The entrance fee is somewhat expensive but is definitely worth it. Take the self guide material for the detailed visit to get the most out of your visit.
Another Gaudi masterpiece. Definitely, Gaudi was not from this planet. Brilliant mind, with such a lot of idea's. Thanks that mankind have this to see.
It was interesting. It was a unique experience to tour this house. I can't say I like the design, but definitely unique and interesting.

By night. Go and see this place at night..via Viator to sign up. The night sky on the roof top is awesome. And we were lucky to have arrived on the biggest shopping night (happens once a year) and it was on Thanksgiving. The music from the street added to the fantasy of the knights on the roof. The guide was awesome and the glass of cuvee finished an incredible evening.

Another great Gaudi roof. This apartment is not as spectacular as the Casa Batllo, but the roof structures are certainly worth seeing. If time is limited and you can only see one house, choose Casa Batllo.
All things Gaudi. The apartment is well worth it and the roof top views are incredible - people live in this building!

Super cool!. We didnt want to pay the price to go inside but its really cool to see from the outside! You will
Never see architecture like this anywhere else! Barcelona is so unique its so fun!

Take the night tour. In the past few months, they´ve added a night tour of the building and rooftop. It´s absolutely magical followed by a little cava to remind you why you´re happy to be in Barcelona! The night tour limits the number of guests and the rooftop at night with city views is awe inspiring. Don´t miss it and make sure and buy your tickets early in the day so you don´t get sold out. The only problem is you must pay cash for the tickets if you buy them earlier. The explanation didm´t make any sense, but we were glad we bought them early when we arrived and there were more people than we expected. The group should be limited to 30 people.

Roof top splendour. Another of Gaudi's famous buildings. There are 2 viewing areas, 1 from the street level where you can see the outside architecture, then you need to go up to the rooftop to appreciate the soldier like columns and almost like giant chess pieces. If you visit in July/August you will be able to enjoy a Jazz festival on the rooftop Friday/Saturday nights with a glass of Cava. It is a very intimate and privileged setting on these occasions. Buy your entrance online so as not to be disappointed.

Lovely. A lot of people double up a visit here with Casa Batllo just down the road - if you are going to do this go to this one first as it is rather overshadowed by the scale of Batllo. The roof here is the main attraction with its chimney stacks! I gave up on the audio commentary and it waffles on for ages without really adding much to the experience

Don't miss the views from the rooftop!. Even if you aren't a Gaudí fan, and you hate queuing up, the building is worth visitin just for its roof and the sights from it. The chimneys are clearly the work of a genious, walking around the roof is an awesome exoerience.All architectural traits of the building are amazing, and the visit to the "real flat" with its authentic furniture etc. is really worth it, one feels transported back to that age and time, and it helps you understand how the burgeoise Catalan families lived back then.Be warned that admitance fees are high, and queues to get in, long.

Great casa but.... According to the website, the best time visiting Casa milla is from 9-10am before cramped with tourists, so we did. We got outside of the ticket office 8.56 am, witnessed the rudeness of a security guard..physically pushed the glass door to get the poor two Taiwanese visitors out who had just stepped into the office because the glass door was open and they thought it already opened. The security lady speaks Spanish but her manner was rude. So, we, standing outside the closed glass door waiting for the last few minutes...then at 9am, the glass door reopened and we were about to step in ...but two young female staff stopped us and shouted...no no no..we need to get the poles out frist, wait outside! ...another few minutes, that was 9.06..we were allowed to get in to get the tickets. Well..we flew many miles to come to the wonderful city to visit Gaudi´s work and did not expect to experience the lack of hospitality at Gaudi´s Casa Milla and we´re expecting the staff will be ready to receive visitors at 9am ..not 9.06..etc...After the lack of warm welcome at the entrance, we were welcomed by other staff (including the staff sells tickets) inside Casa Milla, a young male staff who works at the side of the lift is very professional and instructive which is a relieve compared to our previous experience...Also the price euro 16.50 is way too much for only visiting the roof, a museum and attic...even we were very impressed by Gaudi´s inspiration..

Fascinating insights into Gaudi's world. Rick Steves had highly recommended a visit to La Padrera, so we set out one morning to see it. The admission fee was a bit high, with an audio guide costing extra money. But we felt it was one of those things we "had to do" while in Barcelona. Turns out it was money well spent, as we gained fascinating insights into Gaudi's world. The audio guide was immensely helpful, as it explained Gaudi's vision and gave a far greater perspective on each aspect of the house/museum. We highly recommend spending time on the roof, as the views are wonderful. We were impressed by Gaudi's creativity, as well as by his consistent use of nature in his designs. Casa Mila/La Padrera is well worth a visit.

The roof is the best part!. This building wasn't incredibly interesting inside, the outside was amazing but inside the ROOF was worth going into! It's incredible and with amazing views! There's many blueprints to see until the roof, so maybe skip that part and go on up! Gaudi was a genius!

The wonderful world of Gaudi. We were there on a sunny day and it was amazing coming up to the roof terrace which is the start of the visit, You the go down through the attic with lots of information on Gaudi and the building. Then you visit the very well preserved appartment with all it's beautiful designs. Make sure you touch all the doorknobs designed by Gaudi.

very cool. this place, looks so amzing and when you go to the top it has awesome views of the city from all four sides!! and inside they have gaudi's work and its beautiful. you can see where the man got his inspiration from, it is beautiful! although i was expecting a bit more than just two floors considering how big it is, but maybe its all quite similar! either way its amazing and YOU should go!!

Fascinating. The imagination of Antoni Gaudi is incredible. The pricey entrance fee to this place is well worth it. We spent close to two hours visiting the buildings various levels. Each is quite unique and the attic museum is very informative about Gaudi's inspiration and construction plans. The roof top gives great views over Barcelona.

Very Interesting. This was an interesting attraction. It makes it more worthwhile if you get the headphones for the information on each item you are looking at. I did feel it was a little pricey at 16 euros per person plus an additional 7 euros for headphones. Gaudi was definitely a mesmerizing architect.

what the hell?. It is from the outside one of the most spectacular things we saw. But they ask almost 20 euros to get inside??? And there's a place that if you wanna go there you'll have to pay an extra 30 euros (the so-called secret pedrera) ? What the hell? Not cool Barcelona...not cool

Did this roof come from Outher Space ???. All these places were well worth the entrance fees. The contrast of this house and the adjacent buildings, are striking !Took many hundreds of photos. (Luckily Digital ;-)That ONE person can have so many fantasys ir remarking !One word I will never forget = Gaudi ! The City of Barcelona are LUCKY to have such an inspiring architect.

Great to see Gaudí in "action". It was raining the day we visited La Pedrera, so we did not get to visit the roof terrace, which a friend says is "the best part." But we did spend a lot of time in the Attic and the apartment, which were fantastic introductions to Gaudí's vision and inspirations and construction methods, and gives you a sense of what it must have been like to live there. Amazing spaces and views of the internal open-air courtyard.

So marvelous "quarry" in the center of Barcelona. To continue with our visit to Barcelona, it was sure to happen, to see the famous house, that is, Mila House(Casa Mila), better known as La Pedrera. This fascinating, so unusual, extraordinary building was designed also by Antonio Gaudi as the Basilica Sagrada Familia. The famous architect was working on this chef d'oeuvre from 1906 to 1912 year. The building is located at the corner of the Carrer de Provenca and the Passeig de Gracia. You can get to this magnificenthouse, without any problem, just walking from the Placa de Catalunya, along the street Passeig de Gracia in direction to the northwest or from Basilica Sagrada Familia, along the street Carrer de Provenca, in direction to the southwest.It is widespread known as a very controversial design, at the times, when it was built, but also even nowadays,it captivates with its bold forms of the undulating stone facade and wrought iron decoration of the balconies and windows. So there is no wonder, that You have the long queues during the day, throughout the week, of the visitors, who strongly desire to look at this miracle, both outside and inside. In the building, You can observe the plaster ceilings, the construction of underground car parking and separate lifts and stairs for the owners. From the outside, architecturally, it is a completely innovative work for its steel structure and so called, curtain walls, that is in fact self-supporting facade.Beside of this previous told, there is a furniture, that is done in modernist way, after the design of Gaudi.We stayed amazed, after the perceiving all the building,and decided to see it one more time, when we visit Barcelona next time.

A Different Experience. As with other Gaudi attractions in Barcelona, LaPedrera is a very interesting building expressing his in depth study of nature. You can see the completion of his dream and the feeling that we got visiting was tranquil. I had not known much about Gaudi in the past, but since our vacation I have a great respect for his mind. It is definitely a place you must see to gain appreciation of the man.

Another Gaudi building that put Barcelona on the world map!. Every time I pass through Barcelona, I visit La Pedrera.The exterior, as well as the interior courtyard are fascinating; and that is BEFORE you get to the stunning rooftop!If nothing else, spend an hour on the most unique rooftop you will ever visit!

La Pedrera de Nit - Jazz Concert. Whilst visiting during the day we noticed some posters for an evening jazz concert on the roof top. On a whim we purchased some tickets. They weren't cheap, but I am so glad we did! What a brilliant experience. The atmosphere was wonderful, the music was brilliant (and i'm not a jazz fan particularly). You get a free glass of cava (or orange juice) on arrival with a truffle (yum yum). The only thing I would say is do not be expecting chairs or a formal layout. You literally sit on the steps all around the rooftop. People with mobility issues may want to bear that in mind or make enquiries with the front desk, as they may provide them on request? It was nice to see the skyline at night, and Gaudi's roof all lit up with spot lights. My advice take a camera that is good in low light, as if you keep using a flash you will ruin this very intimate experience. Dress code was a mixture. Some people dressed up (us included) and some were more relaxed. No one really cared, it was very relaxed, with some people laying on the floor with their eyes closed enjoying the music. The band were interactive and amusing. It was also nice to hear the various other concerts and events going on around the city. The whole evening had a real buzz about it, I would definitely go again.

Visit together with Casa Batllo. Both La Pedrera (Casa Mila) and Casa Batllo are close by along Passeig de Gracia. They are about 5 minutes walk apart. I recommend visiting them in tandem to save time. Casa Mila is bigger between the two and has more to offer especially the roof top design. You may wish to spend more time on the roof top compared to Casa Batllo.
Unique!. The rooftop was especially awesome with its unique features, but all the exhibits were interesting also. It is a very very cool example of Gaudi's imaginative work.

What an unusual building!. This is one of the 'must sees' if you want to know something about Antoni Gaudi's style. We went up to the roof top, the attic and the apartment. Very unusual style and character throughout!

Definitely worth a visit. I do not regret visiting Casa Milá. It was a lovely visit a well worth the entrance fee. The building is lovely and it was nice to be able to visit the top apartment and the roof, as well as the exhibitions.

A Gaudi Apartment Building. La Pedrera provides an interesting persepective of Gaudi's unusual architectural outlook. The roof, especially, provides examples of some of his quirky design touches. The "attic" has audiovisual presentations on his life, outlook, and some of his other works.

Gaudi's Roof Top at La Pedrera. If you have young children, I would not pay to go into La Pedrera. It was really expensive. I think it was 16 Euro each. Furthermore, as a mom, I think I would find it nerve wracking to have my children running around on the roof. Some of the stairs are sort of steep.  What you get to see is a 100 year old apartment set up as a bourgeois family of the turn of the last century might have lived. You have access to the attic that has 270 brick arches. The attic serves as a sort of educational site. There is a video running that provides information on Gaudi. There are also little architectural models of his work and displays of his methodologies. I personally loved the models and inspirational explanations. Of course the big attraction is the roof. I also loved the roof. They have set up fences to insure that people stay on a set course. So, if your children are preteen, they will love the experience. The views are great and the functional sculpture is surreal. The dairy queen twists covered in white broken tile shards are delightful. The sculpture that looks like storm troopers or the large sculpture with holes. . .well. . .you're just boggled. You love them and you attempt to figure out how in the world did this enter this man's head so long ago. And how did he get others to understand and create his vision. How did he bring along craftsman to do something so far out, so far from the norm. Amazing.

Creativity and Imagination at Work. Hard to take it all in. Gaudi's work is just too amazing. Get the audio guide to fully appreciate all the work. Be sure to go to the attic where you will find very informative displays of the actual building. There was no wait early in the morning. I just wanted to move in the apartment. Imagining the life lived there was such fun. Lots of better quality gifts and books in the gift shops.
Highly recommed a visit!. We arrived at about 11am and the line of people was looong. However, moved fairly quickly. Might be worth arriving early or in late afternoon.

Pure Gaudi!. A building like we have never seen before. The entire tour (I suggest the audio guide, for sure) was so interesting. The roof area was fantastic with all the chimneys looking like aliens and the ventilation shafts like wonderful ceramic works of art. The attic was fascinating and the apartment was so well preserved with wonderful authentic period furniture and decorations. Well worth the cost and time, for sure.

Help to understand the architecture of Gaudi. It is possible to visit an apartment in the early 20th century. You must be very rich to have two bathrooms in the early 1900s. I enjoyed the tour of the building and understand the thinking of Gaudi architecture. We visited on a Sunday morning and there was no waiting time.The roof terrace is not open if it's rain

If You Like Gaudi, This is a Must!. Certainly a must for fans of the great architect Gaudi. And here's a great tip.....There can be long lines to get in. But if you purchase your tickets on-line (which you can do during your stay), you get immediate entrance, no wait.

No straight lines. Buy tickets ahead of time to avoid lines. You can purchase tickets at several sites in city but they are timed tickets. We bought tickets across the street from Passion facade of Sagrada Familia. Tour includes rooftop with a great view of Sagrada Familia, you walk down to the apartment and also an exhibit in the attic with interesting videos of Gaudi,

16 Euros!?. It's a lovely building but after touring Sagrada Familia and Park Güell we didn't want to pay the 16 euros entrance for this. I was already disappointed with Park Güell which I find over-priced and over-crowded.
Great building - but way overpriced. I attended a conference at La Pedrera and really enjoyed the beautiful building. But if I had to pay the entrance fee I doubt I'd think it was worth the price...

Awesome Gaudi site!. Booked our tickets online in advance (for day and time) and walked right in. Early mornings less congested. Was getting busy with school kids by 11am. Great views from the rooftop. Interesting info in the attic and the apartment was really well decorated with furnishing of that time. Photos were a great deal compared to other sites (8 Euro for 2 photos, or 10 Euro for 3).

Not too much to see. Our first time in Barcelona and we decided to pay the 16euros and visit Casa Mila.It was a bit boring and there wasn't much to see. The price is too expensive just to see the rooftop, attic (which does not have much besides videos and floor plans, and part of the apartment (which was staged). After we left i found myself saying "that's it??" i wanted to see more and don't feel like i got my money's worth. Also, the view is not that amazing.Had i known this ahead of time i would have just admired the building from the outside, and saved my money.

Must See. I loved the organic forms of this amazing rooftop with its sculptural chimneys. Be sure to buy your tickets online to bypass the long lines. You will be given a specific time for your visit.

Outstanding example of Gaudi's work. Casa Mila is a great example of Gaudi's work. The lines to see it are surprisingly not as a long as the other Gaudi work nearby, Casa Battlo but I think Casa Mila is the better attraction of the two. The rooftop alone is well worth the price of admission. On a clear day, the view is awesome and you can even see the Sagrada Familia in the distance. The interior exhibits are also wiorth seeing. Plan to spend at least an hour to 90 minutes in this place. If you had to choose between Casa Mila abd Casa Battlo, I would recommend this one.

unexpectedly fine snack. When told to come up to the restaurant " doner in the Gaudi Style" we wondered if it was a tourist "trap". We had an assortment of cheese and meats and a few grasses of wine in a lovely and quiet atmosphere. Can not comment on the real food but excellent for a snack and drink.

Gaudi's Finest!. I'm not going to bang on about this one, but just don't miss it..... for me it's by far the most interesting Gaudi building & for my money, knocks La sagrada Familia into a cocked hat .

Definitely worth a visit.. We went with a private guide. This is a wonderful example of Gaudi's work. One of the apartments is furnished, and there is also a wonderful museum in what was the attic of the building. The chimneys on the roof are not to be missed.
Gaudi brilliance.. To walk around the roof of this building as the sun was setting over Barcelona surrounded by the stunning roofscape, was one of the highlights of our time in Barcelona.
Really worth a visit. One of Gaudi's finest with spectatular views from Rooftop. Ty & get there early (before lunchtime) as we noticed large large queues as we were leaving

Exterior + / Interior -. The architecture is beautiful, as well as functional. The rooftop gives you a nice view of the area, especially around sunset. I didn't find the interior anything special, and really expected much more. Make sure to book your entrance ticket online which allows you to skip the line, which is always really long.

Magical Night. There were quite large queues for tickets at the La
Pedrera, therefore we booked on-line for the night time Secret Pedrera. This was an excellent choice as the guided tour was really informative, interesting and the attic and roof tour just magical. The audio-visuals and the glass of cava in the courtyard topped it off.
Worth the visit. One of Gaudi's masterpieces that is really worth the visit. Get there in the morning when the wait is not too long.

Goudi architecture at its best. Goudi was a spectacular architect of his time and even today looks are contemporary to many other bukildings. Not as colourful as the Battlo but still well worth a look if you visit Barcelona. One tip pre book to avoid queues

Casa Mila. You only get to see a small part of the inside but so worth it. Very inspiring if you are into art and architecture. The roof is amazing, I have vertigo so tried to stick the middle of the paths, some bits are narrow and original had a very low wall overlooking the courtyard but good, high fences now! The chimneys are fab and you can get great pictures of them. Be prepared for a queue to get in, this queue is for the lift which everyone has to use. The roof is a real sun trap. An absolute must on a visit to Barcelona.

A real time warp. Gaudi designed stuff a long time ago that still looks modern and this apartment and roof top visit is excellent. There really is nothing like this elsewhere. Book in advance on the Internet to avoid queues.

Casa Batllo. I was second in the queue. It opens at 9am. I thought I would see more for the money but you don't. The roof is the best bit and that's the first bit you see. A lot of money for what you really see. A bit too much money for what you see so I guess I was disappointed. You only see the roof and the attic, and some rooms.

Essential of Barcelona. The building is fascinating and throughout the visit, you will ask yourself how it is possible to build something like this. The queues are really big - or at least were, at the time when I visited - but Gaudi's works totally deserves the waiting. La Pedrera cannot be missed if travelling to Barcelona, it is unique, it is breath-taking and it is something that cannot be seen anywhere else

How much more can my mind take?!!. Yet another creation of the brilliant mind of Antoni Gaudi; there is no other building quite like La Pedrera (or if there is I've certainly never seen it!); it's simply a must-see and no visit to Barcelona could be complete without a wander around this almost miraculous edifice - to imagine people actually living in such a space fills me with a raging envy!We booked online and then you can walk to the front of the (usually massive!) queue, as at La Sagrada Familia; once inside there is wonder at every turn - the imagination of Gaudi is given full rein and he doesn't disappoint. Again, the audio guide is a definite boon, and the tour of the apartment was a revelation; however, the most amazing space is the roof, closely followed by the attic. If you are not moved by this amazing building then, my friend, you have no soul!

The roof top alone is worth the visit. Great visit and queues not too bad. Don't be fooled by no credit cards sign, that is only for the ticket booth outside, we had a group ahead of us leave the queue as they thought it was cash only.

Fascinating. A tour of Gaudi's apartment building is worth the time. It is very interesting and the rooftop alone is something out of this world. The creative mind!! Also, the furniture/household store next door is very interesting. The building inside is beautiful and the terrace on the second floor gives you a view of the back of Casa Mila.
Good architecture. Guadi is all over Barcelona but the visit to La Pedrera is well worth it. The roof terrace alone is incredible. Take a camera and snap away. Amazing to think people lived there!

Great Example of Gaudi's work. This is an appartment building designed by Gaudi. Looked like a good part of the building is still in use - offices and residential. How cool must it be to live or work in such a building?The building includes an exhibition of Gaudi's work including an insight into other Gaudi attractions like Guell Park. The roof terrace is a highlight, offering great views around the building and beyond. Note that the roof terrace is closed when it is raining so best to visit when weather is good.An audio guide is available at an extra cost. We chose not to go for the guides and having gone round the build I don't think there is a need.

Unique Building and Attraction; Steep Admission Price. My wife and I left the Hop On Hop Off bus on a whim to get a closer look at Gaudi’s La Pedrera. We spent over an hour touring the building: the courtyards, the roof terrace, the apartment, and the attic which houses an exhibition of Gaudi’s life and work, as well as models of his architectural works, etc. The apartment is set up with each room containing beautiful period furniture, parquet floors, statuary, vases, and vintage items like a gramophone, early telephone, children’s toys, etc. For me, an hour was plenty. I know that this building is a unique and exciting work of art. Still, so much of Barcelona’s economy seems to be focused on Gaudi, that I think I was oversaturated with that focus. The admission was 33 Euros ($45) for us both, which I thought was a bit high. This attraction is fabulous and for those interested in Gaudi and in architecture, it is a must see. My wife enjoyed our time there more than me. For more casual visitors, like me, a few snapshots from outside the building might suffice.

Totally worth a visit. This is definitely one of my favorite places to visit in Barcelona. The exterior is really nice. The roof is also fun to see. The inside is interesting. I loved visiting this place and I definitely recommend the photo that they take for your by the balcony right before you go back down to exit. I believe it costs 10 euros for the photo but I loved the photo that my husband and I took and I definitely thought it was worth the price.

Great roof and views. The views from the roof, both of the roof and of Barcelona are highlights of the visit. The attics are also impressive with the Gaudi parabolic (catenary) arches, and an interesting display. The audio guide information was OK.

Lovely place, extremely pregnant friendly. I enjoyed the interesting beauty of the Casa Mila, but the treatment I received made the experience even better. Being 7months pregnant, all the lines & walking of travel were getting tiring. At Casa Mila, they retrieved me & my husband from the line & took us straight to the front. They also offered extra elevator rides since the tour is on multiple levels (you usually just get one to the top & work your way down, but staff caught me at each point & put me on the elevator). I didn't receive special treatment anywhere else on our trip & was very grateful for their kindness.

Amazing. Understanding what inspired Gaudi and seeing the dedication to his skill is something else. His passion for nature and natural mathematical curves expressed in architecture is so unexpected and unusual. Even if the lines and curves are not your style, you are amazed by the details, down to the shapes of the door knobs. Everybody should visit at least 2 Gaudi creations in your lifetime.

Take the tour. The exterior of the house is interesting but you have to go inside to really appreciate it. The views from the roof are nice as well as the displays in the attic. The tour through the apartment is very interesting.

Not your first choice!. Casa Batllo is far superior. I do not understand the bias I find in the guidebooks. La Pedrera is an interesting building with a different roof top than we will find in the US. So much for walking around a roof. Then you visit the attic. Them you visit an apartment. There is nothing spectacular here. I remain overwhelmed by Casa Batllo. For your money, go there.

worth a visit. It was the first Gaudi's architecture I visited. It reflects the combination of nature and architecture. It is really interesting and creative, but all the introductions are in Spanish.

Fantastic views. The roof at this house is unbelievable everywhere spoke Gaudi. There are many steps and while we were there an accident happened and an ambulance was called so everyone take care. Coming down into the house told us the Gaudi story. There is even a short video to watch. Well worth a visit.

Amazing. When visiting Barcelona this a MUST see. It was amazing and never seen anything like this. We were at this attraction on a very nice sunny day which made looking around the roof terrace very enjoyable, however if it was a rainy day it probably wouldn't be as nice!

I have admired every piece of this house. Casa Milla is better known as La Pedrera which is a building designed by Gaudí. It is located at 92, Passeig de Gràcia in Barcelona, Everyone should see this magnificent architecture

Simply stunning. Like nothing else and hard to describe , it is one of those places you have to see to believe. We spent several hours admiring the sculptures on the roof and taking in the view , and the loft area told the fascinating tale of Gaudi , his life , influences and work. Worth every penny.
Beautifully unique!. Another must see of Gaudi's genius! The rooftop is so unique and interesting. The different room set ups are interesting as well.

A must for Gaudi fans. The Gaudi museum and the roof were the highlights for us. If you're interested in Gaudi's life and work you could spend hours in the museum part! I thought the apartment tour was a bit naff.

Eeek!. Lift straight to roof and then the tour begins. This is jaw dropping and marvellous - unless like me you hate heights and can not understand the low parapet not being surrounded by safety glass
The building opens up to reveal its construction and wonderful period rooms.
It's not a "cheap" visit, but it's certainly the highlight of our break.

Must see La Pedrera. This was the first Gaudi site we visited during our trip. It is really fantastic! We went on a Thursday morning - no queue. The entrance fee and audio guide are well worth the money. Very much enjoyed the visit and it prepared us for the Casa Batllo next day. You must see this and the Casa Batllo when you visit - both display Gaudi's drive for a style inspired by nature very well.
Must see. I've been before and was thrilled to see this amazing building again. For me the rooftop is worth the visit alone. I love the films and exhibits in the attic museum too.

Wonderful afternoon. There is a fabulous museum store inside the casa. You must see the rooftop. Worth the 16 Euro. There are many helpful docents to lead you to the apartments and other floors. I waited in line for 20 minutes since I did not book ahead. There are many groups so lines are long. Metro is steps away.

Night Spectacular. To get into Gaudi's head would seem impossible but doing the La Pedrera at night might give you insight. Plan ahead if travel to Barcelona is on your itinerary because when we picked up our tickets those looking to do the tour that night were turned away. The tour at 915pm started on time. Be prepared to go through security. The guide was knowledgeable and presented the information with a flair. There are many highlights that I do not choose to reveal so that the element of surprise will WOW you.....just a great tour!
A lot less busy. I decided to visit here instead of Gaudi's other location. There was barely a line. Bought the audio tour, which was worth it.

Weird and Wonderful. First, buy your tickets online in advance, otherwise you will waste precious time waiting to buy them. Second, this is not really a handicapped accessible venue, although staff tries to be accommodating. That said, this house is should not be missed. From the roof top to the underground parking garage, and everything in between, Gaudi designed it all. Nothing compares to this place, it's weird and wonderful.

Magic at night. I can highly recommend to do the "secret" night tour for this attraction. We took our group there and enjoyed it very much. It's much more calm then during the day and afterwards we had a group dinner at the cafe. Highly recommended for a casual yet special group activity
Rooftop magic. The rooftop does not only give a great view, but have wonderful sculptures scattered about. I was here as the sun was setting, and you can get some amazing photographs.
Amazing. This was my favorite spot of the trip. Go to the rooftop and see the spectacular sculptures on the rooftop. Great views from everywhere.

night tours. It writes that they've started the night tours (a bit more pricey) so for the short travels to barcelona, it could save a day to visit other monuments.
It was used to be a part of the ArtTicket but as of 2013 summer, you have to buy a seperate ticket. Geerally long lines so must be booked online

No Roof Like It!. We visited in the late afternoon, but the lineup was still long and moved slowly. But it was all worthwhile just to see that incredible rooftop and its unique chimneys, and to explore the floor below to see the intricate structure that supports that roof.

Art Nouveau. The Spanish equivalent of Art Nouveau, this Gaudi house is something special. You get a real sense of the man himself. Visitor-friendly, and one of the must-see places in Barcelona. Head for heights? The roof is as amazing as the rest of the building.

Nothing special. From the 3 houses of Gaudi that can be visited (Casa Batlló, Casa Milá and Palau Güell), the BEST one by Far is Casa Batllo. If you have to choose one definitely choose Batllo. Go early in the morning before it gets crouded.

Controversial Gaudi. Built in the early1900's this building has been made a world heritage site. The exterior intrigues but the rooftop astounds with its different chimneys and water towers overlooking the city. Now more museum than an apartment building its furnished and displayed as it would have been when built, showing design attractions that Gaudi used to highlight the different rooms and common areas. A slice of Barcelona history and well worth a visit.

The best I've visited. One of my favorite of Gaudi's designs. Again the line for tickets was none ending I would recommend to buy the tick online, you won't have to print the ticket as long as you bring your reference number. The place is defiantly worth a visit and you can see how it looks like real waves, even though most people view this place as depressing.

Rooftop- amazing, everything else- average.. We paid 16 or 17 euros to get in. However, I don't think it's worth it. The rooftop IS amazing and it is everything everybody's been telling about but since the inside of the building has been redesigned after Gaudi's original design, I don't think it's worth paying 17 euros just to see the roof.If I had known, I would never have paid to get in.

Amazing Rooftop Architecture. The highlight of a visit to La Pedrera is the rooftop with it's tiled water towers and chimneys. From here you return to the attic which is like a Gaudi museum then visit one of the apartments which is furnished as it would have been when Gaudi cast his magical spell.

Overpriced. The Pedrera is definitely overpriced. The rooftop is very cool, but there isn't too much else to see within it. If you only have time to see one of the Gaudi Houses, go see Casa Batllo instead.

Not much to see at the top. The entrance fee is ?16.50, most of Gaudi's work is at the roof top but not many pieces to view. I'm rather disappointed. Next you will visit the apartment with display. That's it.
A masterpiece. This unique building is not to be missed. It's like nothing else, no strait lines, the appearance is life like. Absolutely worth the walk by if not the stop!
OMG!!!. We love it. It is so beatiful. It's a bit exepnsive 16 euro plus 4 audio guide per person but it was so worth it !!! Definetly a must see.

Beautiful. Peaceful, beautiful and spacious. Very easy to go around with children - made even easier by the staff who directed us through a priority line so we didn't have to queue with 3 little kids.

Amazing. It was packed with people but we were able to see everything and absorb the atmosphere of the house and understand how it worked as a family home - hard to believe when you see it from the outside! Definitely worth the queue to get in.

La Pedrera by night excellent. You can visit by day or by night. The night visit is more expensive, as you get guided as a group and you finish with a glass of cava (local sparkling wine). Our young female guide was very good.This is a huge building - a palace really. There are many Gaudi touches - the curved surfaces, the customised handles, the inner courtyards. The detail is fabulous and the theme of the sea is echoed in doors, in doorframes, in curving handrails on staircases and in wavy plasterwork on the ceilings.What makes the building spectacular is its roof and the many structures on there, for venting air or for storing and releasing water. The roof also provides a great view of the city, though that is hard to photograph by night.There is also an option to have a meal in the restaurant on the first floor, as a package. Given that the visit at night alone is 30 euros per adult, the addition of a very good 3-course meal in a lovely venue, for 19 euros per person, is worth considering. Allow 90 minutes for this. We were rushed at 75.

Easy to tour though not a lot of guidance. La Pedrera might be one of the most interesting buildings I've ever toured. From the outside it looks so strange and foreign, but once you get inside it's very easy to see how a family could live there. I think it would be very romantic to be able to go up to the roof and look out at the city on a daily basis. Anyway - when actually touring the building... prepare to wait in line for a bit outside before being allowed to enter. There is very little to read through about the structures and the architecture, so if you can download a podcast tour guide or visual tour guide beforehand, it's probably a good idea. And plan for about an hour / hour and a half for your tour!

The roof is incredible. This domestic architectural creation of Gaudi's is definitely worth a visit if for no other reason than the incredible roof with its amazing chimneys and view. Your visit begins on the roof which you access via the elevator and then you work your way down through the attic and an apartment. The latter is furnished from the period and is insightful but lacks somewhat in authenticity. The kitchen and bathrooms are noteworthy. Lovely views of Passeig de Gracia from the living room and bedroom windows. Buy tickets online in advance to skip the line although it wasn't bad when we visited at 4.30pm on a weekday. Also worth visiting is the La Pedrera cafe also part of the building for a coffee, glass of wine or Sangria & tapas plate. While there take note of the amazing ceiling, windows and view of the internal courtyard.
jazz on the roof. we went on a Friday nite, drank champagne, listened to the jazz band. It was quite beautiful and the chimneys were amazing

an amazing building. The architect was the genius Gaudi who died in 1923 - also famous for many other masterpieces in Barcelona including the Cathedral La Sagrada Familia.. When you visit Casa Mila you must take time to visit all parts of the building - even the roof - to see how Gaudi crafted every small detail in the use of materials - often in new exciting ways. this is a 5 star attraction and worth a journey to Barcelona for this alone. Lots of good restaurants nearby and a superb tapas bar just a few doors away on the same street..
Incredible. This is a modern wonder, built almost one hundred years ago. If you are in Barcelona, it would be a huge mistake not to see Gaudy's works.
Amazing l, wonderful, must seen. It's really an amazing place i've ever seen. It's worth the entrance price (16.50? ) if you are interested history and interesting buildings, you have to visit there.

Woderful Achitectural Visit. We had no intention of visiting, but Gaudi's Caso Batlo down the street was closed for the day, so we walked back and stood in line for a good 45 minutes to enter. If you plan on touring, buy tickets online as those with tickets were allowed inside immediately. One good thing about the line is they wait for people to exit, insuring you will not be overcrowded inside. We went straight to the roof since it was cloudy and a sigh stated they would close the roof without refund if it rained. It was amazing, but I did resent crowds of young adults that seemed to camp out in areas while playing video games. It seemed as though they had camped there all day. It ruined picture opportunities and though there were staff in place throughout, they did nothing to move these kids along. Keep in mind there was a long line of people waiting to get in. The views from the roof were amazing of the city and the cooling breeze was welcome. Next was the attic. More of a museum and the building features were amazing. You could spend a lot of time there, reading and watching film footage of Gaudi. Next was the furnished apartment to visit. It was a great building, but the entrance fee was high in my opinion at 16 euro without headset. Though I did spend money is worse ways while in Europe. Like 6.50 euro to enter a museum only to use the bathroom. Casa Milla is easy to find from the metro or HOHO bus, and in an area you will want to spend some time walking around.
Worth a visit. Very cool building. Great roof. We arrived around 6 PM, and so had no lineup. Gaudi was clearly ahead of his time. Totally recommend.
A Must See. The view from the top is amazing - go on a clear day and one can see for a long distance. It's a bit pricy but worth a one time visit.

A great intro to Gaudi. Barcelona is a Moderniste/Gaudi treasure trove. This was our first Gaudi stop. We had not bought tickets on-line but were able to enter without too long a wait. We loved the roof top. Magnificent views and chimney sculptures. The brick attic with the arches has photos of other Gaudi buildings. The apartment on the tour is interesting, fully furnished with period pieces to look as it might have done back in the day.

More interesting from the outside. We went here after going to Casa Batllo. While this place is impressive, it's not really comparable to Batllo. The outside is pretty great, the roof is also great, as are the courtyards. Inside they have a fully furnished apartment, which is alright, but it seemed almost unspectacular. It looked normal, like any rich family's apartment would have looked during that period...It's probably better to go here first.

very cool Gaudi building. We chose this over the Casa Batila because we felt like there was more to see (with kids you have to pick and choose what they can stand to see!) Very interesting architecture and rooftop structures, definitely do it at least once. Fascinating to see what his vision was for the inside of the apartments.
essential as part of a moderniste tour of Barca. go off-season and enjoy the space. Or go in summer and suffer massive queueing. But don't miss it out especially the roof.

Gaudi apartment building. Impressive with a very interesting set of exhibits in the top levels of the apartment. If you only have time for two Gaudi buildings I would rate the Sagrada Familia and Casa Botilyo ahead of this. But if you have some more time, worth a visit. Ground floor has a very good gift and book shop with a focus on things for people in the design and creative businesses.
Interiors were drab but the overall effect was great. Go for the roof and the attic. Chocked full of information about Gaudi's methods and greatest works this is a well spent two hours

Best of Gaudi - Book online in advance. In our opinion this is the best of Gaudi. We booked online in advance which was good since at 10 in the morning there was a long line (perhaps an hour to wait) and we just walked in with our pre-purchased tickets. We spent about 2 hours here (more than we had planned) there was so much to see and we didn't want to rush. 3 things to look out for - the wild imaginative architecture; the roof with its undulating floor, chimneys and city views; the museum apartment depicting life when the apartments were first occupied.
Best Site in Barcelona. It's hard to beat the Sagrada Familia, but my partner and I both thought that La Pedrera was the #1 attraction we saw in all of Barcelona.

Gaudi apartment house is really stupendous.. Gaudi's architecture is one of a kind and somewhat mysterious to most of us. He had marvelous engineering abilities and, like Frank Lloyd Wright, flew in the face of convention. Personally, I would give my right arm to score an apartment here. Although the model (the rest of the building is still occupied) was furnished in period furnishings (it had a coal cooking range), it could certainly be fitted out tastefully with contemporary furniture.
