Remarkable. This masterpiece of a building is a MUST for anyone interested in architecture. You have never seen any house quite like this one. It is a building that has been designated at "World Heritage" by UNESCO. Although there is an admission charge, we were glad to pay after having seen the building. Most everything about it is amazing. In particular, the roof is unlike any other one anywhere. You'll just have to see it to understand its beauty and skilled planning. There is also an interesting display in the very large attic, as well as one apartment that is open to the public. To make your visit to Barcelona complete, take some time at La Pedrera.

Expansive Gaudi - well worth a visit but is Bsatllo better?. La Pedrera is clearly one of the must-see Gaudi destinations in Barcelona and has many virtues - the scale of this residential project, and the dramatic roof with its trademark pinnacles, followed by the structural essay in the attic with its slim catenary arches and Gaudi films and exhibits, and lastly the top floor period flat without right-angled corners and Gaudi's décor and furniture. The balcony ironwork is another Gaudi characteristic. However, it did not quite do it for us in the way that Casa Batllo did. There is overall external coherence (at least as Gaudi saw it) but it's harder to get the measure of the complex interior, which is bypassed in an enclosed small lift from the ground floor. We may also have been influenced by an imminent heavy rainstorm which darkened and flattened the light on the roof, severely limiting its photographic value, before driving us down to the attic. But that was just our misfortune. Go there and judge it for yourself. It's impossible to come away in a neutral frame of mind.

Stupendous. Just like every other Gaudi construction, Casa Mila was wonderful and lots of fun. Make sure you include it in your itinerary. It's only a few blocks from Casa Batllo, so you can do both of them in a morning or afternoon. We went during the typical Spanish lunch hour (after 2P) and only had to wait about 10 minutes.

Unusual and Interesting!. The Gaudi house roof-top was very unusual and intriguing!. The audio-visuals in the attic were brilliant! The apartment was interesting too. The entrance fee was a little too high. The surrounding buildings were beautiful - an added treat!

Do it at night!. We did the night tour of La Pedrera and it was an excellent way to see it. We had a small group tour that made it really easy to hear the guide and appreciate the details. I was not sure that I liked Gaudi but this tour completely changed my mind. He was a century before his time and the little nuances of his design were fascinating. If you are going to see the Segreda Familia, I would highly recommend you see this first so you have a better understanding of Gaudi's unique design features. Make sure to book the tickets online to avoid the lines. The rooftop provided great views and was a great way to end the tour, along with the glass of cava as we went back to the first floor. If you have to pick just one Gaudi tour, do this one.

The best Gaudí building. Less espectacular than Sagrada Familia, less colorfoul than Casa Batlló, it is conceptually more interesting, with the curved, no corners façade, the different size of windows by floor (to get equeal amount of light inside) and the thousand of practical and aesthetically appealing solutions. The roof alone is a work of art, but I would prefer the attic, created to have air movement and dry up clothing.Just couple of details, at the beggining most of the building was dedicated to appartment rental, with smaller appartments having 400 sqm. One column had to be modified in the basement (that acted as parking, one of the first in the city) to allow entering the Rolls Royce of one of the tenants.The location is also fantastic, in the middle of the most beautiful part of the city and very good restaurants around.

Distinctive Must See Building. Not called "the quarry" for nothing as the frontage surface looks just like a rough stone cliff. It's on one corner at a road junction on the Passeig de Gracia, the trees and distinctive lamp posts make for a good photo! The must do self-guided tour (not cheap) starts in the courtyard/ atrium and looking up you realise the odd shape is inside also. Lifts take you to the roof which has stepped terraces with weird looking Gaudi chimneys and ventilation shafts like sculptures. Note the view of the Sagrada Familia blocks away and look down on the Passeig de Gracia. The attic is held up by ingenius brick arches, used as exhibition space all about the Pedrera. You next descend to a sample apartment as of a century ago. They give a good impression of the latest creature comforts of that era. Last there's a long descent by stairs to the ground floor courtyard and a turnstile into the large gift shop, full of all things Gaudi.On the Passeig de Gracia frontage there is a separate upscale cafe/ eaterie.

Casa Mila. This building is simply mind blowing in terms of its design and build. If you suffer from Vertigo then the roof might be tricky but one has to really see and absorb the nuances of the architecture here to appreciate the genius of Gaudi. The museum provides insights to the insprations for his work and the tour through the apartments really take one on time travel back though time. Overall, really worth it.
Wonderful, wonderful. I felt in love with it. The conception, what he planned for the building at that time is amazing. Loved t. Cannot be missed.

Rooftop is amazing. Rooftop design and view is amazing. Moreover, spend time in the upper most floor where you can see how the rafters were designed in the attic to support the rooftop design- that is a architectural sight to see. the outside of building is beautiful to view lit up at night as it was a block from our hotel. However, I was a bit disappointed in the rest of the house tour as Casa Cattlo had so much more architectural detail to offer. I found the furniture in this housing nothing special. Make sure you buy your tickets on line before as tickets are timed a minimum of a few hours out. Our hotel concierge bought the tickets in the morning for afternoon admission. We were allowed in 1/2 hour before our admission time.
Loved it!. We enjoyed touring the house and also ate in the restaurant. Both are worth doing. Gaudi's works are stunning.

Good experience. It was a good experience to go into this building built by Gaudi. I took an audio guide and it was very useful. I got a view as to what Gaudi was thinking and I was able to appreciate his work. I recommend the audio guide very much. We also got a discount on BCN card!

Well presented, fascinating experience. I can highly recommend seeing La Pedrera, particularly if you also visit the Basilica La Sagreda Familia. Together they give a great impression of Gaudi and La Pedrera is particularly good at giving you the historical context foe his work.
Gaudi Inside. Something you need to see …. not only if you are an architect or artist. This is about the idea of Gaudi to a finished product. Something you can study over and over.
Guadi's creation. When you tour this apartment house you get a small idea of what was going thru Guadi's mind when he designed it. Go and enjoy.
Mediocre restauration. The outside of this building is terrific, but I found the inside left a lot to be desired. There was very little furniture and illucidation.

Quirky Wibbly Wobbly Architecture at it's best. Amazing building. Said to have no straight lines. Must go to the roof. Not only amazing views. But the sculptures lined up like soldiers were wonderful. And you can look through the middle of the building and see right to the ground floor. One of my favourite things that we saw in Bsrcelona.

Just stood outside. We didn't go in as it was 16 euros each and I wanted to see all Gaudi places but just standing outside and looking at the building was amazing, the work that went into the building is fascinating.

Absolutely fascinating especially when combined with jazz. Very lucky that we saw a jazz concert on the roof of la pedrera at night advertised for the last evening we where in Barcelona. Entry included a tour of the amazing parabolic structure supporting the roof. A brilliant evening. If you see an evening jazz concert advertised, jump at it.
Wonderful architecture. Wonderful architecture and there was also like a museum inside, where you could follow Gaudi's work and success.

La Pedera. A Monolith of an apartment building designed and built by Anton Guadi for the Mila family of merchants. Initially,Not well received by the local residents it was nick-named the "Rock Pile" or 'bunker" Great example of Guadi architecture Be sure to visit the rooftop for the fine example of chimney covers apparently used by George Lucas for his inspiration for Darth Vader's mask and the Storm trooper's Head gear. Another visit is to the loft to see Guadi designed furniture and architectual models of the building. also, check out the garage and garage entrance in the basement of the building. As well as the historic apartments,Nice coffee shop and café on the premises.

A Night Tour You'll Never Forget. You must pay the extra and go for the Night Tour. It is limited to 30 people so you are not with the masses of people that you will have if you go during the night. Gaudi style is just amazing and with such an eye for detail and imagination. Just a fabulous experience that should not be missed while in Barcelona.

Worth seeing inside. If you like the outside then you will love the inside - such an imaginative building and such creative ideas used. Well worth the entrance fee to see the inside and the roof. spend your time soaking in the atmosphere

Breathless!. I can never stop discovering the amazing details Antoni Gaudi had embedded in the apartment, despite my repeated visit. Get your ticket online or have your hotel book it for you to avoid the long queue 16.50 Euro. Book your time of visit, as thousands of people visit this art-partment each day. And you could have your breakfast 9am at the restaurant housed in the same building that serves great coffee and mini baguette. Headphone is a must-have to enhance your experience and understand at 4 Euro even if you'd read about Gaudi. Enjoy this wonderful creation that is going to take your breath away.

Excellent night tour. We did the Pedrera at night tour which I would highly recommend. There was only around 30 people in our group which meant it was much more intimate than visiting during the day time. We booked our tickets the day before and turned up just before the allotted time and went in without queuing.Our guide, Jordi, was very knowledgeable and I learnt a lot, not only about Gaudi and the building itself, but also about Barcelona and the local area at the time the building was commissioned.The tour included the courtyards, apartment, the attic space and the roof, which was beautiful lit up at night. The tour lasted around and hour and a half and there was plenty of time to look around and take photos. At the end everyone was able to enjoy a glass of Cava and ask any remaining questions. The tickets cost €30 each so more expensive than the standard day ticket but worth the extra. It is also worth mentioning that the Pedrera website was not showing any availability for the tour in English on any of the nights we were in Barcelona but I was able to buy online tickets through a booking agency.

Don't miss the evening tour. Let me preface my review by admitting that I LOVE Gaudi's architecture and design. That said, it doesn't get any better than La Pedrera and Casa Battlo. The special evening tour that starts around 9:30 PM shows the interior in a completely different light (pardon the pun). In a small group of 30 or less, our tour guide took us into an apartment where time stood still, as if the people had just abandoned it decades ago. We also toured most of the interior (four apartments are still inhabited because of rent control (!)) and the wonderful roof full of Gaudi's whimsical structures and sculptures. I got GREAT photos and a better understanding of Gaudi himself. This is definitely a not-to-miss adventure.

Stunningly different. If you appreciate something different in architecture then don't miss here. Gaudi's apartment and designs are so unusual. He took his ideas from nature you can see all sorts of shapes and form. I particularly like the Moorish chimney pots, you can imagine them riding horses along the beach in Southern Spain. Barcelona has his work or styles of it all over.even out of season you will have to queue. Lunchtime seemed less busy. It's open until 22.30 this would give the roof terrace a completely different perspective, along with views over Barcelona at night.

Aprecie por fora / Enjoy out. Barcelona é uma cidade incrível, e em muitas das suas atrações, o melhor esta por fora. Assim, eu considero "La Pedrera"... reserve um tempo para admirar a arquitetura de Antoni Gaudi. O impressionante dessa obra é a sua parte externa. Barcelona is an amazing city, and many of its attractions, the best this outside. Thus, I consider "La Pedrera" one of these examples ... take a time to admire the architecture of Antoni Gaudi. The striking of this work is its outside.

A lovely night out. We booked an evening tour at La Pedrera and dinner at the Café La Pedrera, there were husband and I our adult daughter and12yr old granddaughter. The tour was magical and very well run, the dinner was lovely, I recommend both. We booked on line.
Fascinating!. Another of Gaudi's fascinating creation. The architecture is breathtaking and nothing like you may have come across.
Night tour. It's much better than the day visit and I love it so much. The light and sound effect are wonderful and make the trip memorable.

A true Gaudi experience. Buy your tickets in advance from your concierge or a tourist kisok and avoid the very, very long ticket lines! We did the truncated audio version, which was plenty for us. It is a great opportunity to see the impact of Gaudi in a non-religious aspect on this incredible casa!

The excentric Gaudi. What a unique building! This is another piece of excentric work of Gaudi. My tour guide specifically mentioned: "Don't forget to explore the roof". My husband and I indeed spent more time on the roof. Unique shapes and forms are found here. I think that is why I saw many visitors spent their time sitting and drawing some interesting spots. I wished I was good at drawing......

Yet another beautiful building. We visited here in the latter part of the day and had an incredible sunset on the roof that had all the quirky chimneys lit up in yellow and orange. The apartment inside was fascinating -another place not to be missed.
Very nice architecture. The apartment building has very unique architecture using nature as a base even before Frank Lloyd Wright. Interesting layout with imaginative sculptures on the roof.
Probably worth a visit. Like every visit in Barcelona expensive but fascinating building,the restaurant /caffe next door is great and value for money!!

The rooftop of wonder. The entry ticket feels expensive. But the rooftop is your induction to the wonder called Gaudi. Essential for every photographer, every corner of the rooftop is a visual and aesthetic delight. Go there in bright sunlight at around 4 pm as the long shadows of people makes for some stunning photographs.
Huge house. The roof was amazing with the big sentinel chimneys. Lots of lovely details and beautiful colours. Many photo opportunities
It is fine. You can only pass by and look at it - but it is near batlo house (very pretty) so why not seeing both? The street Passeig de Graca is so pleasant to walk at anyways.

Speechless. I visited La Pedrera after visiting Casa Batllo. I liked the interior of Casa Batllo better, but the roof of La Pedrera is simply amazing. I even teared up a little when I got up there. Gaudí was a genius, don't miss his works when in Barcelona.If I could go again I'd try to go earlier in the day, since it was almost crowded when we visited, specially on the roof and you can't take a picture without at least 5 people walking into the frame. Also try to buy tickets over the internet, lines are really long.We bought tickets online for 1pm but arriving there at 11am we went to get our paper tickets and they told us we could go in. So don't wait until the allotted time to go in - the same with the towers at Sagrada Familia.The restaurant downstairs (accessible from the street) has good food but the service isn't the best.

take the night tour!. The night tour provides tours of the apartments, the attic and the magical roof in small guided groups. The guide is outstanding and will provide insight not to be missed. This is much more than just dim lights and nighttime. A highlight of BCN.

Better value than Sagrada Familia. Get there early and its not too crowded so you can take in those fabulous views from the roof and those weird great chimney stacks. If you have a couple of hours to spare its well worth a visit.

Must see!!. This is truely brilliant! Do book your tickets in advance however! It can get a little pricey!This is a great view of how alternative Gaudi's designs were- the rooms inside are incredible and the cafe has nice cakes.The little flats inside are brilliant as is the roof space- MUST SEE

gaudi masterpiece. this is just another great building among so many, not that cheap the entrance fee but the top is something else and a great view too boot. or too film it outside is also worth the time and no charge.
There are no words to do this justice.. From the street up and onto the roof a visit here is a must. Absolutely incredible in all senses of the word

Can't miss this. The city is well set for Gaudi building visits, but although they are all in a certain style - they are all very different too. We visited Casa Batilo, Guell park, La Sagrada and here in three days. I'm not one for architecture, but enjoyed every minute, you would be foolish to give this a miss.

Ticket in advance during the holidays !. I went there during the easter break. I knew that it would be crowded since there're people everywhere so I bought the ticket online and went there early morning. It worked ! love it ! no peeps and I got to enjoy my own space !

Pricey and not that interesting for design. We saw a great deal of the modernist buildings and although this one was supposed to be very different, it truly wasn't. It is impressive in a couple of rooms and fun to envision living there, but not stunning for the price of admission.

Not a fan of Gaudi... Until I came here. The place is extremely interesting, starting with the courtyard and the roof and finishing with the main floor furnished as it would have looked a century ago. But what I really loved is the attic. Apart from being able to see the space, with amazing plays of light and shadow, the movies on the creation of the other masterpieces were extremely good. We left after just over an hour but I felt like having spent all afternoon in a dream evoked by Gaudi's genius

Beautiful building. La Pedrera is a great example of Gaudi's work. It is very interesting to see both inside and out. The audio guide with the tour is quite insightful. The roof with its chimney's is especially beautiful. You can buy tickets before hand to avoid the line. However, it wasn't too long when I visited, only about a 15 minute wait. Overall, I would definitely recommend a visit.

Interesting. Of all the Gaudi buildings we visited, this was probably my least favourite. Interesting - but not mind blowing. Perhaps it was because we had just left the Cathedral. It was about 20 euros per person which I think is a little too much for what it is. You get a great view, and a look at some Gaudi artefacts.

Very very impressive!. Just, plan your tickets well ahead, because the queue is long! You have to go inside anyway! Alternatively, there is a cafe at the principal, so you can see part of the building without paying for a ticket (just for the coffee!)

a must. you have to go here!! 16.50 euro to go in..took about hour to go round the palce...if you go on a wed/thursday/ its buy one get one half price on admission price...well worht the visit to see gaudi at his best

Nice but expensive. Though I am glad I visited Casa Mila I thought it was very expensive for what you get. The thing I enjoyed most was the roof but paying over 20 euros for it is a bit much. The museum inside was not that interesting and I had a feeling they added it so visitors have the feeling they saw more than the roof and some rooms. However, the architecture is magnificent so I would still recommend it to Gaudi fans who are willing to pay the price.

Stunning. This should be in the top 10 attractions in Barcelona with the Sagrada at number 1. Unusual and unique Gaudi building with hardly a single straight wall in the place. The top deck has to be unique and exceedingly unusual and strangely beautiful as well. The reappointed apartment is fascinating. After leaving try a nice meal in the restaurant that is on the ground floor and see the lovely curvaceous ceiling there and enjoy excellent food!

Awesome!. I passed this building whilst on the Gaudi walking tour and it looked so cool that I had to go back on the same day! Although you can book tickets online, I had no trouble getting in - I was literally only waiting in the queue for about 5 minutes before I got in.One of the most amazing things about the building is that absolutely nothing about it is 90 degrees - it is very fluid-looking if that makes any sense? Although this is evident from the outside, it is even more prominent whilst inside and, in particular, whilst exploring the rooftop terrace, which has a number of interesting sculptures (many of which resembled aliens) and was was probably my favourite part of the building! After exploring the rooftop, make your way downstairs, starting off in the attic rooms which used to be the servant quarters, but is now a museum with short documentaries on a projection screen, scale models of the building and various other exhibits to explain the design of La Pedrera.From the attic, you venture further downstairs into the wealthier living quarters which remains established like it used to be while the building was inhabited by the Mila family. The rooms are not only interesting to explore, but provide an insight to how the other half lived!Overall, this building is definitely worth a visit! Two hours is sufficient enough and, as it is located quite close to the Sagrada Familia, it would be a good idea to fit both of these into the same day!Tip: Whilst exploring the attic, I really regretted not paying extra for the headphones and audio-tour (it was 16.50 euros to get in and another 5 for headphones). A written history is virtually non-existent inside the building, so I would advise everyone thinking of visiting La Pedrera to pay the extra for headphones - not having them really spoiled it for me!

Night tour. I recommend taking the guided night tour-- worth the money. We were a small group that got to explore closely and carefully the apartments in the building of the future built in the past. The roof at night is at once eerie in its shadows and shapes and impressive as sculptural beings over looking the city. The arches in the attic are a smaller example of what is repeated on a grand scale in the La Sagrade Familia. This tour combined with a visit to Casa Batllo gives one a full sense of Gaudi's vision.

A must see tourist attraction. This a a must see tourist attraction when you are in Barcelona. You can see videos, models, and pictures of all of Gaudi's work which are fascinating.The roof is amazing and the apartment is also a nice touch. You can see how people used to live back in the day. The audio guides are a bit pricy though over and above the entrance fee. When walking on the street viewing the outside of the building is also fascinating. Very clean, cool and well organized.

Worth visiting with an audio guide. This Gaudi building is well worth an hour or two of exploring - to us it was much more interesting than the construction zone interior of La Sagrada Familia. The rooftop is fabulous, the apartment has some very modern touches and the attic provides insight into the building.
Beautiful building. The roof is amazing, and the other floors are very interesting with short docufilms running and various models etc showing Gaudi's construction techniques.

Nice Stop. La Pedrera is one of Gaudi's residential apartment buildings. Odd, but very interesting to look at. Don't plan a day trip to see this. Make it a stop on your way to or from La Sagrada familia. Sit down in one of the many cafes and take in the architecture, etc.

Gaudi - What an imagination!. La Pedrera is a block of apartments which is one of Gaudi's triumphs in Barcelona! The roof has to be seen to be believed! Think aliens, strange animals and weird shapes and it will still take your breath away! Then there was the attic and an apartment to look at. The attic showed the underpinnings of the building and how it all goes together which was really interesting. The apartment was, in my opinion, the least interesting bit but still worth looking at. I have to say it was my favourite tourist attraction that we visited in Barca. You will need about 1 hour to go round but I could easily that long on the roof alone. Get there early 'cos it's a very popular attraction and the queues get very long in late morning.

Inpressive!. In one word: impressive! A must see when you are in Barcelona. I think when you have visited the park and museum it would make more sense and you will see more details.Btw, look to the left: you will see an incredible mixture of old and new buildings.

Very nicely built. Small queue.Nice place inside. Audioguides tend to talk & talk &talk too much, but you'd be lost without them.3 floors, don't go on a rainy day because they will close the roof if it rains.Enough to spend an hour or 2 there.

If your claustrophobic. you may not like the lift journey to the top. Amazing to see, particularly the roof terrace. The apartment is also an interesting re-creation. It is one stop on the bus then to Casa Batillo and there is a lovely Tapas Bar attached to Pedrero serving jugs of Sangria and tapas

Another Gaudi marvel. Art nouveau at its best with surreal architectural genious gives rise to such wonders. Let you imaginations run wild and far to assimilate the architecture here. Although quite touristy with most of them ignorant to the existing structures busy posing for pictures. Get to the roof and admire the structures sitting peacefully at one corner.
Really interesting. This was great find, had no intention of going in but once we got there decided it had to be done. So interesting and the show rooms inside were lovely to see too

Great views from the roof. I loved this place. The views from the roof are great, especially with all the architectural lines. The Attic area has some great displays and explains well the breadth of Gaudi's work. I was there about an hour and a half.

Third best in Barcelona. Rated by our guide book as the best Gaudi house, but actually less interesting than Guell or Batllo. Attics are beautiful and apartments are interesting, but it is expensive for what it offers. The cafe is god though.
A very interesting visit. We enjoyed our visit to La Pedrera with many features of the architect Gaudi's unique style. On a busy day with many tourists the queue to enter was quite reasonable.

Incredible rooftop. I absolutely loved this masterpiece! The apartment is gorgeous and really takes you back 100 years. It was so interesting to see where a wealthy person may have lived in Spain 100 years ago. I love all of the furniture and household items they have. But my favorite part was the rooftop. It’s so unique, and I’ve never seen anything like it. It’s so pleasant there and you get a great view of the street as well. The design and architecture is one of a kind – it makes for amazing photos. I can’t imagine what would make Gaudi design something like this, functional and great form. I enjoyed this more than Guell Palace, but didn’t have a chance to see Casa Batllo so I can’t compare them. We enjoyed the architecture so much we did buy a reasonably priced souvenir from home in the gift shop. You must visit this while in Barcelona.
An incredible building. Helped by a short guided tour, in English. Quite an amazing building, especially the roof-top and the attic museum.
Very surprised inside... I love Gaudi buildings, but did find some of the rooms very different to what I expected. You must visit, as another wonderful piece of architecture. Great view on the roof.

Eye opening. Wasn't sure what to expect as I didn't know a huge amount about Gaudi but found the whole experience fascinating. To get the most out of the visit I would suggest the audio guide. Queued to get in but in hindsight this was a good thing as they didn't pack the building so full of tourists that you aren't able to see the building at its best

Very interesting architecture. The roof is very interesting and pretty. The view from it is amazing, you can see so much of the city!Inside, there is a section that talks about Gaudi and his work. There is also another section that let's you see some of the rooms in the building and the recreation of what would've been in the rooms.It is a beautifully created building, a piece of art!
Modernism. A must see. First you go to the roof and then work your way down. The apartment has some very nice period furniture.

Inspirational materpiece and beauty to see no matter where you look. The house is beautiful experience from the moment you step onto the sidewalk. It creates a sense of mystery with the curved passages and intricately designed patterns. It is a beauty to look at the apartments and marvel at Gaudi's mind and what inspired a man in his time. Sheer brilliance. The views from the roof tops and the chimneys themselves are masterpieces. This is a must see when visiting Barcelona. I loved the furniture and the style of the kitchen, but how his mind created such designs in the early 1900's is something that will keep you wondering for days after, really a brilliant concept.

it's just something!. The house was constructed by Gaudi from A to Z.
From Architecture to Door handles!!! It's just amassing as all the constructions made by Gaudi!
Enjoy!
Gaudi!. Only saw from the outside but very interesting design. they do day and also do special night tours now, unfortunately we missed out on them as we were only in Barca for a day.

Stunning views. This was our second visit and our friends could not believe the style of these apartments. There is just so much to see and the views from the roof are fantastic. The show in the attic section is relly informative and well worth spending some time looking at the info on the Gaudi creations.

Impressive, though a little dissapointing. The roof and exterior are impressive, the interior less- nice content of early 20th century rich houses.
Took the long audio tour- finished it 30 instead of the promised 75 minutes.

Impressive!. To me, Barcelona = Gaudi. I was very impressed with his works, and among his works, Casa Mila ranks high on my list. I visited most of his creations (architecture) in Barcelona.He creates architecture that is not only aesthetically pleasing to the eyes but he also ensures that it meets the needs of the human being - sufficient light, air and the sound of the music. Genius!

Don’t miss La Pedrara by night.. We visited La Pedrera by Night. This was wonderful to stay on the roof of Gaudi by night and to listen jazz concert with glace of cold champagne. The roof is all in smooth light and make the work of Gaudi to look amazing, you can see the city of Barcelona and the jazz make the night magical. You also have a time to visit the attic with museum of all the works of Gaudi and explanation about how he made the constructions. Everything was well organized by the personal and run smooth, you have a time and don’t wait at all. I strongly suggest to don’t miss this night experience.

If you are into unusual architecture this is unmissable.. Give yourself about one and a half hours. This was a beautiful building with lots of stunning architecture influenced by nature. The theme is Gaudi's designs and very different. We chose not to take the audio tour but still enjoyed the visit.

If you love Gaudi, go see the roof. However, if you don't really care for his work, then it might be "just another Gaudi" building. It was interesting to see the roof and the apartment, but a good chunk of the tour was watching videos (no sound) or reading. It certainly seemed to pale in comparison to La Sagrada Familia, so maybe go here FIRST then Sagrada? It just seemed like an expensive tour for what you got...it was still cool to see, but... We walked over a few blocks to Batllo and skipped seeing that one, as it was even MORE expensive and I was Gaudi'd out by that point.
Not to be missed!. The roof tour and attic visit were the biggest surprise. Be sure and have this on your list of must dos.

My favorite Gaudi building. Built in the early 1900s as an apartment building, this building is revolutionary. If you only have time to visit one Gaudi building this should be it. I would love to live in the one apartment that is on display. The rooftop chimneys form and function is what originally attracted me, but I'd have to say that the apartment sealed the deal.

Stunning!. I've always thought that this buildings looks as if it is melting. The stunning white architecture is all curves. The unusual chimneys seen on the roof are crazy and wonderful at the same time. From the roof you can see the city including Sagrada Familia. The interiors provide a glimpse into the mind of Gaudi. This is worth seeing while visiting Barcelona.

Very interesting Gaudi architecture. We only viewed it from the outside, and it is very intersting. If you have extra time, visit the interior. It is situated in an area with high end fashion and lots of cafes and restarurants.Visit in the afternoon for good photo lighting.
pretty!. not every building of Gaudi is worth your money but here you really should go to the roof because it is really amasing

best chimneys ever!. wether a gaudi follower or a beginner in spanish modernism, la pedrera is such a treat! the curves of each iron works and the play of colors of every tile against the blue Barcelona sky is ...so perfect!

Overrated. I felt like I was herded in and around with hundreds of tourists on a hot sticky day! It was disappointing to see how enclosed the roof top was...obviously for safety reasons, but I had built up the image of the structure and was disappointed. I'd recommend off season visits to this landmark!

A must to visit!. Amazing place. Just seeing it from the outside is not enough, the rooftop is definitely worth a visit. We visited around 4pm and that was the best time to visit as there wasn't a queue.

Gaudi - a creative genius. we only looked at the exterior. It was expensive to go inside. there was a line, and a crowd of people in the store/museum. If you´re interested, do your research before you arrive.

Plenty of straight lines. Not sure how blind people are that say there are no straight lines. The doors, windows etc sure have straight lines. But that is not the point of this building I guess. To see the idea's behind the house and many of Gaudi's designs explained in the exibition in the attic is very nice. Nice to have such a strong contrast in one city. On the one hand Gaudi, on the other hand Mies van der Rohe. My vote goes to Mies van der Rohe, but this is also nice.

Unbelievable!. A must for fans of Gaudi, interesting architecture, and, probably, for everyone else! An example of Gaudi's genius on display. I bought tickets online and ahead of time to avoid the lines. The buildings exterior facade is instantaneously recognizable and memorable. The inside is also very interesting but the rooftop is amazing. Excellent views of Passeig de Gracia from the roof!

The building with no straight lines. I don't know what Gaudi was on, but he must have been a mathematical genius. This building is stunning and strange. The rooftop is a must to see either day or night it is a magical and bizarre sight with great views over the city. The interior is as fascinating as the exterior incredible architecture and a must see. The curves of the structure and high ornate ceilings are unique to any other building I have seen and to think it still stands today, a masterpiece not to be missed.

Remarkable!. If you're interested in architecture this should be number two on your Gaudi list. The building itself is visually incredible, the facade and the roof terrace are the highlights. The ticket entry also includes a great little exhibition about Gaudi's life and work; not comprehensive but certainly a good introduction. You then get access to a model apartment which is, again, very interesting to look round, putting Gaudi within his context. There's also examples of Gaudi's design which are engaging because due to his primary significance as an architect this side of his work is often neglected. The entrance is a bit steep at around 20 euros if you want an audioguide (which I would recommend) but if you can afford it I'd go for it.

nice from the out side - less at the inside. I loved the outside and wanted to see it from the inside. I was a bit descapointed. It is not really a museum to see things. It is more technical info on how Gaudi builded stuff. The technique, the tricks, the theory.
Unique archeticure. Another unique architecture of the Spanish architect Goudy.. I love the outside shape very much, It has a large distance & a museum .. It worth a visit

Wish I lived there!. La Pedrera is an outstanding example of Gaudi's work. The view from the rooftop (which is closed when raining) is worth the price of admission alone. The fact visitors can walk through an architectural relic such as this makes it all the more special. Visitors can walk among Gaudi's famous chimneys on the roof and see Sagrada Familia, the mountains and the sea, before walking through an apartment in the building. The line to get into La Pedrera can be quite long, however, tickets may be purchased in advance online.

Very impressive , gaudi the man. I recomend to visit this place but not to stand in the queue , it is so daft , better to appreciate the beauty from the outside . In the summer the have music nights on the terrace , there are less people and a very nice ambience .
fantastic roof top. We felt the best bit of Casa Mila was the rooftop and its views. The inside is great, but personally I prefer Casa Batllo.
Simply Amazing. The architecture was unlike anything we'd ever seen. Just brilliant and defiantly worth the time and money to experience something so unique. Will not disappoint.

A great close-up with Gaudi architecture. This visit was one of the highlights of our trip. We got tickets for the roof-top jazz concert being held once a week in the summer. We were let in an hour before the concert and had time to experience the very well made museum. Highly recommendable.

Night tour was great!. Amazing architecture and example of Gaudi's impressive imagination. Wonderfully restored. Seeing the shapes and shadows at night were great! Our tour guide was ... average, though.

Hugely interesting and impressive building. We thoroughly enjoyed our visit to La Pedrera - the architecture is very impressive - the roof chimneys amazing and it's very well worth taking the time to go round the "loft" to understand how it is built. The tour of the apartment is also great fun and recreates the past very well. Certainly worth a visit.

Gaudi was amazing. Such a wonderful place and so interesting. Don't miss it. They now do night time tours.
The rooftop is spectacular

Must-see. The ticket is a bit expensive..but it really worth it!! It is amazing,if u r not a paintings lover,that's the right balance between art and fun. From the roof to its particular rooms,the one with the shape of a skeleton for e.g.,it fascinated me!

Great example of Gaudi at work!. This place is excellent, best if you start at the rooftop and work your way down, there is loads to see and do along the way and the architecture is absolutely breathtaking in places.

Wonderland.... From the outside, looks like a little bit decorated regular apartment. But once you get to the roof, everything changes. It's a real wonderland up there, or at least it makes you feel like you're in wonderland. From some views, you feel like you're somewhere in a desert or something like that. Gaudi really knows how to manipulate people's feelings and visions. Was worth the ticket and time.
Gaudi Masterpiece. A very well run attraction, well worth a visit. One of the most amazing buildings in the world.The design and imagination of Gaudi on display.

Worth a look. I thought it was ok, but thought the price was a little high. The roof and the apartment were very interesting. The attic was ok, but some of the exhibits were similar to ones you saw at the Sagrada Familia. I would recommend seeing this before the Sagrada Familia otherwise it could be a let down.
What an imagination. You can get a different perspective of Gaudi's genius when you see this building and the roof top. Make sure to see it at night as well!

Must visit. Along with Casa Batlló, there are also jazz concerts at dawn on the roof top terrace. Must get there a bit early as there will be a queue and you want to pick a good place for the concert.

Perfect. An art building with full of details. Inside, you can see lots of different art and design products. (Audioguide is recommended) aand there is a nice gift shop. Its a little expensive than other shops but lots of different items and books in there.

Amazing fluid architecture. The Gaudi designed, La Pedrera is an apartment building on Passeig de Gracia designed by Gaudi. You can access it on the "hop on hop off" route making visiting the amazing building very easy. The large central atrium, curving staircases and iron balconies (each is different from the next), roof top "soldiers" and mini-towers, and furnished apartment were well worth the visit. Like many of Gaudi's buildings. English language hand-held devices make the trip complete.

Good Gaudi experience. We chose to only visit Casa Mila and not Casa Batlo as well due to reviews we'd readWe thought this was a unique and interesting experience and the audioguide was useful to learn about Gaudi.You go to the roof, attic and apartment on this tour and gave a good insight into Gaudi and his work.It was 16 Euro pp plus 4-5 Euro for the audioguide (my wife and I got one and just shared)Would also recommend going to Sagrada Familia for a more indepth look into Gaudi's work and it's totally different to other churches you'll see in Europe
Pretty good. If you want to see one of the best of Gaudi architecture, here is the second best below La Sagrada Familia though the ticket is a little expensive.

Amazing attraction. Summer night jazz concert made it even better.. Definitely an attraction you have to see. Among the top Gaudi attractions of the city. In summer they have "musical nights" on the rooftop, making the experience even better. Beautiful view of the city as well.

Outstanding building (if not a bit pricey). Fantastic from the moment you step onto the roof, well worth seeing and taking in the view from the roof also, the attic and apartments are interesting also. Personally I thought it was wee bit pricey for what it was (approx €15), but it is an outstanding building.

La Pedrera. I have been inside most of the Guadi buildings in Barcelona and La Pedrera is one of my favorites. The entrance fee to this building and Casa Battlo may seem high to some but one should take the time and expense to visit one or the other. The roof of Casa Mila makes it just a bit more worthwhile to see if you must choose between the two.

Amazing building. La Pedrera (the quarry) as it is called, is an apartment building on Passeig de Gracia designed by Gaudi. The large central atrium, signature ironwork balconies (each is different), roof top "soldiers" and mini-towers, and walk through of one of the apartments, complete with period furnishings make this a worthwhile stop. Like many of Gaudi's buildings, even the apartment rooms have curved walls.

Good place to visit... nice peace of Art for Gaudi!. This is probably one of the biggest homes that Antony Gaudi built in Barcelona. So, if you visit this one, you may not need to visit the other Casa homes that Gaudi did. We enjoyed with the family this home and its nice architecture.

Origins of Star Wars. We arrived early in the morning and were taken directly to the rooftop where not so many people were in attendance and that was great for photography. It was hard to know which to photograph first and from what unique angle. the Star Wars these was definitely there as many chimneys looked like storm troupers of a sort. The chimneys were made of unique and differing materials. The four together were my favourites. Then we moved into the attic and enjoyed the multimedia presentations about Gaudi and his theories on using parabolic arches etc. Then on to the apartment which was very well presented. The only downside is that in August, there are going to be crowds and that can detract very slightly. All in all, I love the Gaudi style and imagination.

One of the main Gaudi's works!. La Pedrera is one of the most important projects designed by Gaudi, using curves and organic forms as a homage to God. For those who love art and architecture, La Pedrera is a must see in Barcelona.
Wow !. One of the most inspiring buildings we have ever seen, or toured. Magnificent to think that one man's mind sees its literal concrete expression in three dimensions of beauty form and function.

Barcelona City. What an amazing place Gaudi was so far ahead of his time when he designed this building - it is so modern and yet Gaudi died in 1926 at the age of 74. Well worth a visit if you are in Barcelona.
Amazing building. Amazing architecture. Nothing is symmetrical. Extremely unpredictable and out of the ordinary. I guess this is what makes Gaudi intersting.

good sample of Gaudi´s architecture. When you find this building it impact you because it is totally diferent of all that is around this one appear to be a mud building of round shapes with phantoms in the top of the chimenies
You will enjoy

Magical Jazz Nights - wonderful experience. We visited Barcelona after many years of planning it and yes we finally made it - two couples enjoyed 4 days in this city full of color and life. We were told to visit la Padrera and while looking to book our tickets online we found out we could do the Jazz night event on the top of the la Padrera building. Highly recommended, this will stay in our memories as a lifetime experience, excellent atmosphere, it all felt surrealistic just like Gaudi's works. Wonderful. A must do when in Barca.

Gaudi's another attraction. this is also very near to Gaudi's another house - casa batlo, just 5 minutes walk. you should visit both houses together. it is city centre. open till late evening. café nearby too. souvenier shop inside too.

Sentinals on the Roof. After 4 visits to Barcelona, I finally visited La Pedrera. It is my least favorite of his works, but I am glad I saw this place. It definately felt more like a business ran this building than Casa Batllo. The line for tickets was long, there is an option for an evening concert and tour also. (this is also something that is offered at Casa Battlo)There are a few private apartments still in this building, but business offices utilize the rest of the space. Your tour is really of one apartment that is reconstructed and the roof. There is a large gift shop on the entrance level.
Not his best work. It was still very nice to see and visit especially the rooftop but not his best work. If i had to choose to see Casa Batllo or Casa milla, I would definitely pick Casa Batllo.

The rooftop is all worth it!. If you want to see amazing sculptures and great city views, head to the rooftop of La Pedrera. Even the outside of the buidling is a piece of art. You'll be taking endless pictures of the magnificent building and rooftop chimneys!

I want to move in. Its unbelievable that people lives in this masterpiece. don't forget to preorder tickets so you can skip the queue outside, and take your time on the roof to see all those crazy chmneys

Preferred this to Casa Batllo. My fiancée think I'm crazy but to me, this house showed the genius of Gaudi's work, brilliant architecture but not so crazy it seemed uninhabitable.Make sure you go on a dry day so that you can go up on the roof, the first day we tried it was raining and the staff there kindly informed us that we would be better off coming back when it was dry so we could get the full experience.The audio guide is also worth the money and the exhibition in the attic will take you an hour or so on it's own so make sure you leave plenty of time to do your visit justice.

Fabulous Gaudi. Definitely worth the visit and worthwhile getting the audio too. This takes you back in time and really gives you an appreciation of the architect Gaudi. There are also interesting stories about some of his other buildings including La Sagrida Familia in the attic. Loved the apartment and the way in which Gaudi incorporated natural light into all the rooms. Brilliant.
A great tour with an audio guide. It's a wonderful place, and the audio guide takes you around everything starting with the building and ending with the history of Antoni Gaudi and his work.

Unique. A Must Visit. Another piece of unique Gaudi architecture. La Pedrera is worth the visit if you are ever in Barcelona. We used a local tour company in Barcelona to "skip the line". This was WORTH it. It saved us many hours of waiting!

Quirky. Chimneys are great but photo opportunities can be spoiled by inconsiderate tourists. Maybe a wee bit expensive for tour of attic apartment and rooftop. Building is incredible. Go early as queues build up during day
Never seen anything like this. This is one of the most beautiful and unique places I've ever seen. The rooftop is so special and offers really wonderful views. This is a must see!

Great night tour. We took the night tour of La Pedrera with the dinner before. We loved the night tour, the roof top beautifully illumintaed, the night time city scape, just magical.The dinner before the trip was nice. The restaurant is lovely, delightful ambiance. The menu is set, no choice, We were just presented with a platter for our main and same for dessert. My husband loved it but I'm not a sea food lover so couldn't eat much of it. It took a little sorting out to find anyone who knew where we should go to for the meal, the lady in the ticket office at La Pedrera was bordering on rude which spoiled the special treat a little. I would recommend this as a special treat.

Really interesting building. We went to see this as I'd read about it. it was beautiful. The light in the building is wonderful and Gaudi was so clever to imagine this amazing building. It is definitely worth a visit.

Fantastic sights of a stunning city. I really enjoyed my visit here, I did the night time tour. Only 30 people so was very special, with a private tour guide. I can definitely recommend a visit to this amazing building

Excelent. La Pedrera is another great creation of Gaudi that can't be missed when visiting Barcelona. Casa Batlo is also in the vicinity so you can shoot 2 rabbits with one bullet :)Didn't get inside but also seeing it from the main street was a good memory.In the evening the house is even greater !

Very cool!. The rooftop is one of a kind, the architecture and the view combine make this attraction well worth the visit! The apartment in side is still decorated as they had it. Lots of interesting choices in the interior design.
Another must see!. We took the nighttime tour with dinner at the end. wonderful tapa menus! the house and furnishings are amazing! really worth seeing!
sightseeing. Had a cheap ticket. But mostly I enjoyed the amount of information regarding Gaudi's history as well as the 3 floor's exhibition and the terrace with view to BCN city
don't miss!! a must see. If you appreciate arts and culture or even architecture, then you CAN'T afford not to spend quality time strolling through the wonders of Gaudi!!!!!!! a must see

Gotta See Gaudi. This is one of the two most famous Gaudi buildings in Barcelona, though there are numerous other buildings or features that were designed by Gaudi around town. We were a bit hesitant to go in since you can see the amazing architecture from the outside. However, we went inside and were glad we did so. The interior is as interesting as the exterior, as is the story behind it. For the price of admission, we believed it was a worthwhile tour. Btw, they have available English language headsets for your walking around.

Nice work by Gaudi. Worth the visit. This is the place with the many, terra cotta chimneys you have probably seen. The interior courtyard, the roof top (chimneys and view), and the attic (which contains models and a very nice museum) make this worth the money. Recommendation would be to book this (and all tickets) online ahead of time. It lets you skip what can be a considerable line. We were glad we did!

for Guadì's fan. if you have to choose between Casa Battlo and La Pedrera, go for Battlo.by the way... the inside isn't worth the ticket, but the roof is! if you are in a rush go straight up (consider the fee is around 20,00 Euro), if you have time take the audioguide (really well done)

Our Introduction to Gaudi architecture. It was hard to know what to expect from the photos in the guide books, and now I understand why! This building defies description from architectural and artistic standpoints, not to mention imagination, form vs function, and "breaking the rules". I liked the organic forms (yes, even the rooftop sentinels) but I also felt like there was a little too much going on, so that it would be hard to live in a place with all this visual activity.

Cool in its own right, but not worth the money. If you really want to experience Gaudi's work, see La Sagrada Familia or Casa Batllo. This isn't anything ground breaking when it comes to Gaudi and the €20 per person with audio guide is pretty steep. Save your money and just take pictures of it from the street and go visit Casa Batllo. You won't be missing anything. For €5-8, this would be a more in line with what you get.

First floor is free only sometimes. For us it was too expensive to go to the roof,but we'd read in our guide that visiting only the first floor is free. However, this is only possible if a temporary exhibition is displayed, and there is none till September 2013.

I wish I could live here. Gaudi's first commission for an apartment is actually two apartment buildings that almost can not be described. For a student of life, art, architecture, imagination or just plain form and function you must see this piece of Gaudi's work which also serves as the Gaudi Museum.

More Gaudi. very close to Casa Batlo. See them in the same day.
Buy your tickets ahead of time to avoid the line.
Outstanding. Such an unusual place, unique. Well worth the entrance fee, you will take loads of photos. Get there early or go late when it is quieter. Fascinating place. Loved it!

Up on the roof top!. Gaudi's genius is never ending. A fantastic visit and a 'must' whilst in Barcelona. Both the roof top and the apartment building is full of design and interesting quirky features.
Another Gaudi marvel. Must see this if doing the Gaudi architecture tour. Not as impressive as Casa Batllo but unique in its own way and has amazing views of the city from the roof.

Awesome... I almost cried. Take the audio guide: it's worth every penny. Go straight to the terrace (take your sun glasses out in the elevator - love the sensation of almost getting blind with the sun shines directly at your face, and love the sensation of discovering Gaudi as your sight comes back). Play the audio guide – if you love architecture, beat you will almost cry when the music starts (as it says: take a calm and comfortable spot and listen to the only words that can describe this place)

Another must see for Gaudi's works. The building has a museum dedicated to Gaudi's works that allows you to see how he managed to create some of his masterpieces.The rooftop is a surreal landscape where the chimneys and vents have been transformed into almost alien looking beings!
Worth a visit. A visit of the building, mainly the roof and one appartment is worth it, just to see the work of Gaudi. The reason I didn't give it 5 stars is because I found it a bit pricey...
Use an audio guide. Beautifull building and rooftop. Very impressive. Good audio guide. You shouldn't miss this ! Also visit the design shop Vinçon that is next door.
A taste of Gaudi. Hard to believe that this was designed by Gaudi one hundred years ago...he was so far ahead of his time, architecturally speaking!

Interesting but a very long wait. I enjoyed this visit but I wouldn't put it on my short-list for Barcelona. It was a bit crowded, a long wait and I wish I would have toured Gaudi's other apartment which was just done the street.

Must see. Remarkable structure with a great history, We did the night tour and there were only 18 of us guided through the building. Expensive, but worth it. Gaudi was such an interesting architect and person. Seeing this building stimulates your imagination. The creativity is superior. Style, craftsmanship and history all in one!

Must visit for Gaudi Fans and/or Architecture enthusiasts.. This is work of art and architectural genius together. By the time we visited La Pedrera, we were as it is awestruck by Gaudi's genius. We thought no matter what we need an audio guide, and we thoroughly enjoyed it.The house showcases apartments of Upper class of those days, you will be amazed to see the emphasis paid on the details.I felt the entry ticket is little overpriced, but we had already seen so much of Gaudi's work that me and my husband had completely become Gaudi fans, so we really did not want to skip La Pedrera.Just a few suggestions that might help make your visit more fun:1. This is more crowded that Casa Batllo, we had to wait in the queue for 15 mins, which we didn't mind much. So, if 15-20 mins is ok for you, don't bother much about buying tickets online.2. Use the discount coupons (that you get from Bus Touristic or other places) when buying tickets.3. Please please get an audio guide, experience really will be much less fun otherwise.4. The staff might ask you if you would like to have a picture clicked, which they will later frame and give you for 10 Euros. We got one, it was cute :)5. If you have to choose between Casa Mila and Casa Batllo, I suggest please don't because they are both very different just like Sagrada Familia and other cathedrals are different. But if I really had to choose, I would go for Casa Batllo.6. Audio guides cost the same, irrespective of the shorter or longer versions. So wherever you think you want to hear some more information about a certain section, select the number printed in red.Have a good visit !

Waaay overrated. This house has only a small portion opened to the public, but the entry price is very steep. I don't think it's worth 16,5 € to see only the very original shapes of the chimneys designed by Gaudi.

Secrets of La Pedrera - absolutely beautiful in the evening.. Highly recommend this tour. We pre booked and arrived 15 minutes prior to the tour. Casa MIla (aka La Pedrera) is absolutely beautiful. I met a couple who had done both day and evening tours and they said the evening tour was more beautiful. Our guide took us through the history of the house, we visited an apartment, the famous attic and then my favourite - the rooftop !Here we walked around, there are great views of the streets but there is more than enough to enjoy on the rooftop itself - absolutely amazing. We then went back down to the courtyard and had glass of Cava and some sweet nibbles. My favourite Gaudi tour by far.

Overrated and disappointing.. After experiencing Casa Batlo,La Sagreda Familia and Park Guell, this was extremely disappointing.We booked the tour on the internet.When arriving at Casa Mila,we were told that our tour was in Cataluna, not English.We had to go back the next night for an English tour.Our guide barely spoke English.It wasn't his fault, but he was really hard to understand.My wife and I were bored out of minds, and I never usually say that!However, after experiencing and becoming more and more obsessed by Gaudi's work. This place is most definately the weakest of all attractions.

Fantastic architecture, and people lived there!. We became hooked on anything Gaudi on this trip!!! This home is a total delight ... each room, each floor, the outside architecture - and you MUST see the roof!!! Such surprises!!

Secrets of La Perdera. Casa Mila was our FAVORITE part of the day. La Perdera (as its also known) is an absolutely breathtaking Gaudi apartment building. We made reservations the day we arrived (which I highly suggest you do) for an English "Secrets of La Perdera" walking tour. It seemed pricy at 30 euros per person, but it was SO WORTH IT! There aren't any secrets (they have some cool holographs for the evening tour) and as night falls, you get to see everything lit up beautifully, you get to visit a private residence, the attic (which was just beautiful) and rooftop with steps up and down in a wave-like fashion. It was amazing. Then they invite you downstairs for a glass of cava (or orange juice or water) and some delicious pastries.

Very Gaudi. Our wait in the queue was only 25 minutes which was not too bad. We thought 16.40 euros entrance and 4 euros for an audio guide was overpriced. But, the audio gives some useful information about the Architect and his work. The rooftop allows great views over the city, and there are some unusual designs to be seen. The Attic holds video and model information. The apartments were interesting to see. The building and design is FAB. It is a to do on your list. The gift shop has lots of books on Gaudi.

Very Interesting:). The tour was very cool:) I decided to do this tour instead of waiting in a really long line at the Sagrada Familia. The lines here was slightly long, but it moved really fast. I was able to go to the roof to see out across the city of Barcelona, see the attic, and Gaudi's apartment. The steps on the roof can be a bit steep. I highly recommend it!:)

COOL place.. Very modern and unique architecture. It is worth seeing. It was not the highlight of our trip to Barcelona and if you have limited time, you could skip it but since we had 5 days in Barcelona we decided to go. It is worth going if you've already seen the Sagrada Familia.

Evening tour a little rushed. First, the good - La Pedrera is a wonderful building and is well worth looking around. The roof architecture and the views of the city from up there are not to be missed, and there was much of interest in the interior.The bad - we paid 30 euros each for the evening tour. There were around 30 people on this tour which is far too many, it was hard to keep together and hear what the guide was saying. The tour lasted less than an hour and ended with a less than thrilling glass of cheap cava, standing around in the entrance.From talking to people in our hotel I think the better option is the daytime visit with audioguide so you can view at your leisure.

Amazing Casa Mila - La Pedrera. This multi-tenant building was *the* place to live for wealthy families xx decades ago -- and not just for the proximity to downtown, but mostly because the architect was Antonio Gaudi's. The rooftop view of Barcelona is spectacular and the apartment tour gives visitors a sense of what it is like to "live with" the home and furniture of Gaudi. There is a small exhibit of structural forms form nature that are said to have inspired Gaudi's very creative mind, and some prototype designs (see photo). A must-see if you want to be jolted out a mundane view of everyday life.

Scary on the roof. Loved the attic and installations of other Gaudi projects. Found the apartment fascinating. I found the roof a bit scary, too many steps without handrails and for a moment felt as if I might topple over the side.

Well worth a visit !. We went on a sunday morning - the queue was short and we reached the top in under 10 minutes! Its an amazing place - you get to walk in the main courtyard before getting a lift to the roof which is the highlight of the visit with its otherworldly chimneys awkwardly reaching for the skies and fabulous views of barcelona - its an absolute masterpiece. From the roof you go to the attic where there is a small exhibition within the equisite, cavernous roof space. You then get to spend some time walking around anincredible old apartment in the building - absolutely beautiful and my dream residence :)

Gaudi Masterpiece. Another architectural marvel by Antonio Gaudi, the La Pedrera is a museum as well as the offices for Fundacio Catalunya La Pedrera. There is an exhibit area, the apartments, attic and roof as well as the gardens.

Great rooftop. This is located extremely close to Casa Batllo so its very easy to do them both in one day. However, I felt La Pedrera/Casa Mila was disappointing after going to Casa Batllo which I thought was much better. The best part of Casa Mila was the roof which was interesting to see and provided amazing views and great photos!! Walking through the apartments was interesting because you saw how people used to live but design wise it wasn't nearly as amazing as Gaudi's other buildings in Barcelona like Batllo & La Sagrada. For me the roof is what made this place worth it!

Most enjoyable Visit. We made two visits, first in the evening when dark and then during the day and it was interesting to see the building under different light conditions. This is another building by the architect Antonio Gaudi. It has a rugged exterior in contrast to a much more refined interior. Built 1906-1911 around large vertical internal courtyards to afford natural lighting and ventilation to all rooms. The detailing and colours are typical Gaudi and most enjoyable. It is interesting to be able to walk across the undulating roofs and view the sculptured chimneys close up. One can do this during the day and at night (adequately illuminated).It is interesting to make comparisons with the Casa Batllo!

A Must See!. We loved going thru this building. We pre-booked are tickets, which is a good idea, cause the lines can get real long. We started a tour in the courtyard, then traveled to the roof. It was amazing to see how Gaudi used spaces. The large chimneys that also functioned as water cisterns and stairwells, as well as the attic space that was to be used by all the tenants. The museum area in the attic was very informative, and the apartment we toured was wonderfully restored. If you like architecture at all this is a must see!

Another Interesting Gaudi House. This house is not as interesting as the others in Barcelona but it does have a lot of information on how it was built and interesting Video's.The apartment is furnished but it just looks like they staged each room with average period pieces

An interesting, enjoyable evening tour.. I loved my tour of La Pedrera at night. The guide was great and she was able to bring the building's past to life through the use of silhouette video images used in certain window frames. Looking at the natural inspiration which Gaudi drew upon to create his buildings was also very interesting. The rooftop was superb and I would happily look round this beautiful building again. Going in the evening on a pre-booked tour takes the hussle/bussle out of queueing etc and I highly recommend it. My 22 year old neice loved it too and took loads of photos.

Night concert. The building us amazing and the museum is well done. I enjoyed the tour very much and is worth while. They offer concerts in the evening but sadly the jazz concert I booked was awful and many people left (including me) before the end. Get more information about the group before booking. The atmosphere, building and organisation is excellent - too bad for the choice of band...

Very Interesting..... It really is hard to believe that one person was responsible for so much work. It was pretty amazing to see the workmenship. I would recommend that you schedule your visit time and pay ahead, you can either do this on line or we actually did it through our hotel. Then you will not have to wait in the long line!

Another of Gaudi's master pieces. This building, also seeing it from the outside, is amazing. From the inside it's very interesting and it helps you learn Gaudi's way of working. It's more educational than architectonic, but it's worth seeing. In the night you can get a tour that takes you around places in the "day tour" you are not allowed to see.

The triumph of human quirkiness and creativity. Our hotel room was on the courtyard facing La Pedrera, so we had beautiful views of it throughout the day and at night, when several nights a week they would have jazz concerts on the roof. I honestly enjoyed touring La Pedrera more than the Sagrada Familia. I wouldn't take the tour if there was rain, as the roof is the best part, and don't forget your camera.

Worth the visit. The rooftop is stunning and the experience of seeing a kitted out apartment makes it a worthwhile visit. Buy tickets online to skip queues , no need to print the tickets a booking reference and your name will suffice.
VERY INTRICATE IRON WORK. A must see when in Barcelona. Another one of Gaudi's masterpieces. Each floor is unique and very intricate.
A must see place. This is one of Gauids nicest buildings. Absolutely worth visiting. Includes an interesting museum of an apartment .

Would be a shame not to see this. Just amazing! Love walking around on the roof and seeing the interior of the flat was great. Also there was an exhibition in the 'attic' showing you how Gaudi was inspired by nature. Shame about the high entrance fees though. Perhaps better early evening - out of the heat.

This Casa was def built ahead of its time. The architecture. The thoughts that was put into this in 1907 by Gaudi, its marvelous. The guided tour was helpful even though our guide struggled with some of his english
Nice rooftop. There's apparently some people still living here. An interesting piece of architecture with good views from the roof where you will find weird undulating sculpture.
Wonderful content and presentation. Gaudi's work is spectacular inside and out, but the presentation of supporting material makes this a truly fantastic and fascinating visit.
Good museum. The attic museum gives a good explanation of the geometry and engineering behind Gaudi's elegant designs. But if you just want to be awed by Gaudi's architecture Casa Batllo is better.
Visit the attic!. I didn't last time around. Now I saw what I had missed! The whole floor pays homage to the great man in a most Gaudi-ish manner.

The restuarant. The restuarant is amazing! Went in the afternoon and had a 3 course meal with wine and coffee for 25 euros. Considering this is a well know building I was very impressed with the price. And the food was lovely. The setting was pretty too.

rooftop was cool but rest not so great. Some of the staff were rude. Expensive ticket for what it is. The roof and the attic which is a small museum of guadis work were interesting. The apartment was interesting architecturally but a bit boring.

Unbelievable!!. What an amazing building!! We had this part of a tour from Context Travel and the guide was great! Learned so much! Be sure to go through the house and the roof and attic! What a creative genius! Interesting life as well! I must see in Barcelona!!

Wonderful half day in La Pedrera. Expensive entry at 20 euros, but well worth it. The roof is out of a fairytale, and it is quite easy to spend an hour or more up there. The attic is full of info about Gaudi and all his architecture, even my wife was fascinated and happy to spend time looking and reading about him. The attic space itself is fascinating, and there are a large number of audio visual displays to sit and watch.The apartment is a real eye opener, how the other half lived! A fascinating insight into how the wealthy of that time would have lived.Well worth the visit, try not to miss it!

Great Gaudi but preferred Casa Batlo. While Casa Batlo is a great showcase of Gaudi's work, Casa Mila is a bit more of a museum of Gaudi's general work and of apartment living at the time. You get to see an apartment, made up as it would have been, and the attic, which houses a Gaudi exhibition. The roof is the real spectacular part of the building, saving the best til last.

Interesting architecture. This house will give you a good insight on the Gaudi architecture. At least for me visiting Barcelona for the first time you understand that Gaudi has been very important for this city.

Loved it. One of the best Gaudi sites, and possibly my favourite one (even more so than the Sagrada Familia, as this felt more personal and more specifically his, rather than designed by an army of lieutenants working to his direction). Lovely to see a real building designed by him, and to get a feel for what it was like to live in - couldn't really get that with the Palau Guell, as that was built as a mansion for his rich benefactor, so I couldn't really "identify" with living in it. The apartment in La Pedrera was more "me" though.As you wander around (with an audio guide if you want for an additional charge) you get to see the sweeping courtyard, a big and informative exhibition of all of Gaudi's works (explaining everything from the Batllo rework to the shape of the hyperbolic arches), a restored apartment showing what the apartments would've looked like originally, and the amazing roof with the twisted smoke-like water towers and chimneys, and the scowling Darth Vader like roof-guards.Did get quite busy throughout - I was grimacing at an (American) family who were not only touching all of the priceless museum pieces, but even rearranged the tables and chairs in the kitchenette so that they could stage a nice family photo or something *rolls eyes*. Also the teens that kept pressing the doorbell on the apartment door.Nice gift shop at the end with lots of Art Deco and Art Nouveau toys, gifts and books.Loved it!

Another masterpiece by Gaudi.. I recommend to go there and take a guide (audio guide on several languages) to get to know the history if that house and how Gaudi used to work: how he suspended future objects, etc. very interesting. If you have a chance to buy ticket in advance, you'd better do it to avoid long line of queue.
Least Favorite Gaudi House. Of the Gaudi houses that you can see in Barcelona, Batlo and Palau Guell are better options to see than this house. If you are a Gaudi fan like us, the more the merrier!

Great Architecture. While it is pricey to get in and does not include an audio guide, the house was absolutely beautiful! Definitely worth it. You can see Gaudi's beautiful architecture as well as get incredible views of Barcelona from the roof!

Saw the roof, saw the views, should have seen Batllo instead. My wife and I were here on Tuesday afternoon July 16, 2013. Purchase your ticket online, then present your receipt at ticket desk inside past the very long lines that had no shade. My title really sums it up. Your tour starts at the top and you walk your way down. The roof is very nice and the views are great. Then you go to the attic - its an attic, that's it. Then lastly you go to one of the open apartments. If you have seen "I Love Lucy" on television, then you know what to expect from the apartment. Lastly take the elevator down to the bottom and out you go. I would only recommend going if you have done everything else on your list.

Interesting (awesome concert space). The house itself is not as impressive as others from Gaudi. It does however offer an amazing space for evening concerts on its rooftop. We attended a jazz concert and we thoroughly enjoyed it! Highly recommended. Great ambience and even greater musicians.

La Pedrera at night. What a unique place to visit. We took an evening tour, called Secret Pedrera and really enjoyed it. This was a tour which started at 9:00 pm, only for our group of 30 people, in English. The guide was provided by the museum and took us everywhere...the mezzanine, the apartment, the roof. The views from the roof are awesome as well! Definitely worth to visit, but make sure to book tickets in advance at their website. lapedrera.com. These tours sell out quick in the summer.
Must visit. Excellent place to visit to get close to Gaudi's work. Go early to avoid the queues. Very busy on the roof terrace but is a MUST SEE.
Worth visiting. Definitely a place that has to be seen; it has a controversial and unique design, characteristic to Gaudi's style!It's worth paying the money and going for a tour inside ;)

Night tour. It was magical. No crowds. Just magical lights and a sweet sweet visit. The attic is out of this world. The only available tour was in Spanish, which we don't speak, and it was still well worth it!

Worth a visit. The roof and attic of this restored example of Gaudi's work is definitely worth seeing once. I prebooked online before visiting and after handing my voucher to someone at the front of the line (without queuing in the line) it was quickly exchanged for tickets for me to enter without queuing. The roof is visually interesting but think it would be worth coming back one evening for a Jazz evening they run in the summer.

la predrera. this casa has more educational content than the other gaudi buildings, wonderful displays . one should plan to spend at least 2-3 hours here. again lines are smaller in the late afternoon

If you like architecture, you'll love Casa Mila. Another exotic idea for city living! I think living in a Gaudi building must be heaven....there are so many interesting details and surprises in his work, from the details on the windows, the floors, the doors, the open air courtyards to provide fresh air to the interior windows. I also really enjoyed the furniture from the era, which helped bring the period to life for me. We had our own guide, which was very helpful. The attic and roof were interesting as well. The roof held the only negative for me - I can't believe that Gaudi would put such ugly metal fencing on top. I was ttood it was original, but I just can't believe it. Overall, well worth the money.

La Pedera a Gaudi great!. Loved it but would advise purchasing the additional audio ticket to get the full experience. You need minimum 1 hour for a quick visit. I fitted it in before leaving for the airport by visiting at 9am when It opens. Great views from the roof and a beautiful building. If you love architecture it is a muse see.
Unique Architecture. If you like architecture - this is a masterpiece. This building has curvy walls and roof. Recommend getting the audio guide to fully appreciate the work by Gaudi.
