Amazing rooftop. While some part of Casa Mila is open to public, the main attraction is no doubt the roof top and its beautifully crafted chimneys. Do consider paying a visit to the museum in the attic where you'll find not only interesting models but also an intricate system of brick buttress supporting the roof top. The cafe downstairs is the great place to rest after your lengthy afternoon walk.

Interesting. Definitely worth a visit. The roof terrace is incredible and unique. From the attic it's more of a Gaudi museum/exhibition, it's worth having the audio guide for this (though it seems unnecessary to charge an extra ?4 for it). Not the most interesting Gaudi in Barcelona but definitely worth a visit.I bought my ticket online in advance and only had to wait for it to open.

Top of Barcelona's sights list. If you're in Barcelona, this should be at the top of your visiting list. The rooftop of this building is amazing. Also, if you want to learn more about Gaudi's work, pay 4 Euros for an audio guide.

Fantastic view and great insight to Gaudi's work. I'm not good with heights and felt a little scared at first after coming out of the lift and walking up the few steps to the roof top but I am so glad I did it! You can get great photos of the views of Barcelona and the sculptures up there - on a sunny day it was lovely walking around and around the walkways. This trip is really worth the money and time!! After the roof top, you go down through an apartment kept as it was when first built and is incredible before entering an exhibition about the building and the art work. You don't have to be an art enthusiast to enjoy this place, it's just amazing to look at and enjoy! Go early to beat the queues - we got on the red hop on/off bus at 9am with our first stop here and were some of the first in Casa Mila..when we came out the queues were building so best to get out early!

Not your average apartment building. Another wonderful building designed by Guadi! Get there early and do the tour. Have fun on the roof walking around the interesting structures he used as chimneys. Take in the view of Barcelona while you are up there!
Great!. Another beautiful place created by the great man Gaudi. You definitely need to visit this place. The roof is amazing.

Fantastic rooftop and museum. La Pedrera exceeded my expectations, especially after seeing Casa Batllo I expected this place to be bare and boring. But I was so wrong! The rooftop chimneys are so interesting, and you get a great view of the Sagrada Familia. But it was the museum with the models and videos that really gave me an appreciation of Gaudi's inspirations behind his creations, especially the way he designed the arches that are characteristic of all his masterpieces. Having visited Casa Batllo really enhanced our experience of La Pedrera and it's impossible to pick a favourite! We loved both!! Excellent museum and audioguide! Book online and you can go straight inside to pick up your tickets.
Gaudi at is best. Have a look around all over this place it will leave wondering where you are on parts and fascinate you on how well built it is.A brilliant mind able to put ideas into practice.
Gaudi. Nice sample of Gaudi's work, I didn't go inside but I really enjoyed the outside. Worth the visit for sure, one of the hot spots of Barcelona

Best place in Barcelona for souvenirs (but you can't take La Pedrera, except in miniature!). I know this may sound awful, but if you are someone who has/must take souvenirs back home, this is the place for quality designer items with prices for everyone. Always something different but totally in tune with the Catalan design ethic. Now they have also added a restaurant and terrace one could easily spend a morning or an afternoon here....not to mention the summer nights with a glass of cava and music, having, of course, visited the house itself!

Not as good as Casa Batllo. I was a lot less impressed by Mila than Batllo. The audioguide is less good, and it seemed to me that there is less to see, too.So if you only have time to visit one of the two famous Casas, go for Batllo (and take the audioguide!).But I must say Mila has 2 things to offer, that Batllo doesn't have : an apartment with furnitures, and a very particular rooftop (Batllo has a terrace, but not as impressive).

Very Interesting. We went when there were protesters outside the building. Although I don't know the details they were protesting that the bank owns this property and by going to this attraction we were funding the same banks that were evicting less fortunate. I wanted to see this attraction so I donated to their cause as well. It is very interesting site. We were able to get a better understanding of Gaudi's work. We got the audio tour and spend several hours here. Cost was $16.50 E. each.

Can't believe that flors are leveled. Antonio Gaudi's master piece. One of many in Barcelona.Make sure you stop by this building....Barcelona is unique city in the world for allowing artists express themselves and then implement that in everyday city life. AWESOME

Impressive architecture. This is one the most famous Gaudi's buildings in Barcelona along with the Sagrada Familia. It's an apartment building in one of the central streets, Paseo de Gracia. The design is modernist, and it's incredible to see the balconies and details on the façade. You can visit one of the apartments and see decorations of the 1900s. You can also go to the attic where there is an exposition of all other Gaudi's buildings and also explains how he used to design them. The figure with the ropes and the weights to see how to make the arches is impressive. The roof is very nice too, with all the warriors-chimeneys and the view you get from the inner patios and the surrounding area, including the Sagrada Familia. In the basement there is a free exposition area, nice to see as well to see one of the inner patios and the first floor of the building.

Evening tour. Incredible building and the evening tour ensured limited numbers of people to share it with. The guide (having trouble remembering his name but a very cute looking ex-ballet dancer) was very knowledgeable, entertaining and good humoured. My 2 words of warning:1. If you are asked if you need to take the lift up and you are hesitating then say YES... we werent told how far up we had to go and being rather unfit with knee problems i nearly had a heart attack to get to the top!2. If you take the dinner option before hand then be prepared for local tasting menu (tapas). I dont think either myself, my husband or daughter really appreciated the food and was glad we had had a sandwich before hand. However: the cake (you could choose which one from a large selection) as dessert was wonderful
the roof!. A very original roof, like most roofs by Gaudi. A good view of the city. Alternatively you could go for a drink to the roof of Hotel Ohm and from there watch the roof at La Pedrera.

Amazing decoration by Gaudi. Visiting BCN Gaudis La pedrera-Casa Mila is really worth a visit specially the roof.ask for special events at casa Mila as there is often in summer concerts and activities.Easy access from city center and paseo de gracia street is excellent for shopping and for very good restaurants

Disappointing. We booked in advance for the evening jazz performance on the roof for the last night of our stay as my husband is a great jazz fan. What a disappointment! It's not a cheap evening and we were really looking forward to it. We had to eat early in order to make the time and then still had to queue (although it was quite a short queue for Barcelona). The mini tour we got was quite good although we didn't get to see very much as we would have had to pay extra again for the extra tour.It was a really hot, humid night and thought it would be a lovely experience to hear good music in such fabulous surroundings. The roof area however was stepped quite steeply in several distinct areas (and we were to sit in one of the stepped areas) and to get a place had to clamber through groups of people, not really able to see where you were going. At one point I stepped around one person thinking she was on one of the lesser steps to find myself stumbling down a steep step and banging my knee. Eventually found a space for us, although we couldn't see much of the trio because of the design of the roof. Thought once we'd got settled with a glass of cava that we could enjoy the evening but .... the jazz was awful. I'm not a jazz enthusiast but my husband is and he wasn't impressed at all. The Otto Preminger Trio was not worth the wait, the struggle to get seated and the heat! We soon felt we wanted to leave but felt a little embarrassed that we would have to battle through several groups, up and down steps and go past the trio to get out but, once we saw several others leaving, we took the plunge and weaved our way out.We were really fed up as we'd raced through dinner to what we thought would be a fabulous finale to our brilliant stay in Barcelona but was a real let down instead. Shame - it was the only place to let us down during what was a fabulous holiday.
Incredible shapes. Amazing architecture and rooftop sculptures, all appear randomly placed, wonderful to walk around the rooftop in and out of the shapes.

Museum, roof-top jazz band & cava package. We went to La Pedrera for a couple of hours one evening. Our package deal for 27 euros per person included a chance to see the inside of the building by way of a visit to the small Gaudi museum, a live jazz band on the roof-top and a glass of cava. There's so much of Gaudi's presence in the city if you look for it, and the museum proved to be very interesting about La Pedrera itself and Gaudi's other projects in Barce. The roof-top was fabulous at night, although I appreciate why they wouldn't allow anyone a second drink (not even to buy). There are quite a lot of big steps and although it's safe enough for sober adults, there aren't any barriers surrounding the rooftop. Rightly so, because they would probably ruin it.
Wow. I was really impressed by Gaudi's talent in this building. Thought the price of admission was a bit high.

Another Gaudi Masterpiece. I did a night tour of Casa Mila. Having done a Gaudi walking tour, I could better appreciate all of the stunning elements to this unusual architectural specimen. There are surprises galore in the detail. Definitely include this on your "to do" list when visiting Barcelona.

Somewhat of a disapointment. After seeing Casa Batllo and Palue Guell I did't think this was worth the high price of admission! Most of the building are private apts. Went to the roof to view the Gaudi chimineys and thats about it. Outside is nice but thats free. Go here only if your are a Gaudi fan.

Well preserved Gaudi house from the 1920s. The entry price is about 18 eur (expensive!). It contains a well preserved floor with about 6 rooms maitained just like they were in the 1920s. This part is pretty good. Apart from this, there is a small musuem in the "attic" containing tiles and furniture from this and ther Gaudi houses and a visit to the rooftop. Nothing else.
great Gaudi house and love the rooftop. very cool. would recommend seeing and standing on the rooftop! nice museum downstairs. love all the Gaudi structures but this is one of my favorites
Triumph of disciplined genius!. La Pedrera - as well as Casa Battlo and Sagrada Familia - are a true manifestation of human genius, incredible power of creativity and disciplined intellect!
Fabulous rooftop!. Loved this Gaudi building. Great tour and museum. Loved the architectural elements. Nice gift shop too!

La Pedrera. Unlike any house you will ever see. The outside walls are wavy and the inside of the house is very unique. The roof has unique chimneys that look like helmets. A lot of aspects of nature were used in the designs. There are also displays that show the artists architectural works from his career.

Inspirational.. A momentous building with a fabulous exhibition that tells a wonderful story of the life of Gaudi, with great background information on some,of his better known work.
Highly recommend visiting, and spend the extra to get an audio guide, otherwise it will not have as much meaning.

So creative!. Beautiful and really creative building. The roof is amazing. No big lines to enter in june.
It is incredible that Gaudi was doing such an avant gard work for his time!

Great roof, but not much of interest inside. The famous roof is wonderful, but the exhibits indoors are fairly dull. Seems a bit like they've put anything related to Gaudi in there to pad out the visit and make it worth the money. Casa Batllo is much better - loads to see indoors as well as out.

Another classic by Gaudi. Another stunning piece of architecture by the one and only Gaudi, this one gets super busy as the day wears on. Though the exterior is something to see, most casual visitors can probably skip the long lines to see the interiors and the rooftop.

One of my favorites in whole Barcelona!. This place was incredible. The rooftop was like a site from Alice in the wonderland, the colors and shapes, everything was very impressive! And also the rooms with the furniture and stuff of its owners was a peek into history. I enjoyed this place so much!
Wonderful piece of architecture!. Good visit on a sunny day to understand the play of light and shadow through the high glazed windows. Take the audio guide.The roof top makes for a good view.

interesting. Expectations exceed reality. This tour will be especially interesting for architects and creative people. For ordinary people is not very impressive. There was a long line of open-burning sun. Not a little thought.

Interesting building. This building show-cases many of Gaudi's ideas. I found the architecture interesting, but it was his unique used of materials and structure that really did it for me. Spend a few euros and get the audio tour. It's worth it.

The rooftop took my breath away!. WOW! What an amazing experience! When you get to the roof, you cannot stop taking pictures...you just want to capture every little detail.
The lines move faster than you expect. Don't let a long line deter you!

Fantastic!. I love Gaudi's work, and hearing the stories behind the buildings he created. This place, as a private residence, must have been astounding. It's quite impressive as an apartment building too. The rooftop is beyond belief.

a de facto Gaudi museum. In addition to Gaudi’s fascinatingly disorienting rooftop, it also has a great exhibition that introduces the natural element that inspires Gaudi's works and showcases Gaudi’s major architecture projects with multi-media installation. I strongly recommend a stroll throughout the city to acquaint yourself with fascinating architectures. A modern architecture walk is ingenious Barcelona experience. Get the Barcelona Art Card to have an instant pass for this attraction instead of waiting hours in the lines.

Key piece of modernist architecture. We went on the night tour, which I highly recommend over the teeming masses during the day. I wish you got to see more of the building. That may happen in time, as people eventually move out and the foundation in charge of the building takes over more of the apartments.
Very unique and interesting. We enjoyed seeing this house given how it was created and the engineering and design behind it. Get tickets in advance and wait in the short line.

Big queues. Luckily we had been inside here on our last visit as the queues stretched right across the front of the building and around the corner! The roof is a must and worth the wait but not if you are scared of heights. I stepped out, freaked out, grabbed the nearest thing - a chimney pot - and hung on while they called the lift back, peeled me off and sent me back down!

A lovely building with amazing chimneys on the roof. This was built by Gaudi as an apartment building for Barcelona's wealthy. A lift takes you to the upper floors. The attic floor has an exhibition, probably of most interest to architecture students as it details the various aspects of the building. The roof is quite spectacular with the various decorative chimneys. You go up there and can walk around them. They are functional and were not just decorative. I think we queued for over an hour to get in, if I remember rightly there was a reduction for those under 29 so my children got in for a reduced rate. I loved the house but I preferred the other Gaudi house, Casa Batilo which is on the same street, Avenue de Gracias as I felt it was more informative. But Casa Mila is well worth a visit.

A great example of Gaudi architecture. La Pedrera is an apartment building that Gaudi built in the early 1900's and is very representative of the modernista Catalan style. It has a rounded undulating facade which was very progressive for its time. One of the apartments can be viewed and it is quite expansive. The exterior of the building I think is the most impressive so the steep admission price ,20 euros or so may be better spent on the Battlo house which has a much more interesting and ornate interior.

Wow!. Wheelchair access to all bar the roof. You'll need some mobility to manoeuvre over the steps plus some doorways in the apartment are a little tight; however staff were helpful & I thoroughly enjoyed my visit

Really interesting. Great place to see more of Gaudi, besides the Sagrada Familia. The man was a genius and one can see it in every little detail of the Pedrera. The rooftop, the attic, the apartment with the furniture. Really interesting. Great views from the rooftop made awesome pics too.

Preferred choice of two houses. Preferred choice of two houses.
Recommended architecture enthusiasts.
You can see the statues on the roof, the Gaudi's Folly.
Beautiful Mid-Case-floor museum.
An impressive model apartment.
The price is expensive, but if you are debating between the two buildings. This house is recommended.

From the outside. Ok - we visitied and looked from the outside so I can only say that yes it was truly a cool facade - and I wouldn't miss seeing it - but that is really all it was in my busy trip - I loved the Gaudi vision - but wasn't inclined to pay to get in.

Gaudi at his best. La Pedrera - definitely worth a visit (after Sagrada Famiglia). It's is as expensive as Casa Battlo - around 25 Euro. The house is very unusual and interesting to visit. Walk on the roof is the best part with great views of Barcelona.

Another Gaudi Masterpiece. If you have visited La Sagrada Familia and Parc Guell, you need to complete you Gaudi Tour with this visit. The architectural genius is breathtaking. The use of natural light and colors is amazing. Couple of notes, the line for the tickets may be 15 to 25 minutes, if you can plan eralier, try to buy them online. The fee is quite high but understandable.. Try to be there early as it gets to crowded after a ouple of hours, it becomes almost impossible to take decent pictures whike avoidng someone elses arm or head :)

Interesting, but not amazing. Gaudis work is all over Barcelona and you can tell Pedrera is one of his works a mile off...but it just doesnt stand out. I have not been inside, which may make a different as even from outside the terrace looks fantastic, but for the entrance price I do not believe it would be worth it (€16+). There is currently a photographic exhibition on inside for free which allows you see the lower floors on the route to it, so check this out for a sneak peek!

Totally worth the 20 Euro!!. This place was right down the road from my hostel, so walking by it each morning was not a problem. Gaudi is an amazing artist and this place from the outside was stunning. I went into and paid for the audio 20Euro and thought that was worth it. They give 2 options for audio (same price) and I took the longer audio (70min) and was very happy I did. I could fast forward when I wanted or skip stuff as I pleased. To get in there is a line starting around 11am, before that there is not much in the way of waiting. But even with the lines, they go fast. IT is worth the look. Amazing view, lots of history.

One of Masterpieces. Once in a lifetime attractions, go and enjoy for 1-2 hours, get your batteries charged for great photoes. Audio guide is useful to understand details. The bad part is the fee for 18€. Rooftop is amazing to see around. And also there is a night experience tour to join. Get an onlice ticket, the queue may be 45 min. long.
great tour, love the roof. The famous apartments that Gaudi made. loved the roof and views! Follow a docent and enjoy the museum and apartments!
Unusual. This house is so much fun, we had young children with us and they loved the unusual roof top sculptures. Gaudi was a genius of design!

What a spectacle.. Not only is the trip to the roof worth every penny of the entrance fee but the audio (75 minute version) gives you such a wonderful, detailed explanation of the building's inception and creation. The view from the rooftop is spectacular but not for the faint-hearted! There are displays of natural items that inspired Gaudi's work as well as rooms laid out with furniture and furnishings of his time.If you see nothing else of Gaudi's work this is a MUST!
Gaudi. How can you not be impressed with someone who blends different elements of texture, metal and whatever is available. Worth seeing and exploring

Summer Evening Jazz night is a MUST!. We looked at buying general entry tickets for La Pedrera, but instead were drawn to the evening Summer Jazz for a very small additional price. The ticket gives you entry to the exhibition, access to the stunning roof and a glass of cava to watch the band with. The views were breath-taking, the band were incredible and everyone at the concert was grinning from ear to ear! Honestly the highlight of my trip to Barcelona, felt like a totally exclusive, once in a lifetime experience!

Overpriced. Interesting certainly, but not worth €18. Only students of architecture or die hard Gaudi fans need apply. For anyone else, admiring the building from the street would be the best course of action.

Beautiful views but expensive.. Being up on the roof was the highlight. The views around the city was wonderful. I do however think the entry fee was expensive for what you got to explore. I would recommend going purely for the roof!

Another proof of Gaudi's genius.. Contrary to many reviewers who seem to prefer the roof, my personal preference was the apartment where you can see Gaudi's genius coming through in his design and all the small details. Don't get me wrong, the roof and the attic were indeed very interesting but it was the apartment that captivated my attention the most. We visited at the end of the afternoon so lines were not very long to get tickets (less than five minutes). It's true that it's a little expensive as it was almost 50 euros for a family of four with two young children and no audioguide. Still, it was worth it. A great way to see Gaudi's magic applied to every day life.

Enjoyed this more than Sagrada Familia. I think maybe because it's more relaxed (i.e. less crowded) I had a better time here than at the Sagrada Familia. There's good examples of Gaudi's style here and the view from the roof is quite nice and you don't have such a large crowd to contend with.
Rooftop Jazz on Thursday nights. Another Gaudi "not to be missed" building. From the gift shop to the towering "guards" on the rooftop, this is Gaudi at his finest.
Do not miss the roof. Of the many Gaudi-experiences to be had in Barcelona I enjoyed this the most. Somewhat less crowded than, for example, Sagrada Familia and not overwhelming.

A Great Site. Once we saw La Sagrada, I was even more excited to see La Pedrera. Gaudí's work is just amazing. My best advice for visiting this attraction would be to buy your tickets online so you can avoid the long line, get there early, and also get the audio guide. I enjoyed the information it gave so I could really soak up and appreciate all the details. The rooftop just blew my mind, the architecture and art of it, just amazing. This should definitely be on your must see list if you are in Barcelona. Really close by is his other apartment, Balto. We didn't tour that one, but just walked by to check out the facade.

Overpriced. Hey, Casa Mila is OK - they've done their best to try to pad out what's there to justified the huge entry fee. But the price is too steep and they're just fleecing visitors. If you've other things to do in Barcelona and not enough time, you could happily give this a miss (unless you're an architecture/ mathematics/ engineering nut).

Even better than what I thought!. This museum is a fine example of this artist's work. The best part is the tour of the apartment and you can go inside most of the rooms. This type of interactive tour I think is a great way to see the artists work.

Book the evening tour or the jazz evening .... See this incredible house at night - floodlight chimneys on the roof overlooking Barca. Explore the turn of the century interior - somewhat incongruent with the modernista architecture. Imagine how rich Mr Mila must have been to commission this building! A truly magical experience . And they throw in una copa de cava!

I loved the crooked hallways. My guidebook said that residents here should have had snakes as pets since the walls were all curved. I loved that about Gaudi's apartment. Tons of Art Nouveau for lovers of that, and of course the views are wonderful.

Worth waiting in line for.. Most of all I loved being on the roof terrace. I didn't choose a good time of day and I didn't pre book. I'd suggest going before 12 or long after lunch as I wanted to spend time on the roof but it was too hot to stay too long at this time of year. The light and the spaces made this interesting for me as an artist and teacher. That also applied to the display in the attic where I would like to have spent longer. I recommend you pre book as that will save you an hour of standing in the hot sun.

A wonderful building with lots of reasons to go.. Loved this building and the tour of it. It's a fabulous insight into architecture of Gaudi, but of interest because of the period, to construction or architecture enthusiasts. Children will find it interesting also. A must in Barcelona.

Amazing. It is a bit pricy to visit but an amazing place to see. I loved the amazing sculptures on the roof top. Made for some interesting photos. The apartment was really cool, wish they made apartment buildings like this one today. I would suggest getting tickets ahead of time or you might have to wait in a line.
awesome! great place. You can visit both, Batló and la pedrera although they're both gaudi's, they are different and both are very beautiful and nice. I loved it!!!

My Favorite of the Gaudí Attractions. I think I got the best sense of Gaudí's intense genius while visiting Casa Batllo. The tour guide was excellent and the building, well, as with most of his works, there's really nothing else like it. Plus, unlike La Sagrada Familia, this is a project that was completed and used by real people during his lifetime.

Must in Barcelona. When compared to the Sagrada Familia this is an amazing example of the practical side of Gaudi. On top of the incredible shapes and forms which were scandalous for its time, the apartments are extremely livable ... do notice the amount of light which every room gets, even those which don't have access to the street. Notice as well the lack of straight lines in the whole building and enjoy the flow of the structure. Truly amazing.
Gaudi magic. Wonderful experience to visit this amazing building. We toured the apartments 1 day and then enjoyed a jazz performance in the rooftop another evening. Just loved both!

Modernisme. We went to La Pedrera /Casa Mila with a private tour guide on June 11th .We booked through Barcelona Day Tours. The building is curvy inside and outside with balconies made of wrangled iron.It is located on the corner of the fashionable Passeig de Gracia.We first took the elevator to the roof top which affords sweeping views of the city.The roof is like a futuristic garden.Chimney stacks, ventilation fans and stairway exits are enveloped in modernisme art and sculpture by Catalan architech Gaudi.Parabolic arches covered with Valencia tile.The attic has a lot of information about the history of the building and Gaudi .We toured the top most apartment.Very nicely decorated in period furnishings.Price is 15 euro pp so 2/3 hours should be spent here.No visit to Barcelona is complete without seeing this unusual masterpeice by Antoni Gaudi.
A must visit place in Barcelona. Very interesting and unusual architecture like all Gaudi's works. Be prepared to queue for tickets and they are not cheap either!

Fantastic. I am a local, so La pedrera-Casa Milà is part of my everyday scenery. Despite seeing it almost every day, I still find it so beautiful! Magical architecture, sinuous shapes, chimneys that look like medieval soldiers, so many decorative details... Located in the northern part of elegant boulevard Passeig de Gracia, amidst luxury stores, La Pedrera stands proud as an emblem that beauty never goes out of fashion. Go up to the roof and admire the centinel like chimneys and the great views of the city. Walk slowly on Passeig de gracia and admire the lamp posts, the buildings, the terraces, it's one of the most beutiful streets in Barcelona.

Wonderful exhibit - and you won't need to wait 2 hours at the Sagra Familia. We had a great time exploring this beautiful bldg, including the roof --- and exhibit in the "attic" about Gaudi was very worthwhile. In fact, with their models and videos we decided not to wait 2 hours to get into the Sagra Familia. We were dubious about paying the price to enter, but it was really worth it.

Anything but a "Quarry". Another amazing building to visit and experience. Yes the roof is impressive but I found walking through the attic more impressive , not in the sense of aesthetics but construction. The engineering brilliance of Gaudi , the artisans and workers who worked with him is astounding.
HANITA1956. I was amased, so wonderfull. It is a work of art. must visit the house to start understand how Genius he was. try to get a guide for more understanding.

confused. outstanding from outside,the roof top amazing and the apartment too furnished and decorated with stuff from the begining of 20th century.i am confused as me and my wife paid 36 euros (2 tickets and one audioguide) to see the roof and the one apartment when in sagrada familia i paid 14 euros and i stay there more than 2 hours.

Beautiful and expensive. what a shame this monument is so expensive even if you are student. Otherwise, without the fact is one of the Barcelona famous monument, Inside there are two cute vintage shop.
Breathtaking. Always blows peoples minds when they have seen the outside and then go in and seem even more! Well worth spending an hour here and learn a bit about the man.

Wonderful Rooftop. Buy your tickets online first! The rooftop was amazing and I spent a long time up there taking it all in. The attic was great too with all the info about Gaudi - wish he was still here! The interior was interesting but not as captivating. Worth a visit.
amazing roof. stood in a short queue which moved quickly.the roof is outstanding and breathtaking. the apartment beautiful.

Really enjoyed Gaudi. After seeing Sagrada Familia, Casa Batllo, and Parc Guell, we decided to also visit La Pedrera on our last afternoon in Barcelona. The line was not too bad on a Monday after 4 pm. The audio tour was extra so we did not purchase it. The roof was really cool and really enjoyed walking around it. I also enjoyed the exhibits in the attics where you could learn more about Gaudi and his architecture. The apartment part of the tour was not as interesting but still enjoyed it.
Great tour. Our favourite is still Casa Battlo but you have to see as much Gaudi as possible when in Barcelona. Casa Battlo is much more upscale and more intimate feeling.

Family visit to Barcelona. This is a marvel to look at - we did not go through this building, just observed from the outside - it is really worth the time to see it and the architecture surrounding it.

Not to be missed. Great place to learn more about Gaudi and to see a place he built from the ground up. Rooftop has nice views and incredible curved pathways and chimneys. Interesting to tour the furnished apartment as well.

Guadi enthusiast, a must go. Get tickets on line and avoid the line. Beautiful structure, educational audio tour. Guadi a true master. Take to time to view the inside of this building and learn the history of this local artisan and history in the process.

Educational opportunity. Again, purchase your tickets in advance! If you have to pick between the 2 Gaudi houses in this neighborhood, you'll need more time here and there are more opportunities for education. Form, function, philosophy, inspiration etc are examined in depth at Casa Mila.

Amazing history of Gaudi and interesting architectural marvel. I wasn't going to go in but the line was short so...I'm so glad I did! The architecture was amazing! If you are an architecture fan, there are great explanations of the architecture in the attic. It was nice to get a chance to see how an actual apartment looked as well. The rooftop is something spectacular to see! We wanted to go back for the nighttime tour and dinner - consider this but make reservations in advance because they were all booked on our last night, but if we get back to Barcelona we'll definitely do the night/dinner!

First class Gaudi experience. Emblematic must see site on any visit to Barcelona. Great views from the roof and an excellent example of Gaudi architecture - perfect for photo opps. Pricey - but worth it for the one time you'll visit - especially towards dark
Awesome!. This is a one of a kind experience. Gaudi was a genius. Breathtaking really! This kind of architecture does not exist anywhere else in the world -- in antiquity or in the present.

For Gaudi fans. Loved the overall structure and the visit to the roof deck where you can see the mountains to the beach. We had a great tour guide (who actually used to work there) who was able to give us great inside stories to the building. There was also an exhibit in the attic that detailed the construction. The line looked long, glad we skipped it with the tour.

Worth the trip to see this roof top. This amazing Gaudi work is really worth the visit...from the exterior of the building to the simply amazing roof top. The apartment is interesting though less dramatic....so busy it was uncomfortable and difficult to take in.
Fun night tour. We did the group evening tour that ended with cava, a nice treat. It is fun to tour something so popular in a small group of 20 people max. Great guide. Did not feel rushed.

visit batllo instead. you can only go to the roof. Its cheaper than batllo but you cant do much inside. I took some pictures from outside of the building and they where enough for me. Gaudi is such a genius!

Sculpted in stone?. This is a really great way to get to know the style of Gaudí.This building seems to have been sculpted from one piece of stone.Though it's, also, very costly to go inside (so is Casa Batlò, another piece of Gaudí), so, as there were a lot of queues and we were not sure about what we could see inside, we decided to go through our sightseeing after only visiting the exterior part of the building.

Casa Milá (La Pedrera) or How Less Is Better. One never ceases to marvel at Gaudí’s genius, and the façade and roof of the Casa Milà, also known as La Pedrera, live up to anyone’s standard of excellence and brilliance. The architect’s inventiveness sweeps one away. (And thus my overall rating of 5) But does the building warrant its entrance fee of 16.50 euros? One can only answer in the negative. By all means search it out, marvel at its undulating façade and take pictures. Then buy post cards of its roof. Unless you have a professional interest in architecture, the shameful price of admission is not worth what is gained by access to the roof. Rather, spend your euros on la Sagrada Familia or la Casa Batlló or the Parc Güell. And if you want to explore another modernist genius, visit the Palau de la Música Catalana by Lluís Domènech i Montaner.

Beautiful must see jazz night. We stumbled across this place after dinner and saw they have a jazz band play on the roof top at night. The next night we bought a ticket and we weren't disappointed. First you see a small museum that tells you everything about gaudi and his buildings then beautiful views as the sun sets you can see from the hills to the ocean while drinking champagne. Lastly of course the jazz band, they play for about a little over an hour.
Opulence and eccentric. Interesting, looks very eccentric and wild. Half museum, half apartments for the rich and famous. Truly unique.
Gaudi Architecture!!. Amazing vision. If you enjoy architecture you must see this ..the balcony on this building look likje marquerade masks.

Gorgeous building - a must see.. Even if you don't go inside the building, you must at least see the building from the outside. We paid the fee to see the inside and go to the rooftop and see the view from up there. If you like Gaudi, you must see this building. I'm told it's is stunning at night but unfortunately, we didn't get a chance to go back to see it at night.

Great Gaudi. We took the Runnerbean Gaudi tour, and picked La Pedrera as the Gaudi house to go into. The undulating lines of the exterior is just lovely. And I just have to see those chimneys! It was easy to buy the tickets online, and there's no need to print out the voucher. I just showed the email confirmation on my phone to the ticket person and we're in. The rooftop did not disappoint! It's a feast for the eyes. Loved the ice cream shapes and the storm trooper chimneys. The exhibit in the attic was very informative, explaining not just Gaudi's work on this house but his thought process for his other works as well. Beautiful furniture in the apartment. It's light and airy in there, just as Gaudi intended. Cute wind up toys in the gift shop.

Nice tour. Did the shortest audio tour and it provided a good amount of information. We only had an hour to spend here but if you have more time I would recommend the more detailed audio tour. City views from this unique roof top were excellent. Glad we do not have to pay to have film developed as we took lots of photos. Gift shop had a nice variety of Gaudi like souvenirs.

Go See The Other Gaudi Works Instead. We saw Sagrada Familia, Casa Batllo, Casa Mila, Parc Guell, and the outside of Casa Calvet. If you are wanting to visit Gaudi's works, I would skip this one. It's not nearly as interesting or well thought out as the others. If you would notice the time that Gaudi spent on this one, you will see that it was more of a "just make us something, anything" and he made this locale. There are a lot of artifacts from the era in this building, but I wish we wouldn't have wasted our time or money coming here.The most interesting parts of this are the rooftop and the brick inside the attic areas.
Truly Strange.. One of the most strangest buildings I have ever seen. One of the must see place's in Barcelona, outside, inside and on the roof.Really amazing.

So unusual!. We toured this after we saw the Sagrada Familia. Of course no comparison - church vs residence. Gaudi's talent & imagination was incredible. The tour starts on the roof, then the attic where you see some "history" of Gaudi and then an actual apartment.
Remarkable. We again didn't pay to go in this building, we passed it in the afternoon. It was grwat to see but the queues were long and we decided the most impressive part was the exterior.
Gaudi. Exotic design in the middle of the city. It is right that travel is important but when you see such things while you are traveling you decorate your life.
Well worth a visit. It is wonderful, the tour of the inside is worth the price of the ticket and the possible wait to go in.

Beautiful decour. Of course the outside of all of the Gaudi places are wonderful, but going inside this set of apartments and going on the rooftop was like a dream. It was great to learn the history of when people actually lived in these apartments and they have kept up the inside quite well and there are many rooms to see. The roof definitely sets the place apart, where you can catch some great views. The architecture of the roof is literally like a dream. It's a pretty entertaining tour.

see as much Gaudi as you can. While in Barcelona, see as much Gaudi as you can. Don't miss the under rated Palau Guell. It is an early commission, amazingly creative and beautiful, and the restored organ plays on the half hour in period music. We also visited La Pedrera and Park Guell, both amazing for different reasons, and the Sagrada Familia, spectacular. I'd like to return and see it when finished.
Beautiful. Didnt go into it but you will not see a building like it anywhere else, very beautiful piece of work.
Beautiful from the outside, but not worth paying the visit (imho). From the outside it is a beautiful building, but inside it is not very exciting or wonderful as Casa Batllo.

Have a look inside.. Not having been to Barcelona for a number of years it was wonderful to finally have access to the inside of some of Gaudi's creations. It is worth every euro to see how he wanted people to live. Lucky them is all I can say. It is fascinating to see inside the mind of this genius.

Amazing Gaudi. A must for your visit to Barcelona. Take the time to visit this amazing museum.
As well as the very interesting roof garden one has the opportunity to enter one of the apartments & look into the past. A very interesting architectural wonder.
The gift shops are full of lovely treats too.

Look from the outside. I have just stayed in an apartment across the road from here. I thought I should take a look inside. Unless you are an architect with a particular interest in Gaudi... dont bother. It is not inspiring and there is not a lot to see for sixteen euros.
Wonderful architecture. No wonder all the guides tell you to visit, should not be missed. Try to work out what he was thinking as he designed the buildings as well as the furniture. What a place!!

La Pedrera is a MUST. The restaurant is most perfect ..The music they play inside The terrace outside .. the food inside is excellent .. and very reasonable ..That s BEFORE you get in the house itself The appartement is so wonderful and from the roof you just melt in wonder and admiration of Gaudi's vision
Good!!!. Worth a visit. Its add to the beauty of Barcelona plus its in centre.. Easy to get and explore. You will surely love it. Try to get with guided tour to know its meanings n history
Pretty. I didn't go inside casa mila just visited outside, much prettier at night if your only planning on taking a look. We didn't have time to take the tour.

Interesting but slightly disappointed.... If you have time and love Gaudi then it is definitely worth your while to visit. I enjoyed our time here but the rain dampened our tour as we were not allowed access to the roof. The roof is where my husband and I wanted to go to in the first place due to the many photos we've seen of it. My rating may be very different had the weather been sunny.

Incredible. What a magnificent building!!!!! Gaudi is an amazing artist, me and my wife enjoyed so so much this visit. The top of the building, called terraza, was marvelous. We also had lunch in the restaurant, it was very goog, a little pricy but worths it.
stunning. Controversial now as it was when Gaudi built it. He was quite a visionary. Very interesting way to spend a couple of hours.

Very informative!. I learned so much about Gaudi's archichetural style and skills at this exhibit. I listened to every word. I also enjoyed seeing the fully furnshed apartment on exhibit. I thought this would be like the Casa Batllo tour, but it was different.

Can I live there?. Stunning building and Gaudi's apartment looks fairly modern given when he designed it. Was unable to visit the last time I came to Barcelona glad I made it this time. Would be good if they could open up more of the building for a restaurant so you could sit and enjoy the surroundings.

Another Gaudi Masterpiece.. No square corners in this building. The roof with with iits uniqe chiminey tops, Great views of Barcelona and Sagrada Familia. A great museum on the attic. And good examples of the appartments and how well to do people lived in that building. Amazing balconies.

A better feel for Gaudi. I was amazed at how the interior of the apartment building looked. I knew from touring other Gaudi works of art & architecture that it would be "unusual". But knowing that you could (for a price) live within the are was different. Park Guell was similar. But there is something about walking in from a hustle-bustle street to this marvelous place seemed surreal.I loved Barcelona! Obviously.
quirky beauty. We sat on one of Gaudi's benches across the road to observe this lovely building! Then strolled down the Rambla de Cataluyna, a really nice area.

Pricey entrance, but spectacular views and an interesting visit.. The rooftop views are great! Paying a bit more, you can get an audio guide in either an extended or summary version. The flat entrance rate is pricey, but we enjoyed the visit nonetheless!

The House. This is really something you need to see when you are in Barcelona. The building was designed by Antoni Gaudi and provides really an experience. The façade is stunning with its curved forms and must be seen both in the daytime and evening hours.The roof is what fascinated me the most with the curved surfaces and sculpted chimneys.Even the old apartment was interesting to see.It was quite a long queue to get into the house, but once we were inside, it was not very crowded.

Gaudi most achieved work. If you want to seee only one of Gaudi buildings, it is a good idea to choose this one. It is the one where his art was in its bes,t and it's also very interesting to see places inhabited. There is also a nice cafe in the ground floor, where you can enjoy live jazz
Worth a visit. Worth a visit to get your Gaudi fix. Plan on an hour or so and then decide if you need more Gaudi at Casa Batillo. We opted out of the latter.

Quite good. Visited here on the ‘La Pedrera by Day’ tour. The visit starts from the roof (by a lift), working down the way of the building. I feel the roof is the most interesting part: interesting architecture, also offering good views of the surrounding neighbourhood and Barcelona. The exhibition in the lower floors was less interesting, but still a comprehensive display of Gaudi’s work. As with other popular attractions in Barcelona, I would recommend getting the tickets online and skip the queue.

Really interesting with views. I knew nothing about this Gaudi creation, but wow! Well worth it. As with all of his creations, it's out of the box, imaginative and really interesting. I really enjoyed this. Lots of walking, if you take the stairs you save on waiting for the elevator...a good workout. The top,is fantastic with many sculptures to look at,mince viewsmofmthe city !! Recommend it. Was not too crowded but apparently in the summer it's really busy

La Pedrera, Barcelona.. While both La Pedrera and Casa Batllo are both worth visiting, La Pedrera is the most whimsical and interesting of the two. The rooftop views are great! Purchase your timed tickets online before your trip.
Recommend the audio tour. For an extra €4 I recommend to take the 75min audio tour - it was very interesting and informative. The rooftop was the highlight!
work of art. I did not expect such beauty, truly amazed at all the work of art in Barcelona. It is a beautiful city with so much to see end enjoy.

Very modernist. Looks like a roller coaster of melting-ice cream eaves. Very,, very interesting. Make sure you tour the rooftop as he has lots of weird columns and a great view. Buy your ticket at the Information building so avoid a very long line.

Well worth a visit. It's pricey but well worth a visit. The roof top and the view is amazing and the exhibition in the attic is excellent. Lovely little film of Barcelona around the turn of the 20th century. The appartment that you can then look round is an insight into the wealthy way of life in the 1920s and the mod cons that were there as well as Gaudi's quirks. The design of the whole block is lovely. Easy to spend 2-3 hours there.

Amazing Gaudi house. Rooftop views (but will be crowded), amazing shapes, attic vaulting and has interesting info on Gaudi and his life, apartment furnished with typical period furniture, ironwork balconies. Can be prebooked to avoid the queue.

Amazing. This is certainly a "must see" attraction. Gaudi was extremely creative and ahead of him time to have designed this house. Enjoyed the visit very much. You can book tours that have pre-paid entry tickets, so that you don't have to stand in long lines.
Not to be missed. Fascinating insight I to the life style of a bygone era. Gaudi must have been smoking some heavy stuff to come up with his ideas, which are sheer genius. A not-to-be-missed stop.

La Pedrera - June 2013. I loved La Pedrera!At first we thought the price (16.50euros) might be a bit steep for only being able to see the roof, the attic and the first floor apartment, but actually it was all very interesting and we were there for quite a long time. The queue wasn't as bad as I thought it would be to get in. We arrived at about 10.30am and only had to wait about a minute to go in. We did buy an audioguide in English to help us round. We opted for the shorter 40minute one which was enough for us, but you could have opted for a 75minute tour. These cost 4euros each and were very interesting. The roof was by far my favourite part! It is spectacular! Not only do you get brilliant views across the city, the chimneys are amazing works of art with plenty of curves and arches and inviting twists and turns. Great photo opportunities!!After the roof, the exhibit in the attic tells you a bit more about Antoni Gaudi and his work. It covered information about Parc Guell, Casa Battlo and Sagrada Familia church so we didn't feel like we missed out too much when we didn't have the time to view these other Gaudi sites. The first floor apartment was laid out as it would have looked when it was first built. Some of the period furniture was beautiful.Finally you are herded out through the shop (where we bought some decently priced postcards). Overall I very much enjoyed this attraction. Heading up to the roof certainly has the wow factor and we spent most of our time up there admiring the views and Gaudi's architectural style. Not having visited any of the other Gaudi attractions in Barcelona I can't compare, but for me, La Pedrera is definitely worth a visit. I only wish we could have gone back for one of the night time visits....

A Must See!. Worth the wait in line (about 30 minutes in late May). Visiting the roof top justifies the price of admission. The views and functionality of the roof is spectacular. Really liked tis place.

Take the night tour - The Secret Pedrera. We took the night time guided tour and thoroughly enjoyed ourselves. It was a cosy group (a maximum of 30 persons on the tour), and we basically had the entire La Pedrera to ourselves. Our guide Jordi was very good, and he shared many interesting stories.The tour started at 8.15pm, and we managed to get a bite at a tapas bar opposite La Pedrera before the tour. Sorry I cannot remember the name of the bar now, but it was pretty good. With your back facing La Pedrera, just cross the road and the bar is on the left.

another gem from Gaudi. I visited all three Gaudi's palaces and this one has less is more maturity to his design, but I find that all three are great and have to be seen to appreciate Gaudi's genius! The museum part has nice summery on all the other projects he has done. The apartment set up is a really good representation how bourgeois family lived at the time and gift shop within the museum had some great things (not available to people without a ticket)

another high light of Gaudi. For any architecture interested person it is a must, the details and variations, artistic and engineering just great! The entire visit is so well organized and done, bravo! i enjoyed the visit very much. Do not miss to have a look at the museum next door as well, a great view to the lobby hall.

Awesome. We disliked that the day was a little chilly with scattered rain. However, this probably kept some of the crowds down. The place is fantastic. I recommend that you purchase your admissions in advance to avoid a line and that you take the time for the audio tour.

Maybe just see outside. The outside is the most impressive part imo. The museum parts - the apartment and the galleries were not that interesting and seemed like a hodgepodge of gaudi items. Going on the roof is pretty cool but it's certainly not the best spot for Barcelona city views. The gift shop is also lackluster and features mostly items not actually related to la Pedrera. The architecture is still beautiful of course!

Not to be missed, a masterpiece!. I came late in the afternoon, and crowd was gone, so don't need to wait long before getting in. I first took a lift to go to the roof. The moment the lift door was open, my eyes were shocked by sorroundins. There are 30 sculptures, grouping in various forms. You can walk around, take photos, but be careful with the staircases.The tour was well organized, one tip is to choose full length audio guide instead of highlight one. I chose the latter and found there was little to listen. I don't understand why they need to separate it as I pay full price. The place was a little overstaffed, almost every corner there was a staff standing, as if it was some top-security place. I went to Casa Batlio and it wasn't like that.

Another beauty. We visited Casa Battlo first, and I preferred the detail and intricacy of that house, and I also think the tour was better for that one. However, I still enjoyed visiting here, and found the apartment which you can tour through very interesting. The highlight for me was the roof and the amazing warrior like chimneys.

Really worth a visit. It is as good as the reviews describe it ! We have visited the other Gaudi's sites and in our views , this ranks as number 2 after the Segrada Familia ! Some tips : reserve a ticket on line , we avoided a 1 hour line up on a Monday morning by doing so ; the audio guides are worth the price ; if you do not have the time or the budget , go and have a look at the paintings exposition , it is free and it gives you the opportunity to see part of the inside of La Pedrera for free . If you have the budget and the time but are not sure if the visit is worth it , have a quick look this way and then decide !

Amazing. Gaudi was a genius. I would recommend spending a couple of hours in the afternoon here. Make sure you go to the rooftop and also make sure that you buy your tickets online before you go to avoid the long lines.

La pedrera. I went to this building as I was exploring gaudi and the modernistas. While it was quite interesting it was way over priced - 16,50 euro with the audio guide extra. I thought the Palau guell had much more to offer and it was much cheaper. A rip off!
Gaudi on a domestic scale.... Not as difficult to get into as Sagrada Familia, and a riveting insight into the mind of Catalunya's legendary architect. The rooftop statues/basilisks are amazing.

The rooftop is spectacular. This is one of the best examples of Gaudi’s architecture. The rooftop alone makes it worth the visit. Our hotel was near the Placa Catalunya, so we took a bus tour that included La Pedrera and other Gaudi masterworks. The guide’s descriptions and the avoidance of lines are worth the few Euros cost.

Outside is more interesting that inside.. This was our last stop for Gaudi some were not as shocked as other buildings. But roof terrace is one of a kind. Interior is mostly decorated to simulate old Catalan times.
An apartment house by Gaudi. A must see attraction of Gaudi's work with interesting design.Go with a guide so you don't have to stand in line.

The Classical Gaudi. This is the Classical Gaudi masterpiece and you should spend some time observing the facade and the details. It is really worth your time. Barcelona and Gaudi are intertwinned. As Barcelona is also permanently tied to Zafon's Shadow of the Wind.
A must see in Barcelona. Architecturally interesting and worth the line-up. Well laid out with excellent historical backgrounds provided.

MUST GO. Beautiful architecture, learn about Antoni Gaudi and his work, inspirations and creativity. A lovely, lovely building and lots of eye-opening insights into Gaudi's work.I guess it's a must go for designers, architects etc

Incredible. Don't pass up an opportunity to tour Casa Mila. Start at the top and enjoy Barcelona from the Roof Terrace and then stroll throughout the house to the Pedrera Apartment for a real feel of life in the past. Suggest you buy your tickets online for the very start of the day and you will almost have the tour to yourself. Great gift shop.

Great Visit. The rooftop is definitely the highlight of this site. On a sunny day, it's easy to spend a good amount of time just relaxing and enjoying the views and sunshine. The apartment offers a rare first-hand insight into how the rich and elite of Barcelona lived, which I found very interesting. There is also an exhibition area which chronicles Gaudi's life and works and the techniques he used. It is never too crowded here as there is crowd control, which means lining up for tickets is inevitable. We spent around 20-30mins lining up at 3pm on a weekday.

An apartment building that is timeless. When you see this amazing place you have to go into the attic area to see how Gaudi utilized his unique designs to avoid supports. What a cool place to live in!!

Another great Gaudi design. Gaudi's work is always worth seeing and La Pedrera is just down the road from Casa Batllo. It is less garish than Casa Batllo but his concepts of light, ventilation, curves and ergonomic designs are all present in La Pedrera as well. The rooftop is the one that is highly photographed and shown all over the world so do not miss this but do note that if it rains, the rooftop is closed to visitors.For us, La Pedrera is an awesome place but if you have to prioritise your Gaudi-buildings to visit, I would prefer Casa Batllo to La Pedrera. There seems to be more aspects of Gaudi to appreciate in Casa Batllo - more fun, craziness and freedom to design. La Pedrera is more refined and in some ways more muted.The attic area has some exhibits on Gaudi - but this section could have been done better. The lighting is very dim and the exhibits could have been given better exposure and be made more interesting. A real pity as it would have been an area of great interest after seeing so many buildings designed by him.

worth seeing. take the elevator to the top floor, descend by stairs. if you have disabilities, they will allow you to use the private elevator to go down to each floor. we used it. they accompany you all the way through halls to restricted areas where the original elevator is for the few guests that still live in the building. every place we went we were surprised the attentions they have for people with limited motion or disabilities, buy post cards of the place and views, good quality and very inexpensive. there is a small room where you can watch a video about Gaudi and la Pedrera.

Out of this world. Wonderful experience - start at the top of the building with amazing view of the city and Guadi's roof and work your way down this extraordinary apartment building. Too many tourists - but suppose this is inevitable!
Gaudi at his best. A "must see." If you do or do not known Gaudi, this is an amazing experience. We took the audio tour which was wonderful but you could also just revel in the experience.

Very interesting. I'm not an art addict but I loved looking around the Pedrera, on the same road as Casa Batllo there's no reason not to visit both. The roof is amazing and offers great views of Barcelona. Inside also showcases Gaudi's work and looks stunning. Unlike any building i've seen before, worth a visit.

Neat place to visit. The La Pedrera was a neat place to vist. The artistic energy that went into the structure is pretty interesting. The roof was amazing, had amazing views and the inside tour was very informative. I would suggest to buy your tickets early and go early to see it. We stood in line for over an hour, and we got there early. I would recommend a visit to The La Pedrera. Take your camera!!

I left with the sense that I had not seen enough.. As I mentioned in other reviews I love Gaudi's work and La Pedrera is so unique. I went in to see the building but was not very happy with the way the place is shown. I did not like the way things were in the loft. It was dark and I would have wanted to be able to see loft in normal light . It was dark so that the different films shown could be seen. I was not content with the whole set up.

Wavy Lines. A little off the beaten tourist track, this building displays a real sense of humour - a million miles from your average 'flat' fronted building. How to 'add' something interesting apart from towers, turrets or chimneys. It makes you wonder whether modern day builders could match wanything like this!It's free to admire from the pavement outside but you can also pay and go inside.

Nice but not the favourite. Though I'm a huge fan of Gaudí, I would recommend visiting his other works instead. La Pedrera is crowded and way too expensive. Moreover, the atmosphere is totally ruined by the (necessary) iron fences. I did not regret visiting but I would not go again.
Worth the visit inside!. Its not just the house you get to see, you also get to see the workings of Gaudi's mind with an exhibit of what inspires him to create the way he does.

Not to be missed.. Gaudi at his best! The building exudes his imagination. If you go in the late afternoon you can see the shadows dancing on the facade making it even mor einteresting. Sip a glass of wine across the street while you watch the sunset behind it. Just beautiful.

Architecture meets Engineering. Another of the many opportunities to see Gaudi's genius, this building is a must see as well. The tour is done very well offering access to the most interesting pieces of the building, its structure, its history and it design. Bring your camera!

Arrive early or prebook tickets. Waited for 2 hours to get in, I suggest pre-booking online or going in the evening. Despite my weariness after queuing for so long it was beautiful inside. You start from the top from the roof and work your way down. I think it's only one floor that you have access to and the courtyard. Must see if your a fan of Gaudi.
nice. it is nice from outside but wouldnt pay 15e for enter..... i like the balconies but thats all...go and see it definitely

Nice place, can only see a small part. This is a really fascinating building and the views of and from the roof are really nice. Since it also functions as a residence, you can only go into a sample apartment and other similar areas. Also very expensive (nearly 20 euros), though this is somewhat of a recurring theme in Barcelona.

A nice view!. Visit La Pedrera and take a walk at the roof terrace. Watch Gaudis sculptures and enjoy the scenery of Barcelona and the sea. Go down to the attic and look at the ergonomic design of chairs and door handels by Gaudi.
Wonderful. We had a wonderful time viewing this Gaudi building. It was the least busy of the Gaudi buildings we visited.
unique. This cazy house by Gaudi is a step into a fantasy world. Not to everyone's taste, one has to admire his vision
Magnificent!. We queued for 35 minutes to get in, well worth the wait. Try not to go when it is wet as there is no access to the roof and this is really worth seeing.

Amazing. The man must have had dreams of the future, astronauts, aliens. Amazing architect. The outside of the house, yhe facade is wonderful but you can see that walking by too. The roof was well worth the €16,- we paid. Nothing short of incredible. The tapas in the bar downstairs are quite good too.

Pictures don't do justice to it. Right on Passeig de Gracia it is a structure you cannot miss. Even if you have seen pictures or film of this building nothing is better than seeing it for yourself. Love the chimneys, each one different as well as vents that have surreal forms. The view of Barcelona from the rooftop is amazing.It's my favourite modernist structure. The different rooms give you an idea of Gaudi's far thinking.
Worth it for the view. Really interesting place to visit. Lots to see from the roof and the chimneys are amazing. Make sure you go into all the areas / rooms of you may miss something.

Worth the wait, but prepare for long lines. We waited two and a half hours in the morning, although the evening before there wasn't a line. History buffs would especially enjoy this 19C house with its inventive shape.

Not cheap, but amazing design and views. I wasn't sure about joining the queue for this attraction, but it was worth it for the roof alone, which delights from every angle, as well as the views of Barcelona. Good opportunity to get close to the detail of Gaudi's work.
Casa Mila. A must see. A wonderful example of Gaudi's artistry. In a lovely area so there is alot to see. Went with a guide from Barcelona Dreaming.

night tour. An incredible apartment house by Gaudi. Everything is spectacular from the open foyer to the gorgeous attics to the unbelievable roof-top. The tour included an original apartment-Gaudi excelled at beauty and function-and all the way up to the roof, where a beautiful light show was given and then to the foyer for cava and snacks.

Buy Tickets Online. We wanted to see at least one of Gaudi's masterpieces while in Barcelona and I am glad we chose to see La Pedrera. If possible, buy your tickets online, but make sure to purchase them when you have the opportunity to print the tickets since you must present these at the counter. By buying our tickets online, we bypassed a line with an hours wait. I highly recommend getting the audio guide (additional 4 euros). There is a 45 min audio guide and 75 min audio guide for the same price. We purchased the 75 min audio guide when we checked in. All of the museum information is in Catalan, Spanish and a little English. We wouldn't have learned as much about the exhibit without the audio guide. This tour was great because it gave you information/pictures/videos about all of Gaudi's works, not just Casa Mila. You start the tour on the roof - then spend most of your time in the attic- and end inside the house. Would definitely recommend.

Worth visiting, even if quite expensive. 16.50 euro entrance fee. Queued for about ten minutes on a sunday eveninng at 6.30pm. Amazing roof. Nice exhbitions presenting Gaudì's works. In the apartment included in the visit you may watch a 7-minutes long video: it's quite nice, but it's only old pictures, no voice or explanation.

A masterpiece. Like all other Gaudi's works, this one too is a masterpiece of Architecture. No one has done more to Barcelona then Gaudi. You may see the roof, the floor under the roof and one of the appartaments.Everything is curved and typical to the master's works. There is also on show his sources of influence from nature and Geometry. Very interesting.Come very early to avoid the huge lines.

Only for serious Gaudi fans. Quite an expensive experience at around 16.50 euros each. We waited around 1 hour to go in and even those that had bought pre timed tickets online were waiting around 20 minutes past their booked time. The roof is fabulous (really worth seeing) but the rest of the building whilst interesting is not that impressive. Having seen Sagrada Familia and been blown away I was disappointed with this building. The entire tour was no longer than about 1 hour.
Exceeded expectations.. Tour organizers went out of he way to make the visit special including a cava reception at the end. The building itsself? Gaudi. What more is there to say!

Very nice but overpriced. This is an amazing house, the roof is unbelievable, particularly in a sunny day. Anyway I can not understand the price absolutely higher than the real value; as usual in Barcelona (especially if we compare it with other "attractions" in Europe).
NEAT-o. I just loved walking by all the Gaudi architecture. We were too cheap to go into it - it was quite pricy to take the tours. But, it is a fun building to walk by and take some photos :)

Weirdly captivating. Innovative organic architecture at it's best. An excellent showcase of the brillance of Gaudi. An Architect and artist in one. Also worth having a bite to eat in the Restaurant in the building with it's unique and beautiful ceiling.

Weird and fascinating. You can visit the building by a tour with headphones. We spend around 2 hours looking at all the different aspects of Gaudi's interesting approach to architecture trying to integrate nature into his buildings. Biomimicriy in architecture. He was ahead of his time!

Gaudi life. La Padrera is a beautiful building that's still inhabited with residents, producing cooking smells, etc. The top apartment, attic and roof are open to the public. Lovely experience but a bit pricey.

Worth a visit. ...if you're a fan of Gaudi's. Personally this is not one of my favourites as it seems to be lacking a bit of colour and style when compared to his other works such as Casa Battlo and La Sagrada. The rooftop and the courtyard are probably the two highlights of this place.

roof is great. The roof is great. Chose good wather if possible to enjoy it. You can see Sagrada Familia from one coner. Overall a unique expeience. Attic expo is interesting. the appartments are nice too,but for some reason i expected more.

La Pedrera at Night. Through the Barcelona Turisme website, I purchased admission to Casa Mila for Sunday, April 14. You meet at the side of Casa Mila and our group consisted of about 14. I enjoyed the opportunity to see and learn more about Gaudi. There is an apartment decorated at the turn of the last century that you explore before the attic and roof. Good opportunity for photos. The cava at the end was nice. Even better, some friends waited for the tour to end about 10:30 before whisking me off to a great restaurant.

Totally worth it. The terrace its amazing... with nice view and that giant sculptures...the building inside its nice... theres like a kind of museum and a flat with room and everything... the ticket its 16 euros.. i think its too much but definitely worth it... a basic in Barcelona!!!

Not quite what we thought it would be. Love Gaudi and looked forward to seeing this apartment building. The exterior is gorgeous and you can see that for free. The best part is the roof, but it is an exercise in keeping your balance. The apartment was interesting, but you only see the one unit and a multimedia presentation on Guadi. Value for the money wasn't great.

Amazing Building. The architecture of the building is really amazing. Nearly everything is curved like the nature. It was good to come early in the morning. 10 o'clock was quite right. But be aware, to get in is not very cheap (about 16 euro each person)

night visit. we went on the night visit to the house. it was fantastic especially the roof at night. The visit included visiting an apartment, the attics with a Gaudi interpretation centre and a guide. even in the rain ti was a lovely experience.

Educational. I really enjoyed the visit the wait was not too long, it was very interesting to learn that the sculptures on the top were water buts and chimneys not just art. The exhibition was very educational how he worked was very unusual the apartment was as it would have been in his time ,hot water on suite bathroom was a surprise well worth a visit but may be to have a photo of the very famous Gaudi as we dont know what he look like it would be nice to know a little more about the man that Barcelona is famous for.

Secrets of La Pedrera. Wonderful magical experience through La Pedrera, definitely worth the extra money for the exclusive tour of these apartments. After a long day of traveling the meal included, salt taste, was a perfect. It had a lot of local meats, cheese, olives and local sardines. The dessert of Catalunya cream was a lighter and creamier version of a creme brulee. The staff walk you through La Pedrera and provide a glimpse into the individuals that lived in these apartments. They do a great job explaining Gaudi's ideas behind his construction of these apartments. The end of the visit is completed with a glass of cava and crispy chocolate delight. Wonderful tour for a memorable experience without the crowds of local tourist.
Must see building by Gaudi!. If you visit Barcelona, you need to visit this building and especially the roof. An architect decades if not a century before his time.

We did the night tour. It was neat to see but not worth the 30 euros we paid. The tour guide was bit green and the tour was a bit longer than I anticipated. There was Cava(Catalyn champagne) after the tour with some sweets.. Very cool to see Gaudi's creation at night though
Once again, great architecture. Didn't have a chance to go into it, but the outside sure is interesting. As you're walking around Barcelona, you can definitely pick out Gaudi's work!

An Impressive Gaudi Building. This building is a must see, even if it's just from the outside. The exterior is so interesting, and then, if you go inside, you get surprises along the way. Gaudi was so ahead of his time. It must be fun to actually live in the Mila House (as there are 3 apartments still renting). I took the night tour, so we saw the main level, an apartment and the roof over about 75 minutes. Well worth it, especially the roof! At the end of the night tour, you get a glass of champaign to boot. Even if you're not a fan of architecture or Gaudi, this is an interesting place to come see

Gaudi, Gaudi, Gaudi.. Even with the long queues and the expensive entry fee, it is well worth the visit. I think the best of all the Gaudi locations, as you are up close to what he has done. Amazingly inside it is not crowded. The audio commentary is really interesting.

Fantastic. Worth the wait in line. A very well designed mini-museum in the attic that takes you through much of Gaudi's work in Barcelona. Lovely view from the roof, and a chance to see this unique's architect's work up close.

Yet another Gaudi Masterpiece. Don't miss this, great views of the city from the amazing rooftop, go early to miss the crowds. Pity they don't do a duel ticket for the other Gaudi sites (it started to get a bit expensive)

Fascinating Gaudi Building. This building is a fascinating example of Gaudi's work. It's well worth the price of admission and the audio guide. We spent about an hour and a half wandering around this place and really enjoyed it. The views from the roof are great and the lines are generally not too long. We waited about 15-20 minutes to get in. If you're a Gaudi fan, it's a can't-miss.
Nice place. The building was very nice and the queue wasn't too long. We had to wait approximately 15min and the roof was the nicest place to be.
lovely building. took a while to find but lovely , we love all of the fantasic building in barcelona we did not go in as there was a queue and hate queueing

beautiful interior. This is a Gaudi "must see". The roof is extraordinary with stunning views of the city, out to sea and of the Segrada Familia. The apartment is stunning: spacious,airy and beautifully furnished and typical of Gaudi the light comes streaming in. Note the walls, no hard edges. Again bet visited early so as to avoid the crowds.

Modernist Architecture at it's best. Situated on a prominent corner on the Passeig de Gracia, it's hard to believe that this apartment building is close to 100 years old. The rooftop alone is worth the price of admission. The ventilation stacks look like Star Wars helmets. Proceeding into the attic you get insights into Gaudi's revolutionary use of arches. Next you proceed to a preserved apartment as it looked in the early 20th Century. The center courtyard is beautiful and provided outside light and ventilation long before air conditioning. Well worth a couples hours of your time in Barcelona.

Definitely worth a visit. Architecture/design lovers will find this hard to miss. Not only do you get to roam the rooftop [our favorite part] but you also have the opportunity to walk through one of the apartments, kept in pristine condition, complete with period furniture/decor/appliances. And the audio tour made it that much more interesting!

Fantastic roof!. Again rather dark and average interiors. Interesting kitchen. Nice door-handles. The roof is worth of all the other places in the house. Note: having bought your ticket on the internet, you can avoid queue to enter! What I didn't like is timing of your visit. When you buy tickets on La Pedrera website a few days before your visit, you have to decide there and then, what time is good for you. We chose 10 am and there were quite a lot of people inside.
nice and unic roof. nice building , nice roof , i had to wait a lot in a big line , but it was good for visiting such a nice artistic and unic building .

Boring and wasted my time waiting in the queue for 1 hour. A forgetful memories of my visit to this place and regretted wasting 1 hour in the queue for this attraction. If i can turn back time, i will skip this place and spend more time at Casa Battlo. Part of the visit it to see the chairs of Battlo, model of Gaudi's building and etc. It is more like a museum visit for me and prefer to understand and see more about the building architecture.

Doesn't measure up to Sagrada or Batllo. While in Barcelona, we visited three Gaudi constructions (Sagrada Familia, Casa Batllo, and La Pedrera) and thought La Pedrera was by far the least interesting. To be fair, it was raining so the terrace was closed, though you could get glimpses of it out the windows, but also to be fair, they still charged full price for admission and it felt value was lacking. The displays in the attic would be interesting if you had not visited Sagrada Familia but having just come from there, we found them repetitive.

Get a tor guide or prepurchase your tickets!. Very popular attraction! We did not have to stand in the huge line thanks to our guide. The house was beautiful and I was amazed by all of it. We went to this attraction near the end of day. I could not have stode in line and still have energy to enjoy the house. It is pretty huge. Go early and prepurchase your tickets to avoid crowd. It was such a treat to see.

Dont miss this one. We happened on this Gaudi Masterpiece by accident we were walking by this home and saw a line of people queuing up for tickets and lots of people looking up to the building. Lots of wrought iron and just gorgeous building inside. An interior decorators and architects dream.
