Book in to see inside!. Again, we could only see the outside, as there was a long queue, it was Saturday afternoon and we were time limited. It looks fascinating and well worth revisiting to see inside!

Wonderful Gaudi. This is just up the road from Casa Batllo and I booked on-line tickets so avoided the fairly long queue. Loved the rooftop terrace and there is a cafe attached to it with reasonable prices which is worth visiting.

Unique building showing the Style of Gaudi. Went to see this building with my family. The top floor is most impressive with many stone carving of beings. It reminds me of beings from time and space. The next floor exhibits videos and works of Mr. Gaudi and his style. Another floor shows his living quarters, when he lived here.

Another special architecture. The roof is probably the most intriguing part of the building. It features a number of surrealistic colorful chimneys. Many of them look like warriors in a science fiction movie, others look more frivolous. You can have a nice view over the Eixample district.

Mad Roof Terrace. A fascinating Gaudi building. The roof terrace affords great views over the city. The curves and crazy sculptures up there can challenge your sense of balance. The roof construction in the attic is amazing.
What every apartment should feel like. From the master, a very liveable and very modern interior - even if conceived a century ago! A must see for all.

Gaudí is brilliant. I love Gaudí and anything he has made, so you don't have to believe me when I say this building is fantastic, I am prejudiced. Go and find out yourself, you'll see I have not exaggerated. Fantastic is the right word, you cannot imagine someone has that kind of fantasies and put them into a building.

Nigth tour. Be sure to take the tour, but take a night tour of my advice, I have been during the day, but I think it is more effective at night because of the lights and the type of room where you are, surreal.

Really different and beautiful. My favourite part of the house was the roof- it was really amazing seeing all the different structures and sculptures. Lots of interesting videos and installations on Gaudi's work. We queued for about 20-25 minutes to get in which I would say seemed to be normal. Really is a must-see.

Night visit. I would recommend doing a night visit to Pedrera: interesting stories about this house + cava as a bonus at the end. However, as there are no much light at night-you won't see much of Barcelona from the roof
Casa Mila. Fascinating look inside Gaudi apartment building. His vision carried through to all parts of his design.
informative excursion. If you want to know about architecture this excursion suits well! Take a 75 mins audio guide and enjoy!

Another fabulous Gaudi project. It's different from the Casa Batllo down the street, but congruent with that kind of vision. The attic area has a lot of information about Gaudi, his life, and how his architecture works. (Hint: it may look free form, but it isn't, it's rigorously mathematical ).One disappointment--I had visited Casa Mila about seven years ago, and at that time, you went up the central staircase, which I thought rivalled the roof in its spectacular beauty. Now you can get just a glimpse around the corner from the collection point downstairs. so sorry to miss out on seeing it again.

Beautiful work. What an interesting building. It was beautiful and so detailed. I mostly loved the rooftop. The attic was very neat but mostly a walk around and read kind of thing and the apartment was my least fav bc in general the most unique parts were the molding on the doors and some of the flooring but a lot if the rooms were simple. Great site to visit I would def make reservations as there was over an 1.5 wait if you didn't. Check it out if you like gaudis work

Awesome Rooftop. House is split into 3 areas: ground, attic, roof. Ground has nothing much. Attic is an exhibition on Gaudi's masterpieces. Roof is the highlight. Loved the way Gaudi created the chimneys. I call it the Star Wars building now as the chimney resembles a Storm Trooper. Apparently George Lucas got his inspiration from here.TIP: Get tickets online if u intend to go in. You get to choose a time and skip the queues. We chose the 10am slot and there was a line round the house.
Book online. Very good but pricey, had to pay extra for the audio comentary, unlike casa Batllo which is free. If you have the time and money visit both but my first choice would be casa Batllo
A must if you like Gaudi. This rivals La Sagrada Familia as the must-see place if you like Gaudi's work. The roof alone is worth a visit. Take your time and bring your camera.
A genius. A genius built house with again this incredible sence of detail in everything he created; from windows to doors ,furniture and door hendles.

Short queue at 6:30. Visited here at 6:30. Got in fairly quickly and was a great way to spend the end of the day. Took us about an hour to see it all. We don't bother with the audio tour. Cost was 14€ with the barcelona card discount, but was well worth it. A lift takes you to the top floor to get an amazing view. The next floor down is an interesting exhibition of some of Gaudis work. The final floor is the tour round the flat which is stunning.

Gaudi & spectacular views. One of the best places to get a full 360 view of the city, an apartment set up like it would've been back in 1910 plus it's all things Gaudi so if you're a fan or not there's something for everyone!

Lovely. Lovely place , very interesting . We particularly enjoyed the views from the rooftop walking around the chimneys . This was booked as part of a tour through Viator where we skipped the line to gain entry - definitely the way to do it .

Fantastic Gaudi's work. See it to believe it. It's strange & visionary. Amazing to know it's something made almost 100 years ago. Very "space-cy" & "alien-ish". Long queue always if u want going inside.

Night tour was exepensive. We did the night "secrets" tour at 9:15 PM and it was 30 euros per person. The building was very nice obviously but there were no real secrets apart from a couple of animations on the walls to show maids or the ladies chatting. So I would recommend the regular visit and no need to spend 30 euros for the night tour.

My favourite Gaudi building!. I want to live here! It's amazing all the way through, but its when you get to the attic that the space becomes truly amazing and then the roof! Wow! We should be making apartment buildings much more like this!
Highly recommended if you are at all into art, architecture or spaces!
Highly interesting!. Gaudi had lots of funny ideas and was a genius, but his customers who made him build their houses must have been quite like him.

A delight to visit!. We lucked out with a short queue - we arrived there about 6pm on a Saturday night and only waited for about 15 minutes. I always recommend paying extra for the audio tour to get the full experience. I was amazed by the rooftop design - very artistic and unique with some nice views of the city. I was also pleasantly surprised that the attic area contained many interesting exhibits and information on Gaudi and his other amazing works of architecture - a wonderful introduction/overview of Gaudi's work. It inspired me to visit other places I had not thought about. Lastly, touring the furnished apartments gives you a glimpse of the affluent lifestyle back then. La Pedrera is a delight to visit!

Unique architecture. Casa Mila is one of the remarkable works of Gaudi. It was a unique and unusual experience. The many chimneys on the roof resembles roman helmets depicting the roman era in Barcelona. Each room in the apartment is a walk back in time to the early 19th century. The attic is a museum of sorts displaying Gaudi's inspiration, drawings, plans and models for the apartments. The railings on the building takes on the appearance of seaweed which is classic Gaudi depicting nature. This is a must see building to visit when in Barcelona. It truly shows Gaudi to be a visionary!

La Pedrera - A delight. Gaudis Casa Mila is another of the must see architectural wonders of Barcelona. The ability to walk on the roof, in the attic with it's amazingly slender brick arches, and to see the apartment in more or less the condition it was in when built is extraordinary. The use of colour, form and detail is amazing.

Well worth a visit!. I am a huge fan of Gaudi and Barcelona is the right city to be in to satisfy my interests. The tour of the house is really interesting and the roof (as everyone has said) is the cherry on top. The apartment is really nicely done (my kids would kill for the dollshouse!) and the attic space is really cool too. Can't say any more - just go!!

You must go.. One of the most incredible places that you must visit. The crowds are horrendous (like most places now) but it's worth it - but try and go on a dry day when the roof is open - preferably in the evening when it's lit up.

Fascinating bit of architecture. A visit to Barcelona is made unique by the amazing works of the architect Gaudi. Many of his works are now (partly) open to the public, as is the case with Casa Mila, now known as La Pedrera. Try to choose a dry day, as you will want to visit the facinating roof with monstlike chimney pots. If it rains the roof is closed. In the attic below you find a museum dedicated to the life and works of Gaudi under an arched ceiling. Further down an apartement as it was in the 1920's. The rest of the building is not open to visitors.Buy your ticketon line to avoid the lines at the entrance.

Gaudi Marvel. Gaudi's work is such a characteristic feature of Barcelona that any visitor to city the should endeavour to vsit as many sites of his work as possible. Casa Mila is my favourite but queues can be long so it is best to avoid peak times like weekend afternoons and wet weather when the roof terraces can be closed. Don't miss the upper floor roof space where Gaudi's designs are explained. This is a wonderful visit of a truly marvellous site.

The roof is the best part!. Rather surprised that we queued to get in and found we were then directed to a lift which took us to the roof. It was a real wow factor as we got out into the sunlight to see the vibrant colours and shapes. This is by far the best part and we spend a great deal of time enjoying the chimneys and the views. The next floor down had rooms furnished as they would have been years ago and a few interesting exhibits.

Crowded but fun. A one hour queue to get in - and that's in April). The roof of this building is an amazing place. The attic has a nice and informative overview of Gaudi's works and time. And there's one appartment restaured in a 1930's setting to get an idea what it was like to live here. Certainly worth a visit.

Roof. We had to choose between Gaudi attractions. The church, house or apartment. To attend all would be very expensive. On the advice of our guide, we went to the apartment. 16 euros each. We really enjoyed our visit. The roof alone is worth the price.
Loved it!. The roof was such a wonderful surprise! It was delightful. We were snapping one picture after another.

Incredible building with trojan helmet chimneys. We spent a couple of hours exploring the top 3 floors of this building. The rooftop is like a fantasy land with its many different white chimneys all with different 'heads' and designs. You learn about the building's history on the attic floor and the next floor down is an apartment, furnished as it was in the 1910's with original furniture & clothing - even a maid's room with uniform. A fascinating visit, well worth the money.

Cool place. The roof is great, after that its a bit like being at school, although very interesting, we had already found out alot of things about Gaudi from other visits, we just wanted to do all the toiursity bits.

Another Gaudi masterpiece that is very relevant today. Another must-see Gaudi building that is still very relevant today for it's ideas about multi-family housing. We were lucky enough to stay right around the corner from it so we were able to view it at various times of day and night to see how it changed in the light and at night. Fabulous roof-top unlike any other - I spent almost an hour up there soaking in the architecture, the views and the sun. Buy tickets in advance so you don't have to stand in line.For a longer review and photos: http://kimpluscraig.com/2013/04/25/barcelona-by-sights-casa-mila/

A stunning Gaudi building. This is one place you have to visit in Barcelona. I'm not mad about buildings but this one designed by Gaudi is quite exceptional. I made a couple of trips. First at 9.15 opening time weekday before all the crowds arrive. Try to be first there to get your ticket. About 22 Euros. I went again at night for 30 Euros on a special tour with only about 20 people which makes it much more personal. And a glass of bubbly at the end. Takes about 2 hours. If you are a photographer like me you cannot take a tripod. Use a fast setting with a wide angle lens for your shots.

Amazing Architecture. It was beautifully sunny when we arrived in Barcelona and we were staying at the Gallery Hotel near by, so we decided to see this house straight off. Lucky we did because the following days were rain, rain, rain! Anyway this house is amazing. The audio guide was very interesting and helped us understand everything. Check out the handles on the doors in the apartment, they are so ergonomic. The roof was lovely in the sunshine and the chimneys were fascinating and stood out fantastically against the blue sky. The attic is very interesting in structure also and has an excellent exhibition. We arrived about 15.00hrs and only had to queue for about 5 mins, no problem at all.
Visit at night!. We joined a guided tour of La Pedrera at night and were fascinated. A must in Barcelona especially in the evening.
Interesting but not great. The rooftop was interesting, the inside of the apartment was like visiting a museum with period furnishings inside, not enough Gaudi design
amazing architecture. Very interesting and quite a climb to the top. Not for those who have trouble climbing stairs. The view is worth it.

Fascinating building. A great audio tour which explains something about how Gaudi designed and built the building and also very interesting is an appartment fitted out in the style it would have been when the building was new. Lots to see.

Inspired Architecture. A must visit while in Barcelona, even if you don't go inside its well worth checking out from outside. The rooftop chimneys and warriors are well worth a visit, just be sure to pre book tickets to avoid the queue.

Unique and worth seeing. I am an artist and found myself extremely inspired by Antonio Gaudi and his art buildings. Each building unique to itself. It was a rainy day, but we were able to see the roof before it started to pour. Nice to have the room with photos, videos and models of his inspiration. The que to get in was long, but the line moved fast and we enjoyed it.

Great Gaudi experience. Visiting La Pedrera makes u lear a bit more about Gaudi and his work. I recommend to tajke the audioguide only four more euros and they are quite worth it!!! Enjoy the roof top view! Must see if u are in Barcelona

The roof is the best part. The sculptural chimneys are the highlight of this building. The attic is very large with many screens playing films about Gaudi's life and work and there are models of his work. A curving stairway leads you down there. Be aware if you are claustrophobic. You get to tour one apartment which is darker and not as exciting architecturally as Casa Batllo. Be sure and go early as lines get long and they don't give senior discounts. 16.50E. It's nice that they have lockers 1E.

Be early before 10-10:30hrs if you don't want to miss it. This house is not as big as the Battlo casa but also worth seeing - you'll take the lift to the upper floors and get down through the stairs.... Darker than the Batllo one but exceptional roof, nice pics to do....This is typically the Gaudi crazy style influenced by nature

Just okay.. I wasn't as inspired by this tour as the other Gaudi house tour. Just ok. Maybe we should have taken the headset but after paying admission it seemed crazy to have to pay more for a headset.

A curvy delight on the eyes. We went around Barcelona on a tour bus (the blue route we thought was best) It was lovely to see something that we have all seen in books and on tv so many times. I do think that the trees could do with a bit of trimming as they block out such alot of this buildings external beauty.

Brilliant night time tour. Paid 30 euro each to go on the tour of La Pedrera at night time. There was a small group of about 15 people and our tour guide brought us around giving us the history of the building and telling us all about the different rooms and views of the building! Although 30 euro may seem expensive there was a animated light show during the night time tour (which you don't get during the day) and the cava at the end was the perfect way to end the tour. It definitely gives another view of the Pedrera, seeing it illuminated at night made it more magical. Probably my favourite part of Barcelona

Do the evening tour. The only way we could fit this into our short stay was to book onto the evening tour 'The Secret Pedrera', as it turns out this was a fantastic choice, places are limited so there was only 15 of us on the tour and the guide was fabulous, speaking fluent English. Instead of experiencing the building full of 500 other tourists we got to enjoy the architecture and space with just the 15 others on the tour. The content was fascintating and very informative finishing on the roof with spectacular views of the Sagrada Familia and a lovely glass of Cava. I recomend you book online in advance and avoid all queues, makes all the difference.

Photo opertunity. You can go in but we just stood and gazed at the outside as with all the buildings you spend a lot of time saying WOW! They are all around the same area which makes exploring easier.

Beautiful. Book your tickets online, otherwise you will queue for hours. Ticket price 16.50 per adult, 14.85 per student. Interesting museum inside and lovely roof terrace with outstanding views. Must see.

Great work of art. Waiting line wasn't too long (we got there at 11 am on a Sunday), so everything went swiftly. The view is great and especially the roof provides many options for picture moments (and photobombing others, haha). Envious of the people with a roof terrace that overlooks this house.

One of the best Gaudi attractions. This house is late Gaudi, a good contrast to Palau Guell. The exterior and the roof are wildly original, but the interior apartment which can be visited is an excellent example of a Modernist interior. The museum shop has a great selection of interesting objects. Hard not to buy a souvenir --they are all beautifully crafted.

One of my favorite buildings..... I am a huge, huge Gaudi fan, I just love his style and design and La Pedrera is one of my favorite buildings. This was our second time to Barcelona and I was unable to tour it last time so this time I decided it was a must see. I found this tour via Viator and when I noticed it was a night time tour I figured this was the way to go. Our tour guide was very good, she had excellent knowledge about the building's history and about Gaudi himself. La Pedrera is a spectacular building and the apartment we saw was just beautiful. There were no angles, just an ever shifting flow of wavy circular walls. I know if I lived there I would never want to move. The attic and the roof top were really the true treats. In the attic space you could see where Gaudi used inspiration from nature to create his buildings. The attic walls had the appearance of a spine and ribs of a whale. The rolling roof top and the centurion looking chimneys appeared to be standing guard of the building. We noticed that from one of the outlooks on the roof and arch seemed to be framing Sagrada Família, Gaudi's current work in progress and probably masterpiece. It is too much of coincidence for it to be accidental and was probably by design to highlight his next work that was financed by this building. After the tour we were treated to a glass of Cava and chance to spend time in one the buildings courtyards. it was a great night and a highly enjoyable tour.

The rooftop is worth the price of admission!. This exceeded my expectations. Stepping out onto the rooftop will be one of the highlights of your visit to Barcelona. I spent at least 30 minutes on the rooftop admiring the views and Gaudi's work. The rest of La Pedrera is wonderful. I loved how the rooms were furnished. The smaller gift shop (not the big one on the ground floor) has some wonderful art nouveau gifts and charming posters of vintage Spanish advertisements. Loved, loved, loved this attraction.

The worst value attraction I have seen in 21 years of travelling the world.. Maybe it was because I saw the sagrada familia yesterday that this was a waste of money and the worst value for money attraction I have seen whilst travelling over the last 21 years through Asia , South America , Africa, Europe and Australia. The roof is of course beautiful , but most of it can be seen from the street, and the fencing whilst important for safety, was tacky and impeded views. The apartment was ok, and the attic was a complete waste of my time in Barcelona. Maybe if it was free I would consider it, but for 16.5 euros it is exorbitant to say the least.
Rooftop views. This Gaudi house has spectacular rooftop views of the city, but the rest is forgettable. Go to Casa Batllo instead.

The Roof Alone is worth the visit. Iconic apartment building in the Eixample designed by Gaudi. Definitely worth the visit. We loved the roof top chimneys and the attic. Gaudi's innovative architecture is unbelievable.

Stopped for a coffee and loved it. We were strolling along the Passeig de Grazia and admiring the architecture of La Pedrera when we realised that there is a cafe on the first floor. The ceiling, door frames and many other features were typical of Goudi. The room is light and airy and had a nice atmosphere. You can reserve a table for lunch. We did not have time to stop for lunch but the food looked fabulous. The service was very good with friendly staff. I would definitely eat here if I came back to Barcelona.

Magical rooftop. Had the pleasure of going here on a beautifully sunny day.The rooftop offers great vistas and the chimneys and impossible curves are enchanting. Kids loved it and also enjoyed learnibg about Gaudi.Highly recommended. Buy tickeylts online and tell the staff at the front you have done so. Immediately run to the entrance.

better than the pictures. To enter the Pedrera is an issue, too many people, too much of a mess, but once you are inside, you feel like Gaudi lives in every corner, you feel his genius , feel like the walls are alive.Is a relatively small place and yet, it feels big, when you walk though it and climb to the roof and see the chimneys with the odd shapes, I love it, and want to go back
impressive. there are no words to describe Gaudi's talent.Should have earned a Nobel prize for Architecture (if it would exist)

Great introduction to Gaudi. This was probably almost my favourite Gaudi building (apart from Palace Guell). We booked our timed tickets through the Tourist Info office near the cathedral which meant we went straight to the front of the queue so worth doing. The light, the angles, the attention to detail are all amazing and especially the apartment - I'd love to live in a space where you want to touch the wood, the mouldings and everything is pleasing to the eye. The roof terrace is lovely too, with the chimneys and undulating tiled roof - a little challenging to an older member of our party but still very much enjoyed. There was a lift for part of the way down for those in need of it.

Excellent. A highly engaging insight into the life and works of Gaudi, with the audioguide helping the visitor understand so much more about his innovative creations and designs - even to someone such as myself with only a passing interest. We arrived before it opened at 9am on a Monday, but on leaving at 10.15 there still wasn't a queue. On another day we arrived at 1130 and there was a long queue.

Go early and get the audio guide. This is a very worthwhile exhibit. The models showing how Gaudi created the innovative design are particularly interesting. Seeing the furnished interior of one of the apartments was a treat too - the floor plan and natural light on all sides are really brilliant!

Favorite Gaudi House - Hands Down. Walking distance from Place de Catalunya. I would recommend that if you're visiting several Gaudi locations, that you start here and take the audio tour. I was in awe of Casa Mila and how everything had a purpose. Gaudi was a creative genius. This location and Church of the Sacred Family were my two favorite sites in Barcelona. Casa Mila gave me a deeper understanding of Gaudi when I visited the other locations. This place is worth the money and time. It's amazing.
A Must See. The rooftop terraces with all the weird and wonderful 'chimneys' are something that you will not see anywhere else. The whole building is fascinating.

Get there early to avoid long queues.. We didn't actually go inside as the queues were huge, so do get there early to avoid this. We did find the façade of the building rather spectacular though. Close to Casa Batillo and on the Passig de Gracia so there is lots of Gaudi to see in this area and places to shop and eat close by too!

Must see Gaudi architecture. Casa Mila is located in Passeig de Gracia and it is another Gaudi masterpiece which shouldnt be missed. The main focal point of this building is supposedly the chimneys. We crossed the street to get a good look and some pictures of the chimneys. Decided not to do the internal tour since it was around 20 Euro pp and we were running out of time.

Surpassed expectations. To be honest I wasn´t happy when my husband told me that we should visit this Gaudi building. I thought, yes it is nice to see it from the street, but I really wasn´t sure what can I see more and why I should pay for an entry, but when we entered the house I understood. This is really unique building with beautiful city view from the roof and I really recommend to visit it. You can learn about history of this building and also about Gaudi, you can pass historical suite (with old furniture and equipment) and like I already mentioned, city view from the roof is really breathtaking.
Roof is where it's at. A very interesting building with Gaudis amazing work. The roof is really neat with statues and a great view. A bit pricey but worth a look. Very unique building.

A bit of a mess really. Not sure I really understood what he was trying to do here. Loved the Attic area but the rest just seems bizarre and a bit of a random mess. The Casa Batllo was far superior in my humble opinion. This is over-rated

Stunning roof. We visited La Pedrera before Casa Batllo. I preferred the inside of Casa Batllo but the roof of Casa Milla was stunning. Gaudi was such an artist! Really I wished we could see more roofs like this in our towns, it would be so much more fun!

Yikes, Expensive!. We loved checking out the Gaudi architecture in Barcelona. But we certainly didn't appreciate the price! At €16.50 each, this is an expensive sight- even more expensive than the Sagrada Familia itself! We would have expected the audio guide or something to come with it, but that was another €4 on top, which we just didn't bother with in the end. Yes, the La Pedrera is quite something to see, but most of what is interesting can be seen from the outside. Going inside, you get to the inside of one of the apartments, which was pretty cool, but the way it was decorated wasn't anything special and sometimes detracted from the architecture around it. On the roof, they've added really quite ugly fences around the sides for safety- not part of Gaudi's design and again really mucking around with the overall sense and flow of the place. We didn't spend much time in the house at all- maybe an hour max. So, for the price I'd almost say it wasn't worth it...almost.

Gaudi at his best. There is nothing like this building, it's a must see by anyone who's interested in how we live and how we could live differently. My only wish is that it wasn't on so busy a street, to move it into beautiful grounds would be ideal. Remember to save some money to eat in the restaurant, we didn't manage to and wish we had.

Preferred Casa Batillo... If you're only doing one Gaudi house then I'd recommend the other.. Casa Batillo. The roof terrace of Casa Mila is fascinating, the attic is an informative 'gaudi exhibition', repeating much information that we'd already gleaned from our other visits. The apartment was beautifully presented, but we felt a bit rushed through (10 mins before closing) by the staff who were walking as a team a pace behind us as we made our way through to the exit. We had allowed an hour and a half, but wish we'd spent more time in the apartment rather than the exhibition.
One of the definitive must-sees in Barcelona. You will walk around completely perplexed by the endless inventions of Antoni Gaudi's genius. Promise!
Views over the city are immense!. This was a great attraction. Was 16 euro and although there was a bit of a queue, it was constantly moving.

Great to See. Fantastic architecture and great views from the roof. Would definitely recommend a visit. Book online though as queues are lengthy. Not the cheapest to visit, but I'd say it was worth it.
Beautiful architecture.. You will learn alot about Antoni Gaudi during your stay. His love of undulating curves and the use of natural daylight in his designs will have you captivated.

An Architectural Masterpiece. La Pedrera is a brilliant piece of architecture by no other but the great Antoni Gaudi. The exterior leaves you lost for words as this building stands out from all the rest on Passage de Gracia. The tour of this building starts from the roof top where visitors explore Gaudi's playful shapes and curved essences this building evokes. As the tour continues visitors move downwards till the last floor. All the rooms are formed through a series of corridors of catenary brick arches which lead to typical 1920's rooms designed in Gaudi's expressionist style- Art Nouvea. This is a must see in Barcelona!
A weird house if ever there was one. Gaudi's complex curved designs are hard to ignore but weird. And for a house built for a couple to live in, it's weirder.

Very Abstract, definitely Gaudi. Very pretty & unique. The Audioguide was helpful, but DEFINITELY NOT NECESSARY! If interested in the design of roof & the layout of the appt, then purchase the audioguide. The top view of the roof was the most appealing part of the apartment. Interesting to find out, people still live there. Also get a view of an apartment in the building. A nice tour, worth the time. Great for pictures. Steps on the roof are deadly, so take caution with kids. Cost - not very expensive. 16 Euros, 4 extra Euros for Audioguide.

A little pricey, but still a stunning site to visit. We stayed at a flat that was practically around the corner, so we felt compelled to visit it. The admission was a little steep but still cheaper than Battlo. Having limited knowledge about Gaudi, we opted for the audio guide, which turned out to be quite helpful. The roof particularly was cool; the rest of the building was pretty amazing too. All in all, consider a trip here to get a peek into Gaudi's amazing talent.

Expected more.. After visiting the Casa Batllo we really were at a level that the Pedrera could not reach. It was a bi disapointing, very litlle to visit, and not so many work as Batllo. Maibe if we went there first, it would have been better.

Good but not great. This is not as beautiful as Casa Batllo. Nonetheless the roof is very famous and interesting to see. In addition there is a very good explanation if you have the audio in the attic area of the building design and Gaudi's work elsewhere... Take the time ti listen and you will learn a lot. The walk through the living area is interesting but not gret and simply emphasises this was a living quarter but for many reasons not on the same level as Batllo

A Gaudi house. A wonderful place to explore both Gaudi's creative imagination and his mathematical creations. The tour is self-guided and takes you first from the ground floor by lift to the roof area where there are wonderful walkways. From there you move to the attic to see how the construction was created and see models of the house. The third area is the living quarters before moving back down to the gift shop and exit. An amazing place that cannot be imagined - it has to be experienced.

Unforgettable rooftop experience. It is best to buy tickets online and go to the front of the queues...because everybody wants to visit. I went with my mother. . . You can get help to the rooftop in a lift if you have trouble with stairs. . and the rooftop is a little difficult but manageable with an arm to assist and really worth the effort. The sculptures take your breath away!
beautiful architecture. The architecture of this building is interesting. I highly recommend this place if you are interested in architecture. The rooftop is also interesting

Great roof!. One of Gaudi's better ideas! We got in cheaper with a voucher we got from buying a ticket for the bus turistic which was good. The roof is the best part where you will probably spend most of your time. The rest of the building is the attic and an apartment but neither are as fancy.
Interresting walk trough. Nice to go inside despite the entrance queues, need to go to the roof for a nice view and understand how big is this place with all the corners inside

Interesting enough. Not as well organised as Casa Battlo but interesting enough from architectual point of view. If you go on a Sunday or a public holiday be sure to be there early in the morning in order to avoid standing in a long line.

One of the great Gaudi sights!. As the title suggests this is one of many Gaudi sights in the great city of Barcelona. Like the others it's a must to see whilst visiting this great city, the rooftops are something else as it the step back in time whilst walking from room to room. As with previous reviews either arrive early 9am / 10am to beat the crowds or book online as this gets very busy! A must do!

Chimneys !!!. If art deco/nouveau is to your taste, then this is the place to go for an overdose of feasts for the eye.Ever thought you would be photographing chimneys ?? Well you will here. There is an originally decorated apartment, a comprehensive and very informative display about the building and the time when it was built and the inevitatble gift shop.I would put it on your list of places to visit.
Rooftop.. Wow. I am not an architect, but I simply enjoyed the architecture and the design of this house, especially the roof top.
Would want to live there!. It's beautiful! The building as soft curvy lines, the balconies simulate waves and the railings seaweed. it's harmonious!
A must see. I don't think i prefer gaudi's style, but i can appreciate his innovation. This was a very interesting visit and well worth the time. A must see.

Building with unusual roof and good museum of Gaudi. Very unusual roof. Combination of aesthetics and practicality in architecture. Building has an exposition concerned with several Gaudi's projects. Eg.: Sagrada Familia, Casa Mila, Casa Battlo, Guell Park and so on.You can walk inside one of apartments of La Pedrera.

New Gaudi Appreciation. After seeing the outside of Sagrada Familia I kind of thought Gaudi was crazy but after going through La Pedrera and seeing/learing about how he put the building together I became a Gaudi fan. He was truly a genius. The roof top was my favorite but watch your step.

Wonderful. I think this is the best way to see Barcelona from above (kind of). Amazing piece of art and I must say, I prefer this rather than the view from Sagrada familia (and it's more crowded at Sagrada familiy) Really nice to be up there at sunset and it's worth the money (a bit expensive)

Dreamy. This is definitely a must-see on any Barcelona itinerary. My favorite part was the iconic rooftop with the surreal chimneys. There are a lot of steps outside to walk up and down, so you want to ideally go here on a sunny, dry day. There were also some interesting Gaudi pieces and tidbits on displaying explaining nature's influence on his work. A bit expensive, but definitely worth seeing. There's also a couple of very nice giftshop on the premises!

Stormtroopers!. La Pedrera is the nickname given to Casa Mila, it translates to 'Quarry' in Catalan...and you can see why with lots and lots of cement! Up on the rooftop, the famous brooding figures...it's easy to see where George Lucas might have seen his StormTroopers! Wonderful winding staircases...the fences spoil some of the photo opportunities, but without them you could fall straight through. Be aware that there are always lots of tourists there and hard to get a shot without people but it was possible to get a couple. I wouldn't want to be there in high season though, I recommend March where it's not into high season yet but still nice weather. You also get to see an apartment as it might have looked in the day of Gaudi. I understand there is a 20 year waiting list to get in the few apartments they have available in this building (The top 2 or 3 floors have residents.)
Cool apartment building. Neat Gaudi building. Liked exploring the old apartment they have set up inside. The roof is cool as well.
Nice to look at!. It is worth to go around and have a look at. If you have time, go inside and go up to the roof - marvelous view on the city!

Wait well worth it.. My husband balked at paying to see yet another Gaudi building, but this is unlike both the Segrado Familla, Casa Botilla and Park Guell - not at all a waste of $$'s. Each of the museums has something different to offer - you get a chance to see the architectural genius of his design in the attic, not to mention viewing one of the apartments, as well as the views of Barcelona from the rooftop garden. Put this one your list of places to visit.
Only if you're a Gaudi or architecture fan. From all the Gaudi buildings in Barcelona, Casa Mila is the least impressive - but still worth a visit if you're interested in architecture.

Forego the crowds - visit at night. La Pedrera offers evening tours for small groups. A truly wonderful and awe inspiring tour. Although it is double the admission price, it is worth it! Visit the La Pedrera website to book your night tour!

The best is the roof terrace. Not as interesting as the Casa Batllo or the Sagrada Familia. The roof terrace is impressive, but the rest not so. Especially the apartment one visits is not very Gaudi-like but like any other from the period. Go to Casa Batllo instead.

Beautiful. This is yet another wonderful building by Gaudi. The whole building is beautiful and strange to behold. The rooftop is the main draw, but spend some time in the attic. There are some great displays explaining how Gaudi drew inspiration from nature and how he designed several of his other landmarks.The apartment you can visit is interesting as a time capsule. Good view of what life was like in the early 1900's,

Amazing apartment and roof and a large display of Gaudi's works. The beauty and design of the roof, with all of Barcelona at your feet, followed by a beautifully arranged and explained gallery of works by Gaudi, and finally the large apartment which preserves the atmosphere of early 20th century, are a must for anyone who has not been there yet, as well as for someone like us who returned after a decade or so.
Amazing. Its is a totally diferent way to see how a building can be. It seems that everything is possible, a work of a genious.

The master gaudi's great work of architectural brilliance. La pedrera which means 'stone quarry' was built as 2 apartment blocks and was constructed in the eixample district on passeig gracia for an elite couple. It is truly amazing. You start off by going up the lift to the roof top terrace where you see the exhibition of gaudi's work the attic, the apartment and even furniture that he made for casa mila. I would recommend that you pay for the additional 4 euro to have the audio guides that gives you a full guide in various languages. This is a must for anyone to visit and you will not be disappointed. I was so impressed, a wonderful display of this genius

Amazing Rooftop. The highlight of our visit to La Pedrera was definitely the rooftop. There are all kinds of crazy chimneys and tops of staircases and stuff like that. As well, you get some cool views of Barcelona from up there. The attic was also very interesting with the exhibit that showed where Gaudi got some of his inspiration. You could really see the animals and plants in the design after learning about this. As an engineer myself, it was quite fascinating. The rest of the tour is through some of the apartments in the building which are set up as though they were from older times. That part was less interesting for me. I would recommend going to the Pedrera if you have enjoyed the other Gaudi architecture you have seen.
Outstanding inside and outside. This is a must see in Barcelona. It is not just an amazing architecture, there is a lot to see inside. The view is fantastic, bring your camera.

Good follow up to Sagrada Familia. Not as overwhelming as La Sagrada Familia, La Pedrera was a nice detour to really experience Gaudi's work. The rooftop is amazing and the museum inside provided some nice details about Gaudi's other projects.

Another Gaudi Masterpiece. This is an extraordinary building from the exterior, to the unique apartments, the roof and the furniture. It is both a marvel of architecture and of engineering. It is well worth visiting!

Had heard a lot about this plae but was disapppointed. Went to the Cas Batllo first and was pleased we did - La Pedrera was not a patch on Casa Battlo in terms of interest and things to see.....except the roof carvings and sculptures and the attic which were very good. My advice....go straight up the stairs to the roof and work your way down.
Rooftop heaven. Fabulous building, I love visiting its great rooftop for views across the city, especially the Sagrada Famillia.

Worth Seeing. Gaudi is amazing - and a tour inside this building will show you just how ahead of his time he was! It was fun to see the apartment furnished and decorated in the period that it was built. The terrace is fun and provides great views over Barcelona. Be warned, however, that even though you can take an elevator most of the way up, there is a short flight of stairs to the top, then many stairs that you have to go up and down (only three or four at a time) to walk around the terrace. This would not be easy for anyone with mobility issues.

Gaudi's Imagination Becomes a Home. While I like Casa Batllo a bit more (more playful), Casa Mila is actually home to real families, which is amazing. The special nighttime secrets tour is about twice the money. There are no secrets, but it is limited to 30 people, making for an intimate tour.

Trippy. The first stop is the terrace. With its uneven stairs, odd shaped chimneys it is enough to make you a little dizzy (I wouldn't recommend this for anyone with vertigo). The museum and the sample living space in the building helps add to the experience. It is a bit pricey but worth it. There is plenty to see.
Love the rooftop area!. The facade of the building is pretty nice but the supreme part of the building is without a doubt the rooftop area with those chimneys!! Like faces! Awesome!
An absolute must!. Just a wonderfully imaginative building. So many interesting things to see & do. Do NOT miss visiting it. Viva Gaudi!
Gaudi Gallore. Go all the way to the top floor, enjoy the views from up there. The roof is pretty cool, too. Then walk down and stop on each floor to enjoy Gaudi's furniture

the roof terrace is a must see. I loved the Mila house, even though the ticket is not cheap (20euros) I think it is worth it and a must see in Barcelona.The most amazing part is the roof where you can admire the Gaudi's chimneys, it is really breathtaking you can also have a clear view of the Passeig de gracia & sagrada familia from the top. Below the terrace there is a museum about the House and Gaudi's works and inspirations. Then you can see how the typical apartment rooms looked like at the time (bathrooms / kitchen / living room etc)
Cool. Very beautiful building. Loved the visit, the shops are nice too, bought a very pretty book for my husband. Worth the trip

The most beautiful appartment building ever.. This modernist building was made by Gaudi for the rich family Milà to live in, but also with apartments for rent. What I loved about it was the natural modernist approach that is reflected in every single detail. Everything in/of this building is a piece of art. In the attic there is a nice display and explanation of Gaudi's work, so this house is also a good place to start your trip if you want to see more of his work (which you definitely will after seeing this).The only bad part is the fencing on the roof. The roof itself is so beautiful with all the sculptures on chimneys and staircases. But on the inside (around the patios) there originally was no fence. This was of course to dangerous for the tourists. But in stead of making something beautiful with wrought iron, in the spirit of Gaudi, they put up an ugly mesh wire.If you buy a guide on Gaudi's work first and read it before you visit, you will enjoy it even more!

Inside Gaudi. It is fascinating going inside a Gaudi building . The attic construction with it's cantenary arches is amazing and houses wonderful models of other Gaudi masterpieces giving an insight into his methods of construction . It also contains some furniture pieces . Visiting the roof terrace and the apartment allows you to appreciate his creativity and attention to detail .

For anyone curious about Gaudi this is a must!. The house itself is the main exhibit but the displays inside enrich the experience. Both about Gaudi and his work and the "sample" living areas from the pperiod when the house was new.

Incredible Roof. I recommend seeing the Casa Mila together with the Casa Batllo. They are each quite unique and incorporate different elements of Gaudi's style. Luckily, they are just down the street from one another! We visited in October, and the line to get in was not terribly long. It took us about 15 or 20 minutes to buy our tickets and go inside.This building is larger than the Casa Batllo, but you do not get to see very much of the inside, though there are some interesting informational displays in the attic area. The inner courtyard that you can visit is quite large and colorful. The roof is amazing. Beautifully designed and executed -- it's an adventure just to walk around and explore! It's quite a large roof, too, and it has some great views of the city. The roof alone is well worth a visit.

grand architecture, right in the middle of the City. This building definitely stands out, even though, the entire Barcelona is supposed to have been built in the shadows of Gaudis architectural vision. I'd definitely recommend a visit for about 2 hrs. the views from the top of the bldg are well worth it.

Interesting Gaudi architecture with a great view.... I enjoyed looking around this interesting exhibit. Gaudi is not my cup of tea, but I could still appreciate the artisanship of this unusual house. Lots of useful videos as you go around. I didn't pay for the audiotour, but there is one available for a few euros extra. I thought the museum was a little overpriced, but the views from the roof were amazing. A good tip is to go in about an hour before sundown, that way you get to see the view by day and by night.

The chimneys!. I was lucky as I got first to the roof and had it only for myself for about five minutes :) I got there early morning, 9 am sharp and due to the fact I booked in advance they let me in first. The roof is an absolute must see - If you see from the street it does not impress at all, but from the top - it is great and the view over the city is also great. The ticket includes also the exhibition in the attic and visit to one of the apartments in the building, equipped in the old-fashioned way, in early XX century style. Expensive but worth seeing.

get there early. I enjoyed my visit here, particularly because I got there a few minutes before it opened, was almost first in line, and went straight to the rooftop. Thus I had it almost to myself, and took pictures free of other people in them. I also found the interior tour more interesting than expected.

Definitely a must see. Entrance fee is expensive now the Bank own the building but everything is so interesting, including how Gaudi set out his buildings. A small display of his furniture well worth inspecting and of course the amazing roof with the chimneys.

for particular tastes and gaudi fans. nice example of an interior with the attic museum and information area and of course the rooftop - maybe a wee bit pricey if you are not into Gaudi, historical living or related !
Worth a visit. Not sure I liked the architecture as it is so wierd but typical architect all curves and no straight lines - so if you like that go and see it.

Really interesting don't miss it. This building is amazing, the variety of landscapes within and on the roof is awesome. Anton Gaudi was undoubtedly a genius. This building is worth every penny to view. There is a fully fitted apartment with artifacts that are also interesting in their own right.

La Pedrera night tour - check it out. We did the "behind the scenes" night tour. Really enjoyed this tour. Gives a different perspective seeing it at night. Really highlights the unique architecture. The tour guide was very informative and entertaining. The cava was cold and delightful at the end of the tour. If you don't go during the day, or if you are too busy in the day, certainly swing by at night and do this tour. A great view of the city at the top as well. One note, if you want to go to the gift shop, go before the tour. The tour starts at 9pm (English tour) and the gift shop closes at 8:30pm. There is also a restaurant at La Pedrera if you want to grab a drink or food before or after the tour. You might need reservations on certain nights.

Another Gaudi works. Tickets are expensive but still worth a see. The building structure is something that you will not get to see elsewhere. I am the most amazed by the roof structure. Its make me wonder at point of construction, what is Gaudi's thinking. For this attraction, you need to pay to get an audio guide on top of the entry tickets.

Very Nice. Its not as impressive as Casa Batlo or Sagrada Familia but its worth your time for sure. The rooftop is fascinating with the column tops looking like faces and thus it appears as if there are sentinals posted on the roof.

Ticket is expensive but a nice place to go. I found the ticket price of 16 euros a bit pricey but the roof was interesting. It had those sculptures of Gaudi. I was able to wander around the attic and room areas and see various items related to Gaudi.

A Must See. Even if you're only going to be in Barcelona for a short time La Pedrera is one of those iconic things you should definitely see. You get an individual audio guide that lets you go at your own pace and is very informative and interesting. I found the attic particularly interesting as I'm not use to attics being used for anything but storage so their description of its original use was cool. You can also see. The roof was definitely a unique thing to experience and while it might be difficult to truly appreciate if you have limited mobility it's fun to visit if you are able to climb around on it. Keep in mind it's very popular so if you have other things planned for the day that don't necessarily involve waiting in lines like just walking around the city or visiting Parc Guell (which is highly recommended if you like La Pedrera).

Must see in Barcelona. The architecture of Barcelona wouldn't be the same without Gaudi, and this house is a fine example of his style. The building itself is so unique, it's something you must see while sightseeing in Barcelona. It's a bit pricey to get in, but worth it.

Interesting. Expensive entrance fee incl audio guide (c.€20pp) Interesting to see inside these apartments. Amazing roof - chimney pots & water tanks. Could have done with a down lift for less able bodied visitors.

Don't miss. Gaudi's architecture is striking from the street view but the "don't miss" part of the building is the roof - wild, colorful, exciting shapes that will dazzle you.Google it before you go, but seeing it in person is a real highlight. For those of you interested in detail, visit the attic. The complexity of the masonry arches that form the undulating roof is a wonder to behold. We took scores of pictures!
Fab. Caught the evening blue night sky - great for photos. Well worth a visit. Open until 8pm; went in about 6. Quite pricey @ €16.50; slight reduction for students and chn. Don't miss.
Gaudi is a must. a bit expensive (16.5 e) but a must. like Palau Guell close to La Rambla. and a magnificent view from the roof terrace.

Gaudi work on a home. You now have visited Gaudi's work at church, park and now home. Everyone comes to see the roof , with lots of sculptures human look alike. Metro : i recommend to stop at passeig de gracia, walk along the higher end shopping street, stop by casa batillo and proceed to this place. or alternatively straight to metro Diagonal station to reach this place.

Amazing rooftop. Amazing architecture both inside and out. Plan to spend 2 hours here. Lots to see - the apartment on the 4th floor with its interesting furniture, the attic which reminds one of being inside a cathedral and the amazing rooftop of the building with its ventilation shafts reminding me of Darth Vader.

Gaudi, Gaudi, Gaudi.... This house is just across the road from the more popular house Casa Batlló but this one I found to be so much more interesting. You start by taking the lift to the roof terrace (important note here: the roof terrace will probably be closed on raining days, so try not to miss it), where you see the amazing sculptures of work. You work your way into the attic where lies a very informative level of smaller models and interior structure of Gaudi's buildings. You will see where and how he gained his inspiration and how it developed into the incredible buildings they are today.Following on through will find yourself in an apartment set up as it once was back in the day, which gives you a great idea of how they lived. This house was one of my favourite visits of Gaudi's works as there is a lot of fascinating information regarding the building and the way he was inspired. Very informative, worth a visit!
Gaudi. Its always interesting to see his work first hand.. it's very easy to find with his work scattered around the city. make sure you have a tour
OK. If you like Gaudi - but for me it was dirty and too much cement/concrete. Not tempted to go on the roof

architectural excellence. This is my second time going to see this house and I was once again amazed. The house is exceptionally beautiful and very spacious. This house is a little cheaper than casa Batllo which is gaudis other house about 500 meters down the road. I would recommend seeing this as you have to when in Barcelona however go to this house first rather than casa Batllo as this one in my eyes is very average in comparison to casa Batllo. The other house is another level to perfection, Epitome of beauty, so in order to not be disappointed, make sure you visit this house first (la pedrera)
Gaudi at his best!. Le Pedrera was quite fascinating particularly the apartment and the roof terrace. Something very different.

Incredible!. This is a great place to start to know Gaudi's work. He is a intriguing architect and this building, apartments, forms and design is beyond his era. The chairs he design is the top of his work. Very good!

Amazing rooftop sculptures.. Incredible Gaudi building, the rooftop sculptures are incredible, one of the most amazing sights anywhere. Slightly disappointing inside, but worth it for the rooftop. Very reasonably priced at around 10 euros. A must see.

Learn all about Gaudi at Casa Mila. The Spanish do museums very well. The entire display about Gaudi's work was great--informative and interesting. Of course you must go to the roof, a most interesting place.

house by the corner. one of gaudi creations on a corner plot, which allows one to gape at this building from various points across the road. the cafe inside is also quite nice. the staircase is certainly a masterpiece/

A master piece and to think it was built in 1910 and already over a hundred years old!. When did they stop building apartment blocks like this? I guess when geniuses like Gaudi died and city planning departments became stuck in the past. Its worth the visit and would always recommend getting the headphones/audio guide. Just means you don'e miss anything. Certainly worth the time and money.!
THE HOUSE. when you visit and you realize that people lives in this house every day. (you only can visit the roof and the attic the attic) it's amazing.

A must to do while off-peak season !. With no queue, no rush, no crowd, this is a masterpiece to see to discover Gaudi's high quality's work !Rooftop is a walk pleasure as we were nearly alone while visiting.The attic is nice to see, and is hosting some explanations about the techniques used by the architect, miniatures, and some artifacts.The apartment is also a great occasion to have a walk in the past and compare with our modern flats.Price is 16€ per adult, visit start by taking a lift to the roof. The you are going down using the stairs !Have seen that this was wheelchair accessible, but with some limitations.If you are visiting it during the peak season, buy your ticket on Internet to bypass the queue who could be really long (seen in August and October).

Stunning in the night light.. My wife and I visited Barcelona in July 2012, and she had heard about Casa Mila from friends. They advised us to take the tour and to do it at night. I was not overly fussed but I went along with it. I am so glad I did.There was only a small group of us on the tour which was a bonus as we could spend more time taking to the group and tour guide.The tour guide was excellent; he was really knowledgeable on the building and its history, as well as having a genuine interest in explaining it to the group.The tour ends with a walk around the roof looking at all the bits of work and an opportunity to see Barcelona by night.It’s definitely a worthwhile tour but try to do it at night.
My favorite Gaudi!. we took the night tour, it was private and beautiful! can't beat the the roof all lit up at night! our tour guide was great

Gaudi is Barcelona's King. This is a very interesting place and pretty different from Casa Batllo. An apartment versus a single family home. The rooftop is the best part and many people sit down, relax and enjoy the Barcelona sunshine :)

beautifull early 20th century apartments. Not only rythmic forms at the outside, but also beautifull formes apartments at the inside of the building, very 'art nouveau'-like. The roof is very special.

Insane. Gaudi's work is absolutely amazing. When you visit the Palace you actually get an idea of the wavelength that he was on when he dreamt this up. It is an amazing display of architecture in the most surreal form. I recommend anything Gaudi to be seen!

Another of Gaudi's masterpieces!. You need a guided tour to understand how a genious Gaudi was! How he thought about all details of the building and how the building was initially hated by the population who finally fall in love with it!
fairy tale house. one of the things that make Barcelona famous. another Gaudi's masterpiece. expensive to get it. but architect's die hard fans should see it anyway

Free (inside), we flew through the museum in five minutes.. It's in a good location, and it's not far from Batllo house. It's an easy activity, free, and worth the trip for the photos. If we had more time, we may have sprung for the roof, which costed money, but we had just spent 40E on Batllo house, so we were still licking our wounds… Modern architecture museum was interesting, which we gave it the time it deserved

A secret entrance. Judging from the other reviews, the price of getting into La Pedrera may be overpriced for many people although there are always lines to get in. However, on the corner there is an entrance to the free gallery space which often has interesting exhibits. Right now there's an exhibit comparing Gaudí with other contemporary architects like Frank Lloyd Wright in the US and MacIntosh in Scotland. The fact that there's a uniformed person standing at the entrance may be enough to disuade any but the most intrepid non-Spanish /non-Catalan speaker but just point to the poster outside or walk in the door as if you know where you're going. Once inside, you enter one of the open patios of the building where you can walk around on the ground level and walk up the stairs to the 1st floor where the gallery space is located. I imagine that for many people this may be enough of a taste of Gaudí and the price is right. Enjoy

Nice...outside !. Very nice house. But very expensive visit entrance for a disappointing visit. The roof is very nice, but for the rest there is only one level in the house to visit with a shop...of course. Better give the money for a visit to Casa Batllo.

For those who loves architecture. I don't remember exactly but the ticket price was a bit expensive. It is a real functioning dwelling building in which one floor is preserved as it was at the beginning of 20th century. The visitor can go through all rooms and see the interior design of that epoch. Moreover one can go to the roof and make a foto with a famous chimneys. But I still think that it is not an object of first importance to attend when you are in Barcelona.

Genius design!. We visited this crazy building in December 2012. The attention to detail by Gaudi was amazing. Every door, windows and their handles are carefully designed. The apartment is well presented and the audio guide (paid separately) was clear. A must for Gaudi fans!

Great House. This seems the more popular choice visitor wise but if I had to choose between this and Casa Batllo I'd choose Batllo. Audioguides are not included in the prices of entrance here, although you do go up in the lift and make your way down through the house - so it's possibly an easier option if you aren't a fan of steps. Never the less it is an amazing property and very worthy of a visit.
Gaudi fans a must. Another of Gaudi's fascinating buildings - wait till you see the roof! Need a head for heights though. Get an audio guide to really learn more about the building and history.

Another great Gaudi piece of work. La Pedrera is again another great piece of architecture by Gaudi. For me La pedrera wasnt as impressive as Casa Battlo but was still worth visiting. The roof terrace is a great place to start when you arrive at the house particularly on a sunny day as there are great views across the city. We paid the 4 euros for an audio guide (total about 20 euros for entrance) which was definitely worth it as Gaudi is all about attention to detail which I think we wouldve missed without it!

Just about everything you need to see you can see without going in. This is just up the road from Casa Batllo (another Gaudi landmark) and in our opinion offered VERY little for the €16.50/person entry charge. You get to access the roof terrace, which has an interesting architectural feature in the "chimney" stacks (but little else) and also to tour an apartment furnished more or less as it would have been in the early 20th century. The museum inside basically repeats the information about Gaudi that the museums at every other Gaudi attraction already say though, and so was not really worth it. We'd have rather just gone to the Sagrada Familia (fantastic!) and the Casa Battlo down the road. Casa Battlo is much more ornate, colourful, etc. If La Pedrera was €5 each we wouldn't have had an issue, but we really felt a bit cheated having paid so much.
Bonkers and brilliant!. The rooftop terrace is a work of art! What a fabulous building! Good value for money and excellent views across the city and to the Sagrada Familia.
Wonderful architecture,. Fantastic place to see Gaudi's work, if you've got a head for heights the roof is amazing !! Perhaps not as good though as Guell Palace, and not as good value for money.

Must see for designers. I studied Casa Mila in both interior design and architecture school and so I was very happy to be able to see it in person.
It was kind of expensive for entry, but I am glad that we got to go.
Always my favourite Gaudi house. Try to time it so you see the sunset from the roof. The colours on the sculptures are amazing in the evening light.
Gaudi-tastic. If you are into architecture and in building landscape this place is a must. From the roof to the show apartment you'll be beguiled

Peaceful place. Very well preserved medieval complex, chapels with frescos were under reconstruction, but they were displayed on video. Although paintings of Tizian were not exhibited during my stay there were many other things to see

Showstopping roof. I didn't pre-book tickets but luckily for me there was no line at all when I stopped by on a Tuesday afternoon. I liked how you start this tour from the roof downward because the roof is really the most magical part about this building. It's a huge maze of sculptures and you'll find yourself getting a bit of cardio in because you go up and down multiple stairs while scaling the top. The attic was fun too because you see a lot of models of different Gaudí buildings so it gives you a taste of what's to come if you plan on stopping by La Sagrada Familia or Park Güell later on your trip. Another plus, the apartments are filled with interesting little touches from old maid's uniforms to a retro phonograph; I preferred it over the really bare Güell Palace.
suprising. another germ of Gaudi, wave lines, great forms, very special, recognizable personal style, worth guided visit inside

A Must Go visit. What can possibly be said about this masterpiece apart of You Got to Go! Fantastical interiors and exteriors...your eyes don't know where to stop. And then there is the roof top!!! If that's what you call this masterpiece of stage design!!!
Very interesting architecture.. It's a must do when you're in Barcelona. Interesting architecture, with no square angles!! Certainly a different personality, the one of Gaudí! Worth the visit.
Amazing. Casa Mila is very unique and interesting piece of art. Defiantly, recommend the visit. The roof top had stunning views of Barcelona on a beautiful sunny and clear day!

Jaw dropping. We were fortunate to arrive here and visit with no crowds so we were able to mooch along and enjoy the views both outside and inside that this attraction has to offer.I've said in previous reviews that the workings of the mind that was Gaudi to have thought to have designed places like this must have been a quirky place indeed. This is a must see visit on the list of things to go and see in Barcelona.
Looks so different.. Went by it at night. So pretty. Was not able to go inside since it was closed for the night. But still worth seeing at least the outside.

What an amazing place. When it was shared that Gaudi's instructors had wondered if they'd unleashed a genius or madman, this amazing building perfectly illustrates that sentiment. A place that incorporated "green" building principles nearly 100 years ago, it's not surprising it was and remains a very unique design. Loved the accessibility to the roof to see all the design features, the attic for its intended community use, and the restored apartments reflecting the flexible design.

CASA MILA – THE LOVE OF THE GENIUS. If you are not yet a big fan of Barcelona’s historical superstar architect Antoni Gaudi, visit and see at least 3 – 4 of his masterpieces and decide if he is for you. Everybody knows about Sagrada Familia (The Holy Family Church), but not everyone has seen a very special place- Casa Mila (The Stone Quarry) situated in a historical area on Passeig de Gracia 92 (near Metro Diagonal). If you have 2 or more hours o visit the place, go ahead, but many people are happy to see just an exterior, which is outstanding and very unusual. You look at the building and the first question is: what is dominating here – walls with its curvy forms or balconies adorned with unique ironwork? Everyone has got his own answer. But the reality is – all those balconies look like they have jumped here from the canvases of the most ingenious abstract painters. And to be exact those balconies have two authors: Gaudi and the iron-artist Joseph Maria Jujol. See my pictures and decide for yourself.  If you want to see the entire house, you need paid reservation or 14 euros plus 4 more euros for the audio-guide, and minimum 2 hours (with reservation) to see the attic, one apartment and will walk on the roof-top. Local guides call Casa Mila the quintessential modernist structure in civil architecture of Barcelona. For Antoni Gaudi Casa Mila was the last huge work ( from 1906 to 1911) before he dedicated his final years to the Sagrada Familia. I am not sure if there is anywhere in the world the apartment building with such brightly visible marriage of the stonework and the ironwork. Ask any photographer near Casa Mila and you will hear that he or she mostly did photograph metal works. Because of its fantastic forms! I was not an exception and now I am inviting you to see what I did pay attention to, when recently was in beautiful Barcelona and saw the Casa Mila.alftul

Amazing!. Casa Mila was very interesting. The quirkiness of the design by Gaudi was astonishing and good insight into his life and progress in his career. The use of curves in architecture was inspiring.

La Pedrera. La Pedrera of Casa Mia is listed as a World Heritage Site by UNESCO and I expected something very good and was not disappointed. We (my husband, college-age daughter and I) were in Barcelona in December 20012. The weather was warm but not always sunny. So when we entered and saw the sun was out, we immediately went to the Roof-Terrace. For me the terrace was the highlight. The architectural sculptures used for the chimneys, the stairwells and the ventilation towers really show Gaudi's talent. We stayed on the terrace over an hour and the views of Barcelona are nice on a clear day. The other areas are the attic which has a lot of info on Gaudi's architecture. You also can visit a recreated apartment of a family from the 1900s with original elements of that time. Lastly is the exhibition hall on the main floor which has an interesting staircase.

Arrive Early. We arrived early so had the roof just about to ourselves which is a great way to explore. By the time we started heading down it was quite busy. The roof is a highlight however as you wander down it is quite interesting to explore the small rooms. For a family of 4 (2 adults and 2 children 12 and 10) the cost was 49 Euro). You do have to go through security screening and then are directed to a lift which will take you straight up to the roof. We spent about 2 hours here.

GAUDI!. i loved Gaudi's way of thinking and his artistry so it was a celebration for my soul to see his work on a living place. In season there will be long lines, thanks to rain we did not wait. But to tell the truth museums in Barcelona are very expensive, you can pick one or two of Gaudi's work.
Gaudi's pride. Another detailed site of Gaudi, very detailed and takes all the shapes and forms. Same ad Casa Batlo, full of visitors and require some wait in queue and time to explore.

Amazing. Seeing how much this football club has achieved in 100 years is unreal!! Full tour of the trophy room, changing rooms, press office & vist to the pitch very memorable
A must for any football fan!!

Gaudi Masterpiece. No matter how many times you come to Barcelona you have to visit this masterpiece each time. The self-guided tour is great. Starting on the amazing roof and working down through the attic exhibit to the apartment museum it is the classic example of Gaudi at his peak of creativity. The unique organic shapes of the window/doors and the iron work through out is fun to see and experience. What a creative genius! Do not miss this World Heritage site.

Great archiTecture!. I really recommend you to visit casa mila! It is an excellent building, with great architecture. Gaudi is the symbol of barcelona (and the barcelona fc, ofcourse!) and you have to visit also palau guel etc.. Although i had great experiences in barcelona, i admired the buildings and gaudi's architecture.. I was too tired of gaudi.. Everywhere you go, a gaudi's building, or a gaudi's frog is in front of you!!!! :) pls be ready for overdose!!!!!

Gaudi: an imagination run riot. In the Passeig de Gracia so very central, La Pedrera is one of Gaudi's great masterpieces. You stand and gape at the outside of the apartment block which conjures up images of waves and seaweed (the balconies). You go into the elegant interior ( don't miss the magnificent iron front gate) and you are taken up to the roof. I had seen the photos but I still wasn't prepared. Gaudi loved roofs and this one is spectacular - the chimneys are known as 'the witch-scarers': I thought of stormtroopers in Sat Wars (I am sure Gaudi didn't !!). They stand there isn the sun like soldiers with visors. Amazing. Then down through a fine collection of furniture to El Pis, the fully furnished Art Nouveau apartment, a wonderful opportunity to see how people really lived. You have got to go and it's on the ArticketBCN (30 euros) which takes you to six other museums for less than half the normal price of entry.
Adorable and shocking. Be wowed by this amazing apartment - and shocked by the contrast with the incongruity of the clothes of the time also on display.

Amazing View. This is a wonderful architecture creation by the genius architect Gaudi. The rooftop is stunning as well as the view. When the weather permits this is a very recommended place to enjoy Gaudi's creativity.
Amazing. It was amazing the pedrera, if you go to BCN is a must place where every tourist has to go...I really don't thing that camp Nou was amazing...sorry

Too expensive:(. Nice view on the roof but the visit is quiet fast for 16, 50 euros, and not so interesting.In the architecture field its still an amazing building.would recomend it if it was only 8 euros...

The outside is amazing on its own.. When I went, I was not able to see the inside. And yet, the outside was beautiful enough to entertain me for half an hour. I cannot imagine how can it be to live in there.

Splendid architecture. Another fantasic massive design by Gaudi built in 1905.This is a must see with tile, and carved wood built to stimulate your mind, all with curved organic style. There are stairs and a lift to the top floors. Worth the price and easy to reach by metro.

Another Gaudi Masterpiece that Must Be Seen. La Pederada, actually named "Casa Milà," is yet another of Gaudi's design masterpieces in Barcelona. If it was built tomorrow in Los Angeles, Paris or Beijing, it would appear modern and futuristic. To think that this was designed a century ago, tells you something about the inner workings of Gaudi's brain.The building appears to undulate, with curving floors at each level, and rounded windows. The interior atrium is beautiful, but the best part is going up to the roof, and looking at the giant alien chess pieces, which are actually the chimneys, which cover the roof of the building.

A close look at the detail of Gaudi's work. Short enough queue to get in when we were there, and well worth the admission price. A lift brings you up to the rooftop where you can view his amazing chimneys and roof design, then you gradually make your way down, floor by floor. The attic gives an insight into the structure of the building with its brich arched vaults, and the apartments a couple of floors below are a delight, laid out as they are in the style of the period.Compared to big works like Sagrada Familia, this is a chance to examine Gaudi's work in detail; don't miss it.
pricey in the extreme. to be fair we didn't go up we'd seen the photo's and decided legendary or not €16 was too steep to look at someones roof

A new found obsession. Between Sagrada Familia and this house, I have become a big fan of Gaudi! Absolutely fascinating. I also liked the room that was on display to show the typical living of an early 20th century family.

Interesting but. To avoid the huge crowds you can pre-buy tickets which gets you directly in the door. The issue here is that the key architecture is the exterior and the apartment that can be toured is rather plain and very crowded. The roof offers a look at some large sculptural pieces but these can also be seen from the street. The tour does not really provide great insight into Gaudi's style in the same way that Sagrada Familia and Gruell Palace do so if time is a factor see those first.

Wonderful. Words can't express what it's like to stand on the roof and see the amazing works before you. The rather steep entrance price was worth it. Amazing views, so original and the inside museum is also a wonderful snapshot of life inside the old apartment. Very cool.

Main museum closed for maintenance! Phone to check opening dates!. Although the main museum was closed for maintenance I found the free architecture exhibition of modernist architects (Gaudi, Loyd Wright) to be extremely interesting and a good conciliation prize for not being able to view the main house. Phone before planning to go to check opening times, especially in winter.

Gaudi At His Best. No need to buy tickets in advance. Easy pay at the door and then acquire the headphones in your language for a self-guided tour, starting at the roof via elevator and then working down. Would recommend watching some YouTube videos of the building prior to entry, but not critical. Expect to stay at least two hours in order to appreciate the complex. Then walk a couple of blocks to Casa Batilo and visit an equally impressive example of Gaudi at this best.

Gaudi strikes again!. If you like one of Gaudi's buildings, you must see them all, and they are all in Barcelona. His structures are like no one else's. At first, they look funny, but as you begin to understand what Gaudi is trying to accomplish, it starts to make sense. What genius!

A Room is a View. One of the most unique buildings you are ever going to see. La Pedrera is fun to look at from the outside. With that being said, I am not sure if you have to pay the price to go inside. The rooftop is very impressive, but the inside of the apartments is not too exciting.
