We were in Barcelona for 12 days and decided to go in here our last after we exhausted all of the other sites. Overall: Impressive building that you may never see the likes of back home. Check it out if you don't mind dropping $20 for about an hour of visiting.

Lovely!. Casa Mila is a beautiful piece of Gaudi. We loved the visit of the house, especially the roof. The appartements are absolutely beautiful. Some of the rooms are decorated as in those days and it gives a nice view of how it should have been.

I Really Wanted to Like It. The view from the roof is excellent and another time I'd like to try it at night, just to see the city lights. The chimneys and ventilation shafts are interesting, but less exuberant and more monochrome than the ones at the Palau.The period apartment was fascinating and for me was the best part of the visit. It was interesting to see how the space was organized.Part of the reason I feel a bit 'meh' about the place may be that I was exhausted and surfeited on Gaudí by the time I got to visit it, but I feel that the ticket price was slightly high for what I got from the visit.
Crazy House. What a quaint little house with it's wavy walls. Another must to visit - Was Gaudi the architect on something or completely insane?

Another great work of Gaudi!. We just passed by the building and did not enter. There is a cafe located on the ground floor which was very busy and lively. You could also visit the surroundings from the roof.Went there on the way to Casa Battlo which is very close.
Go to the cafe. Don't bother going inside, the Cafe at La Pedrera gives you not only a lovely meal in a Gaudi setting, but a look within the structure.

Interesting place!. Quite lovely and lots and lots to see! Tour guides are good and very helpful. Also near lots of great restaurants and a fabulous Catalonian tapas bar on the main drag-also near the bookstore with the best selection of English=language books in Barc-my partner found The Pilgrimage of Harold Fry there, an excellent book!

From the outside is less impressive than Casa Batllò. I didn't visit the inside because I already spent a lot of money visiting Gaudi's stuff so I decided to visit Casa Batllò instead of Casa Mila because of the colors.I already have visited the Sagrada Familia and Casa Batllò and I think it would be more of the same.From the outside is not so impressive as Casa Batllò.

Worth a visit. The roof terrace for me was one of the best part of the visit and the apartments. You need to enter the bulding through the side of the building. There are lockers right by the toilets where you cn leave your stuff and collect on the way back, which are free of charge. You then get the lift and start your tour at the roof terrace and work you way down. The visit will take aroun 1 hour and 30 mins. If you can only chose between this or Casa Batllo, I personally would choose Casa Batllo as it was more colourful and more to see. Otherwise do both, special in there own way.

Beautiful stuff. Good value for your money if you only want to visit one of the houses Gaudí built. The trip starts at the roof, which is a bit strange, but you get to visit the most important quarters as well.

much prefer Gaudi's design. the roof terrace was amazing, beautiful and not over ornated. inside was less elaborated as casa batllo. but the exhibition was informative. it worths the entrance fee and particularly inspiring to design and architectural students and professionals.

an other one of Gaudi's emblematic building. an other beautiful building of Gaudi; it is very close to the Casa Batllo building at the street Paseo de Gracia; you should visit it as well to understand Gaudi's vision of art and architecture

Casa La Pedrera. A little disappointing. At the time of our visit there was a lot of building work going on so we could not visit the whole of the house. We were not offerend a discount an apology. It was worth the visit just for the history of the place but a bit too expensive. If you have visited the Gaudi Experience then you maybe do not need to visit the house.
ok but not worth the 16e. Great views from the roof of the building but not much to look at inside. Couldnt see the interior architecture very clearly, however had many other artifacts to look at,

best views especially at sunset. gorgeous views of Barcelona and fantastic architecture. better than the other gaudi house.. the roof terrace is spectacular. no exaggeration. bit expensive though. don't bother with the audio guide either, buy a coffee in the ground floor cafe instead.

Don't Miss!!. After Sagrada Familia, this is the other Gaudi building that's wortha visit. Make sure you head up to the roof if you can, there's a great view over Barcelona and the audio guide of the place is excellent!

A great introduction to Gaudi. We went here the day before visiting the Sagrada Familia and I think this was a good way round to do things. The roof of the building is very interesting, but the exhibition in the loft area and the apartment are truly fascinating and a good introduction to Gaudi and his vision.
must go. unless you are an art / architecture student, this is a wonderful place to go once.tip, pre-book per internet and avoid the waiting lines, that can be very big.
Interesting architecture. We took the tour of the Gaudi designed building. The details were amazing. There was also a recreation of a period apartment in the building that was worth seeing.

Strange, but incredible!. La Pedrera is one of my favourite buildings in Barcelona. Some are torn on the look of the building from the outside, in fact they say Mila (the owner) absolutely hated the building's look! but no matter how you feel about the look, the architecture behind it is incredible! I suggest going inside and really experiencing the building!

It's all in the details. The secret to enjoying Casa Mila is paying close attention to the details. This is basically just an apartment building with some stores at ground level, but architect Antonio Gaudi re-conceived every aspect of this tired old genre and invented a whole new kind of building.--check out the inventive door knobs modeled in clay and then cast in bronze--look at the door frames made of plaster with a twist--notice the unusual free-form shape of interior windows.--look down at the patterned floors in dining rooms and bathrooms--look up at plaster medallions in the ceilings--look at the iron work in the handrails between stairsGaudi was always thinking over the old form to find a new take.The essence of his re-definition is best found in the details.

Another Gaudi masterpiece. This was well down our list of places to visit but, after seeing Casa Batlló, Parc Guell and the Sagrada Familia I really wanted to compare with Casa Mila. Definitely worth it - especially the terrace on the top floor. Take the audio tour if you have the chance.

Excellent. You can walk around an entire apartment in this block that Gaudi built. He was so forward thinking with his light and space and this is a prime example. The roof space is well known and you should go there just for that. You need at least one and a half/two hours to appreciate it.
Funny looking building. As we visited on Christmas Day the building was closed, however it's worth going to have a look at this iconic building.

Disappointing. We had read that this was a must-see so included it in our itinerary. Of course it's interesting as one of Gaudi's major architectural creations but frankly we thought the inside disappointed in comparison with Palau Guell and La Sagrada Familia. We were also shocked by the price. It was 16.50 euros each excluding an audio guide (another 4 euros) and the only site during our whole visit that didn't offer a discount to over 65s.

Wonderful view of Gaudi masterpiece. Be sure to take the inside tour to see the terrace and the actual apartment of the era. The attic is also amazing in design and is also a museum of his design. The designs on the roof are up close and many more than to be from street.

Amazing!. It was the first place i visited in Barcelona and it was really amazing ...the roof and the beautifull see ..The enterior that provides you how a house in 1900's looked like...Very interesting..

Expensive but very interesting. Visited this site as I was very much interested in Gaudi's work while visiting Barcelona. Generally, architecture is not the main focus of my trips, but since this is such a big part of barcelona, I felt it was worth the entry fee: 40euros. You can do the visit in 1 hour, but can linger around for probably another 1 hr or so. Although the rooftop is the main attraction, I really liked the main lobby area, looking up the open mid-section of the building. Keep in mind that you're not allowed in the roof if it is raining.

Amazing. We were lucky to be there for this amazing building 100th anniversary. It is hard to belive that such a building could have possibly have been constructed 100 years earlier. From the colours to the curved lines it is a must.

HISTORICAL RESIDENTIAL BUILDING. The design of the building is very nice. You can see the historical residential apartment with detailed lay-out and yet the concept is very morden. The rooms were quite big however you could not find a lot of supporting beams around the building so the design concept was very good. On the top floor, you can have a very good view of the city and take some good pictures of the city. Part of the building is still occupied and you can just visit only a very little part of the building however you would be amazed by the lay-out and design of the building as you don't feel congessted walking around the building which was built long time ago.

a superb furnished apartment. This was our first visit to a Gaudi building, we expected a lot and were not disappointed.The highlight of the visit was the beautiful furnished apartment; I was blown away by it, definitely made a lasting impression.It probably helped that we visited in a low season in the morning, so we didn't have to share with a lot of other visitors. As with any Gaudi building (apart from Sagrada Familia) - it's of benefit to time your visit so as to be there when the building is not crowded, e.g. a weekday in the morning or maybe before it closes.

An amazing roof with fabulous views. La Pedrera is located on Passeig de Gracia in The Eixample district of Barcelona. It is an amazing Gaudi-designed structure with curved stone walls and feature balonies made of twisted leaf-shaped wrought iron. You can walk through a large appartment, the attics, an exhibition room and onto the incredible roof which needs to be seen to be believed. The view from the top over Barcelona is also superb. I guess it's like marmite; you'll either love it or hate it.......
The roof is the best part!. The roof had many interesting figures (great for photo ops). You can also see Familia Sagrada from the rooftop. I also enjoyed seeing the apartment with period furniture.

Highly overrated.. This is one of Gaudí’s most famous works in Barcelona, and frankly – I found it to be highly overrated.I know lots of people would think it's almost "blasphemy", but this is one UGLY building and while it does have Gaudí written all over it, even art can be ugly.So once you admit that the building itself is not attractive, the visit in it and on its roof is pretty average (yet rather expensive at 16 Euros per adult).So, unless you are a hard core Gaudí fan, you can settle with watching the building from the street for a couple of minutes and visit the gift shop.

walking inside Gaudi's creation. We had the privilege of visiting this Gaudi creation! From its gorgeous rooftop to the opportunity of visiting one of the huge, fabulous apartments in this building, this was well worth seeing. Gaudi was a genius, and his spirit and whimy show through his remarkable creations.

Rooftop drama. La Pedrera is already fascinating from the outside, wavy balconies with leaf shapes clinging to them, but do part with the rather exorbitant entrance fee of 16.50 euros to go in and experience this unique apartment for yourself. The rooftop is the most spectacular with the giant sentinels of chimney pots that seem to come from some science fiction movie and the pot-bellied stairwells inspired by conches from the sea. In fact, as the exhibits inside show, Gaudi was inspired by everything in nature, acorns, bark and branches of trees, surfaces and textures that form natural patterns. An elevator can take you up and down the many floors but you still need to climb up and down to see nooks and crannies, especially on the rooftop, so not very safe for children or the elderly, and some rooms and passageways are dimly-lit, but a fascinating journey through the wild imagination of an exceptional artiste.Stay in one of the hotels on the Passeig de Gracia to see both La Predera and Casa Battlo further down the road. Hotel Next To has a view of Casa Mila's chimney tops from its terrace. Don't miss the gift shop on the ground floor, full of well-crafted souvenirs, jewelry, stationery scarves, books, calendars.

Incredible building. Thouroughly enjoyable visit to this fine example of Gaudi architecture. Not for the faint hearted with many many steps on the rooftop....stunning views of Barcelona....the apartment below is worth a visit as are the many exhibits of how Gaudi was influenced in his design.

A remarkable sight. Just across the road from our hotel, Condes de Barcelona, and something I would probably not otherwise have seen. Very unusual and impressive with visitors able to wander on the roof top terrace.

Go inside - you aint see nothing from the outside!. PS: Let me start off with this - if you plan to visit Picasso Museum, MNAC and La Pedrera, but the "Art-ticket" - which is only EUR28.5-30. You will save a lot than buying tickets individually.Nuf said, let's focus on the main topic - main people just stopped at the front corner of La Pedrera, looked up and took pictures. Don't just stopped there - go inside and pay a visit. It is definitely worth it - even for us which paid EUR16.5 per pax (see my comments re: Art-ticket above).Sagrada Familia is what Gaudi can do in a church. La Pedrera shows you what Gaudi can do in a residential block.You start off visiting the roof top - very smart idea. You can a glimpse of the neighbourhood and then proceed to the Attic level. The attic level provides good explanation of the technical aspect of Casa Milla and also the social backdrop when these all happened. Do take time to appreciate Casa Milla.

Just Amazing !!!!. If you find yourself in Barcelona wondering where to go...Do not think twice. Jump on the Metro and visit "La Pedrera". You wont be disappointed. It was so worth it and will remember it for the rest of my life.

Stunning. It was great to get up close to this amazingly designed building. Walking around the roof terrace gives a totally different feel to seeing the building from the street. I would highly recommend this tour if you are a fan of architecture or of art nouveaux.

Must visit !!!!!. This is an outstanding place to see. The roof terrace is the start of the tour then you work your way down 1st the attic which is very good for info on how the apartments were built and other info on other Gaudi buildings. Then down to the apartments that you can see one is set up as an info spot the other decorated and furnished as in the early 1900's then its out through the gift shop.

Not worth paying to see inside external architecture worth seeing. If you are wondering which of the Gaudi masterpieces you should be spending money on -I would suggest paying to see Familia Segrada interior and seeing the rest from the outside The external appearance of Casa Mila is worth going past to see as are the other Gaudi apartment/buildings. Casa Mila costs a bit too much and I did not feel that the visit of the interior was worth it.

Very nice but not sure if I would buy the ticket. My friends and I saw La Pedrera for free as it had its 100th anniversary. We arrived there at 10.00 and there was already a long line forming. Took us about one hour to get in. First of all it is important to say that you wont be able to see the whole building as there are people living there! You are allowed to go to the roof, which is quite nice and offers a nice view of Barcelona. After that you go one floor down, to the attic. The vault is interesting. You get to see some videos and expositions, but to be honest, after 5 min I was getting bored. After that you go another floor down and you get to see the flats... Some aspects are really nice, but overall, if you are not the person who will stare on things of other people, you will be bored. I liked the kitchen as it did not have typical angles of a room and the office, but that was about it. I got to try one of the chairs designed by Gaudi and surprisingly although they were from wood only, they were SUPER comfortable! Try it yourself, outside of the dining room, on the right side. And then you go down the stairs till you reach ground floor and that's it! It was really nice to see it for free, but I am not sure if I would recommend it to my friends
Incredible. The first housing velopment in Europe with even the first garage. It is exciting to go to the roof top to see all the Gaudi masterpieces.

Casa Mila. Allthough not as impressive as Casa Battlo, this is still another must see in Barcelona. The rooftop in a warm december sun was very enjoyable, but also the attic with an overview of Gaudi's life and work is definitely worth your time.

Life in 1920s Barcelona - as interpreted by Gaudi. Amazing little Gaudi gem on Passeig de Gracia. The rooftop is a must see, the attic will give you an excellent insight into the world of Gaudi and early 20th century Barcelona and the restored apartment will give a real feel for life in that age. Do not miss the rooftop or the interior courtyard.

Roof terrace is the only highlight!. We had an overdose of Gaudi on our first day but the rooftop terrace is simply cool! The skyline and the way how it flowed was simply interesting. Loved the chair presentation too:)

Interesting to see inside the apartments. The chimneys on the roof are quite enchanting and it's fascinating to see how Gaudi used natural light in his architecture. If you buy the Art Ticket, Casa Mila is included in the price.
good gaudi flavor. even though I love the architecture of the place, if you have limited time, I recomend casa batllo better.

Don't Miss It. Visit the special exhibition to learn more about Gaudi and get a glimpse of this amazing building. Yes, its worth the 16.50 euro to tour the roof, attic and apartment. But the Articket to visit La Predrera and several other great museums.
Mila House. Again, Guardi, you could just do tours of his buildings. They are like something you have never seen before.

Gaudi the Great!. This is one of the best places to experience the wonder of Gaudi's architecture. Don't miss it! You don't need to be part of a tour but you may have to wait to get in. It's worth the wait-amazing interiors and spaces.

The one "Gaudi" I wanted to see.. This place is so unique, unlike any other apartment building! There was a line, but not too long. From the rooftop there is a great view of Sagrada Familia, a bonus. I really enjoyed seeing this place with its unique and quirky architecture!

Rooftop alone makes this worthwhile. Gaudi at his domestic architectural best. It's a bit expensive to get in, but first stop is a whisk-lift to the rooftop, where not only do you get panoramic views of the city and the famous Sagra Familia (take a picture of it framed in the corner archway), but you goggle at the fancy designs that are chimneys or air vents or just fancy ideas! Inside, the film (with English subtitles) gives a fascinating look at the history of Barcelona in the time of change as these apartments were being designed then built. Then there are the museum-piece apartments themselves to see. The tour finishes inevitably in the over-priced shop, but avoid that and you'll remember the tour as interesting and worthwhile.
gaudi type of house. impressive. a bit expensive but nice to see, at least for those who lives in a common and sad condominium and thinks it is just a condominium nothing else

WOW!. It seems like everything we saw in Barcelona was different than anything we had seen before. The roof top designs for the water towers and chimneys, the structure of the attic, the inner courtyard were all wonderful.
Gaudi masterpiece. Took the full tour of La Pedrera and thoroughly recommend it. Had already done a Gaudi walking tour and loved the building, rooftop is amazing.....the best part of the tour for me.
Another Gaudi but more detailed. Another Gauidi but more to the details than Casa Batllo, this one even though it is part museum part normal business it is a museum. Again Gaudi's work detailed

Ok Cafe, Glacial Service. We went for a quick lunch (not an American quick lunch, a European menu) which was quite tasty in a beautiful Gaudi room, but it took fifteen minutes to get a menu, fifty to receive our first course. Three people, one behind the bar pouring the drinks and making the coffee, were serving about 35.Hopefully, three staff called in sick that day and this is not normal, but it was excruciating that day.The room, it must be said, is a must-see.

Another must-see example of Gaudi. Casa Mila is run by a private company and the building is a must-see, from it's whimsical chimneys to the stunning apartment on view, this is a working building, with many floors occupied by commercial businesses, so it's a little different to casa Batlo. Most of the interesting features are internal, so there isn't much to see from the outside. Do take the audio tour and find out why this building is designed that way.

Surprisingly absorbing experience - well worth it.. Leave plenty of time to see La Pedrera, at least two hours from arrival. The roof is great fun on its own, and weird enough to keep you looking for ages. The views are also good across the city. The attic space is informative (although the kids will want to get through it quickly!). The hidden gem in La Pedrera is the re-created apartment floor, which is fascinating and beguilingly extensive. Don't miss it for the complete experience.
The Roof. Very nice to walk on the roof of La Pedrera. Tip: in summer go there just before the sun is going down.

quirky and cool. I didn't see thistle first time I visited Barcelona, boy am I glad I have now. Visit Sagrada Familia and then walk down the street to this, it will take 10 mins to get there, it's a great place for pictures and fascinating architecture. When you are finished visit mauri for great pinxo and then it's 5 minutes walk to Casa Batillo. good little tour!
Can I buy a flat there, MOM PLEASE ;). An amazing architecture! Definitely worth seeing. Be extra careful in the roof! Two shops full of beautiful souvenirs, probably best in the city.

La Pedrera. We did a tour of this house on the morning of our departure and we all thoroughly enjoyed the whole experience and even now we are still talking about the whole experience, and we have loads of photos which we will treasure for a long time.

Interesting building. This was the last of the Gaudi works I visited. Loved and appreciated them all. Learning about Gaudi, his nature-inspired and symbolic style, intention and attention to every detail of design, and then attending each of these works has been an incredible experience. At La Pedrera, it seemed as if there wasn't as much of the building available to explore as some of the others. The inside of the building appeared slightly more refined and classic compared to some of the fantastic/surreal elements found in Casa Batlo or La Segrada Familia for example. Lovely and interesting and absolutely worth the visit nonetheless.

Gaudi was such a visionary. We got here too late one night and could only get into the Architectural Exhibit which was interesting and free. Went back one morning to tour and loved everything from the roof top and attic to the model apartment. Such tremendous and thoughtful detail for the design. The "museum" in the attic gives insight and information about some of the other Gaudi works including Sagrada Familia and Park Guell. Great audio tour.
Rooftop is great.. It's one of Gaudi's representative architectures. The highlights of Casa Mila is its rooftop. you'll see funny african warrior like sculptures up there.

Beware pickpockets!. Our lovely perusal of this beautiful house was capped by my husband being pickpocketed in the gift shop of the building. It gets very crowded, people brushing up against one another to look at the merchandise. The useless security guard, who should be watching on the inside, was outside chatting with people and, when informed of the theft, kinda shrugged and suggested we go to the police, which we didn't as it is a useless waste of time. Fortunately, my husband felt it right away, but the thief slipped away in the crowd. I was able to call immediately and cancel the credit cards, small satisfaction that the use of them was thwarted. Anyway, just a reminder to be vigilant. Signs all over warn about pickpockets. Shame on the gift shop for not having more efficient security inside the store.
go to the roof. Beautiful view of history and design beginning at the roof top. After a day of observing Gaudi it was great to dive right into one of these buildings....

Getting into Gaudi's Vision. There's not much that has not been said about this Gaudi masterpiece, and you can read all that in other reviews. But there are two things I recommend: 1. Go on an overcast day, as that cuts down the lines considerably. It rained less than an hour before our visit, and we had no wait. The roof was open and fairly dry and we had plenty of time and room to move about on it. 2. Spend some time with the models in the attic. Some of the before/after ones are amazing and help you understand his architectural vision.

Another "Gaudi magic". Well, one feels that after seeing few works of Antoni Gaudi, it should look the same. But you are wrong. This is another masterpiece from the him. The apartment shows the life of a resident in early 19th century. It is really amazing to see the modern way of thought that Gaudi had. Casa Mila should not be missed just because you have seen the others and It is very close to the city centre.

Great Experience.. We really enjoyed our visit at La Pedrera. To see the appartments as they would have been furnished was brilliant. Also the rooftop is stunning. There was an exhibition of architects on at the time, which was very interesting. After we went to the bar in the same building and ordered cocktails. Very friendly and attentive service.

One of a Kind. I must admit even after researching La Pedrera I wasn't very excited to go, but I was very pleasantly surprised by the amount of things to see end explore in the building. The architecture is like nothing else in the world. The views from the roof are fantastic. The models and other exhibits in the Attic are not to be missed. We spent several hours at La Pedrera and had a wonderful time. Even after seeing it all, I might return for another visit in the future.

Casa Mila. On the first day we tried to visit, the roof top was closed due to rain, yet they still wanted to charge same price so we did not go up (the roof is the best part!). When we went next time it was very interesting, amazing architecture but a bit pricey for families (perhaps kids could go free with adults?)

I love it!!. This is a very impressive place to visit! it's well located and with fair access price. It is a nice and interesting architecture master piece even for me who knows nothing on the subject

Well, it's nice.... We liked La Pedrera, but both of us came out thinking that it surely is not the gorgeous do not miss thing people say. It is interesting, but it does not come close to some of the other Barcelona attractions.
Great visit. really beautiful- and the detailed audio guide was interesting and informative! I've been to other Gaudi houses on a previous visit- but this was my favorite.

A Highlight of Barcelona. I am not one to typically go to museums while traveling, and picking museums to see in Barcelona can be daunting, as there are so many and they are all quite pricey. With that said, after seeing photos of La Pedrera (Casa Mila), I decided to check it out, and was amazed as soon as I stepped onto the terrace. Gaudi's work is unique, to say the least, and this is one of his gems. The roof is spectacular to explore, and although not huge, it has just enough sculptures to keep you entertained. Not only do you leave feeling like you stepped into a sort of fantasy land/crazy house, but the views of Barcelona are also great from the roof top. Definitely worth the €16.50!

Unique and Very Interesting. I may be a bit of a Philistine but I have to admit that by the end of my visit to Barcelona I was a bit "Gaudi'd Out". However there is no doubt that the man was a brilliant and innovative architect and some of his work is sensational. La Pedrera was the first of his buildings we visited and one of my favourites. The line-up can be quite long and in the summer I would imagine colossal.

What a house!. Gaudi is fantastic! In fact, many architects of the latest XIX century did wonderful buildings in Barcelona and Modernism astounds you, but Gaudi gave his signature to the city. Don't miss it, otherwise, you didn't stayed in Barcelona

The roof of Paseo de Gracia. We just were in awe up on the roof of La Pedrera. The chimineys were so extraordinar and bizarre. What kind of genius could have created them? Only Antonio Gaudi. One more awesome creation by this great man

Save your money. I enjoyed Casa Batllo much more for the admission. The roof is very nice, I would choose a night admission if I was going to return. I would imagine the house and roof to be very beautiful lit up at night.

A must see of Guadi works. I was amazed with this place. Starting with the roof with its signature chimneys. Marvel with this historic building when you go down through the attic and appartments.
I just thought that it is overpriced as a national monument.
An architectural wonder. An artistic expression in the form of a building--so wonderfully creative and unconventional. Especially amazing that it was constructed so early in the 20th Century.

Organic beauty. A must see when in Barca. Gaudi's achitecture is a fantastic experience. This is a lovely Art Noveau apartment building. It's well planned and you get to go into an apartment furnished as it would've been with period furniture many of the pieces designed by Gaudi.

If you like history... u must see. If you, like history, you must see Gaudi arhitecture, is something what will never forgot... Nothing to tell more. If you planning go to the Barcelona, you have to see.

Beautiful and charming. We went to three of Gaudi's houses while in Barcelona, and this was my favorite. I would love to live here, actually - all the adorable moldings and the pocket doors and curved rooms and halls...so charming! Plus the chimneys and attic and entranceway - amazing work. Don't miss it.

an architectural fantasy. The lines can be long but if you go a few minutes before the opening time you can walk right in . Even though the outside of the building is the most interesting it is worth going inside to see the way people lived and the furniture.
Never served us. I am giving this a 2 even though we never received our coffee because it is an amazing place to see a Gaudi design inside for free. We tried to order coffee twice. We never got it.

Fantastic. This was the second time I have visited the La Pedrera. I love and never get bored of looking at Gaudi's work. It was very busy on this occasion and hard to get the ideal picture but was great to just sit a look at his hard work,

Guadi House. Fantastic guided tour with the headset commentaries. Enjoyed the various views of Barcelona available from the roof. A walk through of the attic gives a very powerful perspective on the underlying roof structure.

Masterpiece building. This building / museum is one of the masterpieces (park guell is the other one) of catalan art-nouveau architect Antonia Gaudi. At the beginning everything looks like strange, but when take info about art nouveau, you respect Gaudi. Especially loft is very interesting!
Wow! Don't miss this. Equal to the Sagradia Familia. Gaudi was an enginerring marvel as well as an innovatove designer. Must see!
Amazing!. Just go there and watch!You will be astonished with the beauty! It is one of the most beautiful things I ever saw!

Start your Gaudi experience here. Suddenly appearing from the lift into bright sunlight on the roof is an unforgettable experience. And then one floor down you can see the intricacy of the structure that supports La Pedrera. It all gives some insight into the creation of La Sagrada Familia.

you have to see to beleive. amazing architecture and what blew me away was that Gaudi was allowed to build this. I am so glad there was foresight in those times, puts our modern narrow mindedness to shame

Gaudi is now my new favorite architect. Started my visit to Sagrada Familia; then I saw Casa Batllo; but the piece de resistance is La Pedrera. Buy the audio guide not so much to see the crazy chimneys atop the roof - but so you can also understand more about the architect, and the time when this was constructed. To that end, the furnished fourth floor apartment was equally interesting - to see how a middle-class family of that period had lived.
No roof walk!. Due to rain, the roof was closed! Wish I had control over the weather! Had to be content to peek through the windows!
Gaudi -- again!. Such a unique building. The apartments available to tour are furnished in the time period. Loved being up on the roof overlooking Barcelona. Attic museum interesting.

Second visit a must!. Second tour of building in 6 yrs. a must. Seems like the building exhibit of old apartment has been expanded or I just had more to note. LOVED the exterior, roof, museum is great.

great city views!. On a sunny day, on top of this wonderful work, you can see Barcelona before you. You take the elevator up to the terrace and work your way down. The gift shop is fantastic and I regret not buying those charming art noveau earrings! Next time!

Expensive but interesting. The price was a bit expensive, considering you can visit Sagrada Familia down the road for a bit less. The staff member manning the lift was a bit rude to us so we just took the stairs instead. The roof has great views, I wasn't too impressed with the attic spaces appearance but it had some interesting information on Gaudi housed in it, the apartment was great to see and gives you a real good idea of how it was.
beautiful especially at sunset!. lovely chance to see Gaudis work up close with some excellent resources to show how the house was constructed. Great place to visit!

Great a must!. And if you keep walking on the side street, you arrive at la Sagrada Familia", across the street is a delicious, deli/café, wirh great bread and salads. The house of course is worth visiting especially if you enjoy architecture. Go to the roof, and get a spectacular view of the Paseo de Gracia. The tour bus stops here.
The one.... ... and only one... It's spectacular on the top, mainly. Pretty expensive the entrance, but it's worth it...

Another must see!. Words cannot describe this building. You have to see it for yourself! The view from the rooftop is terrific! You can see the Sagrada Familia as well as all around Barcelona, but the rooftop is worth seeing for itself. Gaudi had a wonderful imagination and his buildings are like nothing else....almost like fairy tale structures!

Worth the tour. The roof top alone is worth the tour. It is quite amazing, it's a geometric wonderland. Like an Escher come to life. Must do the tour for the roof top alone. The apartments we great too.

All about the chimneys. Skip the apartment. It is mostly plain and boring. The exterior and the fantastical chimneys make it more than worth the trip though. Although if I had to choose one house it would be Casa Batllo which has a less interesting roof but has a far better interior.

a must see!!. more insight into Gaudi's work. Only the rooftop, attic and one apartment are open to the public since this is a private apartment complex, but it's enough to get an insight into the architect's work

Very Cool Architechture. Right on Passeig de Gracia, it is an easy site to get to. Worth some good pictures from the outside. Didn't do the inside tour as it didn't make our list of things we had time to do.
another Gaudi masterpiece. Again arriving early is worth the effort and if you can visit when the Mila apartment now the exibition hall is open

Nicer from Outside. It so nice from outside, that when you go inside you wonder if it was worth paying so much.... Anyway the terrace visit is nice and it is fun taking photos up there. The rest is so so...

How to learn about Gaudi. This tour is very educational and is an absolute must to understand Gaudi's genius. it sets you up to understand and appreciate how his designs came about from the smallest handle to the largest towers

Breathtaking architecture. Being a huge fan of the Arts & Crafts Movement in the UK, this building blew me away. It's one of those buildings that is inspirational - the creativity of Gaudi was amazing. I just have to go back and take it all in - all over again

Fantastic views from the roof. Great example of Gaudi's work. Really enjoyed all the information we gleaned from the audio guides. Only negative: unfriendly staff. They seemed so eager to get us out of there, when there was over an hour to closing time. Curt and unhelpful. Definitely a disappointment

It was good. If you have to make a chouce between La pedrera and Casa Batllo, I'd say go to Casa Batllo. But La Pedrera is not bad. When we bought the tickets to LP we it included passes to a few other attractions including the MNAC which made the trip to LP worth while.

It looks like melted wax.. Gaudi built this six-story building for his patron, the Mila family. It is rounded in every way, so that there are no ninety degree angles in it. The interior apartments were designed so that the owners could have complete freedom in arranging the rooms, since there are no structural supports in the interior of the building! Definitely worth a visit.
another Gaudi Masterpeice. gain if your in Barcelona it's a crime not to visit this peice of work by Gaudi. the roof top is amazing and a must
Only saw outside. Impressive. The queue was too big. Was the entry price for us... But it was seriously impressive. Gaudi design and the uniqueness made it stand out

A building that feels as though it is alive.. You can visit the roof, the attic and a floor of this apartment building. The roof is magical, the attic is fascinating (and has a good exhibition of Gaudi's work methods) and the apartment itself is beautiful. Entry numbers are strictly regulated so that it never felt crowded. We took the longer length audio-guide and were so glad we did. It was really interesting. You can go round this quickly, or slowly and thoughtfully. We did it on our last morning in Barcelona and we didn't want to leave.
I want to live here. This incredible apartment house by Gaudi was amazing for its time and is still amazing. The roof is something out of Dr. Seuss. It is a must see.

A must see Gaudi designed house.. This was brilliant. The queues were horrendous so pre booking is a must- however we took the new "night tour" which I would strongly recommend. Although twice the price the guided tour is a small group and got to see amazing rooftop views at night and more of apartments internally than usual.
Absolutely beautiful!. My husband and I enjoyed walking through this wonderful building. There was so much interesting architecture to see.

Very expensive to go inside. This is an amazing building from the outside but at just over €20 each for entrance, we were limited to only viewing the outside. I suspect they keep it at this price to limit footfall and therefore damage to the property but it's disappointing all the same.

Typical Gaudi. This house is magical but in my opinion less than the battlo! The fee was less, which is a good thing! The terrace is very beautiful and during the night that i went there it was like walking around in a house in a fairy tale!

Amazing. Amazing architecture, not a single straight line must have been the rule for Gaudì, why steal with pride and leverage on others successes when you can reinvent everything and be unique from A to Z!

just amazing. Gaudi was amazing. When you learn and see and experience his inspirations from nature in his designs, you are even more in awe. And he devoted his entire life to his works. I must go back to Barcelona and see more!

Good, but..... Being a bit limited for time we had considered looking at the outside and moving on but in we went, parting with another fistful of Euros. Magnificent in parts - I loved the roof but my wife didn't but the display in the attic with its models and films were very good. Perhaps if we hadn't been to the Casa Batllo first we would have enjoyed it more.
Gaudi brilliance. We arrived at 6pm and you go up to the roof terrace first. Seeing it floodlit was stunning. Slightly spooky and surreal. The house is beautiful. This is a must see.

Another miracle of Gaudi imagination. This building is atractive not only from outside and inside but as well becouse you can see amaizing roof with chimneys wich look like Lord Vader mask. More over you can see beatifull panorama of Barcelona. Sagrada Famlia, straight streets of the city, Montjuic ect. Is hard to belive that one man could created so many beatifull buildings in one city.

Amazing. This was my first Gaudi experience. The imagination and execution is amazing. This is a must-see in my view. Apart from the building itself, there's an exhibition about Gaudi and his work in the attics, which could easily take plenty of time if you view everything. There's a lot of audiovisual stuff. The roof is fantastic, but closed if it is raining; so don't go unless you have no choice. It's easy to understand why: the flooring would be very slippery, if it was wet.The only downside: it was very busy. Queues to get in and people getting in the way of photography. Though, no doubt, we were getting in someone else's viewfinder.

Outstanding.. Be sure to go to the rooftop of this building and see how well Gaudi planned even these details. Another masterpiece of this genius, and even after I'd read books & the internet about them beforehand I was not fully prepared for the beauty and intricacy of any of Gaudi's structures.

Iconic. On the Passeig de Gracia, about 15 minutes' walk north of the Placa de Catalunya, this is a masterpiece by Gaudi. The outside of the block of flats is astonishing, with hardly a straight line anywhere. The attraction is accessible in three parts: the roof (great views, flowing rooflines and astonishing chimneys), the attic (a tour de force, unbelievably, and containing an exhibition explaining Gaudi's ideas and principles) and a flat, funished in the style of the period. From the plan in the exhibition, the layout of the flat was bizarre - but on entering, it can be seen to work brilliantly. The piece de resistance.There is a cafe and shop on the ground floor. Also worth looking at are the interior 'courtyards'- if the ovaloid shapes can be termed as such.As Glasgow has Mackintosh, so Barcelona has Gaudi.Only a minor quibble: at E16.50 it was a bit pricy - dearer than the Sagrada Familia.

Very pretty. You can take the stairs or the lift. We opted for the stairs and it is exhausting - especially if you've already done a lot of walking in Barcelona. When we went in, the weather was fine, by the time we got to the roof, it had started raining and it was very slippery and the railings to the outside are few and far between - be very aware if you've got kids with you!

Mind boggling - wonderful. I loved every aspect of this building. We went at sunset so had the glorious vista of the sun catching these quirky shapes. The information of Gaudi's work was cleverly displayed in the attic and it was fascinating . The apartment was full of period furniture and design. It was quite busy but when there was a gap in the human chain you could get a sense of the space . The floors were very beautiful tile and parquet. I could have sat on that roof top for hours

Apartment living in the round!. This colorful and quixotic Gaudi building is a must see. The rooftop chimneys and steps afford a great view. The small museum of drawings is helpful and a tour of a typical apartment is a trip in the round. Don 't miss it!

Easy to see Gaudi house on Passeig de Gracia. It's right on Passeig de Gracia and you can at least take a look and take some photos of the building as you walk along Passeig de Gracia -- we always do when we are in Barcelona :-)

Dissapointed. There was nothing interesting other than the roof. It was raining so the roof also was not enjoyable that much. There were four sections but one of them was closed. However the entrance price was full which is too much for it. If you are to choose one, visit Casa Batllo

much information, few things to see. The building is very big, so you expect to see some things. The roof is one of the main attractions on this building. The attic is fun to see and you get a lot of information about the construction and the idea behind the building. Unfortunately, about 6 stories can't be seen. The remaining one is nice and shows two appartments.
Gaudi was a genius. for me la Pedrera from outside looks a haunted halloween house,I love art and for me was a real learning experince to see how this artist come up with something like that great
Batllo was cooler. If you have time, check this out, especially the rooftop. Otherwise, just do the other Gaudi stuff and call it a day.
Magic Carpet Ride. Another great surprise right in the middle of the city. All about the rooftop. Gaudi had a fantastic imagination, and this site exemplified it to perfection.

Experience the life of a well to do family. What a great presentation of early apartment life for the well off.
The whole building is designed with Gaudi's brilliant innovations to make life more convenient and comfortable .
The Pedrera Apartment is particularly pleasing for its accurate depiction of the period, down to the tiniest of detail. The Roof Terrace is just a "buzz"...the "scare witches" are great !

Gaudi at his absolute best. Even if you do not pay to enter La Pedrera, no trip to Barcelona is complete without admiring this masterpiece at least from the outside. Take the metro to Diagonal and it is just a few steps away. The undulating facades are like a beach after the tide has gone out; the wrought iron balconies resemble clumps of seaweed. This is one of the world's most original buildings.The entrance fee is not cheap - 16 euros, but if you like what you see on the outside, do venture inside - it is well worth a visit. The atrium is like a sumptuous cave, with columns in organic forms and fantastic wall paintings. Take the lift to the roof, which is like a fabulous chimney-top playground with wonderful views over the city. Make sure you get a photo of La Sagrada Familia from up here - this is probably the best place from which to view Gaudi's cathedral.The 'attic' has an interesting exhibition about the construction of the building, with lots of maquettes, but the next floor down is the real highlight - a reconstruction of the decor and furnishings from the building's heyday, when it was built for the Mila family. Wow - this is just incredible. If you love art nouveau style, then do not miss this.If you are planning to see both the Casa Battlo and La Pedrera, I would recommend that you see Casa Battlo first. Although its dragon-backed roof and scaly walls may be more spectacular, I think that the interior of La Pedrera is the more impressive. It only takes five minutes to walk between the two, so make sure you see them both.
You'll see Gaudi in action here. From the roof down, well worth the cost and the time. Real insight into the early 1900 apartment living (for the well to do) and into the artist and his vision.

Roof chimneys. If it's raining don't go as the roof won't be open and that's the best bit. See Gaudi's vivid imagination, sinuous curves and vibrant colours. Then go down into the attics for the exhibition of his other works, the apartment is worth it too. Another great experience!
Worth the money. It was not cheap getting there but we enjoyed it, the roof is very nice, and the inside of the house as well, it was worth our visit, mr gaudi at his best

Fascinating Place to Experience. We were not really familiar with Gaudi before visiting Barcelona but both my husband and I found La Pedrera and his Unfinished Cathedral to be "don't miss" experiences. He was so far ahead of his time and his work is amazing!
Too pricey to get in. We did not opt to see the work as it was 16 euros to get in. So we opted to take the pictures from the outside of the building.
Another great Gaudi. The roof is the main thing here and since it is a sloping roof, it is closed in bad weather. So do not go here in the rain and miss such a wonderful part of th house.
Tourist ripoff. Over priced entry fee at £15 per person! I understand money is needed to keep this type of place going but we felt for what it was the price was a bit steep :-(

Wow, Gaudi was quite the artist. This is located on Passeig de Gracia, we did not go inside for the tour but the outside was beautiful and we did visit the gift shop which had many interesting pieces of art.
Couldn't get in. Such a bummer the line was too long, but I did manage to eat in the coffee shop and could see into the internal courtyard through it.

Overwhelming. Outstanding masterpiece of Gaudi ! It is a must see while in Barcelona. For me it was the most beautiful of Gaudi's works. I would stay there for days if possible. It is incredible how actual can be a masterpiece created more than 100 yrs ago.It is very important to have the audio-guide.Tip : buy tickets on internet in order to avoid lines and save time

Love the roof. Casa Mila, a very interesting piece by Gaudi. The roof is impressive and it offers a nice view of the city. If you decide not to go for the elevator, the stairs will definitely give you a good workout!

Casa Milla. Of my God! I said so when the tears come seeing this marvellios building. Is imposibil to discibe the impresion how stone and iron can be so felexibil and solid in same time, to live toghther in a strong coudle, to releved with this big force love of Gaudi for nature and for human beegns!

A bit of a walk, not really worth it. Expect a long walk from the metro station, long queue, short stroll around a roof top looking at Gaudi chimneys, not really worth all the effort to be honest (even coming from a Gaudi fan)

A work of art. Another must see in Barcelona. The roof is amasing! It has a museum inside with sketches and work of Gaudí. You also get to see one of the apartments and then you'll see why Gaudí is so famous. Reserve 3 or 4 hours for it. If you like architecture, reserve 5 hours. It is definitely worthwhile.

When it rains the terras is not open. La pedrera is nice when you can get up on the terras but that is not possible when it rains. It is abeautiful building but felt that the exhibition floor was a bit dissapointing. The appartement is nice to see.
Wonderful!!. Saw the roof in afternoon sun then headed down to check out apartment then up to roof again to see it at dusk with setting sun, looks so different. Great experience!
Beautiful Gaudi. If you are on a budget, outside will do! Go and see Casa Battlo which is ( even) more interesting. If night lights are on, wonderful. Just cross the street to have a better look.

First stop. Start here and go early to avoid the crowds. In the attic a lot of Gaudi's other works are explained and is very informative. You will get an understanding of the whole city by staring here.

definitely worth the money. Whether or not you like Gaudi, this is worth the 16.50 euros entry fee. its another 4 euros for the audio tour if you require it, but simply walking through this apartment block is great. The ticket gives you access to the rooftop terrace, the attic, Gaudi's old apartment which is a museum. Roaming around this building you understand what a master Gaudi was - interestingly most of his sites are in view of each other which shows how well the thought things through. Luckily the queue was only about 10 minutes and I found the best time (lighting) was in the afternoon from about 2pm.
A must for Gaudi fans!. Truly a must for Gaudi fans! Intricate architecture and design. It is worth booking a ticket in advance to avoid the queues.
Wonderful!. The rooftop is magical! It was interesting to see the recreations of the rooms in the model apartment.
Overly priced. After see Casa Batlo,Parc Guell, the Sagrda Familia and other works of Gaudi this was actually a bit boring and definitely overly priced. Not worth the money.

The architect of the future who came from the past !. I have been fascinated by Antoinio Gaudi for decades, have looked at hundreds of photos, and yet nothing prepared me for the actual visit. A lie up is a given, but when you enter you are taken to the roof, where views of the city are wonderful and the artistry of his original and quirky style hit you with a gasp. Next level down features film, slide shows, and architectural models highlighting his life, his methodology, his wide range of design skill, from building, to furniture making, to mosaic, to wrought iron, to the unimaginable. Since the building was erected as an apartment building, the next level was a tour of an entire furnished unit. Each flat appears to have taken up an entire level, as a serpentine series of rooms around a central inner atrium running down the entire core of the building. If you go to Barcelona, can buy a 7 museum pass for 30 euros and we discovered this only after we had paid the 16 euro entry to this one. We will return to this incredible city and next time we will yake advantage of this wonderful value.
Another stunning piece. A bit expensive to go inside however well worth it. Views from Balcony beautiful. Take Hop On Hop Off tour bus and buy your ticket at entrance

Go there with your children, rain or shine!. Not to be missed. Very child friendly, the visit is very very well planned, from the rooftop walks to the exhibitions in between (with areas where kids can touch and manipulate materials, lots of videos and an excellent short film), looking at the furnished apartment, we went there on a rainy sad day and it cheered us up immensely!

No Straight Lines. The architect Antoni Gaudi created this weird and unique building, intending it as an appartment block. Parts of it is now a museum to weird and wonderful architecture. Best part is the roof with fairytale shapes and walkways. Great views too.

Casa Mila. Very interesting Gaudi sight. Unusual architecture. Tour is through various parts of this unusual housing structure, includes one of the furnished apartments from the 30's --- which Batllo does not. If Gaudi's architecture interests you this is a good sight to visit. Half of our group opted to view from the outsider only.
Wow!. Failed to get in in May 2009...having got to the chimneys and roof top had already decided the entrance fee was worth every eur (16.50)...there was much more...fantastic, Gaudi what a genius!

Wow. This was the first thing we visited. It is amazing. They say Gaudi was an architect, but I reckon there is a very fine line between this profession and modern art. The roof terrace of sculptures that act as air vents and the attic where they explain Gaudi's work is superb. The attic museum has lots of videos presented on large rectangular screens. The whole experience is peaceful and highly enjoyable and informative. A really excellent attraction and worth every penny. It is probably a good attrction to start with as it gives you an excellent overview of Gaudi's work across the city. If you don't like this then you probably shouldn't be in Barcelona!
hellasview. Really amazing building for the time it has been designed for and even for today! Make sure you visit the terrace with a unique view and design. It is also vey nice during the evening.

Good but preferred other examples. If you are short for time, just viewing this from the outside is enough and you could spend more time at,say, the Casa Battlo nearby. However, the tour is still interesting. The foyer is beautiful as are the magnificent entry doors. You take a lift to the amazing roof (from which you can take a photo of La Sagrada Familia). The attic below, with it's arches, has interesting models and displays.Then you walk down to the apartment (furnished not with original pieces from it but with items of the era).The two gift shops have some nice items and books.
Stunning. Amazing rooftop, Gaudi was years ahead of his time. It was less busy than Sagrada Famila but just as beautiful if you love architecture, art nouveau and mordernism

What an apartment block. Looks good from the outside but inside the tour is very good even to going round one of the apartments. The design uses wrought iron and such delicate brick arches whic support the florr above. Used the backbone and rib cages idea from reptile to link the brick arches together. On the roof all the chimneys and ventilation outlet take on the appearance of medievil knights and some are capped with broken bottles in mortar. High use of broken stone and glazed tile on others. Great views as well.
Gaudi strikes again!. If you are into architecture, you'll want to see this building that almost looks alive! The rooftop holds a little sci fi like scenery too. You do have to pay to go up top.
What a magnificent piece of art. Unfortunatelly the long queu for tickets put us off but even from outside you can see what a magnificent piece of art Casa Mila is.

Must see. La Pedrera was the first place we visited in Barcelona and well worth a visit. The architecture is stunning, as is the rooftop, the apartment on view in the building and the attic where the architectural thinking of Gaudi is on display.
Very Impressive. Awesome architecture. Nice views of the city. Worth the time and money. Accessible on Hop on Hop off bus route.

This is a must in Barcelona.. We found La Pedrera an inspiring monument to sheer architectural genius. If you are interesting at all in design, Gaudi is a must and this building gives you lots to see and digest - not to mention photo ops galore.

Very interesting. Don't miss the audioguide, the explanations are great and friendly for the tourists. You should visit the house by afternoon because in the morning it is very crowded. The visiting program is between 9 am-19 pm every day

Too expensive. I6 Euros admission cost. Not worth it.
At least the queue was not as long as the Sagrada Familia -but that was cheaper if you did not want to use the lift.
I only did this Gaudi in Eixample, as I was not prepared to pay another 16 euros to get into the others.
Barcelona attractions are overpriced.

worth a visit but pricey. The main atrraction is the building's roofterrace which offers spectacular views & shows the excentric gaudi sculptures.Next to this, the attic & an appartment can be visited as well which took about 45min in total.We though that 16,5 Euro for a ticket is rather pricey but this is the case for all Gaudi buildings in Barcelona (except Park Guell which is free)

Worth a visit. One of the most photographed roof tops in Spain. You should definitely see it for yourself. Not only do you get superb views over Barcelona but the Warrior chimney structures are quite remarkable. Like something out of Star Wars meets El Conquistadores. The apartment is also worth seeing. I first visited in summer some years ago and returned October 2012 when queues were much shorter. There are often musical events on in the evening which I hope to attend on a future visit to the city.

More Gaudi. Seemed quite expensive entry fee. You go straight to the roof to see the chimneys, difficult to photograph due to all the other people milling about. Next you go down to the attic, which houses an interesting exhibition on Gaudi's ideas and shows off the brick "rafters". Next floor down is an apartment in the block, showing how it was used. Expensive gift shop
Do not miss this!. This is an exceptionally unusual house and the roof should be visited around sunset for the best photos. The apartment which can be visited is beautifully presented.
Gaudi!!!!!!. This is one of those apartment buildings that you think could only happen in a fairytale. Gaudi was a genius.

Expensive, but worth the cost. Like other Gaudi buildings even though you have seen it on pictures, you are amazed when you stumble on it. Ticket is fairly expensive, but for it you get the view on typical apartment on the begining on 20th century, little museum of Gaudi inspirations and models and walk on the roof. But the roof alone is amazing! Don´t miss it!

Spending one hour inside is like stepping back in time. Such an incredible piece of art, and to think that a few people have had the chance to actually live there. Beyond (my) description. Simply lovely!
Not to be missed. One actually gets to go in this site and visit an apartment decorated and kept as it was originally. there is also an area where the designs and plans of Gaudi are shown.

As if concrete was magic...in other words, Gaudí!. Enormous but not bulky, this house is stunning: it looks as if it was done by a mix of sea-worn cream corals, shells and sea stones, layered by a film of soft wax on top. The windows and the balconies are done with sheer artistic freedom, the chimneys are scattered spontaneously in every position making the building look like a fairy tale palace. Gaudí called this house "la pedrera" but it's so much more than a quarry, like the translation could suggest. It looks as if it was done by everything soft and magic; think this was done around 100 years ago! Gaudí here also introduces the so-called chained arch, like a round soft V upside down: this stunning shape is perfect anywhere, it looks from time to time the inside of a whale, or a pure and white gothic monastery. Visiting this house before the Casa Batlló will help you set the correct time frame: believe me, you'll do good if you do like this! Absolutely sure that after you visit this, you will realize everything can be done if you have the right idea.

It is a must in Barcelona!. I travelled around Spain for two weeks and left some important sights to see befoe leaving.I decied to buy an Airticket,as it gives you many advantages.Firts,you have an entrance to seven museums,including Mila House.Second,you dont have to stand in a long line.La Pedrera is the best sights which impressed me a lot.I had a n opportunity to visit the roof,attic,an apartment.There is a shop on the ground floor where you can buy souvenirs and books,I found a nice book with detailed information of this house and one more book of Gauid's masterpieces.As for the museumes itself,you'll be impressed.You can take pictures on the roof and around the museum.Attic has some screens where you can watch other Gaudi's masterpieces.Moreover,there is a detailed explanation of house building on every stage.While visiting an apartment,you'll be automatically taken to another century and feel the air of an old centuy as it has some traces of those times (clothes,furniture,old-fashioned design etc.)Having visited the museum,I decided to find out more information of this building and decided to buy a book called "La Pedrera" Casa Mila.You'll get closer with its history and origin;futhermore,you'll get to know with Gaudi's great works.I would definetely recommend visiting this house as it has an air of those times.Impressive!

Something from a sci-fi movie. I have begrudgingly given this an average review because although I liked it and the rooftops are cool. Loads of crazy Gaudi formations that look like the helmets of aliens or things Steven Spielberg dream up it is overpriced. You can see quite a lot from the outside, especially over the road. Only really do it if you are a real Gaudi fan. It's also a small space so can get really busy so like La Sangrada Familia it's worth going early morning or later on in the day.

Experience uniqueness. The way the house was set-up - The house top, the show of how the house came about and targeted to the common person and the convenience of the furniture and the setting for families. All well thought out by an artist as great as Gaudi and the Guell family and the Spanish government must be complemented.

Amazing place. We had the Barcelona ArtTicket so didn't have to queue although it did take us a few minutes to work out how to get in with our ticket - we ended up asking a member of staff at the front of the queue and she let us straight in.The roof is amazing although does get very busy - it gets a bit frustrating trying to take photos as there are so many people up there all trying to do the same! (But then again this is what we found with all of the Gaudi sites that we visited). The apartment itself is nice, not as stunning as Casa Batllo but still worth seeing.

Wish I could live here. Gaudi, my man! The roof is spectacular and from it you can see Sagrada Familia. Crowded even in October. I suggest an ArteCard, this site is included on the ticket and helps you bypass a long line of ticket buyers. You just go to the front of the line and show the card and the people standing in line will look at you jealously as you glide past them.

Roof terrace is the best. visited early evening,good views over Barcelona, with Sagrada Familia in distance, we feel roof terrace is best part of this house, it did seem strange having to put everything through x-ray machine to get into the building, you start tour by taking lift to roof and then walk down,but not all the floor of this house are open to the public ,some are use by bank and other companies.so you see roof terrace, attic rooms, a large appartment ,shop and then it down to ground floor, liked house but prefered casa batillo.

A must see!. Casa Mila’ or La Pedrera is one of the must see building of Gaudi in Barcelona. I’ve been twice, even if it's a bit expensive (12 euros with the discount voucher from Bus Turistic), but worth it!Gaudi’s work is so innovative and particular, and this house is full of it. I just love it!There is a museum inside with his work and an example apartment where the Mila’ family was living. The best part is its rooftop with lots of chimneys, just spectacular, as spectacular is the view from there!You may want to get an audio guide to understand a bit better the stories behind the architecture and the pieces – it’s 4 euros and in my opinion worth it, unless you go there prepared. On the same street, not very far away is also Casa Batlo, another really important work of art of Gaudi. This one is more particular on the inside. I really loved them both! But they are a bit expensive, so if you have to choose I would go for La Pedrera!
Can't recommend this enough. A wonderful site to visit when in Barcelona. Plan for an hour or two since there is a lot to see. The rooftop is amazing with great views of Barcelona
A must place to go. like the place very much: the roof, explains about Gaudi's works, the restoration of the flat, the short movie - everythinghate - very expensive to go in.
Magnificent building. We spent a few hours in La Pedrera, enjoying all its passages and corners. The roof itself is a great delight.

Yet another unique Barcelona building.. This is another must see building while visiting Barcelona. There is quite a lot to see inside and the tour culminates with a visit to the roof and "the" chimney pots. Another architecturally important building. A visit is highly recommended.
The outside and courtyard is amazing. The outside and courtyard is amazing but the apartment leaves much to be desired. Takes about 2 hours.

The roof teracce is unique,no audioguide needed. The tour begins on the roof and continous on the lower floors;ends on the ground floor.The chimneys and the roof are amazing;but the interior is not so special.the audio guide is not necessary at all,info is written in English/Spanish.At the Palau Guell the entrance fee is only 10€,here you pay much more but the averall experience is not that special.If you are short on time or at lower budget,I recommend you to visit the Palau Guell and/or Casa Battlo!
A perfect example of gaudi. the ouside is wonderful and the terrace and appartment really beautiful - well worth the visit - even the shop really good!

The roof makes it totally worth it.. There is nowhere like that roof in the world! Other than that, it wasn't much of a musuem, but certainly worth the wait in line to take the elevator up. You must do it if you're in Barcelona!

Spent longer here than we intended. once again it was expensive but well worth it. We invested in the audio guide and gained so much more because of it. It got busier by the time we left (about 12.30) so we were glad that we went along first thing in the morning. There were no queues when we went in!
Best spot in Barcellona. Could not get enough of this rooftop. Gaudi was truly a master with an unending imagination. Many have been inspired by him. Don't miss it.

Another fascinating Gaudi design. Gaudi fans will already have La Padrera on their list and it is well worth the time and money for anyone interested in design and architecture. The rooftop sculptures and views are wonderful. I especially liked being able to see the Sagrada Familia towers in the distance and really getting an idea of the impact that Gaudi had on Barcelona. The furnished apartment helps to give a complete picture of how living here really would have felt. I'm a fan of that era so I was ready to move in! I thoroughly enjoyed Casa Mila but would put Casa Battlo slightly ahead of it on the 'must see' list. If you have time see both!

Rainy Day - roof was closed. Apparently the highlight is the roof, so we were unfortunate to miss that. What was the surprise was the depth and richness of the museum in the attic. Very educational and wonderful.

A must see in Barcelona. If you are a fan of architecture and specifically Gaudi, this museum is well worth the steep price. It was a stop along the "on and off" bus route so it was easy to get to...we lucked out since the wait was about 10 minutes. It is also located in a great shopping area. It allowd us to enter an apartment and to walk the roof of the building. Well worth the photo ops from the roof. Glad we stopped to visit.

Best of Gaudi. Casa Mila - La Pedrera is located by Paseo de Gracia and is definitely worth checking out if you're a fan of architecture and Gaudi. It has a famous roof with the whimsical figurines and then a tour of the former appartments in the building. Another Gaudi marvel.
Pedrera is not the best Gaudi example. Nice but seeing palau guell or palau de la musica catalana is much more interesting. Pedrera is also small and costs about 16 euros.
a must see for gaudi fans.... the tour includes his amazing attic area which contains information about his life and work-views from roof are terrific but watch your step!

Amazing is to put it mildly.. I was surprised at the hollow middle of the building. The ticket to enter is a little too steep for what you see but if you are there you might as well spring the extra bucks to see it.
Very good. Another brilliant building, shame today's architects don't seem to have as much vision! Ha ha ha my second fav with Battlo first and Parc Guell third. You can see them all and you should

Another amazing work by this genius. We love Gaudi. Until one sees his work up close and personal, it's possible to write him off as some kind of weird architect. After experiencing him close up, it's a new revelation.
Interesting building. I was their early in the morning, so there was not a lot of people on the roof yet. Amazing how the building was constructed

Roof top fence distracts from magificent Gaudi work. Incredibly interesting architecture and decorations highlighting Gaudi's work throughout the building including the main entrance and gift shop, apartment, attic and roof top designs; however the roof top protective fencing is very unsightly and does keep within the stunning work of Gaudi. The fence is chainlink fencing ruins any photograph or view of the inner court yard. The organization preserving the magnificent work must consider an alternative - perhaps glass panels with framework to accentuate the marvelous Gaudi style.

Must do while in Spain. The entrance was a little expensive 20 Euros per person. But the art of Gaudi made it worth the visit, the top floor was filled with Gaudi's work and the view to the city was outstanding.

An architectural must-see. You can't go to Barcelona without seeing this. It's a beautiful house, both inside and outside. There is often a line, so try no to go during the peak moments. It is not cheap, but worth the price. Iside, there is also a café, where they serve very good (albeit not cheap either) coffee.

Below standard.. Being a great admirer of Antoni Gaudi I placed La Pedrera near the top of my itinerary on a 5 day visit to Barcelona assuring my wife that this was a building not to be missed...but what a disappointment.Alarm bells started to ring at the very start as we followed the direction signs and began a long ascent up the stairs. We almost turned half way up thinking we had taken a wrong turn.Rising up from the ground floor to the 6th floor (not for the elderly or the faint hearted) we emerged onto the `Espai Gaudi`, using it's architectual structure to house an informative exhibition on Gaudi's construction methods and design features with scale models, videos, photographs and text etc. An impressive and professional effort but uninspiring.Another short climb brought us onto the roof terrace, clearly the highlight of the visit with it's weird and wonderful chimneys and ventilation towers but the what can only be described as `brutal` railings detract from the whole effect. Surely someone could have come up with a better solution than this, more worthy of the great man.Next on the tour was the Pedrera apartment (two floors down) which is a recreation, displaying original period furniture, fixtures etc; good, but in my opinion failing to reach the standards of his other Barcelona buildings.The `main` floor, which is actually the first floor was closed for renovation so I cannot comment except to say that this was not pointed out at the ticket desk... Perhaps they forgot as they also forgot to tell us that there is a lift to the roof located across the courtyard!We visited in early September 2012. The cost was a pricey 16.50 Euros each with an extra charge for an optional audio guide.The staff were polite and friendly but I only seen them on the ground floor. The roof should be visited first and you make your way down; first to the attic `Espai` exhibition and then the apartment but if you climb the stairs, as we had to do, you can view the exhibition first (have a rest) and then go up to the roof. Best to avoid the stairs and ask where the lift is.However, unless you are a real Gaudi fan I would avoid La Pedrera, save your money and walk down the street to the magnificent Casa Batllo.

A must-see Gaudi. I went to La Pedrera after Casa Batllo, which I found to be a good order to visit them in as the audio guide at Batllo provided more general information about Gaudi and his work, whilst the guide at Pedrera seemed to be specifically about the building. The crazy roof is a must-see attraction, but after visiting Batllo it feels like you only get to see a very small part of the building (roof, a reconstructed apartment, and the atrium). The "Gaudi space" in the attic was very good, however, and between that and the Gaudi and Nature exhibit at La Sagrada Familia, I left Barcelona with a much better understanding of his work.

Buy the Barcelona Fast pass. this pass allows you to enter four or five museums/sites without standing in line. You buy it at a ticket office located off of the main square. La Pedrera is such a classis work by Gaudi. The models and drawings in the attic are worth the trip alone as they explain the architectural style and engineering. The chimney flues on the roof are classic (look for the one with the broken champagne bottles in it) and the furnished apartment gives a very real impression of what it was like to live in Casa Mila. Get the audio tour.

A good experience if you are an architecture/interior design student. We came here directly after visiting Sagrada Familia (having a bit of a Gaudi day) and there wasn't as much of a wow factor and it was much more expensive than it had said in my guide book. However it was an enjoyable experience, the rooftop was amazing and the exhibits inside the building were of interest, more if you're in the field of Architecture or design as it included drawings, models and furniture samples created by Gaudi.

Amazing Gaudi!. We walked looking for this house and as you approach it you can see right away why it is such a beautiful building. IT is amazing to see all the detail and the architecture itself. We didn't go inside but I believe the outside is the most impressive part.
La Pedrera. This house of gaudi's is just one of many that I never get tired of looking around.It is a really good example of his work.

Mmmmm-a bit disappointed.. This building is spectacular from the outside and I was expecting the same from the inside but didn't get the wow that I got with either the Casa Batllo and Sagrada Familia. It's not that it's any less spectacular in its' own way.There's a good exhibition inside the building and the audio guide is ok. You can take as long as you like to linger and take photo's. It's interesting to see how the inside space is lived in. A shame that one of the main rooms is taken up with a gift shop but they couldn't have put it anywhere else. The roof space has great views of the city and is remarkable if a little spoiled by the metal railings that aren't in keeping with Gaudi style and so spoiled it for me-but that's a personal perspective. If you're short on time admire this from the ouside but go into both or either of the other two.
Wonderful. This was our favourite place so far !!! the roof was amazing!!!! Would like to go back and view at night. The inside was like a dolls house loved it!!!!

Great. Another great place to visit, another one of Gaudi's extraordinary pieces of work!The only disadvantage are the long queues that you will always find, but it's worth a visit, you will see many interesting things there and the view from the roof is amazing.
The best Gaudi building. Is bigger than I expected, you can visit the building and uppstarirs you could visit the way Gaudi worked, his ideas, papers, etc, impressive! Really good
Favorite cafe. within walking distance of our hotel. the food was great and so was the service. and the building so exciting and different
