Another Gaudi Beauty. Again this is a must for day one. - just in case you don't make it to day 2 - The Pedera you must see before you die. If only Perth had a Gaudi to do something about our "industrial architecture"

Gaudi's wonder. This is another must-see Gaudi house in Barcelona. It reminds me of ocean waves and am totally jealous of people who actually live inside! There tends to be a line for getting in but is not as bad as Casa Batllo.

Another "you must see". Simply great. Once you get to the terrace you can enjoy both the design of it as well as great views on Barcelona and surrounding roofs. Casa Mila exhibitions - the attic and the apartment are also great. Take your time and reserve at least three hours.

Nice. Nice!. A must see in Barca. This work of Gaudi is very inspiring to visit. The roof top is great. It wil take you a while to buy a ticket because many people want to visit, but it is worth waiting. Also for kids because of the lively character and the colours of Gaudi.
Nice experience. It was a very interesting experience in La Pedrera, where the only focus is architecture, however, there is not much to do.

I loved it. Be aware that you must walk up about eight flights of stairs to start the tour of the roof. There is a small elevator available. The architecture is AMAZING. Truly visionary. Must see. They have audio guides of varying length available. We did the forty tour was perfect.

So interesting!. We did the nightime tour, and it was lovely to see this residential building at such a quiet hour. Our guide was so informative about Gaudi's vision for it and the history of its development. Unique design and magical to enjoy a glass of cava from the rooftop watching the sparkling lights of Barcelona.

Go for the roof. The most notable aspects are the roof and the exterior, which you can get for free :)
I would visit La Pedrera if you have time left after covering the Sagrada Familia and the Casa Batllo.

Worth it just for the roof. The roof is where you start your tour, and it is by far the best. You can see the whole of Barcelona from there, and there are many great opportunities for photography.The museums and apartment sections are not bad and educate you on Gaudi's methods, as well as give you a feel of what it's like to live there.The audioguide costs 4EUR but it really didn't tell us much so I wouldn't recommend getting it.

Gaudi on steroids. The whole concept of his architecture is amazing. It needs to be seen to be believed. The imaginative use of materials for purely structural and functional supports is what makes his buildings one of a kind.

Gaudi was a genius. Completely unique kind of architecture. Nothing is straight, everything is curved like in nature. My husband's opinion was unlike mine. He thinks the guy had everyone fooled and was just nuts

too expensive. last time I was in barcelona with my husband we came here and I remembered it was very interesting. this time I cam with my duaghters. the lone was extremly long, and the price went up to 16.5 euros. I think price is way too high.

Special. I' ve spent just a few minutes in front of this building while sightseeing tour. It was enough. I've never seen something so impressive in terms of architecture.For me it was like brought from other world on Earth. The construction joins outstanding architecture elements that only an exceptional genius as Gaudi used to be could have performed in a stone expression.Just take a look of this and your day is made for sure!
One of the best Gaudi Buildings. Situated in Mid-Barcelona La Pedrera is well worth a Visit. Entrance - however - seemed at bit costly. Nice to see such a building well visited.

A great/must see sight!. We are so glad that we had the time to tour Casa Mila. The place is well organized so you start at the top of the building and work your way down. They have elevators to get to the roof top where you have an awesome view of the city and an up-close view of Gaudi's work. The attic is filled with miniature replicas of Gaudi's other works, information on Gaudi himself as well as information on what was happening during the time this building was being constructed. The living quarters are very interesting, filled with furniture from the building and the time period. The gift shop is well organized with plenty of things from which to choose. Take the time to go there!
Creative, beautifull achitecture. Beautifull, fasinating, and again uf anybody interested in architecture, it should not be missed. It does not take so much time...

The genius of Gaudi. Do not visit Barcelona without a trip to the outstanding Gaudi apartment building known as La Perdrera, Casa Mila.To say the architecture is unique is like saying tha Godiva makes chocolate. A micro-manager, Gaudi's hand is present everywhere, from the design of the wrought iron to the the design of the glass and even some funishings. The roof top is not to be missed with an amazing view out to La Sagrada Familia but especially its wondefully playful ventilation towers, chimneys and stairwells. The attic too is a treat for the eyes. The space was originally used as storage and for clothes drying. 270 arches support the roof-terrace. The attic also includes some very interesting exhibits of models used by the architect in the design of some of his most famous work. There is an apartment fitted out with furnishings typical of the turn of the century. Indeed there are four families who live in the building today. Lucky them.Go early in the morning to avoid the lines, or go later and stand and wait. JUST GO.
Very interesting. We found Casa Mila very interesting and the audioguide gives great insight into the architectural style and ideas of Gaudi. Really helps you understand Barcelona's style.

Unique Space. A really unique building than has to be visited during a stay in Barcelona where you can admire the architecture. The rooftop and attic spaces is where Gaudi's unique views come to life. The apartment while decorated in period furnishings does not inspire as the roof and attic spaces.

Ooozing with organic interpretation. This is a fascinating building, reachable on foot. Be sure to have a delicious coffee or dessert in the Miro coffee shop where you can enjoy the interior work and some pieces of Gaudi's furniture design.

Exceptional Building. A really unique building than has to be visited during a stay in Barcelona. If you visit first thing in the morning, around 9am, you avoid queues and you can admire the architecture. The rooftop is stunning, a real piece of art. And the apartment travels you through time to the past, when wealthy Mila family used to live in it. Finally, the attic is a very atmpspheric place where information about La Pedrera is exhibited. La Pedrera is really not to be missed!
Another Gaudi masterpiece. A fantastic & iconic Gaudi Masterpiece with a wealth of interior displays of the great man's genius... not to be missed.

Not your ordinary casa. It is impressive because it has Gaudi's signature design. I would love to have a rooftop like La Pedrera. However, I wouldn't pay admission twice [as I would to La Sagrada Familia...yes, I know, apples and oranges]. If you're a Gaudi fan, it would be difficult not to visit; otherwise, take pictures from across the street.

A Gaudi marvel. This is a must see. created by Gaudi as an apartment living quarters. Admire the genius of Gaudi in all the intricacies of this architectural marvel. You can spend all day looking at all the special touches in each of the nooks and crannies of this building

Great Guadi. Expensive, but excellent. V well organised, lockers and a good route thtough. More like a musuem than the other Guadi buildings with furniture and bits and pieces from the right era. The shop is excellent. If you only have time for one Guadi hose, make it the Casa Batllo
Ok if you do not mind a queue. Rather expensive entry but a must see Gaudi building.Avoid busy times to avoid crowds.Steps on roof rather steep and difficult for the elderly

A must see!. If you think the exterior of this building is interesting, wait till you get in. The interior tour of one of the apartments takes you back in time and tells you a story of what life may have been like then. The tour starts off by ushering you into the inner courtyard, from here you are led up an elevator to the roof with a stunning view of roof stacks as well as the city. The next stop is Antonio Gaudi's museum before you are led into one of the apartments with every experience surpassing the previous one.

Special night tour is the way to go, roof is better at night too. The special night tour is worth the extra money in my opinion. You get a nice guided tour at night when it's cooler and there is practically nobody else there but you so there's no fighting through crowds. Ignore the cheesiness of the guide's scripted tour. The information is good, and the climax at the roof is great. The designs on the roof look better lit up. Enjoying a couple glasses of cava up there was nice as well.My favorite Gaudi places to visit in Barcelona in order:* La Sagrada Familia* Casa Battlo* Casa Mila (La Padrera)* Palau GÃ¼ell* Parc GÃ¼ell

A real apartment building. This was the first site I visited in Barcelona when I got off the plane. The line to enter was long, but I'm glad I waited. They have two lines, one for cash and one for credit cards; however, they don't ask you how you're paying until you get near the ticket window. I paid for the audio tour and was glad I did. It was very in depth and gave a lot of information about the chimneys. They have an interior floor, which is similar to a museum, where they have models and slide shows of the building. This is around the corner from Casa Battlo, so visit them both!
Great views. Brilliant tour, and well worth the 17 euros it cost. I very much enjoyed it and you can do it at your own pace.

inspirational building. This is an absolute must if you are going to visit Barcelona. Walking around on the rooftop of this spectacular and fantastical piece of architecture/sculpture gives you an insight into the mind of the genius who was Gaudi.There will be a queue so arrive early if you can as its well worth the entry fee of 17 euros.The attic spaces and the apartment are the other parts of the visit and are glorious to behold.

it's just an ordinary apartment with Gaudi's touch. I would recommend Casa Batlio and Guell Palace than this. La pedrera is too highly priced and too much tourist.Going inside, there was not much to show and see except the roof top, which can also be seen at Guell Palace.

An architectural masterpiece. A very impressive building, reflecting the genius of Antonio Gaudi. Besides the cool roof, the attic displays interesting information about Gaudi's other famous works. I found it more captivating then the other famous building - Casa Batllo - because here the visit tour also includes an apartment fully furnished, with many rooms, that gives you a glimpse of what Catalan life was like at the beginning of the 20th century. You have to see it!
Gaudi in the City. Make sure to see the roof - it and the attic are the most interesting parts of the building. Views from the roof are impressive as well.

Prices are a little steep, but the roof terrace is well worth seeing!. Granted, the entry prices are a little steep (about 17 euros each) but you will be kicking yourself if you miss out on seeing Gaudi's famous roof terrace. The entry price gives you access to the roof terrace, a preserved apartment, and a museum of Gaudi's work.
Amazing place! Want to live there!. This is a great place. So weird and exciting too. Loved it. Loved the apartment, the roof, everything! Wish I could live there!

Another Gaudi Hit. While walking along Passeig de Gracia, you will not miss it. It stands out for being undulating and in motion. The wrought iron work is busy and detailed.
There is a cozy coffee shop just below the building and a nicer cafe above.

Unmissable La Pedrera. But the ARTICKET when you arrive in Barca and the steep costs of visiting the museums is halved- £10 each pp are most of the entry fees.This creation by Gaudi is stunning and inspirational and my tip- go on the late afernoon/ early evening when it is less crowded and the rooftop is not packed. Makes for a better experience. Great building, well presented videos, archetectural displays and information and access to one of the apartments makes this well worth a trip and spending 2 hours there if possible

Good for Gaudi fans. I would recommend this tourist attraction for fans of Gaudi's work- it is an apartment block designed by Gaudi and contains a mock apartment laid out as it would have been in the early 20th century. You can visit the rooftop and admire the creatively designed roof, along with views over Barcelona.For travellers who struggle with steps, take the lift as the climb to the rooftop affected quite a few visitors whilst I was there.Great gift shops!

Definitely worth the price of admission. La Pedrera is an easy walk from the old town/tourist district. Once inside, start at the rooftop - all those intricate, fascinating chimneys and towers. Both the roof and attic offer lots of opportunities for "arty" photos. The exhibits in the attic about how the structure is supported are interesting. The rest of the residence is interesting, too.

Amazing building considering the year it was built. Gaudi rocks! nice building. Price to get in a bit steep. I would recommend to skip the queue of the elevators and get the stairs to the roof. Much quicker. Apartments were very interesting. Everyhting is really thoguth of. I would recommend seeing. It takes at least 1hr30min to visit properly.
Cool architecture. This is certainly a one of a kind. The roof is breathtaking and the attention to detail is phenominal. A must!!

Nice but expensive. One of Gaudi's creations. Beautiful, unique - but really less impressive the Sagrada familia. However much more expensive then it. I think it is not a "must" to see, especially in this price.

What a genius. The roof of this building is what people come to see. Topped with structures like fairy tale salt and pepper pots, it makes you wonder whether Gaudi was a genius or a mad man and just what sort of fantastical imagination he had. The outside of the building is just as amazing. How on earth can stone be made to appear so fluid?
too expensive. we have visited the apartments on our last visit to Barcelona so we were planning to visit this year but it was 20 euros per person!!!

another masterpiece. again,you have to go inside the building.it's like the time stopped in 1930's.you have the original furniture and you get a glimpse of how people used to live before.the rooftop is not as impressive as Batllo but it's still pretty awesome.!!!
Unique and Unusual. The roof of this curious building steals the show with its undulating pathways and chimneys - definitely a must see!

Another spectacular Gaudi house!. Unfortunately we ran out of time to tour the inside--too many wonderful Gaudi creations to see! Given its central location, this house is easy to see at least on the outside even if you don't have time for an interior tour. If we could have changed our plans, the interior based on our Gaudi book would have motivated us to stay another day to see it.

Great rooftop view and architecture. Received a discount as we were students, made it a bit more worthwhile, but Casa Mila is not as outstanding as Sagrada Familia and Casa Batllo. Just be warned that to access the roof you need to climb a number of flights of stairs, but it's worth it once you walk out - the roof is amazing, has great views of Barcelona (and a distant view of Sagrada Familia), and features breathtaking Gaudi architecture. The house features a museum of sorts which was also interesting. Worth a visit if you have the time. Walked from Sagrada Familia to Casa Mila then back to Passeig de Gracia, quite a long walk but great to take in the city!

A fantastic place. It is wonderful that they show the interiors - giving you a feel of what it would have been like to live in a magic house like that! Also, the exhibition in the attic is informative and interesting with all the models and Gaudi inspiration exhibits. The book shop is very good. Definitely a great place to see - highly recommend!

A magical setting. We were very lucky to visit La Pedrera not the usual way, but as part of a large cultural celebration of the city of Barcelona. We ordered tickets online for the evening live jazz performance at the rooftop of La Pedrera. It was truly magical to look from this famous rooftop onto the night city while listening to a live jazz band. The only gripe I have is with the management of this facility: despite buying a ticket online and printing it, we still had to stand in a long line to have our printout "exchanged" for a "real" ticket.

A must see. One or two contributors have moaned about the cost of entry to this attraction - I think that it is something around 16 euros. Well, our visit lasted around 3 hours, which works out at around 5 euros per hour - I hardly call that expensive. Absolutely captivated by everything about the tour. The exhibits are not tacky, decayed & decrepit at all, but state of the art & thoroughly engaging. The gift shop was not even tacky, but contained some quite high quality merchandise that was not overtly overpriced.
Worth the look. I would stop by and take pictures. There is a fee to enter the house, we didn't go inside but were told so. Another great work of Gaudi
Great to see. Lovely to see around the lofts and the appartment but if you're not the great at going up and down stairs give the roof a miss.

Good attraction. Very expensive though. La Pedrera is not to be missed when in Barcelona. You get to see the things you watch on tv for Gaudi and Barcelona. The only problem is that the entrance is really expensive.Interesting place, no big queues probably because of the price, not crowded.Recommended

Visit as night. Unfortunately we visited during the day after Casa Batllo and we were a bit disappointed. Although the roof is definitely amazing, there is not as much to see here as with Batllo. If we visited at night then maybe it would've made it much more worth the entrance fee for the views up top. You should save this for later after Sa Grada, Palace and Batllo.
Amazing.. The price of admission is well worth it (12.5 euros I think). You can walk about the roof top and the apartment. I look at the design and keep thinking where did the ideas come from.

One of 4 Must see Gaudi sights in Barcelona. La Pedrera is one of 4 must-see Gaudi sights in Barcelona after: La Sagrada Familia, Casa Batllo, Guel Park.Unlike Casa Batllo (which is an "open" house where you get to see and touch the house as it was back nearly a hundred years ago), La Pedrera offers a historical and architectural fact/details about Gaudi and his work. The top floor has the famous human-figure chimneys. If visiting during summer, visit in the morning or afternoon so you can use the shade to rest. The attic is a mini audio-visual museum, and it's very informative. Get the audio tour, 75min one, if your time permits.After you visit Perdrera, you should visit Casa Batllo (on same street 4 blocks down).
Great insight into Gaudi. Wonderful little visit. The rooftop terrace is superb. We also got some insight into Gaudi the artist. Worth a visit but get there early to avoid the crowds.

Cafe at LaPedrera. I had a classic Catalon dessert (like a creme brule with strawberries) at the cafe, with a cup of espresso. The ambience was so special, the waitpersons were so cool, and it was very refreshing and relaxing to spend a little time there.

Gaudi in his element. Get up-close and personal with Gaudi's architectural style. Allow at least two hours for the roof, attic, apartment, and exhibition - and go here before you visit La Sagrada Familia to understand Gaudi's background and early work. Another worthwhile destination in Barcelona.

Expensive to go in, but beautiful outside.. We couldn't afford to go inside, about €18 each, so we just looked around its exterior and facade. Really beautiful building and a Gaudi classic. Must see!Note- Most of the Gaudi buildings are owned by banks, I didn't like the idea of paying A LOT of money to go inside a building and then for a bank to get my money. If your trying to decide which Gaudi to go in, La Sagrada Familia! It's is his best work, and all the money goes towards the church's ongoing construction and beauty. Well worth it.

Must see!. Spectacular Gaudi apartment building. The roof is the most interesting part, with very whimsical chimneys and other doo-dads. The apartment you can tour is interesting enough, but just does not compare to the roof. If you have a Barcelona Card (good for several museums), you won't wait on line.
Wow - this is really impressive!. The outside fascade is wonderful, the rooftop walk majestic and the flat very interesting. Take a camera

Great Example of Guadi's work.. Took the tour with audio (the long version) and was very impressed. This was the third Guadi location so we were beginning to hear repeated sections of his history and life story. But still worth the price of admission.

I didn't want it to end!. Even better than Casa Batlo! Not only colorful (as you would expect from Gaudi) but also very informative architecturally. Organized very well so that you take elevator to roof top (where you see all the sculptured monuments and ornaments) and then walk down to the attic (where you see the advanced architectural techniques) and then down again to the living areas (where the rooms still contain original furniture and period clothing).

interesting but overpriced. a nice insight into the architectural designs of Gaudi,but overpriced admission fee which was around 16 euros per person. I think admission to the Acropolis in Athens is 12 euros and to the Colosseum 15...

Impressive construction. In its different forms the building takes your attention and nearby there's Galdi shop with lovely and interesting stuff to buy. Arrive early enough in order to face a long cue.
White Rock Quarry.. The roof top is pretty cool with the Gaudi twist. The apartments are nice and pretty amazing to see and imagine how people from the late 1800's lived.

Wow! a must see apartment by Guadi. La Pedrera is a unique apartment designed by Guadi , it is one of his popular piece. The roof top is just of the most photographed place in Barcelona, the inside of the apartment are also stunning and unique. Can't believe these were designed in the 19th century ! It is in Eixample area and easy to find . Expect a long queque for tickets ! worth the wait for sure
Worth a visit..... However, as others have stated, the entry price meant we just enjoyed the exterior.If a Gaudi then it ought to be added to your "to see" list.
unique. if you have 1 gaudi location to visit, just do this one...it is absolutely unique. you may like or dislike Gaudi's work but you have to see this one

Rooftop is amazing. Loved the rooftop, its beautiful up there. Well worth the visit although a little on the pricey side and we even had a small discount from the tour bus but it was still over 30 for two. We didnt really bother much coming down from the rooftop with the rest of the tour as there was nothing to interest us only old style apartment rooms etc.
Very Impressive. You have to queue a little bit, but it certainly is worth it! Try to go for a visit in the late afternoon, than the queu is not that long. The vieuw on the rooftop is magnificent!

Worth a visit, but pricey. I really wanted to see this building and I did. But the ticket price was ridiculous, 16 euros. If museums are your thing, buy the 7-museum pass (which includes the Picasso and La Pedrera among others) for 30 euros to make it worth admission. If you're not going to do the museum thing, then my recommendation is skip the interior of La Pedrera and just check out the exterior for free. Unless, of course, you don't mind spending 16 euros to be herded through.

Terrible value. All the rave about this has confused us, as we paid over 60 euros for our family to go inside. The roof's architecture was interesting, although inside the building was almost a complete waste of time -- merely showcasing typical rooms from that era. If you are still highly interested in going, buy tickets online to skip the queue and go during a time of day when it is not hot (though check opening hours on its website beforehand) because it can get quite sunny on the roof. Leaving feeling confused, a view from the outside is definitely enough for all but Gaudi's most avid fans.

Great place to go-my kids loved it. Gaudi is a genius and this is a very clever and sympathtic museum that doesnt feel like a museum-the roof is one of the most unique places i have ever been on Not that cheap though but worth it!

What did I pay for?. I definitely fall in to the "I don't get it" category here. We came to here after La Sagrada Familia, which was perhaps the problem. After paying more for this building and queuing outside, I was extremely underwhelmed. What lay inside was an average building with a string of poorly decorated rooms disguised as a museum. The view from the top was nice, but similar to ones I'd already seen at other locations. We were in and out in 40 minutes and were left very confused as to what we'd just paid for. We expected a lot after La Sagrada Familia, but were left extremely disappointed.All in all a waste of money and I would suggest staying clear of this and saving your money. Go and see Gaudi's other buildings, because this one is definitely not worth it.
interesting. We saw it from the outside and was pretty cool...but that is about it. Definitely a building to sit and appreciate for a while

Nice roof. Fascinating roof and ensure you visit the apartment floor with original furniture from the early 1900's. Read the brochure they provide as it gives good information about what Gaudi was attempting.

Gaudi Showcase. Impressive apartment complex is well worth the small price of admission. Get the audio program to gain insights into Gaudi's thought process and art. The rooftop is the highlight of this tour (though you'll have to be patient to get shots of the various structures to avoid framing other visitors)
Expensive. To my mind it's too expensive. 16,5 Euro for a chance to go to the roof?.. Frankly speaking only roof impressed me, there is nothing to see in the apartment.

Fantastic architecture. This is a great example of the architecture of Antoni Gaudi. I particularly recommend walking around on the roof taking in the views of the city and the architectural features on top of the building.

A must see. We bought our tickets on line (worth it due to line ups) and also purchased the audioguide. The terrace is unbelievable. We came back that evening to a jazz concert on the terrace, which was wonderful.

Amazing example of Guidi's work. La pedrera is another amazing Gaudi building. We definately became big fans of Gaudi's work during our visit to Barcelona. This house is very different from Casa Batlló and we loved both of them for dfferent reasons - so if possible try to visit both.Book ahead to avoild the long queues and get an audio guide.

Average at best - you pay too much for this. On my first trip to Barcelona, I planned to go Gaudi-to-the-max. I saw Sagrada Familia (incredible, obviously), Park Guell, and then decided to check out La Pedrera. I left feeling somewhat disappointed, and wish instead I had checked out Casa Batllo as it looked better.The only real draw, IMO, to La Padrera was the chimneys. They were neat, and walking around the roof was very interesting. You can see where Gaudi used smashed wine bottles to decorate one of the chimneys, and you can get an up-close look at the tiling and designs (I think the orange chimneys kind of look like Storm Troopers). Then you go downstairs one floor, to Gaudi's old workspace (which does have some similar design features as Sagrada Familia) and there are some exhibits, models, etc. on display. It is interesting, I suppose, but not so much so that it kept my attention or made me feel like the admission fee was worth it. At the end of this level, though, the part about design of furniture and door handles is interesting and worth watching (there's a short video). Exiting this level, you go down one more level to see an apartment, which is interesting but is nothing spectacular and didn't seem to highlight Gaudi's work in the way I would have liked. All I really took away from that apartment was (1) it's pretty big and (2) the door handles really are made to fit your hand.Overall I just kind of felt like the price they charged wasn't worth it and if I was to return to Barcelona, this would not be something I'd go see. It just isn't nearly as interesting as the Sagrada Familia (comparable admission fee) or Park Guell (free), so I'd spend your money on Gaudi sites elsewhere.

Worth the visit. I honestly loved it! Beautiful work again by Gaudi .. The hassle about it was the stairs! You will have to climb all the way to the top using stairs, although there is an elevator, but it's not in use! It can get hot & exhausting! The somehow expensive entrance fees & the long queue is another hassle .. But again, if you're into Gaudi's architecture, it's really worth it .. Take your time to check every room, every detail & the roof top .. You will end up at the gifts shop while exiting, it's a bit expensive though!
Great wiew. Another great work made by Gaudi. Extraordinary wiew from top of the bulding. Next to other Gaudi masterpiece : Casa Batlo.

Organic architecture before it was trendy. If you're not familiar with Gaudi, this is a good place to start before you visit La Sagrada Familia. If you are here in the summer, the weekend jazz on the roof at night is very romantic and Barcelona is just as captivating by night as it is during the day.
Well worth it. If you come to Barcelona you can't miss this out but Casa Battlo is better (and not so crowded and conveniently on the next block to compare the two)

Exposition of Gaudi works. I was not so much impressed by La Pedrera, it seemed a bit bland compared to Casa Batlo. I missed the colour bursts that are so typical in other works of Gaudi. I saw one reviewer preferring La Pedrera over Casa Batlo, though I would prefer otherwise, because of the forms, colors, details used for interior and exterior.This building was the last of Gaudi that I visited in Barcelona and I did not really found anything exciting or new, facade, chimneys, archs were typical Gaudi style.If you really want to visit inside it, go there first. Inside you can find models of architect's works, so it provides a good overview of how, what and why he did the way he did. So it is more educational sight.
museums. waste of money, although the gift shop was good. Go to other museums or go shopping. Remember that shops close from 2 to 4 every afternoon.

Overpriced Tourist Trap!!!!. It was 20 Euros to go to this including the Audio Guide (Which I find to be helpful on most attractions)The outside of the building is cool and is probably the most famous intersection shot in Barcelona. The front of the building is cool and the Roof is cool. I liked the smoke stacks and stairs enterances. They are famous looking and easily recognizable to most people.Other than the roof, you visit the Attic and an apartment. The attic is an exhibit on Gaudi and shows his many works, Its brick dome look is interesting. The Apartment was useless and a waste of time, It was decorated in the decor of the early 1900's.The Facade and the Roof are really the only interesting things worth seeing and IMO not worth the 20 Euros.Its not worth more than 7-10 Euros
Good, bit pricey. It was interesting, but at seventeen euro without the audio tour even, Sagrada Familia is a better Gaudi bet for your time and money.

best Gaudi works. you can reserve on the web to avoid the long waiting file. La pedrera is an astonishig Gaudi's building sumarizing akll its architecture. If you have too choose it is much better than the Casa Batlló. The roof with its soldier like chimnies is where the visit starts. Under the roof , some presentations and models show Gaudi's concepts. One of the floors is decorated with original furniture showing the life style of the early 1900's Barcelona's upper class. I can recommend you to buy the Eyesight Guide of the building for 10 €: a great choice plenty of information.

Wow!. If you liked seeing Gaudi's basilica, you will love seeing this building. It is expensive to go inside, but it is worth it to see the rooftop. Simply amazing. Get your cameras ready - perfect place for photographers to get some incredible shots of Gaudi's work.
Asi-asi (so-so). Expensive for what you get/see. Really just a tour of the roof, the attic (cool archways) and the apartment area, and although interesting, not sure it was worth the $$ (16.5E).

Breathtaking design. If you see nothing else in Barcelona, take the tour here. The tour includes the roof terrace, the amazing attic with hour museum and a sample apartment. But show up early or prepare to stand in line for a LONG time.

Wonderful!. A great place to visit, to discover the modernist barcelona and the genius of gaudi. Worth buying the called articket, to acess several art places in barcelona. You avoid queues and save money.

Gaudi is simply impressive!. Long line but worth the wait. Walked the maze on lower levels. Enjoyed reading about the history and the Engineering feats of Gaudi. LOVED the rooftop. Bring an umbrella so you can still enjoy the view if it is sprinkling! Enjoyed the art deco chairs on display and signed the guestbook. Great gift shop on bottom floor. Bought small gift trinket box and beautiful post to mail home.Wish I would have bought Pedrera panoramic picture. Really enjoyed it!

The night tour is fun. The night tour gives you a chance to see the lights of Barcelona from the roof top. The roof is lighted in a great way way seeing the shapes and shadows by night light was interesting. They also have historical scenes of people living in the building a 100 years ago which added to the interest. Overall a worthwhile visit.

genious. Expensive -- 20 EUR pp -- but a must see! The genius of Gaudi on full display. The roof is like something from the outer space, almost makes you wonder whether Gaudi drank all of the champagne bottles that are built into the chimneys. It's a long climb up, 6 or 8 floors, which no one warns you about (there's an elevator that they offer on the way down??).

Sublime and will wow whole family. On a swank shopping street you can visit the roof and a modernist apartment in this fantasy apartment building by Gaudi. The roof is an undulating forest of sculptures. Very Star Wars. The guy was a genius but not sure how he got hired to build such outrageous structures. Even the sidewalk pavers are designed and carved! Summer evenings also offer jazz and champagne on the roof and night tours. Just next door, visit VINCON, the very modern design and home store - lots of fun stuff to look at and super cool Vincon t-shirts for the teenage hipsters in your group. Building has an elegant lunch cafe (looked expensive). Line was not too long (ten minutes) in august.

Rather pricey for a brief visit. I've been wanting to see other buildings by Gaudi other than the Sagrada Familiar and Parc Guell, but the admission for this Casa Mila was EUR16 and I thought that was quite expensive (perhaps that's the average price to pay for admission these days). On the inside, the most spectacular views were on the rooftop where Gaudi designed functional chimneys, stairwells and vents into interesting structures. Then there were 2 other levels for visitors: The attic and the apartment. At the attic you get to see models of other Gaudi architecture and the apartment gives you a feel of how a residential area inside Casa Mila is like. Once we were inside we found out that you could also visit Casa Mila at night for a panaromic night view of central Barcelona from the rooftop, which seems like a better idea than to visit during the day. So do check whether it's open at night during the time of your visit and choose according to your preference.

Beautiful!. A great place...the roof is so cool, but I wish the fence were not there...it is an eyesore, and really mars any great photos that try to show the whole roof. Also visit the apartment...it is great! Full of great art nouveau furniture and beautiful floors. I would spend at least 1.5 hours here.

Enjoyable visit. This house was very whacky inside and out, my husband commented that he would have liked to have had whatever Gaudi was on when he built this house. However I felt slightly disappointed with the inside as I thought it would be a more spectacular sight, and the really impressive staircase and hall area was out of bounds to the public. But still worth a look around.

Amazing. My favourite place to visit in Barcelona. I loved roaming atop the roof which transports you to another world. The first time I went I did not know about the apartment downstairs, but found out about it on my second visit.

Amazing!. This place is amazing. It is worth the long queue. When you're on the roof, have a look at the textured finish of the upper windows. You'd think you were looking at a Star wars town house.Tip: - If you have discount vouchers from the tour buses, use a voucher per ticket. We got little Miss Attitude when we went and she demanded one per ticket, unlike Camp Nou where one covered all 3 tickts. Also have plenty water when queing, especially with children. We took about an hour to go through.
Gaudi does it again. Gaudi is an amazing visionary all of his work is breath taking. Even if you don't go inside the outside is beautiful.

The Future, before the Future. Yes, it is obvious that George Lucas did design his movie characters after having visited or examined La Pedrera. Gaudy managed to create something very far from conventional style, so many years ago!. The inside is sublime, a great experience. The balcony is something from another world. The house inside makes a very interesting visit, with many details. The ceilings and floors must not be missed either, astonishing! This is a great visit, not to miss at Barcelona, and something you can not see anywhere else.

Nice Experience. La Pedrera is one of the house designed by Gaudì. It's a wonderful way to understand the art of Gaudì. The top floor is probably the best one.Consider buying the Art Ticket to get into Pedrera and other exciting museum in Barcelona.

Anther Gaudi masterpiece. Very lovely house by Gaudi, located close to Casa Battlo. Once you've seen some other works by Gaudi, you can easily spot his style in this building too. Amazing architecture, with available tours inside.
Casa Mila. We did not enter the house but the outside is so cool and you can get a glimpse of the inside from the souvenir shop!
Lovely house. I loved the style and the building was in great shape I entered and heard the full review and history of the house I even bought some gifts from the gift shop on the way out
wonderfull. well worth a visit, well planned out and the audio headphones were a BONUS ,, a very special building, that you should visit, a must of cultural brilliance viva gaudi...

Gaudì at its best. We loved this building, which is basically a condominium, where you visit in the order: the large courtyard, the roof with gigantic chimneys of strange shapes, the attic where an exhibition explains Gaudì's work, a sample flat with original furniture and objects of everyday use of the 1900s. Interesting and enjoyable, worth a visit. There is a long queue, that can be avoided if you buy a Articket: it costs 30€ and ensures entrance to 7 museums, among which La Pedrera, Fundaciò Mirò and Picasso Museum, where queues are always very long!

A Gaudi Masterpiece. Though not as impressive internally as Casa Batllo La Pedrera was a more pleasant visit due to less crowding. The rooftop was fantastic and the Gaudi exhibit interesting. It was also great due to the period furnishings and art in the rooms.

A must see!. The structures are awesome - whatever must have been going on in Gaudi's mind?! The information in the attic was excellent and to see how the large apartment would have been was tremendous.
great Gaudi. it is one of the must if you visit Barcelona. unfortunately the line-up is all the time huge. better to be there very early in the morning.

In a recent past. Ticket about Eur 16,50 ( audioguide Eur 4.00 more). Gaudi never disappoints the tourist and infact even the Pedrera worths a visit. The house is not as impressive as Casa Battlò, but it's still my favourite because, differently from Casa Battlò and Palau Guell, the rooms are furnished in early '900 style.

Another top sight. Again, Gaudi buildings are a bit over-the-top in terms of taste, but you must take it for what it is and focus on the avant-guarde style at its time and the incredible forward-looking Engineering. In that sense, it is worth a visit inside. The appartment with the totally modern bathroom, and the attic underneath the roof showcasing the house's structural design, are impressive. So are little details such as doorhandles and the building entrance.

Jazz on the rooftop of La Pedrera. During our August 2012 visit to Barcelona, La Pedrera hosted rooftop concerts on Thursday, Friday and Saturday evenings. For 25 euro, you got entrance to the building, a glass of champagne and a great concert. The evening we went, a wonderful jazz trio played. The evening was beautiful and the breeze on the rooftop made for a great evening. Definitely worth it!

An inside look at Gaudi's work. We braved the entrance line - only about 30 minutes it turned out - to take the tour if this iconic building. In a little over an hour we gained a deeper appreciation of the Mondernista master's ethos. There's a proscribed route, but you can go at your own pace. The display of models, furniture and plans in the attic added to our understanding of his work. The visual highlight is the roof with its array of fanciful chimneys that look like sci-fi warriors. The views from here are great, too.I'm sure the interiors are equally interesting to someone who knows more about architecture and design to me.

Nice exterior and roof terrace. Another Gaudi's work of art. Especially the exterior and roof terrace are worth seeing. Also the museum and the lobby are nice.Ticket is 14 euros and minimal queues. Metro stop is Passeig de Gracia.

Architectural Treasure. I knew very little about the architect Antoni Gaudi prior my visit to Barcelona, but I am now a fan! La Pedrera is an apartment block displaying Gaudi's designs and includes an apartment furnished in the style of the period when it was built and a wonderful roof terrace that highlights Gaudi's genius and offers superb views over Barcelona. Also included are audio visual presentations and exhibits detailing Gaudi's inspirations. Well worth a visit.

Too many steps to the top. This building is another Gaudi landmark. Only, I am not sure it is worth the climb to the roof. Maybe I was just too hot. The apartment is lovely & worth seeing. There is an available elevator to go down. The best gift shop in town.

Something For Everyone. If you are a Gaudi admirer, photog, architecture buff, or just like seeing imagination run rampant - La Pedrera has something to offer. It's a wonderful experience and what a thrill the residents must have to still be living there. There's the standard tour with audio guide (take it) offered and you'll spend several hours climbing all throughout the exhibits. From a view of how life was back when the building was finished, to a lovely museum that gives you some great insights into Gaudi's design inspirations. Don't miss the painted details inside the ground floor or the ironwork outside. Not to be missed!Yes - could be boring for kids. Makes for a great day when paired with Casa Batllo just a few blocks away. Good sized lockers available to stow your bulky items and shopping bags before you set out.
Interesting building. It's a outstanding building. It's also a masterpiece. We can't imagine how the designer could make this kind of excellent building. It needs distinguished imagination.
Fantastic. The building, the apartment, the rooftop, all truly magnificent. Add this as a 'must do 'Very informative audio guide.Go early to beat the queus as gets very busy.

Jazz night on the roof. We went there for a different night and not for a simple tour.Every thursday, on the roof there's a little jazz concert (more or less 1 hour), with a welcome drink.You can listen this touching music while u look to all the city around you.The Gaudi's build is perfect to relax you. Few places can look at the musicians, but it's not the main thing: feel the music and feel the place.
Museum is phenomenal. The presentation is excellent, the rooftop is unforgettable, in general one of the best museum experiences in Barcelona.

Excellent insight into Gaudi's artistic processes. This beautifully preserved house epitomises Gaudi's aesthetic and artistic views, and showcases his work in an intimate and revealing way. Each of the rooms is preserved, with furniture, fittings and decorations, although to be honest, some of it has clearly been added since the owners left. The outside is extraordinary, with its organic iron balconies and sculptural roof lines. The visit to the rooftop is wonderful - the chimney tops and the smooth lines of the building really do pre-echo the Starwars characters. I loved this house. It felt real, and lived in, and happy.
One of Gaudí's finest. This has always been my favorite Gaudí house, and it did not disappoint! The view from the roof was amazing.

Wonderful Gaudi apartments. I loved these apartments. Gaudi's detail is just amazing - even the chimneys and air vents on the roof are beautifully designed and shaped. There's an exhibition in the roof space plus an apartment. Well worth a visit!
Amazing!. A must see Gaudi destination while in Barcelona! If you can, pick up a timed tixx in advance to avoid the long lines.

Discover Gaudi & plan your own nexr home :). Casa Mila is a must in Barcelona. why?Since Gaudi is the second name of Barcelona, if you were in Barcelona, but didn't see this house, I'd say you know nothing about Barcelona :)Thoght this is not the only place of Gaudi in this city (Guel Park, Pavilion d'Guel etc.) this house explain a little more about this man and his creativity, so this place is very intersting to visit.As for us, once we've left the house, we started planing the look of your next home :)

Worth visiting to understand Gaudi better. Entrance fee is high I would say. If you go after 11, you will wait about half an hour in the queue, may be even more.After you see the courtyard in the basement, you are directed to the roof with a lift. You use staircase on the way down.Roof is stunning. How can chimneys be so interesting and attract so many people?There is an exhibition about Gaudi at the floor below the roof. One floor down, a sample big apartment decorated with furniture from the times it was built.In total, you are allowed to visit roof, and two floors below it. There is a gift shop at the basement which has access from outside as well.

La Pedrera. It is really great to see it from the outside but 18 euros per entrance is far too much for what you are getting for. The roof is brilliant with its statues but the rest of the house is not worth seeing for the money you pay.

What is Barcelona without Gaudi?. A great sample of Gaudi's genius, a must see in Barcelona. The design, the materials used, the roof, the atrium, leave you in awe. The exposition on the last floor of Gaudi's works also very onteresting.

Amazing Building. The roof terrace is impresive. You could see the towers or the Sagrada Familia from there. The design of the apartments is incredible for a building of the las century. Very innovative and well conceived.

A Gaudi must. A great way to get into the head of one of the 19th and 20th centuries' greatest architects. The amazing detailing, the organic shapes, the intricate decorations. This building is a true gem. To top it off, you get to see an apartment in original style. Oh, and kids love it too.

Pricey, But Iconic. For the Gaudi fan, this is an essential stop, and the rooftop affords stunning photo ops. I'm glad I went, but it didn't really meet my expectations. You only get to visit the roof, the attic (which has a lot of info on the inspiration for the work) and a typical apartment. I don't know what else I expected, but other than the roof it didn't really deliver.

Disappointed after visiting Casa Bitllo. This is an apartment building that Gaudi remodeled. The famous exterior and rooftop are characteristic of Gaudi's work, but the tour of the apartment was unremarkable, i.e. a typical early 1900 design that I've seen in San Francisco. I enjoyed the Casa Batllo tour more.The entrance fee must be paid in cash, no credit cards. The audio handset is a must. The tour starts on the roof, so you can either take one of the two elevators or walk about seven floors.

Stunning exterior. Completely unique, stunning building. You can access the interior and enjoy views from the top. I'll definitely go in the next time, when I have more time in Barcelona. If you are short on time, it's worth a visit from the outside and makes for great photos.

Interesting - but overpriced. Waited 45 minutes to finally get in, and we were not overly excited with what we saw. It was interesting, definitely, but we did feel the price was a bit of a rip-off. Was a good example of his architecture -- and once we saw it, we had no further interest in seeing any other Gaudi buildings. So, I would say when visiting Barcelona make sure you see one of Gaudi's creations, then decide if you want to see any more. Perhaps we chose the wrong one to visit.

Very Good but a Bit Pricey. After having spent the previous day seeing Sangrada Familia, we were compelled to see one of the other Guadi buildings. I would recommend you did it the other way round as we were so overwhelmed by the Cathedral, seeing this place was a little bit of an anti-climax. But impressive architecture.The rooftop is the main attraction and being so afraid of heights with vertigo, I couldn't wander far from the entrance and exit of this area. The walkways are safe. It was just my problem I couldn't do it. My wife went round for me and took my pictures for me. Fantastic views and fabulous features. However I still had a appreciated the chimneys from where I stood.We didn't have time to see Casa Batlló but one reviewer said Casa Mila was poor value for money. I agree it is pricey and after reading that I wish we had seen Casa Batlló. However if you're prepared to pay €16 per person and queue 15-20min to get in then it is worth seeing, just probably not the best one of all the Gaudi places to visit.
Take your pic and move on. Again, this building is cool to see, but the area around it is so beautiful. Take your time and take it all in.
great view from the roof of Casa Mila. the "must-see" of Barcelona, great view of the city, go there in the evening - the line is shorter and photos much nices

Pass on This. Of all the beautiful sites to see in Barcelona, the pricey Mila House is one my husband and I wished we'd passed on. It's an apartment complex designed by Gaudi - but doesn't come close to Casa Batllo, Parc Guell or the Sagrada Familia - all of which are must sees! My advice - go see those and pass on La Pedrera.
Don't miss this amazing building. An amazing piece of architecture - I've never seen anything like it. There are several buildings by Gaudi along this wide avenue in the heart of Barcelona.
must visit!!!. amazing building, just beautiful and is so interesting that there is still people living in that building

Check out the roof. This museum is really worth visiting - the roof is amazing: you have a great view over the city and Gaudi's chimneys are exceptionally beautiful. the museum also gives you an overview of all the Gaudi buildings in Barcelona.

The Night Visit is the Way to Go!. We all know that Gaudis architecture can leave you awe struck - but I recently had the opportunity to do the night visit at La Pedrera . . . and wow!The night tour offers an insight into how the house would have been when in use back in the turn of the century and it has been elegantly designed and is beautifully presented. What I loved about this house is that it is still being used today - yes that means that we could only visit the ground floor, one upper floor and the roof top, but it was definitely worth every penny.The house is both a museum and a living, breathing treasure - such a rarity.The other plus is that the night visit had considerably less people allowing for a very intimate and personal experience . . . No line to get in as it is booked with a specific start time based on language - and it was all followed up with a glass of cava in the company of your fellow travellers. I would have loved to have been there over a weekend when they host live jazz on the terrace during the Summer . . . but no complaints about the thoughtful and elegant evening that I enjoyed with my Mum, my cousin and about twenty other curious companions.I love Gaudi - I would give any building of his an excellent just for existing - but this is truly one of the most surprisingly interesting visits I have done in a long time and it really helped to make the house come alive.

Good for museum types. Not as much to photograph here as some of the other Gaudi buildings. The exhibits are good though and explain the structure of his work and the sources of inspiration. On a sour note, there was no discount for pensioners even though the board outside suggested there were.
Expensive. Was a bit disappointed. Looks better in pictures than in real life. Gaudi park is a much better value

Astounding roof!. A short walk from Las Ramblas. Had to queue for about 15 minutes to get in. For the money, I prefered Casa Battlo, but this is definitely worth a visit. Very informative exhibition inside with some fantastic models.
Cannot see a lot. Mainly the terrace which is very nice, but the rest of the house is rented to people who live there, so you cannot visit much - expensive overall - prefer Casa Battlo !
Spectacular. It was so beautiful and made me truly appreciate the words I had heard in praise of Gaudi's masterpieces.

Well worth a visit. Loved the whole thing, really fascinating
Hated the climb to the roof but it was worth it
2 audio tours available long and short
It gets very busy
Very Beautiful. Parts of it are under contruction right now, which makes it less amazing, but the inside is amazing none the less. Worth the trip

Modern architects, eat your heart out!. A fascinating building and hidden gem... there's so much more to see than you would expect from the outside! Take a walk along the splendid roof terrace, find out about the "Modernisme" movement and Gaudi's work but best of all, enjoy the beautifully furnished period appartment - right up my street and not to be missed if that's what you're into! Gaudi's passion for functionality combined with aesthetic attractiveness and his recognition of the importance of air and natural light for people's quality of life is something often lacking in modern housing. Whilst it would not be financially viable to build like Gaudi now, I think modern architects could learn a lot from his principles!
amazing views from roof,so interesting about gaudi. Loved seeing the apartments gaudi stayed in and the roof terrace was amazing with all the sculptures and the views of barcelona.

a little pricey but worth a visit. Gaudi was an incredible architect. You can clearly see his inspiration from natural forms in the architecture of this building. The attention to detail is astonishing. The 1920s apartment you can visit is so beautiful you won't want to leave!

mobbed with people but worth a visit. The roof is where you want to go. There are a ton of tourists it is hard to get photos without a bunch of strangers in your photos. Try to go at an off time. Line moves more slowly than at the other houses.

La Pedrera. Visited with teenagers and adults, everyone loved it. So fascinating to feel how the building affects the senses, it's like going into a magical cave, so imaginative. The apartment is very interesting too. Great for photographers. We went early which was good as minimal queuing and we had the rooftop to ourselves for a few minutes.

Get there early.... I luckily was in line by 10:30 and was surprised to see how long it was when I left--and it was a hot day. The place is fascinating, the audio-guide well worth the extra. My appreciation for Gaudi's talent, yes even genius, was magnified three-fold after the visit. It may look a bit kooky on the outside but, even after 100 years, it would be a practical and delightful place in which to live today. Don't miss "La Pedrera" if at all possible.

Choose Casa Batllo instead unless you are a Gaudi scholar. But worth it if you are studying the period, love architecture, have time to kill or otherwise enjoy modernist history, art nouveau, or climbing stairs.

A Gaudi piece of arhitecture !. I visited Mila House after I saw Casa Battlo and I was a bit dissapointed. Mila House has open for visit only the groundfloor and the attic. The attic is the real attraction of Mila House, you will not regret your visit.

Wonderful tour. After waiting a reasonable 45 minutes to get in, we truly had a delightful time roaming the roof, attic, and example apartment. This building is a visual and architectural wonder. Although there are a number of people swarming about with you, it never seemed over-crowded. They seem to pace the admittance to keep the flow comfortable. Highly recommend it.

Mila. Gaudi was Really a genius. And these two houses, Mila and Battló, are only what he simply did: beautiful objects, well done as everything else he did. It is a pleasure to visit Casa Mila and imagine hoe people accepted or not living in such a place lika that. I would like to live there, in 1900 or now. Would be quite an experience!

Gaudi Houses in Barcelona. Don't miss the three Gaudi designed homes. There is a retail department store around the corner from the front of these homes that affords a great look at the back yards and rear of the homes. Go inside, and up to their rear terrace. It is actually a part of the store. You will get a view that is not available from inside the homes--some of which are not open to the public as they are private apartments.

beautifully lit at night. I wasn't able to see the interior, but there is a tour during the day and another at night. It's worth just seeing this building on the outside, and another just a city block away.

The prefect introduction to Gaudi. We really enjoyed visiting as it gave a wonderful introduction to the genius of Antoni Gaudi. I agree with others that you should visit before seeing his masterpiece Sagrada Família. The exhibits are well done but the magic is seeing how Gaudi was able to make utilitarian roof top vents into works of art. The atrium design also allows light and fresh to permeate each apartment. The absence of load bearing inner walls was visionary for 100 years ago. The building still seems contemporary in spite of it's age. The lines can be quite long, we would estimate an hour wait BUT with the 7 museum art pass we were able to bypass the lineup and get immediate access! This alone was worth the price of having the pass, not to mention the savings. We purchased our pass at the Picasso Museum but it is available at all the venues.TIP: Buy the Barcelona 7 museum Art Pass. You break even if you visit just 2 of the venues but most important you get to skip the lineup for tickets at all the venues

Another Guadi masterpiece. Although you only get to see part of the interior and the roof, it is certainly worth your time and money. Yet again, the audio guide makes a big difference and alerts you to details you would otherwise miss. There is so much in Gaudi designs - where form, function and simple elegance come together.

Very interesting. As much as I didn't pay to go in this building, I did have a good look at it from the outside. The shape is extraordinary and the balconies are particulary interesting. If you cross the square that it is on then you can see the famous chimneys well and if you go into the shop then there is a window from which you can see the courtyard so it is easy to see much of the building for free. Very good overall.

Very much worth its reputation. The exterior is stunning and the interior very interesting. We had a great time exploring Gaudi`s treasure (as well as Sagrada Famiglia, which was magnificent). Very nice souvenir shop, also.

The facade is the most fascinating. You don't have to go in to enjoy this beautiful building and its facade, although the roof is well worth seeing, with its wavy structure and Gaudis iconic chimneys. It's only an excibition in the first floor and one apartement on the 2nd floor that is available to the public, in addition to the roof top - that is splendid on its own and also for the views. It you go, be sure visit the roof terrace bar at Hotel Omm just one or two blocks up to have a drink and see the sun set on the Pedrera and the light come on. Well worth it!

Nice but a little expensive for what it was. Nice but a little expensive for what it was. 18 Euros for an hour or 2 viewing.Make sure you view this before La Sagrida as you might not appreaciate this as much.10% discount voucher if you do the bus tour.

Loved it!!. Firstly the location is stunning. Just walking around outside is a treat.We opted for the four course dinner show and the choice and quality of the food was excellent but you go to El Tablao de Carmen for the Flamenco show which was really good.The dancers, singers and musicians seem like a big happy family and you could see that they were enjoying performing as much as we enjoyed watching.A great night out!
Don't miss. Great gaudi concept, take the lift to the roof and view Barcelona no problems worth your time to visit

Something you shall not miss. Despite the fact tha there are just few rooms is original state you have to admire the spitir. I was so suprised by the wooden chairs designed by Gaudí - I have never sit on something more comfortable!!!

Nice but not mandatory. The Mila house is definitely worth a visit, although not as important as the Casa Batllo. I would say you get quite a bit of the experience just viewing it from the street. Big plus for well assorted stores in the house.
Amazing. Some of Gaudi's best work, a must visit. The roof is amazing

A must do to get an understanding of just how ahead of his time Gaudi was.. Go straight to the top in the lift (you come down the stairs on the way out) and spend some time admiring the roof (which sounds wierd but you'll get it). Then the attic area which is a very clever design before going through one of the original apartments. Do get the Audio tour it is well worth the extra €4 or so to get a better understanding of what Gaudi was setting out to achieve. The entry is €16 which is expensive but worth it.

A bit of Genius. Gaudi is simply unique, its a experience that isn't duplicated elsewhere. The Casa Mila rooftop alone is worth the visit, but in the top floor the displays show you a little of how Gaudi designed and worked. Then the apartments and rooms tell you the rest.

Great Gaudi Experience. We ordered tickets online ahead of time to beat the lines. The rooftop is amazing along with the apartment showing how upper middle class of the time lived. Must see for Gaudi fans along with Casa Batllo and Park Guell.

Fabulous!. Even though the ticket seems a bit expensive, this is one of the absolute must see places in Barcelona. In fact, of all the Gaudi places and works we saw, this was the one that truly amazed us. Even our kids 5 and 10 had an amazing time here. The place is not only a work of art, it is very "user friendly"-- I will just say this: they have a shorter kids audio tour! My daughter could not get over this treat and actually learned so much that she became our tour guide. Plus the view from the top of the building is unparalleled. I'm afraid of heights but this was spectacular.

Nice. I saw this Gaudí building after Casa Batllo, and even though is really nice for me is not at the level of the Casa Batllo, obviously is a different era of Gaudí and different approach the guy was way ahead of his era!!!

Gaudi is a genius. Gaudi's La Pedrera is a stunning example of his work. The rooftop is incredible, with spectacular views of Barcelona and Gaudi's beautiful chimneys and watertowers. The audio guide is useful in that it provides an insight into Gaudi's creations. There is an interesting display in the attic of Gaudi's techniques and the apartment showcases the functionality of his design. We preferred our visit to La Pedrera over our visit to Casa Batllo, due to the stunning rooftop. We visited early one morning and used the Articket, which allowed us to bypass the line. The Articket is good value if you are visiting a few museums/galleries.

Don't Miss This. What a wonderful building. This is enough by itself but the visit is also very well designed, interesting and inspiring, with glimpses of the culture of the times alongside background to Gaudi's inspiration. Our children also enjoyed this visit very much, particularly seeing the apartment and the audio tour was excellent.
This was the best of gaudi. The roof top is the best. Felt like we were in Star Wars with the storm troopers. A masterpiece of architecture. We did the headset tour.

The rooftop terrace alone is worth the admission fee.. Wonderful view of the city and of the Sagrada Familia. Could have spent hours up there just staring out at the city from every angle. Great photo opps from up there.

Amazing chimmneys!. I liked this very much, it was the first Gaudi house we went to, but because a lot of the building is in private use (it's a big building) you only get to see a very small portion and for me there was not quite as much detail and it's not as ornate as some of the others, that said, it's still stunning. It's worth going up for the Chimneys and crazy roof, but the door and beautiful Balconys are viewable from outside, so if you are limited by funds or time and only get to one Gaudi, do Casa Battlo, just across the road, which is stunning.
Amazing. Gaude is a genious. The roff top is incredible. Must see...
A must see. The architecture was amazing. The entire tour takes a bit of time to see and take it all in. It was a must see for me, and I am glad I went. (a little pricey)

An 1900's Appartment in a Major Work of Art. Great to be able to actually go thru the property and see how the building felt to live in. You don't appreciate the complexity of the building until you see it from the top, and also in the attic space. Informative for architecture students, and certainly interesting for the likes of me (a housewife). So broad appeal!

innovative architectural landmark. this amazing house is a must-see for all fans of Gaudi's work- even my husband, who was terrified of a 'death-by-Gaudi' weekend in Barcelona, was impressed- the functionality and beauty of the design comes to life when viewed first hand, and the roof chimneys and view over Passieg de Gracia are fabulous!

Gaudi at his very best. This is by far my favourite building in Barcelona and, indeed, one of my favourites in the world. It shows once again what is possible when an architectural genius is given a free hand ( and lots of money!) to do his creative best. The building is replete with magical "tricks", such as the false perspective when looking up in the courtyard, the extra-terrestial creatures on the roof and Gaudi's dogged refusal to have anything to to do with straight lines. It is said that when the privileged owner of one of the apartments complained to Sr Gaudi that there was no straight wall against which to set her piano, he replied "Then buy yourself a flute!"My advice is buy yourself a ticket.
worth every penny :). i loved case mila, and took the most beautiful photos inside. well kept, informative and beautiful. you must visit :)
A big stone house!. Magnificent view from the top, but didn't all that steps until you get in!

Lovely place and magnificent architecture. That was my first time in Barcelona. I loved all the Gaudi´s places, especially the Mila house. I loved the building and the views from the terrace at night are amazing.

Get tickets in advance. This was neat to see from outside...but because the line was so long and our time was limited, we could not do the inside. I certainly recommend getting tickets online. The metro is on the corner near this Gaudi Masterpiece, so it is a VERY easy jump off of the metro line. If you arrange your time in Barcelona well, you can see it and a few other great Gaudi works in one day.

It's all about the chimneys.... Terrible audio tour, don't do it! Unlike Guell Palace it starts with the best part (the chimneys) and slowly bores you to death on the way down. The audio tour is quite frankly pointless. The ceilings are also nice. For the fee they charge versus the other Gaudi trips you are better looking at photographs.

Be Tough and Take the Stairs. It costs Euro 16 to tour the building. Skip the elevator and add to your experience--there'll be no one else on the stairs and you'll still get to the top before the people in front of you in the elevator line. The ticket gets you into the attic, terrace, a 1920s apartment, and an exhibit hall. I really liked the apartment gift shop, and I like the more open access for touring the apartment, but it's still a museum, look but don't touch! Take the stairs back down and land in the atrium and primary gift shop with a gasp of relief.
Fascinating and beautiful. Quite pricey at 18 euros but really enjoyed it. This is the only gaudi we've bothered to pay to go inside but it was definately worth it

The inside matches the outside. This is the first time I went inside the Pedrera. I have always been amazed at the works of Gaudi and his brilliant use of materials, air, light and fusion with nature. The Pedrera did not disappoint. It is well kept and well presented. The audioguide is helpful. One of the compliants I would have is that the ticket is very expensive. Though it belongs to a private company and so they can charge what they want, but the Catalan govt should intervene and control the prices so that large number of people can see the work of this famous Catalan architect. It is only for this reason that I would give it a 4 instead of 5 stars.
More to see there. On the first floor is a free museum. I saw Miro's paintings on pottery. A little gift shop also. I was able to take many pictures of the architectural details.
Don't miss it!. La Pedrera is and old condo restored by a genius called Antoni Gaudì, the most significant person in Spanish Modernism. Go and spend some time on the fantastic terrace.
Unique but expensive. This place is something you cannot find in other places. It is something you should visit but I consider the ticket price quit expensive.
Well worth a visit!. The roof terrace is amazing, amazing intro to his work
Fantastic. Loved the place! So interesting to see how it was made and controversy around the building. Great exhibition inside. Wish we'd got the audio now! Worth the money!

Expencive for what it is. The only nice thing about it is the outsite and the rooftop. the apparment that is open to the public display's the rooms how they could have looked in the early 19th century
Gaudi. Good introduction to Gaudi architecture with a very educational museum
One of the coolest places. The architecture was amazing. It is definitely worth seeing while you are in Barcelona.

Do NOT Miss. We have been twice now. Last year was with a docent; this year they have audio tours for purchase instead. If you know nothing about Gaudi or if you just love him, this is not to be missed. The architectural information and the background to it are educational and fascinating. We have also been to Sagrada Familia, but this site has more basic information about Gaudi's influences and philosophy. Even having been before, we did not regret another visit. If you have only money or time for one site, I guess I would have to say Sagrada Familia because the scope is so monumental and awe-inspiring (and I hate the word awesome and try never to use it, so take this for what it's worth!). BUT, if you can- do both tours. You won't regret it.

Gaudi - creative genius!. Each of the works of Gaudi was worth a visit. I am not at all an architectural or artistic sort and had thought, why would I want to go to all of them? My niece though was keen so off we went. Casa Mila was our second Gaudi site and completely different from the first, or third. The detail work matches the large scale design, nothing is overlooked (check out the hinges & handles). Simply amazing creativity!

2 floors and a roof of fun, information and inspiration. And a Gallery, which is separate.. Casa Mila, also called La Pedrera, is a gem of Gaugi design. From the time you arrive at the imposing front gates to the time you leave it is another world, Gaudi's last public building and "Modernista" circa 1912. The downstairs foyer has been re-modeled but is still a delight with a large open light well and high decorated walls and ceilings. The apartment open to visitors is like a film set, decked out in original furniture, artifacts, clothes, machinery and much more from a posh early 20th century family life (with servants). It's amazing to see the rooms themselves, their view and so on but for me the interest was the way they lived. It's a HUGE apartment. Then up to the museum under the roof. Gaudi, like all Moderernista architects was drawing inspiration from 3 things. Nature, the Catalan Empire (14th Century) and the use of "cheap" building materials. Of course, with wealthy clients he would stretch the point on the "cheap materials"and use beautiful and expensive materials with a tem of talented artisans who were drawn to his vision, but the ideal is reflected in the use of mosaics, glass bottle bottoms moulded together and so on. The museum explores his inspirations, from the simple corn cob and snake skeleton to the very sophisticated "upside down hanging arches made from fine chains" (I can't really describe this) that gave him some building forms. There's a lot of interactive exhibits for kids to enjoy, and it's simply wonderful to be in these vast, under-roof, symmetrical but uneven vaulted spaces with columns.The roof, ah the roof. It's uneven, it's spectacular, it has great views, but most of all it has the famous chimneys that supposedly inspired George Lucas for the stormtroopers in the Star Wars films. Lots of other elements too, like the water towers and wobbly walls and railings. Caixa Catalunya, which has it's cultural centre offices in the building, runs a summer program of jazz, music and performances on the roof. Watch their site for information (and sometimes arrive to a complimentary glass of Cava). My photo is from one of these events, a very funny and clever solo mime/musician/performer.The Gallery, which is FREE, and is separate to the above has touring and locally put together exhibitions. We have seen some excellent exhibitions here. These exhibitions, always with well-written notes, at times features artists and movements not so well remembered. At other times it will be a show of for example the famous Russian Constructivists, a Vladamir Melevitch exhibition and so on.Are we allowed to put websites on Trip Advisor? http://www.lapedrera.com/en/what-la-pedrera has all the info you will need for a visit to the building, the events on around the time of your visit and the exhibitions.Please note, I am not 100% sure that there is wheelchair access to ALL levels. There are certainly lifts... but do check. La Pedrera has a programme called “Accessible La Pedrera”, which has sensory resources in exhibitions and concerts. These resources are for the hard of hearing (sign language) and audio descriptions for the partially sighted.

Like a fairy tale come to life. La Pedrera makes it obvious why Barcelona is so over-the-top about native son Antoni Gaudi - he really puts it all together here, the aesthetic and the practical. Obvious why it has been selected a World Heritage Site - this is not just a Catalan treasure!
Another Gaudi House. The house he designed for a friend. All very interesting, especially the original furnished rooms but the rooftop has the wow factor. Warrior chimneys fantastic.

Expensive and Disappointing. After seeing the Sagrada Famila church, this was a big disappointment. It is interesting, and if you are wanting to see all of Gaudi's work, then by all means go. But really we could have skipped it and been quite happy. Don't miss the Sagrada Familia though!
Gaudi- The Architect of dreams. A must of barcelona architecture art nouveau. Located in Paseo de Gracia.
Brilliant. Personally for me the best bit was to see inside the attic spaces and see how the roof was constructed. The roof itself was stunning

Casa Mila. The line to go in might be long, but it moves pretty quickly. My favorite part of casa Mila is the roof. Although the inside is interesting the rooftop and the views from the rooftop were my absolute favorite.

Gaudi genius. La Pedrera is something different. It's one of Gaudi's residential buildings and a reflection of his genius. The roof terrace is a wonder to behold-the weird and wonderful "shapes" that confront you are so engaging as is the panaramic view of Barcelona.The apartments are timeless in nature. Considering the building is over 100 years old, you can still imagine living there-just add some mod cons. There is access by lift to all parts but the terrace itself cannot be negotiated by a wheelchair due to it's design. This is a must see for fans of Gaudi, archtecture and uniqueness.

Get there early. The line was long -- which is to be expected in June -- but it is an amazing building -- a true tribute to Gaudi's vision. I'd suggest getting tickets (online maybe) in advance so as to not stand in the the 2 hour que on a hot day.

A must see of Gaudi's work. As with all of Gaudi's buildings in Barcelona, La Pedrera or Casa Mila confirms in my mind that Gaudi is a genius living in a fantasy world. The way he designed this building as with all of his others defied conventional construction techniques and his sleek designs can be seen influenced in today's modern building and design. The chimneys on the roof top remind me of the Bedouin in the Sahara desert with their faces covered... amazing view of the city as well.You also get to see Pis de la Pedrera, a furnished apartment showing early 20th century urban life...... and it was pretty advanced modern living for those days.

One of the most fascinating buildings. La Pedrera is one of the most charming houses I've ever seen. I do not comment. inside you will find as flat a la Gaudi. Fantastic terrace full of picturesque shapes. The decor is a lot of tourists and high input costs in the high season = € 16.50 ..
