Worth Your While!. We had a brief wait of ~15 minutes to get in. The rooftop is just stunning with the unique chimneys and great view of the city. Every angle has a different view, so make sure to walk the full perimeter. The attic was structurally very beautiful with some great examples of his furniture, inspirations, and models. The apartment was interesting to see how he was such a holistic designer taking care in designing unique molding around windows/doors, doorknobs, window latches and the like. This was a great introduction to Gaudi for us.

Gaudi's amazing work. Really I think the reason to visit Barcelona is to see the Gaudi works and this one is amazing, huge and grand yet organic and unassuming it is a jewel. The views from the roof are great too! If you're on a budget it's a little pricy to do this and the Sagrada Familia and Casa Batilo, but when else will you get to see such amazing feats of architecture. Be sure to sit on the golf ball like stools too in the attic, super comfy!
interesting. of course the roof is wonderful and the lookout too.

Amazing roof top. Worth the trip and the price to get to the roof and see Gaudi's warrior chimney stacks. It also provides great views of the city.Go to the roof first as this feature is only open when the weather is dry - so if the weather is unsettled they could close it whilst you tour the inside. If you are in a rush the rest of the house is a quick spin unless you are a real Gaudi fan
icon. on the last day of our trip we went to see this and were glad we did it gives you an insight into how Gaudi's mind worked with the designs not only pleasing to the eye but structually practical
Our Favorite Guadi Building. The whole thing is terrific. From the basement to the roof. A great first stop of Gaudi's work, since you learn so much about how he thought and worked.

A superb Gaudi-designed apartment house with an other-worldly rooftop sculpture garden. My wife & I visited La Pedrera as part of a 4-hour guided tour of Gaudi masterworks in Barcelona: La Pedrera & the Church of the Holy Family. We strongly recommend both!The highlights of La Pedrera were (1) the exterior, (2) one furnished, restored, period apartment on the 4th floor, (3) a display area about Gaudi's work & ideas, and (4) an other-worldly rooftop sculpture garden. The rooftop was the strangest & most provocative place, well worth the most time during a visit. The rooftop also offers sweeping vistas of Barcelona.

Beautiful building by Gaudi. Situated in Passeig de Gracia,the most beautiful avenue in Barcelona,is another building by Gaudi. The most impressive thing in this building is the way it is curvely shaped and the amazing balconies.You can also visit inside, walk on the "roof" and see the plansGaudi made to build it.Quite interesting.Don't miss at least a visit to the exterior.

Gaudi is pure genius!!. We were not familiar with Gaudi prior to our visit to Barcelona. We are now in a big crush on the genius. I wish we could live in one of his houses! We only saw this from the outside but felt compelled to at the very least see if from the outside after Sagrada Familia and Park Guell. We are new fans of Antonio Gaudi and Barcelona!!

Very expensive. Unfortunately we waited until our last day to visit and it rained heavily so didn't see the rooftop at it's best. Entrance price very high at 16.50 Euros with no concessions so be prepared. Long queues to enter but it's possible to book ahead on line. The apartments were lovely and awesome to think they were built for workers, not the rich.

How could you go to Barcelona and not see this?. If you had to chose between the Miro museum or going here I would say go here! It was definitely work seeing and truly amazing. Make sure you get the headset tour.
beautiful place! :). such a lovely place.worth seeing! :) great way to spend 1-2 hours
Another Gaudi special. Keep in mind that this is on the Bacelona Museum Pass, which allows you to skip the line and included entrance to 7 museums.
La Pedrera De Nit. 2nd visit ontop of the roof one summers evening. Live jazz and a glass of cava at 10pm-11pm, watching the sun set over Barcelona. Great way to see this amazing gaudi building.
Beautiful. Only seen from the outside but a lovely example of Gaudi's work, well worth a visit
a maze of funky rooms. The rooms had furniture in them so you could image how they were used. The line to get in wasn't so long. Loved the children's playhouse, the kitchen, and the roof!

Unbelievable!. Could have spent hours in there, but so may things to see in the city limited my time. Designed by Gaudi It was a controversial design at the time for the undulating stone facade and with wrought iron decoration of the balconies and windows, designed largely by Josep Maria Jujol, who also created some of the plaster ceilings. Architecturally it is considered an innovative work for its steel structure and free form partitioning inside. The façade is self-supporting. Other innovative elements were the construction of underground car parking and separate lifts and stairs for the owners and their servants.The roof is on different levels with oddly designed chimneys, vents and decoration.Included in the tour is a visit around rooms that are strctured and furnished similarly to the original intentions. A visit not to be missed
Another Gaudí Masterpiece. Worth the visit. Another modernism masterpiece where you can witness Gaudí's pure genious

An unforgettable building. Once visited, never forgotten! This building is so organic and is like no other on earth. The rooftop and chimneys make you believe you are in Wonderland. Gaudi at his most inventive.

Stunning architecture. This house has a more "earthy" feel to it than Casa Batlo and the interior is very different. An apartment is open to the public and all I can say is, I wish I lived there. If you like Gaudi, you will love this.
Amazing but busy. Amazing sights, but get there early as it gets very busy and quite expensive.

Nice architecture and good audio. We opted for the "audio" while we roamed around the building... and that made a difference in understanding the history of the building. I wish we had seen the La Sagrada, which was made by the same architect. However, it was good to learn about Gaudi and what inspired him to create his work: nature, insects, etc... explains the interesting shape of the building.Only thing I didn't like was the line.. then again, every museum has a line!
On the list to see!. The highlight of this building is the rooftop. However, it was quite crowded so I didn't enjoy it as much as I would have liked.
Interesting. Interesting introduction to Gaudi's works. I prefer however the details of Casa Batllo over this.

I want to live here,,,!. Another extraordinary building, well worth the wait and the ticket price. The attics are far better than they sound, and the apartment with contemporary fittings and furniture is a joy. Great views from the roof of Passeig de Gracia

La Pedrera. Well worth the visit. Everyone should buy the National museum card -- it covers all of the seven national museums including La Pedrera, the National Museum of Catalonia, the Picasso Museum and the Miro - it is only 30 Euro good for a month and you never have to wait in line. Best deal in Barcelona.

amazing, eccentric Gaudi design. The ability to visit several floors and roof-top gave us amazing perspectives on Gaudi's all-encompassing creativity in designing architecture, furniture, and decorations. The museum-like exhibitions in the garrett were very helpful.

The rooftop is amazing!. Disguising chimneys as sculptures makes exploring the rooftop a must. The museum inside features period decor and an explanation of construction. Expect to wait in a long line!
A roof with a difference!. More interesting design features that shows architecture is not just about function
A great tour!. The rooftop of this building is like another world, unique chimneys and great views of Barcelona. One of Gaudi's best!
Minor Modernism. Once you have seen Casa Batllo and Palau de la Musica, this building strikes a minor chord in the canon. Save yoursel the €18 of each ticket.

Fantastic Example of Gaudi's Brilliance. The tour of this beautiful house is well worth the time. The organic decoration and foundation of this incredible structure is awe-inspiring. Gaudi has become my idol in the world of architecture.

Still great second time around. I visited La Pedrera about 13 years ago, and although the rooftop walk and views were familiar I hadn't been into the apartment below. I think this for me was a real highlight, glimpsing into the past of ths great building. Also not to forget the fantastic exhibition space in the attic which feels like you are inside some great creature, which I guess you are!

A must see!!!. This building is amazing and i have never see one like it. You can wander around the building and onto the roof terrace. See how it was lived in in its day with its original furniture and fittings.You can see Guadis plans and models.We paid 33 euros entrance for 2 adults. We paid with a credit card and had to produce a passport for id.
Beautiful. Great tour of a Gaudi apartment. It was interesting to see how people of this era lived.
La Pedrera. Brilliant and astonishing building. Worth a look and some of your hours
Nice but too expensive!. It's an amazing building, but the entry is quite expensive considering how big the place is.
Gaudi the great. Went to Barcelona to quench my Gaudi fix -- but it just got worse! La Pedrera is fantastical Star Wars landscape. Don't miss it.

Great example of Gaudi's work. Of course Casa Mila is not Gaudi's masterpiece (Sagrada Familia will always be his #1 design) but Casa Mila is a great and clear way to experience in what kind of way Gaudi designed buildings (and also furniture, as it is shown at the exhibition in the building) and what kind of inspiration he got from organic structures. The roof terrace has a nice view, as well the inner core of the building.

Something different. Roof is the place worth visiting. So is the modern house. There is even a collection of furnitre i.e. chairs etc designed by Gaudi on display here. Even models and maps of his designs too. This is one of the houses that Gaudi Built. Roof is on the 7th floor and there is a elevator to it. Tour begins from the roof. Afternoon or early evening could be the best times to visit this place. If you have already been to Casa Balto and Palau Guel then you may skip this place unless you wish to visit all of Gaudi's work's. The place is good and inspiring for young architect students. You may consider audio guide if you wish to get into knowing all the details of this building. You have two options for the audio guide, one which has general information and is of around 30-45 mins, for a general tourist this one should be fine but if you want the information in depth the other audio guide of 1hr or perhaps more is available too.

Into Gaudi. If you are into Gaudi I think this is a necessary visit. It is a way into the residential work of Gaudi. The chance to see an apartment in the building complements his architecture with interior design. There is furniture as well. If you plan to go to three museums there is a pass that you can buy that gives you VIP access to these places and you can skip the entrance line. It does work!
Worth seeing. Unique structure. Roof alone worth trip. Looks like something Dr. Suess would have developed. Tour inside also interesting.
Special architecture.. Nice to have a quick look (I only looked from the street, so the outside).

gaudi masterpiece. what an amazing place although a bit of a queue to get in-best to get there early or pre book tickets if you can.You have to walk up to the roof to start the tour and its a lot of stairs and very busy so be prepared.There is a lot of information about Gaudi's other attractions and where he got his inspiration but it is just fascinating wandering around and looking at all the little details he put into his designing.Very enjoyable visit although think I prefer casa batilo for the wow factor
Amazing. Be prepared to walk up 16 flights of stairs (about 8 stories) to get to the top. Once at the top, you work your way down one of the most amazing structures ever. The audio tour is a must.
amazing!. obligatory to see and experience this work of art. now in summer there are jazz concerts with champagne in the nights. enjoy it!

Antonio Gaudi. These are the apartments that are still being lived in today. The architecture of these apartments is absoulutely breathtaking. The view from the rooftops where the wonderful chimineys are located is amazing.
What a disappointment!. Nothing great except that it is different from other surrounding building built with straight lines. It is better to spend your time in Park Guell.
La Pedrera. across the street from Suites Avenue Hotel. Nice display of Gaudi's work.
Toured La Pedrera. This was an exceptional experience that was worth the wait (20 minutes) to get in. It was amazing what had been done to this house. It also had an excellent gift shop.
Stunning House. Go on the evening tour it costs a little extra but well worth it. Book in advance as there are long queues. The views from the rooftop are stunning at night.

Nice but... I have expected more to be honest. The house is huge you also get to see one of the apartments which is the highlight of this place. Equipped with all old toys, and stow in the kitchen, wardrobes, shelfs in the living room, with stunning chandelier and very interesting bathroom. Also you would see and try wooden chairs which from a distance seem to be very uncomfortable and once you sit down bring a pleasant surprise. My 'but' is more or less for the price and what you get to see.
beautiful mosaics. the house was enormous with the roof garden, the attic and the central courtyard the best attractions

Interesting and insightful. La Pedrera is a Gaudi designed apartment building which you can visit. There are two apartments open to the public which are furnished in the period when the building was originally built, plus other public areas which give you insight into the practicalities of living in a Guadi designed building. The highlight is the roof terrance which features on or in many Barcelona guide books and the views are excellent especially of his masterpiece the Segrada Familia a few blocks away. Dont be put off by the long queue as it moves quite quickly, and prices aren't expensive for what is a veru interesting and unique building.

after Sagrada, this was average. EUR15.00 to see stuffs i could have googled. unless you have visited all the rest, i think looking at the building from the outside and continue shopping would have been a better choice.pictures here if you want to give the place a miss.http://nikikoh.xanga.com/760163009/espa%c3%b1ol-de-invierno---casa-mil%c3%a0/
To Barcelona from Shanghai. Wonderful visit, with audio guide, highly recommended.

Overpriced.. I was disappointed. The rooftop was the best part. A hoard of school children were sitting all over the roof top, tired from trekking the city, like all the other tourists, rather frustrating when you've paid 16 € to get in. The other attractions were an attic which was OK, and an apartment with interior decor from the start of the the 20th century - not really my scene. In order to complete the tour you were directed through 2 gift shops. Overall highway robbery. Would not recommend this.

Amazing, must go just to see the roof!. I really thought this was a great piece of architecture and quite enjoyed walking around and looking at it.The roof (where your self guided tour starts) is probably the best part. The way that even the simple things have been designed to look so good and at the same time be very practical is really nice and worth going to see on its own. The rest of the house varies as parts show what it would have been furnished with but without and specificity great designs in it (compared to the roof anyway) but the attention to detail he had to make things very practical and is probably why it doesn't look amazingly fancy, if it did it would just be a pain to live in.Part of the house, nearer the end has some models and explanations of how Gaudí designed his works and the alternative methods he used to work out how to construct these buildings which was quite interesting and informative.I think the the main houses Gaudí designed that you can see in this area is this and Casa Batlló, out of the two this is the better one (not to say Casa Batlló isn't good though).The length of time to tour around the house varies but if you get the audio guide (costs extra) there are two or three different ones which last different lengths of time, each costing a different amount. I think they've done this as the full tour (which I went for) is around an hour and a half which might be to long for some people so there are shorter versions which I guess cut parts out.
Gaudi's best works. Definitely a must see if you like stuff from Gaudi. Some brilliant stuff.

Not to be missed. I've visited a few of Gaudi houses - all great but this provided greater insight to his amazing work. Really good galleries in the attic and of course the roof is now a symbol of Barcelona

Rooftop terrace is where it is at.... LOVED the rooftop. I spent at least an hour and a half on the rooftop! Such a magical place. The rest of the house was typically museum....but that rooftop was GREAT!

Compared to Casa Batilo, disappointing. Make sure you know that there is an elevator up to the roof if you are with someone unable to walk up 8 floors of stairs.
House seemed run down, and shabby. Make sure to visit Casa Batilo to get the best of Gaudi!

Gaudi was a visionary. La Casa Mila was my favorite destination in Barcelona. Gaudi actually designed the first underground parking garage in Europe! The building is so futuristic for an apartment building yet the artistic inspiration is what makes it so appealing. Do arrive early since there are so many large tour groups. And you will love the photo opportunities on the roof. I have never seen anything like this in Europe or the Americas. ¡Increíble!

Unique Place. Go early to beat the lines. Cost was ok but would not want to pay more - roof top is worthy to see and get some photos, interior walk-through also very interesting to show what living there was like. Note: The roof is closed if it is raining.

Highly recommend. This cost 16 euros to enter, and we did visit towards the end of the day, but thoroughly enjoyed, especially being on the heights of the rooftop! The museum was interesting and beautiful, and the architecture stunning and quirky - a must see for all fans of Gaudi!
Unbelivable!!. Such a different place to visit! was blown away by the roof terrace and the overall shape of the building. Amazing innovative design! One of the highlights of our visit to Barcelona.

Another masterpiece. Fabulous apartment building by Gaudi. Your ticket allows a visit to the rooftop to view the cool chimney sculptures and a great views of Barcelona. You also can wander through one of the apartments. During the summer there are night tours plus a rooftop bar. It's a don't miss attraction. Lines are long so get there early.

Fabulous, informative, and like no place else. Go! Gaudi was obviously a genius and getting to visit the rooftops, the attics (with very informative multimedia displays), and an apartment really help you gain some insight into the full extent of his passion, commitment, and vision.
Don't miss the roof!. Very interesting building but the roof was amazing!
beautiful La Pedrera. just fantastic, another one of Gaudi's masterpieces

Beautiful!. Loved the visit - well worth the entrance fee. Less use of colour than in the other Gaudi residential buildings we visited, but wonderfully creative use of space and light. As well as being able to visit an apartment, entry includes access to the attic and the roof terrace - both really interesting. We opted not to take an audioguide but just to take in the aesthetics.
See it we will be amazed. Great visit take the elevator to the top, many stairs..heheheh see the inside the apartment and the deco of the time.
A fascinating building. The roof of this building is awesome and the exhibition in the loft shows a great insight into Gaudi's other projects. Worth the entrance fee.
Incredible. Just breath taking. Enjoyed it more than Casa Batillo. The views from the top roof are just incredible. Gaudi definitely a genius!

Stunning!. La Pedrera is an architectural wonder that defies description--especially since it was built 100 year ago. Imagine no 90-degree corners. I have visited twice and was amazed each time by the brilliance of Gaudi.

Goudi masterpiece - not to be missed. The rooftop is a wonderful collection of Goudi creations which link with some of the art work at Segrada Famillia. Good vista for the city. The apartment is an amazing collection of rooms.
Another beautiful Gaudi house. Another must-see. Tip: Take elevator to the roof :-). Nice to see original furniture and details in the rooms.Too bad you can only see a few floors of it.

Wow!!!. This was just amazing. But what of Gaudi's is not amazing?! To be able to walk inside, immediately look up and see the open roof is breath taking! I was eager to see the roof top and OH wow it was amazing - it's not just a portion they let you walk over, you get to walk the whole thing! What a view! The museum shows how Gaudi thought and got inspired for his crazy ideas. The apartment was cool, but we kind of just walked through quickly. This city is full of amazing things to remember forever!
Must see. This apartment building is a must see for those interested in Gaudi, and the roof top is a great place to view Barcelona.
Very interesting.. The design, construction and history are great. It has now however become very commercialised and there may be long queues to get in.

The bathrooms were disgusting. How to enter was confusing, and the TSA like method of entering was a a terrible start to this visit. They are fortunate that Gaudi is the headliner because their operations are terrible! But it is an amazing place, and they did a great job with their models and exhibits. Go! It was amazing, but be warned on the other stuff.
Spectacular. The roof is amazing for its architecture and views in the middle of the city. The flat is very interesting and show the ideas of Gaudi in terms of living space. A must see
What a house!. The genius of Gaudi seems to have no limits. In this and other of his works you can see the magic of the artist.

Worth a look and a picture, see it on the way down to La Ramba or something. Another interesting peice of Gaudi's work dotted around the city. I would certainly suggest it - so you have the picture. I would advise starting from the top of the Garcia and walking down past Mila House, then Batilo and on to Placa Catalunya and La Ramba

Underwhelms in comparison with others. La Pedrera is interesting in patches but ordinary in others. As has been mentioned, Casa Batllo (which is located on the same street) is far superior. Not only that, but Palau Guell is another similar construct which beats it hands down.The problem La Pedrera has is consistency - whilst it's rivals are flawless, there are parts of La Pedrera which are bang average. Stairwells that could be in any office block in the world etc.The attic includes a small museum, but the vast majority of it's content is about othe Gaudi works; the two aforementioned plus La Sagrada Familia etc. To me, this suggests there isn't enough of interest for La Pedrera to stand alone (it is also a little boring of you've already visited them and had better explanations).It isn't bad, and I wouldn't say "don't go". But certainly prioritise the others and callibrate your expectation accordingly!

Worth a visit for Gaudi fans!. I enjoyed this place but wasn't as 'wowed' as I was by the Casa Bastillo when I visited 5 years ago and not a patch on the Sagrada Familia. Good views from the roof - don't bother if it's wet and the roof is closed.
The Gaudi to See. Interesting displays inside , but start at the roof and take your time there - stunning architecture , imagination and view
Excellent. If you are going to see Parc Guell and Casa Battlo, go to see this first. It is a family home in the Gaudi style. Not quite as barmy as the Battlo, but still marvellous.

Really enjoyed it! Stunning. This was nothing like ive ever seen before. 16 euro entry but we spent well over an hour there. The roof is amazing and the reconstructed apartment and exhibits were very very interesting!!

The highlight of our Barcelona Visit. La Pedrera offers an evening tour of the building. It's on the expensive side but our tour of 11 people had the whole building to ourselves. The view at night is spectacular. During the day, you have hundreds of people touring at one time. The 1 1/2 hour tour ends with a Cava toast. This was a great end to our visit to Spain.

Quirky. While we did have to queue outside we made friends with fellow travellers and loved the inside. The chimney stacks have real personalities, the museum is well laid out and fascinating.Worth the wait and price of admission to gain insight into Gaudi's brilliance.

unique. i've never seen just a flat concept. the visit is limited. You visit the famous roof, the attic and one flat. The apartment is realy very nice. Just feel how it was to live about hunderd years ago. book your ticket online

This is a must do in Barcelona. It is a bit pricey to go through this amazing building but worth it - how many times will you be in Barcelona? We took the long version of the audio guide which gave us great insights into the building. The wavy roof is fascinating with all of the unusual chimneys decorated with broken pieces of tile. It was an easy walk from the Sagrada Familia.

enjoyable and interesting. quite large queues to see this. This was our first gaudi building we paid to visit.Well worth seeing particularly the roof terrace and the appartment.Good view of barcelona from the roof.We enjoyed our visit.

Roof top is stunning but you only see three floors.. The roof top is well worth seeing. The price is reasonable. I was disappointed that only three floors were open to the public (including the roof).

Very interesting. Quite expensive, but worth it for the roof terrace,so make sure that this isn't closed ( I believe they close it when it rains ) The displays inside the roof area about Gaudi's work are interesting, as is the furnished apartment.
masterpiece. Try to visit it on a sunny day. We were there on a very cloudy day, and impression was definitely affected by the weather.

Creatures on the roof. This was by far one of my favorite Gaudi sites in Barcelona. The figures on the roof take on a magical character when seen from the right angle. Spend some time on the roof, day or night, and let your imagination wander. While there are long lines, the Barcelona Card, gets you to the head of the line.

This is an architectural gem and a world class icon. The entry ticket is pricey and it might not be ideal for kids under 9 but even for them it is amazing. This is, personally, Gaudi at his best. The Sagrada Familia is still unfinished, until then, La Pedrera is the best.
Amazing building by Gaudi. The roof of La Pedrera is among my favourite spots in Barcelona. Feels like being in a fairytale and aslo great views of the city!

Introduction to Gaudi. this was the first of Gaudi's extraordinary creations that I had ever seen. I emerged onto the roof to see these wonderful chimneys,turrets etc. so pleased it was open, as I understand it is closed in wet weather. Unfortunately, the queue was too long this visit. best to come early in the morning - though there are more wonderful things to see than there are mornings, I find

Another Gaudí Masterpiece in Barcelona. Casa Mila is yet another great Gaudí masterpiece in Barcelona.Much bigger than Casa Batlló as it occupies an entire street corner on Passeig de Gràcia.I especially enjoyed the unique iron balconies which I found fascinating in their design. Easily reached by walking up Passeig de Gràcia 5 minutes past Casa Batlló, or via the Diagonal metro stop just out front. Highly recommended!

A stunning Gaudi building. Another must see in Barca, the beautiful view from the roof and the marvellous architecture is awesome.Get the Audio guide to really get an understanding of what Gaudi was trying to achieve.Go on a Sunday when all the shops are shut as it is a tad quieter.
same as casa Batlo. from the outside very nice but to get in it is 15 euros. You have to decide for yourself if architecture/art is your thing.

Unusual but refreshing. Being really ignorant I just heard about Gaudi when I planned my trip. A friend recommended visiting this place, so I did. It's the only Gaudi attractions that I paid to get in (still thought it's rather pricey for the experience). The rooftop is the highlight, and is quite an eye opener - that someone was open-minded enough to commission this bizarre design. Looks pleasing in the eye but not so practical I think. There were a few complex looking steps that look quite easy to trip on if you don't pay enough attention, especially when you're busy taking photographs and it rained (plus a pool of water actually forming in few corners). From a few angles, the low walls intersecting the mid part of the rooftop create an impression of sea waves. Didn't get much impression of city view from there, think it wasn't high enough to get a good view but could definitely see the top levels of the ugly apartments around it.Then there was one building level that has a long, circular design that was supposed to be inspired from snake skeleton. Was dark with strategic yellow lightings that gave an impression of being in a cave (or inside a giant snake). The show apartment unit was interesting in that it still had the items from that era i.e. furniture and small stuff like food tins. Could really picture how a wealthy family lived then.The queue for this place is much longer than Casa Battlo (at least when I passed both midday in the same day). Might take at least an hour and a half before you can get in. So the best thing is either come very early, like a bit before the opening time e.g. 8.45, or book online. The latter is either new or very underutilized judging from the long ticket queue and lack of coordination from the staff side on my online order. There wasn't a special queue for online order - just go to one of the staff and asked to cut the queue. Took them almost 10 mins to find my ticket in the system. In any case, going early is always the best. Be among the first to arrive on the rooftop if you can. Otherwise you can't avoid having other people in your rooftop pictures.
Mama Mia. Make sure you sit down in the couch designed by Picasso with your loved one and just relax...a feeling worth living for...

Casa Mila Star Wars Inspiration?. If you are Star Wars fans like my kids this Gaudi House is definitely worth a visit. It's a contrast to Casa Battlo but still visually interesting and unique. The roof terrace is a great spot for pictures even if you are somewhat afraid of heights like myself. We went at about 9:30 am and the line up wasn't bad but be prepared for crowds. If only doing 2 Gaudi creations I would choose Casa Battlo and the Sangrada Familia but this one would come in third. Whether you find Gaudi's work genius or insanity you will have something to talk about after a visit to this sight.
Wonderful architecture. Worth a visit for the brilliant architecture alone. Amazing views of the city on the rooftop.

Definitely check this place out. Embodying a subdued flamboyance in comparison to its neighbor Casa Battlo; the colors scheme sees more neutral earth tones, but the shapes, textures and overall appearance is no less a spectacle along the city's main promenade. The free flowing wavy exterior with elaborate wrought iron balconies and the rooftop terrace with mosaic chimneys and gypsy caves are major points of interest. See photos from my visit here: http://indulgeinspireimbibe.blogspot.com/2011/11/barcelona-la-pedrera.html
Fascinating. The achievement in terms of artistry is astounding. The rooftop with views to Sagrada Familia is quite lovely.

Go at Night. This place is really interesting and while expensive check into La Pedrera Secreta at night about 930pm. It is a fairly new tour and we pretty much had the lighted roof to ourselves. After they take you to a beautiful room for cava. I think we really got a feel for the life there and seeing the night lights on the roof worth it. Also in summertime if you can book a music event on the roof that would be great too. During the day less exciting (my opinioin) but still worth the time to see it.

Fascinating. I loved this building. From the fascinating roof to the magnificent attics and the wonderful apartment. The flowing lines of the structure are matched by the beautiful architecture inside. Just gorgeous!
Casa Mila. Worth a visit, even if it is only to go up onto the roof top!
Go!. This is one of my top 3 for Gaudi sites. The rooftop is a great way to view Barcelona and feel like you're in another time and space.

What a cool building!. I remember learning about this building in art history class...seeing it in real life was AWESOME! The ticket line wasn't too bad at 11:00 am, 5 min or so. The coolest part is how Gaudi didn't sacrifice form for function; he use nature's forms to enhance it! Such a cool building, top to bottom (and from the outside), I thought the audio guide was worth it. Go!
Unique and interesting sight. Take the tour, the view from the roof is enough to make it worth your while. Lots of tourists but the entrance fee deters the masses.
Beautiful. Nice place, very interesting architecture. Gaudi was awesome

Amazing!. From the outside view to inside, it's amazing. You can visit one decorated apartment and imagine how would be to live there. At night is beautiful too. So, it's a place to go see day and night.

Another great Gaudi attraction. Saw this and Casa Battlo. Had debated picking one or the other but did both. Neither are inexpensive, but when's the next time you're going to be in Barcelona? Anyway, both houses are great. You can't fully see Barcelona without exploring Gaudi. Most do it through Sagrada Familia, which is awesome, but see more if you can.
Gaudi's done much better. If you want a much better flavor of Gaudi's outstanding work, go see Palau Guell or Casa Batllo. This is just ok.

Make sure the roof is open. Although the interior is impressive and their is a very good display in the attic, La Pedrera is all about the roof. In fact, the majority of the building is not open to the public as it is made up of apartments, which still have residents in them. The line up when we went was long, but shorter than most times. Rain earlier in the day meant the roof was closed for safety reason until just before we arrived. Our wait was about 45 minutes and it can be many times this on sunny days. The price is the same whether the roof is open or not, so be careful as you do not want to miss it after waiting so long in line. It is another Gaudi wonder and well worth the wait.

Absolutely a must see. Get the audio tour. If you buy the museum card, you will not have to wait in line for entry. Start at the top and spend time seeing the genius of Gaudi. The attic is fascinating - watch the videos and pay close attention to the models. The apartment is magnificent. I could have stayed here the entire day. It's worth it to buy a book in the beautiful gift shop that explains the architecture as this building was a true feat of design structurally and in every single little detail from floor tile to door handles.
Unbelievable architecture. The design for light in the living units, the ample use of wood, the fact that even the smallest detail has been rounded off beautifully...astounding place.

GORGEOUS VENUE. Another Gaudi design! Creative genius. Take the tour of this fabulous building. Don't miss the undulating roof with its whimsical chimneys. Again, the use of materials is mind blowing- elegant, intimate and warm.

For tourists. It will cost you 15 Euros so be sure to be a sightseeing fan. Nice view from the top but if you want architecture you can just walk the streets because the whole of Barcelon is one big architectural dream

Insane architecture, amazing. From top to bottom, this building is amazing. The lines, curves, the movement of the walls, the colors and the "alien" rooftop overlooking the ciudad condal (Barcelona), is absolutely breathtaking. This is a masterpiece that one must not miss.

I'm the Dissenter Here. We loved Palau Guell, Casa Batllo and La Sagrada Familia. Pure genius. This one however, left us cold. The tour starts on the roof, with the typical Gaudi features, which were interesting but nothing more and possibly something less than at Battlo, or at Guell, and far far less than at Sagrada Familia. Next, one walks through an attic space that was, in essence, nothing. It is in sharp contrast to Battlo or Guell, each of which had hundreds of perfectly executed unique new ideas in the actualization of the design. The next step is through the apartment, where one looks at the old furniture in the rooms. interesting enough, but not designed by Gaudi. The moldings were about the only features of Gaudi note. Finally, as one reaches the bottom floor, staff tells you there is nothing here. That isn't quite true, as there is an interesting foyer on the way out. All in all, this was much much less of an event to us than the other 3 Gaudi destinations listed above. We did not think this was remotely in their same ballpark. If you don't have time for all of them, make this the one you skip.
beautiful, fun, inspirational. The most unique, modern, fun house I have ever seen! If your in Barcelona, you NEED to go here!
Fabulous. There is abuzz of excitement on the street all around Casa Mila. Nice gift shop, too.
Priceless. Great experience, a definite must see when visiting Barcelona. Don't forget to stop by Casa Batllo a little further down the street which is just as great.

Beautiful but over priced and long waiting. The building is beautiful and worth seeing. We thought though that they charged too much to get in for what you see. Also we went on a Monday when most museums were shut so the line was very long and it took like 40 minutes to get in.

Gaudi does it again. Arrived before opening one morning but already a queue, compounded by one of the ticket machines not working so a considerable delay, tour groups were also given priority. Nonetheless, it was worth waiting for, Gaudi a master architect & well ahead of his years, his design not out of place today with many tasteful environmental considerations. Why does Barcelona have all the great attractions, could easily spend a month here to see everything.
Gaudi. Great place to see Gaudi's work. There wasn't a long line to enter, but it might depend on time of year, we went in May

Awesome example of very creative design by Antoni Gaudi. Wonderful example of Antoni Gaudi's work. Go early to avoid the crowds. Well worth the price. The roof is unbelievable! The Casa Battlo by Gaudi is also very good but the La Pedrera has a more traditional interior. The attic was wonderful. No wonder it is a UNESCO World Heritage Site! Don't miss it!
Another Gaudi work. i was on a Gaudi tour .and out of all his work this was the one I like the least.. i loved all others much better specially Casa Batllo
wow. had a private guide with us -- be sure to have Art Card to miss lines and try to go early. lots of steps but i think there is an elevator available.

Not as impressed as with Casa Battlo. If you only want to see one Gaudi house, go to Casa Battlo, where you can visit much more of the house. In Casa Mila you go up about 5 floors, then see the attic (which is indeed absolutely gorgeous) and then go on the roof, which for me was a let down, and then an apartment, which for me was very unimpressive. Skip the audio guide, unless you want to hear everything about Casa Battlo, Gaudi's life, Sagrada, Park Guell, and only very little information about La Pedrera itself, which I found very strange...

Pricey Ticket, but Money Well Spent. We used our Barcelona Card to get a discount. I found the entire tour facinating. Take you time, Go on a day when the weather is nice, because the roof is a highlite.

OK,. In retrospect, I wished I had skipped this Gaudi attraction and done something else (like spend more time in the Bari Gotic). I loooove architecture, but after the Sagrada and Casa Batlio, this was a letdown. If you have more time and want to see all Gaudi, do this FIRST, then Batlio then Sagrada. You'll see a better progression of his thinking and refinement of his ideas.
Differant. One of the great barcelona wonders. Children may get a bit bored at a young age. BIG QUEUES during day.

Love the rooftop!. My favourite place was the rooftop. Really eccentric curves, also you get to see the Barcelona skyline. You'll also get to see an exhibition of Gaudi's works, learn about his history... as well as climb flights of stairs. Lovely place to explore, though I wish more floors were open to visitors.
Excellent. Excellent GAUDI building.Book a ticket online to avoid queuesVisit the roof and stay there!!!!
La Pedrera. Amazing works by Gaudi,cannot miss,people need more orientation to not to miss this area

Don't rush through it like me.. We arrived an hour before closing. We were able to go to the roof, but we rushed through the attic and residence. I would spend the 15 euros to do it properly. What an awesome structure.

The strangest roof in the world?. Prepare yourself for a weird and wonderful experience on the roof of La Pedrera (the quarry) - you will have never seen anything like it before! Take time to study the models in the loft museum to learn what an extraordinary engineer Gaudi was - and well ahead of his time.
This is the best Gaudi did!. If there isone Gaudi MUST, this is it! Take the tour. He did this 100 years ago!! It was built for the Mila family and iscalled Pedrera, which means quarry.

Note: Review from outside view only. We didn't go in to La Pedrera/Casa Mila but we did walk past it on the way from Sagrada Familia to La Rambla. We decided to take this route so we could catch a view/snap a few shots of La Pedrera on the way past.I know that Barcelona is pretty much 'all about Gaudi' but if you also plan to take a detour without going in to La Pedrera - it isn't really worth it. It is interesting, but being in front of it doesn't give it any of the justice that the many photographs of it on the internet provide.Please read other peoples reviews regarding the inside/roof/attraction is though before deciding whether to go or not because I can't help there. Not something I'd go out of my way just to snap the outside though.

Go here before Sagrada Familia, to better understand Gaudí's work. Great show of Gaudí's genius. I would recommend taking the full tour with the audio guide to better understand the techniques used by Gaudí. Go here before heading to Sagrada Familia cathedral, as the tour will take you through several of Gaudí's works and will help you understand the cathedral better.
Brilliant. Gorgeous looking building, Gaudi knew how to capture the imagination, not to be missed.

Photographer's dream. This house was just beautiful. The rooftop was amazing - you could spend hours photographing up here. Arrive early and go in dry weather as if it rains, rooftop will not be open.

Gaudi's best. Expect a line to view Casa Mila, but it's the top Gaudi attracting in Barcelona. There are three separate areas to experience, and all are outstanding. The rooftop offers views over the city with Gaudi's fantastical chimney shapes; the attic shows Gaudi's amazing engineering skills; and the apartment is an unparalleled look into early 20th century life in the apartment house. Well worth a visit.

No apartment for rent :-(. Had to decide which Gaudi building to enter. These properties are expensive (15 euros each, casa batllo is 18.75). We were not disappointed. The roof structures are an amazing example of how to make beauty of the ugly. The apartment that you can wander through makes you want to sign a lease :-). The attic holds models of Gaudi's work showing what a genius he was.

La Pedrera by night, Magic experience!. During the day the lines were huge, so we reconsidered the possibility of coming back at night the next day. We booked in advance and had our reservations, so, no lines! That gave us more time during the day to see other sites, or just eat:). Not every day they have this night tour in every language so you better check as soon as you get to Barcelona if you want to take this tour.The cost is double but it's sure worth it. The guided night tour has sound and video effects. They treat you with Caba wine and cookies but the Warriors terrace, night lighten... The quietness and the breeze together with the light effects t's the highlight of the night tour.Worth every euro!
Not to be missed. Very interesting, don't miss the terrace! be prepared for long queues thou, best to go there very ealy or late in the evening. Quite expensive.
Very nice. I don`t have many words to say about it , only going there to see. Wonderful !

First time visit. Though I've been to Barcelona several times this was the first time to visit La Pedrera. I didn't allow enough time on the visit and want to go back to spend much more time in the Attic studying all the wonderful material it contains. I feel that I understand Gaudi a bit better after spending a good deal of time here. I shall be back.

An incredible fantasy. My last day in Spain and I wanted to try to see as much Gaudi as possible.Gaudi's reputation was built on several old buildings throughout the city and this apartment building on Passeig de Gracia is a fantastical work .Also known as Casa Mila, it has a striking facade, elaborate wrought-iron balconies & a troop of giant chimney pots that look like multi-coloured medieval knights. Definitely worth the cost. The amazing courage of Gaudi's patrons is to be lauded & Barcelona must be praised for maintaining the Gaudi legacy and making it available for others.
Gaudi at his best!. Magnificent, fantastic creation, one of the top 3 attractions in beautiful Barcelona.

the most magnificent place. we thought we were Gaudi'd out and almost didn't go to Casa Mila - what a mistake that would have been, this was a highlight of Barcelona and an brilliant experience. We are not architectural buffs and you don't have to be to really enjoy the brilliance of Gaudi

Okay, at best. Perhaps you just get to the point where you think that any building designed by Antoni Gaudi is going to charge admission, but I'm not convinced that this needs to be on your short list of Barcelona must-see items. The outside is very cool looking and you see lots of people touring the roof so you buy in. The inside has sort of a museum set-up which leads to a lengthy staircase (6 stories?) to get up to the roof. The roof is unique and bordering on weird but doesn't offer enough to justify the entry fee. Unless you have a lot of time in Barcelona (and some extra money) you should take some photos of the outside of La Pedrera - and move on.

Great house but shame the staff were not more helpful. We went at 7pm so there were no queues. The member of the staff on the door was helpful in warning us it closed in an hour and they normally allow 1.5 hours for a visit. We decided to visit as we wanted to see the roof, especially with few people. We were directed out from the ticket office and then spent several minutes trying to find the access to the roof as no staff were helpful in telling us where to go! We went to the roof which was stunning especially in the setting sun which showed off the chimneys beautifully. There were few people on the roof so there was no queuing to get a good photo. We then went down to the attic space which had lots of exhibitions, we spent little time there as we wanted to look at the flat,although the inside of this was lovely. The flat was very interesting. We manged it in the hour.

Another example of the work of a GENIUS!. Another Gaudi must see. A bit annoying that they are charging 14Euro entrance fees + an additional 4Euro for the audio guide, when this is owned by one lf the largest banks. To compare, Casa Baillot that is owned and run by a private family charge 18.15Euro per person including the audio guide.

Gaudi's genius.. Queues are quite long but worth the trouble. The house is like a time capsule of Gaudi's life, with each room authentically furnished by Gaudi. The interior is so spacious and airy, but it is the rooftop that takes your breath away.Huge, glazed chimney stacks, steps and archways ,give a beautiful view of Barcelona, including the Sagrada. Such an imagination to create this house. I haven't even mentioned the magnificent exterior, which has to be seen to be believed. Altogether incredible.

Very interesting interior. On prior visits to BCN, I have seen Casa Mila, but had never gone inside until this time. They offer group tours of the interior, and explain the structure, history, development and the current state of the building.Very interesting and definitely worth doing - shouldn't take more than 2-3 hours.

Excellent tour, beautiful building. I wish I could have an apartment in this unique place! Truly makes one appreciate Gaudi and his sense of whimsy. The building is very well taken care of, and the tour lets you see an apartment, the roof with its sentinel statues, and the breathtaking atrium.

Disappointing after seeing Casa Batilo. Apart from the fantastic chimneys on the roof and the great exterior, the interior of this house was a huge disappointment after seeing Gaudi's Casa Batilo which was astonishing. If you have to make a choice between the two, choose Casa Batilo.

A Gaudi Masterpiece. The B&B we stayed in during our one week holiday in Barcelona was a mere 10-minute walk to Casa Mila. So we got to see this amazing house of Pedro Mila & his family everytime we strolledalong Passeig de Gracia southbound toward La Rambla. Cas Mila is not just modernistic but futuristic as well. Antoni Gaudi was way ahead of his time. The design of Casa Mila is like a huge rock carved in waves with no straight lines. Incredible work of the genius Gaudi. The exterior is covered in stones in their natural color. This is why the Catalans called it La Pedrera or 'the quarry'. The windows, balconies & staircases are made with exquisite wrought iron work. The visionary Gaudi combined art nouveau and expressionist style. Casa Mila is a 'must see' in Barcelona.
Awesome. It's Gaudi, you know it's worth a look. Fabulous. You cannot go to Barcelona and not enjoy one of the cities greatest gifts, his architecture.
Interesting apartment block. Very good but if you are tight for time on the Gaudi trail I would recommend you saw Casa Batilo or Sagrada Familia first.

Surreal and beautiful. Casa Mila is a true masterpiece of Gaudi expression that must be seen and experienced. From the ghostly roof to the arched attic to the beautiful custom interior appointments there is so much to take in that you could spend hours here marvelling at his genius (or perhaps some might say madness?). A must-see!
Astonishing roof. Amazing chimneys and great views over the city. This is an "Exit Through The Gift Shop" Building.
A must see in Barcelona. From my point of view start with Casa Mila, then go to Batllo, they are both charming places to visit

Stunning view from the Top, Harbor & Sagrada Familia in sight. This preserved architectural building was the work and home of Gaudi when he was still alive, from the looks of the different structure on the roof depicting plants to the overall architecture itself. But the admission is over the top, 16euros per person was really expensive and I won't see it as worthwhile for these attraction as what is displayed on the lower floors could be viewed from the La Sagrada Familia Church itself for free, but if you have the Art pass as mentioned, you gain free entry wby skipping the que as well.Start of from the roof top and work your way down as the roof garner the scenic view of much of Barcelona

Very good Experience.. we took the stairs all the way to the top. Don't do it. Use the elevator. Good views of the city and Sagradia Familia from the roof top. Don't miss seeing the apartment. This is a part of ARTICKET! You don't have to stay in the line.

Stunning example of Gaudi's architecture. An extremely well preserved and presented example Gaudi's architecture. A tour includes the roof, with whimsical shapes used for mundane things like chimneys and air vents; the attic, featuring masonry catenary arches supporting the roof and including many exhibits; and a typical apartment. Lines were fairly long, but apparently you could skip the line with an Arts Barcelona ticket (which we didn't have).
Just OK. Glad we visited to see the roof but the rest was a little boring.

once again, genius shines. it's hard to believe all this came from the mind of one genius but each place is more impressive than the last. No bearing walls??who could come up with that so many years ago. Just beautiful.

Architectural waves. La Pedrera is, in my opinion, the No.1 must see in Barcelona.Gaudi's architecture is hard to find.  Casa Mila is a great example of Gaudi's art and offers great views of the city.I think tickets where expencive, though!
Best part is the outside. We loved the outside of this building. Inside was interesting but not the best of Gaudi. Glad we took a peek in though just to see the roof top...amazing!
La Pedrera. Looking at the building, reminds me of the waves of the sea. I find it fascinating. You will have to stop and look closely to appreciate its ingenius built.

Gaudi... always Gaudi.... He found incredible ways to solve the problem of cold in the winter and hot in the summer, and also to get natural light in the whole house. It is an environment-friendly house much before anybody talked about this!!
A masterpiece. How can one man without computers design such amazingly beatiful buildings. the roof terrace has to be seen to be beleived.
Stunning visit!. Again, this is one worth getting out of bed for. We arrived at 9.15 and were almost the only one's on the rooftop! Magic! The flat is amazing too!

Gaudi's fevered dream made real. Well worth the money and the time, you can actually see an apartment just as it was furnished in Gaudi's time. Maybe not our modern taste but utterly fascinating to see. Of course the roof and the chimneys are incredible and not to be missed - especially fun is the view to Sagrada Familia in the distance - but for me the REAL don't miss is the attic where there are wonderful displays that explain how Gaudi created the sensuous angles and motifs that fill his work. Long before the computer and with just his mind and his hands he created these amazing masterworks of architecture. Incredible to think he died by being run over by a tram, then lay unidentified for days before dying, unknown and unclaimed. He sought to give glory to his God with his work and so he did, to our delight and wonder.
must go. not to miss and not to dedicate some time to admire Gaudi!

wonderful visit & Guide book/Map warning. Guide book/Map warning! More frequently you may hear this referred to as Casa Mila, however on our maps it was labeled as La Pedrera. This caused us a little confusion when we went to visit the sight, but just be aware of how your guide books and maps label the location. It is definitely worth a visit.The highlight of the building is the rooftop and the chimneys, however there is so much more to see. The things that makes this a really special visit is after the rooftop there is a full Gaudi exhibit in the attic, which details many of Gaudi's Barcelona buildings. There is also an apartment (complete with age appropriate decor) which you can walk through.

Oh, those chimneys!. This building is all about the roof. You get a glimpse of the inner courtyard before the tour begins on the roof. We wondered why the attic was important. That part of the tour (with the audio guide) was very informative and educational. The walk through the apartment was well done. The rooms were well appointed.

Very cool, the roof alone makes it worth it.. Because our day was planned around certain things we couldn’t go to Casa Mila first thing in the morning (which is what I would suggest doing b/c of the ticket line. I believe it opens at 9:00 a.m.) You can’t pre-purchase tickets online, which I’m a little surprised by, because both Sagrada Familia & Casa Batllo have that option and saved us tons of time. If they had this option I would change my review from a 4 to a 5.We got there around 11:00-11:30, and waited about 40 minutes to buy tickets – which really wasn’t that bad. We didn’t get the audio tour here.If you only have time for Casa Batllo or Casa Mila I’d choose Casa Mila. Rating all Guadi’s stuff in order of “must see” I’d say Sagrada Familia (we did the audio tour here), Guell Park, Casa Mila and Casa Batllo (also did the audio tour here (it’s part of the ticket if you want to go inside)) last.Getting there – Take the Metro to the Diagonal stop, both Casa Batllo & Casa Mila are on the same street

highlight are the chimneys!. as there are so many gaudi attractions and very limited money (!!), we decided to go to la pedrera. it was a long queue as we went after lunch. the best thing about this complex is the roof top where you get a decent view of surrounding areas and also get to see the interesting sculptures/ chimneys. it was really like being transported to a different, quirky world! the weather wasn't great, so it was a shame - it would have been so much nicer to spend time on the roof if the weather was glorious! the mock up of an apartment was interesting as it gave an insight into how some people might lived in the past. there was also a section which gave information on what was behind gaudi's thinking. the leaflet given wasn't very accurate as it mentioned a temporary exhibition hall but the way the visit was routed, we weren't actually given the opportunity to visit this space. part of the reason we chose to visit la pedrera was because it was always rated before casa batllo in guidebooks, however colours-wise, it does seem less dazzling than the latter. definitely worth going, esp if you're a gaudi fan.

The other Gaudi "must do". I think that one could spend many days in Barcelona just visiting Gaudi and Gaudi-influenced places. We didn't. But La Pedrera is in my mind the other "must do", along with La Segrada Familia. Architecturally it's quite amazing, but what really makes the visit great is the explanation (in the attic) of what was behind much of Gaudi's thinking. Really worthwhile visit.

Quite interesting. The Gaudi architecture is just a pleasure to experience and this site was quite interesting without being too much. There were crowds but they seemed well managed. My only issue was that it was a little hot inside.

Impressive. Firstly the queue to get it was huge so I'd advise that you buy tickets in advance. That way you get by-pass the queue. That applies to most attractions, including the Cathederal.Once inside you get a lift to the roof which is simply stunning. Not so much the view but the amazing chimneys designed by Gaudi.From there you descend into a museum and displays of how Gaudi desgined his works with a video of his life. Interesting stuff.Imo not as striking as Casa Batllo but for Gaudi fans a must visit.
Too expensive tickets. First of all..remember pre-book the tickets. Too expensive if you compare with other Gaudi buildings in Barcelona!!
Gaudí's work. One of the several Gaudí's buildings... This one was one of the first and it's interesting to visit. Nothing special, but really worths the visit!
Very imposing. A must see and just have a look at the contrasting architecture on the 4 corners of the junction.

Looking back to old times. Again, we timed it nice and went early, so we didn't have to queue a long time. Casa Mila is a mind blowing house with all it's forms, colors and furniture, we were surprised to find something we also have at home! One got a very good picture of how it looked like in a wealthy family's home many years ago. The museum of how this house was created was interesting. The best part though was the rooftop. A simple maze with amazing forms and funny statues, it was like in a fantasy city! And on top of that, you had a beautiful view on the rest of the city from many angles. Do visit!

Give it the time it deserves.. Another of Gaudi's amazing buildings. We went for an hour and stayed over 3! Time slips by as you are drawn into his vision ... theatrical, mystical and functional. The joy of being in Barcelona was enhanced by Gaudi's architecture. We look forward to the next time.
Extraordinary!. A brilliant work by Gaudi. There's too much to describe, but a self guided recorded tour explains the architect's genius.

Very well set-up as an attraction. Although there were heaps of people there, the house has been well-managed so that it doesn't feel crowded. It's worth paying the extra for the self-guided headset tour. Great gift shop.
Great if you go early. Go in the morning - when it first opens. You have time and peace to enjoy the apartment building and there will be no lines!! It's great!

Stunning example of Gaudi's work... Third time I have visited the building and it is still inspirational. Do take time to look at all the Gaudi history exhibits in the loft, as they really show how ahead of his time he was. The new apartment that is open is superb too.

One of my favorite spots in Barcelona. We almost skipped this gem. So glad we didn't. The rooftop isn't overly crowded, which is part of the appeal. The architecture is incredible and you can take great photos.
A great building by Gaudi. Almost as good as Casa Batlló. The chimneys at the roof are really cool. You can easily spend an hour or two here. Gaudi is a genius!

Beautiful building.. I visited this build before casa batillo. So this was the first Gaudí's creation I visited. A very beautiful building. Must see the roof. But for me I think casa batillo is more impressive...
Looked worth it. Unfortunately we were unable to get in as the queues were way too long and gutted because of it. This looked superb. Tip - PRE-BOOK your tickets.

Impressive construction. We only saw the exterior of La Pedrera. Would have liked to go inside as well as the Casa Batlo, but only 4 days in Barcelona is not enough to see everything this beautiful city has to offer.

the 40 min audio guide is terrible. If you get an audio guide dont get the 40 mins one as its very basic and a lot of wasted time.
Rather get the full guide (u need to choose which to get at entrance)

Unique!. I have only seen the outside of La Pedrera - a visit to the inside is on my list of things to do when I am in Barcelona again. The building made me want to reach out and touch it. The design is completely unique. And all the tiles on the sidewalks around the building were designed by Gaudi, as well as those beautiful mosaic benches that are the base for the wrought iron lamp posts. This is a beautiful building, well worth a visit.

Amazing Gaudi -- and you can avoid the queue. There's not much to add about La Pedrera that hasn't already been said. It's a beautiful building -- a wonderland of design. The tour now takes you to the roof, the attic (where there are extensive displays and explanations), one of the apartments and (when we went) part of the main floor (owners') apartment which housed a temporary exhibition. You get to see a lot, and it's all beautiful and amazing.The queue begins early and can get quite long. However, La Pedrera is included in the 30 Euro Barcelona Articket (which also covers the Miro and Picasso museums as well as the National Art Museum of Catalonia (MNAC) -- which is itself a gem) and if you have an Articket you can enter by a separate entrance (just east of the main public entrance on Provenca) and skip the queue.We picked up a book on La Pedrera from a local bookstore before we visited and that helped a lot -- we had a basic understanding of the significance of much of what we were seeing and knew some things to look for. But even without any advance preparation this is a very interesting place to see.

Interesting architecture. Given that Gaudi states that nothing in nature is a straight line, this building exemplifies that maxim and fascinates the viewer, especially of interest to me was the incredible glazing and the windows, the shapes & designs inherent in the oevrall aspect of the building. Inspirational, amazing and unrepeatable, Gaudi's creations are as unique cakes, one-off designs born of genius and creativity, yet possessing an underlying practicality. Enjoy.
Gaudi:). Worth the metro trip to see another unique, Gaudi masterpiece! I love the wavey brickwork, modern wrought iron balconies and ALL!
Glad it rained. We went looking for something to get out of the rain and luckily chose Casa Mila. Very nice

Apartment to die for!. Another example of Gaudi being ahead of his time. This large apartment is decorated in period furnishings. Great views from the room top; you get an understand of the architecture from the visit to the attic where there are audio/visual presentations. Wonderful to see that this building is still thriving and occupied on this beautiful boulevard.

Futuristic roof the highlight. Well worth visiting, especially to see the amazing roof sculptures. However, there is a huge queue to get into this place, caused not just by lots of people wanting to visit the masterpiece that it is, but because Barcelona tourism think it is appropriate to have one ticket seller in operation! Get there early!

Fantastic roof top and views. Beautiful building. Thoughtful staff helped us around with a pram, although roof was not for toddlers. Try to go early or late to get best views, light, photos and avoid queues.

Guadi in Barcelona. Why are there not more unique designers coming through in the 21st Century? Gaudi was way ahead of his time and others haven't followed. What an amazingly imaginative yet practical genius!!

Don't miss the roof. Though an apartment building since built, with only one floor open for touring, there is still alot to see. See it first, then Casa Batllo and The Palau de la Musica Catalana. This building will prime you. The Roof rivals that of Casa Battlo in a apace alien look.

Another great work of Guadi's. Created in 1906. Famour rooftop with lots of mosiacs, steps, different levels. Open from 9am-8pm. It's 15 Euros, the line was 30minutes long and we only stayed 1 hour. I liked the Casa Batllo much more.

Fantasy building. One of the most spectacular buildings of Genius Gaudy. When you see it you can feel and understand why all the architects from our century should learn from Gaudy and study his work.Beautiful and evening too the lights make it seem like flowing.To avoid the big Q book online and walk the all street it is worthed. Iven if you have seen Casa Ballto this is something diferent. The Italians shuld be proud of the way Gaudy has use the clasical mosaique and made it pice of Art in this stunning building.
Looked interesting. We didn't visit the indoors but you can enjoy the facade if you decide to walk from Casa Batllo to Sagrada Familia (it's a nice and quite short walk).
La Pedrera. Another House (among many) built in Barcelona by Gaudi and is also worthing a visit when in Barcelona!!
Unique structure. Go early! I was there before 9am and there was a line up already!

Lives up to expectations. If you enjoy architecture and Gaudi, don't miss this museum. Go early to avoid large crowds. Buy the Barcelona museum pass - if you go to this and two other museums minimum it's worth it and you bypass some lines. Bring your camera, this is amazing
You Know You're In Barcelona. when you get to the Roof of Casa Mila! Truly amazing, not just the visuals, but that everything is functional! One of the highlights of our visit to Barcelona!
Fascinating. A well presented example of Gaudi's work that gives a good flavour of what it must have been like to have lived there.
A must see!. A beautiful example of Gaudi's architectural genius - from the 'soldier' chimney pots right down to the foyer.Do not go to Barcelona without seeing this wonderful building!!
Another Gaudi marvel!. We waited in line a fair amount but it was wotrh it to see the architecture and hear about his philosophy. A must see!!!
Beautiful architecture. If you love history and architecture it is worth a visit! Neat photo opportunity from roof-top!
Very enjoyable. Great introduction to Gaudi. Very nice gift shop as well.
Very informative. I actually thought the tour for this site was better than Sagrada FAmilia. This is another must see in Barcelona

Gaudi's residential vision. Beautifully done apartment bloc. Interiors gave a good glimpse of the sophisticated lifestyle of Barcelona's population at the turn of the century. Rooftop views of the city are wonderfully panoramic, and it's just fun to walk around the Gaudi Modernista designs.

Genius. Did not know what to expect but was absolutely amazed by Gaudi's architectural genius, especially at the roof/terrace. Imagine living in this apartment, it would've been fantastic. Queues were well managed and so it did not seem crowded inside. Arrive early to avoid queues for tickets.

well worth a visit.. This building is fantastic! Take the lift to the roof and work your way back down...the roof is quite vertigo inducing and I felt a bit wobbly going towards the edge of the roof as some parts are quite low! having said that it's beautiful and well worth seeing. As you go back down through the building the apartment is furnished as it would have been when it was built and is very interesting. The courtyard is also beautiful and the whole building is just one big photo opportunity. Headphone commentary gives you lots of information on each part of your journey throughout the building.
Must at night. Magical at night when light up while taking evening stroll

A worthy visit. For me Casa Battlo is a better example of the breed, but the rooftop wanderings around Casa Mila are very much in the true spirit of Gaudi and a whole lot of fun. It's a business now though, so expect very serious lines and very serious staff. Not cheap, either.

Amazing style and well-presented. You get to start on the roof and work your way down. Well-explained and laid out. Interior of the flat interesting with brief introductory video. Again Articard helped you just long queues.

Lovely building. Not as nice as Casa Batllo, the rooftop and attic space are really worth seeing, the rest of the building I wandered through quickly, was nice but not worth the 19euro fee which was more expensive than Casa Batllo
Build with an imagination that is beyond many of us. Go early morning or late afternoon so that the light at the rooftop terrace is at its best and the lines are shortest.

Gaudi on a human scale. What would it look like if the man behind Park Güell and La Sagrada Familia put his mind to a housing block? The answer is Casa Mila - also known as 'The Quarry' or La Pedrera because of the huge amount of stone it took to build the place. The promise of the facade is kept by its contents 100%. An interesting museum that shows how Gaudi worked, what his influences were and how much he cared about creating environments that make humans feel comfortable. There's also art gallery spaces that were closed when we visited and excellent audio guides that you shouldn't miss. Oh, and there's a six floor climb right at the start of the museum so here's hoping you're in reasonable shape...

Gaudi's genius in action. Get here early or late - it can get very busy at peak periods during the day. Am amazing house full of great architectural elements. Even if you are not 'big into buildings' go along and you may be surprised how this one has something about it.

Pure Guadi. Like the title says, this is a Guadi as it gets. Must see place for anyone remotely interested in architecture. I didn't get as excited about it as I was expecting to, but I don't hesitate at all in recommending it to anyone visiting Barcelona. Best of the Guadi homes though I still lean heavily towards La Sagrada Familia and Parc Guell as my top Guadi sites.
Gaudi`s masterpiece. I prefer Casa Mila rather than Sagrada Familia, because this is a pure Gaudi`s style. The entry fee is still a bit overpriced, but in this case it is worth to spend it.

A little dissapointed. This stop was pretty neat, and the rooftop is incredibly artistic. You can definitely tell that Gaudi had fun with this one.The admission price was very high for what you got to see - I believe around 16 Euros per person, which was around what we paid to get into the Sagrada Familia. If you must do both, do this one first - otherwise you'll feel like you didn't get your money's worth.
Disappointed. Queues were very long and charges high so we gave this one a miss - sadly.
Worth the queue for the rooftop alone. Gets really busy, but the rooftop and chimneys are a mustPark Guell is a free and less busy alternative to see similar artistry by Gaudi

Worth the wait. We spent a morning seeing La Pedrera. When we arrived, it was pretty obvious which building we were headed for - the outside of the building was unlike any other building around it, and the line wrapped around the street corner.It took about 20 minutes to get our ticket and enter, and we felt a little lost inside (which way were we supposed to go?), but once in, it was very cool to see the architectural vision of Gaudi. There is an apartment open to walk through, and the attic and rooftop are worth the climb or the wait for the elevator. Bring your camera! I don't recall what the entrance fee was, but I do recall thinking it wasn't a bad price.
Amazing roof terrace!. This place is beautiful, it is better value than many attractions as there is such a lot to see for the Gaudi enthusiast.

Tour Guide Highly Recommended It. Views from the top are amazing! You can even see Sagrada Familia in the distance. The apartment tour was wonderful; would've loved to be able to see more than a couple floors of the building. Definitely worth seeing!

The one to see. If you have to choose the one to see, this is it. It is amazing inside and out and the roof top was out of this world. The secret to this visit was to get there before they are open and the tourist crowd. We got there at 9:45 a.m. and I think they open at 10.We walked right in, got our tickets and were on the roof top within 5 minutes to take in morning air and Barcelona skyline.

Amazing design. Gaudi's designs for this apartment building are fascinating and unlike any others. Getting the Artticket let us skip the line and go in through the group entrance, which saved a lot of time.

Wonderfully weird and unmissable. The epitome of Modernista architecture is this weird but stunning apartment building. Particularly unusual is the rooftops with the chimneys that look like a cross beetween extra-terrestials and Easter Island staues. Try not to visit when it's raining heavily as they close the rooftop space. Queues are usually long so allow plenty of time for a visit.

Wonderful on the roof. This was one of my favourite places in Barcelona. We had to join a long queue to get in, but it was worth it.There are over 200 steps to climb when you first go in, but then you are in a magical world out on the roof terrace. We just loved exploring this, with its strange chimneys and features. There are also good views of the neighbourhood.As well as the roof terrace, there is an exhibition and an old apartment to explore, but the roof terrace is definitely the star of the show.
Another Gaudi-ism. His strange work never let's the eye down! Must see.
out of this world. Its not everyday you get to see a place like this, so make sure you visit! The roof is out of this world and I loved seeing Gaudi's inspiration from nature.

Unbelievable apartment. Our private tour guide said the apartments rent for something like 6000 Euros a month. Be sure to go see this apartment you can visit, but be CERTAIN you book online to jump the queue! It's a little difficult to figure out, so have your hotel help you. It's some Caixa social club site. At the very end of our trip....we realized we should have bought a pass for 30 Euros at the Picasso museum or wherever else they are sold. The pass is well worth the money. I'm guessing it will let you ignore the long lines. It does at the Picasso Museum, but I'm not certain at La Pedrera.

Not just a rooftop. This is rated as one of the top places to see in Barcelona and rightly so. Stunning on the rooftop and the attic display. You will have to wait but it was not long. Best time to view has to be after 5/6 when the shadows start to lengthen for more dramatic photographs. Yes, it can get a little busy and there may be a body in the shot you want to take but be patient and you will be rewarded.
rooftop!. I could see Sagrada familia from here. the rooftop is amazing, chimneys are huge and beautiful. pathways around add even more to it. could have stood there all day.
Well worth a visit. What a fantastic place. Prebook your tickets to save you having to queue for hours.
One of a kind. At least stop by and take in this one of a kind house.
Superb. Beautiful, the roof terrace is a joy to behold. the attic space gives a fascinating insight into the designs and thought processes of the architect.

Interesting But Expensive. The terrace is worth seeing but I am not sure about the value. The entrance charge is 15 Euros and I think it is little too expensive for the place. They say that they allow visitors till 6:30 but once you reach the terrace they only give you 5 minutes before you have to start heading down. So if you plan on spending that 15 Euro i would say spend it during the earlier part of your day.

exiting!!. Unique!amazing the roof terrace!full of Gaudi sculpture..interesting as well the explanations of the interpretations of Gaudi..and simply exiting the flat where you can go inside and visit all the rooms icluding the old fornitures of the house!!i loved it!!!!!!!!!!
WORTH THE PRICE OF ADMISSION. Super! You'll want to linger on the rooftop. Gaudi was a genius!

Roof terrace is best bit!. I loved the attention to detail throughout, but the apartment was not so exciting to see. The best place in the whole visit was the roof terrace, with the uniquely shaped chinneys. Indoor courtyard is definitely worth visiting.
Gaudi apartment amazing. If you are interested in Gaudi's architecture and development this is the place to see. We saw the apartment and the attic, both extremely interesting.

Worth it just for the roof - the best of Gaudi. People seem to love or loathe Gaudi, but surely you cannot fail to be impressed by just how different he is. For me, what sets Casa Mila apart is the attention to detail everywhere in its design - from the metalwork outside the windows to the interiors of the appartment and the vaulting in the attic ceiling. And that is before you get to the roof!!! Then you will see what people rave about - its just, well, totally different to anything you will have seen.
