Kind of like a fairy castle for adults!The entry fee is expensive, however.... see if you can go early or buy online. The Casa Batllo, Casa Mila/Pedrera and the Sagrada Familia will set you back over Euros 45 in total to see - NOT cheap! I would also start with Sagrada Familia, because I think the museum and exhibits there offer the best explanation of Gaudi's influences and upbringing, setting the scene for visits to the houses.

Great roof. This building has a great roof and quaint little apartement to see. Do not wait in lines, ask to buy Art ticket (30€ per person, price reduced from 64€). Art ticket includes visits to 7 locations, and all locations have separate entrance without lines. One of the locations is La Pedrera.

Doesn't Worth the money. If you adore Gaudi....go...if u don;t.....don;t bother.....19 Euros for some view and an appartment....and 1 hour of waiting in queu......you should better have 3 bottles of Vino de la Casa near by.

Possibly the most bonkers roof in the world!. From below, Casa Mila looks merely interesting. It's only when you get up on the roof that you discover what everybody raves about. The design is fabulous and, in my opinion, completely mad!The views from the top are great, but it is the layout that is jaw-dropping.This is another of Gaudi's works of genius and is well worth the visit.The Gaudi exhibition and apartment below are also rather interesting.

An unique masterpiece. this highly innovative and brilliant construction is a must see for all who love the Art nouveau. The building itself has a single undulating free standing façade whose sinuous rhythms are echoed inside as well and the Pedrera apartment on the fourth floor is a typical bourgeois apartment from the first third of the 20th century.
Interesting. Good background information and explanations about this strange but clever piece of architecture.
Another amazing building!. The queues were horrendous and it was raining too!So much so, we decided to give the interior and roof a miss and come back another time..

Great Gaudi Museum. It was well worth the 30 minute wait. You could spend many hours there. The roof top has great views all the way to Sagrada Familia. All the rooms are furnished with furniture and items of that time period.

Pretty cool place. Ok, if you don't like architecture, or cool buildings, don't bother. The entrance fee is a little steep,butnotas much as Casa Batlo down the street. There is a lot to see, and the rooftop is not to be missed. The attic of the building has a great exhibit about the design of Gaudi.
Surprising!. My education about Ghaudi was only just beginning and I think this is probably a good one to start on. Surprising how ahead of his time Ghaudi was in his artisitic freedom of thinking...

Interesting design, cool view from roof. Gaudi designed apartments with no straight lines, unique concept. Thought this was a little expensive for what you saw and preferred Casa Battlo and Parc Guell over this.

Worth the visit!. We bought the ARTICKET NCB for 30 € and had access to seven museums in the city, some of which deserve to visit.Casa Mila is included in this ticket and with this ticket you don't have to wait to enter. Just go to the main entrance and after showing your tickets you're in!Audioguide is essential if you want to understand a little bit more about the construction of the monument.
Unique building you can't afford not to visit. Absolutely stunning building that you would be mad to miss whwen in Barcelona and it's literally 4 blocks away from Casa Batllo on Passeig de Gracia.
architecture at it's finest!. At first Casa Mila feels a bit of a disappointment after Casa Batilo, but the roof and the attic is pure genius. Enough to inspire anyone to want to become an architect.
Cool to look at, wouldn't go out of my way for it. If you're a serious Gaudi fan, go for it. Otherwise work it into your plan if you are interested in something else and it's on the way.

Spectacular roof - long ques. Waited in line for a really long time to get in. Really cool roof and posterior design - the apartment is less wow. There is a really weird film showing without sound. Come early to avoid the lines, and skip the movie.
Casa Batlo is much more special. You see this is a Gaudi work, but to be honest, the Casa Batlo was so much more special than this one (on the outside).

One of Gaudi's Masterpieces. The architecture is impressive and spectacular... I didn't bother going up there as there were way too many people willing to go to the top roof, where you can have a great view of the city. I don't know if you have to pay to get in, though.

Beautiful. I thought the entrance fee was a bit steep but the house is worth it. Being a great fan of Art Nouveau and Gaudí, I enjoyed the visit a lot, in spite of the many steps you have to take to reach the beautiful rooftop.

Spectacular roof, delight for photographers. Casa Mila is stunning and must for everyone who loves Gaudi and his mindblowing architecture. You will love the roof and its views, dont forget to take long lense with ur SLR camera.

Really cool.. The Casa Mila was a great experience. Gaudi designed this apartment building and due to its design has been called "La Pedrera", or the quarry. The unusual exterior design, rooftop chimney features, and the apartment set up for viewing are all great features.
Very nice. Only saw it from the outside, but it is amazing. And the walk trough Passeo de Gracia is also very nice!

Awesome place. This is another special Gaudi building. The roof is the most amazing aspect, and when do you say that about a building? There are still apartments in this building so you do not see much of it, but the roof is cool, the attic has a lot of educational displays about Gaudi and his time, and the apartment set in historical context is really interesting.
Strange and Beautiful. Could only go to certain levels of the casa which is understand because it has private apartments. However, this building is very strange but very beautiful.
MIXED USE PROPERTY DECADES AHEAD. The planning use of this property was imaginative and again the engineering was decades ahead.

Roof was great..... I loved the roof. I thought it was beautiful and really creative.In general I thought the place was overpriced and not that interesting. My husband and I purchased the audio guide because we had really found it beneficial at the other Gaudi sites (Sagrada Familia, Casa Battlo). So admission was 15 euro and the audio guide 4.The audio guide really just went over Gaudi's life and other woks...which we had already seen.I just felt like the whole place was very repetitious. Personally, I would skip this one.

Amazing roof. One of my regrets returning from Barcelona is that I did not focus more on Gaudi. His style is truly unique. La Pedrera has a good self-guided tour that allows you to really examine the architecture and design. When you recall the time this building was designed and constructed, it was so progressive.
special but overcrowded. Well... there is only one Gaudi. Another option to visit part of it is by going to a conference which are organized regularly by Caixa Catalunya.

Fun on the Roof. Wow, what a treat to actually be able to view the inside of an apartment in La Pedrera. But the highlight is walking the roof at sunset. The whimsical shaped chimneys will make a real Gaudi fan. Note: admission is included in the 6 museum ARTicket.
Living inside a mountain. Gaudi based his design as if you were living inside a rock. The architecture is extraordinary. It's a good activity for adults and children. Don't miss it!
Advanced architecture. What Gaudi did with interior space utilization is astounding given its age. Very well maintained and furnished in the period.
Conservative but only for a Gaudi. An amazing building but strangely conservative for a Gaudi. The gift shop on the bottom floor is one of the most tasteful around and has interesting crafts.
go around 6.30pm. If you go later on in the day you will get shadows on the rooftop and get great shots. Plus is less busy.

Amazing. Pay that fee and head straight to the roof! The walk up can be a bit tiring, although I am sure they have an elevator option for those who need it.But regardless it is definitely worth it. This roof is like nothing you have ever seen before and takes the cake when compared to the roof of Gaudi's other work, Casa Batllo, which is just down the street.Walked around the roof for a good hour or so, taking many beautiful pictures, and taking in the view and wonderful weather.

You either like it or hate it!. I hated this, I really disliked the whole structure and the roof terrace that snaked around etc, all I kept thinking was why build such a repulsive building? Why not finish what you started at the La Sagrada Familia? However my wife loved the building and experience of seeing the apartment furnished in the 1910 style, the roof terrace that snaked around and the furnishings.
Gaudi explained. Good exhibition showing and explaining how Gaudi worked. I would advise to start with this before seeing his other creations. Plus the view from the top is quite good.
another gaudi. not so colourfull like casa batlo, but deserves a visit !

An interesting immersion into Gaudi's style. We enjoyed visiting Casa Mila, and would recommend it. Also recommend taking the audio guide - it completes the visit and enriches the overall experience immensely. Inside you get to see: the roof with amazing unique sculpture-like chimneys and views of Barcelona, the attic with exposition about Gaudi's style and what influenced him, and an apartment which takes up a full floor and is furnished with furniture of the time when Casa was built. Experiencing the roof feels like exploring a new world - the chimneys are unique, the roof itself has different levels (with steps), and you can spend some time wandering around, enjoying the structure, overlooking Barcelona and peeking into the inner yards, appreciating how light penetrates the whole structure and how it all comes together in a single building. There are safety barriers, but you do have to watch your step. If you visit Sagrada Familia later - you will notice that some of the sculptures on the Passion Facade repeat the futuristic style of some of the chimneys. The apartment takes up the full floor and we enjoyed seeing how a well-to do family furnished their place and lived early in the 20th century - including the kitchen, bathrooms, living spaces, etc. A worthy visit. Cannot compare with Casa Batllo as we didn't visit it. Visiting Casa Mila together with Park Guell and la Sagrada Familia gave us a great understanding of Gaudi's work.
Interesting. Enjoyed the architecture and view into a very unique apartment.
Excellent tour!. Great experience to see a "living" Gaudi building. Especially interesting was the apartment!

Interesting. We visited this at night. Beautifully lit. We probably could have seen more detail in the daylight. At night, it's almost a little frightening. I prefer some of Gaudi's other work because it's more colorful, but this is still well worth seeing.

Breathtaking. The roof is amazing - I overcame my fear of heights to walk around most of it. The whole tour - apartment and attic were just fascinating - you can build 'ordinary' buildings in a very different way which completely transforms your experience
Amazing. Really amazing building. Better take the audio guide when you pay the ticket,because it explains everything and completes your visit.

La Pedrera. The rooftop is a must.It's not cheap, so if you're on a tight budget, I'd maybe leave this out.Nevertheless the house is beautiful, one of Gaudi's best in my opinion. I loved the early twentieth-century feel of the interior. What's more it's very central- though I missed it on my first visit as I thought the building was Santander bank which seems to share the same site!
Cumbrian Couples. Visit the roof and the apartments - rather expensive
Gaudi at his best. Fantastic architecture, especially the roof terrace. Definitely worth a visit. Great views. Apartment is fantastic. Wish I lived in it!
Excellent !. A real must when visiting Barcelona. Amazing natural forms brought through to architecture, decoration & furniture design. Unique. Interesting items for sale in the shop

amazing place to spend time and enjoy Gaudi. just a great place to see how gaudi thought and worked, creating an incredible monument to his ideas. breaking from tradition and experimenting with materials. well worth the entrance fee.

Definitely Worth a Look. Visited in March 2012 on a Sunday. Fairly busy but didn't wait in line for more than 15 minutes. A little on the expensive side but would definitely recommend. Roof is absolutely the best part. Has interesting sculptures and beautiful views, including one of La Sagrada Familia. There is an apartment for you to walk around and an exhibition hall but that is really all. We probably spent no more than an hour inside in total. Conveniently located off passeig de gracia, near a metro stop. Awesome baguette place about a block away!
Another work of art. Apartment building with tour and history of Gaudi. Worth the time.
Roof of delights.... The main attraction for me at Casa Mila was definitely the roof with it's enigmatic sculptures and ventilation shafts. Beautiful.

Striking example of Gaudi's vision. The line to buy tickets was over an hour long when we were there and still well worth it.Fortunately being in a group of 7 we could spell each other on line and go sit and have a refreshment in a nearby cafe. Gaudi's compete control over the design of ordinary objects, as well as structural and decorative construction elements is amazing. The walk inside the apartment on display, the interior views and perspective of the building, the attic area, and the roof are not to be missed. If nothing else, please do not miss going by and viewing the exterior.Do take pictures because it is beyond description.

Amazing - another Gaudi materpiece!. Walked around this place much like the Sagrada Familia, in complete awe of the materpieces and ingenious thoughts of Gaudi and his work. No right angles - and I would love to live in an appartment like that. A must see. if you are on the tourist blue/red routes dont forget to use your bus ticket to gain a discount to entry.

Fascinating contrast between the exterior and the interior. Last time I was in Barcelona I visited the roof of this fascinating building but did not have time to see the interior so this time I visited both. I love the outside of the building so I was a little disappointed to find the flat so ordinary. After seeing the inside of the Casa Batllo I had expected a similar style here in the Casa Mila. The way the flat was furnished would not have been out of place in any other building of the period. I found it strange that the people that lived here would have wanted such traditional interior when they lived in a build with wonderfully different façade and court yard. The roof is fantastic, but a little scary if you are as afraid of heights as I am. The views are stunning if like me you love photography you will spend hours taking pictures of the chimneys as the light changes. This is a fascinating place to visit and the exhibiton in the attic below the roof is well worth a visit. The exhibition includes a very interesting film documenting the building of the Casa Mila, which is defiantly worth a few minutes of your time. Unless you want to spend a lot of money, avoid the two gift shops. The same souvenirs are on sale all over Barcelona much cheaper.
Beautiful work of Gaudi, not to be missed. the view of the Sagrada Familia from the roof is amazing!
Sunset over Barcelona.. Ended up here late in the day & watched the sunset from the amazing rooftop. Very well done & a Gaudi masterpiece.

Lovely castle. The Casa Milà commonly referred to by locals, as La Pedrera, meaning quarry, because of its stone cliff-like appearance, is Antoni Gaudi’s vision of an urban apartment building. Taking up an entire city block in the fashionable Eixample district, with its pale wavy limestone facade and free form, wrought-iron balconies, the Casa Mila is one of the most visited Gaudi buildings after the Sagrada Familia. You have to get there. Students get a discount 11€ for a ticket instead of 14€. Going to the rooftop is a must !

Nice to see. If you visited Casa Battlo then you may not find this apartments interesting except for it's roof and attic which we enjoyed the most. The rooms were less magical than the Battlo. The tickets does not include Audio which you need to purchase for 4 Euros.If you are an art fan, it's better to take the Barcelona Art Card which give you 50% discount on the museums and these attractions which fairly a good deal.Enjoy!
wow. take the audioguide if you visite this place. The visit is incredible! You will undertand Gaudi with all the explanations during the visit! a must see!

Least decorative, but still interesting.. Climbing up 8 flights of curvy, narrowish stairwell made me a little motion sick, combined w/rooftop design--lots of curves, all very attractive but needed to sit for a while on level ground afterward.
expensive to get in.. We just looked from outside because it seemed very pricey.

a Barcelona icon; probably the most appealing of Gaudí's residential buildings. La Pedrera is a residential apartment building built in 1912 with a distinctive modernist sculpted façade which is among the must-see works of famed Catalan architect Antoni Gaudí. It is one of the architectural icons of Barcelona, prominently located on a corner of Carrer de Provença with the fashionable shopping street, Passeig de Gràcia.La Pedrera is well-located as a stage in a walking tour of Gaudí works in the centre of Barcelona, just 1.7km southwest of La Sagrada Familia. A pleasant and practical 4km "Gaudí walk" route is from La Sagrada Familia via Carrer de Provença to the Pedrera, then southeast down stylish, boutique-filled Passeig de Gràcia past Gaudí's Casa Batlló, through Plaza Cataluña and La Rambla, to Gaudí's extraordinary Palau Güell in the side-street Carrer Nou de la Rambla.Many interesting displays and exhibits were inside and accessible for the €7.50 per person entry ticket when we visited in February 2012. These included a display apartment; models Gaudi used to plan the design and engineering of the building; and access to the roof, where there are fine views and typical Gaudi decorative flourishes using mosaic tiles.
A Must See!. An amazing example of Gaudi's work - the roof is gorgeous. We went we our three small boys and they were mesmerized the entire time. Well worth a visit.
One of the best places to see in Barcelona!. This Gauid house is one of the best sites to visit. The roof of course is the best.

Don't miss it!. You will start with a ... Roof! be prepared - when the elevator door opens you will most surely be blinded by the sunshine! Be ready with your camera-yuo'd like to remember it and you will find great shots here. really! 2 other floors opened for the visitors are the Attic - a picturesque place, where you can study a lot of history (if you are interested, of course) and gain some rest for you surely tired legs :) Another floor restores the atmosphere of the beginning of 20th century, with all the atricles , furnishing and toys of that time.
Beautiful, especially if you like curves. Loved the colors and art nouveau! Especially the hardware
Overpriced and dull. Go to the other Gaudi homes -- Batto and Guell — they are far superior, more interesting and less expensive.

One more Gaudi – but a must. I was first amazed by La Pedrera when I saw Antonioni's 'The Passenger' and wanted to see it first hand ever since. When I finally got there, I was not disappointed. Visitors access the amazing roof with it's sentinal-like chimneys and curving shapes to find it strangely calming, even though it's hard to avoid being in someone else's photo.Downstairs you visit one of the apartments in close to original state. No simple 2-bedroom 1-bathroom job this! Two entrances, two lightwells, servants rooms, amazing balconies, and lots of light throughout. Some original decoration remains, along with lots of original and period furniture.Back to ground level is the gift shop – it's hard to leave without a few mementos.
Great views from the roof. Gaudy are not cheap to visit, but you have to do a few,this one is cool

If you saw enough gaudi, then don't go. Gaudi is amaizing, you never get enough form him, but for those can't feel the same and feel after a while that what enough is enough, then don't go. I loved it.
very good from the outside!!!!. i didn't go inside and can't tell my opinion for ...
Breath taking!. Gaudi was truly a genius and his designs are awe inspiring! There is nothing like it in the world and it is well worth a visit and the price of admission (to help maintain it).

Amazing Gaudi Property. Came to visit after spending time at another of Gaudi's works and was even more amazed at his creative genius. Well worth the entrance fee, and would strongly recommend the use of the audio guide. The rooftop is just stunning, who would have thought a chimney could look so good! The attic space is incredible too. The use of various architectural techniques is fabulous. And learned a lot more about Gaudi too from this visit.

BEAUTIFUL AND AMAZING HOUSE. Nobody should miss this visit of Gaudi's work.
Maravillosa casa! nadie debería perderse esta visita
Special Gaudi. Large building with very interesting roof. Absolutely woth visiting.
a looker. only saw it from the outside as we had little time. It is one of Gaudy's desings.
Even better than the Sagrada Familia. I fell in love with this building. Pure Gaudi genius. Do have an audio guide.
Spectacular. A "must see". Fantastic building. Really atmospheric. It would have been amazing to have had an apartment here in the 1920's!
Must see. As all of Guell's works, it is a must see. It has the odd shaped architecture as his other works.
ugly. maybe i don't understand art but it was the single opera of Gaudi a disiked.It is ugly,just stone and metal,no joy for the eyes.

Wow !!!. What a building, The Stone Quarry has it all from the lift up to the 17th floor to start the tour, then the amazing shapes of the chimneys and ventilation ducts, the views across the city, then the rooms which have everything beautifully restored even down to Gaudi door knobs !!, a great place to spend an afternoon.
Worth the climb. Thought we might just be viewing a stairwell, but eventually got up to the exhibit. Love Gaudi's works and ideas, and all the roofs offer interesting views of the city.

Great terrace!. I loved La Pedrera, but not so much as Casa Batlló. It is really beautiful outside and on the terrace, but inside the flats are "normal", decorated with old furniture. Just a few objects designed by Gaudi. The terrace is really nice - I loved it.If you have to choose between Casa Batlló and La Pedrera I recommend Casa Batlló. But if you have time and money to spend, go ahead! Photographs are allowed.

The roof is the best part!. If you're in Barcelona and doing a "Gaudi" sweep, of course you need to stop and visit La Pedrera. Our hotel was very near so we walked over and spent an hour or so walking through, it was our first introduction to Gaudi's architecture. Fascintating.Loved walking around on the roof, this was the best part for me. Not only are the winding paths and structures up there fun, you get a great view of the surrounding city.
Looks lovely.. The colours are amazing on this sorry i didnt have time to go inside would say its very nice hopefully next time.
Interesting place to visit.. Pay for the audio guide, it makes your visit most intersting.
Fascinating architecture. The audio guide (recommended) gives a really helpful understanding of the thoughts behind the wonderful design of this building.

Do it with an audio guide!. When I went to the Casa Mila, student tickets were 11 euro, and I decided that's all I wanted to spend to see the roof and one apartment of a building. I wish I had done the audio guide! While the roof sculptures are interesting and the city views are great, the attic exhibit and period-decorated apartment would've been a lot more meaningful if I knew why certain things were on display. It was hard to appreciate everything with only a simple understanding of Gaudi's style. Unless you already know a lot about Casa Mila, I highly recommend finding a guide or buying the audio tour set.
Beautiful and instructive. The apartments were fun to visit with all the original furnishings, and the attic full of videos on the different works of Gaudi was fascinating
Gaudi at his best. very nook, every corner yo turn is amazing, Gaudi was certainly before his time this place is just gorgeous, would love to go back again

Amazing as all Gaudi operas. We were inside in September and saw it most recently from outside. The building is fantastic outside and inside. It is a must to go with all the original furniture which makes it unique.
A must!. The roof is amazing!! Makes you really agree that Gaudi was a genius. The rooms were amazing most especially the hall where concerts were held.

A great first view of Barcelona and Gaudi. We went to La Pedrera the day we arrived in Barcelona after walking around to find Catalunya Plaza. We could notice the cool figures on the rooftop from a distance and we were intrigued. So, we cued up and bought our 12Euro ticket (which we could have gotten for cheaper had we bought our bus tour tickets first!) and explored inside the UNESCO World Heritage Site. The roof was SO cool. From here, we got our first glimpse of the sea, La Sagrada Familia, Torre Agbar and the general beauty of Barcelona. Here, we also learned a bit more about Gaudi and his artworks including the crazy chimneys atop of this building.
Catalan work. Gaudi had to make a living and thanks God this job was kept for human heritage. A vanguard condo that will keep inpiring architecs for years.
Expensive but nice. Very beautiful but a bit expensive, student for example can't visit it because it's rather expensive!
wow. 5 pm last visit ignore guide books and I missed it but the view from the outside was amazing

Inspired design for living. A century and a quarter since construction and the building still amazes. Combination of sensible living space within a structure that challenges the mind is unparalleled. No visit of ours has ever been long enough.
Gaudi's finest. Very well restored and interesting building. especially worthwhile to see the interior of the apartment.

Amazing for architecture lovers!. If you like architecture and decoration, La Pedrera is a must. Both the rooftop and the apartment are beautiful and inventive, maybe even a little intriguing. Unfortunately, the entrance fee is expensive.
An apartment house?. Commissioned to be an apartment house, but there is nothing like in NYC and we have lots of apartment buildings
Only if you have a spare afternoon.... The view from the top was amazing. However, if you don't have a lot of time to spare, Parc Guell is where your time would be better spent (plus it's free).
Don't Miss It. For anyone who loves Gaudi's buildings, this is a must.
a must. didn't get in, but just from the outside you can admire what a genius Gaudi was

go to La Pedrera first, before the rest of Gaudy. After I've visited almost all of the famous Gaudy's pieces (Casa Batllo, Park Guell, Palau Guell etc) I'd say go to La Pedrera first if you intend do all of them. La Pedrera has an excellent video presentations of all the Gaudy origins and it gives you a whole picture and understanding of the time so that later on you can go to the rest of the buildings/park being more prepared.
Loved everything about it. Be sure to buy the Articket BCN... it is an incredible moneysaver and Casa Mila is included on it!http://www.articketbcn.org/en/infogral

another beautiful building from gaudi. every building of gaudi shows his beautiful mind. he was so lucky that he could find sponsors to build his dreams and this is also our chance to see his unique architecture

Another amazing Gaudi experience. La Pedrera was an apartment block that was renovated in the inimitable Gaudi style. The roof is extraordinary and you get some great views of the nearby La Sagrada Familia. Go early to try and avoid the crowds so you can take photos of the roof. It is quite expensive and there are no discounts, but still worth it to get a further experience of this amazing architect.

Very interesting, expensive but worth it. We nearly didn't go it: the price is quite expensive and it wasn't that clear on the outside what there was to see on the inside. So we went into the shop and had a look at the books on Casa Mila. I'm glad we went in.You go first of all to the roof and then to the attic which is most interesting and houses a good exhibition that's well worth seeing. Then you get to see around one of the apartments before descending to the ground floor. The exhibition in the attic and the space on the roof make this worth the cost.

Interesting insight into Gaudi's life. We enjoyed Casa Mila from an architectural point of view but we partciularly liked the presentations in the attic that gave you an insight into Gaudi's life and work. Wandering around on the roof and seeing the Sagrada Familia in the distance though the tiled arches was a fantasic experience.

Unmissable!. Get there early, and get straight onto the rooftop! When it is full of tourists, you'll still enjoy the surreal feel of being up there, with all the chimeneas, but if you can get a few minutes up there alone - wow. I went half an hour before opening time, was just behind a small group of tourists in the queue, and as soon as I got in, I made straight for the roof. The others meandered through the museum, meaning that I got a good ten minutes alone on the roof. Breathtaking! Took lots of amazing shots and generally felt like I was the queen! THe museum itself is good too, but definitely try to do the rooftop alone if possible :)
Casa Mila. I like this big building. It is another sign of Gaudi in Barcelona.
Gaudi masterpiece. La Pedrera is a fascinating place to visit and whilst the exterior isn't quite as spectacular as Batlo the roof is quite extraordinary.
AWESOME. Gaudi's work is facinating, La Pedrera is like nothing you will have seen before, well worth a visit
Another great architectural masterpiece by Gaudi. It's worth standing on line to see a work of such creative brilliance. And it's on the most beautiful street in Barcelona. Go!
Fantastic sculptures on the rooftop. Great view across to Segrada Famillia, so worth the visit to see the Gaudi sculptures - don't miss this out of your trip

A must... Go inside!. We were just going to walk by this unique building. We couldn't resist not going inside. Gaudi at his best. Fab rooftop architecture and view. The apartment on display depicts a period of which opulence was truly envied.

Beautiful. Gaudi's work does not leave people indifferente, either you'll love it or will hate it. This was a building constructed for the workers of the Milà family, and has some of Gaudi at its best. The roof with the chimneys is superb, so is the attic in which the curves of the walls and games of light fill in the space. The rest of the house has some rooms furnished with objects of the era, while other areas are still inhabited, hold shops (there's a gift shop at ground level) or hold art exhibits and events. Some of the exhibits and events are free, wo it's worth checking. The facade appears to be melting and is qite unique; the stone is white but up until 10-15 years ago appeared black because of pollution. It looked even more impressing as it contrasted with the buildings around it that are also quite light in color. Still an amazing sight.

dont miss, must visit. please visit if you are in the barcelona, you will surely realize Gaudi's designing style in his mature period. the atmosphere inside the house and outside the house are totally different, very creative but also charming. 值得一訪 這是了解高地成熟期間作品的一個好去處 門票約15歐元 但是可以停留很多小時 如果你是設計建築有興趣的人 相信兩到三各小時你會駐足不已 驚嘆連連 一定要來 如果你在巴塞隆納

Interesting and creative, just like Gaudi himself!. For me it is one of the "must visit" places in Bcn. Gaudi has 2 houses on the same route (Pg de Gracia) but I highly recommend La Pedrera! It s worth paying the enterance and waiting the queu. The roof part is pretty amazing and funny. You feel you are in a fairy tale!
Gaudi Masterpiece!. Just Fantastic! The whole palace and the visit will make you in front at the genius of this person who has changed the architecture History!

Interesting building across from Casa Batllo. Easy to see these two Gaudi buildings since they are caddy corner from each other. This is the least impressive of the three (though still quite beautiful and unique).
Casa Mila. This is amazing - Gaudi was such a unique original creator. Don't miss if you visit Barcelona.

another masterpiece of Gaudi. From the outside looks like a wavy facade, as if carved out of huge rocks, why is popularly known as La Pedrera (the quarry). The building has no straight lines, or a wall is not straight, even there are no straight lines of the roof.Unfortunately we didn't go in because it was closed...but we will next time !!! :))))))

Excellent Gaudi exhibition!. Excellent and extensive display of Gaudi's works in the city and one not to be missed when in Barcelona.
Lots of interesting exhibits, and several floors of photo-worthy material.

If you do not have time to get in, still great from outside !!. Barcelona is full of great attractions and it`s hard to schedule everything.. We were there in the late afternoon. We did not get inside but we enjoyed the piece of art from outside. especially from other side of the street you can take great photos and zoom in to the details of the building with your camera.
Just incredible. This was great.. have been here several times and can't get tired of this incredible architecture. Gaudi was an incredible man. A must see!

Views are amazing. This is brilliant! The architecture is amazing and the staircases inside are unbelievable. Also the rooftop is a just as the chimenys are incredible and the views are excellent. Could spend the whole day up there!
A real interesting place. We didnt go in; the queue was too long but it was still unbelievable from the outside.
Must Go. The rooftop architecture is really amazing, it's a definite must go to attraction in Barcelona.

Very interesting, great work of Gaudi. We had a brilliant time. I got a audio guide which I found really interesting to learn more about Gaudi and La Pedrera. We were lucky as we walked straight in, no queues and so was able to wander round at our own pace without anyone getting in the way. This was especially good on the roof so we could get some great pictures.If you are interested in Gaudi I would really recommend it.
Gorgeous waves. It's simply a beautiful site that you won't want to miss. The wavelike exterior with seaweed wrought iron railings mimick nature in downtown Barcelona. What a treat!

One of the great houses of the world. This is one house that everyone's who interested in housing design and architecture has seen. It's Gaudi great housing masterpiece, from open air courtyards, to well thought out flowing apartment designs, and to the characteristic rooftop water storage supplies and castle peaks.The exhibition that explains Gaudi's life and his thinking process was wonderful to see as well.
annual closure in Janaury.... so couldn't go in, but looks amazing from the outside

A Must See for Architecture Lovers. Gaudi's design is spectacular and the visit to the house - starting with the views of and from the room are amazing. This should be at the top of anyone's visit to Barcelona.

One of Gaudi's famous houses. Gaudi designed this house with fantastic sculptures on the roof.
Another must-see
do this after Casa Batllo. A definite second to Batllo, but worth a visit if you can find a quiet moment.

A masterpiece of art. One of Gaudi's best work in my opinion. You will never see something like this is your life. You also get to see where he lived and how he lived, it's like going back into time. The rooftop is amazing!!

Guadi. Just when you think you've had your fill of Guadi while wandering through Barcelona, you find yourself in front of yet another and you cannot get enough of it! Each has distinct differences, but at their root you begin to see the commonalities (if one can use the word common in relation to anything Guadi!). We just wanted more and more.....and got it daily! We lugged home many books of Guadi homes!
La Pedrere. We saw all house but roof was beautiful.Chimneys are very extravagant and beautiful. View from the roof is superb.
Gaudi or Gaudy ?. See it from the open top bus tour - the history is a bit muddled as to what was the original design, but well worth a view
interesting. it is nice to see this building from inside , but the entrance is too expensive for this.some of the details are told in sagrada familia anyway
Go inside. Very interesting Gaudi apartment building. Worth the price of admission to go inside and see the design.

Great sightseeing, very bad/confusing website!. The terrible rating goes for the website not for La Pedrera. We tried to buy our tickets online but the website is very confusing. The language options are not working right and although there's an option of buying the tickets online you can't really buy them!You can choose the date of your visit, the time and then you are asked to choose your seats (I mean there's no sitting option in Mila house). Very bad and confusing website and CatalunyaCaixa should do something about it because this is a very popular sightseeing.  Try the website your self (if you can).http://obrasocial.catalunyacaixa.com/osocial/main.html?idioma=3

I had bigger spectations. The place is nice, but I really was specting more. If you go inside, you pay 15 euros just to see an apartment (simulating how it was) and the penthouse. For the price and for the great reputation I really was specting much more. You can see all in 15 or 20 minutes... The point is the style of the building, but if you see outside it´s enough.
Where art and architecture meet. Gaudi, thinking out of the box again. Waaaay out of the box. Fun and interesting tour of this works in La Pedrera's attic.

A unique building in the centre of the shopping district. One of Gaudi's most famous buildings. The tour gives you access to the roof, the attic (which contains an exhibition on Gaudi) and an apartment decorated in period style. Well worth a visit, but if you've only got time for one Gaudi building, Casa Batllo is the more beautiful and unusual. Get there early to avoid the queues.

Must see. Did not have a chance to go in on my first visit to Barcelona. Glad I did on this visit. However, if you must choose between going to Pedrera or Batllo, I would choose Batllo as it is more impressive and has the audio guide.

Spectacular!. This is an amazing structure! I actually spent 20 minutes just gazing at the building. I would have loved to enter the building and go to the roof top but it was very busy and the queue was just too long. I was very suprised as I thought that being over the Xmas period, it would be quiet and not so busy but I was wrong. This will give me another excuse to visit Barcelona again.

Worth a look. We enjoyed visiting La Pedrera, but would rank La Sagrada Familia, Parc Guell and Casa Batllo ahead of it in order of priority for Gaudi sites. Parc Guell actually was our favorite, but La Sagrada Familia must be seen. La Pedrera, however, is very cool and definitely worth a visit if you have time to see the other Gaudi sites, too.
If Only We Could All Live In Spaces Like This!. It's interesting to see how Gaudi took each challenge and created such a beautiful space for city living.

Defininetly Worth Going. This is one of Gaudi's apartment buildings. You get to see an apartment the way it was furnished during the period is was occupied; the attic area houses a museum on the building and his work, and you get to go to the rooftop. If you get a thing called the ArtCard or ArtPass (can't remember which--at the Tourist Offices) it affords a significantly discounted price to get into 5 major museums, this being one them. So that cuts down on the expensive entry fee. Take the audio tour. The apartment is really facinating and the period furniture is wonderful. Looking out the windows, especially in the central atrium--gives you a great understanding of Gaudi's genius and made me, at least, more in awe that ever of his determination to purse his vision. The rooftop is truly amazing, because there is not a straight lined-surface anywhere. It looks like a total fantasy building with all the chimmenies and yet it was highly functioning. Plus the views from the roof of Barcelona are wonderful. Go before sunset, as it gets very crowded for the sunset and you could wait a long time on line. The attic, where the museum part is, is worth spending at least an hour, checking out the short films, the scale models of the building and the influences on his work. My only complaint is the elevator only holds 5-6 people so you end up waiting a long time just to up to the apartment, even though you've waited to get into the building. They need a better system for getting more people into the building faster. However, all in all, well worth the time and the money.

A gem in Barcelona. It looks great on the outside with its curved facade on Passeig de gracia but the inside is also very interesting. We avoided the queues by getting ahead the Articket, and so walked straight in. A marvellous interior yard the whole building is a great example of Gaudi ideas and architecture concept. The terrace is impressive with the soldier-like chimneys and the dizzying views. The attic is impressive with lots of informations and photos on the history of La Pedrera and Gaudi himself. Following this the equally impressive period decoration of the appartment below is very useful to give you a clear idea of how rich people lived at that time. A must-see for Gaudi fans and everyone visiting Barcelona.
Quintessential Gaudi. The terrace is the best part. One can spend hours there observing the various sculptures which have the typical gaudi style. A must see tourist spot.
What a construction!. A must see, confirmation that Gaudi is a great artist and architect!

Almost didn't go in, but glad we did.... We thought tickets were a bit expensive at 14 euros per person and almost didn't go in. However, because I love Gaudi's work, we decided to visit and are glad we did. The highlight is the roof of the house. We got some great pictures and thought the architecture was amazing. You can also visit an apartment and the attic of the house, which has a lot of information about Gaudi's work. If you like Gaudi, you should stop in. This was less crowded then Casa Battlo when we visited and we really enjoyed it.

Great views of the city from a dreamscape. This is a fun place to walk through and once again see Gaudi's vision. Interesting to contemplate that though all the things they now tout in the city, no others really followed up to expand this dreamscape vision to a full movement.

Quick Tour, worth seeing if convenient. Get the audio guide, try to go around sunset, roof top is the highlight. Disappointed to find out that the apartment was NOT that if the Mila family, but an average family of the time.

See it from the street? That's all there is to see. This is one of the apartment building Gaudi designed that is supposed to be a must see in Barcelona. It's interesting, but a really expensive tour for what it is. Once you see the exterior, you kinda get it. If you want to pay the 17 or 18 euros to see the rest, the only thing i found interesting was the roof. Spend your time seeing the Sagrada Familia instead.

Amazing...amazing...amazing!. La Pedrera, one of Anton Gaudi's apartment buildings is privately owned, so only the terrace on the top of the building and one display apartment is open to the public. A lift is available to the apartment if you don't wish to walk up the eight floors. Standing in the area near the staircase you look up into an atrium where the entrances to other apartments can be seen. It's like being in another world....amazing atmosphere...so peaceful...so different.The apartment was designed by Gaudi with modern concepts e.g. the main bedroom had a private bathroom attached (ensuite); there was plan living with a combined living room and dining room; lots of large windows with loads of light flooding the rooms. Almost every room had large windows, except the maid's bedroom, which was quite big by early 20th century standards. I couldn't believe there were copper hot water cisterns in both bathrooms and a shower attachment in the ensuite. The kitchen was amazing with a Butler's pantry with sliding door to the main kitchen which had lots of storage, overhead cupboards and marble sinks. The stove (an Aga)was in own little side nook with two large windows to open for ventilation....huge even by today's standards. Balconies were dotted at different spots around the exterior with iron railings of a modern sculptured look.There was the inevitable shop attached to the building, but unlike most others like it, this one was amazing...quite possibly the best range and quality I've seen in Barcelona. I bought several souvenirs, among them an amazing piece of silver jewellery.Do not miss seeing this building....it is worth the wait and the entrance fee. You will not be disappointed. Just don't rush your way through....the apartment and roof terrace need time to absorb and take in your surroundings.
Must See the Roof. We made this a priority on our trip and it was worth it just for the roof with the star wars chimneys.
If you love Design... You must see this building. It's expensive to get in, but it was worth it if you like architecture, Gaudi, interior design, or design arts.

Gaudi was quite the visionary. Seeing the shapes and forms of the buildings, balconies, details was really an experience. Aside from the Gaudi architecture, the street was a lively and great place to experience Barcelona.

Amazing roof terrace. I've been wanting to visit La Pedrera for some time and found it to be even more worthwhile than I expected.The roof terrace was amazing with a more interesting view at every turn. The architecture so different and wonderful views over the city. We visited one of the apartments on the tour - gosh, I'd have loved to have moved right in.What an amazing place it must have been back in the day.

amazing!. Another one of Gaudi's masterpiece. I'm a big fan of patterns and shapes so everything in this building amazed me. Unlike Parc Guell, La pedrera was not swamped with tourists when I went maybe because it's not free. The rooftop is definitely the highlight. If you look up from the ground floor up, the opening in the middle looks like a moon. I think the most amazing aspect about irregular shapes is that everything is relative to your perspective and where you're standing.

Roof is worth the trip. Rather expensive entry fee, but the roof is spectacular. We were there towards sunset and the colours were fantastic. The internal atria and attic are also worth seeing. The apartment less so.

Amazing architecture. We came from Casa Batlo so we've already to listened to the facts. Casa Mila is of a larger scale but a large part of it is not open to public. Since you only get to see an apartment, you can't really see the full picture of Gaudi's intent. I would definitely recommend you to go during sunset as the views from the roof is stunning.

Great views and interesting exhibits!. This was my second visit to La Pedrera. Still very enjoyable. My only problem is that they now make you visit the roof first then the attic space and then the apartment. i preferred the reverse. Perhaps this is because we went late in the day and they don't want people on the roof late? If you use the hop on hop off bus then ask at your hotel for a discount packet as this will get you a discount here.
Very different. Loved the inside.. Be sure to get a museum pass or you will wait to see La Pedrera. The intside is just as interesting as the outside and you don't want to miss a trip to the roof.

Amazing building + view on Barcelona !. Totally worth it to visit and pay 15 €. The architecture of this building is fabulous and interesting + you will have a beautiful view on Barcelona*exit Diagonal‎ metro station and than 5 minutes walk to reach Casa Milà

Nice roof. I was not that keen on visiting La Pedrera, but my friend wanted to see it. She made a good choice. The inside is very interesting. My favourite was definitely the roof with all different levels, many steps and the views.
A walk over the roof!!!. Excellent place to visit and take in a walk over the roof.Very interesting place with good detail about construction

Worth the long queues. Even though I didn't find it as fascinating as Casa Batllo and Palau Guell, I still think that it is worth the visit to admire the wonderful patio, a few decorative elements here and there and the chimneys which are out of this world. I didn't like the shop so much - probably I was a bit tired at the moment, though.

Excellent lesson on Gaudi and his works. La Pedrera is not only a living example of Gaudi's great works, but an excellent commentary on his life and other commissions. Well worth visiting and I would recommend the full audio guide.

Only for the chimney/alienesque roof-top landscape. Personally, I much prefered Casa Battlo to Casa Mila.The only "wow" factor here was really the roof level with the iconic chimneys but it doesn't offer as much all round in the interior. Most of the rooms are re-created to reflect a typical house of the era but neither the furniture nor interiors were designed by Gaudi and were not as fascinating as Casa Battllo. Audio guide was also rather confusing.Still, I would recommend a visit here if you are in Barcelona and you love Gaudi's work. However, if you are short of time, I would recommend giving this a miss and to target Casa Battllo instead.

Interesting Chimneys by Gaudi. The chimneys/ventilation towers we visited were very extra-ordinary, with faces of people in the design. The building's design was also pretty special. For the work of Gaudi, I wanted to give it a 4 star rating, however, given the overall experience, I would give a 3 instead.Visit wise, it's a little like a regular historic house visit (touring the various room) to some one's home and finally visit the special chimneys that it has on top. Staff were not exactly too friendly, and they were trying to control the crowd visiting the place.Personally, I find that the fencing/barricades they used were very distracting and the choice of color was grey, and it did not go well with the warm colors of the chimneys. There were also quite a number of tourists walking about and taking photos, so it is very difficult to get a decent photo shot without people inside. It was a little disappointing for me as I would like to shoot photographs of the place without the ugly grey fencing and the crowd. Then again, what do I expect from a touristy place like the Casa Mila?
Amazing¡¡. The most amazing apartments bulding in the world. I would love to live in one of those condos. Art Deco furniture, Modernistic arquitecture. Take the guided tour, worths the DAY¡¡¡
Good. This is another must see of Gaudi's work. The design and his ideas are absolutely amazing.

Roof is fascinating and beautiful. Roof is absolutely fascinating-- seeing how Gaudi could translate Christianity into architecture how he did is incredible. Great views of Passeig de Gracia and the rest of the city.

Truly Inspired. Another Gaudi triumph. Would love to live here and some people still do.Great views of Barcelona from the roof top and get up close and personal with some of Gaudi’s most famous creations including the Knights Head chimneys. Too bad I can’t include Photos here as they are stuning to see up close against the sky.
Very interesting architecture. I like the architecture - which I find more interesting than the Sagrada Familia
I Love Gaudi!!. This was a very cool apartment building. This was my favorite of the Gaudi buildings.... The roof and attic was very cool....
Goudi's Park. Lovely place to visit. We went during the day and the views over the city were lovely. The park itself is well maintained and is very pleasant to walk around.
imaginative chimnies. like nothing else. I spent easily more than an hour in this building, just the roof can blow your mind away.
Masterpiece. Loved this place! If you only go to one of Gaudi's houses, it should be this one. The roof is surreal!
pots of chimney pots!. wow! what a trip Gaudi was on when he did this building! Well worth a visit - a little pricey perhaps, but the view of and from the roof is not to be missed.

Don't miss the chimneys. This is a really neat Gaudi building. The Gaudi Space exhibit is really neat, make sure you don't miss the part with the chains and parabolic arches - you can visualize this while exploring the building. The chimneys on the roof are amazing and I read in one of my travel guides that they are rumoured to be the inspiration for the Star Wars storm troopers. I would definitely recommend this attraction, but ensure that the rooftop is open if the weather is poor, you don't want to miss it!
Delicious. Wonderful service and superior food + it's a Gaudi building. Make reservations.

A rooftop to remember... Another fabulous example of Gaudi architecture. Well worth the lineup and take your time wandering through. The roof top is memorable so go when the weather is suitable. The shapes and colours are fantastic. Gaudi's design brilliance is evidenced everywhere including the small cafe inside where you can sit on chairs that he designed and sip some great coffee. Almost sanctuary like in its feeling the top floor introduces some you to shapes, forms and elements which are found also at Sagrada Familia.

A movement lost to modernity. Imagining what it must have been like to have seen this and the other Gaudi creations, similar work such as Charles Rennie Macintosh in Scotland and the artistic movements of the time and then realising that what followed it was the brutalist concrete nightmare of the 50s.
WOW. This is my favourite of gaudi's houses, the apartment is perfect! I would gladly live in it, and the roof is awesome!

Oh, I wish I could live there!. It is the dream of city living. Each apartment is unique...and the restored apartment is a delight. Go early so you don't have to stand on line and you can view the space without too many disturbances. Also, a great gift shop!
Best roof top ever. Very worthwhile and a must see; great photos and view from the roof top.
beautiful house. it so strange to see a house with so many crazy details, cross the street to see its full beauty

Must see! and don't miss the roof!. The hole building i amazing but the roof is my favorite: the sculptures and the fantastic view is worth the trip. Don't miss also the apartment being furnished in the style of the building's age.
Worth at least 1.5 hours visit.
Worth a visit. It's a beautifull bilding made by Gaudi. It's important to go to the rooftop. It has this great chimneys and a good view
Worth a Visit. Wonderful building, take the lift to the top where you have a excellent view all round the city.
Just gorgeous home. This place was more limited in areas, but the audio guide was great and once more Gaudi extraordinary. Tile work just beautiful beyond description
Worth a trip. It was interesting to see how Gaudi's designs worked for living.
Another strange Gaudi building. Is a nice corner gaudi building. The architecture is very unusual.
A Must. we enjoyed this experience especially getting out onto the roof.

Quirky and beautiful building in the middle of the city. It was my first taste of Guadi, and thought it was well worth a visit. The rooftop terrace with the uniquely shaped turrets and chimneys were the highlight. What was also interesting were the models of other Guadi buildings displayed inside the attic.

Like nothing you've seen. A jaw-dropping example of Gaudi at his residential best. The museum exhibit element of the visit was well designed and quite informative. The house's rooms were well appointed and decorated, giving the visitor a true feeling of the time. And the architecture was a dizzying display of Gaudi's unique genius. Not to be missed.

Not to be missed. Let's get the slightly disappointing bit over with first - I was slightly underwhelmed by the apartment that is open to view. It's NOT furnished with originals, merely 'contemporaneous' pieces and the lack of explanatory signs didn't help.Having said that, the price is more than worth it for the spectacular roof and the history and descriptions in The Attic. Spend as long as you can on the roof, go back and explore the attic, then back to the roof....
Roof not to be missed. Very well organized informative display, walk through at your own pace, going through the apartment feels as if traveled back in time, beautifully appointed.

No bad photos in this Gaudi masterpiece. One can't have a bad photo in this amazing work of Gaudi. Best to go just before sunset. But if one is not prepared to pay for an elevator ride, be prepared to walk up 7 flights of stairs to fully appreciate Gaudi in Casa Mila's terrace. Again, a bottle of water is a must have. Once lounging around on the terrace, there's no nearby drinks place in the immediate vicinity.
Lovely. I liked the attic, where they are exposed models, films and all the explanation about the Gaudí architecture.

Loved it!. Viewing Gaudi's work was the reason I visited Barcelona. La Pedrera is an amazing structure, love the lines of the building from the outside. The roof top has views of the city center and amazing mosaic work and architecture. Gaudi was a genius who used nature as an inspiration for his work. This should be in your list of must see in Barcelona.

Rooftop worth the admission!. This is one of the priciest attractions at €15 each, but the rooftop kept us enthralled for around 30 minutes. The views are brilliant and of course Gaudi's chimneys out of this world. Inside the attic area you get the full story of all the other Gaudi sites, we foud it very informative and felt the charge justified. The apartments are interesting and worth taking the time to view. We visited at around 3-3.30pm and found no queue so definitely best to leave until later.

A bit disappointing after La Sagrada Familia. After spending the morning at another Gaudi attraction, Casa Mila left a lot to be desired. The price is steep for what you see (14 Euro - which is slightly more than Sagrada Familia), which does not include an audio guide. In hindsight, it may have been worth the extra money for the audio guide, since we didn't exactly know what we were looking at. The views from the rooftop and sculptures were very interesting.
Part of the Gaudi' tour. Beautiful house, another example of Gaudi's outstanding architecture.

Kind of expensive, but very cool. The roof is very interesting. I am not even a fan of architecture, but this was a very interesting building. I would have to say that kids would probably find it very boring.

A top Gaudi site in Barcelona. If you have the time this site is worth a visit (possibly on the way to or from Sagrada Familia). Get the audioguide, you learn so much more. The rooftop is certainly the highlight, but the whole place is fantastic.If you're in a hurry plan to skip the decorated interior apartment. It's at the end of the tour and wasn't particularly interesting.

Quick stop.. We didn't pay to go inside, but got a cool view of everything from the street and again, the next day, from the tourist bus. From what I read, it's not worth the money to go inside. Definitely worthwhile to stop by and take a few pics though.

Don't Miss It. There's only one Gaudi and only one Barcelona! You can be impressed with Parc Guell (we weren't) and Sagrada Famila (we were) but we really got a feel for this man's genious at La Pedrera

Great. Another outstading building by Gaudi!
The architecture is great and real interesting to see!
Great tour. Corner building. Really stands out. Great tour. The roof and Chimneys will take your breath away. You've seen it in books. Now you're here. Wow!

Awesome rooftop!. The apartments are somewhat interesting, but the rooftop is awesome!! We sat on the roof and my daughter sketched the chimneys, enjoyed the views of Barcelona. Definitely worth a visit.

Bijou Apartment. Very interesting - the roof top was scary outside - learnt more about Gaudi and his engineering on buildings and aesthetics. The apartment was really interesting and a snapshot in time - more freedom to wander than in Uk buildings and even to touch exhibits

A unique building. You will never see another building like this anywhere in the world. Ignore a recent review posted by Luke Earth as there is a lot to see in this building. A visit to the roof, a fantastic and extensive display on the life and history of Gaudi in the attic and two apartments as they were in the early 1900's. Our visit lasted over 3 hours. Good value for money.

The ultimate Eye Candy. From its wavy wrought iron balconies to its whimsical rooftop chimneys, Casa Mila AKA La Pedrera, is a fantasy you can touch and study and marvel at. Designed by Gaudi, this is a Barcelona must-see in addition to the incredible La Sagrada Familia. Enjoy!
Structurally fascinating. The Casa Mila can only be truly appreciated by a visit - the craftsmanship with which the building was constructed needs to be seen with one's own eyes.

Great view from the street, almost nothing to see inside. Inside there's almost nothing to see, except the roof panoramic view of Barcelona - I am not sure if it's worth spendinf 14 euros and waiting an hours to get in and take the elevator to the rooftop.

Great tour!. This was one of my favorite activities in Barcelona. My admission price was discounted because I had a Bus Turisitic coupon, so I think I paid 12 Euro or so. The tour of the roof, attic museum, and staged apartment was well worth it.

Fabulous architecture. Loved the roof top. A beautiful October day and the views of the top and from the top were amazing. Arrived early in the morning and didn't have long to wait. Spent some time on the roof and then explored the rest of the building as we made our way down.
you have to go inside. You have to tour the roof of this house to appreciate it. Gaudi at his practical best up close.
favorite favorite did i say favorite!!. SO amazing. Great views of the city and incredibly unique.

Gaudi Magic. Definitely worth going inside, the building is in itself a piece of art, in fact just about everything Gaudi designed is. There's a real sense of wonder and amazement when touring this incredible structure. The rooftop without a doubt is the best feature, be sure to go see it!
Beautiful Architecture!. A visit to the roof of La Pedrera is a must if visiting Barcelona!
fascinating. allow more time than you think you'll need as there's plenty to see. take the lift as the stairs are a killer!
Amazing. Great architecture, right outside the station so easy to find.

The roof is a must-see!. The rooftop is amazing! The house is worth visiting even if all you want to see is the roof. It was a really hot day and it seems even hotter on the roof so I'd recommend going either early or later in the day - not mid day like we did! The rest of the house is interesting but having just visited the Casa Battlo, the Casa Mila wasn't as impressive. The roof is what made our visit worth it!
Wavy wonder. could have started at this building for a long time.....its so unique and such a architectural marvel.
Outside is mind blowing!. Loved the outside of this building,,,the inside was a bit boring, except for the wavy roof. But even still, it is a MUST see!!!

Oh My GOD!!!!!!!!!!!!!. You are in the cave and in the "space" at the same time. This is a breath taking, mind blowing creation, that makes you want to go back to Barcelona and experience this city again and again

Fascinating. This building is still amazing and must have seemed even more incredible when it was built all those years ago. It is fascinating to see the attention to detail in all aspects of the design and decoration. You could be in another world on the roof
Not to be missed!. What a beautiful house! Especially the rooftop! We took lots of pictures up there! Enjoy ourselves very much in this spectacular structure
Up on the roof. The roof garden and the views are great. The house is worth a visit, especially if you are a Gaudi fan.

A Wonderful Building. La Pedrera (the Stone Quarry) or Casa Mila, completed in 1910, was Antoni Gaudi’s last work before he dedicated the rest of his life to La Sagrada Familia. Fantastic is actually an understatement when describing this mosaic tile covered building. There is nothing conventional about it and about the only straight lines are the floors, everything else is curved one way or another. Gaudi was a genius and paid attention to every detail of his buildings. Nothing was too small or insignificant to be overlooked – down to the door knobs and coat hooks. In this building, there are no interior load-bearing walls, so the interior walls could be moved at will – and did not have to be straight. The building is six stories high, plus an attic. He also designed interior courtyards to maximize light and ventilation. Our first stop was the roof. This was no ordinary roof – it was a “sculpture park,” the chimneys resembled medieval warriors and the huge ventilator ducts were twisted into bizarre organic forms. To say it was surreal is an understatement. To top it off, it also gave us a great view of Barcelona. The roof itself was worth the price of admission, but, wait, there was more. Our next stop was the attic and, you guessed it – not an ordinary attic. This was where the washing was to be done – in a vaulted attic with 270 brick arches which form skeletal corridors. It now houses a museum describing Gaudi’s work and how this building was designed. On display in this area were samples of the furniture and hardware Gaudi had designed for this building. It was amazingly functional and quite attractive. Our last stop was an apartment furnished as it would have been in late 19th-century Barcelona – Gaudi-style. It was really stunning. We had a great time going through it.
Amazing. Not much to elaborate but see it for yourself. It is neat.
Outstanding. Exactly that... We were out standing with our jaws to the ground looking at this building in awe. Def worth it!

Interesting exhibit and great roof-top views. It was worth the attraction fee to get inside this apartment building. The views from the roof are great and you get to see Gaudi's designs close up. The exhibits in the attic are also cool - you get to learn about Gaudi's inspirations and methods. Worth checking out!
roof. you can find very strange but still cute statues up in the rooftop!

Love Gaudi!!!!. Don't hesitate to check out this interesting Gaudi apartment/condo. His vision could be used in this day and age. He designed the building so people could move walls and have open concept living. Unique and timeless!
Wow....Absolutely Amazing!!!!. Antoni Gaudi's creativity at its best......the flavor of His abilities....his imagination made real!!
Be sure and visit.. Fascinating and very imformative plus it's a lovely walk up the Passeig de Gracia.

Amazing architecture. The apartment is worth a visit but it is the architecture on the roof which makes this such an interesting place to visit. Trying to imagine how someone has the vision and engineering ability to create something like this is difficult
Out of this world terrace. An amazing building! I had no idea that you could see so much of it, Gaudi was a very clever man!
Worth a trip. A stunning building both internally and externally. The views from the roof are not to be missed.
Wonderful and a must to visit. Long, long queing not great with kids :( But worth the wait :)

Stunning!. Cas Mila, building which is mostly called "La Pedrera" is a remarkable building designed by the Catalan architect Antoni Gaudi. Gaudi is one of the most famous spanish architects and he has designed also f.ex. the church Sagrada Familia and Park Guell, both in Barcelona. Casa Mila completed in 1912, and It's located at Passeig de Gràcia 92. Passeig de Gracia is major shopping street in Barcelona, along with Diagonal and la Rambla. Casa Mila is very easy to reach, and it's absolutely one of the places You have to see if You visit in Barcelona.Admission charge is 15 euros, and usually they don't take too much people in at the same time, so You have enough room and time to see this wonderful building throughout. At first, You have to take the stairs to the roof, stairs are very narrow and sharp, but as soon as you enter the roof, You'll be amazed... Ventilation towers and chimneys are just like from Star Wars (yeah, look at the pictures...) and the panoramic view over the whole city is unforgettable. You can also enter the attic, atrium and even to one restored apartment.

The Roof is the best part!. The Roof of La Pedrera was my second favorite site in Barcelona (after Sagrada Familia). It is full of Gaudi's abstract art scuptures and offers spectacular views of Passeig de Gracia, the city, and the Sagrada Familia! Perfect place for unique pictures! Well-worth the stair climb (maybe 6-7 floors?) I imagine they have an elevator if needed as well.
look from outside. Tthis is like beeing robbed. 14 euro to go inside. Take your picture outside, and buy a postcard

Gaudi fans will love it.. Gaudi fans will love it. The chimneys, the living space, metal works, architucture, history, quirky all add to the enjoyment. Best part of Gaudi structures is the exteriors are as great as the interiors. If short on cash tour the Cathedral it has more bang for the buck!!!! Otherwise all Gaudi properties as well as Guell Park are amazing examples of genius! Enjoy!
fascinating. This house is an amazing design and definitely worth a visit - the roof top is spectacular!

Casa Mila is Another Gaudi Masterpiece. The façade of Casa Mila is very original and filled with many curves. It really looks like stone from a quarry. The wrought iron shapes for the terraces are very unique. I enjoyed seeing the Gaudi Space at the top of the building which explains how Gaudi worked and how he learned to make the catenary arch, which he invented and made good use of at the Sagrada Familia Church. I also enjoyed seeing the apartment that was completely furnished with period furniture of that time when the building was new. You can see how people who had money lived in apartments at that time. There are decorative objects, paintings and household utensils.And the rooftop terrace is wonderful because you can see the chimney stacks in such fanciful shapes, everything being very original. They really look like modern art sculptures. Gaudi was really a genius in inventing these shapes, and using trencadis to decorate them.

Not much to see. We did the audio tour which was supposed to be 75 minutes long -- we had lots of time. It wasn't very long and left something to be desired. There wasn't too much to see. The roof was interesting, but there was only one floor to visit - the apartment. Maybe we should have visited Casa Batllo instead. After this visit for 38 Euros for 2, we didn't bother to spend any more money and be disappointed.

Good old Gaudi!. I didn't think I liked Gaudi very much, but this exhibition is so well organised and curated that I can now at least see how clever he was and indeed how functional his architecture is

The Casa Mila provides a real insight into Gaudi's architectural design. One of the best visits we made in Barcelona. Wonderful building which clearly demonstrates Gaudi advanced ideas. He has created wonderful apartments for comfortable day-to-day living. Full of light; a fantastic building! Even the chimneys, water towers and roof rafters are a joy!PS If you are short of time, bin Park Guell and don't waste a cent on visiting his house in the park. Just visit the Casa Mila.
Interesting roof. Strange roof sculptures and great views of the city. Very pretty at night.

Interesting and neat. We visited La Pedrera after seeing La Sagrada Familia and enjoyed it as well. The exterior is neat and the inside is interesting as well with the open atriums. The apartment examples were interesting and the terrace was interesting as well. It was a little on the expensive side to visit.
Don't miss this!. The roof top was so spectacular! Gaudi was a genius!

Gaudi overview in the city. Amazing overview of other Gaudi works. You also tour the building he designed and can better understand the reasons hey created his buildings here in Barcelona. Pay the extra couple Euros to get the audio guide. It comes in many languages to fit your needs. There is an elevator but many stairs too if you go to the roof for pictures.

Didn't meet our expectations - too expensive - but ok. The roof is certainly interesting, and we snapped a few artsy pics to show we were there, but there wasn't much else to see. We weren't really interested in the apartment or the lonely exhibits so it just turned out to be too expensive for what it was. Many people will like it, we just found it was too expensive that's all. Thank goodness we did Sagrada after this and not before.

mama mia. Although this apartment complex designed by Gaudi had numerous apartments, there are now only three units that are not occupied by businesses. The wavy roof, attic museum, and a period furnished apartment are all part of the admission price. The audio guides (for a few Euros more) provided excellent commentary about this beautiful Gaudi structure.

Must See. This home was not nearly as amazing as Casa Batillo, but the views from the roof make it a must see! I went on a week day and there was a large tour group that was visiting at the same time, so the line was pretty long. I left, walked around and returned an hour later and there was no line! The cost to get in was pretty high, but it was well worth it!
la pedrera. anything gaudi is fun and inspirational so dont miss it. take an audio tour because you get more out of it.
Modernism meets city living. The chimneys look like roman warriors. Isn't that reason enough to go?
Amazing. Could have stayed there all day, not too busy either which was ideal.

Fantastic!. During our visit to Barcelona we couldn’t see much of La Sagrada Familia because of scaffolding. But we explored all the rest of Gaudi’s works, including La Pedrera. You won’t miss it in Passeig de Gràcia as Gaudi’s hand is unmistakably recognizable in the façade. Inside you can see what used to be living areas a century ago: the dining-room, bedrooms with unique furniture designed by the architect. These were very interesting but the atrium and the roof were fantastic – rounded lines, irregularly shaped chimneys and ventilators. When you look from the bottom of the atrium at the sky, it seems as if universe were opening its doors for you! Up the attic you can learn more about Gaudi as it displays all his works in miniature, with details and plans. And the acoustics is great there; we went to hear a concert of chamber music at night!

Too expensive!. I think 15 euros is too expensive. As other reviews have said, the roof is interesting, but after that, I felt like they were getting desperate for exhibits. A number of the exhibits were of his other buildings/designs. It really wasn't that spectacular.I preferred Casa Battlo and think it was better value. I would admire this building from the outside.

A very comprehensive insight to Gaudi at any level.. Masses of palatable info on Gaudi-good film placing the growth of Barcelona in context. Fantastic presentation on the design and inspirational sources. Wonderful and interesting family flat to view. Great photo venue [no flash inside the bulding but no other restriction. Two shops.

Fantastic architecture, genius at his best. We loved this, felt is was a highlight of our trip -- although as someone who doesn't particularly like heights I found the roof area disorienting. But it was worth it!
Amazing. Well worth the money. Gaudi's most impressive house

Interesting Gaudi architecture. Wonderful tour with headphones. A choice for a shorter tour or longer. Built for a private family with apartments for other families and offices. Now owned by a bank, but still some private residences and offices there.

Excellent audio guide. Casa Mila was a revelation. From the cave-like outside, I expected a very dark inside. Boy, was I wrong. How Gaudi did what he did is very interesting. The audio guide was a big help in this regard. I also thought that the educational discussion of Gaudi's methods and other sites was extremely helpful.

Architectural gem focusing on the structural forms of nature. Located on the passeige de Gracia is La Pedrera . We avoided any queues to get in by going slightly later on in the day as It is open until 8pm at night and costs approximately 14 euros to get in.This house focuses more on the natural shapes,forms and spirals from nature that so inspired Gaudi. The attic space allows you to see the underneath of the amazing roof and how it was created and the displays help you to understand Gaudi's inspiration of form from nature. If like me you don't have a head for heights than you may not want to walk around the walkways that twist and turn around the amazing chimney pot areas - put you can just go up look around and come straight down!The rooms of the flat are very comprehensively furnished and are built around a central atrium stairwell providing lots of light. These are fascinating to walk through and enjoy.Whilst visiting this house you can also visit Casa Batlo which is just a little way down the street on the opposite side.

Overpriced. A visit to Casa Mila starts with the rooftop, which is amazing. But after that, there isn't much to see other than a sort of museum of Gaudi models, photos, etc., and the apartment, which isn't very impressive. The admission fee of 15 euros seems way too high. Sagrada Familia--not to be missed--costs roughly the same (only 10 euros if you're over 65) and is much, much more impressive. If you're on a budget, I'd take a look at Casa Mila from the outside but spend my time at Sagrada Familia.

A Gaudi Wonder. Until you reach the attic you won't realize the complexicity of this structure. The roof is a wonder of it's own with all the chimneys and levels. Spend the time seeing the whole building.
This was built 100+years ago?. Modernisme- exactly! great building. Unique...Gaudi vision is remarkable...design, livability. must see in Barcelona!

Amazing Architectual Design!. I didn't think much or even know much about Gaudi before my trip to Barcelona and my girlfriend was much more interested in seeing this site than I was - i was looking more forward to La Sagrada Familia. But once inside, I was completely blown away by Gaudi's ahead of his time thinking and designs. This was truly a forward-thinking genius. Learning how he came up with his engineering designs for some of his impossible looking structures was mind-blowing.
