Make sure you spend time learning about him and his genius in the 'Attic' exhibit which is excellently presented with models, film clips, photos, etc. The whole place felt like I had visited a house in Dr. Seuss-land and it made me wonder if Dr. Seuss had been influenced at all by Gaudi. I have a new-found appreciation and love of Gaudi's whimsy and brilliance after visiting here. Get the audio-guide for a few euros more; it's well worth it and quite interesting and informative. My only minor quibble was that it was very confusing where the tour started and how it progressed to match up with the audio guide, but once I figured it out, it was great! Don't forget to go to the rooftop and spend some time there early before the crowds hog up the photo opportunities. I also would like to address the other reviewers here who thought this was overpriced - I thought it was well worth it but if you buy an ArteTicket which is an all-inclusive price covering 5 museums PLUS Casa Mila, then it actually is a bargain; even if you only go to 2 museums of the 5 offered and this site, you're saving money. If these other travelers had done their homework, they wouldn't be complaining about the entrance fee. By the way, Casa Batlo is NOT included in the ArteTicket deal and is MORE expensive than Casa Mila.

Best from the outside!. I wouldn't recommend going inside this building, not a lot to see as the real anazing part is the outside. the roof up top is interesting, if it's not overcrowded. it has some nice views up there, but the inside tour is not as thrilling as casa batllo just down the road!

Not Tourist Friendly. If you have to choose one Gaudì house to visit, go to Casa Batllo, where there are a senior discount, audioguide included in the admission fee, and the entire house to see. At Casa Mia the 14 euro admission fee doesn't include the audioguide, and there is no senior discount. When we tried to pay by credit card, we couldn't use it without a picture ID. (Our passports of course were locked in our hotel safe.) The cashier was not very friendly, so we decided not to use our remaining euros to enter.

Overpriced. La Pedrera was only a 5 minutes walk away from our B&B so we nipped over there one morning. The queue was pretty small only took about 10 mins to get in. It costs 14.50 euros each to gain entry which we thought was well overpriced, we understand that the place needs to be maintained but really it should be more like 14.50 for two. The whole house isn't open to the public only part of the ground floor, attic, roof and one other floor. The roof is very interesting with the chimneys etc but there are better views of the city availiable from Montjuic and Tibidabo. Overall not overly impressed for the price but worth a quick look if your nearby.

Makes it clear why Gaudi is a big deal. I liked this Gaudi building because he got to design it from the ground up (not a remodel like Casablanca Batlo or Palau . In addition to the typical Gaudi curves and arches, you get to see his inventiveness in putting together an apartment house for moder living with all the amenities (even a previously unheard of underground parking garage). The roof is amazing!

Very intriguing place. We wanted to go to Casa Mila to see more of Gaudi's work. Took a metro and followed the directions towards this house. Suprisingly, i did not find any signs and there is no way you can distinguish this house from outside (unless there is a long queue for the tickets). This was the impression at the first sight. However, once you enter this house, it is very intriguing. Amazing work, i was impressed with the house model. It looked so well thought of. Yes, light is an issue inside and taking pictures can be challenging. I dont remember carrying a tripod, but a monopod or tripod will be a good option. We took our time exploring the interiors and once we arrived at the roof, what a sight it was. It would give you an eerie feeling during full moon night. Luckily for us, the day was cloudy, and it drizzled for a while making the temperature lower. Lots of angles you can take photgraphs from. It is a photgrapher paradise and an obsessive photographer can spend the entire day in this place. Highly recommended to appreciate Anton Gaudi's work!

Very Worth Seeing. You start the tour on the rooftop terrace which sets a very nice tone for the whole time you are exploring and learning. It is very worthwhile. Go early when it opens so you can spend more time reading and looking. Get the audio guide. You will not be sorry.

Are you kidding me? What a joke.... This place was the worst 14 Euro I have ever spent. There is a roof, which is pretty unique, but there are fences all over the place to keep people from falling so the pictures turn out bad. Then, there is an attic which is very dark and bad for pictures. Finally, there is an "apartment" which is nothing I have never seen before in other museums or old houses. Afterwards, we walked over to the Casa Batilo only to find out that house was 18.15 Euro with 2-3 floors as well, If you ask me, the Gaudi structures are expensive for nothing special and each one "nickel and dimes" you. The Casa Batilo might be worth it but I can tell you the Casa Mila IS NOT!!!!

Great roof for great pictures!. This Gaudi's house is also a little expensive (14 euros entrance plus 4 per person for audio-guide). It is worth it however cause it has the greatest roof ever and you will take marvelous pictures if you are a photo person! You will not regret it!!! Lines are a bit long so maybe you could reserve it through the internet.

Breathtaking - see it first and go straight to the to the roof.. I think the best way to see this is to walk down the Carrer de la Diputacion on your way to La Pedrera, and then take the elevator straight to the roof. There are few sights in the world that compare to the breathtaking spectacle you'll see as you emerge. Do it before you've seen the Sagrada Familia or any other major Gaudi buildings; this is the basis for everything Gaudi. The Articket will get you past the lines at 7 museums, and it's worth the 25 euros even if you just go, as we did, to the Miro and Picasso museums as well as La Pedrera.

what a build. definitely i think is one of the most strange, particular, and beautiful build that i ever seen, diferent forms, an architectural theory that goes beyond than the rest and curiously the build has around 100 years, jejejej a crazy thing!!! and the roof is very very nice, if you go to the roof you`ll find a kind of sculptures, nice build yeah!! nestled in paseo de gracia a famous place in barcelona, where you can find lots of places to have a drink, dinner, and of course see this wonder......recomended!!!

Caixa Catalunya Obra Social at La Pedrera. Close to the entrance of Casa Mila' (La Pedrera), at Passeig de Gracia 92, is the iron gate of Caixa Catalunya. The entrance is free but you are requested to go through a detector cause this beautiful bilding is in fact home of a bank. The exhibits are always worthy and it offers a free restroom right in the center of the city. Inside you can admire the Gaudi' structure in the staircase.

Unlike anything I have ever seen before. This is a very interesting place to visit. My husband and my teenage daughter both enjoyed it very much as well. The roof top is so interesting and the interior is unlike anything I have ever seen before. We especially liked the apartment that is set up as it was, with period pieces and furniture...it is a glimpse of life from the olden days. We went shortly after it opened in the morning and waited on ly 15 minutes. It was less expensive that Casa Battlo, and we lines at La Sagrada Familia were way way too long for us to even consider going in.

wonderfully creepy Gaudi artwork! no straight lines!. the outside was amazing, the inside i think is way better! we got there around 12pm on Friday, the line to go in was way too long for us. but if we had time, i wanted to come back here to go inside.

It was very informative. The building at first strike me with its freakish form. It's not by chance that it's got his second name "La Pedrera" - "stone quarry". "La Pedrera" is very original not only for its facade, but for its interior. Everything is wave-shaped and the house really looks like graceful stone rock, whose balconies and windows look like small caves. I admired walking on its terrace, which is like fairy "wild-life park" and the beasts are its ventilation and chimney pipes, which are very unusual. We also visited a type of museum of the life of modernist style, which is organized in one of its appartments. We saw a baby-room with lots of olden time toys, a bed-room with big adult bed and a tiny cradle, a study, a bathroom and a kitchen/ It gave us a vivid understanding of old-times life. We'll never forget the feeling as if we had traveled through the time and touched a piece of life in the 1900s.

Must see this. La Pedrera is an apartment complex designed by Gaudi but contains so much more. We went because the Sagrada Familia was closed for two days for the World Youth Festival and absolutley loved it. Get the lift to the top floor because there are a lot of stairs. Tehy take you initally to the roof terrace which has good views fo the city's rooftops as well as a good insight into the design of the building and its bizarre chimneys. Afterwards you go down into the attic which was my favourite part - an insight into the influences to Gaudi and some of the other buildings. You then go to the apartment which has several rooms furnished with contemporary but not original furnitureEven the shop is terrific and quirky

loved the "medieval" roof. This is the second time I'm visiting "La Pedrera". this time with my teenagers. I wonderd - would they like it? well.... they loved it!!! they loved the architecture, they were very impressed with Gaudi's way of work exhibition, they were very curious to find out how people used to live, as showen at the apartment. most off all they were fascinated with the chimney "knigts" on the roof. In fact - they enjoyed it and so did we. so we recommend it to all ages!

Great Gaudi. With 3 visits to Barcelona within one trip to Spain, we knew we had to do Gaudi, but weren't so into the overtouristy hype of it all. We preferred wandering the streets and seeing the variety of architecture. La Pedrera was our one concession to the hype, paying the full admission and buying the audio guide so we could check out the museum. We weren't disappointed. The audio guide gives a great synopsis of Gaudi's style and method, but for us, highlights were the amazing, slightly trippy rooftop and the incredible refurbished apartment inside. Definitely worth the lines and the price.

Unconventional but beautiful. Located on the Passeig de Gracia, which is the main shopping street. Its a hardly a 2 minutes walk from Casa Batlo which is another Gaudi Masterpeice. A walk along the Passeig de Gracia is a must where you can see all these sights and much much more. The whole atmosphere, especially in the evenings is electrifying.

Fantastic Building!. Loved this place also, Went twice. The first time for an exhibition about the Art of Eating or something like it. Very interesting. Great art and some beautiful weird things displayed, like a chair made out of meat, a screen with the shape and form of a grater, very nice, made out of bronze.The second time was to visit the house, loved this house, and the furniture, the lamps, the forms, the windows, well everything.....And the shop was great also!

Architecture as art. An amazing piece of art masquerading as an apartment building!The attic with its rib-like brick arches was breathtaking.The attention to every last detail in the carved wood, plaster, doorways, and door knobs is inspiring.We went with a small group tour and had early access to avoid some of the crowds. I'd definitely recommend this approach which avoids the lines and gives you a thorough explanation of Gaudi's work.

Two very good tours with Runnerbean. We did the Old city and Gaudi tours with Runnerbean, Both were excellent although the Gaudi tour was especially good. Please note that the tours do not take you inside the Gaudi building but provide all the detail to help you enjoy when you visit. We had a much greater appreciation of Sagrada Familia as went inside right after the Guadi tour and we would have missed so many details if not for the excellent tour guide. The tour guides were very good with our two children as well (9 and 6) and my nine year old still raves about the Gaudi tour.

Too expensive for what you get. I was waiting more from Pedrera. We paid 14 euros to get in. The tour starts from the roof, which is nice and you see a top view of Barcelona. Then we went to a little museum in the attic (nothing really special) And then a quick visit to one of the apartments. Finally, we ended up straight to the museum's shop(which also was expensive). It will be ok for 7-10 euros but noway for 14euros.

Roof makes it worth the time and money. Yes, as other commenters have said - this is pricey, but the roof contains some fascinating stuff. The 'attic' provides an assortment of items that provide a good general overview of Gaudi's work. We came here after trying to get into La Sagrada Familia, but the lines there were too long. We managed to get here before the lines built up. For us, it was a good overview of Gaudi's whole work.Also, the staff was very helpful and saw that we needed to use the elevator instead of the stairs.

Gaudi is amazing. So the trick is to see the inside for free by going to the exhibition hall on the second floor. While much of the house has been renovated by some folks who know nothing of the genius of Gaudi, there are some elements remaining which are absolutely stunning. You can only really see the first and second floors and up the column in the center of the house. While the view from the top might have been nice, there's so much of Gaudi's genius that you can enjoy from the exterior and the interior.

Interesting Gaudi house - if I had to choose would visit Casa Batllo instead!. As with everything Gaudi in Barcelona there are queues and it is expensive to visit.As mentioned previously there is a discount voucher from the Touristic Bus - meaning it 'only' cost us €30 for the 2 of us. However, I do regret not getting the audioguide, as I think we would have appreciated what we were seeing more with it. We visited late in the day (after 6 pm) and think we only queued for 15 - 20 mins at this time of day and it wasnt too busy inside. I think we spent 1 - 1.5 hours on the roof and visiting the attic exhibitions. It was definitely worth the visit - however, as mentioned by other reviewers it is quite expensive to visit and the outside of the building is better than the inside. If you had to choose which house to visit I would visit Casa Batllo instead, although this is more expensive!

Expensive but interesting. La Pedrera was an interesting first taste of Gaudi's work, and inspiration. Having travelled a lot in Europe, we thought the tickets were overpriced at EU14 per person. The exterior of the building gives the impression you will be seeing level upon level of Gaudi wonderfulness, but in fact you really only see 3 levels, the courtyard at the start, the rooftop terrace and the attic. I think the most interesting bit for me was actually the apartment designed to give you a taste for the way they looked when Gaudi was commissioned to build La Pedrera!

Runnerbean Tour Gaudi first before going here.... We did the free walking tour with Runnerbean first before checking out La Pedrera and it was so much more worthwhile. We felt like we knew Gaudi before and all the information our tour guide provided us on the Gaudi tour made it so much more intimate when we walked through the museum. Gaudi's genius of following the Fibonacci sequence in the nature pieces he chose to utilize in his architecture influence is GENIUS...Student ID gives a discount here too so don't forget it!

Amazing Experience. A very special evening was had on the rooftop of Gaudis famous La Pedrera ! I heard about this event which only takes place on Friday and Saturday evenings during July and August..I booked in advance online, a few weeks before my trip and so glad I did! The event was sold out. We enjoyed live classical guitar music on the rooftop whilst watching the sun set over Barcelona, with a glass of cava.I will never forget this evening.

Wonderful!. Went to La Pedrera and it truly is a wonderful piece of art that flows onto the street. I didn't go inside (line too long), however, from the street you can even see the quarky chimneys. I got lost getting here and also ran into Gaudi's and Julol's Casa Batllo, see my review...This is a must see for artists and art afficionados!
Expensive. Fourteen Euros entrance fee to go up on the roof. Really was not worth it. I enjoyed the church more than this house.

The roof is definitely the best part. The lines for the Casa Mila can be daunting. We arrived early but it was summertime and the lines were already long. When we made it to the ticket office, the woman was very rude to me about my student I.D. This really frustrated me, because Casa Mila is not a cheap attraction and there was nothing wrong with my I.D. Fight for your discounts!The house is okay, but it's difficult to enjoy when there are a million people there. The attic is more interesting, and the roof is definitely the best part. We spent most of our time there. It's a great place to take pictures, get some fresh air, and see interesting views of the city - you can see the Sagrada Familia from the roof. You end in a gift shop, of course, but it has a lot of cool Gaudi/design souvenirs.

Great outside, beautiful Inside and on the roof. It's free to look at it outside 14 euros to go in, walk around the museum inside, see a big example apartment and go on the roof and you could pay an extra 4euros for an audio guide if you wanted to.The architecture outside is instantly Gaudi, inside is even better. There is a brilliant museum inside in the shade and (get the lift) to the roof for spectacular views.If you only want to pay into one of Gaudi's buildings don't get this confused with Casa Batllo as they're the same metro stop. La Pedrera is the one you see first which is sand coloured outside, but carry on walking straight down that street and you will find Casa Batllo.

Not worth it, for the price.. We were attracted to this place because it was one of Gaudi's works. We paid around 24 euros to go in with an audio guide. We spent around 1.5 hours there. I personally think that Gaudi was 'experimenting' with La Pedrera, because it isn't his best work. If you have time in Barcelona, skip this. Go straight to La Sagrada Familia and be amazed. If you have plenty of time, is a fan of ALL Gaudi works and want to see all things Gaudi, you can come to La Pedrera. However, I do suggest that you visit this BEFORE visiting La Sagrada Familia. So that you can see Gaudi, so called 'improving'. For the price we paid, we felt it wasn't worth it.

worth visiting. As previous reviews, this is really a 'must see'. Go early to avoid the long lines, it opens at 9am. Roof, attic and apartment all worth a visit. The tour buses stop here, or it is near the metro 'Diagonal' stop.

Worth visiting, specially the roof top. Long wait for the tickets, around 2hours in the line. Best time to visit is 9am, when the queue is short. Dont go during rainy day as the roof top will be closed.

Awe Inspiring. The incredible roof is so memorable, and the views of Barcelona therefrom are so beautiful, that this is an absolute must see. The interior has some interesting background information about Gaudi, but it is the roof that makes this site so wonderful. Don't miss it.

The outside is he best part. We enjoyed this site on a tour from the outside. Later we had some extra time and went in and it wasn't as great inside as it is outside. However, I'd recommend if you go inside to go up to the roof top, as it's the best part.

so impressive. Casa Mila is so impressive for me, I love Gaudi's work and every time I visit Barcelona I have to go and see all of his buildings. And i quie often try to get inside, though there are usually a lot of people waiting. It is biuld from wait rock, and as usually has rolling walls. The balconies are amazing with beautiful art from iron. The roof is great as well with planty of surrealistic, magical chimneys. This is a must in Barcelona.

Average interior, awesome roof. From the outside, Casa Mila is a great building from the outside, no doubt, but don’t expect the inside to live up to that. Only the roof (which is really amazing, including the view) will make your time and ticket (expensive, like almost all tourist attractions in Barcelona) worth. So, if you can spend the extra euros and time, be sure to give it a visit.

Good place to understand Gaudi's studies. We have planned to visit Casa Mila a day after Casa Batllo. I was astonished by this building's exterior, but enterior was not so good. When we went in, we had to wait for the lift, fortunatelly there were not so many guests! Tour starts from the attic where you'll see a small exibition of Gaudi's models and studies. Then you visit the roof which is the jewel of this building! If it wasn't for the roof, I'll be feeling robbed... We spent aprox 1 hour going around this amazing roof! After that, you'll visit an apartment which is not much interesting.

Outside was amazing...inside, ok!. My husband and I fell in love with Gaudi while visiting Barcelona. I would recommend seeing just the outside of this building though- its quite amazing! Had to believe how ahead of his time Gaudi was! Please don't miss out on this building..its just as good as his others, or better. but we felt the inside was only worthwhile on the roof- the outside we stared at for 30 minutes!

Skip the interior and go straight to the roof. Almost all of the interior of Casa Mila is forgettable. The admission is expensive, and most of the exhibits are underwhelming if you've already seen the Sagrada Familia. That being said, the rooftop is otherworldly. The views are amazing and Gaudi's quirky style is on full display. Visitors may walk around the circumference of the building, taking in the sights (Sagrada Familia from afar among others) and construction of the more interesting rooftop.

Underwhelming. I personally found this attraction to be underwhelming. The architectural design was interesting but there was nothing else about this place that I had not already seen in photos. It was my understanding that there was a "museum" but all they have done is dressed the rooms using furniture from the period in which the apartment was built. I did not feel that the experience was worth the money paid.

inspired. Like most attractions in Barcelona, this isn't cheap, but for those with an interest in Gaudi's astonishing vision it is well worth the visit. The highlight is undoubtedly the rooftop, with its dreamlike forms and curious groupings of soldier-like figures. It is a little like wandering through a Dali landscape, except for the fact that Gaudi predated Dali and was far less commercial. The loft below the rooftop is also wonderfully executed, evoking organic forms and feeling very much like moving through the belly of a snake. I was surprised by how much time I spent in this remarkable space.Surprisingly, the least interesting section for me was the actual apartment. It is decked out with period furniture and features no architectural highlights of great note, and I passed through the rooms rather quickly.However, the rooftop and the loft make this place a must-see in Barcelona.
the roof is amazing. another must.we queued 15 minutes to get in but this wasn't a problem.gaudi roof top - amazing.

Amazing, a must see. We had no wait to get in Mila House. It was early afternoon. We had the whole place to ourselves. The decor in the house, makes you feel like a guest waiting to visit with Antoni Gaudi, as though he will walk into the room at any moment. Do not miss the rooftop, it is jaw-dropping. Worth the money and worth the time.

Terrific Gaudi building - Get there early if you want to go inside. We stopped by the building on our tour, but the line to go inside was quite long (late Saturday morning). So we did not go inside.The outside of the building has a look and feel of the sea.
Very cool. Family loved it. Rooftop is Amazing. A must see when in Barcelona. A great display of Gaudi's work and interesting background about his style inspiration.

Outstanding roof and exterior. Once inside you’ll have a great exposition about several buildings from Gaudi and several house parts.The roof is outstanding … one of those things that pictures does not show the beauty of it.Sometimes there’ll be queues to get inside but it really worth it :)

Gaudi attraction. Of the four main Gaudi attractions in barcelona i would say this one is the least interesting, however the roof architecture was amazingly beautiful and the view through the middle of the building has wonderful random painting.

Great Gaudi site!. I visited here with my grandparents, and absolutely loved it. I'm a big fan of Gaudi architecture, and it was absolutely what I expected from the site. The roof is not to be missed, for sure, and the staff is so friendly and helpful.

Worth the visit. I visited Casa Mila in the span of an hour. Because I had an appointment to make if not I would have stayed much longer. The roof itself is worth the entrance fee. But the "museum" inside was my favorite. Stay to watch all the videos of Gaudi works all over the city. The miniatures of his buildings were fascinating. I took a bunch of pictures when I visited on Thursday June 17th, 2010 and put them in my blog about Barcelona... www.todayinspain.blogspot.comThis is a must go for Barcelona!

Very interesting, but really just the exterior and the roof. I liked Gaudi's other designed house, Casa Batllo, much more than La Pedrera. La Padrera is very cool from the exterior, but the interior is sort of boring (you can only go in the attic). It's a huge building, yet 90% of it you can't get into see. They do have guides at every elevator to help direct traffic, which is good. The roof is very cool, however lots of stairs, so be in good shape to get around.

Great building, poor staff.. This place was amazing but please be aware that where you purchase the tickets is not the entrance. The entrance is not marked at all. We tried to get in the front and was barked at by a member of the staff who told us it was the exit. Then we tried to enter thru the gift shop but was told again by rude staff that we couldn't get in that way. Please keep in mind that we have tickets in our hand during this whole process and showing them to the staff as they continued to turn us away without telling us where the entrance is. Once inside the interior was nothing spectacular compared to Casa Batllo. It was the roof that was the main attraction for us. It was spectacular. This place is a must see just try to ignore the rude staff.

Start your Gaudi Orientation Here. When in Barcelona and plan to hit the Gaudi sites (Sagrada Familia, Park Guell, Casa Batllo, etc.) start here. Great orientation tour that explains Gaudi's genius and the era in which he created his masterpieces. It will inform all the other sites you visit. Don't miss it!

Blown away by the roof!. Following advice of others we opted to visit La Pedrera rather than Casa Batllo and were not disappointed. The tour starts with the roof and to an extent is all down hill from there! The chimneys and view from the roof were literally breathtaking. Those great mosaic lumps looking like dragons with their backs turned to you from whatever angle you view them from, the plain 'helmeted' ones and those sprinkled with bottle shards.Then to the ribbed attic and the period flat all quite spectacular, but that roof, that roof. Go in the winter, we visited in January, walk straight in - no queue and no leaves on the trees so that external views (of any building) are unobstructed.

The best of Gaudi's buildings is the cheaper. Curiously enough, the most interesting Gaudi’s buildings, was the cheapest. Casa Milo definitely worth a visit, especially the apartment located in the last floor.

Great Gaudi structure. Gaudi put his personal stamp in many places in Barcelona and this is one of them. Oddly beautiful, this reasonably priced tourist spot is another must for Gaudi fans. Inside is beautiful, a small museum of Gaudi's creations but the roof is the best. Come in fall it's less crowded, the weather is not as hot but still humid and enjoy views of Passeig de Gracia below as well as Gaudi's colorful work.

Gaudi's "La Pedrera" worth the visit. We visited the building designed and built by Antoni Gaudi, La Pedrera and loved it. The visual appeal and even the feeling of the structures was delightful. The floor under the roof top was educational but not boring. The roof with its architectural oddities provided a great view of the city and the structures even feel good to touch. The apartment with period furniture from early 1900's is a must see. Definitely worth the price of admission.
personally i prefer the Casa Batllo. both were Gaudi's masterpieces, but this one is "Less unusually pretty" compared with the other one.But sure, it is worth a visit.Go early to avoid the crowds.

Great Intro to Gaudi. This should be your first stop on your tour of Gaudi's Barcelona. The Sagrada Familia is too crowded, and the others don't offer such an indepth tour. Take the complete audio guide to learn more about the man and his architecture. The rooftop gives you a great bird's eye view of the city as well.

Enjoy!. The Casa Pedrera is a true wonder in Barcelona, and a real source of happiness for Gaudí´s lovers…After having seen the exuberant front of the house, go and have a look at the fanciful roof; the mask-shaped chimneys remind of Catalan Knights legends, and the convoluted chimneys made of ceramic are examples of Gaudí´s avant-gardism of the 90s. Then, go down the beams to understand the 20th century architectural conceptions. What is particularly fascinating is that not only the roof is typical and overview the whole city, but also the fact that we learn a lot about the architect who worked using weight on threads and he also used a mirror to get the reflection of the building. As far as I’m concerned, the residential floor, the Mila Family one, is of little interest. The Pedrera house is half the price of the next door house (only 8euros for students), the Balto House, and is a must-do for all the travelers!

La Pedrera, "The Stone Quarry". We almost missed this awesome building. We had time on our last day & decided to fit it in & we are glad we did! We used a coupon from Bus Turistic & paid 8,50 Euro...without the coupon the cost is 9,50 Euro, both include the audio guide in choice of Catalan, Spanish, English, French, Portuguese, German, Italian, Basque & Galician. Hours: March to October, 9 am to 8 pm. There are 2 small lifts that bring you to the roof or the apartment if you don't want to walk. There is a gift shop. From the outside the curved facade & balconies catch your eye enticing you to go in & explore. The vaulted Attic museum with its 270 brick arches forms skeletal corridors and is dedicated to the architect, the unique furnished museum apartment reconstructs a typical bourgeois Modernista flat of late 19th century Barcelona & the spectacular roof with its rambling stairs, whimsical chimneys resembling medieval warriors & great views over the Eixample are not to be missed. This building was Antoni Gaudi's last major work. In 1984, UNESCO declared La Padrera (Casa Mila) a World Heritage Site.

Don't miss this. The house designed by Gaudi is a great attraction close to the inner city. Of course there is many people, but not that crowded actually. All though the queue is long it goes pretty quick. We came about 2 pm and we only waited 15 min. PROS:- the apartment- the roof (and the view - you can bring your binoculars)- not much waiting at the entrance- not crowded- audiovisual guide for FREE (ever experienced that before)CONS:- any

La pedrera - a Gaudi masterpiece. The case mila rooftop called la pedrera is a gaudi masterpiece you should see. Students can get a discount on the entrance price so you'll pay only € 5,5. We didn't take the audio guide (you can get some free information leaflets).

A breathtaking intro to Gaudi. La Pedrera was absolutely stunning! We spent ours exploring the rooms and took millions of pictures on the roof (which is, by the way, worth a visit on its own). We used the audioguide which was a bit corny but informative nevertheless. We just bought into its super-tourist nature and had fun with it. The gift shop is not to be missed! They have an excellent collection of books and gifts. I was almost as enthralled there as with the works of Gaudi in the floors above it!

A must for any visitor. We arrived early and took the long audio guided tour (no deposit required) – a good decision. The tour starts in the attic and gives you a very good insight into the man and his works. The tour then takes you onto the roof where you get good views over the city and onto the Church of the Sacred Family in the distance. Finally, the tour takes you down to an apartment set out in the period of Gaudi – again something not to miss. Bus Turistic vouchers can be used here.

Make this your first stop in Barcelona. I was very sad when I realized that I had saved the best for last. I wish we had gone here first because the displays and the audio tour gave a wonderful explanation of Gaudi and all of his works, Park Guell and Sagrada Familia. I would have been so much better informed if I had gone here first. Well worth the 9,5 euros.

Loved it!. Highly recommended! We hesitated a bit outside because of the price, but decided to go for it (my mother's name was Mila, so I had a special interest) and were glad we did.The house is simply astonishing, especially the roof. You can choose from a short or long audioguide, which was very informative. The museum in the attic was interesting and the rooftop was spectacular. It was also nice to tour the apartment. We hadn't heard of Gaudi before we came to Barcelona, but he's our favorite architect/artist now!
Check it out!. Great way to learn about Gaudi. Take the audio tour. great views from the roof top. AMAZING

The roof's the high point :). On our last day - cases packed & awaiting collection - we chose to go to La Ped (the other 2 nearby houses - one covered from head to toe in a blue tarp, the other too expensive) for our 3rd Gaudi experience (SF Cath & Parc done before) in 6 days. We'd been to Sitges the day before to replenish the lungs & smile at the Med, after a fair bit of rain. I think it's important not to feel you HAVE to 'do it all' in Barca.Most of the reviews below say what needs saying - the loft allows one to float about in a relaxing informative space, the apartment is so-so; the high point is doubtless the roof. One has to be careful not to become too obcessed with finding the perfect photo, as people-free as possible; well they will insist on 'cluttering' up the arches & dramatic roof furniture :) It was lovely to say farewell to SF in the distance from the sunny roof. There is a v disturbing description in French below of organised gangs pick pocketing in the apartment loo area - though we resented the way crime warnings almost made us paranoid before arrival I repeat it here in case it saves one unfortunate English speaker.

best of Gaudi. The Pedrera is a great example of Gaudi's work. there are 2 tours for this house. one is about 40 minutes, the other 1.5 hours.great audio presentation. tip: if you take the tourist bus (hop on hop off) you will receive a booklet that offers a 10% discount on Gauid attractions.also hotels have discounts for this attraction as well as Gaudi'sBatllo & Sagrada Familia Cathedral which is a must see.

Interesting and well laid out visit; MUST for any Gaudi enthusiast!. The building with a more reasonable entrance fee of the two famous Guadi buildings, the visit includes the arched attic as a museum of Gaudi’s work, access to the roof and its spectacular view, a glimpse of an apartment as it would have been in the early 20th century, and a (free) audio guide for the whole visit. You get to see and learn about Gaudi’s furniture and handle designs, his use of arches and nature in all his works and see the famous chimney towers up close. Overall a great visit and well worth the time and entrance.

Facinating building, excellent tour. After seeing the €16.50/person entrance fee at Casa Batllo, my fiancee and I walked 2-3 blocks up the street to La Pedrera, another much bigger Gaudi apartment building from the same decade where we had an easier time with the €8/person entrance fee.The audio guide tour was excellent, very well organized and extensive. It covered not only La Pedrera, but also Gaudi the man and all of his major works in and around Barcelona...including Casa Batllo, La Sagrada Familia, and others. There are a number of multi-language multi-media displays, models, replica furniture, and more that inspired us later to visit Casa Batllo anyway (much to our disappointment...see my separate review).Visitors have access to the building's ground floor entrance, gorgeous vaulted attic (where the bulk of the exhibit is), full roof with stunning chimneys, and an entire apartment which is fully outfitted in period furnishings. There's a lot of scaffolding up at the moment for renovation work on the roof and interior light well, but it didn't detract too much from the visit.In short, an excellent place to spend a few hours of your Barcelona visit and great compliment to exhibit at the Sagrada Familia.

Worth waiting in line for!. A top notch tour ... you'll enjoy the apartment, but also the view from the roof. Well worth the 45 minute or so wait to purchase tickets. Go early to avoid the lines, or go late to enjoy the view at night.

My dream apartment!. I did a "Gaudi day" during my weekend break to Barcelona in September. After deciding to see just the Casa Batllo from the outside, I paid to see inside Casa Mila because I had heard so much about the roof. I was impressed by the outside - the balconies carry on the acquatic theme of Casa Batllo and look like seaweed. You start off in the amazing attic, where you can learn all about Gaudi's life and buildings (I suspect similair info would be in Casa Batllo which is why I decided not into go to both... I may be wrong of course). Next ascend to the amazing roof which is full of large and small chimneys and walkways criss-crossing the vast apartment block. The small chimneys look like Jedi knights. There is a great view of Barcelona - you can see the Sagrada Famiglia cathedral a few blocks away and a skyscraper that reminds me of the London "Gherkin" Swiss Re building. After spending way too long on the roof, I ventured down into the open apartment. It's like a tube apartment which goes right round the apartment block, so you can walk around in the circle, visiting all the rooms before ending back where you started. It was full of art deco furniture and lots of windows. Absolutely stunning. I can definately recommend this as one of the top attractions of Barcelona. Even if you're not an architecture buff, you'll be impressed by the structure.

wonderful but not my favorite. So maybe I was a little bit Guadi-ed out by the time I reached Casa Mila/La Pedrera. It was wonderful but not my favorite. One thing I will say is that it's ALWAYS open -- I toured at 6 pm- 8:30 pm on a Sunday night. The courtyard and entrance is breathtakingly beautiful and the apartment is OK although lacking the whimsy of Casa Batllo. Loved the museum installation in the attic (and the attic itself) and the roof looked cool but couldn't go up because of the rain. :-(Fortunatly I did go up on the roof of Batllo and there are lots of pics of Casa Mila's roof. The attic also has a nice wide window and skylight where you can see the main chimneys.From what I saw if I had to choose between Casa Mila and Casa Batllo I would take Casa Batllo, absolutely. Still, La Pedrera IS worth a look.

Whimsical Treasure in the City. La Pedrera is not to be missed. It is in the center of the city near the Passeig de Gracia Metro station on Calle Provenza. The apartment building is 6 stories tall and features of Gaudi are displayed on the first, sixth, and roof. An elevator is available, or just walk up. The roof is a playland of weird and interesting architectural shapes that cannot be described. Go see it! You also can view the La Sagrada Familia temple from the roof, right down Calle Provenza. (Another place to see). There are videos, audio, and models of Gaudi's other projects around the world, all watched over by a competent staff. The sample apartment is interesting for its then contemporary decoration.

Barcelona's second cathedral. My last day in Spain I had a choice to make - I could go with friends to Montserrat, the cathedral to hear the boys choir and have paella on the beach or trek to the Picasso Museum and try to see as much Gaudi as possible.It had been raining for an entire week and the idea of more wet and cold on a mountain lost out to wet and cold in the city where I could duck in for a coffee when warmth was needed.I'm sorry I missed Montserrat but I found a cathedral in the sky in Gaudi's La Pedrera/Casa Mila. The fantastical work of Gaudi became beautiful and serene in the attic under the roof. Wonderful job of presentation combining models and video, music and views. Cost is 7Euro to visit the apartment replica, the attic and the roof - definitely worth it. Well trained quides within the building.Amazing courage of Gaudi's patrons is to be lauded. Barcelona must be praised for maintaining the Gaudi legacy and making it available for others.
